title: Show Us the Money
description: When I was a kid, I remember my parents telling me that going to college would broaden my horizons and give me all the opportunities in the world. What I've found out, though, is that the benefits of being a student become clouded when you add the word ''athlete.'' That's because the National Collegiate Athletic Association not only rules college athletics, it also limits the opportunities of the 360,000 student-athletes it purports to serve.

title: Grabbing The Nettle
description: The Pentagon held an all-day meeting a couple of weeks ago seeking ways to restrain North Korea. At the end of it, one expert turned to another and summed it up: ''In other words, we're'' doomed -- except he used a pungent phrase I can't.

title: Paris Journal; Back to Barricades: Liberty, Equality, Sisterhood
description: Since the French Revolution, she has been the idealized embodiment of freedom, a supposedly immortal figure that nevertheless gets a new look every once in a while.

title: 2 G.I.'s Killed and 5 Wounded After Lull in Iraq Attacks
description: An explosion today on a road near the Baghdad airport and a shooting attack 50 miles northeast of the capital late Wednesday killed two American soldiers and wounded five, military officials said. The incidents shattered a rare two-day stretch of relative quiet in which no soldiers had died.

title: Ansel Adams -- '100 + 1'
description: Robert Mann Gallery

title: The Guggenheim Offers a Primer In the Development of Modernism
description: In the season when beginners by the thousand pour into our museums, a selective anthology of perennial in-house favorites in a major museum has much to be said for it. This year's summer anthology at the Guggenheim Museum is ''From Picasso to Pollock: Classics of Modern Art.'' The bait is irresistible, the promised classics turn up here and there, and both the young and the not-so-young have a fine time on the ramps.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Reliance Profit Rises
description: The industrial conglomerate Reliance Industries Ltd. announced a 28.5 percent rise in quarterly profit yesterday, backed by a healthy growth in sales. The company -- India's most valuable private enterprise, with a market capitalization exceeding $10 billion -- has businesses spanning petrochemicals, energy, textiles and telecommunications. Reliance announced a profit of 11.8 billion rupees ($255 million) in the quarter that ended in June, compared with 9.18 billion rupees ($199 million) a year earlier. Reliance shares rose 2.6 percent as the results beat market expectations. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: The Series Is 'Boys Life,' With a Hint of Maturing
description: Now in its fourth installment, the ''Boys Life'' series from Strand Releasing unites a group of gay-themed shorts into a feature-length passage. While previous editions have had six or seven short films, ''Boys Life 4: Four Play,'' which opens today in Manhattan, requires only four titles for its 87-minute running time, a sign of how much more substantial and ambitious work in the field has become.

title: Silent Classic About a Marvel
description: We have the chess-playing computers Deep Junior and Deep Blue. Now meet the Turk, a turbaned automaton from the 1770's that not only played the game but also defeated virtually everybody it came up against in matches across Europe. In Raymond Bernard's highly entertaining 1927 silent classic ''The Chess Player,'' released this week on DVD and VHS by Milestone, the vanquished include Catherine the Great, who has the device shot shortly before dawn for the crime of lse-majest.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: NURSES AUTHORIZE STRIKE The nurses' union at University Hospital has voted to authorize a strike if contract negotiations do not progress. A strike deadline was not set, said Bernie Gerard, the vice president of the union, the Health Professionals and Allied Employees. He said yesterday that the nurses were "angry and frustrated that four months of negotiations have been stalled." In a vote tallied Wednesday and released yesterday, 418 nurses voted for the strike authorization, with 19 opposed. The union represents about 800 registered nurses who have been working without a contract since July 1 at the state-owned hospital. The nurses have said they are concerned about understaffing and want the hospital to include the hiring of more nurses in the contract. New Jersey law prohibits state employees from striking; the union risks getting fined if the nurses strike. "Frankly we are surprised by HPAE's decision because talks have been very productive," said a statement released by the hospital. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK Telecom Income Gains
description: SK Telecom, the premier company of the SK Group, the country's third-largest conglomerate, reported a net income of 548 billion won ($464 million) in the second quarter of this year, up 19 percent from the second quarter of last year. Sales totaled 2.4 billion won, up from 2.1 percent in the second quarter of 2002. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLANGER, , SYDELL
description: SCHLANGER--Sydell. 94, of Wayne, N.J., formerly of Jamaica Estates, L.I. Survived by her loving daughter Ellen Cohen and her husband Irwin, cherished grandchildren Greg, Brian, Wendy, Harry, Debra, Michal and Jill, Gwen and Mindy; and nine great grandchildren. Services were held at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: MOSCOW PROSECUTORS OUSTED The federal prosecutor general forced the resignation of Moscow's top prosecutor, dismissed his deputy and reprimanded several other officials after an internal investigation found what officials said were significant shortcomings in prosecuting crimes. "While a significant increase in crime is being noted in all administrative areas of Moscow, the rate of solving crimes is significantly worsening," a spokeswoman for the Prosecutor General's office, Natalya Vishnyakova, said in an interview on the radio station Ekho Moskvy. "The checks revealed that the structures of the Moscow prosecutor's office were more or less idle." According to news reports, the investigation found that more than 9,000 crimes in Moscow had not been registered, while less than half of the gravest crimes committed this year had been solved. Officials also said that 203 verdicts had to be annulled because of procedural mistakes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Candidacy Endorsed
description: The European Central Bank endorsed the candidacy of Jean-Claude Trichet, left, as its president. Mr. Trichet, the governor of the French central bank, is expected to succeed the current president, Wim Duisenberg, in November. The bank's governing council described Mr. Trichet, who was recently cleared by a French court of false-accounting charges, as a ''person of recognized standing and professional experience.'' Mark Landler (NYT)

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Jets and Bucs Get a Small Taste of Tokyo
description: A few hours after arriving in Japan, Jets quarterback Chad Pennington ventured out for sushi with Buccaneers center John Wade, a former teammate of his at Marshall.

title: A guy's guy tired of plain old soap? Old Spice is counting on it.
description: OLD SPICE, seeking to wrestle the top spot in sales of men's deodorants and antiperspirants away from Right Guard, is hoping that adding a dose of celebrity to its image of studly self-sufficiency will do the trick.

title: Energy Bill Gives Way To Old One In the Senate
description: Bogged down in an effort to pass a new energy bill, the Senate tonight hit on a novel solution: It took its energy bill from last year off the shelf and passed it again, throwing a fight over the nation's energy policy into negotiations with the House.

title: Residential Real Estate; On 10th Avenue, a Boom in Apartments
description: A residential no man's land three years ago, 10th Avenue from West 48th to West 56th Streets has sprouted three mixed-income apartment buildings in three years, and more housing is planned.

description: P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center

description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency issued proposed regulations yesterday that are expected to exempt national banks from many state laws against predatory lending, including those in New York and New Jersey.

description: In percent

title: Vatican Exhorts Legislators To Reject Same-Sex Unions
description: Worried about the spread of laws that recognize same-sex couples, the Vatican today urged Roman Catholic lawmakers and others to fight back, calling support for such legislation ''gravely immoral.''

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Big Find For the Met

title: A New Spin (And Hand) For 'Mozart'
description: IT may be the newest and most elusive of new maths. Add a French conductor little known in America, Louis Langre, to a festival long established in New York, Mostly Mozart at Lincoln Center, and the outcome may be a figure closer to 1 than to 2. Such at least is the impression gleaned from conversations with several players in the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, which just a year ago wiped out much of the season with a last-minute strike.

title: BECKMAN COULTER'S 2ND-QUARTER EARNINGS ROSE 25%
description: Beckman Coulter Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 25 percent as strong sales in its clinical diagnostics unit and favorable exchange rates raised revenue 6.9 percent. The company earned $52.2 million, or 82 cents a share on revenue of $551.8 million, compared with earnings of $41.9 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenue of $516.1 million last year. Analysts expected earnings of 77 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Beckman Coulter said it expected third-quarter earnings of 59 cents to 64 cents a share, while analysts expect 62 cents.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Employee Resigns Over Poem
description: The director of the state's emergency management bureau resigned after apologizing for forwarding to the agency's employees an e-mail message that ridiculed welfare recipients and illegal immigrants. The director, W. R. Harper, said that he had received the message, in verse form, several weeks ago, and that it did not reflect his own beliefs. Gov. Mike Huckabee described the poem as ''racial stereotyping'' and ''neither humorous nor acceptable.'' Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Racing Must Close The Excitement Gap
description: The horse racing in ''Seabiscuit'' -- thrilling, exhausting and stunning -- creates an elevated excitement that cannot be matched on television, even in Triple Crown races.

title: Slain Immigrant's Family Here Asking Why
description: Sali Mata Sanfo and Daouda Zongo faced a tight circle of reporters yesterday, their second day ever outside Burkina Faso, in West Africa, and peered quizzically at a translator who relayed questions. The answers were simple enough, but they caused Ms. Sanfo to cry.

title: New Law Raises Obstacles to Israeli-Palestinian Marriages
description: The Israeli Parliament voted today to block Palestinians who marry Israelis from becoming Israeli citizens or residents, erecting a new legal barrier as Israel finished the first section of a new physical barrier against West Bank Palestinians.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: ACCUSED WILL NOT BE TRIED IN DEADLY FIRE A woman accused of setting a nursing-home fire that led to the deaths of 16 residents, many of them severely disabled, is incompetent to stand trial, a judge ruled yesterday. A Hartford Superior Court judge, Elliot Solomon, ruled that the woman, Leslie Andino, 23, suffers from dementia and depression. After a psychiatric evaluation, Ms. Andino is to undergo further treatment at Connecticut Valley Hospital and will be evaluated again in two months. Ms. Andino told the police that she might have accidentally started the February fire at the Greenwood Health Center while playing with a cigarette lighter. But an investigation later determined that a lighter would have had to be held under sheets for at least 30 seconds to start a fire. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about James P. Shenton, a Columbia University history professor, omitted attribution for an anecdote about a beating he suffered during the 1968 campus unrest at Columbia and, because of an editing error, omitted credit for accounts of other aspects of his career. All were obtained from an article by Eric Wakin in the summer 1996 issue of Columbia College Today. The obituary also misspelled the name of an endowed chair at Princeton held by Sean Wilentz, whom Dr. Shenton influenced. It is the Dayton-Stockton chair, not Dayton-Stockon.

title: Going for Glory (In Miniature)
description: ONLY a handful of racing fans were watching when John Kindhart crossed the finish line on a bright Saturday in late June, but judging from his reaction, you would think that the entire world had just witnessed his first-place performance at a track 40 miles northeast of Pittsburgh.

title: Consumer Electronics Surge Ahead of Office Computers
description: The lesson in the latest round of quarterly earnings seems clear: If you want to succeed, work your way into the living room, not the boardroom.

title: Sam Phillips, Who Discovered Elvis Presley, Dies at 80
description: Sam Phillips, who founded a small Memphis record label that made Elvis Presley a star and turned black blues and country music into what the world came to know as rock 'n' roll, died on Wednesday in Memphis, where he lived. He was 80.

title: An Offer of Love He Can't Refuse
description: In ''Gigli,'' Ben Affleck is Larry Gigli, a mob enforcer with a vintage Chevy Impala convertible, a closet full of vintage-style rayon shirts and a threadbare, thirdhand wiseguy accent. (Though he is a Los Angeles native, Larry's accent sounds as if he had been raised in the part of New Jersey that's just outside Boston.) Before we go any further, however, we should clear up the question of how to pronounce Larry's surname, and the title of the picture, in which Mr. Affleck is joined by his real-life fiance, Jennifer Lopez. In places -- especially the long denouement, set on a beach full of bikini-wearing extras -- it is certainly jiggly. And audiences, at inappropriate moments, will find themselves helplessly giggly. But Larry's name is pronounced ZHEE-lee, or as he likes to say, ''rhymes with really.''

title: Johnson's Hit in 10th Lifts Yanks To Victory
description: It had been a struggle for the Yankees. When Nick Johnson stepped to the plate in the 10th inning tonight, his team had already had 16 base runners and 11 walks, which should have added up to a lot more than one run. But Johnson made sure that this did not turn into what could have been a bitterly frustrating loss. With a line single to left, he brought home Bernie Williams with the second, and winning, run.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Ally Returns
description: Claudio Scajola, an interior minister who was forced to resign last year after he made made crass public remarks about a government aide shot to death by left-wing guerrillas, returned to Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's cabinet. Mr. Scajola, one of Mr. Berlusconi's most trusted political allies and a campaign manager for his Forza Italia party, is returning as minister without portfolio.

title: Chechen Terror Bombing at Hospital Kills Dozens
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1  A truck loaded with explosives blew up outside a military hospital in southern Russian this evening, killing at least 35 people and wounding more than 100, in the latest in a wave of suicide bombings that have spread Russia's war in Chechnya beyond that battered republic's borders.

description: Pfizer, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, has awarded three large consumer advertising assignments and begun a review on another, with total billings estimated at more then $200 million.

title: 4 Suffolk Teenagers Charged In Fire at Home of Mexicans
description: Nearly a month after someone lobbed a burning object into a Mexican family's home, forcing them to flee as the house erupted into flames, the Suffolk County police said today that they had charged four teenagers who live nearby.

title: A Dentist With Dreams and Assorted Suspicions
description: When you hear that Campbell Scott is starring in Alan Rudolph's intensely appealing new domestic comedy, ''The Secret Lives of Dentists,'' your first response may be, why not? With his furtive voice and fluttering diction, Mr. Scott nearly always sounds as if he were slipping information under an embassy door; the lines waft angrily around his mouth before disappearing and leaving a whispery trace. Dave Hurst, the dentist he plays, works hard to keep his messy domestic life in order as he slaves away at a dental practice with his wife, Dana (Hope Davis), while murmuring about the existence he doesn't get to lead.

title: The Sands of Nantucket
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., was once made wealthy by returning whaling ships and has been remade as a tourist destination served by ferries endlessly chugging over from the mainland. Once there, the tourists find pristine natural areas and reminders of the island's rich history. Page 4.

title: Federal Judges Find Courts Short of Money to Pay Jurors
description: The federal courts are running out of money to pay jurors and have asked Congress for authority to tap into emergency funds.

title: From Lurid to Luminous: Pre-Nazi German Images
description: Looking at ''From Expressionism to the Bauhaus,'' a choice selection of early-20th-century German art and design at the Neue Galerie, it's hard not to think about the background of creative ferment, social revolution and terror that culminated in the rise of Nazism.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Change Urged For Riot Trials
description: Citing allegations of witness intimidation, the National Human Rights Commission asked the Supreme Court to order five high-profile trials involving the killing of more than 1,000 people, mostly Muslims, in sectarian riots in Gujarat last year moved to other parts of India. The petition came after a judge in Gujarat acquitted 21 Hindu men last month accused of burning 11 Muslims and 3 Hindu workers to death in a bakery during the riots. In that trial Muslim survivors of the attack unexpectedly recanted their testimony and said they could not identify the perpetrators. After the verdict, the witnesses said that two local politicians threatened them with violence and that they had changed their testimony out of fear. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Draw for Haskell Favors Peace Rules
description: Funny Cide, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, will break from the No. 5 post as the 8-5 morning-line favorite in the Grade I, $1 million Haskell Invitational at Monmouth Park tomorrow. His main rival, Peace Rules, drew the No. 1 post on the rail, which is ideal for his early running tactics.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Gartner Profit Declines
description: Gartner, an information-technology consultant and researcher, said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 30 percent as sales declined. Net income decreased to $12.9 million, or 13 cents a share, from $18.3 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier, Gartner said on its Web site. Sales fell 9.7 percent, to $213.3 million from $236.2 million. Gartner said earnings this quarter will drop to 5 cents to 8 cents a share; analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had expected 12 cents a share on average. Gartner has been cutting jobs and closing offices as sales of research and consulting advice have slowed. The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., has reduced its work force by 200 since January, leaving it with 3,700 employees.

title: Mayor Aims To Ride Wave Of Recovery
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that New York City had turned the corner on its financial crisis and, after two extraordinarily painful years, appeared to be on the verge of an economic revival. His remarks sounded a theme he plans to take across the city's five boroughs as he tries to restore his embattled image.

title: Editorial Observer; Lending a Hand in an African Village (Don't Mind the Goats)
description: The first time a goat walked into the classroom, when I was going over some of the fine points of complex sentences, I was not sure exactly how to proceed. But by the second time, a few days later, I knew the drill: I was expected to keep teaching while a student in the front row quietly led the wayward goat out the door.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Free Internet At Marriott
description: Marriott International will offer free Internet service in 1,200 of its hotels by the end of 2003, including the Courtyard by Marriott, Residence Inn, SpringHill Suites and TownePlace Suites midrange hotels. The company has already installed service in 600 properties and will add 600 more by the end of 2003. By the end of 2004, all 500 Fairfield Inns hotels will also have free Internet service. Most rooms will have wired broadband connections, while wireless access will be available in common areas where Marriott now charges $2.95 for 15 minutes and 25 cents per additional minute. A spokesman, Scott Carman, said that the majority of the company's 377 Marriott and Renaissance business hotels would continue to charge $9.95 a night for high-speed service in rooms and unlimited local and long-distance domestic calls. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAUSSIG, , WALTER
description: TAUSSIG--Walter. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our beloved associate conductor, Walter Taussig. A member of the Met's music staff since 1949, Walter meticulously coached several generations of singers in their roles, including many of the most famous artists of the last half of the 20th Century. He was truly a link to the great musical traditions of the past, having assisted legendary conductors like Fritz Busch, Emil Cooper, Karl Bohm, and Herbert von Karajan, and tirelessly brought his wealth of knowledge and experience to the musical preparation of Met performances. Walter matched this wonderful musical pedigree with a true talent for teaching musical ideas, and an engaging, warm personality that endeared him to all those who had the privilege of working with him. With Walter's passing, we at the Met have lost one of our artistic treasures and dearest friend. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Lore, and his daughter, Lynn, and his many friends. Joseph Volpe General Manager James Levine Artistic Director >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Exactly When No Means No
description: Sex partners have the right to stop engaging in sexual activity at any time, a new state law says. description: Afront-page article on July 24 about the recall drive against Gov. Gray Davis of California misstated the affiliation of Howard Kaloogian, a supporter of the drive. He is associated with the Recall Gray Davis committee; he is not a founder of Rescue California.

title: Silent Classic About a Marvel
description: We have the chess-playing computers Deep Junior and Deep Blue. Now meet the Turk, a turbaned automaton from the 1770's that not only played the game but also defeated virtually everybody it came up against in matches across Europe. In Raymond Bernard's highly entertaining 1927 silent classic "The Chess Player," released this week on DVD and VHS by Milestone, the vanquished include Catherine the Great, who has the device shot shortly before dawn for the crime of lese-majeste.

title: Plan to Move More Inmates Out of State Draws Criticism in Connecticut
description: Since Connecticut began moving some of its convicts to out-of-state prisons four years ago to ease overcrowding and save money, it has paid a steep price in lawsuit settlements and stinging criticism over two prisoners who came home in body bags.

title: On Busy Trading Day, the Giants Get Ponson
description: The San Francisco Giants made the biggest and boldest trade on baseball's trading deadline yesterday as they acquired Sidney Ponson from the Baltimore Orioles for three promising pitchers. Ponson, a 14-gamer winner, was the most appealing starting pitcher available, and he should bolster the Giants, a powerful first-place team that has tiptoed through the season with a spotty rotation.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: RELIANCE PROFIT RISES The industrial conglomerate Reliance Industries Ltd. announced a 28.5 percent rise in quarterly profit yesterday, backed by a healthy growth in sales. The company  India's most valuable private enterprise, with a market capitalization exceeding $10 billion  has businesses spanning petrochemicals, energy, textiles and telecommunications. Reliance announced a profit of 11.8 billion rupees ($255 million) in the quarter that ended in June, compared with 9.18 billion rupees ($199 million) a year earlier. Reliance shares rose 2.6 percent as the results beat market expectations.

title: Saying He's Hussein, Speaker on Tape Tells Iraqis to Resist
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 1  Another audiotape surfaced today in which a speaker purporting to be Saddam Hussein, and sounding almost desperate, urged Iraqis not to cooperate with Americans.

title: Yanks-Red Sox Rivalry Is White Hot
description: When George Steinbrenner was asked for his reaction to last weekend's series at Fenway Park, when the Yankees lost two of three games to the Red Sox, he issued a bland two-sentence statement through his personal public relations man.

title: Your Choice Of Satellites
description: CHOICE is what satellite radio in cars is all about. Freed from relying on just what comes over the local air waves, you can choose from programs of any type you like, no matter where you are driving. Now Nissan is expanding the concept, allowing drivers to choose which of the two major satellite services they want to use: XM Radio or Sirius. Buyers of 2004 Infinitis and Nissan Pathfinders or Muranos can specify their choices when they order their stereo systems.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Varig Posts Big Loss
description: Despite posting an operating profit for 2002, Brazil's troubled flagship airline Varig incurred a record loss for the year of 2.8 billion reais ($947 million), underlining the need for a merger with its rival, TAM. The airline posted an operating profit of 42.6 million reais, a better performance than the 2001 operating loss of 159.8 million reais. But its losses were nearly double the 1.6 billion posted in 2001 and the company ended last year with negative equity of 4.5 billion reais. The carrier attributed most of the losses to a 35 percent drop last year in the real's value against the dollar, the currency in which most of the airline's bills must be paid. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS ORBITZ DOES NOT IMPEDE COMPETITION
description: Orbitz Inc., the Internet travel seller owned by the five biggest airlines in the United States, has not hurt competition or ticket buyers, the Justice Department said yesterday in closing an antitrust investigation of the company. The department looked at whether Orbitz, based in Chicago, would result in collusion among carriers, raise fares or become dominant in online distribution of air travel data, R. Hewitt Pate, the assistant attorney general for the antitrust division, said in a statement. American Airlines, United Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines had invested $204.8 million in Orbitz through last year.

title: Edward Jones In Agency Search
description: Edward Jones, a financial services company based in St. Louis, said yesterday that it had begun a review for an agency to handle creative, direct marketing and interactive duties on its account, which have been handled internally. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: A Homemaker and the Pop Star She Swoons For
description: What is unconditional love, and can we ever find it? We track that question across two continents, two endangered marriages and a long-term love affair cut short by murder. Our reward is a conditional but highly romantic answer.

title: Bankrupt Thinking: How the Banks Aided Enron's Deception
description: SOME Enron frauds were remarkably complicated, masterpieces of sophisticated financial engineering. When investigators try to explain them, they produce charts that would make Rube Goldberg proud.

description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 31 - With so many accomplishments in his record, Roger Clemens did not appear to have done anything Wednesday night that he had not done dozens of times before.

title: 36 Hours | Nantucket, Mass.
description: NANTUCKET is adorned with sprawling cedar-shake houses and windswept vegetation, symbols of its dual nature as a sanctuary for both wealthy summer visitors and many rare and endangered species. Wide swaths of pristine sand framed by grasslands hug the shoreline, while freshwater ponds, salt marshes and cranberry bogs speckle the interior. On the north shore, Nantucket town bustles with chowder houses, stately inns and art galleries. The town becomes a congested tangle in July and August as the island's population -- year-round and summer residents -- swells to 40,000 and is joined by tens of thousands of daily and weekly tourists. Visitors are discouraged from bringing cars to the narrow cobblestone roads, and parking is scarce. So leave your vehicle at the mainland ferry parking lot in Hyannis, Mass., and enjoy the island by bike. The bus is a convenient and affordable alternative. If you can sort through the barrage of overpriced, mediocre restaurants and look beyond the perpetually tanned 20-somethings in their parents' Land Rovers, Nantucket offers a lovely respite amid a wealth of natural beauty. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Still No Sign of Vaughn Returning Anytime Soon
description: Another day passed yesterday without a Mo Vaughn sighting at Shea Stadium. He has been the missing Met for almost three months, and yesterday he reached a significant milestone, at least from the club's perspective. It was the 90th day Vaughn has spent on the disabled list because of his arthritic left knee, completing the deductible the Mets had to pay before they could begin collecting on his insurance.

description: Renaissance bronzes may be an acquired taste for most people, but should you want to assess your interest, the Frick Collection has provided an excellent test site: an illuminating exhibition of the small, powerful bronze figures of the neglected Dutch sculptor Willem van Tetrode.

title: NET INCOME AT NEWMONT MINING INCREASES $22 MILLION
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, the world's biggest gold producer, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 32 percent. A reduction in hedging increased the company's ability to benefit from higher gold prices. Net income rose to $90.8 million, or 22 cents a share, from $69 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier, Newmont said in a statement. Revenue rose to $747.2 million from $643.7 million. The company said it reduced the amount of gold to be sold at a fixed price to 195,000 ounces as of June 30 from 3.7 million three months earlier. Excluding one-time costs and gains, Newmont's earnings matched the average estimate of 18 cents a share from analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Its shares rose 66 cents, to $36.10.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: FREE SPEECH AND BERKELEY Faculty members at the University of California at Berkeley voted to revise guidelines drafted in 1934 largely to assure lawmakers that the university was not a haven for Communist professors. The rules advised professors to "stick to the logic of the facts." The new policy says students and faculty members are free to express the widest range of viewpoints within scholarly and ethical standards. President Richard C. Atkinson has final say over the policy change.    (AP)

description: Senate Republicans failed to break a filibuster that Democrats have used to block a vote on the confirmation of William Pryor Jr. to a federal appeals court. Mr. Pryor, the Alabama attorney general, becomes the fourth judicial nominee of President Bush to be blocked by Democrats who contend that many are staunch conservatives who are being used to tilt the nation's courts rightward. description: The news that peacekeeping troops from Nigeria and other West African countries will head into Liberia next week and that Charles Taylor, the country's thuggish ruler, may go into exile at that time is to be cheered. But it should not become an excuse for the United States to delay or decide against sending ashore its own forces to ensure Liberia's return to security and political stability.

title: The Growing Inmate Population
description: The nation's prison and jail population rose again last year, to 2,166,260, a record. The increase comes at a time when crime is falling and state and local governments are struggling to close budget deficits. The price of imprisoning so many Americans is too high, in scarce tax dollars and in wasted lives. Congress and state legislatures should find ways to reduce the number of people behind bars.

title: EXXON MOBIL SAYS HIGHER ENERGY PRICES AIDED PROFIT RISE
description: Exxon Mobil, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 58 percent because of higher energy prices and improved performance in its refining business. Net income increased to $4.17 billion, or 62 cents a share, from $2.64 billion, or 39 cents, a year earlier, the company, based in Irving, Tex., said. Revenue rose 12 percent, to $57.16 billion from $50.8 billion. Higher oil and natural gas prices increased profits from the production business by 27 percent, to $2.84 billion, and rising fuel sales helped stoke a 50 percent jump in earnings from refining. Shares of Exxon Mobil rose 26 cents, to $35.58.

description: After months of arguing over Daniel Libeskind's winning design for the World Trade Center site, officials overseeing the rebuilding said yesterday that they had resolved most of their differences, and many agreed that the Libeskind plan was now likely to be built in substantially recognizable form.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: 2 TO BE NAMED TOP POLICE OFFICIALS A 24-year police veteran will become the highest-ranking woman officer in Police Department history today when she is promoted to the three-star post of chief of the Housing Bureau. Assistant Chief Joanne Jaffe will oversee the 1,600 officers who patrol the city's 376 public-housing developments. Chief Jaffe is currently commanding officer of the Office of Management Analysis and Planning, which proposes policies, strategies and new programs and monitors the department's crime reporting system. She joined the department in 1979, working first in the 75th Precinct in East New York. She went on to serve as commanding officer of the First Precinct in Lower Manhattan, the 19th Precinct on the Upper East Side and the 33rd Precinct in Washington Heights. She earned a bachelor's degree in criminal justice and a master's degree in forensic psychology from John Jay College. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly is scheduled to promote Chief Jaffe at a ceremony today where he will also appoint Chief Douglas Zeigler, the current Housing Bureau chief, to head the Organized Crime Control Bureau. In that job, Chief Zeigler, the highest-ranking black police official, will oversee the Narcotics Division and the units that investigate organized crime and prostitution. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Senators Push Saudi Arabia to Improve Antiterrorism Efforts
description: Republican and Democratic senators sought today to compel Saudi Arabia to intensify its antiterrorism efforts, calling for a variety of measures, including the removal of a powerful member of the royal family from public office and asking the United States government to consider criminal charges against Saudi entities that sponsor terrorism.

title: Clothes With Tales to Tell and Lives to Enliven
description: Before Park Slope became a variant of TriBeCa -- before the sake bars and $250 throw pillows arrived -- Alison Houtte was this Brooklyn neighborhood's most glamorous asset. Ms. Houtte is one-quarter inch short of standing six feet tall and looks like Ali MacGraw without the vague air of melancholy. During the era in which the neighborhood's dress code seemed to dictate earth tones and shoes ostensibly designed by chiropodists, Ms. Houtte wore halter tops she had made out of red silk scarves affixed to her neck with gold chokers.

In the process perhaps something could be done about the multimillion-dollar losses of the city's tourism and hospitality industries.

The sequel to ''American Pie'' and even more pathetically the sequel to ''American Pie 2,'' ''Wedding'' struggles so hard to be tasteless that it's almost quaint. (Don't presume such a remark to be a compliment; you'll see better film on ponds.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPHAEL, , JACOB H.
description: RAPHAEL--Jacob H. Husband of the late Lillian. Loving and Devoted father of Deborah and Myron Mallen, Alan and Susan Raphael, Dr. Irving and Ava Raphael and Judith and Henry Shrager. Adoring grandfather of twelve, great-grandfather of three. Jacob Raphael was the Founder and first Principal of Thomas Edison Vocational High School 1950-1964, and Principal of the High School of Art and Design 1964-1972. Mr. Raphael was an assistant to the Board of Examiners, NYC and Adjunct Assistant Professor at Brooklyn College. He was also active as a consultant to the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues 1942-1976, during which time he founded 38 Religious Schools in 38 new synagogues in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. title: Once More With Feeling: A Lelouch Jet-Set Fantasy
description: If Claude Lelouch had made only one movie -- ''A Man and a Woman,'' his wildly popular 1966 romance starring Jean-Louis Trintignant and Anouk Aime -- he would be assured at least a footnote in cinema history. That film, which won the Palme d'Or at Cannes and two Academy Awards, gave the formal innovations of the French New Wave a glossy, accessible appeal and was a huge international hit. But it is not altogether clear, based on Mr. Lelouch's subsequent career, that he did make more than one movie. His brand of melancholy, stylish romanticism, at once jaded and swooning, does not vary much from picture to picture, and his world-weary, glamorous love stories have a tendency to run together in the mind.

Area residents boast that the spot is one of the most scenic in the West, with the San Jacinto Mountains to the west, the Little San Bernardino Mountains to the north and Joshua Tree National Park to the northeast.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Nurses Authorize Strike
description: The nurses' union at University Hospital has voted to authorize a strike if contract negotiations do not progress. A strike deadline was not set, said Bernie Gerard, the vice president of the union, the Health Professionals and Allied Employees. He said yesterday that the nurses were ''angry and frustrated that four months of negotiations have been stalled.'' In a vote tallied Wednesday and released yesterday, 418 nurses voted for the strike authorization, with 19 opposed. The union represents about 800 registered nurses who have been working without a contract since July 1 at the state-owned hospital. The nurses have said they are concerned about understaffing and want the hospital to include the hiring of more nurses in the contract. New Jersey law prohibits state employees from striking; the union risks getting fined if the nurses strike. ''Frankly we are surprised by HPAE's decision because talks have been very productive,'' said a statement released by the hospital. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RACKMAN, , HONEY
description: RACKMAN -- Honey. The partners, associates and staff of Gottlieb, Rackman & Reisman, P.C. mourn the passing of Honey Rackman, wife of founding partner Michael I. Rackman after a long battle with cancer. Honey was active in many Jewish causes that she felt passionately about, including The Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance and Agunah, Inc. She exemplified the modern Jewish woman, while keeping faith with Jewish tradition. Her home was always open to family and friends, who can attest to her warmth and thoughtfulness. Our thoughts are with her husband, our longtime colleague, and to her children and grandchildren. We share their loss. Gottlieb, Rackman & Reisman, P.C.

title: Filling a Creative Void at Ground Zero
description: The site plan represents the destruction of Sept. 11. Now the architecture will provide the creative response. That's the implicit message in the selection of Santiago Calatrava to design a permanent replacement for the PATH station that was destroyed by the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001. At last, the controversial plan developed by Daniel Libeskind for the site begins to make sense. From it, great things might grow.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Sales Grow
description: The Nissan Motor Company said yesterday that it sold 700,215 cars from April to June, a 2.7 percent increase from the period a year earlier. The company, which is Japan's third-largest carmaker, said car sales brought in 1.65 trillion yen ($13.6 billion). Sales in Japan fell, while volume in the United States and Europe grew. The company left its full-year forecasts unchanged and still expects to earn a 495 billion yen ($4.1 billion) profit. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: IOWA: IMMIGRANT SMUGGLING CHARGES Three men were charged with smuggling 11 immigrants whose bodies were found in a rail car last fall. Prosecutors said Juan Fernando Licea-Cedillo, 26, Rogelio Hernandez Ramos, 38, and Guillermo Madrigal Ballisteros, 45, were charged with conspiring to smuggle the immigrants into the United States. Mr. Licea-Cedillo was in custody on an unrelated federal charge. Warrants had been issued for Mr. Hernandez and Mr. Madrigal, the prosecutors said. Workers who were cleaning rail cars in Denison, 90 miles northwest of Des Moines, found the bodies of the Mexican immigrants on Oct. 14, 2002. They had been trapped for four months.    (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schering Issues Warning
description: The Berlin-based drug maker Schering warned yesterday that full-year profit would be hurt by the stronger euro and come in lower than in 2002. Presenting its half-year results, the company said net sales dropped 8 percent, to 2.3 billion euros ($2.6 billion), from a year ago, while the figures adjusted for the exchange-rate effect rose 3 percent in the first half-year. Operating profit fell 6 percent, to 374 million euros ($420 million), and net profit dropped 10 percent, to 250 million euros ($281 million). Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Motorola Wins $4 Billion in Dispute Over Loans to Turkish Family
description: Motorola won a $4.26 billion fraud judgment yesterday against members of a wealthy Turkish family who got loans from Motorola to expand a cellular phone company.

description: Officials with the Teamsters union said yesterday that the union would officially endorse Representative Richard A. Gephardt for the Democratic nomination for president.

title: Weapons of Mass Confusion
description: CAMP DOHA, Kuwait, Aug. 1  There is a bold and entirely plausible theory that may account for the mystery over Iraq's missing weapons of mass destruction.

title: Leader of Iraqi Arms Search Gives Senators a Confident but Cautious Report
description: The administration's new chief weapons hunter, who gave closed-door briefings to two Senate committees today, said afterward that teams searching for evidence of illegal weapons in Iraq were making ''solid progress,'' but he also counseled patience.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Windows Security Patch
description: Computer users running most recent versions of the Microsoft Windows operating system need to patch a major security hole recently disclosed by Microsoft, the Department of Homeland Security said yesterday. A virus taking advantage of flaws in a part of Windows that permits a ''remote procedure call'' could take full control of the target computer; computer security experts say they expect to see such viruses appear soon. A full description of the problem and how to fix it can be found at www.microsoft.com/security/security_bulletins/ms03-026.asp. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: In Connecticut, Officials Say Deaths in Shop Are Homicides
description: The police here were calling the deaths of three people found on Wednesday inside an auto repair shop homicides, but declined to say how they died and would not say whether there were any suspects.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Sueos (the name is Spanish for dreams) does have an air of enchantment about it. The tiny dining room, a few steps below street level, is decorated in hot tropical colors, with glass-enclosed displays of folk art substituting for windows on one wall. On the other, an open-air desert rock garden occupies the space between the restaurant and the building next door. When it rains, the thirsty desert drinks. When the sun shines, it bakes. A few reptiles would add a nice touch.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Federal Customer Service
description: In an effort to simplify communication with the public, the federal government is creating a customer service program to consolidate and disseminate information from all federal agencies. The program, called USA Services, seeks to provide responses to all inquiries via the World Wide Web, e-mail or the telephone within two business days, the General Services Administration said. Much of the effort will focus on the government's Web portal, FirstGov.gov, which was created to make finding information and doing business with the government easier.

Well known collector of 20th Century American Art and President of Polychrome Lithography Co., Inc. of New York City. Graduate Phi Beta Kappa Rutgers University, 1942. Husband of Barbara. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPP, , STEVEN
description: PAPP--Steven. The faculty, staff and students at Columbia University Health Sciences mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Steven Papp. For the past 25 years, Steven was Deputy Director for Administration at NY State Psychiatric Institute and Associate Vice President in the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University. Steven brought a wealth of knowledge and experience to both Columbia and the Psychiatric Institute. He was at once a world class administrator, a leader, a mentor, and most importantly, a friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. He will be deeply missed. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D., Exec Vice President & Dean, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons

title: World Officials Agree to Share Ecology Data
description: Officials from more than 30 countries agreed today to expand monitoring of the atmosphere, the oceans and the land and to create a system for sharing the resulting data.

description: In March, Giants Coach Jim Fassel gave himself and his assistant coaches some well-deserved time off. Most of the coaches scattered to their vacation destinations for rest and relaxation.

title: Schwarzenegger and Top Ally Mum as Filing Deadline Nears
description: With the deadline for entering the recall race for California governor little more than a week away, the two most prominent potential Republican candidates, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Richard J. Riordan, former mayor of Los Angeles, continued their strange, silent dance today.

title: HALLIBURTON SAYS QUARTER WAS PROFITABLE
description: The Halliburton Company yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $26 million after a year-earlier loss as revenue from government contracts more than doubled because of work in Iraq. Net income was 6 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $498 million, or $1.15 a share, in the period a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose to $3.6 billion from $3.24 billion. Engineering and construction sales rose 23 percent, partly on United States contracts in Iraq. Iraq work generated 9 percent of operating profit and revenue. The company, based in Houston, said it expected third-quarter profit from continuing operations, excluding asbestos-claim settlements, of at least 32 cents a share. Shares of Halliburton rose $1.06, to to $22.17.

description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell approved payment of a $30 million reward to the informant who led American soldiers to Saddam Hussein's sons, hoping the payment would speed efforts to find Mr. Hussein himself, the State Department said today.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: U.S. TROOPS WOUND AFGHAN SOLDIERS American soldiers opened fire on a taxi near Kabul, wounding three officers of Afghanistan's new national army. American military officials said the taxi was "driving aggressively" as it approached American military vehicles. The Afghans wounded in the taxi were taken to a German military hospital for treatment. Two months ago a suicide bomber in a taxi killed himself and five others, four of them German peacekeepers, on the same road, which leads to bases used by foreign peacekeepers and American forces.    (Reuters)

title: FINANCE UNIT OF FORD NAMES A NEW CHIEF OF OPERATIONS
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, the finance unit of the automaker, promoted Michael Bannister to president and chief operating officer yesterday. Mr. Bannister was president of Ford Credit International, which handles the finance business in Asia, Europe and Latin America. Mr. Bannister will take the president post from Greg Smith, the chairman and chief executive of Ford Credit. The chief operating officer position was vacant. Ford Credit produced $401 million of Ford Motor's $417 million in second-quarter earnings.

title: Dispersing Americana Treasures
description: ''The old dealers had catholic taste,'' said Chris Jussel, speaking about his father and his father's friends Cora and Benjamin Ginsburg. ''They were renaissance dealers. They bought anything that was good -- furniture, porcelain, glass, prints and books. Today, dealers are so specialized.''

title: Advance Peacekeepers Assessing Liberia
description: The shelling subsided and children poured into the streets today for the first time in 13 days, as 10 unarmed West African soldiers, here to assess conditions for the deployment of a peacekeeping force, drove around the city and brought a glimmer of hope to a capital without much.

title: The Danube Transformed: From River of Blood to River of Hope
description: It begins here or at least the people here say it does -- as a spring bubbling up from beneath a stone urn beneath the walls of the white and yellow St. John's Church. After flowing for a short distance under the garden of the Frstenberg Castle it pours, at a rate of about 20 gallons per second, into another stream, the Brigach, flowing nearby.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Not Guilty Plea In Seton Hall Case
description: A father who prosecutors said obstructed justice in an attempt to shield his son from prosecution in connection with a deadly fire at Seton Hall University pleaded not guilty yesterday in Superior Court. On Wednesday, the son, Joseph T. Lepore, 21, and four others pleaded not guilty in the 2000 fire that killed three students. The son and another man are charged with murder. A friend and Mr. Lepore's mother and sister are charged with obstructing the investigation and witness tampering. Yesterday, Joseph E. Lepore, 58, pleaded not guilty to obstruction, tampering and perjury in testimony to a grand jury investigating the fire. Prosecutors said the elder Mr. Lepore instructed family members to withhold information from investigators. A court hearing for the father is scheduled for Sept. 22. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: High School Under Scrutiny For Giving Up on Its Students
description: Haydee Garcia admits she was having a rocky time at Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn last year. At 17, she had amassed only enough credits to be considered a sophomore. School officials had already called her and her mother in to discuss her frequent absences, her suspension for fighting, her pregnancy.

title: Clairvoyant but Clueless on the Case
description: In real life, the names become household words: Laci Peterson, Chandra Levy, Elizabeth Smart. Television viewers see the photographs and the home movies of birthdays and vacations again and again. And when there's an occasional happy ending, like Ms. Smart's safe return to her home last March, people who have never even met the victim can feel strong emotion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Is Indicted In Death Of Child
description: A Queens teenager has been indicted in connection with the hit-and-run death of a 10-year-old boy in April. In a three-count indictment filed earlier this week, a jury charged the teenager, Emmanuel Kanios, 19, of Astoria, with manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide and leaving the scene of an accident. The victim, Stephan Trajkovski, was struck while riding his bicycle at 75th Street and Ditmars Boulevard in Astoria. A law enforcement official said Mr. Kanios was speeding in a 1998 Honda sport utility vehicle and, after striking the child, left the scene. If convicted, Mr. Kanios faces up to 15 years in prison. His lawyer did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: If unions representing 78,000 Verizon workers in the Northeast go on strike this weekend, the company insists customer service will not suffer.

title: Ah, To Be Young: Working All Day, Partying All Night
description: IT is 10 p.m. on a Saturday in Wildwood, N.J., and as the ''no vacancy'' signs at the 1950's-era motor lodges along Atlantic Avenue light up, Anthony Bongrazio, 19, of Medford, N.J., is standing on the roof of his summer rental. Suddenly, something catches his eye. ''Hey, lady in red,'' he shouts at a woman walking on the street below. One floor down, Michael DiClementi, 23, is leaning over the railing of the front deck, sipping a drink and watching the evening ripen.

description: The All Nippon Airways Company said yesterday that its loss in the April-to-June quarter grew 55 percent because severe acute respiratory syndrome limited overseas travel. Japan's second-largest airline lost 18.3 billion yen ($151.7 million) in the quarter, compared with a 11.8 billion loss in the period last year. title: REVLON LOSES MONEY FOR THE 19TH CONSECUTIVE QUARTER
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed to $37.8 million as the company increased sales with new products and higher advertising spending. The net loss fell to 68 cents a share from $38.9 million, or 74 cents, a year earlier, the company said. It was the 19th straight quarterly loss for Revlon. Sales rose 4.6 percent to $322.3 million. Revlon shares fell 16 cents, to $3.35.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE'S EARNINGS INCREASE 4.9%
description: Procter & Gamble said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 4.9 percent, helped by higher sales of Pampers diapers and Tide detergent. Net income increased to $955 million, or 68 cents a share, from $910 million, or 64 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the quarter rose 7.4 percent, to $10.9 billion. Excluding restructuring costs, the company said it would have earned 87 cents. On that basis, profit was 1 cent more than the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Shares of Procter & Gamble rose 12 cents, to $87.87.

title: Moody's Officer to Retire
description: The Moody's Corporation, the parent of Moody's Investors Service, said yesterday that Clifford L. Alexander Jr. would step down as chairman on Oct. 1. Mr. Alexander became nonexecutive chairman in October 2000, after the company was spun off from Dun & Bradstreet, which is now called the D&B Corporation. He will reach Moody's retirement age of 70 next month, a spokeswoman, Fran Laserson, said.

title: Truck Bombing at Russian Military Hospital Kills 35; Officials Blame Chechen Separatists
description: A truck loaded with explosives blew up beside a military hospital in southern Russia this evening, killing at least 35 and wounding dozens. Russian officials immediately blamed Chechen separatists for the bombing, the latest in a wave of suicide attacks that have spread Russia's war in Chechnya beyond the battered region's borders.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senate Confirms Woman As Head Of D.E.A.
description: The Senate has confirmed a longtime Justice Department official to become the first woman to lead the Drug Enforcement Administration. The official, Karen Tandy, a former federal prosecutor who currently heads the Justice Department task force on drug trafficking, was confirmed by the Senate without dissent late Thursday night. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, praised Ms. Tandy for ''a long and impressive 25-year career with the Department of Justice.'' She succeeds Asa Hutchinson, who left the D.E.A. this year to become undersecretary of homeland security. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Muting The Call To Service
description: A little over a week ago, in New Orleans, I met two young women who had driven hours, through the heat of July, in rural Louisiana, to talk to me about tutoring kids. Sarah Garb and Megan Peterson are both in their early 20's, both graduates of very good colleges, and both have been living in Clinton, a tiny Louisiana town far from any large city, a town with quite literally one stoplight. They were Teach for America participants who had committed two years of their lives to teaching in low-performing schools. After they talked with me and a pair of men who run a tutoring center through Tulane University, it was 11 p.m., and time for them to drive back.

title: Credibility of Witness Is Challenged in MCI Inquiry
description: A Minnesota telephone company at the center of the most recent criminal inquiry into MCI today attacked the credibility of a whistle-blower who may be the most important witness in the case.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota Ratings Upgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service upgraded the long-term credit ratings of the Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's third-largest carmaker, citing its strong performance and balance sheet. Toyota's debt is now rated Aaa, the highest possible, from Aa1 before, and the outlook for its credit is stable. Moody's said the upgrading was also based on the company's ability to continue cost reduction programs and its diverse product line-up and new model plans. Toyota last had a Aaa ranking five years ago. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Jury Clears Houston Crime Lab
description: One of two grand juries looking into problems at the Houston Police Department crime laboratory ended its investigation without filing charges. The DNA unit of the laboratory was closed in January after a state audit found widespread flaws in its work. ''We have learned that the knowledge of problems and lack of action to correct them do not constitute criminal negligence,'' the grand jurors said, in an unusual news release. ''Ethics and moral violations, even if they severely violate the public trust, are beyond our jurisdiction.'' The other grand jury is continuing its inquiry. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Unmasking Writers Of the W.P.A.
description: Writers are usually unabashed about claiming authorship for their work. So it's curious that many of the alumni of one of the most significant American literary projects of the 20th century were ashamed of it: the Federal Writers' Project, a program of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Works Progress Administration.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Banks Ordered To Improve
description: Japan's banking regulator, the Financial Services Agency, ordered 15 of the largest banks to submit by the end of August fresh plans to bolster their businesses. The agency said the banks had failed to meet their earnings goals even after their bad- loan write-offs. It wants the banks, which have received taxpayers' money, to begin reporting results quarterly. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Documentary Recalls Half Million Murdered
description: Among Gypsies it is known as the Porraimos, or ''the devouring.'' From 1938 to 1945, more than half a million Gypsies were murdered by the Nazis, along with six million Jews and many others singled out for extermination. The little-examined Gypsy Shoah is the subject of ''Porraimos: Europe's Gypsies in the Holocaust,'' a nightmarish documentary to be shown tomorrow night on PBS.

title: Man in the News; A Concern for Cities -- Nicholas Anthony DiMarzio Jr.
description: Nicholas A. DiMarzio grew up across the street from Sacred Heart Cathedral on Ridge Street in Newark, and he said he wanted to be a priest before he was sure what being one meant.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TOYOTA RATINGS UPGRADED Moody's Investors Service upgraded the long-term credit ratings of the Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's third-largest carmaker, citing its strong performance and balance sheet. Toyota's debt is now rated Aaa, the highest possible, from Aa1 before, and the outlook for its credit is stable. Moody's said the upgrading was also based on the company's ability to continue cost reduction programs and its diverse product line-up and new model plans. Toyota last had a Aaa ranking five years ago. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Senator Criticizes Bush On Liberia Case
description: With American warships full of marines steaming closer to Liberia's coast, an influential Republican senator criticized the Bush administration today for preparing plans to send troops to that country without making a convincing case to Congress, which has just started a month's recess.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Exports Slowed In July
description: With its currency strengthening, Brazil's exports slowed in July and the country posted a trade surplus of just over $2 billion for the month, bringing the surplus to $12.45 billion so far this year. In July, exports totaled $6.1 billion and imports $4.04 billion, the second consecutive monthly drop in the surplus after it topped $2.5 billion in May and $2.35 billion in June. Since May, Brazil's currency, the real, which lost more than 40 percent of its value last year, has appreciated against the dollar, recovering to around 2.7 to the dollar and prompting protests from exporters. Yesterday, however, the real was back at 3 to the dollar in part because of uncertainties over government reform proposals. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Saturday with an Associated Press photograph of Japanese legislators tussling after the chairman of a Parliamentary committee cut off debate on a proposal to send troops to Iraq misstated the day the measure passed. It was early Saturday, not on Friday.

title: An Earlier Revolution In Russia
description: In the explosion of creativity that transformed Russian art in the early 20th century, only a handful of painters -- Chagall, Kandinsky, Malevich, Tatlin and El Lissitzky among them -- gained world renown before the Soviet Union clamped down on modern art and imposed the creed of Socialist Realism.

title: Shares Decline on Lackluster July Employment Report
description: Stocks dropped yesterday, as the economy unexpectedly lost jobs last month and a gauge of manufacturing fell short of economists' forecasts.

title: Ethical Use of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of 6 Kidneys, or She Gave Him Her Love, He Gave Her His Kidney
description: Jeremy Weiser-Warschoff, 13, met Paul Boissiere, a soft-spoken 30-year-old electrical engineer from Trinidad, for the first time today, even though they had been linked for the last five days by Jeremy's newly implanted kidney, which Paul had donated.

title: Cigna Reports $53 Million Loss in Second Quarter
description: The Cigna Corporation, the health insurer, posted a loss yesterday for the second quarter as membership rolls shrank and it set aside more money for its former reinsurance business.

title: Less Power, More Influence
description: Three years into the new century, America continues to struggle over what W. E. B. DuBois famously called the problem of the last century: the problem of the color line. In several decisions at the end of its term, the Supreme Court pointed the way forward on two difficult issues: race and education, and race and politics.

title: Sticker Shock: Tattoo Without a Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE RULES RIGAS FAMILY CAN USE COMPANY FUNDS
description: Four members of the Rigas family can use cash made by cable television companies they control to defend themselves against accusations they built a personal fortune by looting Adelphia Communications, a bankruptcy judge ruled yesterday. Judge Robert E. Gerber of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan ruled that John, Michael, Timothy and James Rigas can have access to $15 million generated by cable companies other than Adelphia. An Adelphia lawyer, George F. Carpinello, indicated he would appeal the decision. He also said that Adelphia's banks might have the right to take control of these other companies, effectively blocking the right of the Rigases to tap into their revenue.

title: Ancient Art at Met Raises Old Ethical Questions
description: Almost lost in the sumptuous display of Mesopotamian antiquities in the ''Art of the First Cities'' exhibition now at the Metropolitan Museum is a small limestone fragment, triangular in shape and delicately carved.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: 105 Convicted In Ethnic Killings
description: A Rwandan court convicted 105 people for their roles in mass killings in 1994 that left as many as 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu dead. The defendants received punishments ranging from the death penalty to a year in jail. Thirty-seven others were acquitted, some after spending up to nine years in jail awaiting trial. Rwanda has convicted 6,500 people in the killings; 600 to 700 received death sentences, prosecutors said. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would not go through this pain for fun. But what else could I do? I could not just lose her.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIASTUCH, , MICHAEL
description: PIASTUCH -- Michael. Be loved husband of Catherine. Devoted father of Veronica and Lorraine. Also survived by grandson Milo and sister Sophie Gamley. Reposing Peter Jarema Funeral Home, 129 E. 7th St., NYC, Sunday 2-9 pm. Services Sunday, 7 PM. Funeral Monday, St. George Ukrainian Catholic Church, 9:30 AM. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. >>AD#

title: Senate Approves Treaty Updating Limits on Airlines' Liability
description: The Senate approved on Thursday night a treaty that will give the families of passengers killed on international flights the same rights to recover damages as those on domestic flights. The move sets aside a 70-year-old system of liability limits, and generally gives Americans the right to sue in this country even if the accident occurred elsewhere.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BELARUS: LEADER HINTS AT 3RD TERM President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, whose authoritarian policies have left the country's 10 million people increasingly isolated, signaled that he intended to extend his power, saying he would consider holding a referendum to allow him to serve a third term. The constitutional limit is two. Mr. Lukashenko, who came to power in 1994 and extended his first presidency with a referendum, was elected to a new five-year term in 2001 in voting that was widely criticized as neither free nor fair. Since then his government has intensified its repression of the opposition and the news media. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Production Rose In July
description: British manufacturing expanded in July for the first time in nine months, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply, a trade group. The group's manufacturing activity index rose to 50.9, up from 49.5 in June. A reading above 50 indicates that manufacturing is expanding. The survey also showed that export orders dropped in July, with that gauge falling to 49.1 from 50.2. While some British manufacturers benefited from the pound's decline against the euro, its strengthening against the dollar hurt business with the United States. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an Op-Ed article on July 25 by Gustavo Arcos Bergnes about Cuba misstated where Mr. Arcos's younger brother, Sebastin, died. It was Miami, not in a Cuban prison. A translation credit was also omitted. The article was translated by The Times from the Spanish.

title: Victims in Shop Killings Were Shot in Head
description: Three men killed Wednesday in an auto repair shop in Windsor Locks, Conn., died of gunshot wounds to the head, according to autopsies performed yesterday by the Connecticut chief medical examiner.

title: INSIDE
description: 35 Killed in Russia Bombing

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about methods of guarding against unsolicited e-mail, or spam, referred imprecisely to the filtering method of Yahoo Mail. While the service provides a link in incoming messages that can be used to designate them as unfiltered spam, it is Yahoo employees who modify the filter based on that information.

title: Pataki's Veto Prevents Ban On Closing Subway Booths
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill yesterday that would have blocked New York City transit officials from closing 62 subway MetroCard booths over the next year while an advisory panel studied safety threats to the city's subways and buses.

title: A Stern Vatican And Gay Marriage

description: LIPPINCOTT--Stephen Wharton. August 2, 1993. Forever missed. Dad and Ber

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: LLOYDS POSTS 4% PROFIT RISE The Lloyds TSB Group said yesterday that profit rose 4 percent in the first six months, to 1.15 billion ($1.86 billion) as its consumer lending and savings businesses improved, but it warned that profit margins could narrow. The bank also said it would acquire Goldfish Bank, a credit card and personal lender, for 112.5 million ($180.7 million). Lloyds could also pay out as much as 300 million ($482 million) to customers in its Scottish Widows fund management unit who lost money on investments. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: No Contest As the 'Idols' Sing for Fun
description: Here's a great idea for a sport: get a bunch of boxers together, and have them beat one another up for hours. There would be no judges, no scores, no surprising victories or disappointing defeats. The athletes would be flailing away purely for fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HATFIELD, , JOHN D.
description: HATFIELD--John D. of Wallingford, CT. 59, Executive Vice President and Provost, University of New Haven in West Haven, CT, died July 30. Online Registry at www.mcculloughfh.com >>AD#

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: U.S. ATTORNEY REVIEWS DETROIT CASES The United States attorney's office in Detroit is reviewing what could exceed more than 100 criminal cases to see whether any convictions should be overturned as a result of the indictment in June of 17 Detroit police officers on corruption charges. The officers are accused of conducting illegal searches of houses and vehicles, making unlawful arrests, using excessive force, falsifying police reports and planting evidence. An assistant United States attorney, Alan Gershel, said most of the cases were federal gun charges brought when officers encountered people illegally possessing guns or using guns to commit crimes. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: About New York; When Seeing Is Believing. Or Is It?
description: NATALIA LULOVA could be like other 12-year-olds. She could be practicing how to swim, how to jump rope, how to spit through gaps in her teeth. Instead, she diligently practices the paranormal exercise of ''seeing'' with her eyes blindfolded, so that one day she might open them to find a check for one million eye-popping dollars.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL EMERGES FROM CHAPTER 11
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after two years and eight months. The announcement came two days after union steelworkers approved a five-year contract that included wage concessions and was an important part of the company's restructuring. The president and chief executive, James G. Bradley, said the company could now claim a $250 million loan package.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Governor George E. Pataki's views on the future of the Indian Point nuclear power plant referred incorrectly to a public statement by his press secretary, Lisa Dewald Stoll. She said the governor hoped to ''phase out'' the plant eventually if ''cleaner, safer, more sustainable replacement energy can be identified.'' She did not say whether he favored keeping it open now. Yesterday, Mr. Pataki himself said he had not yet decided. Article, Page B1.

title: Family Seeks Longer Term For Stabbing In Crown Hts.
description: The family of Yankel Rosenbaum, who was fatally stabbed in the Crown Heights racial violence in 1991, argued in a legal filing yesterday that the man convicted of a civil rights violation in the case should receive a far longer sentence than is being sought by either the prosecution or the defense.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about Howard Dean's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination misspelled the name of the Iowa city where he spoke at Taso's restaurant. It is Oskaloosa, not Oskalossa.

title: Beliefs; A new poll gauges the evolving American attitudes about Islam and about gay marriage.
description: You simply cannot get it all in one story. That was surely the case with an opinion poll on religion and politics conducted in late June and early July by the Pew Research Center and Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

title: Surgery Will Keep Serena Williams Out of U.S. Open
description: The announcement last night that Serena Williams would not defend her United States Open title created a wide-open tournament while depriving the field of the most compelling player in women's tennis.

title: In Pursuit of Prokofiev: A 2-Saturday Marathon
description: The pianist Anne-Marie McDermott and some of her colleagues from the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center spent the last two Saturdays exploring Prokofiev's piano sonatas and chamber works in a pair of endurance-testing marathons, offered as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Security Council Supports a Liberia Force
description: The Security Council late tonight approved a United States resolution for a multinational force to quell the violence and the keep peace in Liberia while a new government is formed.

title: U.S. and North Korea Announce Accord on Wider Atom Talks
description: North Korea and the United States announced today that they had agreed to hold regional talks over North Korea's nuclear weapons program, in a victory for the Bush administration, which resisted 10 months of pressure to hold one-on-one talks with the North.

description: The Bush administration has backed away from demands that the Palestinian Authority dismantle militant groups immediately, concerned that the authority's security forces are too weak at this point to carry out a speedy crackdown, administration officials said today.

title: Wider Korea Talks
description: North Korea and the United States have agreed to hold talks along with regional neighbors over the North's nuclear weapons program. By guaranteeing seats at the table to China, Russia, Japan and South Korea, Washington hopes to draw regional players into a pact to curb the North's nuclear weapons program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARLOW, , ETHEL
description: BARLOW--Ethel. On July 31, 2003. A lifelong resident of New York. Widely traveled, Ms. Barlow made over 60 trips to Europe. She is survived by her grand-nephews David Rubin and Michael Rubin, and her cousin Hyacinth Hoffman. Contributions may be sent to the Simon Wiesenthal Foundation. Services are Sunday 10:00 AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ. >>AD#

title: Boy, 5, Dies After Being Struck By Car Near Queens Playground
description: A 5-year-old Queens boy was fatally struck Thursday evening after he darted into the street from between two cars parked near a playground in Astoria, the police said yesterday.

title: Vehicle Sales Dipped in July For Big Three
description: American consumers gave the auto industry its best month of the year in July. Unfortunately for Detroit, they did so by buying vehicles with foreign nameplates.

title: An Officer's Colleagues Accuse Him of Fraud and Larceny
description: A year ago in April, a longtime member of the police force here, Scott M. Lavallee, had his own crime to report. He said his black 1990 Corvette had been stolen.

title: Months Before Debut, Movie On Death of Jesus Causes Stir
description: With his movie about the death of Jesus under attack as anti-Semitic, Mel Gibson is trying to build an audience and a defense for his project by screening it for evangelical Christians, conservative Catholics, right-wing pundits, Republicans, a few Jewish commentators and Jews who believe that Jesus is the Messiah.

title: U.S. May Cut Foreign Fliers' Layovers
description: President Bush is being urged by senior law enforcement and counterterrorism officials to suspend or eliminate two troubled programs that permit foreign air travelers without visas to pass through the United States on their way to other countries, administration officials said today.
