title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPERBER, , BERNARD
description: SPERBER--Bernard, 92, 1933 graduate of NYU Law School, passed away July 31, 2003 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved husband of the late Helen Tobias Sperber. He is survived by daughter, Peggy Flanders of Syracuse, New York; sister Lillian Wechsler of Boynton Beach, Florida; grandsons David and Eric Flanders; five great-grandchildren and one nephew, Dr. Stephen Wechsler. Bernard retired in 1986 as President of Rich Plan of the Southern Tier and remained active his entire life with study, golf and service on the Legal Committee and Board of Boca Greens Country Club. Service at 1:00 PM on Sunday, August 3, 2003 at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York. >>AD#

title: G.E. TO POST $150 MILLION GAIN ON EDISON SALE
description: The General Electric Company, which plans to sell some finance units for as much as $10 billion this year, said yesterday that it would post a $150 million gain on the sale of its Japanese life insurance unit to the American International Group. The gain was disclosed in General Electric's quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company agreed on June 26 to sell GE Edison Life Insurance as well as its car and home units to A.I.G. for $2.15 billion in cash.

title: Pataki Says He Remains Undecided On Indian Pt.
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he had not yet reached a decision on whether the Indian Point nuclear power plant should remain open, a debate that has been raging in New York State for nearly two years.

title: Boone Has the Fire, and Could Provide a Spark
description: Aaron Boone started his week as a member of a team in the midst of imploding. The Cincinnati Reds' record was diving further under the .500 mark, the team was numbed by injuries, selling off quality players, angering fans. And it had fired the manager, Boone's father, Bob.

title: Dutch Send 1,100 Troops to Iraq, Relieving as Many U.S. Marines
description: Breaking ranks with many of its European neighbors, the Netherlands has sent 1,100 Dutch peacekeepers to southern Iraq so a nearly equal number of American marines can go home.

title: Iran Said to Hold Qaeda's No. 3, but to Resist Giving Him Up
description: Iran has taken into custody the third-ranking member of Al Qaeda, Saif al-Adel, United States officials said today, but has rebuffed an initial American effort to have him and other top Qaeda figures handed over to Washington.

Devoted father to Kevin and Kristin. Beloved son of Mary and Jimmie. Adored son-inlaw of Stephanie Ball. Dear brother of Mary Agnes Del Tufo, and Regina. Brother-inlaw of Lou Del Tufo and Dick Brass. title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a Parisian update of a French icon of freedom reversed the identities of two women pictured on oversize posters titled ''Mariannes of Today'' and misstated the surname of one. The woman at the right in the display on the steps of the National Assembly building was Awa Khiar; the one in the center was Samira Cadasse, not Bellil.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Car Sales Fall At Hyundai
description: An off-again-on-again strike by workers at the Hyundai Motor Company led to a steep drop in sales in July. The company said it sold 40,208 vehicles in South Korea last month, 42 percent less than in the month a year earlier, and shipped 57,732 vehicles to foreign markets, down 40 percent. All Korean carmakers, including Kia, which is affiliated with Hyundai, as well as GM Daewoo, Renault-Samsung and Ssangyong, sold 247,339 vehicles in July, down from 276,269 a year earlier. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: KT Posts Net Profit
description: The KT Corporation, which operates most of the telephone service in South Korea, has reported a net profit of 325.5 billion won ($275.6 million) for April through June, down from a net profit of 488.5 billion won ($413.7 million) in the second quarter of 2002. Formerly Korea Telecom, KT reported sales of 2.95 trillion won in the second quarter, up 2.9 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: COURT BACKS REJECTION OF SOME SCHERING PATENT CLAIMS
description: Schering-Plough yesterday lost its appeal of a federal court decision that found certain patent claims on a derivative of the allergy drug Claritin were invalid. Claritin is battling generic brands after the expiration in December of the patent on its active ingredient. Schering-Plough sought to delay generic rivals by arguing that some patents on desloratadine -- the chemical Claritin becomes when it breaks down in the body -- should restrict copies until at least 2004. Last August, a New Jersey court ruled those claims were invalid. Yesterday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit upheld the ruling. Claritin sales in the second quarter were $112 million.

title: A Newspaper Reports Lindbergh Fathered 3 Children in Germany
description: Charles A. Lindbergh's sympathy for the Nazi regime in prewar Germany has long been a stain on his gilded legacy -- a puzzling detour in a life of heroic aviation and adventure.

title: Failed Students, Plenty of Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy's TV Drag Queen, Underneath the Eyeliner
description: THERE are no stairs in Platinette's home. She has learned her lesson.

title: Coke Makes Up With Burger King Over Rigged Test Of Frozen Drink
description: Sweeping aside one of the more embarrassing episodes it has faced recently, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had resolved its differences with Burger King over a rigged marketing test.

title: Time to Move
description: When he met with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel in Washington this week, President Bush urged him yet again to freeze expansion of Israeli settlements in the West Bank and Gaza, whose existence is a constant roadblock in peace negotiations, including the ''road map'' now in play. Judging from Mr. Sharon's noncommittal response, Mr. Bush's plea fell on deaf ears.

title: Sneaking a Trick In Early To Make an Unlikely Game
description: Two of the world's strongest teams faced off a week ago in the final of the Spingold Knockout in Long Beach, Calif. One of them included six world champions: Rose Meltzer, Kyle Larsen, Lew Stansby, Chip Martel, Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag. They were winners of the 2001 Bermuda Bowl in Paris, and the four last-named have other titles. They had eliminated the powerful Nickell team in the semifinal.

title: XEROX TO PAY $300 MILLION IN PENSION DISPUTE
description: The Xerox Corporation was ordered yesterday by a federal appeals court to pay about $300 million to settle a dispute over how it calculated retirement benefits for former employees. Xerox recorded expenses of $183 million, or 25 cents a share, in the first quarter in anticipation of losing its appeal. The company still needs to assess yesterday's ruling, a spokeswoman, Christa Carone, said. Xerox was sued by retirees in 2000 over the methods it used to determine payments to 25,000 employees. The United States District Court in Illinois ruled in favor of the retirees in October, and Xerox appealed. Any payment would come from the company's Retirement Income Guarantee Plan, which has denied any wrongdoing, the company said last year. Shares of Xerox fell 15 cents, to $10.65.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Bomb Suspect Kills Policeman
description: A suspected terrorist who was picked up by the police in Mombasa set off a grenade while in custody, killing one officer and seriously injuring another. The prisoner, who suffered severe injuries, had been seized in connection with the bombing of a tourist hotel near Mombasa in November, which investigators consider the work of Al Qaeda. Five men have been charged but investigators suspect that many accomplices are still at large. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: HAMILTON TO START NEW YORK CITY RACE
description: Tyler Hamilton, who overcame a broken collarbone to become the second American finisher behind Lance Armstrong in the Tour de France last month, will serve as the official starter tomorrow at the BMC Software New York City Cycling Championship.

title: Democrats Put On Defensive By G.O.P.'s Israel Policy
description: In the battle for Jewish votes, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader, undoubtedly scored a few points this week when, during a speech to members of the Israeli parliament, he proclaimed himself ''an Israeli at heart.''

title: Verizon Talks Bog Down as Deadline Nears
description: With a strike deadline set for tomorrow morning, Verizon and its two main unions again reported no progress yesterday in negotiations that were assisted by the top federal mediator.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: MALI: TOURISTS' KIDNAPPERS DEMAND RANSOM Officials in Mali have received a videotape of 14 European tourists abducted in the Sahara in which they appear to be in good health and refer to a ransom demand. The officials did not mention a figure, but N-TV television in Germany reported that an Islamic group was demanding $5.2 million for each hostage. The 14 tourists  9 Germans, 4 Swiss and a Dutchman  are believed to have been kidnapped by the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, a radical Islamic group. They were reported missing in February and March while traveling without local guides in Algeria. One hostage has died; the other 14 are now apparently being held across the border from Kidal, Mali. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Benitez Gives Yankees What They Wanted
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 1  It was a pressure situation and Armando Benitez was on the mound. This time, though, his New York team survived.

title: TELLABS TO CLOSE PLANT AND LAY OFF 325 WORKERS
description: Tellabs Inc. said yesterday that it would close a plant in Bolingbrook, Ill., and send the manufacturing work to the Sanmina-SCI Corporation, eliminating 325 jobs. The shift will cost Tellabs $90 million to $110 million in the third quarter. Tellabs, a maker of fiber optic network equipment, has been struggling as customers including Verizon Communications Inc. have cut spending on networks. Sanmina-SCI, based in San Jose, Calif., makes electronic products like printers and computers. Tellabs has been a Sanmina-SCI customer for more than 10 years. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Gift From a Loving Husband: Part of Himself

title: Leadership Needed on Liberia
description: All the elements of a desperately needed American intervention in Liberia are moving into place. Last night the United Nations authorized a multinational force, to be succeeded by blue-helmeted peacekeepers this fall. West African soldiers could take up positions in Liberia on Monday. The first two of three warships carrying 2,300 American troops arrive offshore this weekend. The only thing missing is an order from President Bush for those troops to go ashore and join the West Africans in trying to impose a cease-fire and stop the killing. While he hesitates, Liberians die.

title: Editorial Observer; The Modern Pickup Truck Retires From Work and Moves Into Town
description: Not that long ago, a pickup really wasn't a pickup unless it wore the raw patina of overwork. There might be a logging chain under the passenger seat, a pry-bar or a chain saw or a few sacks of grain in the bed. The springs in the driver's side of the bench seat were likely to be shot, and it went without saying that the transmission was manual. An owner tended to have mixed feelings watching a pickup age. It lost its showroom aura, but what it lost in polish it also gained in character. A farming cousin of mine, like many people, has solved the problem by having two pickups. One is rarely driven. Then there's an everyday pickup, which had an upended five-gallon bucket for the driver's seat while the seat springs were being fixed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Exports Gain
description: India's exports rose nearly 10.95 percent in June, helped by large orders from the United States and the European Union. Exports in the April-to-June quarter rose more than 11 percent, to $13.14 billion from $11.83 billion a year earlier. More than half of India's exports are to the United States and the European Union. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: A Bioethicist's Take on Genesis
description: Before Eve ate from the Tree of Knowledge, the serpent had already opened her eyes. Genesis tells us that she saw that the tree was ''good for food,'' that it was ''a delight to the eyes,'' and that it could ''make one wise.'' She already understood, that is, three human needs: the physical, the aesthetic and the intellectual, and that the tree promised satisfaction. Reason is at work; so is imagination. What she did not yet know was what it would mean to choose to transgress.

Thorn countered with something less, and that was that.

title: Capitol Hill Cross-Fire

The legislative blitz, engineered by the National Rifle Association, took the House Appropriations Committee by surprise last month. Yet it was approved 31 to 30, in bipartisan homage to the N.R.A.'s power to stir politicians' fear and obeisance.

title: ANADARKO PLANS ASSET SALES TO FINANCE DRILLING
description: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation will sell $100 million of assets by the end of the year to help finance its drilling program and reduce debt, its chief executive, Robert Allison, said yesterday. The asset sale had been planned, and properties to be sold are mostly offshore and ''pretty scattered,'' Mr. Allison said on a conference call with analysts and investors. Shares of Anadarko, an oil and natural gas producer, have lagged those of rivals in the last 18 months, prompting the board in March to replace John Seitz as chief executive with Mr. Allison, his predecessor. Anadarko said on Thursday that it would eliminate 400 jobs and cut annual costs by $100 million. Its shares fell $1.12, or 2.6 percent, to $42.68.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN TO SWAP UNITS WITH AFFILIATED
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation and Affiliated Computer Services Inc. have agreed to sell separate information-technology services units to each other. Under the arrangement announced yesterday, Lockheed will buy Affiliated's federal-government technology services business for $658 million, and Affiliated will buy Lockheed's commercial information technology business for about $107 million. The transaction will allow Affiliated to concentrate on the corporate market and Lockheed to focus on civilian agencies and the Defense Department. Shares of Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., closed at $51.52, down 82 cents. Affiliated shares closed at $48.20, down $1.35.

He spoke at the funeral of Ramchandradas Paramhans, 92, a Hindu holy man, in Ayodhya, where Hindus believe the god Rama was born. Mr. Paramhans had been associated with the temple project since 1949. A 16th-century mosque at the site was demolished by Hindus in December 1992, setting off widespread ethnic violence. title: Picturing a New Webster's
description: Just as extreme makeovers and the new and improved Demi Moore are having their cultural moment, so, too, in a much more understated way, is the latest update of Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary. Last month, the 11th edition made its debut, and along with the 10,000 new words and meanings (for a total of 165,000), 230 new illustrations were added (total: 725). The man responsible for deciding how to depict which nouns -- and, with the sole exception of rampant, every drawing illustrates a noun -- is Jeffrey Middleton, who rendered all the new images himself. Middleton says the advantage of the pen-and-ink pictures over photographs is that ''you can emphasize certain aspects; you can get closer to the abstraction of what the item is.'' Here he explains some of the thinking behind the dictionary's pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, , MARTIN
description: GREEN--Martin, age 89, native New Yorker, died late last week at home surrounded by loving friends and family. A lifetime of passionate devotion to the arts--dance, theatre, film; a few turns in vaudeville and theatre; edited a magazine of theatre and dance, Interlude; manager of Dance Cooperative; partner in Kamin Dance Bookshop. As a lieutenant in the Air Force in the Aleutians, managed radio station WXLT. Post-war worked at Columbia Pictures under the legendary Harry Cohn in development. Then director and actor in summer stock at Candlewood Lake; developed ''Theatre Guild'', ''Cadillac Hour'' and General Motors programs as assistant producer and casting director of the Metropolitan Opera Saturday broadcasts; producer/ editor of educational films for TV and radio at National Film Associates and Evergreen Films from 1956-68. Finally finding his special niche in men's clothing manufacturing as coordinator of sales and PR. His Air Force uniform served as the original models for a company that introduced them as contemporary clothing. An avid art collector; world traveler with friends in every country; and dedicated supporter of dancers and dance companies, serving on several Boards. He is survived by his sister, Cynthia Navaretta, and loving nieces, grand nieces, nephews and a multitude of friends. A Celebration of Life Service will be held in early September. >>AD#

title: 'Morningside Heights'
description: This neighborhood was always middle-class and urban. The advent of the subway at the start of the twentieth century transformed the countryside so rapidly that less than a decade after the stations opened, the fields were gone and the massive, sedate apartment buildings that you see today already lined the streets. They were grand places, designed to persuade prosperous New York families that their bourgeois dignities could be preserved as well in an apartment as in a brownstone row house with a stoop. The building at 635 West 117th Street was similar to scores of others built around the same time, and, like them, it filled with tenants as soon as it was completed, in 1906. It had twelve stories, with four ample apartments per floor, each divided into a living and dining room, several bedrooms, two bathrooms, all large and airy, plus a small library, and, behind the kitchen, a miniature bedroom and bathroom for the live-in maid. During the Depression, the landlords carved most of the apartments into two or three, creating the ten to twelve on a floor that you find now. The cut-up layouts made no architectural sense, but in those hard times the new tenants could not afford to be choosy. Only a few apartments in the building retain the original floor plan, with the cramped kitchen and tiny sleeping nook where a lonely girl spent her days and nights in service to the family living in comfort in the other rooms.

title: Errand Express
description: An extra set of hands but not full-time help: that's the concept behind Taken to Task, a three-month-old temp service that supplies personal assistants in Manhattan. For $30 an hour ($24 if you book a solid day), temps, some of whom are at right, attend to such boring-but-essential errands as dry-cleaning, gift-buying and picking up film. Clients include celebrities with more money than time: Taken to Task (www.takentotask.com) organized a move for the actress Parker Posey, now ensconced in the East Village; haggled over the price of a first edition of ''Great Expectations'' on behalf of Jimmy Fallon, the comedian; and cleaned out some closets for John Lyons, the movie producer. Heather Smith, an owner, says Taken to Task is the human equivalent of TiVo, springing into action at the user's convenience. And like TiVo, the temps don't ask questions. ''Sometimes the problem with a full-time helper is that you get to know them so well, you feel uncomfortable asking them to do anything really personal,'' she said. And given the recent popularity of celebrity-assistant tell-all fiction, maybe hiring workers by the hour is the best way for well-known New Yorkers to keep their private lives from becoming pay-per-view. He was suspended from performing autopsies in February after a botched autopsy led to false murder charges against a man whose wife had died. He had been the coroner for the two counties since 1995. In a letter released on Tuesday, Dr. John Krolikowski, the acting state medical examiner, told Dr. Gross that he had failed to pass a series of remedial examinations and supervised autopsies. We support the school system's basic aim, and we obviously deplore the homophobic response that creation of the school has unleashed in some quarters. Still, we cannot condone the concept of establishing a special school specifically for students based on their sexual orientation.

title: The Real Hollywood Novel
description: Usually there's nothing less authentic than novels that promise to tell us the truth about Hollywood, especially the ones that mingle real people with fictional characters. But Robert Cort is no Jackie Collins, lounging in leopard prints by a pool in Beverly Hills and churning out pulp like ''Hollywood Wives.'' Cort has produced 52 films, including ''Runaway Bride'' and ''Mr. Holland's Opus,'' and he clearly knows his way around what Collins and her competitors invariably call Tinseltown. He has put his knowledge to good use in ACTION! (Random House, $24.95), a sprawling book that manages to be both entertaining and smart. ''Action!'' traces three generations of the Jastrows, a family of filmmakers. It opens in 1948 when Harry Jastrow, the most powerful lawyer in Hollywood, fails to persuade the Supreme Court to overturn a court ruling against the distribution monopoly of the five biggest studios. The story then shifts to his son, AJ, whose life is dedicated to gaining the power in Hollywood that his father lost. Along the way, father and son are taught the intricacies of the town's politics by everyone from a bitter Bing Crosby and a rebellious Steve McQueen to a sex-mad Romy Schneider and the comedian Sam Kinison. AJ's enemies are worthy opponents: the agent Mike Ovitz; the studio head who helped do in his father; even AJ's own mother and son. Unlike his father, however, AJ fights the power and prevails. Cort does succumb to a Hollywood ending, but after so many pages of quirky realism, his way of saying ''Cut!'' actually works. Dana Kennedy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RACKMAN, , HONEY
description: RACKMAN--Honey. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the passing of our special friend and benefactress, Honey Rackman, beloved wife of Michael Rackman and devoted daughter-in-law of our revered Chancellor Rabbi Emanuel Rackman and Ruth Rackman, z''l. Honey Rackman possessed an indomitable spirit that extended to the practice and teaching of chesed for the poor, isolated and oppressed. She was an outstanding leader in Orthodox feminist circles and deeply committed to the plight of agunot, exemplified by her tireless activities on their behalf. At Bar-Ilan University, she was a long-time supporter of the Exodus Student Program, took pride in the progress of Ethopian students that she and her husband sponsored and hosted events to foster the participation of others in this important effort. She was a frequent visitor to the Bar-Ilan campus where she enjoyed meeting and interacting with students. She set a wonderful example for all to emulate. May the family derive solace from inspiring memories and be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Aharon Dahan, Chairman Global Board of Trustees Melvin Stein, President American Board of Trustees Professor Moshe Kaveh, President Bar-Ilan University Brigadier General (Retired) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University

description: McDERMOTT -- Keith Pa trick, devoted father of Fiona and Vanessa and widower of his beloved Sylvia, passed away on July 23rd at his home in Greenwich, CT. The only son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward McDermott of Johannesburg, South Africa, Keith McDermott was born in England on July 23, 1938 and grew up in the former Rhodesia and South Africa. After finishing university and his national service in the U.K., he followed in the family tradition of working in the mining industry in South Africa and London. He also held several positions in international banking and finance in London, New York and Beirut. Keith McDermott will forever be remembered, by his family and friends, as a wonderful father, loving husband, great gentleman and scholar, loyal friend, good-humored sportsman as well as an esteemed and affectionate mentor to many of the next generation. description: When Liberian citizens late last month deposited the corpses of their friends and loved ones, killed by rebel shells, at the gate of the American Embassy compound in the capital of Monrovia, they were not only issuing a desperate plea for salvation but also making a statement of responsibility: it is you, the United States, who must answer our prayers. But why? Because freed American slaves settled in Liberia 180 years ago? Do these ties of history impose a special obligation? Can the dim colonial past exert a tug even on the hardheaded policy makers in the Bush administration?

title: Healed Golfer Hopes Game Is Mended, Too
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., Aug. 2  For David Sutherland, arriving at a golf course feeling healthy feels like a victory.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 13 about the Orkney Islands of Scotland referred incorrectly to the location of the Highland Park distillery in Kirkwall. At least one other distillery, Mackmyra in Valbo, Sweden, is farther north; Highland Park is not the world's most northerly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCHEN, , JERROLD I.
description: HIRSCHEN--Jerrold I. Beloved husband of Carole Slater-Hirschen. Loving father of Jill Hirschen. Adored son of Miriam Hirschen. Service will take place Tuesday, August 5, 2003, 10 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St, NY, NY. For information, ''The Riverside,'' 212-362-6600. >>AD#

title: Meghan Norling, Benjamin Huebner
description: Meghan Dildine Norling, a daughter of Barbara Dildine and Peter Norling of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Benjamin Thomas Huebner, the son of Jean and Tom Huebner of Rutland, Vt. The Rev. Donald W. McKinney performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn. The Rev. Christopher Powell, an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Executive Life; Business Lessons for a Law School C.E.O.
description: AS more than a thousand lawyers-in-training head for George Washington University Law School for another year studying torts, antitrust and contracts, the school is emerging from a five-year turnaround effort with better qualified students, a faculty with more visibility and a spruced-up campus.

title: There's Indian Point, and Counterpoints; Battle Over Nuclear Plant Shifts From Policy to Politics and Lawsuits
description: If there was ever a moment when it seemed possible to force the closing of the Indian Point nuclear power plant, it was after two planes flew into the World Trade Center.

title: Iraqis Struggle to Retrieve Goods From G.I.'s
description: After the war, American soldiers referred to Iraqi looters as ''Ali Babas.'' Now, the name is more commonly used by Iraqis to describe the soldiers.

title: Giants Devise a Way to Gain More From Dayne
description: Ron Dayne longs to be a workhorse running back, a guy who never, or rarely, comes out of a game. But because Tiki Barber is the unquestioned star of the Giants' backfield, Dayne has been used in spot duty, most often in short-yardage situations.

title: Coffee With the Old Cat Or the Lush Life Uptown?
description: The Hungarian Pastry Shop, as any of its hordes of regulars will eagerly tell you, is a Morningside Heights institution. Would-be philosophers, artists and intellectuals cram themselves into rickety wooden chairs, pile their books, laptops, croissants - and, of course, coffee - on rickety wooden tables, and sit discussing everything from politics to culture to sex for hours on end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, , SIDNEY
description: COHEN--Sidney. On August 1, 2003. Beloved husband of Bernice and devoted father of Diane and Edward Koones. Adoring grandfather of Gabrielle Koones and loyal brother to Bert Sossin and Jean Wolin, and the late Mary Goldberg and Frances Keenberg. He served his country as a captain in WWII and retired as Senior Vice President of Foodarama Shop-Rite. He dedicated his time to the betterment of others, including Deborah Hospital, Religious Zionists of America and Temple Beth Shalom in Livingston. He will be remembered always for his great love of life and people. He will be missed deeply for his kindness, generosity and humor. Services will be held 11 AM, Sunday, August 3, at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ. Contributions may be sent to Temple Beth Shalom, Livingston, NJ. >>AD#

title: Affirmative Action Foe's Latest Effort Complicates California Recall Vote
description: Though he is 64 and insists he does not ''want to do this the rest of my life,'' Ward Connerly is at it again, turning California into a laboratory for his contentious views on race and injecting some uncertainty into the already topsy-turvy recall election on Gov. Gray Davis.

title: ARTS & ENTERTAINMENT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212)556-7219; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Page Two: July 27 - Aug. 2; For the First Time, Progress on Ozone
description: NO global environmental problem captured the world's attention as quickly as the erosion of the ozone layer, a molecular veil that shields Earth from ultraviolet radiation. Recognition that most of the damage came from a group of synthetic chemicals -- chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's -- led in 1987 to the passage of a treaty, the Montreal Protocol, phasing out the substances.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Nasdaq Gives Acclaim A 180-Day Reprieve

title: The Probability That a Real-Estate Agent Is Cheating You (and Other Riddles of Modern Life)
description: The most brilliant young economist in America -- the one so deemed, at least, by a jury of his elders -- brakes to a stop at a traffic light on Chicago's south side. It is a sunny day in mid-June. He drives an aging green Chevy Cavalier with a dusty dashboard and a window that doesn't quite shut, producing a dull roar at highway speeds.

title: Erin Carroll, Evan Halper
description: Erin Catherine Carroll, a daughter of Enrica C. Carroll and Dr. James P. Carroll of Longboat Key, Fla., was married last evening in Radnor, Pa., to Evan Scott Halper, the son of Leslie and Robert Halper of New York. Rabbi Bernard Perelmuter officiated at the Willows, a house and grounds owned by Radnor Township. The Rev. Christopher C. Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Valor of 6 Lost Firefighters Is Celebrated 25 Years Later
description: At the corner of Ocean Avenue and Avenue Y in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, next to a Staples Office Superstore, is a little street sign that says Firemen's Way. Many people who pass by now do not know why it is there.

title: Bird Call
description: THE Black Duck on Sunset represents a considerable departure for Cape May dining, and a welcome one.

title: Tough New York Cops, Just Doing Their Jobs
description: AN HOUR TO KILL

title: Adapting Dostoyevsky? Sure, Add a Few Gags
description: LAST May in New York, the Lithuanian director Kama Ginkas encouraged a man auditioning for the lead role in an adaptation of a Chekhov short story to be more fearless in trying to seduce the female character in the scene. Minutes later, the actor was making faces at her from a ledge outside the window of the rehearsal room on the 22nd floor of a building on Eighth Avenue. He got the woman's attention but not the part.

title: Ideas & Trends; Iran's Nuclear Program: For Electricity or a Bomb?
description: THIS summer, international attention has been focusing on nuclear sites in Iran. Kenneth Brill, the American representative at the International Atomic Energy Agency, has accused Iran of ''aggressively pursuing a nuclear weapons program,'' and President Bush has warned that ''we will not tolerate the construction of a nuclear weapon'' in Iran. Iran is building a string of nuclear plants, and the International Atomic Energy Agency has criticized the country for failing to report nuclear material.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUSH, , RODERICK MCLEOD
description: BRUSH--Roderick McLeod, of Darien, CT, died peacefully at home on July 26, 2003. Mr. Brush, born in Greenwich, CT in February 1920, was a U.S. Navy officer and pilot and received the Air Medal for Combat Service in WW II, began his career in textile sales management in 1947, became Vice President of Cannon Mills in 1959, retiring in 1985, and thereafter was retained as a consultant to Charles Owen Manufacturing. Mr. Brush was a widower, Mary Harriett Bell Brush, his wife of 47 years, died in 1995. Two adult children survive: Roderick McLeod Brush Jr. of Stamford, CT and Susan Bell Brush Clark of Charleston, SC. A memorial service will be held at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT on Friday, August 8, 2003 at 11:00 AM. Following the service, the children will welcome friends and relatives at Woodway County Club, Darien, CT. >>AD#

title: Loss of Good Feelings Leads to Incorporation
description: The incorporation of yet additional villages on Long Island will produce more than just additional bureaucracy and expense -- it will produce more bad local government.

title: What It Took to Be the Angel of Times Square
description: LAST month, flocks of theatergoers took part in ''The Angel Project,'' the strange, solitary scavenger hunt conceived by the British director Deborah Warner that kicked off this summer's Lincoln Center Festival on July 7 and closed it last Sunday. Using a guidebook, the audience -- one by one, as decreed by Ms. Warner -- combed parts of the city looking for angels, each played by one of 40 performers at nine different habitats created by Ms. Warner and Tom Pye, an installation designer. The angels took various forms, from the classic winged variety (haunting the Liberty Theater on West 42nd Street) to a passed-out slacker seraph (no wings, no worries) in a beached rowboat on Roosevelt Island.

title: Riskier Vanguard Funds, But Moderation, Please
description: The Vanguard Group announced last week that it would expand its offerings of index funds and add 10 sector funds.

title: Art Falls Victim to Smash and Grab in Austin
description: Who's stealing the art?

title: Corrections
description: A capsule guide on July 13 with an article about surfing on the North Shore of Oahu misstated the Web address for the JW Marriott Ihilani Resort and Spa. It is www.ihilani.com.

title: Dean and the Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: BackTalk; Walsh Network Produces Diversity as Well as Success
description: As the National Football League's recent $200,000 fine against the Detroit Lions demonstrates, there is continuing pressure on owners to hire more coaches who are members of minority groups. Although two-thirds of the league's players are black, there are only three African-American head coaches. The lawyers Cyrus Mehri and Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., who have won multimillion-dollar discrimination settlements against some of America's leading corporations, have served notice that they will sue the N.F.L. unless substantial progress is made.

title: Death Toll Rises as Bombings Escalate Chechnya's War
description: Vera Khalitskaya's daughter-in-law, Yelena, lay buried today somewhere in the shattered wreckage of a military hospital here, along with perhaps 17 other people still missing, victims of the latest of the suicide bombings that have struck Russia over the spring and summer.

title: Stacey Riegelhaupt, Kevin Bloomfield
description: Stacey Vanessa Riegelhaupt, the daughter of Edward I. Riegelhaupt of New York and the late Joyce Firstenberg Riegelhaupt, was married yesterday at her family's summer house in Plainfield, Mass., to Kevin Matthew Bloomfield, a son of Mary and Roger Bloomfield of Colorado Springs. Peter T. Schneider, a friend of the bride's family, was granted permission by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the way American embassy design reflects the image of the United States misspelled the middle name of one architect and the surname of another. The architects, who have both designed embassies, were Edward Durell Stone (not Durrell) and Max Abramovitz (not Abramowitz). A picture caption with the article referred incorrectly to the building shown in London. It was the American Embassy, not the British Embassy.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Industrial Buildings Are Looking More Classy
description: DRIVING along Long Island's highways today, it is often difficult to distinguish a new industrial building from a prime new office building.

description: To the Editor:

title: N. Korea Seeks to Exclude Outspoken U.S. Policy Maker From Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 3  North Korea sought to exclude one of the most outspoken United States policy-makers today from multilateral talks on its nuclear weapons program as American, South Korean and Japanese officials prepared to coordinate on a united policy with which to confront the North at the table.

title: Blending Cultures
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading List
description: AT Cornell University, 3,500 incoming freshmen must sit down this summer and read ''Antigone,'' prepping for a group chat at orientation. Not everyone is thrilled. On hearing the selection, Mark Harrison, a columnist for the campus newspaper, wrote that required reading instills ''hatred for academia'' before freshmen even arrive in Ithaca. ''Let's face it,'' he said, ''summer reading just smacks of high school.'' Nonetheless, it has become as common an orientation experience as the Outward Bound trek. Here's what they're reading:

title: The Ultimate in Parental Supervision
description: Few people who have ever held jobs will deny that some bosses can be complex and difficult. But problems in the manager-worker relationship may be ratcheted up to dizzying, though occasionally delightful, levels when the boss is a member of the family.

title: Unequal Taxes on 2 Attached Houses
description: Q. I own two four-family brick houses in Washington Heights. The houses are attached and are mirror images. They were gut-rehabilitated in the late 1990's. On one house, I pay $6,149 a year in real estate taxes, while on the other I pay $10,368. I appealed this discrepancy to the New York City Tax Commission, but the appeal was denied with no explanation. I researched the taxes on other four-family properties in the neighborhood, and, to my surprise, they pay less than $5,000 a year in taxes. What can I do to lower these taxes? . . . Carlos Medina, Manhattan.

title: Life Is Good if You're a Nerd
description: IN his 44 years, Jim Garcia, lead singer and bass player for The Nerds, one of the more established Jersey Shore bar bands has never had a day job.

title: Nothing Random
description: For a guy who seems to view books as just another commodity, Peter Olson shows a remarkable lack of understanding of comparative commodity values (Lynn Hirschberg, July 20). Asked about the 30 or so writers who left Random House when he fired Ann Godoff, he shrugged it off, saying, ''We have thousands of writers.''

title: Furyk Takes the Lead, But Many Stay Close
description: Having already won the United States Open, Jim Furyk hopes to make a superb year even better.

title: Suzan Atesoglu, Michael Brassard
description: Suzan Atesoglu, a daughter of Jane Bentz Atesoglu and Dr. H. Sonmez Atesoglu of Potsdam, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael James Brassard, the son of Barbara A. Durkin and Michael G. Brassard, both of Hannawa Falls, N.Y. Kevin Patnode, a town justice in Plattsburgh, N.Y., officiated at the Whiteface Club, a resort in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Hot Off the Turnpike, a New Cool
description: LIKE any good rock star, Chris Collingwood of Fountains of Wayne arrived at his ''Late Night With David Letterman'' gig last Wednesday with an entourage. But as a member of a band that champions losers and traffics in tacky New Jersey iconography, he chooses not to stand on rock-star convention. Mr. Collingwood, a singer and guitarist, showed up surrounded not by vacant-eyed women in small clothes but with his devoted wife, his proud brother and his adoring father. During the rehearsal, Mr. Collingwood's father asked a mystified Paul Shaffer, the musical director of the show, if it was all right to take pictures.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about mushroom hunting referred incorrectly to joint walks held by the Connecticut-Westchester Mycological Association and the New York Mycological Society. The two groups indeed still hold a joint walk each fall, according to David Rose, president of the Connecticut-Westchester group.

title: At Two Rallies, Protesters Accuse Police in Killings
description: As protests go, the groups that gathered in two New Jersey cities yesterday were small, a few dozen people at most. The contrasts between them were stark -- a vociferous crowd in Newark, a somber one in Union City -- but their aims were similar: to accuse the police of brutality and of murdering two young men.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page picture of the Milwaukee Art Museum in the Travel section today carries an erroneous credit. It is by Erol Reyal.

title: Trading Lamb for a Sheepskin
description: JOHN JAMISON figures his daughter Rachel's junior and senior years of college cost him roughly 300 lambs. A father of three, he paid for a portion of her English degree from Washington & Jefferson College with cuts of lamb from his 210-acre sheep farm in Latrobe, Pa. As a member of the Green Apple Barter Service, a fee-based barter bank in Pittsburgh with 1,000 members, he had racked up $30,000 worth of credits by throwing his naturally fed lambs into the pot; restaurants took his meat; he picked tuition credits; the college chose free advertising offered by other companies.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Come to the Cabaret

title: Foreign or Domestic? Not All Taxes on Dividends Are Equal
description: SOME international stock mutual funds are going to great lengths to avoid the withholding tax that many foreign governments levy on dividends paid to foreigners. But those funds' cures may be worse than the disease.

title: Taking a Temperature By Squeezing The Trigger
description: JACQUES TORRES says a MiniTempFS thermometer is indispensable for tempering chocolate in his Brooklyn shop. Thomas Keller, the owner and chef of the French Laundry, a destination restaurant in Yountville, Calif., in the Napa Valley, uses it to assure himself that his food is served at a temperature that delivers optimum taste.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: ACTION!

title: DataBank; Investors Turn Jittery as Interest Rates Rise
description: The three main stock market indexes declined last week, as investors worried about rising interest rates and uneven corporate earnings.

title: As Numbers of Screeners Fall, Airport Lines Grow
description: PASSENGER traffic at the airports is rising a bit, because of the season and the end of major combat in Iraq, but the number of security screeners is falling, as the Transportation Security Administration ''rightsizes'' itself to fit budget mandates. One result is longer lines at the checkpoints.

title: Robertson Is Approaching the Preseason at Full Speed
description: The tsunami that carried Dewayne Robertson from his Memphis neighborhood to the Tokyo Dome for his first professional football game has subsided.

title: Giving a Fig
description: My friend George Peterkin Jr. is fig obsessed. He lives in Houston and travels all the time, but from mid-June until mid-July, when the figs are ripe on his trees, he refuses to leave them. He can't. For one thing, somebody has to shoot the squirrels when they get after them. (The birds are less of a problem. A pair of territorial mockingbirds keep the other birds away, and George estimates that they can only eat ''maximum 5 percent'' of the crop by themselves. ''I love those mockingbirds,'' he says.) Also, the more than 50 people on his fig list would be extremely upset.

title: Private Gifts Bring a Public College to Town
description: Amid the bounty in the desert, awash in golf courses and gated communities, the absence of a university was like a leak in the well, draining away what little youth the area had.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: Why People Still Starve
description: Turning hunger into an indictment of the West is rather cynical. I don't doubt that the West, and the United States in particular, could do more, but the question is how? Nobody likes to see people starving, but huge amounts of aid are squandered around the world. Why send aid that is wasted? To clear our conscience? I'd submit that withholding aid until specific guidelines are met may seem heartless, but the benefits outweigh the costs. Some people will surely die until the situations are sorted out, but many more will not have to suffer a similar fate. In order for these people to eat and rise from poverty, the aid must be applied properly and their governments must be held accountable.

title: Butterflies Aren't Free, Nassau Finds
description: IF they could read a balance sheet, the flocks of painted ladies, tiger swallowtails, skip jackets and spangled fritillaries that make their home on Long Island would be as anxious as Nassau County residents awaiting the annual county budget proposal, which is due from Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive, on Sept. 15. That's because an extensive butterfly garden is scheduled to be planted in Eisenhower Park by the Nassau County branch of Cornell Cooperative Extension -- if enough money is allocated in the budget to support the effort.

title: A Landlord's Lot Is Sometimes Not an Easy One
description: IT was a blistering Saturday afternoon in late August, and while the rest of Manhattan was relaxing at a beach somewhere, I was mopping up water as it spurted from a hole in the second-floor ceiling of a small apartment building in Murray Hill. The tenants were away, and by the time I had gotten there the water had had plenty of time to ruin a lovely parquet floor, while also taking down part of the ceiling. Moreover, every emergency plumbing service was booked.

title: Editorial Observer; The Middle East Cease-Fire Feels Ephemeral
description: As the summer sun sinks into the Mediterranean in a pink flare, the patios of Gaza City's seaside restaurants fill with chatter and smoke. Weddings are common in this season and the beach hotels are booked with them. There is gaiety and excitement in the air, a rare intrepid feeling due to a month-old cease-fire between the Palestinian armed factions and Israel. No one need fear Israeli military action on these warm, lazy nights.

title: Brickyard May as Well Be Gordon's Backyard
description: Not long after Jeff Gordon moved with his family to Pittsboro, Ind., from California, they took a 14-mile pilgrimage to the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Any boy in pursuit of a racing career had to see the Brickyard.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/New Dorp; Convenience Near Staten Island's Shore
description: ''WE spent a year and a half looking for a home, but we kept coming back to New Dorp,'' in part because of its convenient location, said Kevin Carney, who bought a five-bedroom ranch on Jacques Street in November 2001 for $360,000.

title: Donna Hanover, Edwin Oster
description: Donna Hanover, an actress and television host, is to be married this evening to Edwin A. Oster, a lawyer, in Tarrytown, N.Y. Judge Denise Cote of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York will officiate.

title: The Photo Booth: A Portrait Studio Of One's Own
description: WHEN the self-portrait studio came to the amusement park in the late 1920's, people were appropriately amused. When it came to the railroad station, travelers considered it as good as a vacation, and when it came to Woolworth's, people were glad to find it cheap. It was called a photo booth. Just a little room with a lens and nobody but you in it to tell you to smile or to make you self-conscious, it was a quick chance for some narcissistic fun while no one was looking, and it had an aura of secrecy and daring. In 1927 a photo magazine said: ''You need no longer be dull in Boston if you have 25 cents and a face. Go to the new Photomaton, in Filene's basement, some noon and see how romance and adventure have been injected into the hitherto grim business of having your picture taken.''

title: Ideas & Trends: Chain Reaction; Facing A Second Nuclear Age
description: THIS week, ten minutes by car south of Omaha, Neb., the United States Strategic Command is holding a little-advertised meeting at which the Bush administration is to solidify its plans for acquiring a new generation of nuclear arms. Topping the wish list are weapons meant to penetrate deep into the earth to destroy enemy bunkers. The Pentagon believes that more than 70 nations, big and small, now have some 1,400 underground command posts and sites for ballistic missiles and weapons of mass destruction.

title: Catch a Wave And You've Got A Documentary
description: ''HE'S not coming back,'' hisses the F.B.I. agent Johnny Utah (Keanu Reeves, possibly the only actor who could get away with playing a character whose name sounds like a pro baller's online pseudonym) at the end of ''Point Break'' (1991). Then he watches his quarry (Patrick Swayze) surf away on a monster wave that must have been rolled by Neptune himself. Utah's line may just typify how real surfers feel after seeing wave-rider movies. Surfing seems almost impossible to ruin on the big screen -- it's so photogenic that it's hard to believe that color film wasn't invented just to capture it.

title: Cuba Tour Companies Add New (Last) Trips
description: Time is running out for groups offering educational trips to Cuba. Since 1999, when the United States government began licensing companies to take groups on people-to-people educational exchanges, an estimated 50,000 Americans have participated in study trips to Cuba. But in March, the Treasury Department announced that it would no longer grant or renew educational-travel licenses unrelated to academic coursework. Many permits have already expired; the rest will run out by early next year.

title: 'Gettysburg'
description: John Beauchamp Jones, the observant, gossipy clerk in the War Department in Richmond, took note in his diary under date of May 15, 1863, that General Lee had come down from his headquarters on the Rappahannock and was conferring at the Department. "Lee looked thinner, and a little pale," Jones wrote. "Subsequently he and the Secretary of War were long closeted with the President." (That same day another Richmond insider, President Davis's aide William Preston Johnston, was writing more optimistically, "Genl Lee is here and looking splendidly & hopeful.")

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: LUCCA

title: Knives Out, Everyone, It's Time for Truffle Class
description: Summer in New York is hardly a season for smelling. But last Wednesday evening, 16 men and women dared to inhale deeply.

title: Milwaukee
description: Milwaukee may not be the city that made beer famous, but it comes close. For generations it was a center of German, Scandinavian and Polish cultures, with all the beer and sausage that come with them.

title: Playing the Horses (and the Horse People, Too)
description: I WAS sitting with my horse trainer outside her office at Santa Anita racetrack. It was 101 degrees, and we were waiting. It was still and quiet. Most of the other trainers had already moved their horses to Del Mar for the summer meet. Between her barn and the one next door, a groom was walking a sleek mahogany bay colt. They paused at the water bucket, and the colt took a drink, then turned his narrow, elegant blaze and his large, expressive eyes toward us. ''That's the big horse,'' said Alexis. ''That's their horse.''

title: Rebecca West's Mexico
description: SURVIVORS IN MEXICO

title: New York's New Approach
description: IN the never-ending struggle waged between the forces of traditionalism and of progressive education over the soul of the American classroom, the former has been gaining a decisive advantage in recent years. Reading experts have coalesced around the principle that step-by-step phonics instruction works best, especially with children at risk of failure. Los Angeles, Houston and other major cities have adopted a highly structured, phonics-based system called Open Court. The No Child Left Behind Act, President Bush's most prized achievement in domestic policy, restricts federal financing to classroom methods backed by scientific research, which in practice favors phonics.

title: 'Tales of Grabowski'
description: This, he said to himself, you push away.

title: I.Q. and A.
description: The Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales, the oldest English-language I.Q. test (1916), has undergone a major update in its fifth edition, new this year from Riverside Publishing. In recognition of a more diverse population, it now tests each of five ability areas nonverbally as well as verbally. It also covers the entire life span, with national norms for scoring set by test takers up to age 90 (not, as before, up to only their mid-20's). Age matters. ''Fluid reasoning, visual-spatial processing, working memory, quantitative reasoning peak in the 20's and 30's and then begin to decline,'' says Andrew D. Carson, a senior project director at the company. What improves with age? Knowledge. It peaks in the mid-50's. ''It's important as you get older to realize that knowledge is the part that can continue to accrue and improve,'' he says. Below are sample items, moderate to difficult.

title: Frugal Plus
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Portland With Umbrella Unopened,'' (July 20), I know I would have enjoyed the ''Grease'' sing-along with Hope Reeves and her friends in Portland, Ore., but I feel that people who were looking for some insights into a ''frugal'' trip to Portland would have come away short.

title: Cold-Water Plunge Perks Up Cut Flowers
description: IHAVE spent many a happy hour picking and arranging flowers. It is one of the most compelling reasons to garden. Thankfully, picking encourages flowers to rebloom. Left to their own devices, they quickly go to seed.

title: Chip Designer Bucks a Trend and Turns a Profit
description: THE global slump in electronics continues to stretch out, but apparently no one has told the Standard Microsystems Corporation in Hauppauge.

title: Bad Boy Executive Gives P. Diddy A New Name: 'Doll'
description: The word ''mentor'' doesn't necessarily pop out if you are trying to describe Sean (P. Diddy) Combs. ''Hip-hop artist'' or ''party animal,'' maybe. But mentor is how he is viewed by Francesca Spero, senior vice president at Mr. Combs's Bad Boy Entertainment, his record-label and management company. She credits him with her latest milestone in the music world.

description: To the Editor:

title: What an Artist Puts Up on His Own Walls
description: AFRINGE benefit of being an artist is that you get to trade artworks with your peers. If you are an artist as famous as Sol LeWitt, the grand pooh-bah of Minimalism and Conceptual art, then you get to trade with other important artists, leading, over the course of a career, to a really amazing collection of works.

title: Burying Himself In a Good Book
description: Popularity isn't everything. Besides, when you think nobody likes you, you can always go home and bury yourself in a good book.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; A Commercial Space Overhang in Fairfield County
description: FOR the last two years, commercial leasing brokers in Fairfield County have not been subscribing to the popular notion that there are no pessimists in real estate. Vacancy rates around the county have risen into the upper teens and even, in some places, to the depressing low- to upper 20's of the 1980's.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWYER, , JAMES J. (JERRY)
description: DWYER--James J. (Jerry). On July 31, 2003 after a courageous battle against cancer. Chief of Pensions NYC Law Department. Loving husband to Christine. Devoted father to Kevin and Kristin. Beloved son of Mary and Jimmie. Adored son-inlaw of Stephanie Ball. Dear brother of Mary Agnes Del Tufo, and Regina. Brother-inlaw of Lou Del Tufo and Dick Brass. He was greatly loved and will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Family will receive friends Saturday, 79PM and Sunday, 3-5 and 79PM, Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, NYC. Mass of Christian burial, Church of the Epiphany (Second Ave at 22 Street) Monday, 10:00 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Goldstein Fund for Esophageal Cancer Research, C/O MSKCC, PO Box 27106, New York, New York 10087.

title: Nothing Random
description: Readers shouldn't worry about the book business perishing because Random House has adopted the strategy of combining mass production with mass marketing. That will simply create new opportunities for small and medium-size firms -- maybe even aggressive university presses -- to move into the niche for good books. It happened in beer. It will happen in books. And that, thank heavens, should keep Ann Godoff busy for many years.

title: Undisclosed Financial Ties Prompt Reproval of Doctor
description: Two scientists are raising concerns about an article in a medical journal that described experimental treatments for depression because an author did not disclose his significant financial ties to three therapies that he mentioned favorably.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASSMAN, , WALLACE
description: GLASSMAN -- Wallace. On August 2, 2003, at age 78. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving and devoted father of Jonathan and father-in-law of Randi. Ecstatic and proud grandfather of Joshua. Funeral services 1 PM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Family will be sitting shiva at 15 Fenimore Rd., New Rochelle, NY. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RESCHKE, , DR. STEPHEN E.
description: RESCHKE--Dr. Stephen E. Of Rego Park, NY. Died on July 30th at age 62 after a battle with brain cancer. An industrial organizational psychologist, he was a graduate of the Ramaz School, the City College of New York, and Case Western Reserve University. A native New Yorker, he was the son of the late Dr. Morris and Selma Reschke. title: Bzios, Rio's Playground In the Sun
description: FOR all its obvious appeal, Rio de Janeiro has some drawbacks as a vacation destination these days, particularly for travelers looking for an escape from urban anxieties like Rio's continuing problem with crime. As an alternative, look no farther than the line of cars heading out of town as Cariocas, the city's residents, seek a getaway themselves. Their destination is Bzios, an amoeba-shaped peninsula two and a half hours north of Rio best known for the nearly two dozen beaches nestled in its curves and coves -- some less than a hundred feet wide, others more than a mile long, but each with a personality of its own.

description: Kiara Maria Vigil was married yesterday to Matthias Malek on Sankaty Beach in Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Tim W. Jensen, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: A Reluctant Reunion

By ''my class,'' I mean one of the fifth grades in Public School 2 on the Lower East Side, where I taught when John F. Kennedy was president.

title: Citing Intelligence Reports, U.S. Closes Visa Loophole
description: The Bush administration announced yesterday that it was immediately suspending two visa exemption programs that permit foreign travelers to enter the United States temporarily, a move that administration officials said was prompted by intelligence reports suggesting that Al Qaeda was planning to exploit the programs to hijack passenger planes.

title: Hip-Hop Is a Guest At the Indian Wedding
description: EVERY now and then, a song bursts into the atmosphere with its own gravitational force and manages to pull even the most resistant music fans out of their usual orbits. Run-DMC's cover of Aerosmith's ''Walk This Way'' did it in 1986, winning over rock skeptics and persuading hip-hop fans that good beats are where you find them. Nirvana's ''Smells Like Teen Spirit'' did in 1991, convincing millions of punk, pop and metal partisans that they could find common ground. And now, ''Beware of the Boys (Mundian to Bach Ke)'' by Panjabi MC and Jay-Z is doing the same thing for the hip-hop nation and members of the Indian diaspora.

title: Corrections
description: An article July 20 about New York sports fans, which said that many of them ignored last year's World Series, gave an outdated name for the Series winner. Since 1996 it has been the Anaheim Angels, not the California Angels. The article also gave an incorrect date for the last time, before this June, that the Yankees visited Wrigley Field. It was 1938, not 1936.

title: Page Two: July 27 - Aug. 2 -- The Week Ahead; THE CONGRESSIONAL AUGUST
description: Congress is gone until September, but lawmakers might still be heard from. Leaders of both parties are urging their members to hit certain messages with constituents. Republicans want their members to talk about the emerging Medicare drug plan and prospects of an improving economy. Democrats will be focusing on joblessness and the need to invest more in homeland protection. Carl Hulse

title: Hamilton Trades Bike For a Starter's Pistol
description: Tyler Hamilton earns well over $500,000 a year by riding a bike, so why didn't he leave his comfortable apartment in Spain all week to ride? Why did he agree to take part in today's New York City Cycling Championship, but not as a participant swooping around financial district street corners at 30 miles an hour? Instead, he will fire the starting gun.

title: Other Women in the News
description: Mary Meeker. The prominent, highly paid Morgan Stanley analyst, who raised regulators' eyebrows with her optimistic market assessments, is returning to writing. She'll become co-leader of Morgan Stanley's technology research.

title: Finding the Romantic Side Of the Vistas of New Jersey
description: A 10TH-GENERATION New Jerseyan, George Tice, 65, has spent the last four decades compiling a detailed photographic record of the state's urban and industrial landscapes. He is not the only American photographer to have embraced this theme, although he was the first to train his lens on the gritty Garden State. Mr. Tice is the Bruce Springsteen of photography.

The three-quarter-mile walk can be quicker than taking the Underground (about 20 minutes).

Others add a contrasting top. Of course, white is more commonly worn for day (top right), vanishing, traditionally, on Labor Day. Whether for day or evening, the message is always the same: Marlene Dietrich glamour.

title: Fears That the New State of Sumo Defiles Tradition

No one spoke, in keeping with the solemn rituals of morning practice, and only the thump of another wrestler striking his bare palms against a wood pole could be heard. The smell of sweat, from more than a dozen nearly naked men, filled the room.

description: As a resident of a hamlet contemplating incorporation, my first reaction to ''Villages, Inc.'' But bottom-line concerns do not by themselves justify the simple dismissal of the idea of becoming a village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURLEY, , JOHN WALTON
description: CURLEY--John Walton. 50, died at home in St. Louis on July 28, 2003 of lung cancer. He is survived by his children, Nina Galbraith Curley and James Ross Curley, his parents Ambassador Walter J.P. Curley and Mary Walton Curley, his brother Patrick of New York, his sister Margaret C. Wiles of North Yarmouth, ME., and his grandmother Rachel Mellon Walton of Pittsburgh. He was predeceased by his brother James. John Curley, a journalist is former City Editor of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and previously a reporter with the Wall Street Journal. He attended the Buckley School in Manhattan, Phillips Academy in Andover, MA, the University of Grenoble in France, Yale University and Washington University in St. Louis. >>AD#

title: Treasury Dept. to Refuse Senate a List of Saudi Suspects

title: Shattering Ceilings
description: I COME from a family with no preconceived notions of roles. Though my father was a lawyer and had an advanced degree in chemistry, he would make breakfast for us every morning. I thought all men did that. I always believed that I could be anything I wanted to be.

description: Service on nearly all of the city's 27 subway lines is being altered because of repairs this weekend. Work began at midnight Friday, and most service disruptions will continue until 5 a.m. tomorrow.

title: Tice and Vikings Work to Bury the Past
description: The game of football took 11 teeth from Mike Tice's head during his playing career and has now started in on his hairline. Age, to be sure, is one culprit. Being the head coach of one of the more confounding teams in the National Football League is another.

title: Corrections

title: Cons In Class
description: IGNORE the razor wire twisted outside the windows, and the school building at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility feels like most other academic institutions. Classrooms are filled with blackboards, freestanding globes, desk-and-chair combinations. Inspirational messages line the walls: If you don't get it, try again! Some people have to learn the hard way! Never settle for less than your best! But here, 30 miles up the Hudson from New York City, students don't linger after class. They are herded back to their cells the minute the clock hits 8:30.

title: Shaping a Meal of Inventive Dishes
description: WITH the advent of Malfetano Ristorante, settled in for almost a year now, the curse on the building seems to be lifting. In recent memory, the restaurants Max's 22 Grill, Legacy and Maruzzella Due opened and closed in relatively short order, oddly enough never quite finding an audience in an area dense with both residents and shoppers. Malfetano, however, with its interesting menu and understated elegance, may very well be a keeper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLWES, , WILLIAM
description: COLWES -- William. Died peacefully on July 29. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Matthew (Alyne Schwartz) and Carrie (Jeffrey Hymowitz), adoring grandfather of Jacob Ethan and Ari David. A great guy who will be sorely missed. title: Habitats/Lincoln Towers, West End Ave. Between 66th and 70th Sts.; To Jerusalem and Back, To Her West Side Oasis
description: THAT sofa has been all the way to Jerusalem and back. So has the deep red, tufted La-Z-Boy, the electric piano and the cat. Only the piano carries a mark -- just a small crack -- from the two-ocean, round-trip passage. Last August, its owner, Caren Westrich, gathered her courage and her belongings and caught up with a lifelong quarry: a dream of following her sister to Israel and settling there.

description: Logging on to www.Bayridge.com, a neighborhood Web site with about 4,000 members, you can learn about Bay Ridge's forthcoming 150th anniversary. You can find tinted postcards of the South Brooklyn neighborhood when it was virtually car-free. And you can find a message board where, for the past month, a battle has raged over postings that criticize, sometimes with violent overtones, the presence of Arabs in the community.

title: The Week in the News: July 27-Aug. 2
description: FOR THE FIRST TIME, PROGRESS ON OZONE No global environmental problem captured the world's attention as quickly as the erosion of the ozone layer, a molecular veil that shields Earth from ultraviolet radiation. Recognition that most of the damage came from a group of synthetic chemicals  chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's  led in 1987 to the passage of a treaty, the Montreal Protocol, phasing out the substances.

The comment is often typical of those applied to friendly little neighborhood spots with easy-to-swallow prices, pleasant waitresses and traditional dishes.

title: Katie, Bar The Door
description: When Senator Larry Craig of Idaho held up approval of Air Force promotions until four cargo jets were supplied to his state's Air National Guard, a Pentagon officer -- speaking on the deepest of background -- vowed to resist. ''If we say yes to this,'' he or she told The New York Times's Eric Schmitt, ''Katie bar the door.''

title: The Literary Freud
description: However powerful Freud's literary voice may be, there is something absurd in seeing him as primarily a literary figure, alongside Joyce, Kafka and Proust (Daphne Merkin, July 13). Freud's undying claim to fame is his forcing us to attend to one of the major areas of experience that the philosophical and intellectual tradition of the West had systematically ignored and obscured: human sexuality. He opened the world's mind to an essential part of our humanity, and in so doing changed forever the way we see ourselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBLAUM, , ALAN H.
description: ROSENBLAUM--Alan H. Family and friends of Alan Rosenbaum mourn his passing on July 27 at his home in Charlottesville, VA. He was 70 years old. The son of Murray and Rose Rosenbaum. He is survived by two sons: Steven Rosenbaum of Manhattan, NY and Roger Rosenbaum of Saugerties, NY, two grandsons Max and Murray Rosenbaum and sister Sue Briansky of Needham, MA. title: A Place Where Parents Have Lives Too, Just a Few Miles From 90210
description: PITY the poor grown-ups in the new Fox series ''The O.C.'' Sure, they live in a ritzy beach community and have loads of money, fancy cars, massive homes and the latest clothes. And, yes, they're invited to the most fashionable parties, where they can sip the nicest Champagnes while looking gorgeous. But does that mean they're happy? Apparently not, judging by the hints of infidelity, corruption and parenting problems shaping the premiere episode of the series.

It was normal for a car bred to hunt lions -- in this case, of the Ferrari breed -- to have sprouted an aerodynamic ridge on the engine cover, tapering from the air intake to the rear suspension.

title: A Wall of Sound From the Top of Foggy Mountain
description: RANDY WESTON -- The pianist's early work has just been reissued as a three-disc set by Blue Note in its limited edition ''Mosaic Select'' series. The set covers the years from 1958 to 1963, as well as the distance from Mr. Weston the player of piquant, swinging miniatures with a profound extreme-register style to Mr. Weston the concocter of large-ensemble evocations of Africa. Unlike Ellington, who used African and Asian elements with a very conscious air of paraphrase, Mr. Weston wanted to make the link more explicit. And that's what Langston Hughes's liner essay to the 1960 album ''Uhuru Afrika,'' reprinted here, confirms. ''That jazz owes its basic debt to Africa, no one disputes,'' Hughes wrote. ''Therefore contemporary Africans did not really have to learn to play jazz because their own tribal music from time immemorial has contained the major elements that distinguish jazz from other musical forms.'' Wow, how simplified and yearning that reads now. Randy Weston loved music from many parts of Africa, and still does. But most of his aesthetic DNA comes from Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk, who descended from the Harlem stride-piano players of the 20's, and all of those guys were as American as apple pie.

description: LAWSON--H.E. Bartholomew J. Age 54, on July 31, 2003. Family, friends and colleagues mourn the loss of a public servant, executive and healthcare advocate who died in Grenada while serving as Ambassador at Large to the United States Grenadian Mission to the United Nations. Mr. Lawson was President and member of the Board of Managers of CarePlus Health Plan, a community-based health service plan serving New York families and children. He was a member of the Board of the Brazelton Foundation, which fosters positive relationships between parents, professionals, communities and children. He was also President and Executive Director of the Greater New York Healthcare Facilities Association. Mr. Lawson served on the Transition teams of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani (1993) and Governor George E. Pataki (1994), and was appointed to serve on the Governor's Medicaid Task Force. He was a member of the University Club, the Friars Club of New York and the Nyack Field Club. He was a resident of Manhattan and Piermont, New York, and a graduate of New York University. He leaves behind his beloved wife Karen L. Lawson and three children, Bartholomew John (BJ), Mackenzie John and Katia Mary Grace. He was the loving brother of Debbie Holloway, Beth Lawson Kalt, Catherine Muhly and Maria Sheard, Sarah Lawson and Bernard Lawson. He will be missed by his many friends, colleagues and family members, both here and abroad. Services will be held on Tuesday, August 5, 2003, 10:30 AM, at The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, NY. Donations may be made to: Bartholomew J. Lawson Foundation for Children, c/o Karen Lawson, 360 West 31st St., 5th Floor, NY, NY 10001. For information, contact Jennifer Thermansen or Emily Therway at 212563-5570, ext. 813 or 247.

title: Medici of the Meadowlands
description: The tangled relationship of art, illusion and the marketplace being what it is -- an ongoing melodrama, set to the strains of keening violins -- it so happened that 250 tuxedoed, gowned and bejeweled members of the patronage class showed up for an Italianate palace ball one night this spring at a defunct train station in a Jersey City marsh. Guests were met at the gate by a young man in a pleated skirt, pointy black slippers and a frilly blouse under a gold brocaded vest, who bowed theatrically and said, ''Buona notte, signori e signore.'' The title of the ball was Palazzo di Cremona, and the domed terminal of the Central Railroad of New Jersey was done up for the evening with garlands of citrus leaves and blood oranges. Three former governors of New Jersey were present, along with Paolo Bodini, mayor of Cremona, Italy, a 2,300-year-old town north of Milan. Cremona occupies a status among violin aficionados akin to that of Detroit among car buffs, having been the ground on which such violin-making luminaries as Niccol Amati, Giuseppe Guarneri and, above all, Antonio Stradivari thrived. Mayor Bodini was a guest of the evening's honorees, an elderly couple named Evelyn and Herbert Axelrod, who had gained vast wealth by addressing themselves to the needs of caretakers of guppies, goldfish, parakeets, lizards, gerbils and the like, and who elicited, throughout the evening, comparison to the beneficent Medicis of Florence.

His chatty 1970's heroine, identified only as ''K. O'Connor,'' is an author of slick celebrity profiles who lands a book contract to do a come-clean show-biz biography of Vince Collins, the mellow singer-swinger half of a popular comedy act (ever so close to Martin and Lewis) that broke up in the late 50's under shady circumstances. It seems that neither Vince nor his partner, Lanny Morris, could explain how a woman with whom they had both dallied in Miami wound up dead in the bathtub of their private suite at a mob-run casino in New Jersey. Holmes, who has won honors galore for his inventive storytelling on Broadway and elsewhere, can be forgiven for milking the mystery of ''the Girl in New Jersey'' because he delivers such a giddy fun-house ride through bygone eras. As the go-go girl of the 70's, O'Connor tempts us to throw on a pair of bell-bottoms and dash out for some reckless sex, while Vince and Lanny invest the forgotten 50's with all the brash and vulgar celebrity glamour of a mad tea party in Las Vegas.

title: The Way to a Better Budget

Even if the state should avert a deficit this year, State Comptroller Alan Hevesi estimates that next year's budget is already out of balance by $5.3 billion. Unfortunately, the governor and the Legislature will be in no better position to solve this problem because they do not have the capacity to measure the efficiency and effectiveness of the state's spending.

title: Conductor Dares to Tweak Tradition
description: For a conductor quoted as saying that he doesn't believe in interpreting music, Louis Langre surely found plenty to tinker with in the Mostly Mozart program he conducted on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Granted, his interpretive touches were not radical: there was none of the fussy tempo manipulation one hears in a Lorin Maazel performance, for example. But in works by Mozart and Weber, Mr. Langre's balances were often unusual, his dynamics were fluid and often dramatic, and there were even occasional touches of rubato.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Wayne: Questions Over Parking Lot Death
description: The Wayne police said yesterday that they would continue to question a young woman who ran over her sister and her sister's 2-year-old daughter in a strip mall parking lot on Saturday, killing the girl. The woman, Honiusca Garcia, 19, of Paterson, was driving when the accident occurred at 12:30 p.m. outside a Big Kmart in Wayne. She was charged with careless driving and driving without a license, but is no longer in police custody. Sgt. Don Pavlak, a spokesman for the Wayne police, said investigators are unsure what led up to the accident. He added that the victims may have been dragged through the lot after being hit. Ms. Garcia's niece, Katherine, died an hour later. Ms. Garcia's sister, Katiusca Garcia, 23, also of Paterson, is in stable condition at St. Joseph's Regional Medical Center in Paterson. Jonathan Miller (NYT)

title: Report Says U.S. Should Subsidize Vaccinations
