title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWSON, , H.E. BARTHOLOMEW J.
description: LAWSON--H.E. Bartholomew J. Age 54, on July 31, 2003. Family, friends and colleagues mourn the loss of a public servant, executive and healthcare advocate who died in Grenada while serving as Ambassador at Large to the United States Grenadian Mission to the United Nations. Mr. Lawson was President and member of the Board of Managers of CarePlus Health Plan, a community-based health service plan serving New York families and children. He was a member of the Board of the Brazelton Foundation, which fosters positive relationships between parents, professionals, communities and children. He was also President and Executive Director of the Greater New York Healthcare Facilities Association. Mr. Lawson served on the Transition teams of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani (1993) and Governor George E. Pataki (1994), and was appointed to serve on the Governor's Medicaid Task Force. He was a member of the University Club, the Friars Club of New York and the Nyack Field Club. He was a resident of Manhattan and Piermont, New York, and a graduate of New York University. He leaves behind his beloved wife Karen L. Lawson and three children, Bartholomew John (BJ), Mackenzie John and Katia Mary Grace. He was the loving brother of Debbie Holloway, Beth Lawson Kalt, Catherine Muhly and Maria Sheard, Sarah Lawson and Bernard Lawson. He will be missed by his many friends, colleagues and family members, both here and abroad. Services will be held on Tuesday, August 5, 2003, 10:30 AM, at The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, NY. Donations may be made to: Bartholomew J. Lawson Foundation for Children, c/o Karen Lawson, 360 West 31st St., 5th Floor, NY, NY 10001. For information, contact Jennifer Thermansen or Emily Therway at 212563-5570, ext. 813 or 247.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Milford: Trains Delayed For Hours
description: Torn electrical wiring over the train tracks just east of Milford caused lengthy delays for passengers on Amtrak and Metro-North trains yesterday, according to officials of both railroads. Dan Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North, said the problems began about 2 p.m. when the wiring was torn down, apparently by a passing train, over one of three tracks. The damaged wires fell across those over another track, putting it out of service, and the third track was already closed for construction, he said. Mr. Brucker said Metro-North put diesel engines and buses into service. But he said 18 Metro North trains between New Haven and Manhattan were delayed, some for just over an hour. Amtrak trains, which run on the same tracks, were delayed by up to five hours, Dan Stessel, an Amtrak spokesman, said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: A Night of Straight-Ahead Jazz
description: Ethan Iverson and Mark Turner have been heard recently at the Village Vanguard playing music that, it can be argued, is not quite jazz  at the Vanguard!  and have occasioned some hand-wringing. In the case of Mr. Iverson, a pianist, it happened with his group the Bad Plus, known to use backbeats and to remake rock-radio tunes. For Mr. Turner, a tenor saxophonist, it was an ascetic new trio in which he sometimes let go of syncopation altogether, playing slowly in chamber-music dynamics.

title: Patents; With the help of holographic technology, an inventor creates a business out of thin air.
description: A DECADE ago, R. Douglas McPheters wrote a novel. ''It was a thriller about a Manhattan loan shark operating in what's left of the Soviet Union,'' Mr. McPheters, a former banking and securities lawyer, recalled. He never did publish the book, but he became fixated on one of his fictitious inventions: a holographic keypad that floats in midair.

title: Feeling Horrible, Franz? That's Nice
description: Sure, happy people can create great art, too, but the old Romantic myth of misery as muse is given altogether stunning support by two works that Schubert wrote in the mid-1820's: the A minor Quartet and the D minor quartet, ''Death and the Maiden.'' In a letter from the time quoted in countless program notes, Schubert describes himself as ''the most unhappy and wretched creature in the world,'' and yet these pieces are among his most gripping chamber music creations.

title: Downtown's Architectural Promise
description: Not that long ago, it looked as though the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site might be slipping into the mundane track of ordinary commercial construction. The selection of Daniel Libeskind's dramatic plan was all well and good, but the real question was whether the economic and political realities of Lower Manhattan would allow the design to survive in any recognizable form, and whether it would inspire other architects of equal renown. For a while, all the moving parts in the reconstruction of ground zero seemed to be going in different directions toward what might have been, at best, architectural and civic banality and, at worst, incoherence. That risk is still present, but it has been greatly reduced by a number of significant decisions, agreements and compromises over the past few weeks.

title: A Changed Climate in Turkey
description: The votes by Turkey's Parliament last week to curb the political power of the military and increase freedom of expression are a significant step away from army domination of Turkish politics. The challenge now for the government, dominated by moderate Islamists of the Justice and Development Party, is to ensure that the new measures are carried out. Not long ago, Turkey's military would have responded to such initiatives by seizing power -- the armed forces removed four governments in the last four decades. That is less likely today because of broad support in Turkey for democratic rule, but these reforms present a test of just how much the climate has changed. The military should step back and let the nation continue unhindered along the path to a fuller democracy and the coveted prize of European Union membership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YERKES, JOHN NICHOLAS
description: YERKES -- John Nicholas. Age 33, died on Fishers Island, July 31 after a lengthy battle with cancer. He is survived by his loving wife Darcy, daughter Mackenzie, son Peyton, mother and father Harry E. Yerkes and Nancy Spofford Yerkes, sisters Elizabeth and Nathalie and brother Harry. His grandfather, the late Charles M. Spofford, was U.S. Deputy to NATO, Chevalier of the Legion of Honeur in France, and, as Chairman of the Metropolitan Opera, was instrumental in the formation of Lincoln Center. He graduated from St. Bernard's School in Manhattan, the Taft School in Waterbury, CT, and Rollins College in Florida. title: GENERAL ELECTRIC TO SELL BOND INSURANCE UNIT
description: General Electric yesterday agreed to sell its bond insurance unit for $1.9 billion to a group led by the mortgage insurer PMI Group Inc. as part of a strategy to exit slower- growing businesses and raise cash to bolster its GE Capital unit. PMI, based near San Francisco, is buying the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company with the backing of the Blackstone Group, the Cypress Group and CIVC Partners, which includes the Bank of America Corporation as an investor. General Electric, the world's biggest company by market value, will keep $260 million of the unit's profit as part of the sale. G.E. is disposing of units that do not have leading positions in their markets and raising cash to protect the credit rating of its GE Capital unit.

title: Ranks Thin In Hazard Unit Of Fire Dept.
description: In the aftermath of Sept. 11, when 11 members of the New York City Fire Department's highly trained hazardous materials unit perished, there was widespread agreement, from outside experts to city officials, that the elite emergency unit needed not only to be rebuilt but also expanded, perhaps even doubled in size to deal with future disasters.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: WebMD Sells 2 Divisions
description: The WebMD Corporation, which runs medical information Web sites, said yesterday that it had sold its Porex Bio Products and Porex Medical Products units for a combined $46.5 million in cash. WebMD said it would lose $36 million on the divestitures and would take a $33 million charge in the quarter ended June 30. The remaining charge will be recorded in the quarter ending Sept. 30. The chief executive of WebMD, Roger C. Holstein, said the units would require additional long-term investment to remain competitive, though they were profitable. Apogent Technologies bought Porex Bio Products, which makes disposable plastic items for storing and handling liquids in laboratories. Medegen Holdings bought Porex Medical Products, which makes plastic supplies used by hospitals and other health care providers.

title: Red Hat Sues SCO Over Claim to Unix Code
description: Red Hat Inc., a large publisher of the Linux operating system, filed a lawsuit today accusing the SCO Group of making inaccurate statements that Red Hat software infringed the SCO rights to Unix, a related operating system.

title: People

Ms. Murcko succeeds J. Daniel Brock, who is leaving to pursue other interests.

title: NORTHROP WINS NAVY SPY PLANE CONTRACT
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the world's largest naval shipbuilder, received a $1.93 billion award from the Navy to design, build and demonstrate an updated version of the E-2 Hawkeye spy plane. Northrop, based in Los Angeles, will modify two of its E-2 aircraft to the new E-2 advanced Hawkeye design, the Navy said yesterday. Work is to be completed by December 2012. Hawkeyes have been the Navy's primary surveillance and patrol aircraft since 1973, and have been continually upgraded to keep pace with new technology. The current version, the Hawkeye 2000, entered production in 1999. Most of the design and testing work on the new plane will be done in Bethpage, N.Y., the Navy said. Northrop's shares fell 11 cents, to $91.75.

title: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS SPINS OFF FUND MANAGER
description: Fidelity Investments yesterday split off Geode Capital Management, an index fund manager and test-bed for new investment strategies, as a separate company. Geode, founded by Fidelity in January 2001 and run by Jacques Perold, has $293 million in assets and now can solicit customers outside the company, a Fidelity spokeswoman, Anne Crowley, said. Fidelity oversees $880 billion. Geode was first disclosed publicly in April when Fidelity, based in Boston, mentioned the unit in its 2002 annual report.

title: U.S. May Reduce Aid Plan to Get Israel to Halt Barrier
description: The Bush administration, looking for ways to press Israel to halt construction of a barrier separating its citizens from Palestinian areas, is considering a reduction in loan guarantees for Israel that were approved by Congress this spring, administration officials said today.

description: HIRSCHEN--Jerrold I. The Board, Staff and Clients of the Women's Prison Association and Home (WPA) are deeply saddened by the death of Jerry Hirschen. Jerry was pivotal in the development of the Sarah Powell Huntington House, WPA's residential facility for women reuniting with their children, now celebrating its tenth anniversary. He was always available to help us and so many others who sought to make the world a better place. Our deepest sympathy goes to Carole and Jill, and to the many people who loved him. Valerie S. Mason, President of the Board Ann L. Jacobs, Executive Director

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Herr Berlusconi
description: A month ago Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, gravely offended many Germans. Now he says he is ''almost a German'' himself. That comment came in an interview in the German newspaper Bild. Mr. Berlusconi's prior offense was to compare a German member of the European Parliament to a concentration camp guard. In the new interview, he says Italy and Germany are once again chummy, and he casts his own affinity for Germany in terms of his constant complaint that he sacrifices everything for Italy. ''Work, work, work -- I am almost a German,'' he is quoted as saying. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: A London Market Inquiry Into Aluminum Trading
description: The London Metal Exchange, the world's largest metals market, said today that it had begun a formal investigation into ''possible collusion'' among traders in the aluminum market. In June, about $94 billion worth of aluminum was traded on the exchange.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Health-Premium Measure Becomes Law
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he had signed legislation to help self-insured workers who lost their jobs because of foreign competition. Under the law, such workers will be reimbursed for 65 percent of the cost of their health premiums. The legislation also covers those age 55 and older who are self-insured and whose failed company pensions were taken over by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the government agency that guarantees pensions. To qualify, a person must directly subscribe to an insurance company. The reimbursement may be credited to an individual's federal tax filing or be paid to the insurance company. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: Olympus Optical said that profits in the April-to-June quarter jumped 86 percent, to 9.1 billion yen ($76 million), thanks to strong demand for the company's digital cameras. Sales over all grew 15 percent in the period. The company maintained its full-year profit goal of 37 billion yen ($307 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

The rich teams are still richer and the poor teams, in comparison, are still poorer.

description: If you've got to have a gimmick in politics, Senator Bob Graham may have found the next big thing. Mr. Graham, one of a slew of Democrats running for president this year, has spent as much as $500,000 to help underwrite a souped-up Jack Roush pickup truck that has been screaming around some of Nascar's racetracks. After the Bob Graham Ford won a race in Kansas City, his campaign got thousands of dollars in free publicity as TV cameras followed the machine for a full victory lap.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Settles Lawsuit
description: AT&T Wireless, a leading mobile-phone company, and other defendants have agreed to pay $47.5 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of shortchanging investors when it bought TeleCorp PCS last year. AT&T Wireless, along with eight former TeleCorp executives, agreed to pay the money to avoid a trial in Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington, according to court papers. Almost a dozen TeleCorp shareholders said in the lawsuit that the wireless company secretly paid TeleCorp executives $140 million to win their support for the $4.6 billion buyout. The settlement came as AT&T Wireless completed a buyback of $540.4 million in high-interest debt it had assumed in the acquisition of TeleCorp and another company. AT&T Wireless executives declined to comment on the settlement. Lawyers for the company, which is based in Redmond, Wash., said in court papers that AT&T Wireless denied any wrongdoing and settled the case only to ''avoid the substantial expense, inconvenience, risk and distraction of continued litigation.''

Despite making about $400 million over the past 20 years, Tyson managed to squander his fortune.

And what could be more absurd than the sight of the world's richest nation -- a fiery preacher of free-trade and free-market values at that -- spending $3 billion or $4 billion a year in taxpayer money to grow cotton worth less than that and selling its mounting surpluses at an ever greater loss?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPP, STEVEN M.
description: PAPP--Steven M. The Research Foundation for Mental Hygiene mourns the loss of our friend and colleague Steven M. Papp. Steven was Deputy Director for Administration at the New York Psychiatric Institute, a member of the Board of Directors of the Research Foundation and Chairman of the Fiscal Committee. For many years the Research Foundation has had the tremendous fortune of his wise counsel and leadership. He was respected for his superior intellect, sense of humor and superior management style. He was a leader with understanding and deep concern that allowed him to help others in a constructive, unselfish manner. He had only friends and no enemies among the scientists and administrators who had the honor and pleasure of working with him. He will be missed by the scientific community as well as his fellow administrators. We extend our sympathies to Steven's family and co-workers as they have lost an exceptional individual. His memories will live on with all of us at the Research Foundation. Abel Lajtha, PhD, President Robert E. Burke, Managing Director Frank L. Mucha Deputy Director for Admin.

Merck and Medco did not admit to any liability as part of the agreement, which requires changes in the way Medco notifies subscribers of coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POULAKAKOS, ADRIENNE M.
description: POULAKAKOS--Adrienne M. February 24, 1934-August 4, 2003. Beloved wife of Harry and mother of Peter passed from this life peacefully on August 4, 2003 after a short illness. Adrienne, who was the second child and only daughter of Alfred and Mary Alice Nahas, was born on February 24, 1934 in Brooklyn, New York. She married Harry Poulakakos on June 6, 1965. Together they built a life and lived in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, New York. They were blessed with a son, Peter, who was born on April 21, 1976. Adrienne lived life to its fullest and with her husband and later her son, helped to build a successful restaurant enterprise in the Wall Street area of Manhattan. She will be remembered as a pillar of the social, economic and philanthropic community of lower Manhattan through her family's restaurants, most notably Harry's at Hanover Square, Harry's at the American Exchange and most recently Bayard's. The generosity and care she bestowed upon those she served in her life's work will be most missed by those who knew her. Adrienne Poulakakos is survived by her husband Harry and son Peter, her two brothers Edmund and Alfred Nahas and their wives, Vickie & Anne Marie, respectively. She also leaves her brotherin-law, George Poulakakos and his wife Despina also of Brooklyn, New York, sistersin-law Angelique & Catherine, numerous nieces and nephews and many other family members and friends. Viewing will be held at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, New York Wednesday and Thursday, 25 and 7-9 P.M.; funeral services on Friday, August 8, 2003 at 10:00 AM at St. Mary's Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or St. Mary's Orthodox Church.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Telemig To Buy Stake In Rival
description: Telemig Cellular, a cellphone operator in Brazil's vast central state of Minas Gerais, said that it would buy 75 percent of a rival, CTBC, for an undisclosed sum. Telemig Celular, controlled by the local investment group Opportunity, informed So Paulo's stock market regulator that it was buying the share of CTBC, which had 310,000 customers at the end of June and is not publicly listed, from Algar Telecom, a fixed-line operator. title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fires Spread Across West
description: Thousands of people in western Canada were forced to evacuate their homes because of fast-spreading forest fires, considered the worst in the last half-century. In one area of southern British Columbia, near Kamloops, about 180 miles northeast of Vancouver, 10,000 people from mostly rural communities were evacuated, while forecasts for more hot, dry weather stoked fears that the fires could spread. Nearly 2,000 residents from the mountainous region of southwestern Alberta have also been evacuated. Hundreds of firefighters from around the country have been called in to fight the 380 fires, some of them burning for more than a week. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Critic's Notebook; Seattle Opera Gamble: The Results Are In

The public has been free to wander into the spacious and colorful new lobby with its airy glass walls that flow right into an outdoor courtyard overhung with delicately laced metal scrims. For the first time passers-by can stroll through the inviting walkway onto the grassy expanses of the Seattle Center, the city's arts and entertainment complex. The opera house has been open for tours and tried out in some special festive concerts.

title: Antiterrorism Experts Warn More Attacks May Be Coming
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  The aftershocks of the deadly terror bombing at the J. W. Marriott hotel in Jakarta reverberated around the world to the nation's capital today, where intelligence experts said the blast fit a rising tempo of threats and intelligence reports indicating the possibility of more attacks overseas, and possibly inside the United States.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Cape May Court House: Teenager's Murder Trial Rescheduled
description: The trial of Joseph M. Campon, 19, whose first trial in the stabbing death of another teenager ended in a hung jury, has been rescheduled for Jan. 20. In June, a Cape May County jury could not reach a verdict after deliberating for five days. On July 2, 2001, Mr. Campon, of Schenectady, N.Y., confronted Christopher Loftus, 19, of Lower Township, and another man for making sexual remarks to Mr. Campon's sister and cousin in a beachfront arcade. Mr. Campon, who was charged with first-degree murder, said he had stabbed Mr. Loftus in self-defense. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: China Lags In Sharing SARS Clues, Officials Say

title: A Homecoming for Balanchine; City Ballet Shows St. Petersburg That a Master's Art Is Still Alive

Patrons of the company have flown in en masse from New York, arriving with a sense of history. For this is George Balanchine's hometown, and the visit is the first by the company -- Balanchine's company -- since 1972, when the choreographer himself made the trip.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL TO CUT AS MANY AS 1,000 JOBS
description: The Lincoln National Corporation, a Philadelphia-based life insurer, said yesterday that it would cut as many as 1,000 jobs, or about 17 percent of its work force, after combining its life insurance and annuities businesses in June. Severance-related costs will cut after-tax profit by $45.5 million this year after $16.3 million in expense savings, said a spokeswoman, D'Arcy Rudnay. Costs were $9.9 million in the second quarter, she said. Lincoln's chief executive, Jon Boscia, is trying to reduce expenses after three years of stock market declines eroded net income to $91.6 million last year from $605.8 million in 2000. Shares fell 54 cents, to $35.74.

title: UNDERWEAR MAKER TO CLOSE TEXAS PLANT
description: Fruit of the Loom Inc., the underwear maker owned by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., will close a plant in Harlingen, Tex., that employs 791 workers because of competition with imports from Asia. The plant will be closed by the end of the year, Fruit of the Loom said in a statement yesterday. Fruit of the Loom, based in Bowling Green, Ky., said it had to close the plant to remain competitive with imported goods. Berkshire Hathaway bought the company last year for $835 million as it reorganized under bankruptcy reorganization. Shares of Berkshire Hathaway, based in Omaha, rose $190, to $72,190.

title: Shanghai Journal; A New Policy of Containment, for Baby Bottoms

title: A War Russia Loses By Winning
description: To hear Russian officials, what's happening in Chechnya is not a war: it is a phase in an antiterrorism operation that has reached such a point of ''normalization'' that control was switched last week from the Federal Security Bureau, which handles war operations, to the Interior Ministry. After all, the Russians say, the Chechen people rebuffed the Islamic separatists by voting overwhelmingly in March to remain part of Russia, and they will vote again in October, this time for a Chechen president.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Leads To Gas Explosion
description: A fire that broke out yesterday in the basement of a 21-story office building in the garment district led to a gas explosion and an evacuation of the building, the authorities said. Firefighters responded to the blaze, at 580 Eighth Avenue, between 38th and 39th Streets, shortly after 5 p.m. Robert Callise, a Fire Department spokesman, said no one was injured when the building was evacuated. Consolidated Edison crews shut off gas lines after the explosion. Fire officials said the blaze was under control by shortly before 9 p.m., but traffic in the area was snarled because the police blocked traffic on Eighth Avenue from 37th to 39th Streets to allow emergency workers access to the building. title: Security? Boldfaced Need Not Wait

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Trenton; The Changing Face of a State Capital
description: Since 1935, visitors to Trenton have been greeted by an enormous neon sign mounted on the Delaware River Bridge announcing the city's slogan: ''Trenton Makes, the World Takes.'' If you're the sort who thinks about such things, you would be struck by the size of the sign (327 feet wide with letters 9 feet high), its brightness, but mostly the incongruity of it, since Trenton doesn't make that many things anymore.

title: F. C. Robbins, Virus Researcher, Dies at 86
description: Dr. Frederick C. Robbins, a pediatrician who shared a Nobel Prize in 1954 for discovering a way to grow the polio virus in a test tube and paving the way for the vaccines that have eliminated the crippling disease from much of the world, died yesterday in Cleveland. He was 86 and until earlier this year worked at Case Western Reserve University, where he was a university professor emeritus.

title: Russell Simmons brings his style to a new line of clothing.
description: RUSSELL SIMMONS, the rap impresario and hip-hop businessman, is making another foray into the clothing business. His new collections of men's and women's sportswear, called Def Jam University, will be accompanied by a wider than usual marketing campaign.

title: Sum of Yankees' Parts Not as Great as Whole
description: It is tempting to look at a lineup and think of each player in the best-case scenario. The offense has so much potential that way, and its chance of success is tantalizing. Too bad, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said, that baseball does not work that way.

title: Toyota Dealers Stay With Saatchi
description: The Greater New York Toyota Dealers Association has decided to stay with Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, which is part of the Publicis Groupe, as the agency handling the creative duties on its account. Billings were estimated at $80 million to $90 million.

title: Living the Life of the Sea From a 5th-Floor Walk-Up
description: AVAST there, me hearties, and shake the hand of the grizzled, bearded captain himself, Peter Neill, way up in his crow's-nest on historic Front Street. He is, as usual, anticipating sunny skies while cannily keeping a weather eye for icebergs.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 13 Soldiers Killed In Blast
description: Thirteen Afghan soldiers were killed and 21 wounded when a truck full of weapons exploded in northern Afghanistan during a disarmament exercise, local officials said. The soldiers were men loyal to the Uzbek deputy defense minister in Afghanistan, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, and were disarming local units and transporting the weapons to General Dostum's base in Shibarghan. The blast, apparently caused by unstable ammunition, destroyed five trucks. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: $85 Million Project Begins For Revival of the Aral Sea
description: After nearly half a century of studying and deploring the drying up of the Aral Sea, one of the world's greatest environmental disasters, an international agency is building a dike to resuscitate part of the sea.

We love you, we will miss you and we will think of you always. Funeral service, Tuesday, August 5, 2003, 11AM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

description: An $18 dry Johannisberg riesling from the Finger Lakes region was voted New York's best wine of 2003 yesterday in a major contest limited to the state's wines.

title: Bulgari Builds on Brand in Many Ways
description: Francesco Trapani, Bulgari's chief executive, drowns his brand, as if it needed it, in buzz.

title: Lewis Putting Off Klitschko
description: After being cleared to fight by three medical experts, Vitali Klitschko will have to wait at least until next year to have another crack at the heavyweight champion Lennox Lewis, who has passed up a lucrative Dec. 6 rematch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAFFE, JANE
description: JAFFE--Jane. Age 76. Of Cross River, N.Y. Formerly of Waccabuc, N.Y. Died August 3, 2003, at home. Wife of the late Lee. Mother of Jim (Laura) of Katonah, N.Y., John (Robyn) of Wesburn, Australia and Jed (Kathie) of Eden Prairie, MN. Sister of Susan Cole of Casper, WY. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jacob Burns Film Center, The Jane Jaffe Fund, 39 Washington Ave, Pleasantville, N.Y. 10570.

title: Taking Advice, to Dinner Table
description: Government warnings urging pregnant women to reduce their consumption of fish that may carry high mercury levels appear to work, researchers say.

title: Reluctant Inquisitor Steers Senate Panel
description: Pat Roberts, the droll Kansan who is chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, cuts an unlikely figure as the watchdog of the nation's spy apparatus, given his expertise in farm policy, prairie wit and features straight out of a Grant Wood painting.

title: G.E. to Buy Transamerica Finance From Aegon
description: In a move that will increase its presence in the commercial finance business, the General Electric Company said today that it had agreed to buy most of the commercial lending business of the Transamerica Finance Corporation from Aegon N.V. , its Dutch parent, for about $1 billion in cash.

title: Dentistry, Far Beyond Drilling and Filling
description: Dentistry may not be the oldest profession, but for reasons of sheer, tearful necessity it is surely right up there among the Top 10 of humanity's primal callings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, BARBARA B.
description: THOMPSON--Barbara B., 49, on August 1. A talented photographer. She will be missed by her mother, Odette Dahlberg, her sisters, Linda, Cynthia and Miriam Thompson, her nieces, Jeanne, Felmly, Chiara Gerding, and all of her friends in Liberty, Pittsburgh, NYC and across the country.

title: Tyson's Bankruptcy Is a Lesson in Ways to Squander a Fortune
description: For the former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson, a cash machine to himself and to others, record earnings in the boxing ring became a license to spend  on jewelry, mansions, cars, limousines, cellphones, parties, clothing, motorcycles and Siberian tigers. Despite making about $400 million over the past 20 years, Tyson managed to squander his fortune.

title: Peter Schwed, 92, an Executive At Simon & Schuster and Author
description: Peter Schwed, a former editorial chairman and trade books publisher at Simon & Schuster and an author in his own right, died last Thursday at Beth Israel North Hospital in Manhattan. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom In Talks On Refinancing
description: Alstom, a Paris-based electrical engineering company, said it was in talks to refinance and reschedule payment of its short- and medium-term debt. The company is looking to pay back a 1.25 billion euro debt due in April 2004. The company said it would issue a news release after a board meeting this morning but declined to comment on the parties on the other side of the negotiations. J. P. Morgan Chase, Citigroup, BNP Paribas and HSBC Holdings are among the company's creditors. The chief executive of Alstom, Patrick Kron, above, has been working to avoid bankruptcy by selling 3 billion euros worth of assets. Among them is the power and transmission branch, which could fetch more than 1 billion euros. The company's overall debt stood at 4.9 billion euros ($5.56 billion) as of March 31, 2003. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, FLORENCE (NEE PROPP)
description: KLEIN -- Florence (nee Propp). Of Kingston, N.Y. Died Sunday, August 3, 2003. Daughter of the late Louis and Pansy Lunitz Propp. Wife of the late Aaron E. Klein. Survived by son Louis Klein and daughters Phyllis Reer and Brenda Ross. Funeral services will be Wednesday, 9 AM, at Simpson-Gaus Funeral Home, Kingston, New York.

title: HORSE RACING: Racing Analysis; Immature 3-Year-Olds Don't Follow the Script
description: Funny Cide fever has finally extended to the horse himself -- he was running one today after a third-place finish Sunday in the $1 million Haskell Invitational at Monmouth Park. Funny Cide, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, was back here today and had a temperature of 102 degrees. He also had a closed eye after having sand kicked in it, and was said to be exhausted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, GERTRUDE
description: MARCUS--Gertrude. On August 2, 2003. Adored wife, lover and best friend of Arthur. Cherished mother of Joan Rosenberg and Steven Marcus. Beloved grandmother of Scott and Ali, Stacey and James, Jamie and Jimmy and Kimberly and Jeff. Proud great-grandmother of Jake, Ryan, Emma, Brett and Charlie. Dear sister of Rose. Gert and Arthur shared a fairy tale marriage of passion, laughter and devotion, always together and always madly in love. They radiated an aura of happiness and joy, whether exploring the world or a local art fair. Gert saw the best in people, with never a bad word to say. She loved her family deeply and exulted in their love and affection. An elegant, beautiful, compassionate woman of total loyalty, integrity and caring. She will be terribly missed but constantly remembered.

He was Regional Vicar, Northeast Bronx Vicariate, Archdiocese of New York. Beloved brother of Joan Toner, of Williamsburg, VA; Kathleen Scully of Ft. Lee, NJ and the late Matthew Toner. Dear uncle of several nieces and nephews. The Monsignor will be received into the St. Barnabas high school Chapel, 240 1st St. and McLean Ave., on Tuesday, August 5 at 2:00 PM. He will lay in state from 2-4 & 7-9 PM, also on Wednesday from 2-4 PM with the Mass of the Holy Eucharist being offered at 7:30 PM. The Funeral Mass will be offered on Thursday, August 7 at 10:30 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers kindly make donations to St. Barnabas Church, 409 East 241st St, Bronx, New York 10470.

description: DONOHOE--Louise F. Died August 3, 2003. Born Cuddy, Pennsylvania, June 11, 1915, she graduated from Bellevue School of Nursing in 1936 and served as captain in the Army Nursing Corps from 1942-46. She was the widow of Charles J. Donohoe and is survived by a son Charles D. Donohoe, M.D., Mission Hills, KS, Louise A. Resor, M.D., Greenwich, CT, Michelle A. O'Reilly, Melville, NY, and nine grandchildren. description: Prevaricate. Equivocate. Fib. Call it what you like, it's still lying. And lying, as everyone knows, is just bad and wrong.

description: Planes were more crowded than ever last month, mostly because carriers have cut back on the number of seats in the sky to save money and address falling demand.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Say It, Play It, Then Do It Again
description: Repetition is one of music's most elementary devices and one of its most powerful. It can be hypnotic or propulsive; it can create stability or disorientation. It can set up expectations or defy them; it can make a bad joke funny or wear out a good one. Repetition is at the core of the albums here, and on each album it tells a different story.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am frustrated with Washington. It has gotten totally partisan. We are not serious about anything except the next election.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bradesco Posts First-Half Profit
description: Banco Bradesco, Brazil's largest private bank, posted first-half profit of a bit more than 1 billion reais ($326 million), 13.6 percent higher than in the period last year, the bank reported. Interest rates at their highest levels since 1999 have helped Bradesco and other banks improve lending margins. The bank also reduced its costs for bad-loan provisions. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Winning Beside Point In Winston Cup Series
description: Matt Kenseth does not exactly look like someone who is running away with the Nascar Winston Cup championship. He has won one race this season, and that victory came five months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDERSON, LUTHER
description: HENDERSON--Luther. The family of Luther Henderson would appreciate, in lieu of flowers, contributions be sent to the Jackie Robinson Foundation for the Luther Henderson Scholarship Fund. The Foundation is located at 3 West 35th Street, 11th Floor, New York, New York 10001.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Claims Court Victory
description: Motorola said yesterday that the Swiss Federal Supreme Court had upheld a lower court decision in Zurich freezing the Swiss assets of the Uzan family, a wealthy Turkish clan that failed to repay $2.7 billion in loans from Motorola and Nokia to expand a cellphone company the Uzans controlled. The ruling appeared to settle an apparent conflict that had arisen when a local court in Geneva found that there were insufficient grounds to attach the Uzans' assets. The worldwide asset freeze order was originally issued in Britain and covers up to $800 million. Motorola won a $4.2 billion fraud judgment against the Uzans last month in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The Uzans have said they would appeal that decision. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

description: The Suzuki Motor Corporation earned 13 billion yen ($108 million) in the first quarter of Japan's fiscal year because of strong sales overseas. Suzuki, Japan's largest maker of minicars, said sales hit 575 billion yen ($4.8 billion) in the April-to-June period. This was the first time that Suzuki, which is 20 percent owned by General Motors, reported quarterly figures, so no year-on-year comparisons were available. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: China's state council, or cabinet, appointed a new security chief and financial secretary in Hong Kong today to replace officials who resigned after mass protests rocked the Chinese-installed government in the former British colony.

title: CHARLES SCHWAB SELLS $6 MILLION OF HIS SHARES
description: Charles Schwab, who stepped down in January as co-chief executive of the discount brokerage firm he founded, sold $6.24 million of shares in the company last month in his biggest stock sale in two and a half years. Mr. Schwab sold 600,000 shares of Charles Schwab & Company on July 30 at $10.40 each, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He remains the company's chairman, marketing figurehead and biggest shareholder. Through personal and family holdings, he owns 242 million shares, or about 18 percent of the firm. Last month's transactions came near the upper end of the stock's 52-week price range of $12.38 to $6.56.

title: Petty Enterprises and Yankees Team Up on Racecar
description: Richard Petty is a legendary former stock-car driver from Level Cross, N.C. He laughs when he says there was a day he never would have dreamed of forming a business partnership with any Yankee, let alone the New York Yankees.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Army And Rebels Clash
description: Army soldiers clashed with Maoist rebels in Dailekh district, in western Nepal, the rebels reported. They gave no casualty figures but said their forces had been ordered to attack government troops that move more than three miles outside military bases. The two sides are engaged in peace talks, but the government has refused to agree to a Maoist demand that government forces patrol only within three miles of their bases. The clash was the first in weeks. Another round of talks is to begin by Friday. Dhruba Adhikary (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GORMLEY, FRANK J.
description: GORMLEY--Frank J. Because of you, I love you more each day. I miss all your ''voices'' and dreams we shared. In awe of your courage, I rage at your suffering. Then...''I think on thee...for thy sweet love remembered such wealth brings I scorn to change my state with kings.'' Your forever adoring wife, Eileen Sini Gormle

description: Ike Hilliard is being asked to cross the line of scrimmage into chaos on almost every down.

Amory Host and Nathaniel and Bethany Grinnell. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Volkswagen Cuts Production
description: Volkswagen de Mxico has begun production cuts at its plant in the state of Puebla that threaten to eliminate 2,000 jobs from the company's only North American factory. Volkswagen ended production of the Beetle last week and it is also reducing output of its Jetta, New Beetle and New Beetle Cabriolet models because of reduced demand in the United States. Overall production has fallen from 1,360 cars a day to 1,100. Talks between the union and management continue in an effort to save the jobs. A company spokesman said that in principle both sides have agreed to a reduced workweek but details on pay and benefits need to be determined. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Relatives Recall 9/11 Victim; Prosecutors Say It's Fiction
description: According to two men who called him their brother, Wilfred Kendall was about 5-foot-10-inches tall with dark brown skin and a heavy West Indian accent. They said he drove a gypsy cab, a black Lincoln Mercury, and dealt auto parts for a living.

description: Israel today published the names of nearly 350 Palestinian prisoners to be freed soon, in a move intended to improve the atmosphere for peace negotiations, but the list brought only cries of complaint from Palestinians.

description: Principal Financial Group Inc., the biggest seller of 401(k) retirement plans in the United States, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 68 percent as pension deposits increased and the company sold more mortgages.

description: Three men attacked a family of Indian immigrants outside the family's Queens home on Sunday night, the police said. The victims said they were punched, spit on and told ''bin Laden family, go back to your country.''

title: Everything Is Political
description: The agency's analysts find that they are no longer helping to formulate policy; instead, their job is to rationalize decisions that have already been made. And more and more, they find that they are expected to play up evidence, however weak, that seems to support the administration's case, while suppressing evidence that doesn't.

title: From a Speeding Bicycle, a Look at the Brain
description: Early on during this year's Tour de France, the American cyclist Tyler Hamilton stumbled out of a crash with two fractures in his collarbone, an anxious time for him, his teammates and family. To JoAnna Baldwin Mallory and Bayley Silleck, the accident threatened an elaborate project.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: 3COM CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., a provider of broad-based networking systems, said it would take a charge of $800,000 in the fiscal first quarter related to the deal to sell its 511,000-square-foot plant in Rolling Meadows, Ill., for $35.8 million and lease back 43,000 square feet of space.

title: Politics Reasserts Itself in the Debate Over Climate Change and Its Hazards
description: Just as the global climate ebbs and surges, with droughts followed by deluges, so does the politically charged atmosphere that has long surrounded research pointing to potentially disruptive global warming.

description: ''We're from different worlds,'' Ryan, a juvenile delinquent from Chino, Calif., tells Marissa, a stunningly beautiful and, needless to say, troubled rich girl from Orange County.

title: Athletes and Accusations
description: Kobe Bryant, who is scheduled to appear in court tomorrow on charges of sexual assault, is the latest of a long lineup of sports stars who have been charged with crimes against women. The list includes many athletes prominent in their communities as well as nationally famous figures like the baseball Hall of Famer Kirby Puckett and the former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a campaign by Taliban insurgents in Afghanistan to kill Muslim clerics who support the government misstated the number of senior clerics assassinated in recent weeks. It is two, not three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RACKMAN, HONEY
description: RACKMAN -- Honey. We mourn the untimely passing of our founding Board Member, Honey Rackman. A woman of great strength and courage, Honey was a committed advocate for agunot, and passionate in her zeal to remedy their plight. She will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Carol Kaufman Newman, President Robin Bodner, Exec Director Board of Directors, Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance

title: North Korea Moves to Win Some Friends Before Nuclear Talks
description: The tinny loudspeakers fell silent along the 148-mile demilitarized zone this past weekend as North Korea shut down a cross-border propaganda barrage by radio and megaphone that it started in 1970.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Union To Back Gephardt
description: The United Steelworkers of America will announce today that it is backing Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri for the Democratic presidential nomination, union officials said. The union, with 500,000 members in the United States, will make the announcement hours before the nine Democratic presidential candidates conduct a debate at a meeting in Chicago of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council. A top steelworkers' official said Mr. Gephardt was trying hard to win the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement, which requires the backing of unions that represent two-thirds of its 13 million members. Although Mr. Gephardt has far more support than any other candidate, many union leaders say he will have a hard time obtaining the needed two-thirds. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Nets Hire Newman as Assistant Coach
description: The Nets took the first step toward rebuilding their coaching staff yesterday when they announced the hiring of Don Newman as an assistant coach.

title: Making New Efforts to Convince Youths They're Not Invulnerable to H.I.V.

title: Treasury Dept. to Refuse Senate a List of Saudis Investigated for Terror Links
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it would decline to provide the Senate with a list of Saudi individuals and organizations the federal government has investigated for possibly financing Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAMPEL, HARRY A.
description: GAMPEL--Harry A. The Yeshiva University family expresses profound sorrow upon the passing of an outstanding humanitarian, Jewish communal leader, and philanthropist. Mr. Gampel served as a member of the Board of Directors and, more recently, honorary director of our Sy Syms School of Business. With his beloved wife, Edith, he endowed the Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Gampel Communications Center in the Schottenstein Center on our Wilf Campus, and, in recognition of his leadership, he received an honorary doctoral degree from YU in 1989. Our heartfelt condolences to Edith; daughters Margo (and Richard) Absher, Cheryl Gampel Shapiro, Debra (and Bruce) Fischman, and Linda Kornblum; seven grandchildren; and sisters, Marcia Schimmel and Estelle Cushner. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Bernard L. Madoff Chairman SSSB Board of Directors Dr. Charles J. Snow SSSB Dean

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Algerian Held In Bomb Plot
description: The police have arrested an Algerian man they say was planning attacks at resorts along the Costa del Sol in Spain, prosecutors in Hamburg said. The suspect, identified as Abderrazak M., 30, was taken into custody on July 25 on ''urgent suspicion of preparing an explosives attack.'' Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Hilfiger Announces New Chief Executive
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, struggling to regain its allure among Wall Street analysts and customers, ended its search for a chief executive yesterday by naming David F. Dyer, who headed Lands' End during some of its most successful years.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Wildlife Killed Cats
description: A panel investigating 45 cat mutilations in the last year in the Denver region has determined that the deaths were caused by wildlife and not people. Wildlife experts say they believe that owls, foxes, coyotes or even dogs killed the cats. Animal control officers said some attacks were carried out with surgical precision. Reward money will be returned to donors. The authorities in Utah also determined that wildlife caused several cat deaths there when they found fox hair on one cat and cat hair in a nearby fox den. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: For Travelers, Many More Rivers to Cross
description: Blinding rainstorms danced across the New York City region yesterday afternoon, disrupting the homebound rush with widespread flooding that turned some highways, streets and subway tunnels into running rivers, all but closed the three major airports and left low-lying intersections and basements awash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYONS, THOMAS F.

Funeral mass on Wednesday 10:45 A.M. Holy Trinity R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: So What Came After Elgar? This Did
description: Concerts of 20th-century British chamber music are not standard fare in New York, so it was a pleasant surprise when Bargemusic scheduled not one but four consecutive evenings of intriguing and ambitious programs performed by the group Chamber Domaine of London. A lively crowd turned out for the second of these on Friday night, perhaps curious to hear how the English tradition developed after Elgar, one of the few composers on the programs with wide name recognition in the United States.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Sniper Kills U.N. Policeman
description: A United Nations police officer was killed when his car was ambushed in what a police spokesman called a ''planned and deliberate'' attempt. The dead officer, Satish Menon, 43, a major with the Indian police, was the first international police officer killed in Kosovo since the United Nations took over the province. Major Menon was driving in a car with United Nations markings on the highway between Mitrovica and Leposavic when one or more snipers attacked. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Mexican Group Is Latest To Seek to Draw the Expos
description: The Montreal Expos sit four and a half games out of a wild-card berth in the National League playoff race. But where the team will actually reside when this race is over and next season arrives remains a mystery.

title: Speculation About Powell: Main Topic In Washington
description: With President Bush, Congress and aides on vacation, this sleepy capital occupied itself today with a news report about the supposed departure plans of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and by the vehement administration denials that seemed only to fan speculation about his future.

title: As Cancer Returns, Ex-Mayor Quits Hoboken City Council
description: Anthony Russo, the colorful two-term former mayor of Hoboken who was stricken with cancer and left politics in 2001 only to return this year after winning a City Council seat, said yesterday that his cancer had returned and that he would be retiring from politics for good.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas prices fell as mild weather sapped demand from power plants. In New York, natural gas for September delivery fell 24.4 cents, or 5 percent, to $4.63 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: In California, Davis Sues to Avert Recall 'Train Wreck'
description: A suit filed today by Gov. Gray Davis places the state's Republican-dominated Supreme Court at the center of a flurry of challenges to the recall voting while exposing deepening rifts among some Democrats about how to fight the effort to oust Mr. Davis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a vote by the Senate to give the families of passengers killed on international flights the same rights to recover damages as those on domestic flights referred incorrectly to the person who signed the Warsaw Convention of 1929 -- establishing liability limits -- on behalf of Poland. It was the president, not a king. (Poland last had a king in 1795.)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Up 10.4%
description: Global semiconductor sales rose 10.4 percent in the second quarter from a year ago as computer demand rose 8 percent, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday. Chip sales rose to $37.6 billion in the three months through June from $34.1 billion in the same quarter last year, the industry trade group said. The gain was 3.2 percent, from $36.4 billion, in the first quarter. June semiconductor sales totaled $12.54 billion, compared with $12.5 billion in May, the fourth consecutive monthly rise since a seven-month low of $11.83 billion in February.

title: Brutal Death of an Actress Is France's Summertime Drama
description: She was a beautiful and successful actress and the daughter of one of France's best known leading men. He was a musical icon, the lead singer in a band that defined French rock.

title: And the Forecast Is . . .

Survived by her beloved daughter Rachel Russo, brother Gary & Jan Gottesman, step-daughters Taylor and Alexa Pratt, Lita Karp, Dr. Hal and Judy Gottesman, dear Karp and Gottesman cousins. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fairfield: Prison Guard Charged In Killing Of Girlfriend
description: A corrections officer at the South Woods State Prison has been charged with first-degree murder in the shooting death of his ex-girlfriend, who was also an officer there, said the Cumberland County prosecutor, Ronald J. Casella. The man, Keith Norman, 31, is accused of shooting his ex-girlfriend, Teneka Milbourne, 26, just after 6 a.m. Saturday. Mr. Norman surrendered to the police Saturday afternoon. He told them Ms. Milbourne was dropping off the couple's 16-month-old daughter before work when an argument ensued. Mr. Norman then shot Ms. Milbourne in the back of the head, Mr. Casella said. Mr. Norman is being held in $350,000 cash bail and was to be arraigned this morning. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Boston Curator Chosen To Direct the Frick
description: For the first time in its 68-year history the Frick Collection has named a woman to be its director. She is Anne Little Poulet, curator emerita of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The announcement, made to the staff yesterday, came after six months of searching and speculation. Ms. Poulet will replace Samuel Sachs II, who announced in January that he would step down after having run the institution for six years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Borrowers To Share Mortgage Settlement
description: As many as 25,000 New York residents may share in $37 million, part of a legal settlement of nearly half a billion dollars with Household International Inc., a mortgage lender, state officials announced yesterday. Mailings will go out on Aug. 15 to eligible borrowers who took out loans from January 1999 through September 2002. Payments may be as high $1,000. Household International was accused of granting loans that are difficult to repay without the borrower's surrendering his collateral. The company agreed last year to settle allegations that it misled borrowers in more than a dozen states and to pay a record fine of as much as $484 million without admitting guilt. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Lieberman Denounces Tilt to Left
description: Staking out the political center, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut warned today that nominating Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, as the Democrat to face President Bush in 2004 would be ''a ticket to nowhere.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: KOSOVO: SNIPER KILLS U.N. POLICEMAN A United Nations police officer was killed when his car was ambushed in what a police spokesman called a "planned and deliberate" attempt. The dead officer, Satish Menon, 43, a major with the Indian police, was the first international police officer killed in Kosovo since the United Nations took over the province. Major Menon was driving in a car with United Nations markings on the highway between Mitrovica and Leposavic when one or more snipers attacked. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Chiefs Defeat Packers; Storm Shortens Game
description: Priest Holmes looked fine in a brief appearance, and so did Brett Favre as the Kansas City Chiefs beat the Green Bay Packers, 9-0, in the Pro Football Hall of Fame game last night. The game was shortened by lightning and torrential rain.

title: Jet Crashes Into Houses, Killing 2 on Board
description: A Learjet attempting to land here this morning slammed through several houses and crashed short of the runway, killing the two pilots on board and scattering debris for nearly a quarter-mile before tumbling into a river, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Steel Reports Loss on Personnel Costs

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Faults L.I.R.R. In Response To Heart Attack
description: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority report released yesterday blamed miscommunication within the Long Island Rail Road staff for the delayed response to a passenger's heart attack on a Huntington train last year. The train passed two stations before stopping for an ambulance, and the passenger died. The report, by the authority's inspector general, blamed malfunctioning radios, an unexplained gap before an ambulance was called and confusion among the car crew, the engineer driving the train, the dispatchers, the control towers and the police. Railroad officials said they agreed with the report and would carry out the procedural changes it recommended, including making clearer assessments of medical emergencies. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Mayor Hopes to Refinance Debt Over Pataki's Objections
description: The Bloomberg administration is rushing to get a municipal bond deal to market before the Pataki administration, which opposes the plan, can quash it.

description: Chohung Bank reported a loss of 419.3 billion won ($353 million) in the first six months of this year in contrast to a profit of 53.9 billion won in the first six months of last year. The loss was attributed largely to delinquencies on credit-card loans as well as credit extended to troubled companies. Chohung Bank is joining the Shinhan Financial Group, which agreed to buy the government's 80 percent stake in the bank. Shinhan Financial is dominated by Shinhan Bank, but Chohung will operate independently for three years. Don Kirk (NYT)

Railroad officials said they agreed with the report and would carry out the procedural changes it recommended, including making clearer assessments of medical emergencies. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

description: An American civilian was killed today when the mail truck he was driving was blown up by a homemade explosive north of the town of Tikrit, military officials said here today.

A brief menu accompanies the cocktails, including tender, spicy spareribs sizzled on a big grill by ABE DE LA HOUSSAYE, formerly of Texarkana, the consulting chef.

title: Sports of The Times; No Losing Sleep Over Losing Games
description: I LOVE my profession, I really do. But I am baffled by a persistent ambivalence in sports journalism when it comes to athletes and money. We acknowledge that sports is big business, but in our hearts, we seem to resent the business aspect of games that turn young athletes into multimillionaires. For the last three years, Alex Rodriguez of the Texas Rangers has been Exhibit A of our ambivalence.

title: Diller's Company Grows, but Not Enough for Investors
description: Strong growth in travel and a rebound in television shopping helped InterActiveCorp post slightly better revenue for the second quarter than had been expected.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: SUSPECTS TIED TO HOTEL BOMBING The authorities said two suspected terrorists detained by the police in Mombasa last week were Kenyans of Yemeni origin. Investigators have tied the two, and a third man who got away, to the bombing of a beach-front hotel in the coastal resort last November. One of the men detonated a hand grenade while in the back of a police van last week, killing himself and an officer. His associate was transferred to Nairobi, where he is being interrogated by antiterrorism officers. The American Embassy in Nairobi, which has criticized Kenya in the past as being sluggish in cracking down on terrorists, praised the investigation. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: HERCULES, MAKER OF SPECIALTY CHEMICALS, HAS PROFIT
description: Hercules Inc., a troubled maker of specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it had a profit in the second quarter as higher sales of thickeners and fibers helped its bottom line. Net income was $32 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with a loss of $11 million, or 10 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations, excluding items, totaled $25 million, or 23 cents a share, beating an estimate of 21 cents a share by analysts. Revenue grew 8 percent, to $472 million from $437 million. The company, based in Wilmington, Del., is burdened by debt and was the subject of a proxy fight last month.

title: Strahan Breaks a Small Toe
description: Michael Strahan broke the small toe on his right foot in practice Monday and was held out of today's afternoon practice. Strahan and Coach Jim Fassel said the injury was not serious, but Strahan could miss the Giants' preseason opener Thursday against the New England Patriots in Foxboro, Mass.

title: Cuke of Another Color, and None of the Length
description: What looks like a lemon and tastes like a cucumber? A lemon cucumber, of course. This uncommon heirloom variety is actually a tad sweeter than a regular cucumber, and its nice, broad slices are great in sandwiches. Ray Bradley of Bradley Farms in New Paltz, N.Y., sells lemon cucumbers for $2 a pound at the Greenmarkets at 97th Street and Columbus Avenue on Fridays and Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn on Saturdays; he expects to have them until fall. Honey Hollow Farms of Middleburgh, N.Y., will start selling the cucumbers in a week or so at the Union Square Greenmarket on Mondays and Fridays. It will offer other heirlooms, too, like bianco lungos, white with white spines, and Boothby's blonds, yellow with black spines.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Credit Suisse Profit Soars
description: Second-quarter profit swelled at the Credit Suisse Group, far exceeding analysts' predictions, aided by a leaner business and an upswing in investment banking. Profits surged 1.35 billion francs in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of 579 million francs in the second quarter of 2002. Credit Suisse earned 2 billion francs in the first half of this year after losing a record-breaking 3.3 billion francs for all of last year. Credit Suisse has staged one of the strongest turnarounds the financial services industry, analysts said. Investment banking revenue rose 32 percent year-on-year to 628 million francs. The private banking division earned 469 million francs, unchanged from the period last year. Shares in Credit Suisse jumped 4.4 percent, to end the trading day at 43.7 francs. Alison Langley (NYT)

A graduate of both Juilliard and Parsons Art School, she created beauty and art all her life, was a dedicated conservationist, and will be remembered and greatly missed by family and friends for the nets of love she cast. Her life, affirming exuberance, sardonic wit and passionate independence. For more information call ''Wien & Wien Memorial Chapels'', 800-322-0533

title: Giants Exhale as Joseph Ends Holdout
description: By the end of William Joseph's days in the National Football League, few people will probably remember the cat-and-mouse negotiation that opened his stay with the Giants, a career that finally began when his sizable hand gripped an ink pen and he signed a contract at 2:30 a.m. today at the State University at Albany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, RUTHIE
description: COHN--Ruthie. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Ruthie Cohn, beloved sister of Nina Weiner. We extend our deepest condolences to Nina and her family Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Power Failure Has Workers At a Hospital Struggling
description: A power failure forced New York University Medical Center to shut its emergency room and turn away visitors and some patients yesterday, as the hospital staff struggled with limited use of the air-conditioning, computers and other equipment.

title: U.S. Expected to Resume Patrols Over Colombia for Drug Flights
description: President Bush is expected to approve the resumption of anti-drug surveillance flights in Colombia that result in the forcible grounding or destruction of planes suspected of smuggling narcotics, officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Warplanes From Russia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, meeting with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad in Kuala Lumpur, signed a $900 million deal to sell Sukhoi fighter planes to Malaysia. Mr. Putin said he hoped that ''from this Malaysian platform, Russian aviation techniques can be moved to the region of Southeast Asia.'' Military experts said the Su-30MK's will be the most powerful combat planes ever operated by a country in the region, Reuters reported. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: More Charges For Ex-Leader
description: Former President Frederick Chiluba was arrested and charged with embezzling more than $30 million in public funds during his tenure, adding to his legal woes. The former leader, who left office in December 2001, now faces more than 100 counts of theft. President Levy Mwanawasa, who began the corruption investigation, once served as Mr. Chiluba's vice president. He resigned in 1994 to protest what he regarded as the Chiluba administration's tolerance of graft. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Suspects Tied To Hotel Bombing
description: The authorities said two suspected terrorists detained by the police in Mombasa last week were Kenyans of Yemeni origin. Investigators have tied the two, and a third man who got away, to the bombing of a beach-front hotel in the coastal resort last November. One of the men detonated a hand grenade while in the back of a police van last week, killing himself and an officer. His associate was transferred to Nairobi, where he is being interrogated by antiterrorism officers. The American Embassy in Nairobi, which has criticized Kenya in the past as being sluggish in cracking down on terrorists, praised the investigation. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular and Nextwave Sign Deal
description: Cingular, a leading wireless phone company, has signed an agreement to buy wireless licenses for 34 markets from NextWave Telecom for $1.4 billion, the companies said yesterday. The sale, representing about one-fifth of NextWave's spectrum licenses, is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission and the federal bankruptcy court that is overseeing NextWave's reorganization. Other companies have the right to bid a higher price. NextWave will maintain a presence in 20 of the 34 markets. The licenses would give Cingular, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC, room to grow in some of the most lucrative urban markets, including Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington. In addition, the deal will give entry into a handful of other markets, including El Paso, Portland, Ore., and Salt Lake City. Executives of NextWave, which owns licenses in 95 of the largest markets nationwide, said the money would be used to pay the debt owed the F.C.C. and to help finance future ventures as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: City Officials Suggest a Shot In a Police Raid Was Accidental
description: City officials said yesterday that the police shooting of an unarmed woman during a raid on a basement apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, appeared to have been an accident, following a detective's brief struggle to open the door to a bathroom where the woman was hiding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN RAALTE, BYRON (BUDDY)
description: VAN RAALTE--Byron (Buddy) of Lawrence, NY on August 4. Beloved husband and best friend of his darling Enid (nee Godnick). Most loving and adored father of Dr. Polly Van Raalte and Susan Van Raalte Hershman. Cherished father-in-law of Dr. Elliott Hershman. A very special Grandpa to Todd and Danny Hershman. Brother of Barbara and Sandy Elias and Kathryn Feidelson. Dearest brother-in-law of Natalie G. and the late Michael Ressner, and the late Bob and Audrey Godnick. Uncle of the late John W. Ressner, David Lorne and Julie Godnick, Nancy and Margaret Elias, and Emily, Ann and John Feidelson. Graduate of Phillips Andover Academy and Harvard College, 1943. Captain US Army World War II. Retired businessman. Former President of the Lawrence Association. ''In quietness and confidence shall be your strength.'' Services private.

title: The Quest for a Peaceful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENNI, THERESA (NEE PERRECA)
description: ENNI--Theresa (nee Perreca), beloved wife of Serge Enni, passed to eternal life on August 2, 2003. A lovely lady of great compassion, love & kindness to all who knew her.

title: Abbas Cancels Meeting With Sharon Over Prisoner Issue
description: The Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, today canceled talks scheduled for Wednesday with his Israeli counterpart, Ariel Sharon, to protest a planned release of Palestinian prisoners as a damaging diplomatic stunt, Palestinian officials said.

title: Deal Is Sought on Plan for Train to Meadowlands
description: New Jersey officials say they are trying to reach an agreement on a proposal to bring train service to the Meadowlands Sports Complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'BYRNE, FRANCIS M.
description: O'BYRNE--Francis M. On August 3, 2003. Retired Lieutenant N.Y.P.D., Former Special Assistant to the Police Commissioner and Senior Vice President Support Services for St. Vincent's Hospital, New York City. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor (nee Casey). Loving father of Brian, Barbara Gogan, Michael and Ellen Mauser. Fond father-in-law of Patrick Gogan, Donna O'Byrne and John Mauser. Adored grandfather of Patrick and Casey Gogan, Erin and Michael O'Byrne and Christian and Keelin Mauser. Loving brother of John. Reposing Riverdale on Hudson Funeral Home, 610 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx (W. 261st Street). Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 1 P.M., St. Barnabas R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Feng Shui and Vegan Fare Battle a Neighborhood Curse
description: IF you noticed them at all, you would think they were part of the restaurant's new design: two small octagons outside, each with a mirror at its center. The point? To protect the restaurant from the building across the street, whose sharp edges, according to Judith Wendell, a feng shui consultant, ''create a knifelike effect on the restaurant's energy, cutting into it -- so we're reflecting it back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORBATY, JOY MARION
description: GORBATY--Joy Marion. For Joy--my old beauty--we have seen the elephant and it is grand-Love, Normy

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cisco's Profit Climbs a Bit, But Sales Slowed in Quarter

title: Shortchanging Security
description: The Associated Press headline picked up by newspapers across the country last week said it all: ''Air Marshal Program Could Be Cut, Despite Hijacking Threat.'' That was not exactly welcome news to millions of Americans at the height of the summer travel season, and the ensuing uproar helped kill the proposed spending cuts. Yet sadly enough, the story line was all too familiar. The Bush administration and Congressional leaders in Washington have been too reluctant to devote enough resources to protect the nation against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDYNSKI, JACOB
description: LANDYNSKI--Jacob. On July 29, 2003. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of New School University mourn the loss of Jacob Landynski, Professor and former Chair of Political Science at the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science for over 40 years. His scholarly work, cited in over a dozen Supreme Court opinions, focused on the intersection between governmental power and individual rights. His commitment to teaching was unparalleled. Our condolences to his wife, Miriam; four daughters, Suri, Sagie, Tevorah, and Malka; three sons, Moshe, Pinchas, and Azrohom; and many grandchildren. Philip Scaturro, Chairman, Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President, New School University Richard J. Bernstein, Dean, Graduate Faculty

title: Political Memo; As Mayor Misspeaks, City Runs To the Bank
description: For a Republican mayor looking to restore his credentials as a fiscal conservative, it was a politically perfect thought: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced last week that he was ''reasonably confident'' he would be able to repeal three of the major tax increases imposed on city residents this year.

title: Cuke of Another Color, And None of the Length
description: What looks like a lemon and tastes like a cucumber? A lemon cucumber, of course. This uncommon heirloom variety is actually a tad sweeter than a regular cucumber, and its nice, broad slices are great in sandwiches. Ray Bradley, left, of Bradley Farms in New Paltz, N.Y., sells lemon cucumbers for $2 a pound at the Greenmarkets at 97th Street and Columbus Avenue on Fridays and Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn on Saturdays; he expects to have them until fall. Honey Hollow Farms of Middleburgh, N.Y., will start selling the cucumbers in a week or so at the Union Square Greenmarket on Mondays and Fridays. It will offer other heirlooms, too, like bianco lungos, white with white spines, and Boothby's blonds, yellow with black spines.

title: Nets Hire Newman As Assistant Coach
description: The Nets took the first step toward rebuilding their coaching staff yesterday when they announced the hiring of Don Newman as an assistant coach.

title: Profit Falls By 9.7% At Toyota
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest automaker, said today that a stronger yen and the adoption of new accounting rules pushed its profit lower by 9.7 percent in the latest quarter.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: BHUTTO SENTENCED IN SWITZERLAND A Swiss magistrate has found former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her husband guilty of money laundering. They were given six-month suspended jail terms, fined $50,000 each and were ordered to pay $11 million to the Pakistani government. The six-year-long case alleged that Ms. Bhutto, who lives in exile in London and Dubai, and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, deposited in Swiss accounts $10 million given them by a Swiss company in exchange for a contract in Pakistan. The couple said they would appeal. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Smoke and Dust at Ground Zero Is Linked to Smaller Babies
description: Scientists say they have measured a slight but significant rise in the percentage of small babies born to women who were around the World Trade Center during or after the terror attack compared with babies of a large sample of pregnant women who were elsewhere at the time.

title: Anglican Leaders Warn of Global Schism Over Gay Bishop
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 6  Anglican church leaders across Africa, where homosexuality is publicly scorned, today denounced an Episcopal Church USA decision to install an openly gay bishop, and they predicted a schism within the global Anglican Communion unless that action was overturned.

title: GENERAL MILLS' PENSION PLANS FALL SHORT BY $224 MILLION
description: General Mills reported yesterday that its pension plans were underfinanced by $224 million at the end of the 2003 fiscal year on May 25, compared with being overfinanced by $571 million a year before. The company plans to contribute less than $10 million toward the pension plans in the current fiscal year, according to a regulatory filing released by the Securities and Exchange Commission. General Mills' other retirement benefit plans were underfinanced by $612 million as of May 25, widened from $378 million a year earlier. The weak stock market in recent years has opened a financing gap in the pension plans of many corporations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHILLINGER, MORTON, PH.D.
description: SCHILLINGER -- Morton, Ph.D., ABPP. Section V, Psychologist Psychoanalyst Clinicians, of the Division of Psychoanalysis of the American Psychological Association mourns the loss of its president, colleague, leader and friend. Dr. Schillinger gave much to American psychoanalytic psychology; over his long and distinguished career he was its devoted champion and protector. His energy, warmth and generosity will be greatly missed.

title: And Now, Absurd TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Piers as Parks Downtown
description: Lower Manhattan's residents face a long period of reconstruction before the promise of a redesigned World Trade Center site becomes reality. In the meantime, there is something that can be done quickly and relatively inexpensively to reassure people who remain committed to the area, and that is to proceed expeditiously with the next downtown segment of the Hudson River Park.

title: Lottery Numbers
Rescue Its Economy
description: Now that the United States and North Korea have finally agreed to talk, the issue is what to talk about. A priority of the Bush administration, as well as its predecessors, has long been the dismantling of the North's nuclear-weapons program. This goal is realistic, but only if the United States is prepared to engage North Korea on a wide range of issues -- especially its failed economy.

title: Hope Rises for Patient Cooling Therapy
description: Israel Singer was slipping into a coma after suffering a stroke as his wife, Vicki, arrived at the hospital. ''They took my daughter and me aside and suggested a D.N.R. -- do not resuscitate,'' she recalled. ''They said he would definitely die'' or, at best, be in a vegetative state.
