description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Royal Bank Reports Profit Rise
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group reported a 25 percent jump in pretax profit during the first half of 2003, to 2.9 billion euros ($4.6 billion). Low interest rates encouraged consumers to take out new loans, but also cut into the bank's profit margins. The bank, which has been buying up smaller competitors on both sides of the Atlantic, said that acquisitions accounted for only 20 percent of its growth over the six months ended June 30. Shares closed down 5 percent on the London Stock Exchange, to 1,657 pence. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Safety at Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: German TV Group's Creditors Accept Hollywood Mogul's Offer
description: Haim Saban's dogged pursuit of a foothold in the German television market cleared a decisive hurdle yesterday, as creditors of the bankrupt KirchMedia empire accepted his $1.3 billion offer for control of ProSiebenSat.1, one of the country's leading broadcasters.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: LG Bid For Hanaro Is Blocked
description: Shareholders of Hanaro Telecom narrowly defeated a bid by the LG Group to take over the company as part of a push by LG, which already has a 13 percent stake in Hanaro, to compete with KT, the nation's dominant broadband Internet provider. The takeover bid failed when only 62 percent of the shareholders voted for the plan, which involved making a 500-billion-won rights issue. Hanaro last month rejected an offer from a consortium led by the American International Group to buy new Hanaro shares for $450 million and take over $600 million of Hanaro's debts. LG's offer required two-thirds shareholder approval. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: France Confirms Plan To Help Rescue Alstom
description: The French government showed its continued willingness to bail out struggling French businesses today when it confirmed reports that it intends to buy up to 30 percent of the privately owned French industrial group Alstom to prevent the company from going bankrupt.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Joins Fight Against California Recall
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California, turning to one of the Democratic Party's traditional pillars of support, received the backing today of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in his recall election.

title: Saintly Spirit Remembered, in a Truly Balkan Way
description: Mother Teresa will soon become a saint. But this celebration of the divine in a human being has turned out to be as good a moment as any to fight about all the worldly things that usually get fought about in the Balkans: namely, religion, ethnicity and history.

title: A Public School For Gay Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Karl Rove's Water Policy
description: It's hardly news that Karl Rove, President Bush's political strategist, keeps a hawklike eye on domestic policies emerging from the executive branch, the better to make sure that everything meshes with his boss's political interests and those of the Republican Party. Yet rarely have Mr. Rove's efforts to bend policy to politics been more transparent than his intervention in a seemingly remote dispute involving water rights in Oregon's Klamath River basin. As detailed in a Wall Street Journal report last week, Mr. Rove has worked almost obsessively behind the scenes to ensure that the outcome satisfies the party's agricultural base at the expense of conservationists and Indian tribes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIVINGSTON, ROLAND
description: LIVINGSTON--Roland. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Roland Livingston associated with The Times from April 1, 1976.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Itau Posts 42% Profit Rise
description: Brazil's No. 2 private bank, Itau, posted first-half profit of 1.49 billion reais, or $460 million, 42 percent higher than in the period last year, the bank announced. Second-quarter net profit was 776 million reais, compared with 544 million reais a year earlier. First-quarter profits this year were 714 million reais. Soaring interest rates in Brazil -- the central bank's overnight base rate is at 24.5 percent -- have helped protect banks from the strong economic downturn. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VENTRESCA, LOUIS N.
description: VENTRESCA--Louis N. I mourn the untimely passing of a dedicated, kind and compassionate man. His dedication to the Sherry Netherland and its employees was unprecedented. He will be sorely missed. Marilyn Q. Lipman

title: Flavorful Fishland
description: To the Editor:

title: On Oahu, the High Cost of an Archaeological Find
description: After setting a brush fire that burned out of control late last month and scorched half of this artillery and infantry training range, on land considered sacred by many Hawaiians, the Army says a blessing of sorts has emerged. The fire exposed about two dozen previously unknown cultural sites here that experts say will add to the knowledge of Hawaiian life in the centuries before Europeans arrived.

title: KLM Delays Start of Baghdad Flights
description: Don't count on that window-seat view of Baghdad's palm-lined boulevards just yet.

title: Storms Cause 2nd Day of Flooding; 2 New Jersey Preschools Are Evacuated
description: A line of heavy rains moved from southern New Jersey to the lower Hudson Valley yesterday, soaking basements, forcing scattered evacuations and submerging highways during the evening rush. It was a repeat of the flooding that swept across the New York region a day earlier.

title: Neocon Coup at the Department d'tat
description: Let others fight over whether the war in Iraq was a neocon vigilante action disrupting diplomacy. The neocons have moved on to a vigilante action to occupy diplomacy.

title: The Jakarta Bombing
description: Indonesia, hit yesterday by its second high- profile terrorist bombing in less than a year, is acquiring a reputation as a soft target for international terrorism. The country's oil, large Muslim population and strategic location are all contributing factors. But as important as anything are the cumulative effects of chronic misgovernment.

title: Europe Accuses Microsoft of Continuing Antitrust Abuses
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 6  Microsoft has continued to abuse its dominance of the software market and may be subject to fines, the European Commission said today in a preliminary ruling in its long-running antitrust case against the company.

title: The Haves and Have-Nots Reside On Both Sides of Liberian Capital
description: Rebel-held Monrovia's only hospital is inside a brewery. Its operating table is a long wooden desk. The surgeon, who cleans shrapnel wounds, extracts bullets and ties up intestines punctured by gunshots, is a nurse who used to work at a maternity clinic. This afternoon, a patient with a fist-sized wound in his arm was howling in pain. The hospital is almost out of painkillers, as well as medications for its 50 cholera patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GETRAER, HERBERT
description: GETRAER--Herbert, of Tucson, AZ, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. Devoted husband of 55 years to Lita, father of Susan and Marty, and father-in-law of Saunda, adoring grandfather of Maris, Michael, Ira and Ali. Burial was Sunday at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Special Education Overhaul Is Criticized as Too Much, Too Soon
description: The chairwoman of the City Council's Education Committee said yesterday that Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein might be moving too quickly to dismantle the bureaucracy that oversees special education.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On Barriers In Chinatown
description: A state judge has ruled that the New York Police Department must take the first steps toward removing security barricades that have angered Chinatown residents, but it stopped short of ordering the reopening of the street. The barricades, north on Park Row from Frankfort Street to Chatham Square, helped protect nearby police headquarters after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack. But Chinatown residents complained they were not consulted about the street closing and were unable to invite family members or friends to their homes. In a decision Monday, Justice Walter B. Tolub of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered the department to have an independent agency conduct an environmental analysis of traffic congestion and pollution. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department was studying the ruling, but that ''obviously we'll do whatever the court directs us to do.'' Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Art What You Eat: A Museum View
description: Arcimboldo wasn't the first artist to have fun with vegetables. During the Renaissance, he became famous for creating portraits out of tomatoes, lettuce, squash and the like. Contemporary artists have continued in the same vein, as is clearly demonstrated by ''Food Matters: Explorations in Contemporary Art,'' an exhibition opening on Sunday at the Katonah Museum of Art. One of Margaret Adachi's ''Running Chickens,'' right, is in the show, as are a beaded jar of Marshmallow Fluff and anthropomorphic photographs of popped corn. During the show, which runs through Oct. 26, the museum will hold events like a chocolate-making session and a children's class in making marzipan treats for Halloween. The museum is at Route 22 and Jay Street in Katonah, N.Y. Information: (914) 232-9555, or www.katonah-museum.org.

title: Fire at Brooklyn Sewage Plant Sends Stench Across Borough
description: A fire last night at a major sewage treatment plant in Sheepshead Bay sent a putrid smell drifting across Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Two Scripts on an Italian Stage
description: MANY New Yorkers, if asked to name the finest Italian restaurant in the city, would instinctively answer, ''San Domenico.'' With its high visibility, high prices and general air of luxury, the restaurant has served as a flagship for serious Italian cuisine since it opened in 1988. Tony May, the owner, has kept it that way through his unflagging efforts to promote Italian wine and Italian ingredients, and his remarkable ability to keep top talent in the kitchen.

title: The Quest for a Peaceful Death (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Posts Rise In Revenue
description: Ryanair, the low-cost airline, reported revenue of 245.2 million euros ($278.3 million) for the three months to the end of June, a 26 percent increase from last year, despite a drop in yields and average load factor, the proportion of passengers to available seats. After-tax profit for the quarter grew 4 percent, to 40.5 million euros ($46 million), including the 3.3 million euro ($3.7 million) cost of Buzz, the Royal Dutch KLM subsidiary that Ryanair bought in April. In a statement, the chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said that the record number of passengers -- 5.1 million people flew with Ryanair in the quarter -- came as a result of the airline's opening of 50 new routes and hubs outside Milan and Stockholm. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOL, PHILIP
description: SOKOL--Philip. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its member, beloved husband and father of Rose and Sam Sokol. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: INDONESIA BOMBING KILLS AT LEAST 10 IN MIDDAY ATTACK
description: A sport utility vehicle packed with explosives blew up here in Indonesia's capital early Tuesday afternoon, killing at least 10, and as many as 15, people and wounding nearly 150 in a Marriott hotel, a large restaurant and an office building. It was the most devastating attack on Indonesian soil since the twin blasts in Bali last October.

title: Europe Sizzles and Suffers in a Summer of Merciless Heat
description: A sweaty sense of dislocation was palpable today throughout Europe, where unusually high temperatures and a summerlong dearth of rain have damaged crops, fanned wildfires, and left residents and tourists baking, broiling and steaming as seldom before.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Thursday about the Midtown International Theater Festival in Manhattan referred incorrectly to an honor for the actress Lilia Skala, the subject of a play by her granddaughter that was part of the festival. While she was nominated for an Academy Award for her portrayal of a nun in the 1963 film ''Lilies of the Field,'' she did not win the award.

title: Inspired by the Chinese, And Reshaped at Home
description: AS much as I believe in an honest repertory in the kitchen -- we all return to foods we feel comfortable cooking and eating -- there is something exhilarating about stretching beyond the familiar.

description: Though Shirley Was a Gerbil at the Time

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHILDS, LUCINDA E.
description: CHILDS--Lucinda E., 88, on August 1, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Edward P. Childs. Adored mother of Eleanor Sackett, choreographer Lucinda Childs and Edward P. Childs Jr. Cherished by seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Authentication For Illegal Nickel
description: A coin kept in a closet for four decades was authenticated as the last of five that were illegally minted 90 years ago, making it worth $1 million. The 1913 Liberty Head nickel was authenticated by six experts the American Numismatic Association brought together in Baltimore. In May, Bowers and Merena Galleries, the dealer and auction house in Mandeville, La., offered a $1 million reward for the coin. It was brought to light by the heirs of George Walton, a North Carolina dealer who died in 1962. The heirs had been unsure of its authenticity, and now say they have no intention of selling it. The Liberty Head nickel was eliminated in 1912; the five dated 1913 may have been struck by a mint official.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDNER, ALFRED
description: GOLDNER--Alfred. Of Boynton Beach, Florida on August 4, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy, devoted father of Joanne and Penny, loving grandfather of Jonathan, David and Megan, fatherin-law of Richard and Rick. Services private.

description: To the Editor:

title: Tax on Absentee Landlords Is Criticized as Hard on Poor
description: A new city property tax surcharge on absentee landlords who rent out one- to three-family homes will hit low-income and minority neighborhoods the hardest, according to a report issued yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Leading In West Nile Cases
description: State health officials say Colorado leads the nation in human cases of West Nile virus this year, with 72, more than three times any other state's total. A 77-year-old from Greeley died last week from the mosquito-borne disease. Last year, Colorado had 13 cases, none fatal. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: A Public School For Gay Students
description: To the Editor:

title: In Most of the U.S., A House Is a Home But Not a Bonanza
description: On a tree-filled boulevard known as Doctors' Row, the four- and five-bedroom brick Tudor homes that are the jewels of this city's housing stock were selling for about $150,000 two decades ago. At the time, some homes in the nation's most desirable suburbs, like Brookline, Mass.; Sausalito, Calif.; and Great Neck, N.Y., cost the same.

title: Army Is Devising Ways To Reorganize Its Forces
description: The Army, stretched by commitments in Iraq and stretching to prove it can be as nimble as the Air Force, the Navy and the Marine Corps, is undertaking dramatic changes in the way it organizes and deploys troops in combat, a senior Army general said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALAMARI, DONALD L.
description: CALAMARI -- Donald L. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Donald Calamari, beloved brother of Frank Calamari, President and Chief Executive Officer of Calvary Hospital and a Board member of GNYHA. We extend our sincere condolences to the Calamari family and their many friends. Stanley Brezenoff, Chair Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

title: Looking on the Bright Side About North Korea
description: I don't know much about the Discovery Channel's new documentary series ''Discovery Spotlight,'' which is produced in association with The New York Times. But watching its portrait of the Korean nuclear issue, I kept thinking ''Frontline Lite.'' In format (hourlong documentary), tone (urgent crises breathlessly described by bass-voiced narrator) and political slant (liberal with a veneer of objectivity, to judge by this example), ''Spotlight'' emulates the veteran PBS series right down to the look and feel of its opening credits.

title: A Summer Alternative From Austria
description: FOR at least a decade, Austrian winemakers have been turning up in the wine capitals of the world and whispering in the ear of anyone who would listen: ''Austrian wines are the wine world's best-kept secret.'' Well, they are a secret no longer.

title: Beady-Eyed Stinkers Feast on Urban Fringes
description: The day the vultures arrived here was a moment made for Hitchcock.

title: Comeback by Piazza Undergoes Tweaking
description: By Mike Piazza's logic, if the Mets had more games like tonight's, his move to first base would be delayed indefinitely.

title: John L. Selover, 72, Christian Scientist Newspaper Publisher
description: John Lewis Selover, vice chairman of the Christian Science board of directors and publisher of The Christian Science Monitor, died on Friday at his home in Boston. He was 72.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Doubling Of Sales Is Seen By 2008
description: Sales made over the Internet will more than double to $229.9 billion and account for 10 percent of domestic retail sales in 2008 as more people use the Web for purchases, according to Forrester Research. About five million American households will make their first online purchases each year for the next five years, said Forrester, which is based in Cambridge, Mass. In 2008, 63 million American homes will be shopping on the Internet, it said. Companies like Amazon.com and eBay forecast continued growth as more people become comfortable with Internet shopping. Web sales will rise as more people buy groceries from companies like Safeway and the Peapod unit of Royal Ahold, and other fast-growing categories will include sporting goods and home goods, Forrester said. Domestic shoppers will spend almost $96 billion on Internet purchases this year, it said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Penalties Raised For Sleepy Drivers
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed a bill yesterday that sharply raises penalties against drivers who fall asleep at the wheel and cause fatal accidents. The law was prompted by the death of Maggie McDonnell, 20, who was killed in a 1997 crash caused by Michael Coleman, a driver who had been sleepless for more than 30 hours. He was fined $200. Under the new law, a driver who has gone without sleep for 24 hours and causes a fatal accident may be fined up to $150,000 and charged with vehicular homicide, which carries a sentence of up to 10 years in prison.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Program For Dean's Son After Theft
description: The son of Howard Dean, the Democratic presidential hopeful, will join a diversion program for being involved in stealing alcohol from the Burlington Country Club. The boy, Paul Dean, 17, will appear before a diversion board, a panel of citizens who sentence first-time offenders who admit culpability. The police charged Mr. Dean and four others with larceny in June. Prosecutors said they recommended diversion for all five because none had a record. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHUTICK, DR. LILLIAN
description: CHUTICK--Dr. Lillian. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the recent passing of a longtime Benefactor who, with her late beloved sister, Dr. Rebecca Chutick, established scholarships and many facilities within the University's various schools, namely the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology, and the Philip and Sarah Belz School of Jewish Music. May her memory serve as a source of abiding blessing in our midst. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: One Curriculum, Many Skeptics
description: Exhaling a long, smoky sigh during a cigarette break in his weeklong training for the city's new school literacy curriculum, David Strahl did not seem particularly ''invested.''

title: Recipe: Weakfish Grilled Over Basil
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: MERCK SETS DATE FOR SPINOFF OF MEDCO HEALTH SOLUTIONS
description: Merck & Company plans to spin off Medco Health Solutions, its pharmacy-benefits manager unit, on Aug. 19. Trading in Medco will begin Friday on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol MHS. Merck investors will get a special dividend of 0.1206 shares of Medco common stock for each share held as of Aug. 12, the company, based in Whitehouse, N.J., said yesterday. Merck, which wants to focus on the faster-growing pharmaceuticals business, announced the plan in April after calling off an initial public offering for Medco for lack of investor interest.

title: Hyundai and Union End 7-Week Strike
description: ULSAN, South Korea, Aug. 6  The signs on the walls of the union offices in the Hyundai Motor complex here proclaim a dream that had seemed all but impossible when the company's 39,000 workers walked off the job on June 20.

title: Safety at Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Peanut Butter And Chicken (No Jelly)
description: THAT peanut butter is relegated to the sandwich while sesame butter (tahini) is seen as an exotic food item is one of the wonderfully preposterous anomalies of American cooking. In the rest of the world, especially Asia, peanuts are special, used not only as a garnish but as a main ingredient in sauces.

title: Judge Who Ruled on Forests Is Faulted for Energy Holdings
description: Environmental advocacy groups filed an ethics complaint yesterday against a judge who struck down a nationwide land conservation rule last month. The groups say the judge, Clarence A. Brimmer of Federal District Court in Wyoming, had $400,000 to $1.1 million invested in the oil and gas industries, which stand to benefit from his ruling.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PARK PLACE ENTERTAINMENT CORP., Las Vegas, the world's largest casino operator, may have its credit rating cut to below investment grade by Standard & Poor's because it plans to build a casino near Chicago. Standard & Poor's said Park Place should pay down debt before expanding.

title: Text of European Competition Commission Statement on Microsoft
description: The following is the text of a statement from the European Union's Competition Commission as posted on the Commission's web site, http://europa.eu.int/comm/competition/index_en.html

title: Two Sides Differ On State of Talks For Verizon Pact
description: Verizon Communications indicated yesterday that it was nearing an agreement with its two main unions, but a spokesman for the company's largest union said little progress was being made.

title: A Public School For Gay Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * BiZBash Media, New York, which specializes in the event marketing and event planning industries, granted publishing and trade-show licenses in Florida and Canada. In Florida, a new company, BiZBashFla, Miami, is being formed by Hardy Katz, Peter Haines and Stanley Schwartz, who own Communications and Show Management and Industry Publications Inc. In Canada, the licensee is Stanley Shenkman, a partner in International Media Advertising, Toronto.

title: Recipe: Flounder in Saor
description: Time: 40 minutes

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Government Raises Outlook
description: Japan's government raised its monthly outlook for the economy for the first time since March, encouraged by rising exports and stock prices. The cabinet office said the American economy was showing signs of change, helping increase shipments overseas. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   TEPPERBERG, BENJAMIN
description: TEPPERBERG -- Benjamin. 08/15/75 -- 08/06/78. Beloved son, brother and twin. 25 long years without you

title: Soriano's Hands the Cause of His Slump
description: If the baseball gods constructed the perfect player, part by part, they might take the hands and wrists of Alfonso Soriano. For Soriano, the Yankees' second baseman, the foundation of greatness is in his ability to whip his wrists through the hitting zone, giving him some of the game's quickest hands.

title: A Khomeini Breaks With His Lineage to Back U.S.
description: The grandson of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the strident Iranian cleric who built his Islamic revolution on a platform of attacking all things American, said today that the overthrow of Saddam Hussein would allow long-awaited freedoms to flourish throughout the region, and if they did not, United States intervention would be welcomed by most Iranians.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: FEDERAL AGENCIES CHALLENGED ON INDIAN POINT /> Local officials are asking the federal government for internal data on how it concluded that the Indian Point nuclear power plant's public evacuation plan was sound. The county executives of Westchester and Rockland have filed Freedom of Information requests with the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The federal approvals have angered the local residents and the county governments that have refused to certify the evacuation plan for the plant, in Buchanan, N.Y.

title: Nassau to Try To Get Drugs For Residents At a Discount
description: Nassau County officials announced today that they were setting up a discount plan for prescription drugs that could save 350,000 residents without insurance or drug coverage millions of dollars in pharmacy bills.

title: So Beer Keeps Its Head in a Storm
description: Just because the boat is rocking, your bottle of beer needn't end up overboard. The L'il Sucker, a three-inch neoprene disk, grabs a bottle, a can or a glass and holds it by suction to almost any flat plane, even at a sharp tilt.

title: Whistle-Wetters That Tend Toward the Dry
description: When my children were young, I gave them orange juice mixed with sparkling water instead of soda. Steve Hersh had the same idea, and turned it into a brand: GuS Grown-up Soda. Mr. Hersh said he was inspired to create his modestly sweetened sodas by his father, who added seltzer to everything. Most flavors have less than 100 calories in 12 ounces, compared with 140 or so for traditional sodas. Dry Valencia Orange, Dry Star Ruby Grapefruit, Extra Dry Ginger Ale and my favorite, Dry Meyer Lemon, are $1.50 to $2 a bottle at Zabar's on the Upper West Side; the Yura & Company store at Madison Avenue and 92nd Street; Blue Apron in Park Slope, Brooklyn; and Sobsey's Produce in Hoboken, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUARDARO, EDWARD J., ESQ
description: GUARDARO -- Edward J., Esq. Deputy Clerk to 2d Circuit Court of Appeals for 31 years, co-founder Fordham Law School Alumni Assoc., died August 2, 2003. A kind, generous, intelligent, dedicated family man. Husband of the late Mildred. Survived by his sister Evelyn Fantaci, two children, Edward Jr. and Anne G. Appel, a son-in-law, Louis, daughter-in-law, Melissa, and two grandsons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, 7-9 PM, and Thursday, 25 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th St., Friday, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELL'OLIO, ALBERT R.
description: DELL'OLIO--Albert R. Age 78, died Sunday, August 3rd, 2003. Born in Manhattan, July 20th, 1925, Albert served in the U.S. Army and retired from a career at the New York Times. Surviving are two daughters, Doreen Staffieri, Lorraine Brokaw and son, Steven Dell'Olio. Albert also had five grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 6th, at Young and Prill Funeral Home in Stuart, FL.

title: About New York; The Best Lips Ever Asked To Zip
description: AS Steve Herbst walks the crowded streets of this city, he possesses the strange knowledge that he can whistle better than anyone he passes. If you challenged him to a whistle-off, he would look you square in the eye and blow you away with a three-octave range. Mozart, Brubeck, Sondheim; you name it, he does it. The man can whistle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SONTAG, ROLLIN H.
description: SONTAG--Rollin H. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System is greatly saddened by the loss of our esteemed trustee, Rollin H. Sontag, an active member of our organization for 34 years. He became an associate trustee of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset in 1969, was named to the Board of Trustees in 1972, served as board president from 1984 to 1986, and was named a life trustee of the North ShoreLIJ Health System in 1997. Throughout his tenure, Rollin showed tremendous passion and commitment. We extend our sincere condolences to Rollin's wife Joan, an associate trustee, and the couple's five children: Ellen Kuba, Ann Shapiro, Deborah Sontag, Cathy Nish and Richard Sontag. His generosity and dedication will be remembered always. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael Dowling, Pres./CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: The Paradox of Global Warming
description: GLOBAL warming is a fearsome proposition, dredging up visions of rising tides engulfing shoreline cities, and other cataclysms. For winemakers, especially those in historically cool grape-growing regions, the changing climate has already markedly affected their lives and wines.

title: Off the Fast Track, the Simple Joys of a Summer Job
description: For Jessica Phillips-Patrick, the summer internship grind began after she graduated from high school in Bethesda, Md., when she landed a position with a biotechnology company working on the human genome project. She had the same internship the next summer, after her freshman year at Stanford University. The following year, having decided she liked economics more than biology, she got an internship at the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Freed Palestinians Get Joyous Welcome
description: TARQUMIYA CHECKPOINT, West Bank, Aug. 6  Israel today released more than 330 Palestinian prisoners who were hugged, kissed and hoisted onto the shoulders of friends and relatives who greeted them at checkpoints in the West Bank and the entrance to the Gaza Strip.

title: Reading a Score, and Beethoven's Mind
description: It has been 20 years since Roger Norrington began researching the way Beethoven's symphonies were performed in the composer's time and how that style might be revived. Sir Roger was not the first to raise those questions, but the startling set of Beethoven symphonies he recorded in the 1980's with his period instrument band, the London Classical Players, lighted a fire in the world of Beethoven interpretation.

title: Trying Saddam Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Connection to Terror Threats Is Seen in Jakarta Bombing
description: The deadly terror bombing at the J. W. Marriott Hotel in Jakarta fits into what counterterrorism officials said today was a pattern of threats and intelligence reports indicating the possibility of more attacks overseas or inside the United States.

title: Walking in Mom's Shoes With Mom's Feet, Too
description: The new version of ''Freaky Friday'' nudges Mary Rodgers's much-loved 1972 novel of mother-daughter conflict into the modern era and makes a few changes along the way. The daughter, Anna (Lindsay Lohan), is a teenager now, and she inhabits the noisy, bumptious, body-pierced world of contemporary adolescence, speeding through her youth over a power-pop soundtrack and playing lead guitar in a coed garage band. Her mother, Tess (Jamie Lee Curtis), is the very model of modern multitasking maternity, juggling a purse full of cellphones and PDA's along with two children, a busy psychotherapy practice, a doddering dad (Harold Gould) and an impressively patient fianc (Mark Harmon).

title: Pakistani Detainee to Face Terror Charge, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for a Pakistani man who has been detained in Manhattan since March as a material witness said he expected his client to be indicted on charges of providing support to a terrorist conspiracy whose goal included obtaining chemical weapons.

title: HISPANICS IN U.S. REPORT OPTIMISM
description: A new survey of the nation's Hispanics finds they are far more optimistic about life in the United States and their children's prospects than are non-Latinos, despite the fact that many are much poorer and many do not intend to gain the full benefits of citizenship.

title: Democrats Largely Endorse Labor's Views
description: All but one of the nine Democratic presidential candidates made extravagant bids for support from organized labor here tonight, calling for expanded health care coverage and some restrictions on free trade policies and denouncing the Bush administration for cutting funds to state governments.

title: The Quest for a Peaceful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeter's Bat Still Glows As He Hits 2 Homers
description: It was the best pitch Derek Jeter saw all night, a fastball down the middle from the Texas Rangers' Colby Lewis in the fifth inning. Jeter pounced on the ball, and though he hit it off the end of his bat, it carried earnestly toward the fabled black seats in center field. Ramon Nivar, the Texas center fielder, sprinted back in pursuit.

title: Weakies, Blackies and Blues: In Praise of Local Fish
description: NICKERSON'S FISH AND LOBSTER has been on the fish dock in Chatham, Mass., on Cape Cod, for 50 years. There, shoppers looking for fish for dinner can choose among cod, haddock, gray sole, bluefin tuna, striped bass, fluke, bluefish and black sea bass, all locally caught. The exceptions are swordfish and halibut from Canada, and salmon.

title: Bush and Powell Try to Quell Exit Rumors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 — President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell tried to swat away speculation today that Mr. Powell will not serve in Mr. Bush's second term if the president is re-elected.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; More Losers in Funds Seek Equity in Court
description: When Thomas P. Gallagher sold his shares in a sinking investment fund in January 2002, he thought that he was just cutting his losses in a fund punished by a broadly declining market. But when he saw a notice describing a class-action lawsuit against the fund's manager, he decided that something sinister might have taken place.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nintendo Reports Profit
description: The Nintendo Company, maker of the GameCube, earned 11.5 billion yen ($96 million) in the April-June quarter thanks to strong sales of its Gameboy Advance SP hand-held console and the Pocket Monster video game. Sales of the new Gameboy have helped offset slowing sales of the GameCube home console, which is losing ground to the Sony PlayStation2. This was the first time Nintendo released quarterly figures, so no comparisons were available. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BURBERRY EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE Mike Metcalf, the Burberry Group's chief operating officer and finance head, who helped turn around the British company by marketing its plaid fashions to younger buyers, said that he would leave in March 2004 to pursue outside interests. Mr. Metcalf has been with Burberry for five years, and helped the company go public last year. Burberry said it would start searching for a new chief financial officer this week.

title: Profit at Edison Drops on Charge
description: Edison International posted a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings today, weighed down by a charge for the declining value of several power plants.

title: Mets Suspend Negotiations With Top Draft Choice
description: The Mets have suspended negotiations with their top draft pick, outfielder Lastings Milledge, after a spokeswoman for a Florida sheriff's department repeated accusations that in high school Milledge had had inappropriate contact with minor girls.

title: Officials Say U.S. Troops' Role Will Be Small
description: Bush administration officials hailed the arrival of Nigerian peacekeeping forces in Liberia today, but cautioned that conditions were not yet right for American forces to follow suit and that the American military role, if it materialized, would be extremely limited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONOHUE, ALFRED
description: DONOHUE--Alfred. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alfred Donohue, associated with The Times from October 8, 1977 until retiring on June 1, 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAYSON, SAMUEL V.
description: PAYSON--Samuel V. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Samuel V. Payson, beloved brother of our past Board colleague, Martin D. Payson, a cherished friend and dedicated supporter. We extend our deepest sympathies to Martin and to the entire Payson family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: 'Producers' Stars' Encore?
description: Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick are in negotiations to return to ''The Producers,'' the hit Broadway show by Mel Brooks that won a record 12 Tony Awards, including one for Mr. Lane. ''There is a good chance,'' said Rocco Landesman, one of the show's producers. ''We're in the discussion stage now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEREZ, STEVEN
description: PEREZ--Steven. Your untimely passing has left the world a far less humorous place. Memories of your razor sharp wit, contagious smile, and zest for life will always be in the minds of those you touched so deeply. You were a little brother to us all, and you've left a crater in our lives. Our deepest sympathies to your adoring family, Carole, Lou, Dana, Rickey, and Rachel. Mellen and Jack Genatt Jessica, Peter, and Harrison Goldring Kara and Adin Kahn Tara, Eric, and Natalie Schiff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMAS, FLORENCE
description: THOMAS -- Florence. Born April 27, 1915. Died June 18, 2003 at age 88. Memorial services will be held at Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th St, New York City, Saturday, August 9, 2003, from 2-4 PM.

title: Welfare for King Cotton
description: To the Editor:

title: Services Index Records a Broad Expansion in July
description: Service industries, the largest part of the American economy, staged the broadest expansion in six years last month and orders surged, an industry report showed yesterday.

title: From Venezuela, Corn Cakes With Full Pockets
description: NEW YORK'S fascination with sandwiches embraces many variations. The path from standard American sandwich to panino or Cubano is short, requiring only a sandwich press to toast and flatten the package. The pita extends the definition further, with its flatbread pouch. From Mexico come both the torta, a traditional sandwich on a crusty roll, and the more rustic taco. Venezuela's entry is the arepa, which combines the virtues of the soft corn tortilla and the pita into what is essentially a pouched corn cake.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I now have half the house and twice the mortgage.''

title: Creativity As an Ingredient Of Madness; A Wide Variety of Art by Patients In Psychiatric Institutions Is Featured in Paris Exhibitions
description: Always mysterious, the creative process becomes still more inscrutable when the artist in question is of unbalanced mind. Yet, as with van Gogh, perhaps the most telling example, visual art is a form of expression that often appeals to those suffering from mental illness. Indeed, for more than a century, psychiatric hospitals have tried both to understand and treat their patients using art as therapy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POULAKAKOS, ADRIENNE M.
description: POULAKAKOS--Adrienne M. February 24, 1934-August 4, 2003. Beloved wife of Harry and mother of Peter passed from this life peacefully on August 4, 2003 after a short illness. Adrienne, who was the second child and only daughter of Alfred and Mary Alice Nahas, was born on February 24, 1934 in Brooklyn, New York. She married Harry Poulakakos on June 6, 1965. Together they built a life and lived in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, New York. They were blessed with a son, Peter, who was born on April 21, 1976. Adrienne lived life to its fullest and with her husband and later her son, helped to build a successful restaurant enterprise in the Wall Street area of Manhattan. She will be remembered as a pillar of the social, economic and philanthropic community of lower Manhattan through her family's restaurants, most notably Harry's at Hanover Square, Harry's at the American Exchange and most recently Bayard's. The generosity and care she bestowed upon those she served in her life's work will be most missed by those who knew her. Adrienne Poulakakos is survived by her husband Harry and son Peter, her two brothers Edmund and Alfred Nahas and their wives, Vickie & Anne Marie, respectively. She also leaves her brotherin-law, George Poulakakos and his wife Despina also of Brooklyn, New York, sistersin-law Angelique & Catherine, numerous nieces and nephews and many other family members and friends. Viewing will be held at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, New York Wednesday and Thursday, 25 and 7-9 P.M.; funeral services on Friday, August 8, 2003 at 10:00 AM at St. Mary's Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or St. Mary's Orthodox Church.

title: COSTCO CITES INSURANCE COSTS IN EARNINGS WARNING
description: Costco Wholesale said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings would fall because of higher costs for health care benefits, workers' compensation and customer service. The company said profit would decline to as little as 46 cents a share, from 52 cents a year earlier. The retailer had expected profit of as much as 56 cents in the three months ending Aug. 31. Costco, based in Issaquah, Wash., pays for most of its employee health care benefits and has not raised prices to compensate as those costs have risen, analysts said.

title: Searching for Amelia Earhart, Within Herself
description: Doris Abbate, a septuagenarian aviator with an operatic recall for every airplane she has ever flown, has briefly shooed her husband of 50 years, Ronnie, out of earshot; some reveries require no co-pilot.

title: Trapped at the Beach Long Past the Summer
description: Gray clouds hang like a shroud over the small French resort town of Julie Lopes-Curval's melodrama ''Seaside.'' They remain in place for most of the 12 months of modest, vaguely stirring complications that roll past during this French-language film, which begins a run today at Film Forum. That is undoubtedly Ms. Lopes-Curval's aim; she has managed to create a world of people mired in their limitations, the petty jealousies of a town that stinks of no ambition.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry Executive To Leave
description: Mike Metcalf, the Burberry Group's chief operating officer and finance head, who helped turn around the British company by marketing its plaid fashions to younger buyers, said that he would leave in March 2004 to pursue outside interests. Mr. Metcalf has been with Burberry for five years, and helped the company go public last year. Burberry said it would start searching for a new chief financial officer this week. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Cisco Reports Higher Profit on Lower Revenue
description: Cisco Systems Inc. reported a higher profit but slightly lower revenue for its fourth quarter yesterday as it continued to weather the downturn in corporate technology spending.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about plans by the Belo Corporation, the owner of The Dallas Morning News, to start Al Da, a Spanish-language newspaper that will compete with another paper, La Estrella, in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, referred incorrectly to the role of Gilbert Bailon. While he is on special assignment as president and editor of Al Da, he remains vice president and executive editor of The Morning News. He is not the former executive editor.

title: The Kennedy Center Honors: This Year's Bid for Glamour
description: Carol Burnett, Mike Nichols, James Brown, Loretta Lynn and Itzhak Perlman were named today to receive this year's Kennedy Center Honors in the performing arts.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Utility Drops Mine Plan
description: An Arizona utility has decided not to pursue plans for a strip coal mine near Gallup after opposition by Indian tribes and environmentalists. The utility, the Salt River Project, said it dropped the mine after 22 years of planning because it found coal in Wyoming and it was more effective to buy coal than operate a mine. The Zuni Pueblos had opposed the mine because it would be close to the sacred Zuni Salt Lake. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corporate Jargon. Ugh.
description: To the Editor:

title: Updated, Artest Says He Respects Van Horn
description: It is safe to say that Ron Artest does not watch ''SportsCenter'' or make a point of keeping up with his hometown basketball team, the Knicks. When asked his opinion yesterday of the trade involving Latrell Sprewell and Keith Van Horn, a bewildered Artest said that it was the first he had heard of it.

title: Optimism at Mentor Corp.
description: The Mentor Corporation, which makes breast implants and other products used in plastic surgery, will probably meet its earnings forecast for the fiscal year that ends in March, the chief executive, Christopher J. Conway, said yesterday.

title: An Umpire With Everything in Perspective
description: A few years ago, in a game between the Chillicothe Paints and the London Werewolves, a foul ball smashed through Umpire Max McLeary's mask and knocked him down, as someone later recalled, like a sack of rocks.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about the food culture of northwestern Michigan misstated the price of the surf-and-turf combination of fried smelt and a hamburger at Art's Tavern in Glen Arbor. It is $7.25, not $2.75.

title: A Southern Italian Version
description: To the Editor:

title: What North Korea Wants
description: The news that North Korea has agreed to multilateral talks has been greeted with relief and hope from Moscow to Beijing to Washington. The United States has consistently insisted on multilateral talks with the North, while North Korea had been calling for talks only between the United States and North Korea. Now that North Korea has agreed to talks that will include Japan, China, Russia and South Korea, the Bush administration is focusing on the need to dismantle the North's nuclear-weapons program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the past and present of countries along the Danube River misstated the year in which Romania and Bulgaria hope to join the European Union. It is 2007, not 2004.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the past and present of countries along the Danube River misstated the year in which Romania and Bulgaria hope to join the European Union. It is 2007, not 2004.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Nassau Redistricting Is Upheld
description: A federal judge has upheld the remapping of the Nassau County Legislature's districts by its Democratic majority. A lawsuit filed by the Republicans called the changes politically motivated to benefit the Democrats. It challenged the districts as odd-shaped with unequal populations and divided communities. In a decision dated July 31 and made public yesterday, Judge Denis R. Hurley of Federal District Court said that ''redistricting is essentially a political and legislative process,'' but ruled that the new districts were within federal law. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Theaters Are Dark, but Actors Lighten Up
description: If your typical American high school drama club grew up and moved as an ensemble to Manhattan, the reunion might look something like the Green Room.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: More Errors At Cablevision
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had discovered more accounting errors. Second-quarter profit from continuing operations was $163.8 million, or 56 cents a share, in contrast to a loss from continuing operations of $87.7 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Without a gain on the sale of wireless licenses, the company, which is based in Bethpage, N.Y., would have had a loss. The company said an internal review had uncovered at least $3.4 million in incorrectly booked expenses at its Rainbow Media programming unit. The widening investigation, which comes about seven weeks after the problems were revealed, prompted Cablevision's auditor, KPMG, to say that it would not be able to complete a quarterly review. Cablevision shares fell $1.73, to $19.27. In June, the company fired 14 employees for improperly booking some marketing expenses and fabricating invoices. An internal review then found $6.2 million in expenses that were recorded in 2002 instead of 2003.

title: Report Cites I.R.S.'s Failure to Follow Up on Tax Cases
description: The Internal Revenue Service has identified nearly 2,000 businesses that are not withholding taxes or are filing frivolous returns, but it mostly fails to follow up on those cases, a government report shows.

title: Bryant Makes Appearance in Colorado Courtroom
description: EAGLE, Colo., Aug. 6  In what the presiding judge called "an extraordinary event," the basketball star Kobe Bryant, charged with raping a young woman in a Colorado hotel room, appeared for a mere seven minutes in a courtroom here today and uttered just two words.

title: Peter Safar, 'The Father Of C.P.R.,' Is Dead at 79
description: Dr. Peter Safar, an anesthesiologist who developed lifesaving cardiopulmonary resuscitation techniques that are widely used today, died on Sunday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 79.

title: That Domestic Goddess Prays for More Attention
description: The why is rattled off right up front. ''I'm an exhibitionist; I have a huge ego; I need attention,'' the tragicomedian once known as Roseanne Barr tells the camera at the beginning of ''The Real Roseanne Show,'' tonight on ABC. She looks defiant, but also disconcertingly needy. ''I have to go back on TV,'' she says. ''There is no other place to make people laugh.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Federal Agencies Challenged On Indian Point
description: Local officials are asking the federal government for internal data on how it concluded that the Indian Point nuclear power plant's public evacuation plan was sound. The county executives of Westchester and Rockland have filed Freedom of Information requests with the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The federal approvals have angered the local residents and the county governments that have refused to certify the evacuation plan for the plant, in Buchanan, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWSON, BARTHOLOMEW J.
description: LAWSON--Bartholomew J. The trustees, directors, staff, participants and beneficiaries of the 1199 SEIU Greater New York Benefit, Pension, Education, Job Security, Worker Participation and Child Care Funds mourn the loss of our valued Trustee, Bartholomew J. Lawson. Bart served as co-chair of the Boards of Trustees of the 1199 SEIU Greater New York Funds. He was deeply committed to improving the quality of life for the health care workers covered by these benefit plans. We will miss his intelligence, wit, commitment and inspired leadership. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends.

title: Management Issues Looming In Inquiry on Shuttle Safety
description: Senior officials of NASA said today that they were making progress in addressing the five technical recommendations made so far by the independent board investigating the breakup of the shuttle Columbia.

title: What's Happened To Sex In Movies?
description: The death of the director John Schlesinger was a reminder that the adult-rated studio film also seems to have died. But it perished long ago.

title: Brooklyn Community Is Fighting To Save School Custodian's Job
description: Until last year, Public School 81, an elementary school in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, was plagued with bad ventilation, broken windows, peeling paint, cockroaches and rats, parents say. After Mike Finneran took over as custodian, they say, everything improved.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: WARNING OF LEGAL ACTION AGAINST EXILES Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst warned 11 Democratic state senators in temporary exile in New Mexico that he might use legal action to force them to return to deal with a Republican redistricting plan that they are trying to thwart. "There are a number of things we can do to compel the attendance of the absent members," Mr. Dewhurst said. The absence has brought the Senate, which has a Republican majority, to a standstill for more than week because of a lack of a quorum. (AP)

title: The Quest for a Peaceful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: A new agency is born into a difficult marketplace.
description: AT a time when start-up agencies confront an environment about as welcoming as the annual meeting of the Traditional Values Coalition would be to the cast of ''Queer Eye for the Straight Guy,'' a team of longtime Madison Avenue executives -- four of them former agency heads -- are opening a shop.

title: SPLIT THREATENED
description: The Episcopal Church approved the election of its first openly gay bishop tonight, reaching the historic and divisive decision after rejecting accusations of sexual misconduct against him that had suddenly halted the vote on Monday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: Herman Schneider, 98, Author Of Science Books for Children
description: Herman Schneider, the author of more than 80 books, mostly science books for children, died in Boston on Thursday. He was 98 and lived on Martha's Vineyard.

title: VANGUARD TO OFFER AGE-BASED RETIREMENT FUNDS
description: The Vanguard Group, one of the nation's leading mutual fund companies, will start selling six new funds that invest in a mix of stocks and bonds suited to a person's planned retirement date, which have been among best sellers for rivals. The funds will go on sale in the fourth quarter. Vanguard, based in Valley Forge, Pa., joins Fidelity Investments, T. Rowe Price and other companies in offering so-called age-based funds, which are capturing record deposits this year as investors seek to diversify their investments and risk as they get older.

title: Forget the Dalmatian. A Queens Firehouse Needs a Rat Terrier.
description: New York City's firefighters do not scare easily, and neither do its rats. But an escalating showdown in a Queens firehouse between these two factions of New York's bravest seems to have been won for the moment by the four-legged team.

title: Real I.R.A. Leader Is Found Guilty of Directing Terrorism
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 6  Ireland's antiterrorism court today convicted the head of the Real I.R.A., Michael McKevitt, for leading the republican guerrilla group that carried out a 1998 car-bomb attack in Omagh, Northern Ireland, killing 29 people.

title: Expedia Doubles Its Profit
description: The online travel service, Expedia, said yesterday that second-quarter profit more than doubled as revenue rose 71 percent, spurred by strong online sales of package trips and hotel rooms.

title: Accounts
description: * Taco Cabana, San Antonio, a chain of Mexican restaurants, to the Atlanta office of West Wayne, to handle its creative account, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million. The assignment had been handled by McGarrah/Jessee, Austin, which resigned to work for another fast-food chain, Whataburger. Taco Cabana is part of the Carrols Corporation.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Bhutto Sentenced In Switzerland
description: A Swiss magistrate has found former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her husband guilty of money laundering. They were given six-month suspended jail terms, fined $50,000 each and were ordered to pay $11 million to the Pakistani government. The six-year-long case alleged that Ms. Bhutto, who lives in exile in London and Dubai, and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, deposited in Swiss accounts $10 million given them by a Swiss company in exchange for a contract in Pakistan. The couple said they would appeal. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: PROFIT RISES 34% AT PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL
description: Prudential Financial said yesterday that quarterly profit rose 34 percent as the company made more from annuities and investment losses fell. Net income climbed to $127 million, or 25 cents a share, from $95 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Excluding investment gains and losses, profit rose 24 percent to $358 million, or 67 cents a share, above the 60-cent estimate by analysts. The chief executive, Arthur F. Ryan, is shedding businesses like car and home insurance to focus on annuities and life insurance.

title: INSIDE
description: Democrats Court Unions

title: Leasing of Retail Space Shows Signs of Softening
description: As the office and industrial markets have struggled with rising vacancies during the economic downturn, retail real estate has remained surprisingly stable. Vacancies in shopping centers increased after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but only modestly.

title: CALENDAR
description: Pizza Practice

title: Two Army Teams Investigating Puzzling Outbreak of Pneumonia
description: The Army has assigned two teams of medical investigators to determine the cause of a puzzling spate of pneumonia cases among American troops in Iraq and other countries in the war region, Pentagon officials said yesterday.

title: Sweet Onions and Tomato Balance the Spices
description: SOMETIMES a wine gives you no clues for pairing it with food. A great cabernet sauvignon may leave you wondering if food is beside the point. And dessert wines often seem to ward off food altogether.

title: Cancer Drugs Face Funds Cut In a Bush Plan
description: The Bush administration will soon propose significant cuts in Medicare payments for cancer drugs, based on new data suggesting that the government pays far more than the market price for such medicines, administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOGG, JOHN GOLDSBOROUGH
description: HOGG--John Goldsborough, on August 1, in a tragic flying accident in England, U.K. Much loved husband of Sally and father of Jane and Joanna. Funeral private. Memorial service details to be announced.

title: Robert J. Ward, 77, a Senior Federal Judge
description: Robert J. Ward, a senior federal judge in New York, who presided over nationally prominent lawsuits that included charges of illegal interference with abortion rights and accusations of plagiarism by a best-selling author, died yesterday at New York-Presbyterian Hospital. He was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Powells Visit Bush at His Ranch
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage arrived at President Bush's ranch late this afternoon for dinner and for discussions about foreign policy on Wednesday, White House officials said.

title: Phelps Not Resting On Success at Worlds
description: In 1976, John Naber qualified for five individual events in the United States Olympic swimming trials. Which ones would he swim?

title: News From Credit Rating Agency Bolsters City's Debt Relief Effort
description: The Bloomberg administration's efforts to get the state to pay off New York City's last remaining debt from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's -- a move the Pataki administration opposes -- got a boost of sorts yesterday from a major credit rating agency.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Judge Faces More Severe Charge
description: Criminal charges against Justice Gerald P. Garson of State Supreme Court were raised yesterday to include bribe-receiving, three months after he was indicted on charges of accepting gifts from a lawyer in return for preferential treatment. Justice Garson, 71, left, was indicted yesterday on one count of third-degree bribe-receiving. The new charge carries a maximum seven-year sentence. The six counts of the previous charge each carry a penalty of up to four years in jail. Prosecutors said the lawyer, Paul Siminovsky, plied Justice Garson with meals, cigars and cash, and in return, the judge advised him on how best to try matrimonial cases before him. Justice Garson's lawyer, Ronald P. Fischetti, said it was nonsense to describe the relationship between the judge and Mr. Siminovsky as criminal. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; New Impetus for Even More Retailing in Paramus
description: The Swedish home furnishings retailer Ikea opened a 375,000-square- foot store last week in Paramus, N.J., as part of an expansion that will add 50 stores in North America over the next decade. The new store is the latest change in the sprawling retail landscape that has made Paramus synonymous with suburban shopping and heavy auto traffic.

title: Props for the Movie Set or Home
description: For a 1950's pay phone or a fake computer bank, try Modern Props in Los Angeles.

title: Dorm Linens 101
description: Help for the college-bound who are in search of linens.

title: Phish's Musical Theme Park
description: An estimated 60,000 people attended a festival by the rock band Phish at the former Loring Air Force Base in northeastern Maine.

title: Key Players in the California Recall
description: A brief introduction to some of the people involved in the recall election.

title: Nothing but the Truth?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Giants Will Get First Look At Off-Season Improvements
description: A fleet of buses whisked the Giants away in a rainstorm, rolling the team east toward its first stop in what the team hopes is a journey to Super Bowl XXXVIII in Houston.

title: Oyez! The Supreme Court, Now on MP3
description: THE United States Supreme Court is known as one of the least public of all government institutions. Cameras remain off-limits in the courtroom and official audio recordings are usually released months after the justices hear a case.

title: AOL Makeover, In Muted Tones
description: WHEN a software company is working on a new program, it tries to throw competitors off the scent by using a code name, like Whistler (which became Windows XP) or Cheetah (the original Mac OS X). Nobody outside America Online knows the code name for the new AOL 9, but it should have been Humble Pie.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung To Make Sony Product
description: Sony will permit the Samsung Electronics Company, South Korea's largest electronics maker, to produce and sell Memory Stick storage cards under license. The wafer-thin Memory Sticks allow users to store and swap pictures and data with their digital cameras, personal digital assistants and computers. Sony, which licenses its technology to three other companies, said it expected shipments of Memory Sticks to nearly double this year, to 35 million units. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Suit Challenges Climate Change Report by U.S.
description: An antiregulatory group sued the Bush administration yesterday to force it to stop distributing a report on climate change that the group contends is inaccurate and biased.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YODER, HATTEN SCHUYLER, JR., PHD
description: YODER -- Hatten Schuyler, Jr., PhD, died on August 2, 2003, of Bethesda, MD. Husband of the late Elizabeth Marie Yoder. Father of Karen M. Wallace Yoder and the late Hatten S. Yoder III. Grandfather of Brianna Wallace. Father-in-law of Keith A. Wallace. For more information, please view and sign guest book at www.pum phreyfuneralhome.com or call 301-652-220

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Jury Award Reduced In eBay Case
description: A federal judge refused yesterday to overturn a jury's finding in May that eBay Inc. infringed the patents of a Virginia company. But the judge, Jerome B. Friedman of Federal District Court in Norfolk, Va., reduced the $35 million award by $5.5 million, to $29.5 million. MercExchange of Great Falls, Va., sued eBay, asserting that it and its Half.com unit infringed patents for the technology to conduct sales over the Internet. The dispute centered on eBay's ''fixed price'' sales. Fixed-price sales have grown steadily in importance at eBay since it acquired Half.com in June 2000.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Life Term For Subway Arsonist
description: A man who set fire to a South Korean subway train in February, killing 198 people and injuring 147, was sentenced to life imprisonment by a court in Taegu, the scene of the tragedy. The arsonist, Kim Dae Han, 56, poured gasoline in a subway car, flicked a lighter, and jumped out of the train, which was stopped in a station. The ensuing fire engulfed two trains. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Open Access to Scientific Research
description: A number of influential scientists have begun to argue that the cost of research publications has grown so large that it impedes the distribution of knowledge. Some subscriptions cost thousands of dollars per year, and those journals are usually available online only to subscribers. This looks less like dissemination than restriction, especially if it is measured against the potential access offered by the Internet. That is why a coalition led by Dr. Harold Varmus, the former director of the National Institutes of Health, is creating a new model, called the Public Library of Science.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Iceland: Whale Hunts To Resume
description: Ending a 14-year self-imposed suspension, Iceland plans to resume hunting whales for scientific research, with the goal of killing 38 minkes through next month. Iceland will be the third country to conduct whaling as government policy, along with Japan, which undertakes it for research, and Norway, which carries out commercial whaling. In June the International Whaling Commission adopted a resolution against research whaling, which its opponents contend is a cover for commercial whaling because the meat is sold for consumption. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An article on Sunday about attacks on the American military in Iraq over the previous two days, attributed to military officials, included an erroneous account that quoted Pfc. Jose Belen of the First Armored Division. Private Belen, who is not a spokesman for the division, said that a homemade bomb exploded under a convoy on Saturday morning on the outskirts of Baghdad and killed two American soldiers and their interpreter. The American military's central command, which releases information on all American casualties in Iraq, said before the article was published that it could not confirm Private Belen's account. Later it said that no such attack had taken place and that no American soldiers were killed on Saturday.

title: Untangling the Path To a Wireless Network
description: Q. My computer runs the Windows 98 Second Edition operating system and uses a cable modem. I also have a hand-held computer that has 802.11b wireless capability, or Wi-Fi. How would I install a wireless access point at home so that I can use the Internet wirelessly?

title: Pentagon Asserts Baghdad Bombing Won't Alter U.S. Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7  The bombing of the Jordanian embassy in Baghdad will not disrupt American military operations in Iraq, a high-ranking Pentagon official said today while offering tantalizing hints that pursuers may be closing in on Saddam Hussein.

title: Debate Resumes on the Safety Of Depression's Wonder Drugs
description: Warnings by drug regulators about the safety of Paxil, one of the world's most prescribed antidepressants, are reopening seemingly settled questions about a whole class of drugs that also includes Prozac and Zoloft.

title: California Design, Without a Look Back
description: California design has long been defined by giants of postwar modernism like Ray and Charles Eames and the graphic designer Saul Bass. Looking for what's making waves now, the Pasadena Museum of California Art put out a statewide call last year. The exhibitors in its first Design Biennial, on view through Sept. 13, were selected by a jury that included Michael Maltzan, the Los Angeles architect who designed MoMA QNS, and Brooke Hodge, the design and architecture curator of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

title: Top Orthopedic Implant Maker In Europe Is Down to U.S. Bidder
description: Zimmer Holdings emerged today as the top bidder for Centerpulse A.G., Europe's top maker of orthopedic implants, after Smith & Nephew said that it would not raise its bid for Centerpulse.

title: A Force Behind the U.N.
description: Ralph Bunche was born in Detroit 100 years ago today. His passionate determination to get results did not extend to seeking credit for them, so his work is better remembered than he is. Of all his many accomplishments -- civil rights pioneer, Nobel Peace Prize laureate, chief drafter of two chapters of the United Nations charter, negotiator of the armistices that ended the first Arab-Israeli war -- Bunche said he was proudest of developing what came to be known as peacekeeping.

title: Corrections
description: The Minor League Notebook article in the sports pages on Friday misstated the name of the broadcaster for the Lansing Lugnuts, a Class A affiliate of the Chicago Cubs, who on Tuesday commemorated the first broadcast of a major league baseball game, in 1921. He is Jim Tocco, not Joe Tocca.

title: YUCAIPA SUES SAFEWAY OVER BIDDING ON DOMINICK CHAIN
description: Safeway Inc., the supermarket chain, conducted a ''biased and unfair sales process'' for its Chicago-area Dominick's grocery store chain and should accept new bids, according to a lawsuit by the Yucaipa Companies. Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private-equity company run by the billionaire Ronald Burkle, said that Safeway wanted Yucaipa's participation to make it easier for another buyer to achieve labor peace. A Safeway spokeswoman, Melissa Plaisance, said yesterday that the allegations had ''no basis in fact or in law.'' Safeway has been trying to sell Dominick's since last year after it failed to negotiate a revised labor contract.

title: Spam Reconsidered
description: Last week, I described a chat I had with Bob Wientzen, chief executive of the Direct Marketing Association (DMA). He contends that not all spam is bad spam. Legitimate offers from companies that dont hide behind phony addresses, and swear to take you off their lists when asked, should be permitted by any of the legislation now before Congress, he says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERSHOFF, HELEN
description: HERSHOFF -- Helen. With deepest sympathy at age 95 on August 6, 2003. Devoted teacher, member of UFT, Workmen's Circle and numerous other charitable organizations. Beloved aunt/cousing of Ann Froman, Jane Froman Godfry and family, Pamela Froman Goldman and the Hershoff family. Services Friday 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Legislator Acts On Nepotism Question
description: The Republican Senate co-president, John O. Bennett, left, has dismissed two family members working as aides to remove them as possible issues in his November re-election campaign. Joseph E. Farren, a spokesman for Senate Republicans, said yesterday that Senator Bennett's aides -- his mother, Florence C. Bennett, and his mother-in-law, Joan M. Stewart -- would continue on his staff as volunteers. They began working for Mr. Bennett in September 1999 and each earned $9,900 per year; both took a $900 pay cut in January 2002. The women, both in their 70's, provided information about programs for the elderly in Mr. Bennett's Senate district, Mr. Farren said. Mr. Bennett did not want their positions to become a campaign issue, Mr. Farren said. John Holl (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Keeping a Lost World Alive: A Last Remnant of Iowa's Tallgrass Prairie
description: Look deep enough into the history of almost any Iowa town and you come to the primordial 19th-century tale of breaking the prairie as if it were a herd of wild horses. It took special plows and large teams of draft animals. The first step was skinning the earth, turning over the sod, exposing unimaginably fertile soil. But what really broke the prairie was ending the cycle of wildfires and then draining the land, ditching the sloughs and laying tile to carry away water that was good for wildlife and thick stands of native vegetation but not so good for alien row crops.

title: Economic Scene; Regardless of the progress of a few, many nations still face economic despair.
description: THE fierce arguments over whether income inequality and poverty rates in the world have risen or fallen somewhat in recent decades dominate international economic policy discussions. But for many poor nations, they are almost beside the point.

title: For Aspiring Raconteurs, an Online Portal to Public Radio
description: JAKE WARGA wasn't looking to get into public radio when he first started making tapes. It was 1994, and he was working as a camera technician in Hollywood when he began tape-recording conversations with a friend who had chosen a very different path by joining the Peace Corps. ''I wanted to record her before she left so I could give her a recording when she came back to see how different she was,'' recalled Mr. Warga, who now lives in Seattle. ''Then she started sending me tapes from Africa, and I wanted to mix them together.''

title: Gore Denies Plans for '04 and Assails Bush Integrity
description: Wading back into presidential politics with his first major speech since announcing in December that he would not run in 2004, former Vice President Al Gore today accused the Bush administration of fomenting "false impressions" about the need to go to war in Iraq and to cut taxes.
