description: Same-Sex Unions Rejected

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tenet to Pay $54 Million In Settlement With U.S.

title: Astros Hit 4 Home Runs In Chugging Past the Mets
description: The choo-choo train was busy tonight.

title: Tony Blair's Troubles
description: Britain has long been America's closest ally. But more than any previous British prime minister, Tony Blair has made himself a crucial factor in Washington's foreign policy debates. For Americans unwilling to accept the White House's flimsily backed assertions of imminent danger from Iraq, Mr. Blair offered his supposedly independent intelligence dossiers. For those unswayed by the administration's belligerent rhetoric, Mr. Blair stepped forth with a mellifluous moral summons to action. When Washington appeared most vulnerable to charges of unilateralism and bypassing the United Nations Security Council, there was Mr. Blair, providing living proof that the United States didn't stand alone. Polls found that Mr. Blair was the international leader Americans respected most, at times ranking him higher than Mr. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDNER, ALFRED
description: GOLDNER--Alfred. Of Boynton Beach, Florida on August 4, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy, devoted father of Joanne and Penny, loving grandfather of Jonathan, David and Megan, fatherin-law of Richard and Rick. Services private.

title: Producer Plans to Plead Guilty In Extortion Plot, Officials Say
description: A former business associate of the actor Steven Seagal who prosecutors say used his connections with the Gambino crime family to shake down Mr. Seagal has agreed to plead guilty to extortion, the authorities said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Seiko Epson Returns To Profit
description: The Seiko Epson Corporation, one of Japan's biggest makers of printers, said it had earned 6 billion yen ($50.1 million) in the quarter to June, in part because of the demand for its color printers. The company, which recently completed a large share offering in Tokyo, lost 1 billion yen in the same period a year ago. Seiko Epson cut its full-year sales goal by 4.1 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: FORD PLANS TO CONTRIBUTE $700 MILLION TO PENSION PLAN
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to make a $700 million pension contribution for overseas workers by the end of 2003, the vice chairman, Allan Gilmour, said yesterday. The company's pension deficit outside the United States accounted for almost half the total shortfall in 2002. Speaking at an investor conference in Dearborn, Mich., where Ford is based, Mr. Gilmour said the company's American pension plans had a ''double digit'' performance in the first half, without elaborating.

title: Rookie's Long Wait Ends Right on Time
description: Joe DePastino began making the phone calls around 6 p.m. Monday. Amy, his wife, was at his parents' ice cream parlor in Sarasota, Fla., and she took one look at the caller ID on her cellphone and immediately thought something was wrong. Class AAA Norfolk's game at Richmond was about to begin, and her husband should have been on the field.

title: At Least 11 Die in Car Bombing at Jordan's Embassy in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 7  A car bomb exploded today outside the Jordanian Embassy here, killing 11 people and wounding at least 65, in the deadliest episode since the Bush administration declared an end to combat operations on May 1.

title: Vote Scheduled On Contract By Strikers At A-Plant
description: Striking electrical workers at the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station have reached a tentative contract agreement with the plant's management and are scheduled to vote Thursday on whether to end their 76-day walkout, according to company officials.

title: Man Receives Death Sentence for Bali Blasts That Killed 202
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia, Aug. 7  An Indonesian motorcycle mechanic was found guilty today of planning the Bali terror attack that killed 202 people last October and was sentenced to death for what a panel of Indonesian judges called a crime against humanity.

title: Broadcasting Local Politics
description: It is not news to most candidates for local office that they would have to get indicted or run naked through the streets to be noticed by their hometown television stations. ''Free media,'' as the campaigns refer to news coverage by working journalists, is hard to come by when the campaigner is not running for president or senator. In some states even the governor's race gets short shrift from television news. Candidates who want to connect with the public are often forced to buy their own airtime -- an expense that is usually the main cost of running a successful campaign.

title: AES Corp. To Hand Over Power Plant To Creditors
description: The AES Corporation said today that it was walking away from Britain's largest plant and the roughly $3 billion it paid for it in 1999 after creditors refused to accept a plan to buy back some debt.

title: The Court of Last Resort
description: The events of 9/11, as well as the war in Iraq, require our government to intensify its efforts to combat terrorism. So it is more important than ever that we do our utmost to show the world that we will enforce human rights laws evenhandedly.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Strike Ends
description: The signs hanging from windows of the union office at Hyundai Motor in Ulsan proclaim, ''Win a 40-hour week'' and ''Give the union a place in management.'' Those goals that had seemed all but impossible when the company's 39,000 workers walked off the job for two hours on June 20, the first day of an off-again, on-again strike that ended early yesterday with an agreement in which the union achieved both goals. As workers returned to their jobs after hearing a three-hour explanation of the agreement, a union leader, Chang Kyu Ho, said, ''We got what we wanted.'' The company estimated that the strike had been one of the costliest in its history. The union leader said he was confident that workers would accept the agreement when it goes to members for a vote tomorrow.

title: Episcopal Church Leaders Reject Proposal for Same-Sex Union Liturgy
description: Only a day after approving the election of the Episcopal Church's first openly gay bishop, prelates of the church tonight rejected a proposal to begin writing an official liturgy for the blessing of same-sex unions.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: LEGISLATOR ACTS ON NEPOTISM QUESTION The Republican Senate co-president, John O. Bennett, left, has dismissed two family members working as aides to remove them as possible issues in his November re-election campaign. Joseph E. Farren, a spokesman for Senate Republicans, said yesterday that Senator Bennett's aides  his mother, Florence C. Bennett, and his mother-in-law, Joan M. Stewart  would continue on his staff as volunteers. They began working for Mr. Bennett in September 1999 and each earned $9,900 per year; both took a $900 pay cut in January 2002. description: THOMAS -- Florence. Born April 27, 1915. Died June 18, 2003 at age 88. Memorial services will be held at Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th St, New York City, Saturday, August 9, 2003, from 2-4 PM.

description: That seafood dinner you enjoyed recently may have been fished illegally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUPU, JACK
description: LUPU--Jack, 96, on August 5, 2003. Co-proprietor of Lupu's Dress Shop in Brooklyn before retiring to Florida. Beloved husband of the late Hattie Lupu, loving brother of Laura Stern and Rusty Remin, and uncle of Diane and Robert Remin, Chip and Jerry Lupu, and the late Sandy Stern. We will all miss his warmth and his incredible stories. Services Friday 11:30AM at Mount Ararat in Farmingdale.

description: New Life for Old Grapes

title: Federal Audit Find Flaws In Foster Care In New Jersey
description: Citing another failure of New Jersey's troubled child welfare system, a federal audit has found that the state has not followed key foster care placement guidelines, state officials said.

title: U.S. Is Inspecting Overseas Airports for Missile Threats
description: The Bush administration has dispatched teams of aviation safety investigators to Iraq and to major capital cities in Europe and Asia to determine if their commercial airports can be defended against terrorists who might try to shoot down passenger planes using shoulder-fired missiles, senior American officials say.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New York Firefighters Go West
description: New York State is sending a team of 20 firefighters to assist in battling forest fires in Montana, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. The team -- 12 forest rangers from the State Department of Environmental Conservation and eight civilian firefighters -- left yesterday. The team will join thousands of other firefighters from across the country in trying to extinguish the fires, currently covering 100,000 acres. This is the 24th year that the state has sent personnel to help combat fires in the west, Mr. Pataki said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Old Airplanes Never Die, They Just Turn Into Lamps
description: What becomes of airplane parts dumped in Arizona junkyards? Some are recycled into furniture by Giancarlo de Astis, a designer in Los Angeles.

title: Hiroshima, Nagasaki and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Smart Walls, Smart Future
description: LAST week, Stephen Kieran and James Timberlake watched a worker install a banner for their show, ''SmartWrap,'' on a garden wall of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.

title: Opera in Rome Returns To Old Stomping Ground
description: About midway through the first act of ''Carmen'' gaping holes in the ancient Roman ruins behind the stage swallowed the doomed Gypsy's aria about love being a rebellious bird. ''Carmen'' also had to compete with crickets chirping in the cypress trees, motor scooters buzzing in the distance and helicopters roaring overhead.

title: A Smoky Bar In New York? It's Just TV, Bloomberg Says
description: A new sitcom called ''Whoopi,'' starring guess who, takes place in New York City and is being filmed in New York City. Its newly built sets on Stage H of Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens look very New Yorkish indeed -- with one exception that became readily apparent when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg dropped by yesterday.

title: CATHAY PACIFIC SAYS FIRST 6 MONTHS SWUNG TO HEFTY LOSS
description: Cathay Pacific Airways, the airline based in Hong Kong, yesterday reported a loss of $159 million in the first half of the year, its worst six-month performance ever. In the period last year, Cathay had a profit of $181 million. Revenue was $1.6 billion, down 21 percent from a year earlier. The loss was a result of fears over SARS, which kept travelers from flying to many parts of Asia in the spring. In April, at the height of the SARS scare, Cathay parked 22 aircraft and reduced its schedule by canceling up to half of its regularly scheduled services in May and June. The airline has since restored much of its schedule and now has four planes sidelined , said Mary Jersin-Shammas, a Cathay spokeswoman. Cathay still runs a reduced schedule between Los Angeles and Hong Kong: one nonstop flight a day instead of two. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: First Test for Freshmen: Picking Roommates
description: Ankith Kamaraju has never met Zachary Manfredi, but he is confident that on Aug. 23, when they move into the room they will share as freshmen at Emory University, they will get along smoothly.

Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle May Seek Other Deals
description: Oracle, a leading business software company, may make other acquisitions as it pursues a hostile bid for PeopleSoft, Oracle's executive vice president, Charles Phillips, said yesterday. The Justice Department's antitrust investigation into Oracle's offer should be completed in September to November, Mr. Phillips said at the CIBC World Markets Enterprise Software Conference in New York, in remarks broadcast on the Internet. ''We may be working on the PeopleSoft one now,'' he said, ''but that doesn't stop us from looking at others.'' He would not say what other purchases Oracle, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., might consider.

title: For Absent-Minded Travelers, Electrical Gear at the Ready

The company's TravelPower case comes with an adapter that can recharge a computer and two other devices simultaneously from a single outlet.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Reports Falling Sales
description: The drug and chemical maker Bayer reported declining sales and profit yesterday for its second quarter based on weaker demand for industrial chemicals and currency effects. While Bayer's operating profit increased 80 percent to 454 million euros ($517 million), net profit suffered from a higher tax rate and dropped 56 percent to 128 million euros ($146 million) from a year earlier, which was far below market expectations. The results and the company's cautious outlook for the year's second half, adding to risks from continuing lawsuits against the drug producer over the cholesterol medication Baycol, made shares fall 6.5 percent to 19.90 euros.

title: In Italy, summertime is for divorce
description: MILAN:  August traditionally finds Italians swapping their Armani suits for swimsuits and hunkering down to the serious business of basking in the sun. But for Maretta Scoca, it is the season to be busy.

title: I.R.S. Delays New Scrutiny Of Tax Credit for the Poor
description: The Internal Revenue Service is putting off until next year a pilot program to require certain low-income taxpayers to provide conclusive proof of their eligibility for a special tax credit. It is also reducing the number of people covered by the program, but will look more closely at other poor wage earners seeking the credit.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Sentenced For Attack
description: A Queens man was sentenced in State Supreme Court to 11 1/2 years in prison yesterday after pleading guilty to biting his girlfriend's face so savagely that she needed prolonged reconstructive surgery. The victim, Jessica Mencia, 22, remains ''severely disfigured,'' according to the Queens district attorney's office. She was hospitalized for almost a month after the attack in February 2002, which occurred in the couple's South Ozone Park home. Ms. Mencia required skin grafts to repair the disfigurement, which included the partial severing of one ear. The man, Felix Rondon, 32, pleaded guilty to assault on May 27, admitting that the attack was intentional. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Mapping Technology Speeds Help to Fire-Scarred Land
description: IT'S wildfire season, the time not only for burned forests but for the erosion that often follows when bare, scorched soil repels rain instead of letting it infiltrate. The damage from such erosion -- from mudslides to contamination of reservoirs -- can be extensive. So conservation teams typically move in quickly, often before the fire has been extinguished, to assess problems and protect homes and water supplies before rain comes.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Wireless Access At F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission is providing free wireless Internet access to visitors at its Washington headquarters. ''When you come to the F.C.C., leave the cords at home,'' said Michael K. Powell, chairman of the commission. ''We're embracing the power of 'Wi-Fi' and the freedom and convenience of wireless Internet access it gives to consumers.'' Last year, Mr. Powell told his staff to take steps to make the F.C.C. one of the first federal agencies to provide public Internet access through the Wi-Fi radio signal technology. Visitors who bring their own hardware will be able to use the service at the agency's building and in its courtyard. In May, Verizon announced that it would provide Wi-Fi access from phone booths around Manhattan. Wireless access is also available in some hotels, airports, convention centers, restaurants and other locations.

A disaster designation by Ann Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, would allow farmers to qualify for low-interest emergency loans as well as for federal aid. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Genesis Falls After Deal Fails
description: Shares of Genesis Microchip, a maker of chips for flat-panel computer monitors, fell 8.2 percent yesterday after Pixelworks dropped plans to buy the company for $513.5 million. Genesis shares declined 87 cents, to $9.70. The stock had fallen 22 percent since the agreement was announced on March 17. Pixelworks, which also makes chips for flat-panel computer screens, rose 90 cents, or 13.4 percent, to $7.60. The companies did not say in statements on their Web sites yesterday why the deal would not go through. The agreement was in doubt after Genesis, based in Alviso, Calif., said on July 30 that sales for the quarter would be less than forecast. Pixelworks, based in Tualatin, Ore., will pay $5.5 million in expenses to Genesis.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adidas-Salomon Posts Profit
description: Adidas-Salomon, one of the world's leading sporting goods makers, said its second-quarter net profit rose 26.8 percent to 32 million euros ($36.4 million) from 25 million euros in the same quarter a year earlier, beating most analysts' expectations. Operating profit, however, fell 10.5 percent to 62 million euros ($70.1 million) in the April-June period and sales were down 8 percent at 1.4 billion euros, as a result of both the strength of the euro against the dollar and the weak economic environment. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Approves O'Hare Plan
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich signed into a law a $6.6 billion modernization plan for O'Hare International Airport. The plan is meant to reduce delays and secure Chicago's spot as the transportation hub of the nation. The plan, which angered suburban residents because it means the removal of hundreds of houses, will take at least 15 years to complete. Mayor Richard M. Daley said the plan would generate 195,000 jobs. It must be approved by the Federal Aviation Administration before work can start. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Is There A Place For DDT?
description: The outbreak of West Nile virus in the United States is rapidly becoming a significant threat to public health. With the peak season just beginning, the mosquito-borne virus has been found in animals (primarily birds and horses) in 38 states, and has caused 103 serious infections and three deaths in humans in 15 states.

title: Rain or Shine? Homing In on Your Microclimate
description: ONE HUNDRED SIX years ago this month, an editorial appeared in The Hartford Courant stating that ''Everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it.'' The words have been attributed to one famous Connecticut Yankee, Mark Twain, but they were actually written by his friend and sometime collaborator Charles Dudley Warner. And they are every bit as true today as they were then -- which is to say, not true at all.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: NEW FIRES APPEAR Strong winds and smoke-filled skies continued to stifle efforts to control the spread of raging forest fires in western Canada, while lightning storms caused at least 30 new fires in the worst hit region of southern British Columbia. About 1,000 firefighters and 100 members of the Canadian military were called into the province from around the country to fight blazes near Kamloops, 180 miles northeast of Vancouver. The province's premier, Gordon Campbell, who has declared a state of emergency, visited the area and said he was shocked by the damage, including the leveling of Louis Creek, a town north of Kamloops. Officials said it could be weeks before the blazes are all under control. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: STATE'S POPULATION SHRINKS People moved out of Connecticut during the late 1990's at a faster rate than out of other New England states, new data from the United States Census shows. Over all, the state had a net loss of domestic migrants of 64,610 people. Massachusetts was the only other New England state where more people moved out than moved in between 1995 and 2000. Data on migration showed that Connecticut had the ninth-highest rate of net migration loss in the nation for the period. Florida was the top destination for Connecticut residents, especially for the retired. About 40 percent of Connecticut's residents age 65 or older who left the state went to Florida. (AP)

title: A Park Bench That Remembers The Pigeon Flocks of Memphis
description: Gere Kavanaugh, an artist and designer in Los Angeles, grew up in Memphis, home to flocks of pigeons and a thriving cast-iron industry. She has fused those memories in her abstract iron bench, left, made on a grant by the Los Angeles Cultural Affairs Department. One challenge of designing a public perch, she said, is to make furniture that does not ''wind up being a public motel.'' To dissuade overnight visitors, the bench has a narrow seat (48 by 10 inches) and no back. Pigeons can be a nuisance, Ms. Kavanaugh said, but ''I've affection for their shape.'' She also drew inspiration from William Edmondson, a Nashville artist whose work included pigeon sculptures. The benches are $10,000 each. Ms. Kavanaugh is at (213) 687-8270.

title: Partly Mozart Followed by the Real Thing

One angle showed him in a familiar guise, beautifully depicted: his C minor Piano Concerto, illuminated with quiet radiance by the soloist Piotr Anderszewski. From another angle, he was completely deconstructed and reassembled in Alfred Schnittke's 1977 ''Moz-Art  la Haydn.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom Gets Aid Package
description: The government stepped forward yesterday with a 2.8 billion euro rescue package ($3.19 billion) for the troubled engineering company, Alstom, which makes trains, ships and power-generation equipment. In return for the bailout, the government will take a 31.5 percent stake in Alstom. The government is leading a group of more than 30 banks in an effort to keep Alstom, which was privatized in 1998, out of bankruptcy and to protect creditors and tens of thousands of jobs. The conservative government of Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin has outlined a policy to speed up privatizations, and promised that its involvement with Alstom would be over as quickly as possible.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Admits To Widespread Vandalism
description: A man pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct and criminal mischief this week in State Superior Court after admitting that he had vandalized statues at five Newark sites last winter, the Essex County prosecutor's office said yesterday. The man, Jamil Gadsden, 21, of Newark, had been charged in connection with only one incident of vandalism, in which he took a sledgehammer to a statue of the baby Jesus at St. Thomas Aquinas Church on Christmas Eve, knocking its head off. But he admitted in court on Tuesday that he had also used a sledgehammer to shatter statues at Washington Park, the Public Service Electric and Gas building, the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart and St. Lucy's Church. Under a plea agreement, he is to be sentenced to time served, followed by probation and psychiatric treatment. John Holl (NYT)

Its beat was grounded in Jamaican dancehall reggae, although it had also bounced through Panama. Above that beat, rappers rhymed in Spanish, mostly about dancing, drinking and sex. The rappers used street slang; many older listeners and upscale Puerto Ricans looked down on the music as vulgar. But for a younger audience, the beat, the attitude and the close, slow-grind dancing that went with them were irresistible.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ceiling Collapse At Grand Central
description: Part of a ceiling over a platform off the main concourse at Grand Central Terminal collapsed last night, damaging an empty train but causing no injuries or schedule delays, the authorities said. Marjorie Anders, a spokeswoman for Metro-North Railroad, said the collapse occurred about 9:30 p.m. It involved a large electrical junction box, or vault, which was suspended from the ceiling. When that fixture gave way, chunks of plaster and sections of wiring fell on a train car. Debris also fell on a platform, between Tracks 27 and 28, which was empty at the time, Ms. Anders said. She said train service would not be affected today, since trains that would normally use the two tracks can be rerouted. Ms. Anders said the only effect on riders last night was that lights went dark on platforms throughout the concourse level of the station, and passengers had to rely on the dimmer lights from inside trains. The cause of the collapse was unclear. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Web House-Hunts: 2 cents From All Over
description: ALONG with just about anyone looking for a home these days, Edie Hu, a 28-year-old cataloger at Sotheby's in Manhattan, hit the Internet earlier this summer. Across the country, her father, Michael Hu, an engineering consultant in Menlo Park, Calif., logged on, too.

title: Accounts
description: * Ricola Inc., Laufen, Switzerland, to McCaffery Ratner Gottlieb & Lane, New York, as the first agency to handle a new product in the United States, Refreshers sugar-free throat drops. Billings were estimated at $1 million. A radio campaign is expected to begin next month.

title: Court Order in Hamptons Murder Case Focuses on Lost Laptop
description: A state judge has ordered two lawyers to answer questions about the whereabouts of a missing laptop computer that prosecutors believe contains key evidence in the killing of R. Theodore Ammon, a millionaire Manhattan financier found dead in his Hamptons home two years ago.

title: College Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHILLINGER, MORTON, PH.D.
description: SCHILLINGER -- Morton, Ph.D., ABPP. On July 31, 2003. Clinical psychologist; founder and Executive Director of Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy; former Executive Director of the New York State Psychological Association; President, Section V of the Division of Psychoanalysis of the American Psychological Association. He is survived by his beloved partner, Elaine Rich; his daughter, Kristina Wyatt, her husband, Richard L. Wyatt, Jr., and their son, Richard John; his daughter, Erika Schillinger, her husband, Marc Tarpenning, their son, Griffin, and their daughter, Morgan; his son, William Schillinger, and his partner, Jeannie Amos; his son, Peter Schillinger, his wife, Lori Finsterwald, their son, Daniel, and their daughter, Hannah; and by his sister, Beverly Goodman. Talented jazz musician who played saxophones, clarinet, flute and trumpet since the 1940s, and, more recently, an outstanding student in the Jazz and Contemporary Music Program at New School University. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Contributions, if desired, may be made in his name to the Beacons in Jazz Scholarship Fund of New School University.

title: KEYSPAN REPORTS LOSS AFTER SALE OF CANADIAN ASSETS
description: The KeySpan Corporation reported a second-quarter net loss of $5.9 million yesterday, and it cited the costs of selling stakes in Canadian assets. The loss per share was 5 cents after payment of preferred dividends, in contrast to net income of $9.5 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier, KeySpan said. Revenue rose 16 percent, to $1.41 billion. Expenses from selling stakes in the gas processors KeySpan Canada and Taylor NGL were $34.1 million, or 22 cents a share, the company said. KeySpan, which is based in New York, used $120 million from the sales to pay debt. KeySpan sells gas to about 2.5 million customers in cities including New York and Boston.

title: A Suicide and Uncertainty in Korea
description: In life, Chung Mong Hun was this capitalist nation's economic ambassador to the Communist North, negotiating for South Korean tour buses to drive across the demilitarized zone, setting off fireworks to inaugurate North Korea's first industrial park, and posing with the North's reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Atlantic Beach: Body Of Missing Boater Is Found
description: The body of a boater missing for three days has been found by the Nassau County police and identified. The body of Yaakov Wiczyk, 57, of Hewlett Bay Park was recovered from Crooked Creek on Tuesday, the police said. Mr. Wiczyk was alone in his Boston Whaler motorboat in Reynolds Channel on Sunday when a large wave apparently struck the boat and washed him overboard, the police said. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Yanks Trade Benitez And Get Nelson Back
description: In the theater of the bizarre that Yankee Stadium can be, few news items are truly shocking. But the one announced in the tunnel beside the home clubhouse last night qualifies: Jeff Nelson is a Yankee again, and Armando Benitez is a Seattle Mariner.

title: NBC Is Said To Be Close To Signing Private Lynch
description: Representatives of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch are close to concluding a deal with NBC for her paid cooperation in the making of its television movie about her experiences as a prisoner of war in Iraq, two executives involved in the proposed deal said yesterday.

title: HALLIBURTON LOSES APPEAL OF $98.1 MILLION RULING
description: The Halliburton Company, a provider of oil field services, lost an appeals court bid to overturn a $98.1 million jury award to its rival, the BJ Services Company. BJ Services claimed Halliburton, which is based in Houston, infringed a patent for a method of hydraulic fracturing, which pumps liquid into the ground at high pressure to break open underground formations so that more oil can be recovered. Halliburton lost an April 2002 trial over the patent. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington upheld the jury finding that the patent was valid and infringed.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Fires Appear
description: Strong winds and smoke-filled skies continued to stifle efforts to control the spread of raging forest fires in western Canada, while lightning storms caused at least 30 new fires in the worst hit region of southern British Columbia. About 1,000 firefighters and 100 members of the Canadian military were called into the province from around the country to fight blazes near Kamloops, 180 miles northeast of Vancouver. The province's premier, Gordon Campbell, who has declared a state of emergency, visited the area and said he was shocked by the damage, including the leveling of Louis Creek, a town north of Kamloops. Officials said it could be weeks before the blazes are all under control. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARD, JUDGE ROBERT J.
description: WARD--Judge Robert J., August 5, 2003. Beloved husband of Renee J. Loving father of Judge Laura A. and Carolyn Ward; devoted brother of Joan W. Hill; cherished stepfather of Lawrence D. and Jonathan E. and Lauren Roberts, Jeffrey and Leslie Sokolow, Judith Sokolow, and Jonathan Sokolow and Dr. Laura Pasternak; doting grandfather. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services or M.S. Society, N.Y.C. Chapter. Funeral service Thursday, 1 PM at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 Street, New York City.

title: Aramark Reports Increase in Profit
description: The Aramark Corporation, a stadium concession and management company, said yesterday that fiscal third-quarter earnings rose to $89.3 million as sales increased.

title: Private Lynch Pulls Out of Proposed Movie Deal With NBC
description: Representatives for Pfc. Jessica Lynch have pulled out of a proposed deal with NBC that would have added Private Lynch's cooperation to a television movie that the network is producing about her ordeal in the war in Iraq.

title: Props for the Movie Set or Home, And Some That Are Comfy in Both
description: Need a 1950's pay phone or a fake computer bank for a futuristic movie? Try Modern Props in Los Angeles. If you want a reproduction of a Corbusier chair, head for a sister company, Modern Living, in West Hollywood. Top-of-the-line Italian kitchen? Try baby sister, Boffi Los Angeles, in Santa Monica.

title: Restoring the Blue Twinkle In Great-Grandpa's Eye
description: With help from photo-editing software, scanners have long made it possible for people to breathe new life, or at least color, into faded family photographs. But Grace Huang, assistant product manager for consumer scanners at Epson, said few people with a box of snapshots have been willing to tackle the chore.

title: Recuperating Gold Medalist Passes Test
description: Brooke Bennett has it all, almost.

title: UMass President, Facing Pressure Over Brother, Quits
description: William M. Bulger resigned today as president of the University of Massachusetts after months of mounting criticism and political pressure over his ties to his fugitive brother.

title: Pfizer Moves to Stem Canadian Drug Imports
description: Just days after the House of Representatives voted to legalize the import of cheap prescription drugs from Canada, Pfizer has moved to squelch the nascent trade at its source.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, BENJAMIN J.
description: GOLDSTEIN--Benjamin J. On August 5, 2003. Peacefully, surrounded by his family at the age of 88. Beloved husband of Gertrude, cherished father of Walter and Joel, loved father-in-law of Debra and Toni, adored grandfather of Marc, Rebecca and her husband Michael. Dear brother of Sylvia and David. A gentle man who was a friend to all and devoted to his family. He will be sincerely missed by all who knew him. Chapel service will be on Thursday, 1PM, at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, N.Y. Interment to follow at Mount Eden Cemetery. Donations in his memory can be made to Congregation Anshe Sholom, 50 North Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y. 10805.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMONS, NICHOLAS
description: SIMONS -- Nicholas. The Board, staff and children of East Harlem Tutorial Program mourn the untimely passing of Nicholas Simons. We extend our deepest condolences to our committed Trustee Marilyn Simons and her husband James. Our hearts go out to them in this time of sadness. Carmen Vega-Rivera Executive Director Lili Lynton Board Chair

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Expects To Meet Forecast
description: The EMC Corporation, one of the largest makers of computer data-storage systems, said yesterday that it expected to meet its third-quarter forecast for profit to rise to 4 cents a share, on an estimated sales increase to $1.45 billion to $1.5 billion. Second-half sales will increase by an unspecified percentage in the ''midteens,'' and gross margin, the share of sales left after production costs are paid, will widen to 48 percent by the end of 2004, EMC said. The company held its annual analyst meeting in New York yesterday. The chief executive, Joseph M. Tucci, is rebuilding profit after losses in 2002 and 2001. Last year, EMC had third-quarter net income of $21.3 million, or 1 cent a share, on sales of $1.26 billion.

title: Tenet Healthcare Paying $54 Million In Fraud Settlement
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $54 million to resolve government accusations that doctors at a hospital in Northern California conducted unnecessary heart procedures and operations on hundreds of patients.

title: Probation Dept. Is Now Arming Officers Supervising Criminals
description: New York City probation officers have been authorized to carry handguns under a new policy intended to enhance the supervision of criminals by increasing the number of officers required to routinely go into their neighborhoods and homes.

title: Colombian Warlord, Facing U.S. Charges, Turns On Charm
description: The United States has called him a major drug trafficker, and human rights groups want him tried for the slayings of thousands of villagers in Colombia's long war.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the Kennedy Center Honors misstated the age of the singer James Brown, who was among the artists named. He is 70, not 78.

title: Citigroup Selects Chief for Global Consumer Division
description: Citigroup promoted a longtime senior manager yesterday to chief executive of its largest and fastest-growing division.

title: U.S. Court Rejects Tire Safety Rule, Saying Margin for Error Is Too Great
description: A panel of three federal judges rejected a proposed tire safety regulation yesterday, saying it allowed for too much error.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Man Arrested In Death Of Son's Tennis Rival
description: The father of two teenage tennis players was arrested on suspicion of causing the death of one of his son's opponents by spiking a water bottle with an antidepressant before a game. Christophe Fauviau, 43, the father of Maxime, 15, and Valentine Fauviau, 13, was detained near his home in the southern town of Dax after Maxime's opponent, a 25-year-old school teacher, was killed in a crash after apparently falling asleep while driving. Traces of an antidepressant that causes drowsiness were found in his blood. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: A Jewel Courts a Better Setting
description: NESTLED behind tall bamboo groves two blocks from traffic-clogged Santa Monica Boulevard lies one of the 20th century's architectural treasures, the radically Modernist home that the architect Rudolf M. Schindler built for himself more than 80 years ago.

title: Liz Phair
description: In June, singer and songwriter Liz Phair released her first album in five years. Here, she answers questions from readers about her musical departure, touring and living with geeks.

title: Hiroshima, Nagasaki and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Former Post Editor Settles Suit
description: A former New York Post editor who had accused her British and Australian supervisors of discriminating against her because she is an American woman has settled her wrongful-termination lawsuit and recanted her statements. Citing unspecified ''evidence'' provided by The Post, the former Sunday editor, Maralyn Matlick, said she was mistaken when she said was unfairly dismissed last year. In a three-paragraph statement released yesterday, she said she now understood her previous claims ''to have been incorrect.'' In return for withdrawing the lawsuit in July, she will receive ''severance pay in recognition of my many years of dedicated service,'' she said. A Post spokeswoman, Suzanne Halpin, said the newspaper had no comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: MAN SENTENCED FOR ATTACK A Queens man was sentenced in State Supreme Court to 11 1/2 years in prison yesterday after pleading guilty to biting his girlfriend's face so savagely that she needed prolonged reconstructive surgery. The victim, Jessica Mencia, 22, remains "severely disfigured," according to the Queens district attorney's office. She was hospitalized for almost a month after the attack in February 2002, which occurred in the couple's South Ozone Park home. Ms. Mencia required skin grafts to repair the disfigurement, which included the partial severing of one ear. The man, Felix Rondon, 32, pleaded guilty to assault on May 27, admitting that the attack was intentional.

title: Both Sides See Verizon Talks Inching Toward an Agreement
description: Negotiations between Verizon Communications and its two main unions inched forward yesterday, with officials on both sides saying that they expected an agreement in the next few days.

title: BID FOR HISPANIC BROADCASTING SAID TO ADVANCE
description: The proposed $2.8 billion purchase of the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation by Univision Communications has been approved in an initial vote by the Republican majority of the Federal Communications Commission, agency officials said yesterday. The three Republicans, led by the chairman, Michael K. Powell, voted privately last week to approve the merger, said four Washington officials who asked not to be named. Univision, the largest Spanish-language television broadcaster in the United States, and Hispanic, the top Spanish-language radio company, proposed the merger in June 2002. It is possible that the two Democratic commissioners, Michael J. Copps and Jonathan S. Adelstein, who have not yet voted, could secure changes in the proposal or persuade Republicans to switch their votes, the officials said.

title: Market Place; Another Departure as Merrill Chief Tightens Hold
description: A week after the ouster of his powerful mentor, Arshad R. Zakaria, the head of the institutional banking business at Merrill Lynch, yesterday joined the burgeoning ranks of senior Merrill executives forced out by E. Stanley O'Neal, the firm's chairman and chief executive, who continues to solidify his grip on the firm.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Jerry Springer Is Not a Candidate
description: To the relief of some national Democrats, Jerry Springer said that he would not run for the United States Senate in Ohio because he could not escape ''the clutter'' of his television show, where guests often brawl. Mr. Springer, a former Democratic mayor of Cincinnati, had hired a team of consultants and had traveled the state widely for months, testing the waters for a 2004 campaign against the Republican incumbent, George V. Voinovich. In a news conference, Mr. Springer said he thought voters were receptive to his populist message, but he said he was ''not the perfect messenger,'' acknowledging high negative ratings in some polls. James Dao (NYT)

title: Group Linked to Al Qaeda Seen Behind Jakarta Blast
description: The terror attack at the J. W. Marriott Hotel that killed at least 16 people and wounded 150 on Tuesday was almost certainly the work of Jemaah Islamiyah, a group terror experts have linked closely to Al Qaeda, American officials said today.

title: A Landscaper Who's Partial To Southern California Natives
description: After working for the fashion designer Richard Tyler, Kathleen Ferguson, below, switched to fashioning landscapes. Smitten by Southern California's flora, Ms. Ferguson, a self-proclaimed ''plant geek,'' has created nearly 60 landscapes since 1999, including a 4,000-square-foot garden in Glendale Hills, detail at bottom.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Decline a Bit in July
description: Magazine advertising pages declined last month for the second consecutive month, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported yesterday.

title: Leader of I.R.A. Offshoot Convicted in Bombing That Killed 29
description: Ireland's antiterrorism court today convicted the head of the guerrilla group Real I.R.A., Michael McKevitt, for his direction of the organization, which killed 29 people in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998.

title: First Year of Hormone Treatment Is Found to Raise Risk of Heart Attack
description: Hormone therapy nearly doubles a woman's risk of having a heart attack during her first year of treatment, according to a new report, lending more weight to the idea that its use should be limited to healthy middle-age women seeking temporary relief from the symptoms of menopause.

title: After Sewage Plant Fire, the Real Odor Begins
description: Summer often brings special smells to the city, like the sharp aromas emanating from restaurant Dumpsters, or the hot, foul winds rising from the bowels of the subway. But few odors rival the stench -- part rotten egg, part chemical char -- that yesterday overpowered areas of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, where part of a system designed to clean odors at a sewage treatment plant was destroyed by fire on Tuesday night.

title: Banish Unwelcome Memories, or at Least Hide the Evidence
description: The new Digital Image Suite 9 from Microsoft packages the company's photo organizing program with its photo editing and retouching program, but the suite's most compelling new feature may be a tool that Microsoft calls Smart Erase.

title: Read His Lips: Do They Say Repeal All Those New Taxes?
description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg casts an eye toward the 2005 mayoral elections by traveling around the city more and holding ever-more-elaborate photo opportunities, he is beginning to hone his message in an area that he is particularly sensitive about: taxes.

title: Pataki Blocks Deal Crucial to City Plan To End Fiscal Crisis
description: In a direct rebuke to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki and State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi moved today to block a municipal bond deal that is critical to the city's efforts to close its $6.4 billion budget gap this year.

title: Police Hope T-Shirt Yields Identity of '91 Murder Victim
description: Maurice Sendak's most famous children's books are known for their darker side, with the roaring of terrible roars and the gnashing of terrible teeth. Now, the police are hoping that a Sendak illustration may lead them closer to solving a 12-year-old murder case.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We had a match that seemed perfect, until we discovered that one was a cattle rancher's son and the other was a vegan.''

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Front-Office Miscue Turns Into a Positive
description: Armando Benitez said he was not surprised that the Yankees unloaded him to the Seattle Mariners in what felt like a New York minute. But less than three actual minutes later, Benitez contended that everybody was surprised he had been traded. Some snippet of uncertainty about Benitez continued until his final seconds in pinstripes.

title: ASTROPOWER ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS FOR 10% OF WORK FORCE
description: AstroPower Inc., the maker of solar-power equipment that was delisted from the Nasdaq stock market in July, said yesterday that it laid off about 55 workers, or 10 percent of its work force, to try to control costs. The company said in a news release that it now employs about 500 people. Last month, AstroPower hired Bridge Associates L.L.C., a turnaround firm, to handle the daily operations and help the company stabilize its finances.

title: Crowded Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: POLICE CHIEF EXONERATED A judge declared Police Chief Earl Sanders of San Francisco "factually innocent" of conspiring to cover up a street brawl involving three off-duty officers, six months after a grand jury indicted him in the case. The formal exoneration entitles Chief Sanders, a 39-year veteran of the department, to have his fingerprints, mug shot and booking sheet destroyed. Although the charges against the chief and six other police commanders were dropped for lack of evidence, Chief Sanders said that only a full public acquittal would begin to undo the harm to his reputation. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WICZYK, YAAKOV
description: WICZYK--Yaakov. Yaak, our 30 years of relations and friendship have gone by in the blink of an eye. We grew up together and watched our families grow and prosper together. We will always remember you and carry you in our hearts for the rest of our days. Our love and prayers are with you and your wonderful family. Hank and Gerry

title: For the College-Bound, Dorm Linens 101
description: COLLEGE-BOUND students can be puzzled by lists of dorm-room necessities. What, for example, are extra-long twin sheets? And where can they be found?

title: The Kinko's Caper: Burglary by Modem
description: ON a steamy summer day, the 16-story apartment building on Kissena Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, hardly looks like a place where Secret Service agents would show up with a search warrant, and later for an arrest. Women trudge from the bustling markets just two blocks away, children and bags in tow; elderly couples sun themselves on park benches. Nothing about the quiet, neatly kept grounds suggests a crime scene.

title: A British All-in-One Is a Laptop on Tiptoes
description: England is not known as a hotbed of PC manufacturing, but a new machine from the British company Pelham Sloane may put the region on the design map. The company's PS1500 gracefully integrates the computer into a flat-screen monitor that is essentially a laptop standing on its edge. The entire unit is less than two inches deep.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AZERBAIJAN: PRESIDENT FLIES TO U.S. FOR TREATMENT Heydar Aliyev, the ailing 80-year-old Azeri president, left a Turkish hospital for treatment at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio, the embassy said, but gave no details about his condition. Doctors told The Associated Press that his condition was serious. CNN-Turk television, citing hospital officials, reported that Mr. Aliyev was on a respirator and only occasionally conscious. (AP)

title: Early Endorsement From A.F.L.-C.I.O. Eludes Gephardt
description: Despite aggressive efforts by Representative Richard A. Gephardt to quickly win the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s endorsement for the Democratic presidential nomination, the labor federation said today that it was not prepared to back anyone yet and would not decide before mid-October.

title: Murder, or Act of Mercy Under an Unforgiving Sun?
description: JOURNAL OF THE DEAD

title: African Episcopal Bishops Attack Vote for Gay Bishop of New Hampshire
description: Anglican church leaders across Africa, where homosexuality is widely scorned, denounced a decision installing an openly gay bishop in the Episcopal Church USA and predicted a schism in the global Anglican Communion unless the vote is overturned.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawsuit Planned After Shooting
description: The family of an unarmed woman who was shot and wounded by the police on Monday night during a search for stolen goods in a Williamsburg apartment wants a full investigation and plans to sue the city, the woman's lawyer, Steven J. DeLorenz, said yesterday. The woman who was shot, Vivian Rodriguez, 30, a visitor from the Dominican Republic, was listed in serious condition at Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday. Her mother, Gladys Rodriguez, said through a Spanish interpreter that her daughter, who was shot in the abdomen, appeared well, and added: ''I want to know, why did they have her arrested? Why did they shoot her?'' The police have said the shooting was accidental. The detective responsible has not been interviewed yet, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Hiroshima, Nagasaki and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Loses Fight to Avoid Listing on Sex Offenders' Registry
description: A Minnesota man must register as a sex offender even though he has not been convicted of a sex crime, the federal appeals court in St. Louis ruled yesterday. That ruling ''turns reason and fairness on its head,'' wrote Judge C. Arlen Beam, who nonetheless concurred in the unanimous decision of the three-judge panel of the court.

title: Chief of Sony Pictures Plans to Step Down
description: John Calley, who has led three film studios in his 40-year career and championed movies like ''The Exorcist'' and ''Catch-22,'' plans to step down as chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment to become a producer, the studio said today.

title: College Athletes (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Despair of the Jobless
description: The folks who put the voodoo back in economics keep telling us that prosperity is just around the corner. For the unemployed, that would mean more jobs. Are there more jobs just around the corner?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: A Horse Of the Same Color
description: Italian researchers say they have cloned a horse, opening the way for champion geldings to produce successors. The technique required preparation of nearly 850 embryos, made by transferring the nucleus of skin cells from adult horses into empty horse eggs retrieved from slaughter houses, the researchers say in this week's Nature. In one of the few successes, a foal named Prometea was born, brought to term in the womb of the horse from which she had been cloned. The horse joins a growing list of cloned mammals, starting with Dolly the sheep. Nicholas Wade (NYT)

title: Hiroshima, Nagasaki and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffeepots Out of the Old West, Some to Take Home to Tip and Sip
description: In the first half of the 20th century, California was a leader in commercial ceramic production, blending Mexican, Japanese and European aesthetics with new industrial processes. The evidence can be seen through Jan. 25 in ''California Pottery: From Missions to Modernism,'' an exhibition at the Autry Museum of Western Heritage in Los Angeles. The show traces California pottery from tiles of the teens to minimalist planters of the 1950's. Above are demitasse coffeepots from Pacific Pottery's 1934 Hostessware dinner service, examples of the solid-color dinnerware that became a national fad. Now reproduced by Bauer Pottery, they are sold at the museum store for $75 each. The Autry Museum is at 4700 Western Heritage Way; (323) 667-2000.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Hostage Holders Seek Contact
description: Kidnappers from Algeria who are holding 14 European hostages in neighboring Mali have phoned German government officials, seeking to cut out any mediators, the public television network ARD reported. But Berlin had ruled out negotiating with the kidnappers directly, to avoid dealing with ransom demands themselves, the network said. The German Foreign Ministry declined to comment, as it has done since the abductions in March. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Gruesome Discovery at Pet Store: 200 Animals Dead or Starving
description: When the police here investigated claims and counterclaims by the owners of a pet shop and its landlord, they thought they might find evidence of a burglary.

title: Talks Progress On Drug Card In Medicare
description: House and Senate negotiators say they have made progress toward agreement on a discount card that could cut prescription drug costs for the elderly by 15 percent in 2004 and 2005.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about rising sales of Japanese cars in Europe misstated the percentage increase for Toyota through June, over those in the period a year earlier. It was 2.7 percent, not 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GETTENBERG, FRIEDA. (NEE LIBEN)
description: GETTENBERG--Frieda. (nee Liben). On August 6, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Gustave. Loving sister of Jay Liben and the late Mildred Yenkin. Cherished aunt of Nina Kurzban and Lynn Liben. Dear great-aunt of Steven, Robert, Amy Kurzban and David Liben-Nowell. Private service.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Soft Drinks Investigated
description: The Indian government said yesterday that it was investigating an accusation by an independent environmental group that the Indian products of soft drink makers Coca-Cola and Pepsi contained dangerous levels of pesticide residue. The health minister, Sushma Swaraj, above, told the Indian parliament, ''It is a serious issue, and we are seeking to collect all the facts.'' But irate members of the parliament demanded that the government impose a countrywide ban on Coca-Cola, Pepsi and several other drinks marketed by the two corporations. The Indian parliament stopped the sale of the soft drinks within the parliament building and grounds. Coca-Cola and Pepsi on Tuesday challenged the accusations by an independent New Delhi-based environmental group that their Indian products contained dangerous levels of pesticide residue. Hours earlier, Sunita Narain, head of the group called Center for Science and Environment, said that Coke and Pepsi contained 30 and 36 times more pesticide residue, respectively, than the levels allowed by guidelines of the European Union. Coke and Pepsi are the country's two largest selling soft drink brands, and their allied brands like Sprite, Mirinda and Fanta are also popular. Researchers of the Center for Science and Environment tested 12 bottles of Pepsi and Coke bought in New Delhi and said they found high levels of toxic chemicals like the banned DDT, as well as Lindane and Malathion. But soft drinks sold by Coke and Pepsi in the United States showed no pesticide residue, the group said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARBER, GENE
description: FARBER--Gene. Of Westport, CT, NYC and Roussillon, France. On August 1st, 2003, age 65, after a courageous 17 year battle with prostate cancer. Gene was the owner, along with his wife Joanna of Parc Monceau Country French Antiques in Westport. His family, Joanna, Jonathan, Samantha, Anna and Nicole deeply mourn his loss. Dad, you will be in our hearts forever.

description: A selection of sculptures and paintings that can be found in New York City's parks and museums this summer.
