Modern Saints
description: Josh Gosfield's series of modern "saints" began when he turned a friend into Santa Isabella.

title: Fierce Firefight in Baghdad
description: A fierce gun battle broke out between U.S. soldiers and unidentified attackers in Baghdad on Thursday.

title: Separate But Equal Opinions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: U.S. Panel on Religious Freedom Drops China Visit, Protesting Curbs
description: A United States commission that planned to examine religious freedom in China called off its visit after the Chinese authorities imposed ''unacceptable last-minute conditions'' on the trip, commission officials said today.

title: 'Half Air'
description: Marianne Boesky Gallery

title: Shuttle Flights May Resume Before NASA Culture Changes
description: The co-chairman of an independent panel monitoring the resumption of space shuttle flights said today that it would probably be unable to measure NASA's efforts to change its management culture. The conclusion comes even though the board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia has identified management problems as being equal in importance to the specific physical causes of the crash.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARZULLO, FRANK N., M.D.
description: MARZULLO--Frank N., M.D. Peacefully on August 5, 2003. A loving husband, father, step father and grandfather to us all; a physician and friend who touched many lives with his gentility and humanity. Jamie and Neil

title: Court Told of $46.5 Million Amassed From Jailed Mogul's Assets to Repay Creditors
description: After a six-year international search for the assets of Robert E. Brennan, the imprisoned former penny-stock tycoon, a bankruptcy trustee disclosed today that he had assembled a fund of $46.5 million to repay some of the millions of dollars in debt Mr. Brennan amassed while living a grand lifestyle in the 1980's and 90's.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the conviction of Michael McKevitt, a leader of an Irish Republican Army offshoot known as the Real I.R.A., misstated the charge. He was accused of having directed the faction, which carried out the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland; he was not accused of direct involvement in the bombing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Antiterror Exercises
description: China conducted a large joint military exercise with its Central Asian neighbors in an effort to show that it is serious about terrorism. The drill was seen as an attempt to balance the growing United States military presence in Central Asia and to reinforce a regional group called the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, which comprises Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Russia and China. The exercises involved more than 1,000 troops and included training in fighting terrorists and rescuing hostages, state media said. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Batting Lefty Remains a Problem for Williams
description: The Texas Rangers started a right-handed pitcher yesterday, which meant Bernie Williams would have to hit left-handed. That is a problem for Williams these days, so Manager Joe Torre rested him.

title: 'This Is Lagos'
description: Skoto Gallery

title: Rockefeller's Legacy Of Roads
description: John D. Rockefeller Jr. (1874-1960), son of the founder of Standard Oil, is remembered for his philanthropy: $537 million in gifts to educational, cultural, medical and other charitable projects. In New York alone he founded Rockefeller University, built Riverside Church, bequeathed the site for the United Nations headquarters and donated the Cloisters and Fort Tryon Park.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: No one has done an official count, but it seems safe to say that Astoria, Queens, ranks near the top when it comes to sheer numbers of Greek restaurants and sidewalk cafes. Cavo combines both, in a setting straight out of Club Med. The place is enormous, with a bar and lounge up front and a vast dining room whose front section, called the Paradiso Lounge, is dominated by a living bamboo tree. The furniture comes straight out of Trader Vic's. There's more. A large sunken patio, dotted with canvas umbrellas and equipped with its own bar, takes care of the outdoor-cafe function.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Chechen women who have become suicide bombers during the war with Russia rendered the English spellings of two surnames incorrectly. The 20-year-old woman who attacked a music festival in Moscow was Zulikhan Elikhadzhiyeva, not Yelikhadzhiyeva. The head of the Society of Chechen-Russian Friendship, an advocacy group, who called suicide attacks an inevitable result of Russian atrocities, is Imran Ezhiyev, not Yezhiyev.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Jos Antonio Hernndez-Diez
description: New Museum of Contemporary Art

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Reversing Trend, Insurer Enters State
description: The first automobile insurer since 1996 to enter the New Jersey market was announced yesterday by Gov. James E. McGreevey. In the last decade, 20 insurers, including most recently State Farm Insurance, have withdrawn or have made plans to withdraw from the state, complaining of over-regulation and other unfavorable business conditions. The new company, Mercury Insurance Group, plans to offer 4,000 policies to drivers whose insurance will not be renewed by State Farm. The state has 5.9 million drivers, including more than 550,000 residents who drive without insurance, officials said. Plans by Governor McGreevey to overhaul insurance include easing insurance regulations and cracking down on driver fraud. Wendy Ginsberg (NYT)

title: F.B.I. to Lead Inquiry Into Embassy Bomb Attack in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 8 - A team of F.B.I. agents is being sent here to lead the investigation of Thursday's bomb attack outside the Jordanian embassy, American officials said today.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BASF Reports Lower Earnings
description: BASF, the world's top chemicals company, posted lower second-quarter earnings and sales yesterday and pointed to major difficulties in achieving the 2002 results for all of 2003. Operating profit rose 1.2 percent to 832 million euros ($944.1 million), but special charges for restructuring in the region of the North American Free Trade Agreement reduced it to 774 million euros, 5.3 percent lower than a year earlier. Net profit, hit by one-time tax charges, fell 61 percent to 195 million euros. Sales declined 1.6 percent, to 8.2 billion euros. The company, based in Leverkusen, Germany, said that was mainly because of the weaker dollar. Shares fell 3.8 percent to 39.83 euros on the news. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Ted Faiers -- 'Paintings From the 1950's'
description: Richard York Gallery

title: Working Up A S.W.E.A.T.
description: The feature-film version of the 1970's cop series ''S.W.A.T.'' preserves the most memorable thing about the old television show: Barry DeVorzon's wah-wah crackle theme song. (Hearing constant variations on it as arranged by the gifted Elliot Goldenthal is hilarious.) Unfortunately the director, Clark Johnson, and a battery of writers have also retained the punitive monotony and barely coherent narrative thinness of the old show as well. This film evokes the feeling of wasting a rainy Saturday afternoon.

title: Harmful Cuts for Cancer Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Are Considering Legislation in Hartford That Could Threaten Budget Deal
description: One week ago, with little discussion and less enthusiasm, lawmakers here passed a bipartisan budget deal that neither side liked but both agreed was the only way to settle a stalemate on how to finally close a billion-dollar deficit.

title: Jets' Tackle Given Look as a Short-Yardage Back
description: The last time the Jets experimented with using an unorthodox player in a goal-line situation, it turned out so badly that their offensive coordinator, Paul Hackett, contended that he removed all film clips of it from the team's training facility here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORTCHMAR, LUCY (NEE CORES)
description: KORTCHMAR -- Lucy (nee Cores). Died peacefully on Martha's Vineyard on August 6 at 91. Born in Moscow she came to the US at the age of nine and made a career as a graphic designer and later an author. She combined a warm and generous heart with a brilliant intellect. A loving wife of the late Emil, she will be missed by her children Michael & Daniel, grandchildren Grace, Samuel, Sophia and Stella; daughters-inlaw Maggie and Ellen and her friends of all generations. A memorial service in New York will be announced.

title: Judge Criticizes Police Methods Of Questioning War Protesters
description: A federal judge in Manhattan criticized police officials yesterday for the way demonstrators against the war in Iraq were interrogated earlier this year, and he made clear that civil liberties lawyers could seek to hold the city in contempt of court in the future if the police violate people's rights.

title: 'Protest'
description: Pace-McGill Gallery

title: 'Koi . . . Mil Gaya'
description: Directed by Rakesh Roshan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPERMAN, ELIZABETH ''LILLIAN''
description: COOPERMAN -- Elizabeth ''Lillian''. Of Coconut Creek, FL, passed away August 7, 2003. Loving wife of the late Philip, adored mother of Dr. Avram Cooperman, Gerald Cooperman and Amy (Fred) Weiss, cherished grandmother of Daniel and Meredith, Aaron, Alisha and Cameron, Jeffrey, David and Beth. Memorial contributions B'nai Torah Congregation C/O the ''Lillian and Philip Cooperman Adult Education Academy,'' 6261 SW 18 Street, Boca Raton, FL 33433. Services Sunday, August 10, 10 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: New Video Releases
description: Spider

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 34 Arrested In Drug Operation
description: The police, state prosecutors and federal authorities announced yesterday that they had dismantled four major heroin and cocaine operations in the Bronx and shut down a Colombian trafficking organization in Washington State. That operation, in Seattle, supplied two of the operations and coordinated large drug shipments into the city. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the two-year investigation led to the arrests of 26 people in New York and 8 in Seattle and that more arrests were expected in both cities. Bridget G. Brennan, the city's special narcotics prosecutor, said the investigation, known as Operation Slam Dunk, was a textbook example of police starting with street-level buys and working up to major traffickers. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Pataki Warns of Financial Consequences if Racing Agency Is Indicted in Tax Fraud
description: New York State stands to lose millions of dollars in gambling revenue if federal prosecutors decide to seek an indictment against the New York Racing Association on tax fraud charges, the Pataki administration has informed the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn.

title: Fire Department and Union Disagree on Closings' Effect
description: The New York City Fire Department released figures yesterday that it said proved that closing six engine companies in May had had only a minimal effect on fire operations. But fire union representatives said that the department was misleading the public by releasing only part of the data.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Landlord Convicted In Tenant Death
description: A landlord who shot one of his tenants to death in 1999 after a rent argument was convicted yesterday of first-degree manslaughter in State Supreme Court in Queens. According to court testimony, the landlord, Richard Kearney, 49, of Springfield Gardens, argued over rent payments with the tenant, Bernard Giles, 37, on Nov. 30, 1999. Later, Mr. Kearney shot Mr. Giles in the neck and fled New York City. He was arrested in Memphis in September 2001, after the Cold Case Squad of the New York Police Department began investigating the case. Mr. Kearney faces a prison term of up to 25 years.

title: Younger Blacks Tell Democrats To Take Notice
description: The debate had become a familiar one for LaShannon Spencer. As director of political affairs for the Democratic Party of Arkansas, Ms. Spencer, 30, is charged with taking the pulse of voters and keeping them connected to the party.

title: Women Get Jail for Forcing Girls Into Brothels
description: Their words, relayed through an interpreter, were halting and disjointed. But the poignancy of their stories was magnified by the fidgeting and sobbing of the three teenage Mexican girls, as they told a nearly full courtroom today how they had been lured to the United States from poor villages and forced to work as prostitutes in two New Jersey brothels.

title: Episcopalians Approve Local Option on Same-Sex Unions
description: Episcopal Church leaders approved a landmark resolution this evening stating that local dioceses are within the bounds of the church when they allow clergy members to bless the unions of gay or lesbian couples.

title: David Webster, 72, High-Ranking BBC Official
description: David Webster, a former high official of the British Broadcasting Corporation who helped many of the countries of Eastern Europe develop independent broadcasting services, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 72 and also lived and worked in Manhattan.

title: National Security Aide Evokes Civil Rights Era
description: Condoleezza Rice, one of the highest-ranking African-Americans in the Bush administration, told a gathering of black journalists here today that growing up in the South during the civil rights movement had informed her view of American foreign policy in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Shares Advance as Retailers Raise Forecasts for Quarter
description: Stocks advanced yesterday as Wal-Mart Stores and Best Buy said quarterly earnings would exceed forecasts, bolstering retail shares. A surge in natural gas prices lifted energy companies like Exxon Mobil.

title: Paris in the Summer, When It Sits There
description: The young, honey-haired heroine of ''Le Divorce,'' the new Merchant-Ivory adaptation of Diane Johnson's brisk and funny novel, is named Isabel Walker. Played with sweet, laid-back abandon by Kate Hudson, she arrives in Paris from Santa Barbara to visit her half-sister, Roxie (Naomi Watts), whose marriage to a pouty French artist (Melvil Poupaud) from an imperious bourgeois family is abruptly ending.

title: TNT Hires Kerr To Serve as Analyst
description: TNT yesterday hired Steve Kerr, the former Chicago Bulls and San Antonio Spurs guard, as an analyst for its National Basketball Association coverage.

title: Coverage of Bryant? Let's Go to the Tape, Over and Over Again
description: One day after Kobe Bryant's seven-minute court hearing on a sexual assault charge, television was still showing him walking and walking and walking. No man has arrived more times for a public appearance of so little consequence. Bryant did sit during the hearing, but it was his walking that captured TV's imagination.

title: 36 Hours | Vancouver, British Columbia
description: THE 2010 Winter Olympics, recently awarded to Vancouver, British Columbia, promise to bring a new level of attention to Canada's far-western gem. But this is a city at its best in summer, when the weather is reliably decent and perfect at times. Vancouver is surrounded by water and mountains and is breathtakingly beautiful, especially when the sun shines. And the city combines its frontier feel with a lack of pretension and a modern aspect. It is by far Canada's most important Pacific city, a global magnet that attracts immigrating and visiting Asians. Physical and cultural riches abound, and the Asian food scene is so good and so vast as to have few rivals in North America. MARK BITTMAN

title: Stopping A.T.M. Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping List | Yard Party
description: IF you let the summer go without having a yard party, it will not be for the lack of this year's supply of portable, stackable, foldable and inflatable party gear -- ready, at a moment's notice, for people-packed celebrations. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Acts to Prevent Rift on Gay Bishop
description: LONDON, Aug. 8 - The Archbishop of Canterbury, spiritual leader of the world's 79 million Anglican Christians, said today that he would convene an extraordinary meeting of Church leaders here to avert a schism over the confirmation of the first openly gay bishop in the United States Episcopalian Church.

title: Julius Baker, Principal Flutist Of Philharmonic, Dies at 87
description: Julius Baker, the principal flutist of the New York Philharmonic for 18 years and the most prominent American flutist of his generation, died on Wednesday in Danbury, Conn. He was 87 and lived in Brewster, N.Y.

title: AMERCO, IN CHAPTER 11, REPORTS ADDITIONAL LIABILITIES
description: Amerco Inc., whose stock has doubled since its June bankruptcy filing on speculation that it will be able to repay debts, said yesterday in a court filing that it had liabilities almost three times larger than previously disclosed. Amerco, parent of the truck rental company U-Haul, listed $1.78 billion in assets and $2.35 billion in debts. When it filed to re organize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on June 20, it listed $1.04 billion in assets and $884 million of debts, an indication that creditors might be fully paid. The additional debt makes it less likely that there will be money left over for shareholders, lawyers said. Amerco shares fell 89 cents, or 10.5 percent, to $7.60.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: ABN Profit Rises 46%
description: The banking company ABN Amro Holding said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 46 percent, to 782 million euros ($887.3 million), thanks to cost-cutting measures, low interest rates and a thriving mortgage business in the United States. ABN beat analysts' forecasts of a 682 million euro profit. The bank said it expected a 15 percent rise in annual profit. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Of Revenge, Redemption And Parole
description: MORE than most, Norma Hill had a right to want Kathy Boudin to rot in jail for eternity. ''I lived with anger and the need for revenge for 10 long years,'' Ms. Hill wrote recently to state parole officials. Somewhere along the line, though, something changed her mind and her heart. She met Ms. Boudin.

title: Editorial Page Of Times Gets A New Deputy
description: Andrew Rosenthal, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, has been named the newspaper's deputy editorial page editor.

title: Some Hear a Last Hurrah for Boston's Irish Democrats
description: The abrupt resignation by William M. Bulger as president of the University of Massachusetts on Wednesday was more than just the end of the career of one of the most powerful political figures in the state over the past four decades.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Freaky Friday'' yesterday misspelled the surname of one screenwriter. She is Heather Hach, not Hatch.

title: Private Lynch Pulls Out of Movie Deal With NBC
description: Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch has pulled out of a proposed deal with NBC to cooperate with a television movie about her ordeal as a prisoner of war in Iraq.

title: Hollywood Is All Eyes as One of Its Own Takes a New Stage
description: George Butler, the producer and director of the 1977 documentary that helped make an Austrian immigrant bodybuilder named Arnold Schwarzenegger a star, today recalled the early days when he met Mr. Schwarzenegger in Brooklyn.

title: 'Mighty Graphitey'
description: Feature

title: Hanging 10, From Surf to Sheboygan
description: With the surfing documentary ''Step Into Liquid,'' the filmmaker Dana Brown takes over the family business. His father is Bruce Brown, whose 1966 film, ''The Endless Summer,'' which followed a group of clean-cut surfing champions on a world tour, became one of the most successful documentaries of all time. The younger Mr. Brown was the co-writer and an associate producer on ''The Endless Summer II,'' a sequel released in 1994. With ''Step,'' he assumes the entire process, which includes writing, editing and delivering the casual, conversational narration that the senior Mr. Brown made a trademark of his films.

title: Jones Apparel Wins Auction To Gain Anne Klein Parent
description: The Jones Apparel Group prevailed in an unusual auction yesterday for a bankrupt clothing company that owns the potentially lucrative Anne Klein brand.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MOSS, CHARLES B.
description: MOSS--Charles B. We celebrate your life. Love, Nancy and Charle

title: Chevrolet Aims to Take Lead From Ford With Nine New Models
description: The Chevrolet division of General Motors plans to introduce nine new models over 20 months, starting in January, setting up a battle to overtake the Ford brand as the nation's top seller.

title: YankeeNets Unravels, And Teams May Move
description: The strains within YankeeNets, once heralded as a model for sports conglomerates, are so deep and bitter that the holding company is close to breaking apart, according to people involved with the company.

title: Big Board to Eliminate Rule On Moving to Another Market
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would drop a rule that has made it difficult for companies whose shares are listed on the exchange to leave it and move to another market, like the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Science Times on July 22 about a study of athletes' use of black greasepaint under the eyes misstated a finding. Greasepaint reduced glare and increased the athletes' contrast sensitivity -- their ability to distinguish an object from its background. It did not reduce contrast sensitivity.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bechtel Ends Move for Work In Iraq, Seeing A Done Deal
description: The Bechtel Group, one of the world's biggest engineering and construction companies, has dropped out of the running for a contract to rebuild the Iraqi oil industry, as other competitors have begun to conclude that the bidding process favors the one company already working in Iraq, Halliburton.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Chinese Envoy Arrives
description: With six-party talks over North Korea's nuclear program expected to take place within a month in Beijing, China's vice foreign minister, Wang Yi, arrived in North Korea to exchange views on the talks and on bilateral ties. Earlier this year, China's new leadership asked North Korea to renegotiate their mutual defense treaty, but North Korea refused until world pressure eases over the nuclear program. Next week, a higher-level Chinese delegation, led by Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing, is to visit South Korea. James Brooke (NYT)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Rises At Barclays
description: Barclays yesterday reported a 12 percent increase in pretax profit for the first six months, to 1.96 billion ($3.16 billion), as consumers took out more loans, and corporations issued more debt. Higher revenues from mortgages and personal loans pushed Barclays's personal-finance profits up 12 percent, to 534 million. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: A True Story of Courage Rearranged Into a Drama
description: A compelling true story sometimes becomes less so when translated to the stage, and ''Conversation With a Kleagle,'' at the WorkShop Theater on West 36th Street in Manhattan through Aug. 16, is a case in point.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about a dispute at the Opera Company of Brooklyn over plans to use a virtual orchestra tomorrow referred incorrectly to the board that was reportedly not informed. That body, from which the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne and the soprano Deborah Voigt resigned in protest, was the board of artistic trustees. The artistic director and principal conductor, Jay D. Meetze, says the board of directors had agreed to the decision.

title: It All Depends on What You Mean by 'Have'
description: So if you're asking me did Iraq have weapons of mass destruction, I'm saying, well, it all depends on what you mean by ''have.''

title: New Rules on Disclosure Proposed for Fund Brokers
description: Brokerage firms that sell mutual funds should tell customers when the firm or a broker has financial incentives to sell one fund instead of another, the NASD said yesterday. It announced plans to propose rules to require such disclosure.

title: DEAN FOODS EARNINGS RISE; WARNING SENDS SHARES DOWN
description: The Dean Foods Company said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 14 percent because of lower costs. The company said profit this quarter would be less than analysts expected, sending its shares down as much as 7.5 percent. Net income in the second quarter rose to $83.8 million, or 54 cents a share, from $73.2 million, or 48 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales fell 3.2 percent, to $2.22 billion. In the last year, the company has closed its dairy operations in Puerto Rico and plants in Ohio and Vermont to reduce costs. Dean Foods said third-quarter earnings would be 51 to 53 cents a share. Analysts had expected earnings of 54 cents, according to Thomson Financial. Shares of Dean Foods fell $1.17, to $27.96.

title: Printz Dance Project
description: Joyce SoHo

title: Back in Fray, Gore Urges Voters to Fire Bush
description: Former Vice President Al Gore waded back into presidential politics yesterday with a speech accusing the Bush administration of having promoted ''false impressions'' about the need to go to war in Iraq and to cut taxes.

title: Is Monday The New Friday?
description: DURING the summer months, callers to Benjamin Doller's office on Monday morning sometimes get a voice mail message informing them that he is away from his desks and probably won't be reachable until later that afternoon. That's because Mr. Doller, a Sotheby's senior vice president, is probably on a tennis court near his rental house in East Hampton, N.Y., fine-tuning his backhand. Monday also finds Andr Balazs and his wife, Katie Ford, relaxing by the water at Sunset Beach, the trendy boutique hotel that Mr. Balazs owns on Shelter Island. And while the publicist Harriet Weintraub used to race back from her summer home in Water Mill to Manhattan on Sunday nights so that she could be at her desk first thing Monday morning, she now takes the 10 a.m. train on Monday, arriving at work sometime after noon.

title: ALLIANT, MILITARY CONTRACTOR, SAYS EARNINGS ROSE 32%
description: The military contractor Alliant Techsystems said yesterday that first-quarter earnings jumped 32 percent, helped by acquisitions. The company is raising sales and profit forecasts as more money is being spent to supply United States troops in Iraq. Net income rose to $32.9 million, or 84 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 29 from $24.8 million, or 63 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose to $559 million from $520 million. Alliant benefited from the January acquisition of the satellite-parts maker Composite Optics, and the purchase last year of Boeing's ordnance business. The company increased its forecast for 2004 orders to about $2 billion from expectations of $1.8 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBIN, LORRY BREED
description: ROBIN--Lorry Breed. On August 3, 2003 at age 75. Mother of Michael and Craig and his wife Melissa. Grandmother of Shawn and Nathaniel. Aunt of Kathleen and James Breed. Interment private. Memorial Service at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76 Street, Saturday August 9th, 1 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Green Eggs And Mozart

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKS, WILLIAM
description: MARKS--William. We extend our condolences to Joanne, Jason, Ellisa and family. Billy will remain forever in the hearts of everyone he touched. We loved him. Karen and Buzz

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The targets were the American and the Jews.''

title: A Marriage, and Divorce, of Convenience at Verizon
description: Negotiations between Verizon Communications and its two main unions appeared to grow more thorny yesterday, with a settlement now unlikely in the next few days.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADAMS STREET PARTNERS, Chicago, a manager of private equity investments for institutions, said it had sold $61.7 million worth of shares in the polling firm Harris Interactive for its clients and collected about $3.4 million in fees.

title: NTT DoCoMo Earnings Aided By Sales of New Wireless Gear
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc., the world's second-largest wireless carrier after Vodafone, said today that it earned 197 billion yen ($1.6 billion) in the three months to June, thanks to a new lineup of handsets with cameras and growing demand for high-speed phone service.

title: 'From the Neck Up'
description: Garth Clark Gallery

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Campaign For Importing Drugs
description: Two members of Congress have mounted a bipartisan effort to build support for a bill that would allow Americans to buy imported prescription drugs. Representatives Rahm Emanuel, Democrat of Illinois, and Gil Gutknecht, Republican of Minnesota, spoke before 150 elderly people in Chicago. Mr. Emanuel said current laws turn people into ''drug runners,'' traveling to Mexico and Canada to buy drugs at much lower cost. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: $1.5 Million Award In Killing By Officer
description: A Cook County jury ordered the City of Chicago to pay $1.5 million to the family of a young man who was fatally shot in the back by a police officer in 1998. Witnesses testified in the civil suit that the officer, Kenny Lunsford, shot Michael Russell, who was unarmed but with a friend who had a gun, in a section of the Cabrini Green housing project known as The Wild Land. ''I have received justice today for my son,'' Mildred Hamilton, the mother of the victim, said. Mr. Lunsford, who has since retired, was never charged. Ainsley O'Connell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILL, KATHERINE JOHNSON
description: HILL--Katherine Johnson. On August 2, 2003. Beloved wife of the late A.C.C. Hill, devoted mother of Ruth, loving sister of Lillian Johnson. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC. Funeral Mass Saturday 5 PM at Church of Ascension.

title: Political Memo; For Pataki and Bloomberg, The Rift Is Becoming Visible
description: In the nearly two years of Michael R. Bloomberg's mayoralty, he has enjoyed what many political experts and government officials say is the best relationship a New York City mayor has had with his governor in decades.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Exile Figure Says He's Returned
description: Eloy Gutirrez Menoyo, a revolutionary comrade of Fidel Castro who later fought against him, endured a 22-year prison sentence and has been living in exile in Miami since the 1980's, announced that he was settling in Cuba to join the island's beleaguered dissident movement. Mr. Gutirrez Menoyo now espouses dialogue with Cuba, earning him the enmity of other Cubans in Miami, where he founded the exile group Cambio Cubano, or Cuban Change. The Cuban government has allowed him to visit in recent years, and it was during his current trip that he decided to remain while his family returned to Florida. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GODDARD, DONALD C.
description: GODDARD--Donald C. Beloved husband of the late Natalie Donay, died in Sussex, England on August 2, 2003. Survived by his wife, Carol Goddard and three sons, Adrian, Julian and Mark, as well as a godson, Donald Duvoll.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Drop In Retail Sales Slows
description: Store sales of goods were 6.4 percent lower in June than the same month a year earlier. The decline was welcomed by economists because May was even worse, with a fall of 11.1 percent compared with May 2002. An outbreak of the SARS virus crippled Hong Kong retailers in April and May. But the disappearance of the disease in early June and the city's removal from the World Health Organization's list of infected areas brought residents back to stores and allowed tourism to start to recover. Sales of motor vehicles, auto parts, jewelry and watches fell the most in June, while sales of photographic equipment, shoes, furniture and miscellaneous consumer durables increased. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Emotional Return Highlights the Yankees' Victory
description: The bullpen door opened, the country music played and 51,763 fans rose to cheer. It was the eighth inning, the Yankees were leading the Texas Rangers and Jeff Nelson was back where he belonged. It was almost too much for him to take.

title: Indonesia Links Hotel Bomber to Group With Qaeda Ties
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 8  The suicide bomber who police say was responsible for the car-bomb attack on the J.W. Marriott Hotel here this week was identified today as a 28-year-old recruit of the militant Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah.

title: State to Monitor Houston Schools To Ensure Reporting of Dropouts
description: The Texas Education Agency said today that it would closely monitor the Houston Independent School District, where an audit showed schools were vastly undercounting their dropouts, but that for now it would not accept an auditor's recommendation to rank the district's performance as unacceptable.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Verizon Unions See Delays Because of New Proposals

title: Productivity Jumps Again As Job Creation Remains Slow
description: The productivity of the nation's workers climbed at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the second quarter, the government reported today, an increase that was good news for corporate profits but that also heightened fears about a jobless economic recovery.

title: Munz Able to Overcome Injuries and Lack of Size
description: Diana Munz is different in many ways.

title: STEINWAY IS CLOSING A PLANT AND LAYING OFF 90 WORKERS
description: Steinway Musical Instruments said yesterday that it planned to close a plant in Nogales, Ariz., and that it would lay off about 90 workers to trim operations as demand for band and orchestra instruments declines. The company expects to record about $6.3 million in costs in the second half of the year for the closing, including about $700,000 in expenses for severance pay, it said. Net income for the second quarter, which ended June 28, fell 47 percent, to $2.16 million, or 24 cents a share, from $4.08 million, or 46 cents, in same period last year. Sales at the company, which makes pianos, trumpets, drums and other instruments, fell less than a percent, to $78 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAWKINS, HOWARD R.
description: HAWKINS--Howard R. Global Satellite Communications Pioneer, Dies at 87. Howard R. Hawkins, a leader in the development of the international satellite communications industry, died yesterday of respiratory failure in Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT. Mr. Hawkins was 87. Mr. Hawkins' six decade career in global telecommunications included over 30 years with RCA Corporation, where he served as Executive Vice President and Director. He was responsible for the establishment of RCA's satellite communications network, including the first communications satellite launched by private industry and the opening of satellite communications with China. During WW II he served as an FBI Special Agent in charge of a counter-espionage radio station that communicated with German Intelligence from 1943 until 1945. This covert operation was memorialized in the 1945 film ''The House on 92nd Street'' for which Mr. Hawkins served as technical advisor. From 1980-2000, Mr. Hawkins acted as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of American TransCom, a communications and business ventures consulting firm in Greenwich, CT. He also served as Trustee of twelve Merrill Lynch mutual investment companies and Chairman of Continental Steel Corporation from 1982 to 1985. Mr. Hawkins was raised on a 600-acre family farm in Pulaski County, Indiana, which he managed until 2002. A graduate of Indiana University with a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration and Doctor of Jurisprudence with distinction, Mr. Hawkins was awarded a Distinguished Alumni Service Award from Indiana University in 1969 and inducted into the Indiana University Academy of Law Alumni Fellows in 1994. A former research fellow at Harvard University Program on Information Resources Policy, Mr. Hawkins was a member of the bars of the United States Supreme Court, the State of New York and the Federal Communications Commission. Mr. Hawkins is survived by his wife, Helen Foley Hawkins, his children Katherine A. Hawkins, Howard R. Hawkins Jr, Rosemary Hawkins and Suzanne E. Hawkins, and his grandchildren Eric Hawkins, Brian Hawkins, Terence Gibbons and Jeffrey Gibbons. Visiting hours will be August 10, 2003 from 4PM to 7PM at the Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. The funeral will be held at St. Michael's Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT on August 11, 2003 at 10 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Maryknoll, Ossining, New York 10545.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hamilton: Anthrax Cleanup To Last Until 2004
description: The cleanup of the Postal Service's Hamilton mail processing center, contaminated with anthrax spores since October 2001, will last until at least next spring, federal authorities said yesterday. Fumigation equipment has been installed at the sprawling center, just a few miles east of Trenton, and cleanup crews are scheduled to begin using chlorine dioxide gas to decontaminate the building and equipment. The decontamination equipment now installed at the Hamilton center was used at the Brentwood mail center outside Washington, which took five months to purge of anthrax spores. Four anthrax-contaminated letters with Trenton postmarks were processed through Hamilton. Five people died and 13 were sickened in the fall of 2001.

title: New Targets in Iraq
description: The car bomb that ripped apart the Jordanian Embassy today has brought terrorism to the heart of Iraq's capital and presented the American-led occupation with a new and unpredictable threat.

title: Unflappable Britons Smile at Lunacy
description: A well-dressed, well-groomed woman takes a table at a sidewalk cafe and speaks to the waitress, slowly, searching for exactly the right words: ''I'd like something -- something warm but yet quite inviting. Something tantalizing on my tongue but succulent and reminds me of summer. Something that lets me know that I'm cherished and loved. You know, something that says to me, you know, 'Hey, girl, you're all right.' ''

description: FRIENDS have just invited us to their beach house in the Hamptons. They have a tennis court, a swimming pool and a Jacuzzi. They are lovely, charming, wonderful people. The following weekend, we've been asked to visit friends whose enchanting weekend home is the former gatehouse of an estate in the mountains. They are fabulous. So are the views.

description: A car bomb exploded today outside the Jordanian Embassy here, killing 11 people and wounding at least 65, in the bloodiest day since the Bush administration declared an end to major combat operations in Iraq on May 1.

description: Until last week Salimata Sanfo had never seen an ocean.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: MAN INDICTED IN HANGING DEATH OF TODDLER A man accused of tying an electrical cord around the neck of his 1-year-old son and hanging him from a shower-curtain rod has been indicted on two counts of murder, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The child, Omar Arias, was found dead, hanging in the bathroom of the Crown Motor Inn in Elmhurst last month. The authorities said at the time that the man, Juan Batista, 27, of Corona, had unsuccessfully tried to hang himself in the motel room. Mr. Batista is being held without bail and is undergoing psychiatric observation at Kings County Hospital Center. If he is convicted of the charges, he faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: TIAA-CREF Places Account in Review
description: TIAA-CREF, the financial services company that sells mutual funds, has placed its account in review. The account has been handled for more than 15 years by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group . Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: LOCKHEED SELLS ITS REMAINING STAKE IN LORAL SPACE
description: Lockheed Martin, which bought a stake in Loral Space and Communications for $344 million seven years ago, has sold its remaining holding in Loral for less than $750,000. Lockheed, the maker of commercial satellites, owned 10 percent of Loral and is an unsecured creditor, Lockheed said in a regulatory filing. The shares were sold on the open market after June 30, a Lockheed spokesman said. Loral Space filed for bankruptcy protection on July 15, citing a collapse in telecommunications investment. The value of Lockheed's investment had been reduced to $3 million by the end of last year, from $393 million at the end of 1999, Lockheed said last month. Shares of Lockheed fell $1.20 cents, to $49.70.

description: PRAGER -- Esther Spiro, peacefully in her sleep on August 6, in her 99th year. Devoted wife of the late William W. Prager, beloved mother of William, Jr. and Ruth Cogen, mother-in-law of Edward Cogen, cherished grandmother of Karen Balliett, Emily Prager, Deborah Cogen Swartz and Mark Cogen, beloved by seven great-grandchildren. title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Chechen women who have become suicide bombers during the war with Russia rendered the English spellings of two surnames incorrectly. The 20-year-old woman who attacked a music festival in Moscow was Zulikhan Elikhadzhiyeva, not Yelikhadzhiyeva. The head of the Society of Chechen-Russian Friendship, an advocacy group, who called suicide attacks an inevitable result of Russian atrocities, is Imran Ezhiyev, not Yezhiyev.

title: By and About Men, and They're Running With It
description: The White House is concerned. The Vatican is upset. And honestly, who can blame them, with so much normality up for grabs? Marriage and the family are under revision. Sodomy is, suddenly, not a crime. Gays are in Congress, in pulpits, on prime-time television. When I tell you that a show titled ''Bravehearts: Men in Skirts'' opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art this fall, you'll see how far things have gone.

description: Smit Salvage has been besieged with calls ever since a Norwegian-registered ship with thousands of luxury cars on board sank late last year in the English Channel.

title: Elegance, Wit and Pop in a Quarter-Century of American Design
description: Why is the architect Michael Graves so preferentially featured right at the start of ''USDesign 1975-2000,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Arts & Design (formerly the American Craft Museum)? Is it because he is one of the most important designers of the 20th century's last quarter? Or could it have anything to do with the fact that Target Stores, which sells housewares designed by Mr. Graves, is one of the exhibition's two main sponsors? (The other is J. P. Morgan.)

title: 3 Northeast States Win Verdict Against a Utility
description: A federal judge ruled today that an Ohio utility violated the Clean Air Act when it failed to install better pollution controls at a coal-burning power plant. The ruling was an important victory for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which along with the Environmental Protection Agency brought the case decided today and have filed similar suits against some of the nation's largest power companies.

title: Local Pick Making Twins Look Good
description: With the first pick in the 2001 amateur draft, the Minnesota Twins passed over pitcher MARK PRIOR from the University of Southern California and picked JOE MAUER, a catcher out of Cretin-Derham Hall High School in Minneapolis. The Twins gave Mauer a $5.15 million signing bonus.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Air Canada Posts Loss
description: Buffeted by intense competition, the outbreak of SARS in Toronto and the war in Iraq, Air Canada reported a second-quarter loss yesterday of 566 million Canadian dollars ($403.4 million), compared with a profit of 30 million Canadian dollars in the same period a year earlier. Revenues shrank by 24 percent to 1.95 billion Canadian dollars. The airline, based in Montreal, expects to complete a court-supervised restructuring by the end of the year. Its chief executive, Robert Milton, said the current focus was on renegotiating unsecured debt and commercial contracts, as well as raising equity to ensure the airline's stability. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Jodhpurs, Top Hats -- and Poison?
description: Here in Paris we had been basking in the glory of our homebred 1938 thoroughbred Horse of the Year, Seabiscuit. (Though much of the story covered in ''Seabiscuit'' is set in California, the horse spent his first year on a Paris farm.) Hundreds of Bourbon County residents turned out to be unpaid extras in the film and again to see its premiere in Lexington. But now we're throwing salt over our shoulders.

title: 4 Mexican Banks Still Fight Government Over '99 Bailout
description: A dispute over the auditing of bad loans sold to the government by four of Mexico's leading retail banks after the 1995 banking crisis is reopening one of the murkiest chapters in the country's recent financial history.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: 20 Years For I.R.A. Splinter Leader
description: The Special Criminal Court in Dublin sentenced Michael McKevitt, leader of the guerrilla group Real I.R.A., to 20 years in prison for directing terrorism. He was convicted by the antiterror court on Wednesday. His group was behind the 1998 bomb attack in Omagh, Northern Ireland, that killed 29 people. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Satellite Loss Widens
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings, the biggest satellite radio service, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss had widened to $161.9 million, partly because of costs to attract new customers. The net loss expanded to $1.38 a share, from $117.2 million, or $1.38 a share, a year earlier, the company said. The number of shares increased after XM sold new stock, a spokesman, Chance Patterson, said. Sales more than quadrupled to $18.3 million. XM added 209,178 subscribers in the quarter, increasing its total to 692,253. The company also wrote down the value of some satellites. Its shares fell $2.75, to $10.52.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POST, JEANNETTE
description: POST -- Jeannette. Beloved wife of Dr. Bernard Post (deceased); mother, great grandmother, twin sister of Israel M. Dolgin, aunt, great aunt, devoted friend. Her life's accomplishments are numerous; an attorney for nearly 70 years at a time when women weren't readily accepted, president of numerous civic and philanthropic organizations, a voice always to be listened to with admiration and respect. But her greatest and most lasting legacy to all who follow was her incredible devotion to family. She led by example, she was a Shepherd who made sure that her flock was never separated. She was surrounded by over 60 members of this extended family at her joint 90th party just two months ago; what a joyous memory! She truly will always be remembered as ''The leader of the Pack.'' May her memory be a blessing and inspiration. Kalmon & Peggy Dolgin, Joshua & Rebecca; Daniel; Brynn, Alan & Emma Klein

title: Rick or Victor? A Fateful Choice
description: The critic Roger Ebert has long examined certain movies frame by frame in the company of filmmakers. When he began, the films were 16 millimeter. ''Now we use DVD,'' he said this week by telephone from Chicago. ''Just go into a room with the lights off. Freeze a frame. You can back up.'' In his commentary on a new DVD edition of ''Casablanca'' (1942), released on Tuesday by Warner, he tells about watching the movie one shot at a time with the cinematographer Haskell Wexler.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT NEARLY TRIPLED
description: Lincoln National, a Philadelphia-based life insurer that is cutting as many as 1,000 jobs, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings almost tripled as rising equity markets increased profits from annuities. Net income rose to $142.7 million, or 80 cents a share, from $48.5 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier. Profit excluding realized investment gains and losses, as well as costs related to job cuts, rose to 86 cents from 62 cents, in line with a Thomson Financial survey of analysts. Lincoln is cutting as much as 17 percent of the work force, after three years of stock market losses have eroded its annuities portfolio. Shares of Lincoln fell 20 cents, to $35.

Howard knows he is straight. Or does he?

title: FOSTER WHEELER REPORTS SEVENTH CONSECUTIVE LOSS
description: Foster Wheeler, the power-plant and refinery builder, yesterday posted its seventh consecutive quarterly loss. The net loss, in the second quarter, narrowed to $29.3 million, or 72 cents a share, from $86 million, or $2.10, a year earlier. Sales fell to $935.8 million from $958.9 million. The company has laid off workers and renegotiated loans to avoid a bankruptcy filing and rebuild credibility after former executives priced contracts too low, analysts have said.

description: The duality of life in New York City usually comes down to its intense visceral pleasures versus the agonies of getting at them.

title: Editorial Observer; An Israeli Barrier That Could Have Reduced Conflict Is Increasing It
description: If you want to understand the dispute over the barrier that Israel is constructing to keep out Palestinian terrorists -- a twisting mix of barbed-wire fencing, electronic sensors, guard towers and concrete walls -- this economically depressed Palestinian town of 40,000 is worth a visit. Qalqilya sits next to the Israeli town of Kfar Sava. It was from here two years ago that a suicide bomber slipped into Israel and massacred 21 youngsters outside a seaside Tel Aviv discothque. Hundreds more Israelis have been killed since then, and many of the murderers came from this part of the West Bank.

title: Many Retail Stores Report A Surge in Sales Last Month
description: Retailers including Wal-Mart, Target and Gap said yesterday that July sales rose more than forecast as shoppers bought clothing and discounted summer merchandise.

title: With Kids in the Country, Parents Paint the Town
description: The cats don't quite know what to do with themselves. They keep wandering into the room my daughters share, gazing, bewildered, at the empty bunk beds, giving me a quizzical look when they can't locate their most willing playmates. The room is uncharacteristically tidy, since most of the girls' belongings were stuffed into trunks and hauled off, along with them, to sleep-away camp in the Adirondacks.

title: Iraqis to Keep Responsibility For Guarding Embassies
description: The deadly bombing of the Jordanian Embassy in Baghdad today will not prompt American troops to shift their mission and begin specifically protecting such installations, Pentagon officials said. The task of guarding foreign embassies will remain with Iraqi security forces, they said.

title: Bali Blast Defendant Gets Death Sentence
description: An Indonesian court sentenced a suspected member of the militant group Jemaah Islamiyah to death after convicting him for plotting the Bali nightclub bombing that killed 202 people in October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GETTENBERG, FRIEDA
description: GETTENBERG--Frieda. The officers, board and staff of the Women's Division/American Technion Society express profound sorrow at the loss of Frieda Gettenberg. Frieda Gettenberg served as National Women's Division President. She loyally served on the Women's Division National Board, Executive Committee and the Plaza-Midtown Chapter. We mourn the passing of our esteemed friend. Evelyn Berger, Women's Division Chairman of the Board Natalie B. Lyons, Women's Division National President Gloria Neimark Dir. Women's Leadership

title: A Seasonal Migration of Cultural Scope
description: IT is summer, when some of us will look for any flimsy excuse to be outside. There are people who can sit on a stoop, point their chins toward the sun and call it a day. I admire them. But there are also those of us, guilt-ridden, who need to feel we are going somewhere or doing something. The city, accommodating of most relatively harmless psychological maladies, fortunately satisfies a neurotic's needs with endless options, some frivolous, others less so.

title: U.S. Charges Pakistani in New York With Aiding Al Qaeda
description: APakistani man detained in Manhattan as part of the federal government's terrorism investigation was charged today with conspiring to support Al Qaeda.

title: Where Every Student's Goal Is to Design a Legendary Car
description: MARK KIM was hard at work creating a new line of Rolls-Royces that he had scheduled for a 2012 release. On the wall behind his desk were pinned photographs of lions, Movado watches, minimalist Italian couches -- all inspirations for his car designs, which were sleek and low-slung, with slitlike windows and snarling grillwork. The idea, he said, was to create something more modern and affordable than the big and boxy Rollses currently popular with hip-hop stars and anglophile billionaires.

title: In New York, Hispanics Hold Bleaker Views
description: Hispanics in New York City are unhappier with their government and more pessimistic about the economy than Hispanics in the nation as a whole, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found. In many ways, the poll shows, they hold opinions that are closer to those of their fellow New Yorkers than to those of Hispanics in the rest of the country.

title: A New Director For the Whitney
description: Ending one of the art world's most high-profile searches, the Whitney Museum of American Art has chosen Adam D. Weinberg, below, to be its next director. Mr. Weinberg, director of the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy, is no stranger to the Whitney. He has worked there twice before, most recently as a senior curator.

title: In the Church of Baseball, Idol Worship Is No Sin
description: EVEN aside from the emergency after-hours bat X-ray, it's been a hectic summer for Ted Spencer, chief curator of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.

title: The Smartest One of All
description: THE rearview mirror has come a long way since Ray Harroun, the winner of the first Indianapolis 500 in 1911, took an inspiration from horse-drawn taxis and installed the first one in a car. (He put the mirror in his Marmon racecar, having shown up at the race without the usual riding mechanic to watch for cars coming up from behind.)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Moves To Improve Rural Service
description: The Federal Communications Commission says it is taking steps to improve telephone, Internet and digital television services in rural areas. The commission said it was trying to educate people about government programs that can improve access to telecommunications services, like federal discounts for local phone service and for phone line installation. Officials said the effort would focus on Appalachia, the Mississippi Delta, American Indian lands and Alaskan native villages. The commission said it would study the use of grain silos, water towers and pumping stations as broadcast towers for delivering wireless high-speed Internet service.

title: Israel Reportedly Willing to Delay Portions of Barrier
description: Acknowledging American concerns about segments of the West Bank barrier it is building, Israel has agreed not to construct those segments until it reaches a compromise with the Bush administration, a senior Israeli official said today.

title: I.B.M. Files Countersuits in a Dispute Over Linux Licensing
description: I.B.M., the biggest corporate backer of Linux, the free computer operating system, has filed a barrage of counterclaims against the SCO Group, the software company that has put the computer industry on edge by asserting that users of Linux must pay it a license fee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARD, HON. ROBERT J.
description: WARD--Hon. Robert J. A wise and gentle man who was our dear friend. His sudden loss leaves a void in our lives that will be impossible to fill. Our hearts go out to Renee, Laura, Carolyn and family. They will be consoled in the years to come with so many wonderful memories. Diane and Arthur Abbey

description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the focus of several investigations, reported a second-quarter loss yesterday as it wrote down the value of some of its hospitals and spent more to cut jobs and fight litigation.

title: Finding The Model In Demand
description: YOU absolutely, positively have to have it. The latest, hippest, hottest car, that is, the one that is flying out of dealerships so fast that it's hard to get hold of one. What if the local dealer doesn't have the Honda Pilot sport utility vehicle or the Toyota Sienna minivan or the Nissan 350Z sports car -- all in demand right now -- or will sell it only for a premium over the sticker price? What is a lusting buyer to do?

title: Legal but Absurd: They Borrow a Billion and Report a Profit
description: IT sounds like a debtor's dream. The lender pays interest to the borrower, and the borrower reports a profit.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of Korea has left the basic interest rate at 3.75 percent. The governor of the bank, Park Seung, called for caution, citing weak consumer confidence despite rising exports and increased industrial output. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Send In The Marines
description: When Nigerian peacekeepers landed in Liberia this week, there was joy in the streets of Monrovia for the first time in months. There was also great relief in Washington, where the Bush administration is hoping West African forces will enable American soldiers to avoid intervening in Liberia's 14-year-old civil war. But the administration's sense of relief is misguided: counting on regional forces to bring peace to Liberia without substantial American participation is a mistake, one that will likely come with tragic consequences.

title: People
description: * Linus Karlsson and Paul Malmstrom, a leading creative team at Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, are leaving to join the New York office of the London agency Mother, which will open soon. The team, known in the industry as the Swedes, will be the co-creative directors of the office, Mother's first outside Britain. Mr. Karlsson and Mr. Malmstrom, who were most recently based at the Fallon New York office, have created award-winning campaigns for brands like Diesel jeans and MTV.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Official Faults China And Japan
description: A senior South Korean official berated the country's two huge regional competitors, China and Japan, for their reluctance to let their currencies float to higher levels for fear of having to increase the prices of products on world markets. Kwon Tae Shin, deputy finance minister, at a meeting of Asian finance ministers yesterday in Manila, said the Chinese opposed any move to strengthen the value of the yuan. The Bank of Japan, he added, was too quick to intervene to hold down the value of the yen, giving Japanese exports a competitive advantage. Korea, said Mr. Kwon, preferred to let the market decide the rate. Don Kirk (NYT)

And the wonder of her new ''Fuera de Tiempo''(''Out of Sync''), commissioned by the Latino Cultural Festival 2003 and performed on Wednesday at the Queens Theater in the Park, is the feeling of instinctual drama inherent in what is essentially pure or nearly abstract movement.

description: Joseph C. Wilson IV, a retired ambassador who was a secret envoy of the Bush administration to Africa and who publicly voiced doubts about a reported Iraqi weapons program, says he has become a target of a campaign to discourage others like him from going public.

title: Games Lift Spirits in Santo Domingo
description: The 400 meters' worth of hurdles that faced Flix Snchez on the track were nothing compared with the obstacle course confronting thousands of his fans who descended upon Olympic Stadium on Wednesday night. Soldiers with shotguns tried in vain to slam shut entry gates while frantic groups of people with and without tickets rushed through any opening, dashed up ramps and packed every available inch so that the standing-room-only crowd could hardly breathe, much less move.

title: Neighborly Vultures
description: There is really nothing adorable about vultures, adorable in human terms, that is. Most of the other animals that have learned to cohabit with humans -- to cause trouble in the suburbs, that is -- look comparatively warm and fuzzy, endearing enough if they are not eating your roses or your garbage. But a vulture has only the beauty of adaptation, of pure function, and its function -- feeding on animal remains -- is not a glamorous one. Even the chicks look like skinheads with switchblade beaks.

The decision, which was voted on by the museum's board yesterday afternoon and announced to the staff this morning, ends one of the art world's most high-profile searches. title: Coach Plans 2-for-1 Split
description: Coach Inc., the large seller of luxury leather goods, plans a 2-for-1 split of its common stock. The shares have risen 58 percent this year. Shareholders as of Sept. 17 will receive one additional share for each share held, payable Oct. 1. Coach will have about 183 million shares outstanding after the split. Coach said last month that fourth-quarter earnings increased 73 percent. It also raised its sales and profit forecasts. Shares rose $1.05, to $51.92.

description: Patrick Dennehy did not die. He just went home.

description: Joyce Theater, Chelsea

title: BEST BUY SHARES RISE ON HIGHER EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: Best Buy, the largest electronics retailer in the United States, said yesterday that it was increasing earnings estimates after controlling costs and selling more digital products, which generate greater profit. The company's shares rose 14 percent, the biggest daily gain in more than two years. Earnings from continuing operations in the quarter ending Aug. 30 will rise to 37 to 42 cents a share from 24 cents a year earlier, Best Buy said. Full-year profit will increase to $2.27 to $2.32 from $1.91, it added. Shares of Best Buy climbed $5.81, to $46.49. They have risen 93 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WICZYK, YAAKOV J.
description: WICZYK--Yaakov J. August 3, 2003 at age 57. Mr. Wiczyk emigrated to the United States after serving as both a Tank Commander and an Intelligence Officer for the Israeli Defense Forces during the Six Day War and revolutionized the concept of the American gasoline service business. After attaining an MBA from NYU's Stern School of Business, Mr. Wiczyk purchased a station where he pumped gas and from this, built one of the largest holdings of gasoline service stations, car washes and related facilities on the East Coast. Mr. Wiczyk was a founder of the Gasoline Automotive Service Dealers' Association, a retail dealers' trade association which lobbied at both state and federal levels. He also served as a board member of the National Marketing Advisory Committee of Amoco Oil. He is survived not only by a loving group of friends, business partners, associates, and employees, but by a large family including his mother Tzipora Freidman, his sons Mordecai, Roee, and Omer, daughtersin-law Kate and Melissa, and his beloved wife of 34 years, Hana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, JULIUS
description: BAKER--Julius. The Juilliard community profoundly mourns the death of Julius Baker, a member of the Juilliard faculty from 1954 to 2003, and one of the most prominent flutists and distinguished teachers of the 20th Century. With impeccable technique, expressive sound, flawless phrasing, and great imagination, Julius Baker brought the art of flute playing to new and unexpected levels. As a teacher, he worked with future generations of principal orchestral players, chamber musicians and solo artists who now perform on the world's stages. His quick wit and warm personality will be deeply missed, but his legacy continues through his teaching and through his performances. We send our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Ruth, his children, and his many friends. A service will be held on Sunday, August 10, 2003, at 2 PM in The Old Southeast Church in Brewster, NY. For information, contact Beecher Funeral Home, 845-279-3615. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Flemington: Ruling Against Jayson Williams
description: An attempt by the former basketball star Jayson Williams to get a new grand jury to look at the manslaughter case against him failed in court here yesterday as a judge rejected each of his lawyers' arguments. Mr. Williams, a former member of the New Jersey Nets, is free on bond. He is charged with reckless manslaughter, witness tampering, tampering with evidence and possession of a firearm for illegal purposes. He could be sentenced to 55 years if found guilty on all charges. Jury selection is scheduled to begin next month. A limousine driver, Costas Christofi, was killed by a shotgun that the authorities have said was in Mr. Williams's hands while he was entertaining friends at his Hunterdon County estate on Feb. 14, 2002. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fight Against Fare Increase Continues
description: The Straphangers Campaign, a transit riders' advocacy group, is continuing its fight against the transit fare increase. It asked the state's Court of Appeals yesterday for permission to appeal a court ruling that found that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was within its rights when it raised transit fares and tolls in May. The ruling last month, by a five-member panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, reversed two Supreme Court decisions in May and June that rolled back the increases on the grounds that the authority had intentionally misled the public and violated the law. The Appellate Division said there was no evidence that the authority had broken the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FURTH, MEGAN LOUISE
description: FURTH--Megan Louise. On July 30th, 2003 in Freiburg, Germany at the age of 31. Beloved daughter of Donna Wickham Furth and Frederick Paul Furth, and stepdaughter of Peggy Jane Furth. Loving sister of Darby Furth Bonomi and Ben Stearman Furth. Sister-in-law of Thomas V. Bonomi, Jr. Niece of Mary Jo and John Arthur Odell, Jeanne and James McTighe and Jackie and Jerry Minor. A 1993 graduate magna cum laude of New York University, Phi Beta Kappa, with majors in history, philosophy, and Italian, Megan went on to pursue a career as a writer and poet. Her works have been published in the Black Warrior Review and Carte Italiane. At the time of her death, she had many works in progress. A scholar of languages fluent in Russian and Italian, she also spoke some German and Spanish. In addition, she was a dedicated and beloved teacher. She was a member of the Faculty of Foreign Languages at Moscow State University, where she lectured in American literature and taught English as a second language. Megan was also an avid horsewoman. Nationally-ranked from the age of 12, she was the youngest rider in history to compete in the American Grandprix Association Series of Show Jumping and, at the age of 18, rode for the United States Equestrian Team in international competition. Megan had a brilliant mind and huge heart. She touched everyone who came in contact with her, and will be deeply missed by all. A service to celebrate Megan's life will be held at St. Dominic's Catholic Church, 2390 Bush Street, San Francisco 94115 on Monday, August 11, at 11 A.M. The family has asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Megan Louise Furth Memorial Fund, 710 El Camino del Mar, San Francisco, CA 94121.

title: MCDONALD'S REPORTS 9.9% INCREASE IN U.S. SALES
description: McDonald's said yesterday that sales in the United States rose 9.9 percent in July, driven by demand for new salads and McGriddle breakfast sandwiches. Sales at restaurants open at least 13 months increased for the fourth consecutive month after declining for more than a year, the company said. The introduction of the McGriddle breakfast sandwiches and a line of $3.99 salads, along with increased advertising for the Big Mac, increased sales, it said. McDonald's shares rose 24 cents to $22.06. They have risen 37 percent in the last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Indicted In Hanging Death Of Toddler
description: A man accused of tying an electrical cord around the neck of his 1-year-old son and hanging him from a shower-curtain rod has been indicted on two counts of murder, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The child, Omar Arias, was found dead, hanging in the bathroom of the Crown Motor Inn in Elmhurst last month. The authorities said at the time that the man, Juan Batista, 27, of Corona, had unsuccessfully tried to hang himself in the motel room. Mr. Batista is being held without bail and is undergoing psychiatric observation at Kings County Hospital Center. If he is convicted of the charges, he faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Rick or Victor? A Fateful Choice
description: The critic Roger Ebert has long examined certain movies frame by frame in the company of filmmakers. When he began, the films were 16 millimeter. "Now we use DVD," he said this week by telephone from Chicago. "Just go into a room with the lights off. Freeze a frame. You can back up." In his commentary on a new DVD edition of "Casablanca" (1942), released on Tuesday by Warner, he tells about watching the movie one shot at a time with the cinematographer Haskell Wexler.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: OFFICIAL FAULTS CHINA AND JAPAN A senior South Korean official berated the country's two huge regional competitors, China and Japan, for their reluctance to let their currencies float to higher levels for fear of having to increase the prices of products on world markets. Kwon Tae Shin, deputy finance minister, at a meeting of Asian finance ministers yesterday in Manila, said the Chinese opposed any move to strengthen the value of the yuan. The Bank of Japan, he added, was too quick to intervene to hold down the value of the yen, giving Japanese exports a competitive advantage. Korea, said Mr. Kwon, preferred to let the market decide the rate. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Solitude, And No Need To Pack A Hair Dryer
description: A FEW weeks ago, I sat with a handful of other passengers in the stern of a small mail boat surrounded by packages, mail and other cargo -- all of us bound from Stonington, Me., to Isle au Haut, a pristine 6,900-acre island some seven miles off the coast of Deer Isle. As we pulled out of Stonington's picturesque harbor, one small island after another drifted by, each covered in the dark spruce forests and granite ledges so distinctive of Down East Maine. While the late afternoon sun hovered in the sky, the haze turned the distant islands of Merchant's Row into dark, shimmering mirages.

title: SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT FALLS 20% AT SEMPRA ENERGY
description: Sempra Energy said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 20 percent as earnings from unregulated power sales dropped and the company, under a regulatory agreement, had to give utility customers more savings from a 1998 merger that created Sempra. Net income slid to $124 million, or 55 cents a share, after payment of dividends on preferred stock, from $155 million, or 71 cents, a year earlier, Sempra said. Sales rose 24 percent, to $1.84 billion. Utility profit fell 31 percent from a year earlier, to $78 million. Net income at Sempra Energy Resources, its wholesale-power unit, fell 85 percent, to $5 million. Shares of Sempra rose 31 cents, to $27.90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BATTEN, KATHRYN CLARK
description: BATTEN--Kathryn Clark, 92, died Wednesday, August 6th, in Hilton Head, South Carolina. She was born in Gettysburg, Ohio, the daughter of Zachariah and Daisy Myers Clark. Mrs. Batten was a graduate of Ohio State University where she was President of the university YWCA and a member of Kappa Alpha Theta. After graduation, she was an English teacher in Lansing, Michigan. She was married for 63 years to the late William M. Batten, former CEO of J.C. Penny Company and former Chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. She lived for 50 years in Manhasset and Mill Neck, New York and was extremely active in local organizations, serving as Chairman of the Manhasset High School PTA, a Trustee of the Manhasset Public Library, Chairperson of the Women's Club of the Congregational Church of Manhasset and as an officer of the P.E.O. Sisterhood Chapter AW. She and her husband moved to Hilton Head in 1993 and were one of the founding families of The Cypress. They were also significant contributors to the Batten Family Boys and Girls Club of Hilton Head. Mrs. Batten, a loving and caring mother and grandmother, is survived by her daughter, Jane B. Wild of Hilton Head, by her son, David Batten of New York City, and by her grandchildren, Cynthia Batten of Los Angeles, Hayes Batten of San Francisco and Lydia Batten of New York City. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Friday, August 15th, at the First Presbyterian Church of Hilton Head Island. A reception will follow at the church. Contributions in her memory should be sent to the Batten Family Boys and Girls Club of Hilton Head or the First Presbyterian Church of Hilton Head Island. For information: The Island Funeral Home of Hilton Head

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Leucadia Makes 2 Offers To Wiltel
description: The Leucadia National Corporation said it had made two proposals to acquire the 52.6 percent of the WilTel Communications Group it does not own. The first option allows for an exchange of stock that would leave Wiltel shareholders with a 13.7 percent stake in Leucadia. The second would leave WilTel shareholders with a 14.8 percent stake and would carry some different conditions. Leucadia disclosed the offers yesterday. WilTel shares rose $1.33, or 10.7 percent, to $13.72. Leucadia declined $1.14, or 3 percent, to $36.99. Last week, Leucadia, based in New York, withdrew a $365.1 million offer for the WilTel shares it does not own after the company's board rejected the proposal and decided to seek other bids. Leucadia said WilTel, based in Tulsa, Okla., had until Tuesday at noon to respond to the offers.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: A.C.L.U. Challenges Sale To Mormons

The A.C.L.U. said city officials ignored the Main Street Plaza's role as a public forum. The block was sold to the church in 1999, but a public easement was retained. When the church restricted public behavior in the plaza, the A.C.L.U. sued, citing free speech. An appellate court sided with the A.C.L.U., but the city negotiated a land swap with the church instead of trying to maintain the public easement. Mindy Sink (NYT)
