title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: MARYLAND: NO REGULAR JOE The 1963 prototype for G.I. Joe, which was spurned on the auction block last month when no one posted the minimum $250,000 bid, has a new home. A comic book distributor, Stephen Geppi, paid $200,000 for the handmade 11 1/2-inch figure in a private sale. Mr. Geppi, 53, bought the figure from Don Levine, a Korean War veteran and former Hasbro executive involved in the toy's creation. "I remember playing with G.I. Joe when I was a kid, and who'd have thought some 40 years later I'd would be buying the actual prototype for this action figure," Mr. Getti said. (AP)

title: Holding On Is Challenge for Jets' Smart
description: Even fairy tales have their difficult passages, and Ian Smart is in the middle of another one. Jets Coach Herman Edwards says Smart must learn to hold on to the football better. Smart shrugs and agrees, but these are the pedestrian challenges of football, not the life-altering challenges of his youth.

title: Backstroker Won't Allow Age To Curtail His Olympic Dream
description: Jeff Rouse had a glorious swimming career: a silver medal in the 100-meter backstroke and a gold in the 4x100 medley relay at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics; a gold in each event at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics; and induction into the International Swimming Hall of Fame at age 31.

title: Tenet Healthcare Says It Faces Florida Medicaid Investigation
description: Tenet Healthcare, already the subject of multiple government inquiries, said yesterday that it was under investigation by Florida for Medicaid fraud.

title: Dead in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in Iraq:

title: New Arbitration Claim in Battle Over Czech TV Station
description: Fresh from its $355 million victory last May in an arbitration dispute with the Czech Republic, the central European television conglomerate controlled by the New York cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder, has begun a new arbitration claim for $275 million against the very television station it lost control of in 1999.

title: Never Bitten, Twice Shy: The Real Dangers of Summer
description: August, the peak of summer vacation season, a time for rest, relaxation and, well, risking our lives. Warm weather and free time entice many Americans to do things that increase the chances we will be seriously injured but do we fear the right ones? When asked in the abstract about the term ''risk,'' Americans correctly tend to talk in terms of statistical probability, about the chances that something bad will happen. Yet when they are faced with specific threats, emotion overrules logic pretty quickly -- we fear the unlikely and are relatively unconcerned about the truly dangerous.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: ELAN GETS DEADLINE EXTENSION The Elan Corporation, the drug maker, said that creditors had given the company a one-week extension on a deadline for filing its 2002 annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The extension should forestall a run on Elan's $2 billion debt that could have forced the company into bankruptcy. Elan, which develops treatments for autoimmune disorders and chronic pain and was once the largest company on the Irish Stock Exchange, is the subject of an S.E.C. investigation for its off-balance-sheet accounting. It is in technical default on its debt because it failed to file accounts on time in June; according to the terms of the new waivers, Elan must submit its annual report by this coming Friday. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: To Insurers, a Long, Free Ride Is Looking Risky
description: It has been a wonderful business for insurers: tens of million of dollars in premiums collected over 30 years, and not a single claim paid.

title: Insurers Block Plans to Raze Deutsche Bank
description: Plans to tear down the Deutsche Bank building at the foot of the World Trade Center site are being blocked by two insurance companies arguing that the 40-story skyscraper can be repaired and reoccupied, a position that threatens to complicate the redevelopment of ground zero.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Your Neighborhood Highway
description: If you lived through the mid-1960's in an American city, your memories of the period are probably punctuated by the crash of the wrecking ball. In those days, the federal government's ''urban renewal'' program and the construction of the Interstate System were operating in high gear, flattening older buildings and even entire neighborhoods from coast to coast.

title: Mickey McDermott, 74, Pitcher For the Red Sox and a Memoirist
description: Mickey McDermott, who was known as much for his quick wit, blithe spirit and unfulfilled potential as for being the pitcher who led the Boston Red Sox in strikeouts from 1950 to 1952, died on Thursday. He was 74.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Workers Accept Pact
description: Workers at Hyundai Motor voted overwhelmingly to accept an agreement negotiated by their union that guarantees a five-day workweek along with an 8.6 percent wage increase. The union reported, however, that 19 percent of the 36,685 workers who cast their ballots still opposed the new contract. Unions at other large companies hope to win similar agreements. Workers at Kia Motors, affiliated with Hyundai Motor, staged a four-hour walkout, striking for the same terms as those in the Hyundai agreement. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Can a Barrier Bring Mideast Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Called Target Of Plane Plot
description: The Justice Department has told a federal judge that it has a witness and other proof that Zacarias Moussaoui was plotting to fly a hijacked plane into the White House in 2001 and had bought knives for the attack, according to a secret court transcript made public today.

title: Belated Help for Afghanistan
description: Twenty-one months after American-backed forces drove the Taliban from Kabul, Afghanistan remains a long way from recovery and stability. The Bush administration, distracted by Iraq and dismissive of nation-building, initially failed to provide Afghanistan's president, Hamid Karzai, with the help he desperately needed to rebuild his country's economy and institutions, undermining one of America's first and most important accomplishments in the war on terrorism. Fortunately, the White House is now considering a more generous approach.

title: INSIDE
description: Violence Flares in Mideast

title: AMERCO SAYS EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AND IT WILL REPAY DEBTS
description: Amerco Inc., the parent of the truck rental company U-Haul, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Andrew Stevens, had resigned. The company, based in Reno, Nev., said in an earlier statement yesterday that it planned to repay its creditors in full after completion of bankruptcy proceedings that it began in June. ''Mr. Stevens has decided to pursue other interests,'' the company said. ''The move is mutually agreed upon and is effective immediately.'' Shares in Amerco rose $1.76, or 23.2 percent, to $9.36.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Gain
description: Orders for new machinery, an important measure of corporate capital spending, grew 2.4 percent in June from May. Most economists had expected orders to decline in the month. The increase suggests that companies are investing more in anticipation of growing sales during the rest of the year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mexico, But Also The World
description: The audience started to chant, ''Mexico! Mexico!'' as Caf Tacuba, from Mexico City, tuned up between songs on Tuesday night at the Bowery Ballroom. The band's lead singer, Rubn Albarrn, who's now calling himself Elfego Buenda, grinned and rerouted the chant: ''El mundo!'' The world, not just Mexico, is Caf Tacuba's playground.

title: In California, Anxiety and Drama
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Break, Verizon Talks To Split in Two
description: After more than a week of intense negotiations with the assistance of a top federal mediator, Verizon and its two main unions said yesterday that they would take a break from contract discussions until Tuesday.

title: Smaller Psychiatric Hospital Planned for Greystone Site
description: New Jersey's mental health officials have drafted plans to replace the state's aged and troubled Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital with a smaller and more centralized hospital of about 400 beds by the end of 2006.

title: In Hartford, Tussle Over Bill Adds to Budget Uncertainty
description: Despite Republican threats that passing a contentious bill offering union concessions and forcing the governor to rehire laid-off state employees could shatter a fragile budget deal reached only last week, Democrats in the state legislature did just that today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEELER, RICHARD W.
description: SEELER--Richard W. It is with great sadness that the Real Estate Board of New York mourns the loss of its beloved member and esteemed former chair Richard W. Seeler. His contribution to the real estate industry spans five decades, and he will be sorely missed by his many friends and colleagues in the industry. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family, friends and colleagues. Officers and Members of the Real Estate Board of NY Burton P. Resnick, Chair Steven Spinola, President

title: Mideast Calm Is Disrupted By Exchanges on 2 Fronts
description: After five weeks of relative calm, violence flared today on two fronts of the Middle East conflict.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LINEAR TECHNOLOGY CORP., -- Milpitas, Calif., a maker of chips used in cellular phones and notebook computers, said it expected its conventional markets to return in the next year as demand for high-end consumer products increases.

title: America's Television Flop in Iraq
description: If democracy is ever going to flourish in Iraq, one element will have to be lively, independent news media, professionally operated by Iraqis and featuring a broad range of political viewpoints. While new Iraqi news outlets are proliferating, their quality and credibility are far from ideal. Meanwhile, the television station representing the American occupation authority is an embarrassment.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Shorter Workweek Approved
description: The Mexico unit of Volkswagen and its 9,800 unionized workers have reached an agreement for a shorter workweek that will save 2,000 jobs. The union agreed to accept a four-day workweek and an overall temporary pay cut for the 20 percent of the workers with the least seniority. The other 80 percent of the work force will lose pay just for the day not worked. The plant in Puebla, about 75 miles east of Mexico City, is VW's only North American plant and exports about 80 percent of its production. Earlier this year, Volkswagen said that reduced demand in the United States would force it to cut the jobs. VW management has long been seeking a more flexible workweek from its Mexican union. The plant produces the New Beetle and the Jetta models and will begin making the new generation of the Jetta, called the Bora, in 2005. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Politics and Pop Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy Slides Into Recession
description: Italy has slipped into a recession for the first time in 11 years, the government reported today after studying the effect of the conflict in Iraq, which hurt consumer confidence, and of a sharp rise in the euro, which sapped strength from the Italian economy.

title: Security Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Loss of Ancient Art
description: To the Editor:

title: TYCO SAYS REGULATORS FINISH A REVIEW OF ITS FILINGS
description: Tyco International Ltd., the biggest maker of security systems and electronic connectors, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of corporation finance had completed its review of the company's filings. Tyco, which is based in Bermuda, said it was notified Thursday of the review's completion. Tyco and its former executives remain under investigation by the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, the company said in a statement. In July, Tyco restated quarterly results back to 1998 after the S.E.C. requested that the statements be changed. Shares of Tyco rose 22 cents, to $18.36.

title: Taxes and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Fassel Says Offensive Line Must Improve
description: Jeremy Shockey created a furor yesterday, but it did not distract Giants Coach Jim Fassel from addressing the team's subpar showing in Thursday night's 26-6 loss to the New England Patriots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWERDLIN, JULES
description: SWERDLIN--Jules. Husband of our beloved cousin Marilyn, father of June, and Scott. Loving grandfather. The Gladstone Family Circle

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Visitors do more damage than anybody else The thing is going to deteriorate anyway, but it doesn't help when you've got all these subs going by, disturbing the sediment and whatnot.''

title: Pasco Journal; The Whisper That Carried Beyond Pasco
description: It all started when the mayor leaned over to a councilwoman during a City Council meeting the other week, cupped his hand over his mouth and whispered in her ear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SONTAG, ROLLIN
description: SONTAG--Rollin. The Aragon Board mourns the passing of Rollin Sontag. Our sincere condolences to Joan, her children and grandchildren. Lawrence Ackman, Dieter Rapp, Louise McNamee, Ian Haxell

title: $916.50 Later, Cabby Finds He Was Taken for a Ride
description: It was a gamble. Alaaedien Abdelgwad, who drives a taxi, knew that much. But he also believed in good fortune and took the risk.

title: Can a Barrier Bring Mideast Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Trade Barriers Won't Fall
description: Trade negotiators often use a bicycle analogy to describe their craft: if you are not moving forward, you begin rolling back down the hill. Actually, global trade talks are more akin to the Tour de France: an arduous, multistage race that requires endurance and cooperation among a strong team. Unfortunately, with a World Trade Organization meeting set for Cancn, Mexico, next month, there is little cooperation among the leading trading nations, and the backsliding into protectionism has begun.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Calls Meeting of Anglican Leaders Over Gay Bishop in U.S.; Discord Deepens For Episcopalians
description: A group of conservative Episcopal clerics and laypeople said today that they would call on the leaders of the Anglican Communion to create a second province for the church in the United States.

title: CHURCH IN BOSTON OFFERS $55 MILLION FOR ABUSE CLAIMS
description: The Archdiocese of Boston today offered $55 million to settle lawsuits by 542 victims of sexual abuse by priests, according to a copy of the proposal. Lawyers for the victims said it was the first time the church had made a concrete offer to resolve the scandal.

title: ORACLE EXTENDS OFFER FOR PEOPLESOFT
description: The Oracle Corporation yesterday extended its hostile bid to buy PeopleSoft Inc. until Sept. 19; only about 12 percent of PeopleSoft shares have been tendered. The offer to pay $19.50 a share for PeopleSoft was set to expire next Friday. As of yesterday, 37.7 million shares had been tendered. That was down from 43.8 million shares that had been tendered as of July 11. Oracle said that it remained ''fully committed to acquiring PeopleSoft.'' Shares of Oracle, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., fell 10 cents, to $11.29. Shares of PeopleSoft, based in Pleasanton, Calif., rose 12 cents, to $16.54.

title: Iraqi Trailers Said To Make Hydrogen, Not Biological Arms
description: Engineering experts from the Defense Intelligence Agency have come to believe that the most likely use for two mysterious trailers found in Iraq was to produce hydrogen for weather balloons rather than to make biological weapons, government officials say.

title: OHIO ATTORNEY GENERAL SUES FREDDIE MAC OVER LOSSES
description: Freddie Mac, the federal mortgage finance company, was sued by the Ohio attorney general yesterday to recover $25 million that two state pension funds lost on shares in the company, a spokesman, Mark Gribben, said. The suit was filed in federal court in Cincinnati by Attorney General Jim Petro to recover losses the state teachers' and public employees' funds suffered on Freddie Mac stock after the company admitted accounting errors. The company said in January that it would restate its earnings for the previous three years.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Prosecutor Lobbies To Keep Rwanda Post
description: Carla Del Ponte, the prosecutor for the United Nations war crimes tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, made what is likely to be a futile effort to keep the Rwandan mandate, telling the Security Council that it would be costly, inefficient and politically unwise to relieve her of those responsibilities. Simultaneously, Rwandan officials told reporters that it would be costly, inefficient and politically unwise to keep her. Secretary General Kofi Annan has recommended that each of the tribunals have its own prosecutor. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Unemployment Rate Rises
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 7.8 percent in July from 7.7 percent in June, Statistics Canada reported, confirming recent evidence of a weakening economy. About 13,000 jobs were lost in July, mostly because of a sharp fall in part-time employment among young people. Youth unemployment moved up 0.2 percentage point in July to 14.1 percent. The jobless rate in July was higher than most economists had expected, reinforcing expectations that the Bank of Canada will again cut interest rates at its next review of monetary policy on Sept. 3. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Indonesia Identifies Hotel Bomber
description: The suicide bomber who the police say was responsible for the attack on the J. W. Marriott Hotel here was identified today as a 28-year-old recruit of the militant Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: First Amendment Doesn't Protect Reporters' Notes
description: A prominent federal judge ruled that journalists have no right under the First Amendment to keep their interview notes and tapes confidential. The judge, Richard A. Posner, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, explained why the court last month ordered two Chicago newspapers to turn over tapes of an interview to a defendant accused and since convicted of terrorism in Ireland. At least in cases where confidential sources are not at issue, Judge Posner wrote, ''it is difficult to see what possible bearing the First Amendment could have.'' The decision is at odds with those in several other federal appeals courts. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Vanguard Fires Newell
description: The Vanguard Group, one of the nation's largest mutual fund companies, said yesterday that it fired Newell Associates as co-manager of its $2.6 billion Vanguard Equity Income Fund.

title: Univision Shares Climb After Profit Report
description: Shares of Univision Communications Inc., owner of the nation's biggest Spanish-language television network, rose more than 13 percent yesterday after the company said second-quarter profit almost doubled. The stock jumped $3.89, to $32.96.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Court-Martial In Air Force Rape Charge
description: A recent graduate of the Air Force Academy who faced a possible court-martial on rape and sodomy charges will instead be offered a lesser punishment for dereliction of duty and providing alcohol to a minor. The officer, Second Lt. Ronen Segal, could lose up to a month's pay, receive a written reprimand and face 30 days of house arrest. Lieutenant Segal, who is stationed at Cheyenne Mountain, was accused of buying alcohol for a younger cadet and molesting her shortly after his graduation last year. An investigating officer had recommended against a court-martial. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: For Church Leaders, 2 Tacks on Gay Issue
description: A group of conservative Episcopalians said they would ask the worldwide Anglican Communion to create a second province for the church in the United States following approval of an openly gay bishop. And the spiritual leader of the world's Anglicans said he would call a meeting to avert a schism over the issue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Israel's construction of a barrier between Israelis and Palestinians referred incorrectly to the affected area. While the barrier indeed veers into the West Bank, it will not affect Gaza or its Jewish settlements. (A barrier around Gaza has been in place since the 1960's, with Gaza's settlements surrounded by their own walls.)

title: Fake Rockefeller Pleads Guilty in Hamptons Swindles
description: A Frenchman who appropriated the Rockefeller name and swindled the rich from East Hampton to Hong Kong out of more than $1.5 million pleaded guilty yesterday to four counts of grand larceny in Suffolk County Court in Riverhead.

title: Utopia's $500 Million Repair Bill; Co-op City, Once a Working-Class Dream, Is Crumbling
description: Co-op City, the cooperative apartment complex built for working people in the Bronx, no longer cooperates nor works quite the way it used to.

title: NIKE EXPECTS DISPUTE TO CONTINUE TO HURT SALES
description: Nike Inc. expects its shoe sales in the United States to remain below earlier levels for the rest of the year because of its dispute with Foot Locker Inc., according to its annual report filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said that it did not expect to fully offset the revenue decline from Foot Locker Inc. in the short term and that the amount of future sales to the chain was uncertain. Foot Locker, Nike's largest customer in the United States, said early last year that it was cutting its Nike orders to protest Nike restrictions on shoe prices and selection. Nike responded by cutting its shipments to Foot Locker. Nike shares rose $2.21, to $52.81.

title: Coinages That Last
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CENTRAL BANK STANDS PAT Comforted by signs of a growing recovery, the Bank of Japan's policy board left its monetary stance unchanged. The central bank has kept policy unchanged for two consecutive meetings after easing its policy at the first five meetings under its new governor, Toshihiko Fukui. The bank said it would continue to keep a surplus of as much as 30 trillion yen ($250 billion) in its accounts.

title: Drake's Secret Trip Up the West Coast
description: On the evening of Sept. 26, 1580, the vessel Golden Hind sailed into England's Plymouth Harbor commanded by the privateer Francis Drake. The ship's ballast had been thrown overboard and replaced by 26 tons of silver and hundreds of pounds of gold that Drake had plundered from Spanish galleons on the Pacific Coast of South America.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Stands Pat
description: Comforted by signs of a growing recovery, the Bank of Japan's policy board left its monetary stance unchanged. The central bank has kept policy unchanged for two consecutive meetings after easing its policy at the first five meetings under its new governor, Toshihiko Fukui. The bank said it would continue to keep a surplus of as much as 30 trillion yen ($250 billion) in its accounts. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Gets Deadline Extension
description: The Elan Corporation, the drug maker, said that creditors had given the company a one-week extension on a deadline for filing its 2002 annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The extension should forestall a run on Elan's $2 billion debt that could have forced the company into bankruptcy. Elan, which develops treatments for autoimmune disorders and chronic pain and was once the largest company on the Irish Stock Exchange, is the subject of an S.E.C. investigation for its off-balance-sheet accounting. It is in technical default on its debt because it failed to file accounts on time in June; according to the terms of the new waivers, Elan must submit its annual report by this coming Friday. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the formation of a political action committee, America Coming Together, aimed at defeating President Bush for re-election misstated the affiliation of a founder, Gina Glantz. It is the Service Employees International Union, not America Votes.

title: Diller Finishes Buying Expedia
description: InterActiveCorp, the Internet commerce company run by Barry Diller, said yesterday that it completed its acquisition of Expedia Inc., the No. 1 Internet travel agency, and the Web-based loan service LendingTree Inc.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the euro on optimism that the economic recovery in the United States will outpace growth in Europe. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1305, down from $1.1374 on Thursday.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: FUND FOR BOMB LAWSUITS The British government will provide $1.3 million to help the families of people killed in the 1998 bombing by the guerrilla group Real I.R.A. in Omagh, Northern Ireland, bring a civil case against five men they contend were behind the attack. One of the men is Michael McKevitt, the leader of the group, who was sentenced in Dublin this week to 20 years for directing terrorism. The Omagh attack killed 29 people and wounded more than 200. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Democrats Add To Chaos in Bid To Foil Recall
description: In an atmosphere that hovered between carnival and chaos, Democratic leaders here today quarreled over how best to beat back the drive to recall Gov. Gray Davis.

title: F.T.C. APPROVES LIBERTY MEDIA'S PURCHASE OF QVC STAKE
description: The Liberty Media Corporation's $7.9 billion purchase of Comcast's controlling stake in the home-shopping network QVC was cleared by antitrust authorities, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. The government's review of the transaction was closed after 30 days, according to a list of completed merger investigations published in Washington by the F.T.C. Liberty, which is controlled by John C. Malone, agreed last month to purchase Comcast's 57 percent stake in QVC. The acquisition is still subject to approval by European regulators and the Federal Communications Commission.

title: A Scarlatti Premiere, But for the Father
description: A generation ago when you mentioned Scarlatti, everyone assumed you were talking about Domenico Scarlatti, the 18th-century composer of some 550 single-movement keyboard sonatas, wondrously inventive works that were championed by Vladimir Horowitz and that turned up on recitals by conservatory pianists everywhere. And Alessandro Scarlatti? Oh yeah, he was that forgotten Baroque composer who was Domenico's father.

title: Charles P. Tolchin, 34, Author And Lecturer on Cystic Fibrosis
description: Charles P. Tolchin, who survived with cystic fibrosis decades longer than expected and who wrote and taught about the disease, died today at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 34.

title: Boy, 3, Is Shot by His Cousin, 9, in Brooklyn
description: A 3-year-old Brooklyn boy was fighting for his life last night after being shot in the head by his 9-year-old cousin, who was playing with a gun he found under a bed yesterday morning, police officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an apology issued by Prime Minister Tony Blair's spokesman for a remark about a dead British weapons scientist misstated the surname of the singer at whose villa Mr. Blair is vacationing. He is Sir Cliff Richard, not Richards.

title: White House Sway Is Seen In E.P.A. Response to 9/11
description: An investigation by the Environmental Protection Agency's inspector general into official statements about air quality after the collapse of the World Trade Center has found that White House officials instructed the agency to be less alarming and more reassuring to the public in the first few days after the attack.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Warning Shots At Northern Vessels
description: For the third time in three months, South Korean navy boats fired warning shots at North Korean boats that crossed the disputed sea border to fish in rich crab grounds. The boats, which ignored commands over loudspeakers, returned to North Korean waters after South Korean sailors fired a machine gun burst. South Korea says North Korean fishing boats have crossed into its waters almost daily since late May. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Engineered Drugs Open New Issue Of Regulation As Patents Expire
description: Somatropin, a hormone that sends a message to the pituitary gland to stimulate growth in the human body, is not a new discovery. And its synthesis is not a new technological advance -- somatropin products have been on the market for more than a decade, each protected by patents covering varying things, like the way the hormone is made and how it is administered.

title: What a Tangled Web We Weave
description: This week's historic election of the Rev. V. Gene Robinson as the first openly gay Episcopal bishop almost didn't happen. The day before his scheduled vote, critics launched a last-minute campaign to discredit him, in part by pointing out that he helped start an organization for young gay people whose Web site linked to pornography. An investigation found that Bishop-elect Robinson had nothing to do with the group's site, and his nomination was approved the next day.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tennessee Court Intervenes In Deal for Clayton Homes

title: Lawmakers Criticize Bush's Air Safety Efforts
description: Two lawmakers suggested today that the Bush administration was not moving quickly enough to improve passenger safety despite new warnings of possible terror attacks.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Jessica Grace Wing, a composer and filmmaker, omitted two survivors, and a correction in this space on Thursday misspelled the surname of one of them. The survivors are Ms. Wing's companion, Damian Volpe, and her father's companion, Prof. Jacqueline Sharkey, not Sharke.

title: Thousands Rally in France, Trade Battle in Mind
description: Call it a summer camp for antiglobalization crusaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POST, JEANNETTE S.
description: POST--Jeannette S. The family of Jeannette S. Post acknowledges with deep sadness the loss of its beloved wife, sister, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Born in Brooklyn in 1913, she grew up with her parents, sister and two brothers behind the family's grocery store. She graduated from Long Island University in 1933 and from Brooklyn Law School in 1936, becoming one of the few women attorneys of her generation. Jeannette successfully combined a general law practice with her roles as wife to the late Bernard S. Post, a prominent physician and professor of rehabilitation medicine, and mother of three children. She was active in Brooklyn politics before moving to Kings Point, NY, where she participated in local government, serving as president of the Kings Point Civic Association. Jeannette was an authentic original and leaves the legacy of her keen intelligence, unflinching honesty, unfailing elegance, boundless generosity and unconditional love for all those whose lives she touched. She is survived by her twin brother, Israel Dolgin; her children, Gerard and Linda Post, Kalmon and Linda Farber Post, and Shari and Mitchell Buchbinder; her grandchildren, Illana and Lawrence Raia, Stacie and Mark Thompson, Andrew and Jodi Buchbinder, Brett Post, Kim and Rodney Khazzam, Brooke and Jeno Tamas, Alexander and Lauren Post, and Hallie Buchbinder; and her great-grandchildren, Sophia and Lawrence Raia, Samantha Buchbinder, Alexa Khazzam, and Samuel Tamas. She will be deeply missed and her memory will be a lasting treasure. The funeral will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza in Great Neck, NY on August 10th at 11 AM.

title: Study Finds Many Ignore Warnings on Sex Practices
description: Most New Yorkers with multiple sexual partners do not know whether they are infected with H.I.V., and more than 40 percent did not use condoms the last time they had sex, according to what city officials say is the most comprehensive survey ever conducted of the city's sexual habits.

title: Baylor Coach Bliss Resigns; Violations Discovered
description: A day after attending the funeral of the basketball player Patrick Dennehy, Baylor Coach Dave Bliss resigned yesterday because of National Collegiate Athletic Association violations discovered by the university.

title: F.B.I. Team To Investigate Bomb Attack On Embassy
description: A team of F.B.I. agents is being sent here to lead the investigation of the bomb attack on the Jordanian Embassy, American officials said today. The move appeared to underscore concerns among officials that the attack might have been the work of organized terrorists aiming to kill civilians rather than of the insurgents who have been striking at soldiers.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Reserve Requirements Eased
description: The central bank cut the minimum-reserve requirements for banks to 45 percent from 60 percent, further easing a tough monetary stance that has tamed inflation but has also stifled the economy. The cut in reserve requirements should free 8 billion reais, or about $2.6 billion, theoretically allowing banks to lower interest rates for consumers and small businesses and help jump-start the moribund economy. The move follows two rate reductions in recent months. Brazil's overnight interest rate, although off its 26.5 percent high of earlier this year, remains stuck at 24.5 percent and the economy is suffering. Industrial production slumped in May, and is at its lowest level since December 2001. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Subway Interruptions Return for Weekend
description: Commuters can expect more rerouting on the subway system this weekend, with 17 lines affected by service changes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Rock Star Faces Murder Charge
description: A French rock star has been put under formal investigation by a court in Lithuania on suspicion of having fatally beaten his lover, the French actress Marie Trintignant, there in July. Bertrand Cantat, 39, the lead singer of the French group Noir Dsir, faces a murder charge. Ms. Trintignant, 41, died last week in a Paris hospital of injuries suffered during a violent argument with Mr. Cantat in a hotel room in Vilnius, Lithuania, where Ms. Trintignant was shooting a film. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Mets Win in Glavine's Return

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, JULIUS
description: BAKER--Julius. The Juilliard community profoundly mourns the death of Julius Baker, a member of the Juilliard faculty from 1954 to 2003, and one of the most prominent flutists and distinguished teachers of the 20th Century. With impeccable technique, expressive sound, flawless phrasing, and great imagination, Julius Baker brought the art of flute playing to new and unexpected levels. As a teacher, he worked with future generations of principal orchestral players, chamber musicians and solo artists who now perform on the world's stages. His quick wit and warm personality will be deeply missed, but his legacy continues through his teaching and through his performances. We send our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Ruth, his children, and his many friends. A service will be held on Sunday, August 10, 2003, at 2 PM in The Old Southeast Church in Brewster, NY. For information, contact Beecher Funeral Home, 845-279-3615. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLHISER, ELEANOR, MCGUE
description: MILLHISER -- Eleanor, McGue, 83, wife, mother and volunteer died August 7, 2003 at Memorial Regional Medical Center, Richmond, VA. Mrs. Millhiser born in Cleveland, Ohio was the daughter of Alfred J. McGue of Cleveland, Ohio and Rosina Steinbrecher McGue of Richmond and the sister of Jean Virginia McGue and the late Mary Ann Brockenbrough and Patricia Walsh. At age 9, Mrs. Millhiser moved to Richmond, she attended Cathedral High School in Richmond and was graduated in 1941 from Trinity College in Washington D.C. and enjoyed being one of Trinity's major supporters. In 1942, she married Ross R. Millhiser and played the key supporting role for him throughout his career at Philip Morris. Mrs. Millhiser was a communicant of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, Sacred Heart Cathedral and St. Bridget's Church all in Richmond, VA and Holy Cross Church in Rumson, NJ. She was a corresponding secretary of the Holy Cross School PTA. Mrs. Millhiser's other volunteer roles included being the corresponding secretary, vice president and executive board member of the Auxiliary for St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York City. She also served as the president of the Richmond, VA and New Jersey Shore Alumni Chapters for Trinity College. Mrs. Millhiser was a coordinator for Drivers for FISH (For I Shall Help) in Monmouth County, NJ, a volunteer for Lunch Break in Red Bank, NJ and a member of the English Speaking Union and the New Jersey Historical Society. Mostly Mrs. Millhiser was a loving wife, mother, sister and friend, who dedicated herself to helping her husband, raising her four children at her beloved seaside former home ''Dawnmere'' in Rumson, NJ. Mrs. Millhiser delighted particularly in its gardens and its water views. Mrs. Millhiser was also known for her innate sense of style and flair-always looking terrific! Mrs. Millhiser will be missed by her husband, Ross; sister, Jean and four children, Ross R. Millhiser Jr. and Timothy McG. Millhiser both of New York City and Thomas McN. Millhiser and Mary McGue Millhiser both of Richmond, VA, as well as, her eight grandchildren, Ross R. Millhiser IV, Liam R. Millhiser, Nicholas A. Millhiser and Lillian W. Millhiser all of New York City, Ian R. Millhiser of Durham, NC and Neal McG. Millhiser, James McN. Millhiser and Hugh Stuart Millhiser Halsey all of Richmond. A funeral mass will be held Monday, August 11, 10:30a.m. at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, 909 Rennie Ave., corner of Chamberlayne and Rennie. Interment will be private. A reception for all will be held at the residence at 1PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the MCV Foundation, P.O. Box 980234, Richmond, VA 23298, Parker Clinic Riverview Medical Center, 1 Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, NJ 07701, St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, Development Office, Suite 6-B, 130 West 12th St, NY, NY 10011. Information Bliley Funeral Homes' Augusta Chapel.

Jeb Bush's daughter, Noelle, completed a drug rehabilitation program, and a judge dismissed drug charges against her and allowed her to go home. Ms. Bush, 26, had been ordered into treatment after she was arrested in January 2002 on charges of trying to use a fraudulent prescription to buy the anti-anxiety drug Xanax. "It's been quite a challenge," Ms. Bush told Judge Reginald Whitehead of Circuit Court. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Sales Sour

Under pressure to cut prices and develop a new, healthier menu, the company cut its full-year profit target by 47 percent, to 2.1 billion yen ($17.5 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

The industry estimates that only 12 to 18 percent of the shrimp consumed in the United States are caught in domestic waters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHASE, MARTHA
description: CHASE -- Martha. The trustees, faculty, and staff of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory note with sadness the passing of Martha Chase Epstein. In 1952, together with Dr. Al Hershey, Dr. Chase performed an experiment that became famous not only because it helped confirm that DNA, not protein, is the genetic material, but also because it involved an unexpectedly familiar tool, namely, a kitchen blender. The Hershey-Chase experiment remains a classic example of elegance and simplicity in experimental design, and it helped lay the foundation for the field of molecular biology. Dr. Chase's contributions continue to inspire generations of researchers at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. Bruce Stillman, Director & Chief Executive Officer

title: Democracy's Landscape
description: The 843 acres of Central Park represent not only a masterpiece of landscaping art and artifice, but a secret garden of 19th-century symbols waiting to be decoded, Sara Cedar Miller, the official historian and photographer for the Central Park Conservancy, writes in CENTRAL PARK: An American Masterpiece (Abrams, $45). Designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux in the years around the Civil War, Central Park combined democratic ideals with the latest in Victorian technology. Picturesque rambles disguise the circulation patterns, which seamlessly integrate footpaths, bridle trails and carriage drives. The sunken transverses that handle crosstown traffic anticipated highway overpasses by decades. Even the most naturalistic elements of the park are engineering triumphs: the Pond at the south end is lined like a sink and fed with the same water that fills the city's bathtubs, and sloping meadows like Cedar Hill were formed by blasting away rock and covering it with lawn. Americans in the 19th century looked to our natural resources as a symbol of national pride, and during the Civil War, the park came to stand for what was best about the United States. The balustrades of Bethesda Terrace contain encoded symbols of the Union for the sharp-eyed: a buckle of Union stars, and sheaves of wheat, which represented the North as much as cotton did the Confederacy. Though the photographs are occasionally pedestrian, relying too heavily on scenic beauty for interest, Miller's history is as clear and sprightly as Huddlestone Cascade (uptown, near Lasker Rink), at 15 feet the highest waterfall in the park. Eric P. Nash

title: Called Your Telemarketer Recently?
description: TOM MABE -- Though Tom Mabe's first two ''Revenge of the Telemarketers'' CD's were prank-call classics, the third CD in the series, ''A Wake-Up Call for Telemarketers'' (Megaforce), pushes the joke too far. On his earlier albums, in which he pulled pranks on the annoying telemarketers who called his home, the victims of his jokes never realized that they were being duped. On practically every phone call on the new CD, instead of fooling the telemarketers, he ends up annoying them -- and, in the process, the listener. There is more anger than humor directed at the pests here, but there are still some laugh-out-loud moments. What saves the CD is a segment in which Mr. Mabe calls telemarketers (who are in a Washington hotel for a convention) in the middle of the night, waking them to try to sell them things. Here the listener learns the people who are the rudest to nuisance phone calls just may be telemarketers themselves.

The door they had me make for the refrigerator cost more than the refrigerator itself, and the stained glass in the upper cabinets cost more than it would to renovate an entire kitchen that size.

description: The sum-is-greater-than-their-parts San Francisco Giants had as comfortable a cushion as any major league team except the Atlanta Braves coming into this weekend, a stunning 12-game lead in the National League West. The Giants obviously have Barry Bonds, one of the premier players in the game, doing incredible things. But after reflexively citing Bonds, it is much more complicated to explain how and why the Giants have become so formidable.

title: Southern Westchester Is Seeing More Deer
description: DEER have been spotted with growing frequency in southern Westchester County in the past few months, in densely populated communities like Bronxville, Mount Vernon and Yonkers, raising concerns that they will bring with them an increase in Lyme disease as well as damage to gardens and collisions with cars.

title: A Bad Trip Down Memory Lane
description: The failure of Susan Clancy and her Harvard colleagues to understand the politics of her research agenda is evidence of extraordinary navet, arrogance or both (Bruce Grierson, July 27). And surely the rank deception involved in her feigned neutrality or reported displays of apparent support for the accounts of those ''alien abductees,'' whom she sought out and seemingly befriended, raises serious ethical and methodological concerns. As she relocates her research agenda to Nicaragua, let us hope that this time she will make the effort necessary to understand the impact of her academic ambitions upon the lives of those she recruits for her experiments.

The couple is asking $10.75 million for the six-bedroom, six-bath, 14,000-square-foot home on 15 acres and with views of the ocean. Corporate governance was also a topic of discussion. Three company chairmen -- Warren E. Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway, Howard Stringer of Sony and Barry Diller of InterActiveCorp -- even participated in a panel on the subject for the lustrous crowd.

Dent's book ''Mozart's Operas,'' first published in 1913, the work merits a bare sentence and a half: ''The following April saw the performance of another serenata at Salzburg. 'Il Re Pastore,' a string of arias written with an unfailing sense of grace and beauty, but without the least suspicion of dramatic power.''

description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10  Tensions rose over Israel's northern border today as Hezbollah guerrillas fired anti-aircraft shells from southern Lebanon, killing an Israeli teenager, and Israeli warplanes struck back.

title: Dancing in the (Wet) Streets
description: ON a street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, at an indoor location its keepers will not divulge, sits a convex aluminum disc with seven holes drilled into it. Most of the time, it doesn't go anywhere. But each year, as July slips into August and the asphalt glimmers in the heat, this perforated cap and thousands of others like it start appearing across the city as people attach them to fire hydrants, turn on the water and frolic in the spray.

title: Air France Co-Pilot Is Accused Of Making Remark About Bomb
description: The co-pilot of Air France's late flight to Paris was arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Friday after making a remark about having a bomb in his shoe at a security checkpoint, officials said. No bomb was found, but he was charged with two felonies, the flight was canceled and 353 passengers were grounded overnight.

description: SHORE POINT CAFE opened less than three months ago, one of several new restaurants to appear recently in the shoreline town of Branford. It is arguably unfair to review a place that so recently opened, but I like to see what is going on early on as the restaurant invents itself. It goes without saying, though, that you've got to be prepared for inconsistencies and imperfections in so young a restaurant.

description: THERE's a magical moment in P. L. Travers's ''Mary Poppins'' after Bert, the Match-Man, draws landscapes on the sidewalk. On a whim, he invites Mary Poppins to enter one of the pictures. This week, on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, audiences seeing ''Geyser Land,'' a site-specific performance and installation, can look forward to just such a moment when they board the train for a trip through Paradise Valley.

Mr. Ashcroft has ordered federal prosecutors to start collecting information on federal judges who give sentences that are lighter than those suggested by federal guidelines. Critics are right when they say this has the potential to create a ''blacklist'' of judges who could then be subjected to intimidation.

Nut cake is nusstorte, not nsstorte. The Austrian currency until the euro was introduced was the schilling, not the mark.

Chanel's new fall line includes blue-tinted mascara, eyeliner, lip color and nail polish as well as Jeans de Chanel eyeshadow (right, $55 at Saks Fifth Avenue), which is laser-etched to mimic the look of real jeans.

description: JOSH GOSFIELD, a commercial artist living and working in Manhattan's West Village, was going about his business two and a half years ago when he was transported by a vision. It was a saintly vision, the likes of which he had never experienced. Stranger still, it was a saintly vision of an old friend, and it came to him when she stopped by his studio for a visit.

title: Streetscapes/Henry Hudson Bridge; A Controversial '36 Span Through Dreamy Isolation
description: THE HENRY HUDSON BRIDGE over the Harlem River, opened in 1936, was denounced by Bronx residents and civic groups when planned by Robert Moses a year earlier. While providing one of the most dramatic river crossings in the city, the new span and highway bisected the western Bronx's dreamy isolation. Now, as work crews repaint the bridge, traffic sometimes slows to a point where one may actually pause to contemplate the view from -- and of -- this unusual work of engineering.

Most Americans say they know someone who is gay, and a vast majority support equal rights for gays in the workplace. title: Denver Perennials That Travel
description: THOUGH the mile-high Denver Botanic Gardens at the foot of the Rocky Mountains are considered among the finest in the country, it can be dispiriting for a mid-Atlantic gardener used to low-level, steam-bath conditions. Last month, as I prepared to venture through 23 acres of borders filled with towering prairie perennials, tiny alpines, swaying grasses and a variety of conifers that were actually enjoying the near-100 degree dry heat, I assumed there was nothing of interest for my garden in central New Jersey.

title: Kitsch and Charm On the Peninsula
description: THE Hope and Glory Inn was dark -- pitch-black -- when we arrived late Friday night. With not a light in sight, the inn, a converted old schoolhouse, was barely visible from the road that ambles through Irvington, off the Chesapeake Bay in Virginia. As a friend and I fumbled through a white picket gate, considering the prospect of sleeping in the car after a long crawl of a drive from Washington, to our relief we spotted candles through the window. A squall had knocked out the electricity.

title: HOLDING THE LINE ON TUITION
description: Tuition costs at the 19 county community colleges in the state will rise an average 3.8 percent this fall. Those in Morris, Passaic, Sussex and Union will have no increases, and most of the others were able to hold increases down thanks to a restoration of $8 million in state aid that had been scheduled to be cut. In recent years, the average year-to-year increase has been only 2 percent. ''We owe it all to the governor and state Legislature,'' said Jacob Farbman, a spokesman for the Council of County Colleges. ''Without that funding restoration, there is no way we would have been able to hold the line for the seventh year in the row.'' Tuition at public four-year colleges is rising an average of about 9 percent. Debra Nussbaum

Field-goal kickers ice their feet while specialists handle kickoffs. And in baseball, some left-handed relievers get paid millions of dollars to face a whopping one batter a night. Pretty good gig if you can get it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHASE, MARTHA
description: CHASE -- Martha. The trustees, faculty, and staff of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory note with sadness the passing of Martha Chase Epstein. In 1952, together with Dr. Al Hershey, Dr. Chase performed an experiment that became famous not only because it helped confirm that DNA, not protein, is the genetic material, but also because it involved an unexpectedly familiar tool, namely, a kitchen blender. The Hershey-Chase experiment remains a classic example of elegance and simplicity in experimental design, and it helped lay the foundation for the field of molecular biology. Dr. Chase's contributions continue to inspire generations of researchers at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. Bruce Stillman, Director & Chief Executive Officer

title: Sexed Texts
description: Men -- as we know now, thanks to investigators like Dr. John Gray -- are from Mars, women from Venus. On our respective planets we, or our ancestors, learned to do certain things differently: shop, argue, deploy the TV clicker. To this ever-expanding list we must now add writing. Not writing in the literal sense of making marks on a page -- though clearly there are vast differences there as well (legibility must be more prized on Venus) -- but writing as linguistic expression. This is slightly different from conversation, in which, as Deborah Tannen, another of the scholars in the Venus-Mars debate, has taught us, the differences between men and women are so vast as to be almost unbridgeable without years of therapy.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Simmering Europe Finds Creative Relief
description: WHEN the mercury rose yet again last week, Europeans who had already endured several atypically hot months inaugurated a new rule: if it was wet and possibly cool, it was fair game. From Rome to London, residents and tourists waded -- and sometimes plunged -- into pools never meant for that purpose, turning grand monuments into therapeutic havens. Dehydrated and desperate, people drank from the nearest spigot or trickle, wherever they found it. Bowed and almost beaten, they enveloped themselves in any available mist.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: GWYNETH PALTROW is a buttoned-up British scholar researching the Victorian poet Christabel LaMotte in Neil LaBute's gorgeous romance POSSESSION (2002). Aaron Eckhart is a regular-guy American scholar doing research on Randolph Ash, another poet of the era. Mr. Eckhart's character discovers letters between the two poets that suggest a romantic relationship, which is surprising because LaMotte was a lesbian. The scholars set out on a tour of England to learn more, and naturally they're forced to share a hotel room. The conclusion of the film, based on A. S. Byatt's novel, is that the Victorians were a passionate people. We're the repressed ones, paralyzed by fear of commitment -- Wednesday at 9 p.m., Wednesday/Early Thursday at 4 a.m., Saturday at 5:35 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 5:15 a.m. on Starz.

Such buildings are valuable commodities in historic districts because they are developable sites; they can be demolished and replaced with new buildings approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: King's Life in Pictures of Every Kind
description: HO CHE ANDERSON'S brush with greatness was delivered by the most unlikely of messengers. In 1990, Mr. Anderson, then a 19-year-old rookie comic-book artist and high school dropout, got a job offer from Fantagraphics, a Seattle company that is perhaps the medium's most sophisticated publisher.

title: Ah, Springsteen's 'Born to Trot'
description: Rocky had the ''Eye of the Tiger,'' and Kevin Bacon was ''Footloose.'' But the trotters at Monmouth Park's Haskell Invitational will forever be ''Born to Run.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 34 of The Times Magazine today about Stanley Williams, a convicted murderer who has written books and spoken from his jail cell about the perils of gang membership, refers erroneously to an anti-violence advertising campaign that uses him as spokesman. It has not been endorsed by the Advertising Council (cited informally in the article as the National Ad Council).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUDGIN, CHESTER
description: LUDGIN--Chester. On August 9, 2003. An extraordinary American artist and musician. Leading Baritone of both the San Francisco Opera and the New York City Opera. Nominated for a Grammy for Leonard Bernstein's ''A Quiet Place:'' Creator of the role of John Proctor in Robert Ward's ''The Crucible'' and stars on the original recording. Services today August 10, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Those Three Sailors, Lost on Shore Again
description: ''ON THE TOWN,'' a romantic view of three sailors on 24-hour leave in New York during World War II, has become an urban fairy tale in praise of a time and ''a helluva town'' that many people wish they had back and others might not believe ever existed.

title: What Investors Should Do Now
description: DOROTHY O. MULVI has developed something of a following at Golden West Manor, a high-rise retirement home overlooking the Rocky Mountains in Boulder, Colo. When other residents are thinking about how to stretch their savings to pay for retirement, they often come to Ms. Mulvi, an 82-year-old former bond trader, for investment tips. These days, however, she tends to have only one piece of advice, and it is not very comforting.

title: Creating A Park At a Lake
description: AS the sun heated the rippling water of Silver Lake here one afternoon not long ago, young children shrieked gleefully every time a fish bit a hook. Teenagers lolled on the newly cut lawn, lazily reading Mark Twain and F. Scott Fitzgerald, and a large Hispanic family picnicked on chicken salads in the shade.

title: Different Kind of Sizzle for a Restaurateur
description: ''I'M a five burger per day guy,'' John J. Tunney III was saying. ''That doesn't count my breakfast, lunch, dinner and pizza.''

title: Sweet, Sentimental and Punk
description: ON the same night that the WB network broadcast the final episode of ''Dawson's Creek,'' a few hundred young fans (everyone calls them ''the kids'') squeezed into S.O.B.'s, the downtown Manhattan nightclub, to hear a punk rock veteran named Christopher Ender Carrabba strum an acoustic guitar and sing lugubrious songs about breaking up. Mr. Carrabba records and performs as Dashboard Confessional, and at his cult-like concerts, the kids sing along with every word, not just mouthing the lyrics but matching Mr. Carrabba's full-throated delivery, and often drowning him out.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SKLOVER, CHARLES M.
description: SKLOVER--Charles M. Eight years since you're gone. You are missed terribly every day. Love, Branka

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERENBACH, RICHARD SCHOOLEY
description: FERENBACH -- Richard Schooley. 75, of Morristown, NJ, on August 8, 2003. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Heffernan). Adored father of Richard Jr., Gray, TN, Claire Whelan, Greenwich, CT, and the late Laura Ferenbach. Cherished grandfather of Thomas, Courtney, Evelyn, Edward and Amanda Whelan, Alastair and Oliver Ferenbach, brother of Colin C. Ferenbach. Graduate of the Hill School and Brown University. President of LeonFerenbach Inc., Johnson City, TN. Member of Morris County Golf Club, The Anglers Club of New York and the Hillsboro Club of Florida. Past President of the Point O'Woods Association. Service Wednesday, August 13, at 11 AM, St. Peters Episcopal Church, Morristown, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Laura Ferenbach Scholarship Fund, Peck School, Morristown, NJ 07960, or to Atlantic Hospice Program, Millburn, NJ 07041.

title: At Camp, but Not Carefree
description: WHEN my husband and I left our son at summer camp this year, I wasn't at all worried. This was his fifth year at the camp; and he was to be a ''senior,'' one of the older campers. And how my son loves his camp! The boys sleep in platform tents along the shore of a lake. They take backpacking and canoe trips, play sports on bumpy fields that tend to be covered with pine needles, enjoy crazy traditions that only the campers seem to understand, and no one seems to miss electricity all that much.

title: He's a Player, Too

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last Sunday about the cost of mass e-mailings to businesses and consumers misattributed a quotation, ''A billion here, a billion there and pretty soon you have real money.'' It was from the former Senate minority leader Everett M. Dirksen, not the former House Speaker Sam Rayburn.

title: Moving Closer to Regaining a Riverfront
description: FOR almost a century, this village of 8,000 has been largely cut off from its namesake river by hulking factories that used the waterway as a highway and, too often, a sewer.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Residences Flower in a Once-Seedy Hoboken Area
description: DEAN S. GEIBEL lived in this famously bohemian city for a while after he got out of college 20 years ago and remembers the prevailing wisdom among those gainfully employed was: ''You don't live west of Willow. O.K., maybe you could live there if you were a fullback, but you wouldn't want your girlfriend living there.'' The area back from the Hudson River, along streets named for presidents -- Adams, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Monroe -- was ''sketchy,'' Mr. Geibel said, and marked by ''old warehouses, boarded-up windows, raw sewage coming out of pipes and packs of wild dogs running in the streets.''

title: Wall Street's Legal Woes Aren't Over Just Yet
description: CHEERS erupted across Wall Street on June 30 when Federal District Judge Milton Pollack in Manhattan dismissed several cases against Merrill Lynch that involved accusations that its research was tainted.

The civil ceremony, which took place in St.-Guillaume, France, was performed by Maurice Vallier, an assistant to the mayor. Later in the day, the Rev. Jean Berkman, a Roman Catholic priest, performed a religious ceremony at St.-Paul Church in St.-Paul-les-Monestier.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Stronger Codes Are Easing Fire Island's Fear of Fire
description: BECAUSE of the wooden boardwalks and closely packed cottages, also built of wood, fire is the biggest fear in the 17 communities on Fire Island, the 32-mile-long barrier island off Long Island's south shore.

description: WHEN the State Legislature passed a law in May saying that liquor stores can now stay open on Sundays, many store owners in Westchester County considered it, but only a few jumped at the chance.

description: Kenyon Martin, angered by the Nets' failure to offer him the maximum allowed by the N.B.A. on a contract extension, has asked to be traded, according to a person close to the discussions.

title: CAP ON BENEFITS UPHELD
description: New Jersey can continue denying additional welfare benefits to women who have babies while on public assistance, the state Supreme Court ruled last week. Women's rights groups, advocates for children and anti-abortion groups opposed the policy, which was adopted in 1992 and ended the practice of increasing welfare benefits by $64 a month when a recipient had an additional child. In its unanimous ruling, the court said the policy simply placed welfare families ''on par with working families,'' which do not automatically receive wage increases when they have children. David Kocieniewski

title: The Real Consequences Of Illegal Immigrants
description: One can count on the Rev. Allan Ramirez to exploit any opportunity to push the interests of illegal immigrants and promote their ongoing invasion of the United States. His July 27 letter uses the recent firebombing of a house inhabited by illegal aliens in Farmingville to castigate the local citizens as violent and raise the cry of racism.

title: Steak Tips
description: The deals at these steakhouses are hard to pass up even if you're not on the Atkins diet.

title: L.I.'s Latest Export: Little Green Lizards
description: SYLWIA NER was working in her garden about eight summers ago, planting flowers, when she first spotted them: little lizards running around on her driveway, sniffing at berries that had fallen from a tree. At the time, the Ner family was new to Garden City, and their neighbors hadn't yet told them about the lizards, which are green, thin and average about six inches in length. ''At first, I was scared,'' Ms. Ner said. She said she made inquiries and learned that Long Island doesn't have native lizards.

title: Business People; One of the Few That Got Away From Icahn

More recently, he fought doggedly to gain control of VISX, a Santa Clara, Calif., maker of lasers to correct vision. But to hear the woman who fended off that fight in May tell it, the man who uttered the words, ''You learn in this business if you want a friend, get a dog,'' should probably invest in a kennel.

description: After three mornings and nights of swimming races he seldom tries, Michael Phelps returned tonight to one of his specialties, the 200-meter individual medley. All he did was break the world record for the fourth time in 41 days.

title: A Laboratory of Taste
description: Several months before our defense secretary downgraded France to the ''old Europe'' and our restaurateurs started pouring French wine into the gutters, I was talking with Marc Veyrat, a French chef whose two restaurants have received top scores from the Michelin and Gault-Millau guides. To my surprise, Veyrat told me that the most creative cooks in Europe were no longer French; they were Spanish. Had my source been located in the Pentagon and not in a sumptuous auberge on the shores of Lake Annecy, I would have taken the assertion with several fistfuls of gros sel. However, this declaration of Spanish creative supremacy came from one of the most forward-looking chefs in France. I paid attention.

title: Why It's a Wide Wide Wide Wide Screen
description: IN 1950, when Norma Desmond, the mad old silent star in Billy Wilder's ''Sunset Boulevard,'' complained that the pictures had gotten small, she knew whereof she spoke. The American film industry was in a period of contraction. Box office revenues, which had soared during World War II, were sinking. The studios were reeling from the impact of the Justice Department's antitrust campaign, which had just stopped distributors of motion pictures from owning the theaters in which their wares were shown and unshackled stars from restrictive studio contracts.

title: The Brooklyn Problem
description: IT may be the hub of a thriving cultural district, both gateway and playground to one of the city's most vibrant and creative neighborhoods. But to the people who decide where and when to open rarefied films like ''Swimming Pool'' or ''Whale Rider,'' the BAM Rose Cinemas might as well be in Levittown.

title: The Secret of the Black Paintings
description: The Black Paintings make an interesting and provocative whodunit and academic controversy. But does it really matter? These paintings look like Goya's -- they reflect his tormented nightmare vision as expressed in ''Los Capriccios,'' his famous etching series. The inscription on one etching reads, ''El Sueo de la razn produce monstruos'' (''The sleep of reason produces monsters''). This may well sum up the very spirit of the Black Paintings, as well as the present intellectual squabble over their authenticity. Whoever actually painted the Black Paintings, they are, in every sense, style and spirit, Goya's.

title: Militant Islamic Meeting Draws Sparse Crowd in Indonesia
description: SOLO, Indonesia, Aug. 10  Menacing looking young men in battle fatigues and army boots and with their heads wrapped in Arabic scarves guarded the foot of an outdoor stage, and many more guided guests to their seats for the opening of a militant Islamic congress here today.

title: Gainsborough Show On View in Boston
description: ''The Blue Boy'' isn't in Boston, but many of Thomas Gainsborough's other great works are. It continues the Boston museum's recent interest in great portraitists, following shows on Mary Cassatt and John Singer Sargent and preceding one on Rembrandt in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEELINE, PAUL CUSHING
description: SHEELINE--Paul Cushing. Of Lloyd Harbor, New York, died on August 6, 2003. Husband of Sandra Wahl and father of Christopher, William, Mary, Leonora and Abby, and grandfather of Mila, Sophie, William, Alec and Haya. Predeceased by his first wife, Harriet Moffat, B.S., Harvard College, Editor, Harvard Crimson; J.D., Harvard Law School. Service to Captain, U.S. Army Air Forces, 1942 to 1946; received Silver Star, French Legion of Honor, and Croix De Guerre with Palm. Chairman, president and C.E.O., Intercontinental Hotels Corporation, 1971 to 1986; Director, Pan Am Corp., 1971-1992; Director, National Westminster Bank, U.S.A., 1978 to 1992. Member, President Ronald Reagan's Board of Advisors on Private Sector Initiative, 1987 to 1989; Director, Foreign Policy Association, 1981 to 1990; Director, Scientists for Public Information, 1980 to 1991; Chairman, American-Arab Association for Commerce and Industry, 1984 to 1986; Director, Resorts International, 1990 to 1994; Trustee, St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital Center, NYC, 1983 to 1998; Co-founder and Trustee, Battle of Normandy Foundation, Trustee, Camargo Foundation, Cassis, France 1973 to present. Services, Monday, August 11, 12 noon, St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York. Contributions in his memory to East Woods School, Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: DANGEROUS SCHOOLS
description: The state Department of Education has named seven schools as ''persistently dangerous,'' based on reports of violent incidents. The schools on the list, which is mandated by the federal No Child Left Behind Act and will be published annually, will be required to notify parents within 15 days that they can ask for their children to be transferred. The schools are Camden High School, East Camden Middle School and Bonsall Family School, all in Camden; the Lakeside Middle School, in Millville; Atlantic City High School; Patrick Healy Middle School in East Orange; and Simmons Elementary School in Clayton. Schools that are placed on the list may appeal the decision, and officials at the Millville district have already said they will do so. Maria Newman

title: Two Bridges in Queens, And a Whole Lot of Sighs
description: Picture two bridges about a quarter mile apart and roughly parallel, each crossing the canyon of the Sunnyside Rail Yards. These would be the 39th Street and Honeywell Street Bridges, which connect Northern Boulevard and Skillman Avenue, major rush hour arteries that jam with traffic moving to and from the Queensboro Bridge. Especially messy is the intersection of the 39th Street Bridge and Northern Boulevard, where left-turning drivers leaving the bridge cause a cascade of delays by scooting through red lights en masse.

title: The Emo Diaries: No Wonder the Band Is Called Confessional
description: MOST every night before she goes to sleep at her home near Los Angeles, Frances Michelle Lopez sits down in front of her computer, loads up a playlist of her favorite music -- emo old-schoolers like Rites of Spring and Weezer, indie faves like Belle & Sebastian and Sleater-Kinney -- and pours her heart out. Fights with the folks? Check. Relationship squabbles? Check. The acute sense that the world isn't always kind to a highly self-aware 16-year-old? Naturally.

description: NEW STADIUMS

title: Double Vision. Double Vision.
description: THOSE ungrateful French, treating us like day-old wine, snickering behind our backs at our high-school French. For years they made us believe that we loved Paris in the springtime, we loved Paris in the fall, Paris when it drizzles and when it sizzles.

title: Iran Plans to Try Qaeda Suspects
description: An Iranian government minister has said that foreigners suspected of being Al Qaeda operatives whose home countries refuse to take them back will be put on trial in Iran, the daily Entekhab reported today.

title: RAIL PLAN FOR MEADOWLANDS
description: State officials said last week that they were close to proposing a $470 million train line that would include a 2.6-mile loop around the stadium, arena and racetrack at the Meadowlands Sports Complex. The loop would connect to the Secaucus Transfer station -- slated to open next month -- giving nearly every New Jersey Transit line in the state access to the Meadowlands. The plan is said to be crucial to the $1.3 billion Xanadu entertainment and office complex to be built on 100 acres starting late this year or early next. A spokesman for Governor McGreevey noted that financing would have to be ironed out before a plan goes to the Legislature for a vote. Jonathan Miller

title: Banshees Howl on Oregon's Dunes
description: THE sound is the drone of a thousand angry hornets. As throttles are cocked, amplified insect whines fill the air. Dune-buggy riders in groups of three let loose and rip up the side of a 200-foot sand hill, tires spraying silica plumes as friends and families watch from a parking lot at the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area. At the end of each informal heat, contestants crest the hill, turn and plummet to the bottom, then line up to repeat the whole thing.

title: Corrections

title: Kara Sundlun and Dennis House
description: IN the past 10 years, Kara Sundlun has met the two most important men in her life, getting to know both in the glare of television spotlights. Neither story could have been better scripted.

title: River Views Worth Viewing
description: GREAT strides have been made in recent years in reclaiming Westchester County's Hudson River waterfronts for the use and enjoyment of its residents. A great deal of public and private investment has been made to clean up old industrial sites, build parks and appropriately scaled development projects. Communities that for decades turned their backs to the river have rediscovered its beauty.

title: California to Ban Chemicals Used as Flame Retardants
description: Reacting to research showing the rapid accumulation of widely used flame retardants in humans and wildlife, California will become the first state to ban the chemicals, which are suspected of contributing to learning disorders, attention deficit and hyperactivity in children.

title: The Land of Lewis and Clark
description: As he worked his way along the Missouri River in western Montana in the spring of 1805, Meriwether Lewis wrote rhapsodically of ''seens of visionary enchantment,'' of coming upon ''immence herds of Buffaloe, Elk, deer & Antelopes feeding in one common and boundless pasture.'' To read the chronicles of Lewis and Clark now is to imagine a world that no longer exists. Gone is much of the wilderness that enveloped the expedition as it moved westward across the continent; gone too is most of the wildlife. Thomas Jefferson thought it might take a thousand years to populate the newly acquired Louisiana Purchase. It required less than a hundred. As the Times's Timothy Egan observed in his recent series marking the 200th anniversary of the Purchase, as well as Jefferson's decision to send Lewis and Clark to explore it, only ''tattered scraps of once-splendid mosaics'' remain.

title: The Horror, the Horror
description: WHILE at the playground in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, a few weeks ago with Dean, my 3-year-old, and another child very much on the way, a woman with a newborn and a toddler sat down next to me.

description: On a typical day, elite swimmers may cover more than nine miles in workouts. They may swim for two hours in the morning and two or three in the afternoon.

title: Gambits and More Gambits, And It All Ends in Fireworks
description: Some old gambits never fade away, they just go on creating wild ruckuses. The granddaddy of these is the Schliemann Gambit in the Ruy Lopez, which begins with a pawn sacrifice by Black, followed by malicious gifts of queens, rooks and minor pieces. Who is the gambiteer and who the defender often cannot be told except by hindsight.

title: Armand Gustaferro, 79, Dies; Studied Fire's Effect on Treated Concrete
description: Armand H. Gustaferro, who helped develop fire-resistance standards for prestressed concrete, a mainstay of modern construction, died Aug. 3 at his home in Glenview, Ill. He was 79.

title: The Secret of the Black Paintings
description: As an art historian and artist, I find that the possible reattribution of the Black Paintings to Francisco Goya's son, Javier, suggests several re-readings of the images (Arthur Lubow, July 27). The paintings are no less interesting or skillful, and may still be read as the painterly ''outflow of a tormented'' soul. We have a horrific image of a father consuming his child in ''Saturn,'' which may be seen as the vision of a painter's son overwhelmed by a successful father. In ''The Sabbat,'' Javier may have painted his father as a he-goat captivating the admiring masses. And in ''The Fates,'' well, yes, what would have been Javier Goya's fate, had his father not been the great Goya?

title: BackTalk; Protesting Through the Streets
description: The most grueling would-be event at the Pan American Games involves a torch, running, shooting and crying.

title: U.S. Moved to Undermine Iraqi Military Before War
description: The United States military, the Central Intelligence Agency and Iraqi exiles began a broad covert effort inside Iraq at least three months before the war to forge alliances with Iraqi military leaders and persuade commanders not to fight, say people involved in the effort.

title: Between One Wedding And a Funeral, All of Life
description: I FIRST saw Edward Yang's ''Yi Yi'' at an evening press screening three years ago, a few weeks before it was shown at the New York Film Festival. It had been a long, wearying day, and, to be perfectly honest, sitting through a three-hour movie, in Mandarin and Hokkien with subtitles, seemed more likely to be a chore than a pleasure. But when it was over I found myself, like so many others who have seen this quiet domestic epic, not drained but revivified. One of the characters proclaims that movies give you more life, and ''Yi Yi,'' which shows tonight at 9 on the Sundance Channel and repeats throughout the month, proves him right.

title: Why People Still Starve
description: Your July 27 Letters column on Barry Bearak's article on hunger in Africa (July 13) stressed the importance of population control. Unfortunately, the decision to have many children in such dire circumstances may, at least in the short term, be more rational than not, for the more offspring two adults have, the more likely that one or more children will survive and be able to care for their aging parents.

title: She Earns Big Ratings, but Can't Buy Groceries
description: STRIDING up and down the stage in three-inch heels, the talk-show host Laura Bozzo is all bluster and outrage. As her guests, a collection of drug addicts and wife beaters, mistresses and sobbing wives, squirm in their seats, she shouts and reprimands, telling one adulterous, drug-addicted husband to ''go under a bridge and kill yourself.'' A child pornographer, she declares, deserves nothing less than a public lynching. Motley guests go for each other's throats, held back by black-shirted bouncers; the audience oohs and aahs in delight, or hisses in revulsion.

title: Denver Perennials Fit for East
description: THOUGH the mile-high Denver Botanic Gardens at the foot of the Rocky Mountains is considered among the finest in the country, it can be dispiriting for a mid-Atlantic gardener used to low-level, steam-bath conditions. Last month, as I prepared to venture through 23 acres of borders filled with towering prairie perennials, tiny alpines, swaying grasses and a variety of conifers that were actually enjoying the near-100 degree dry heat, I assumed there was nothing of interest for my garden in central New Jersey.

Summer's Palette
