Mr. McDonald is a master at mixing colors, patterns and fabrics with his classically cut suits from Vivienne Westwood of London. In the mix are gingham shirts, paisley ties, two-tone shoes and fedoras from the Harlem men's hatter Rod Keenan.

title: Old World Style, With No Concessions

And so, by the time you are seated at one of the restaurant's 13 tables, you will be well aware that this place is different.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: CAMP GRANADA: Sing Along Camp Songs. Compiled and illustrated by Fran Lessac. Holt. $18.95. (Ages 5 to 12) Cheerful illustrations of a season at summer camp, and the words to over 30 songs that link generations of Americans who have gone to camp and sung from morning till late at night. Adults never quite forget them; children, especially in August when they return home, can't stop repeating them, from ''Make New Friends'' and ''Do Your Ears Hang Low'' to ''Found a Peanut'' ''Kum Ba Ya'' and ''Taps.'' Oh yes, ''Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh,'' the anthem of the legendary Camp Granada, is there, of course. THE CANNING SEASON. By Polly Horvath. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 12 and up) For Ratchet, who grew up in Florida, a summer in the Maine woods with two eccentric aunts, Tilly and Penpen, is full of unexpected, often hilarious events.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE CRIMSON PETAL AND THE WHITE, by Michel Faber. (Harvest/Harcourt, $15.) This novel's heroine, a 19-year-old prostitute who plies her trade in Victorian London, confronts a wretched world armed with nothing more than wit, moxie and a good heart. Against the odds, she begins to climb socially when she goes from being a wealthy man's mistress to becoming his child's governess. Last year our reviewer, James R. Kincaid, admired the book's ''sweep and subtlety'' and its narrative technique, which allows readers ''to find feelings and states of being we didn't know we possessed.''

title: Queer Guy With a Slob's Eye
description: IN a classic scene from Robert Anderson's ''Tea and Sympathy,'' a 1950's Broadway play about a teenage boy whose classmates taunt him for acting like a girl, the boy's closest straight buddy tries to teach him to walk like a man. Of course, the boy can't get it right. He walks back and forth across the room, aping his friend, but failing to swagger and glare convincingly. Finally, he is saved from his ruinous girlishness only by the headmaster's wife, who seduces him, saying famously, ''Years from now, when you talk about this -- and you will -- be kind.''

I've been touring too much this past year and writing too little, and this summer was supposed to be spent clearing my head and getting back to work. But summer is a disobedient season. We plan our summers to be one thing but they turn out to be something else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLD, WILLIAM (BILL)
description: GOLD--William (Bill). On August 9. Survived by his beloved wife Cindy of 51 years; sister Muriel; daughter Laurie and partner Nancy; son Mark and wife Lisa; grandchildren Alex, Jessica, Sydney and Ross. Graduated Bronx High School of Science '46, Harvard '49. Since then he has been an active volunteer fund raiser for Harvard as a ''thank you'' for accepting him and giving him a scholarship. Ater graduating Columbia Law School he was an Assistant DA in Manhattan before becoming a trial lawyer. For the past 38 years he has been an active member of the Great Neck community, and recently served as Village Judge and Trustee of Temple Beth El. His keen wit, charm, intelligence, warmth and friendliness will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral Tuesday, August 12, 10 AM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset.

title: Black Sheep of the Family
description: If books are, as Jonathan Swift put it, ''the children of the brain,'' then it stands to reason that a few of them will wind up being disowned. What could possibly provoke an author to repudiate the product of months, if not years, of work? It's hard to say, for when a writer chooses to omit a title from the list headed ''By the Same Author'' at the front of a new book (that page is known, for reasons lost in the murk of publishing history, as the ''ad card''), he or she usually doesn't want to talk about it either. He or she usually just wishes the whole thing would go away. At a book signing for Don DeLillo, a friend of mine presented the novelist with a copy of a little-known work DeLillo had written years ago under a pseudonym. ''I don't sign that,'' he said firmly.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: FISHING IN ALASKA -- Through Sept. 3, Angling Unlimited has late-season specials on fishing trips in southeast Alaska, for coho salmon and halibut. Three days' fishing is $1,195 a person, double occupancy; four days, $1,545; five days, $1,895. That rate includes fishing with a licensed captain and crew, fishing licenses, airport transfers, breakfast and lunch daily, use of tackle and rain gear and packing of your catch to airline specifications. Accommodations are at the Sitka Rock Waterfront Suites (the number of nights is one more than the number of days fishing), and there's use of a rental car. For more information, call (800) 297-3380 or go to www.anglingunlimited.com.

title: Why People Still Starve
description: The common response to your article on famine was to blame the Malawi family for having 12 children and to prescribe population control. There is a complex relationship between high infant-mortality rates and high birthrates. There is also a relationship between a woman's education and her family's size. If we want to use some of America's riches to help the poor, we should educate women.

There, the transformation from catcher to first baseman will continue.

title: POLLUTERS PAY MORE

About 9,000 suits already brought against polluters will be reviewed to see if additional damage awards can be obtained. ''We are committed to aggressively pursuing damage settlements for the residents of this state who have lost the ability to use and enjoy some of our most precious natural resources, including drinking water sources and wetlands,'' said Commissioner Bradley Campbell. Karen DeMasters

title: Italian Spot Upholds Tradition

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, JUDGE HAROLD
description: HYMAN--Judge Harold. Age 93. Died on August 9, at peace and surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Ruth (deceased). Father of Edward Hyman (deceased), Franklin Hyman and Myra Diamond, father-in-law of Sharyn, Marjory and Philip, 12 grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren. A resident of Florida, he was vactioning in New York at the time of his death. Judge Hyman was elected to the New York State Supreme Court in 1973 and served with great distinction, first as a Justice of the Court and later as a Judicial Hearing Officer. He routinely was asked to preside over complicated multi-party cases as well as cases of great social significance, including the landmark case in which he found that a child infected with AIDS must be allowed to attend NYC public schools. A private service is planned by his loving family at Mt. Golda Cemetery, Dix Hills, NY.

title: The Bow of Bach's Dreams? Not Quite
description: HOW was Bach's music performed during his own lifetime? The question has inspired impassioned debate and meticulous scholarship, not to mention one of the more bizarrely misguided yet fascinating musical inventions of the early 20th century: the ''Bach bow,'' designed to render three or four notes of a chord at once without requiring the player to roll the bow across strings and thereby arpeggiate the chord. A reminder of its strange story and even stranger sound comes in a new two-CD Testament reissue of the Hungarian violinist Emil Telmanyi's famous 1954 recording of Bach's solo sonatas and partitas, using the Vega Bach bow he championed.

title: Corrections

Riot gates and plywood-covered windows would follow, they feared, inevitably casting a forbidding pall on a thoroughfare that is struggling to emerge as Banana Republic- and Sephora-worthy as its South of Houston counterpart.

title: Denver Perennials That Travel
description: THOUGH the mile-high Denver Botanic Gardens at the foot of the Rocky Mountains are considered among the finest in the country, it can be dispiriting for a mid-Atlantic gardener used to low-level, steam-bath conditions. Last month, as I prepared to venture through 23 acres of borders filled with towering prairie perennials, tiny alpines, swaying grasses and a variety of conifers that were actually enjoying the near-100 degree dry heat, I assumed there was nothing of interest for my garden in central New Jersey.

description: THE route from here to Ullapool across the north of Scotland is one of Europe's most remote. Apart from free-range sheep and an occasional vehicle, the road is almost empty for miles as it hugs the seashore and plunges between gaunt, gray mountains and silvery lochs. It is a perfect place to test the new Bentley Continental GT, an imposing four-seater that performs like a supercar.

title: Shiva Meets Martha Graham, at a Very High Speed

His choreography fuses classic Indian and Western modern dance, a style he calls contemporary kathak, an homage to the 16th-century North Indian dance in which he trained.

title: The Nation: Making Book; Handicapping the Race From Page to Screen
description: WHENEVER Hollywood releases a movie based on a popular book -- even, for that matter, an obscure one -- at least one wiseguy, usually a critic, is sure to point out what has been lost and added in the translation. Chronology is warped, important details are changed, composite characters are invented, sprawling, ambiguous narratives are shoehorned into the sacrosanct three-act structure -- and each of these departures will give someone cause to cavil.

He served as the disciplinarian in Mr. Taylor's rebel army and then as ambassador to Libya. He was appointed vice president in 2000, but then was imprisoned for 10 days last June, accused of taking part in a coup attempt.

An individual with a blood-alcohol reading of .26 is not making a decision about ending his life; he's following an irrational impulse triggered by the drug. Tragically, the impulse occurred at the same time a weapon was available.

title: Flight Risk
description: On a flight from Los Angeles to New York, I bought three seats, as is my custom, so my girlfriend and I would be assured of an empty seat between us. We find it an order of magnitude more comfortable to dump our stuff in the middle seat and enjoy the ''extra'' room we paid for. A flight attendant tried to seat a passenger in the middle seat (and reimburse us). I refused, and with a look that could smelt iron, the passenger debarked to await a later flight. It would have been charitable of us to give her our empty seat, but were we obligated to? Anonymous, Nutley, N.J.

title: The Real June Is Still Singing Out
description: THE overture began: the varied sounds of six dogs barking, running, growling, skidding toward the visitor who entered the sun room where their mistress sat. They warned and announced, loped back and forth as the guest drew nigh, trying to gauge their mistress's pleasure. description: A teenager whose .38-caliber revolver was used in the accidental shooting on Friday of a 3-year-old boy pleaded not guilty in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday to a charge of illegal weapons possession. Anthony Rodriguez, 17, who investigators have described as a gang member, was held last night after failing to post bail of $30,000, according to Sandy Silverstein, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Rodriguez was sleeping in an apartment in Brownsville on Friday morning when Darrell Williams, 3, was shot in the face by his cousin Glenn Bowman, 9. Investigators said Glenn found the gun as he was looking for pictures under the bed where Mr. Rodriguez was sleeping. Darrell was in extremely critical condition last night at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

His flight, Air France Flight 9, which was scheduled to leave at 11 p.m. on Friday for Paris, was canceled. The co-pilot, Philippe Riviere, 51, was searched and did not have a bomb. He was arraigned on charges of falsely reporting an incident and could face up to seven years in prison if convicted. Judge Deborah Stevens Modica of Queens Criminal Court set bail at $7,500. His lawyer, Florence Morgan, did not return a call seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Dies In Queens Crash
description: A Staten Island man was killed yesterday morning when the car he was driving collided with a sport utility vehicle at Grand Central Parkway and Parsons Boulevard in Queens, the police said. The man, Raymond Dash, 47, and a 12-year-old girl with him in the 1991 Ford Taurus were taken to Queens Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead about an hour after the 6 a.m. crash, the police said. The girl was treated for minor injuries and was in stable condition. The driver of the S.U.V., a 1999 Dodge Durango, refused medical attention, the police said. No summonses were issued, and the police said the investigation was continuing. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

Four months after the fall of Baghdad, his unit was still eating the dreaded M.R.E.'s: meals ready to eat. When Italian troops moved into the area, their food was ''way more realistic'' -- and American troops were soon trading whatever they could for some of that Italian food.

title: U.S. and Canadian Inquiries Into Energy Trader
description: Daniel Gordon, the former chief energy trader for Merrill Lynch, is being investigated on suspicion of embezzling $43 million from Merrill in 2000 by disguising the theft as an energy trade, according to a letter written by a federal prosecutor in New York and interviews with Canadian law enforcement officials.

title: Bad Will Hunting, Armed With Venom Darts
description: Is there anyone who isn't sick of Ben Affleck, with his J.Lo and his ''Gigli'' and the salaams he elicits when he deigns to show up in ''Project Greenlight''? To me, his pal Matt Damon is easier to take, partly because he doesn't seem quite such a sellout and a glory hog and partly because his talent is more than skin deep. But I'm not a young actor puzzled, exasperated and moved to vindictiveness by the good fortune that has descended collectively on the two childhood friends from Boston after they wrote the Oscar-winning screenplay ''Good Will Hunting'' and appeared in it.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Suspect Chemical Taken From North Korean Freighter
description: Acting on a tip from the United States, Taiwan customs officials boarded a North Korean freighter and seized 40 tons of phosphoros pentasulfide, a chemical that can be used for rocket fuel, Japan's Kyodo News reported. Soon after the chemical was unloaded in Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan, the ship proceeded to North Korea. Taiwan, firmly anti-Communist, is not part of the Proliferation Security Initiative, an 11-nation coalition forged this summer by the United States to repress the trade in materials for unconventional weapons. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Soloists and Orchestra Share the Limelight

This summer, though, the orchestra's performances have been so vital, sharply defined and full of surprises that it has become an attraction itself. Perhaps it has something to do with the festival's new music director, Louis Langre, although there seems to have been a renovation in the orchestra's ranks as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, WALTER FORBES

Beloved husband of Margaret O'Brien Sloan for 64 years, loving father of Tina Sloan McPherson, John Sloan, and the late Margo Sloan Pearson. He leaves six grandchildren. Born in Niles, Michigan, he was a graduate of the University of Illinois, and of Harvard Law and Business Schools. He served in World War II as a Lieutenant in the US Naval Reserve in the Mediterranean. He lived for 65 years in Bronxville, NY and was a member of the Bronxville Field Club and The Siwanoy Country Club where he served on the Board of Governors and as Secretary of the Board. A Memorial service will be held on Monday, August 18 at 11:00 AM in the Chapel at The Osborne, 101 Theall Road, Rye, NY.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Second 9/11 Trial
description: A suspected member of the Hamburg terrorist cell behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in New York and Virginia will go on trial in Hamburg on Thursday. The Moroccan-born defendant, Abdelghani Mzoudi, 30, is charged with 3,066 counts of abetting murder and aiding a terrorist organization. Mr. Mzoudi was a friend of Mohamed Atta, one of the terrorist pilots, and was a witness for his will. Mr. Atta and two other pilots in the attacks were from the Hamburg cell. If found guilty, Mr. Mzoudi faces the same 15-year jail term to which a fellow Moroccan, Mounir el-Motassadeq, was sentenced in February for aiding the hijackers. The trial, with 125 witnesses, could last into early next year. Victor Homola (NYT)

Books, files and storage boxes are crammed in a corner, walls are adorned in a style known as basic bare, and the desk has that lived-in look. A campaign poster for Brazil's blue-collar president and a child's drawing provide the only splashes of color.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Hughes And Cooperative Settle DirecTV Dispute
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation, the nation's largest satellite television provider, said yesterday that the National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative would give up its right to distribute Hughes's DirecTV service by the end of June 2011, under the terms of a settlement. DirecTV said it would continue to pursue a $50 million lawsuit claiming the Pegasus Communications Corporation, which markets DirecTV on behalf of the cooperative, breached a marketing agreement. Representatives of the company and of the cooperative did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment. Pegasus shares fell $13.80, or 37 percent, to $23.10. Hughes, based in El Segundo, Calif., rose 30 cents, to $13.70.

title: Bush Nominates Utah Governor To Lead Environmental Agency
description: President Bush today nominated Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, the three-term Republican governor of Utah, as the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, tapping a veteran of the West's volatile land use debates.

title: 86% Rise In Profit For Hyundai In Quarter
description: The Hyundai Motor Company today reported an 86 percent increase in second-quarter profit, despite a strike that began in the third week of June and declining sales in the domestic market.

title: Deutsch Chairman In Deal With CNBC

Terms were not disclosed.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Lead Exposure Reported Declining
description: Fewer toddlers are testing positive in New Jersey for elevated levels of lead in their blood, according to a report by the Department of Health. But the smaller numbers may be a statistical effect of increased testing, officials said. Lead, when ingested, can damage vital organs. The study, released last week, reported that 3.2 percent of children under 2 tested positive for elevated lead levels, compared with 3.8 percent in 2001 in a slightly smaller sample. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

Funeral Home, 569 E. 184th St., Bronx on Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9PM and Wednesday 2-4 PM. Viewing Wednesday 5-7 PM at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, 627 E. 187th St., Bronx. title: Why the Great Smog of London Was Anything but Great
description: In early December 1952, a great mass of cold air moved off the English Channel, draped itself over London like an icy comforter and then simply stayed put.

description: The members of the Charter Revision Commission appointed earlier this year by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have reached consensus on a number of features of a plan that would radically restructure politics.

It is $1.13 million, not $885,000.

description: MULDOON -- Sylvia Rivera del Moral, 67, died peacefully at home on August 10, 2003. Born in Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, March 17, 1936, Sylvia was the daughter of Francisco Rivera Camacho and RosaLinda del Moral de Rivera. Beloved wife of Thomas O. Muldoon, M.D. Loving mother of Brian Thomas, Sarah Catherine and John Francisco. Mother-in-law of Timothy Dillon. Cherished grandmother of Emma, Thomas and Grace. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, Tuesday, August 12, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 AM on Wednesday, August 13 at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Catholic Health Care Foundation, 155 East 56th Street, NY., NY. 10022, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Retina Center, 310 East 14th Street, NY, NY 10003 or Padre Pio Homeless Shelter, Box 55, Larchmont, New York 10538.

title: 2 Suicide Bombings, One Claimed by Hamas, Kill 2 Israelis
description: ROSH HAAYIN, Israel, Aug. 12 - Two Palestinian suicide bombers, both teenagers, killed two Israelis today and inflicted the most serious blow yet to the fragile American-led plan to find peace between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: New Chink in the Armor Of the Malaria Parasite
description: Researchers racing to develop new treatments for malaria, a disease now resurgent in Africa, have found a peculiarity in the parasite's molecular machinery that may make it vulnerable to the biological equivalent of a computer crash.

title: Companies Faulted for Using Old Maps in Quecreek Collapse
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 — The accident that flooded the Quecreek mine in Pennsylvania last summer, riveting the nation to a rescue mission that saved all nine trapped miners, could have been avoided if the mining companies had realized that they were using out-of-date maps, federal safety investigators said today.

title: A Specialist in Fighting New Diseases Is Chosen to Wipe Out an Old One
description: At 57, Dr. David L. Heymann has had an extraordinary career. The epidemiologist has helped discover two new diseases (Ebola and Legionnaire's), rid the world of an old one (smallpox) and stop spread of the newest (SARS).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Windham: Queens Girl Drowns Upstate
description: A 13-year-old Elmhurst girl drowned yesterday afternoon while on a church retreat, a State Police spokesman said last night. The girl, whose name was not released, was with six other children in a pond at Kelly Acres, a country inn in Greene County, when she went under. The pastor of her church pulled her from the water and tried to revive her, the spokesman said, but she was pronounced dead at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Saudi Company Sues Lucent
description: Lucent Technologies won favorable treatment from Saudi Arabia's telephone agency by paying more than $15 million in bribes to the office's minister, a lawsuit charges. The National Group for Communications and Computers Ltd., a Saudi-based company, said Lucent bribed Ali al-Johani, whose ministry oversaw the Saudi phone system. In return, Mr. Johani directed the government-controlled Saudi Telecom Company, of which he was chairman, to take actions that favored Lucent and harmed National Group, the suit asserts. National Group has previously brought a contract claim against Lucent in federal court in New Jersey. Lucent denied the accusations. ''While we have not yet been served with the suit, we are generally familiar with the allegations,'' a spokesman, John Skalko, said. ''We believe them to be without merit and will defend ourselves vigorously.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENOFF, MURRAY
description: MENOFF--Murray. Died August 10, 2003. Loving husband of Renee. Devoted father to Anne, Jeff and Jill. Beloved grandfather of Matthew, Rachel, Angel, Dakota, Andrew, Eron, Jarod and Sam. Loving brother of Arthur and Sara. He took much pleasure in life, and in teaching and sharing the things that he loved with his family and friends. Services today, 12:45PM, ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Fed Suggests It May Keep Rates Low for Some Time to Come
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 - The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1 percent this afternoon, and it strongly suggested that it would keep short-term rates at their current low level for at least the remainder of this year.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Profit Shows Steep Drop At Stewart
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said yesterday that second-quarter earnings fell sharply, another sign that the legal troubles of Ms. Stewart remain an albatross for her formerly lofty company.

title: Bush Flies Over Fire Site to Promote 'Healthy Forests'
description: President Bush went on a helicopter tour today over a national forest hard hit by fires to promote a plan that he said would help control them, but that his critics said would allow excessive logging on federal land.

title: What You Do Know Can't Hurt You
description: A recent report that one of the most widely prescribed antidepressants, Paxil, might be linked to an increased risk of suicidal thinking in teenagers and children has sent a wave of anxiety through doctors and depressed patients alike.

title: Indian Point Is Said to Pass U.S. Test in Mock Attack
description: The private security force at the Indian Point nuclear power plant successfully repelled multiple mock attacks in a high-tech training exercise conducted two weeks ago, the head of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said in a letter released yesterday, the first public assessment of the exercise.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Shrinks
description: Singapore's economy had its biggest contraction on record last quarter after the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome decimated the tourism industry. Gross domestic product shrank 11.4 percent in the three months ended June 30 from the previous quarter, after adjusting for seasonal factors, the trade and industry ministry said. The outbreak of SARS drove visitor arrivals to the lowest level in more than two decades and is expected to curb economic growth for the full year. On Friday, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong lowered the government forecast for economic expansion for the year to zero to 1 percent, down from 0.5 percent to 2.5 percent.

title: Mets' Franco Is Not Putting His Future to Rest
description: Like any reliever, the Mets' John Franco has had plenty of sleepless nights, when a friend's words go only so far. Franco is pitching through the final two months of the season with an uncertain role and an uncertain future.

title: An Actor's New Role: Fund-Raising
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger has not been in politics for a full week yet, but he showed on a campaign swing through New York City yesterday that he has already learned a thing or two: pose for lots of pictures with children, avoid talking policy or taking questions from reporters and fish for campaign contributions at the Four Seasons.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Economy Maintains Growth
description: Two economic indicators showed that China's economy maintained its strong momentum through July. Industrial production rose 16.5 percent in July from a year earlier to 341 billion yuan ($41.2 billion), led by automobile manufacturing and electronics, particularly cellular telephones, the National Bureau of Statistics said. Total exports for the January-July period rose by about one-third to $228 billion, the state-owned People's Daily said. Chinese economic statistics are often released via official media.

title: Dodgers Batter Marlins' Sensation
description: He earned a standing ovation just stepping onto the field to stretch. Every time his gum-chomping visage flashed on the JumboTron during warm-ups, the crowd cheered. ''You're the real thing,'' crooned Bono, U2's lead singer, in a recording played over the public address system, an assessment Miami's re-emerging baseball fans have affixed to the rookie pitcher Dontrelle Willis.

title: Bullets in Canarsie, and a Wounded Boy 'Kept Running'
description: The shots sounded moments after Janard Knight left a basketball game in Canarsie, Brooklyn, to look for a bottle of water on Sunday night.

description: FLORIN--Gertrude ''Trudy,'' 87, of Longboat Key, FL, on August 11. Born New Bedford, MA. description: As the Federal Reserve prepares to meet about interest rates on Tuesday, recent fears about price deflation have in large part abated.

title: Rebuilding, Royals Stand Atop the Heap
description: For Carlos Beltran, this was an impossible situation. The only way Beltran expected to be in first place in Kansas City this summer was if he visited Kauffman Stadium with another team.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Porch-Safety Review Set For Bayside
description: City officials announced yesterday that buildings workers would begin providing no-questions-asked safety reviews of outdoor decks and porches in Bayside, Queens. On Saturday night, a backyard deck in Bayside collapsed, killing a woman and injuring three other people. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that during the next 30 days, the workers would go door to door to inspect the decks and inform homeowners of unsafe conditions but would not issue any violations. Residents elsewhere in the city can call 311 for a buildings worker to be sent to look at their decks. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: A Misdirected Forest Strategy
description: A year ago, President Bush used the the worst of last summer's forest fires, the Biscuit fire in southern Oregon, as a backdrop to unveil his Healthy Forests initiative -- a plan that on close inspection has less to do with preventing forest fires than it does with helping his friends in the timber industry. In a replay yesterday, Mr. Bush used a visit to the site of the Aspen fire in Arizona to reaffirm his support for the same strategy. The strategy has not improved with age. Indeed, as encapsulated in legislation that was passed by the House and is nearing approval in the Senate, it may have gotten worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, HAROLD B., CPA, MBA, CFP
description: STERN--Harold B., CPA, MBA, CFP, Senior Partner of Bronstein and Stern, CPAs. Passed away on August 11, 2003 of natural causes. He was 89. He is survived by his wife Ruth and brothers Bill and Mel. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Mannes College of Music and the Hebrew Home and Hospital of Manhattan will be gratefully acknowledged.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Athens; An Ancient City Is Sprucing Itself Up
description: Athens is getting a makeover for the return of the Olympic Games in 2004 to the land of their birth. The new Metro system is a model of speed, efficiency and beauty, with many stations displaying archeological artifacts excavated during construction or bold contemporary works by Greek artists.

In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to BI Medical Center Oncological Support Group, c/o Hester Hill, 330 Brookline Ave, Boston, MA, 02215.

title: FIVE EXECUTIVES AT DELTA TO FORGO BONUSES
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that five top executives would forgo bonuses this year as the company tried to persuade pilots to accept pay cuts to help stem losses. The chief financial officer, M. Michele Burns; Vicki Escarra, an executive vice president and chief marketing officer; and Robert L. Colman, the executive vice president for human resources, will not accept bonuses, the chief executive, Leo F. Mullin, said in a memo to employees. Mr. Mullin and the president, Frederick W. Reid, already were planning to pass up such payments. Delta is asking its pilots to take pay cuts to help reduce unit costs by about 15 percent. The airline had net losses of $2.49 billion in the past two years. It would not disclose how much it expected to save with the executive-compensation changes.

title: Summer, Minus the Air-Conditioning
description: To the Editor:

title: The Governor and the City
description: Residents of New York City can be forgiven for sometimes thinking that Gov. George Pataki is out to get them. After Mayor Michael Bloomberg supported Mr. Pataki in the last election -- holding off dealing with the city's financial emergency until the governor was safely re-elected -- the mayor went to Albany for a payback. After cutting city services and raising city taxes, the mayor still needed funds to fix a crippling $6.4 billion budget gap. Mr. Bloomberg proposed that those who live in the suburbs and work in the city should pay their fair share of the cost of fire and police protection through a commuter tax. But the governor refused, snubbing the city and instead giving the suburbs what amounted to a bonus in special aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMS, DOROTHY
description: ABRAMS--Dorothy. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dorothy Abrams, beloved mother of our cherished friend and supporter, former New York Attorney General Robert Abrams. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bob and to the entire Abrams family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: Five Linked to Mt. Vernon Pet Shop Are Charged With Animal Cruelty
description: Four store owners and the landlord of a Westchester County pet shop face criminal charges, a week after the store was found abandoned and padlocked, the animals inside left to starve.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NORTH KOREA: TALKS LIKELY THIS MONTH Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing of China confirmed that six-party talks about how to end North Korea's nuclear program are to take place this month. Mr. Li, visiting Japan, said there was "some foundation" to reports that North Korea and the United States, along with China, Japan, South Korea and Russia, would hold talks in Beijing beginning Aug. 26, though he declined to provide more detail. China diplomats have been engaged in shuttle diplomacy around the region to nail down the format and the timing of the negotiations. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Train Maker Is Investigated
description: Alstom, a maker of trains, said that its rail unit in the United States wasunder a formal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission over accounting improprieties. Alstom said on June 30 that there were accounting problems related to a rail car contract at the factory of Alstom Transportation Inc. in Hornell, N.Y. Alstom suspended the senior vice president and vice president for finance of the unit pending the completion of its review.

title: Bringing Peace to Liberia
description: The prospects for an end to Liberia's bloodletting brightened considerably yesterday with President Charles Taylor's resignation and flight to Nigeria. With rebel forces pounding his capital and international pressures mounting, Mr. Taylor finally honored his oft-broken promise to depart. For 14 years, his efforts to gain, then hold onto, power brought endless war to Liberia and unimaginable suffering to its civilians. Although Nigeria has granted him sanctuary, Mr. Taylor must eventually be brought to justice.

title: For Flight Attendants, Stress Comes With the Job
description: First the passenger cursed Mary Sutphen for refusing to serve him another whiskey on the flight from New York to Amsterdam. Then he kicked her in the knee. Then he decided to get her attention by urinating on her jump seat. On arrival, he was met by the local authorities at the aircraft door.

title: LEADER OF LIBERIA SURRENDERS POWER AND ENTERS EXILE
description: Charles G. Taylor, a star player in this country's 14 years of sporadic civil war, resigned from the presidency today and left his country for exile in Nigeria.

title: BBC Reporter Testifies in Inquiry of Dead Scientist
description: LONDON, Aug. 12  A journalist at the center of a brutal row over the credibility of Prime Minister Tony Blair's government today stood by his disputed report that suggested a senior Blair aide had exaggerated the threat from Saddam Hussein's weapons systems before the Iraq war.

title: YELLOW SEES HIGHER SAVINGS FROM ROADWAY ACQUISITION
description: The Yellow Corporation, the trucking company, said potential savings from its planned acquisition of its larger competitor, the Roadway Corporation, might reach about $198 million after five years. The companies, whose combined sales would be $6 billion, had forecast savings of $125 million after five years when the purchase was announced on July 8.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLAUSTEN, LUCIE GELDZAHLER
description: BLAUSTEN--Lucie Geldzahler. 9/8/13 - 2/27/03. Memorial service August 13, 11 AM, Temple Emanu-El, NYC. Deeply missed.

title: GILLETTE ACQUIRES 72% STAKE IN CHINESE BATTERY MAKER
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of batteries, acquired a 72 percent stake in the Fujian Nanping Nanfu Battery Company of China, where Gillette already sells the Duracell brand. Financial terms were not disclosed. The purchase will give Gillette the closely held Chinese company's state-of-the-art manufacturing unit and a distribution network of more than three million retail outlets in China, Gillette said. The company is adding products and stepping up advertising to compete with rivals including Energizer Holdings Inc. About a quarter of Gillette's annual revenue is from Duracell batteries.

title: AUTOMAKERS DROP SUITS ON AIR RULES
description: General Motors and DaimlerChrysler are dropping lawsuits against California over a landmark clean-air regulation that requires the production of millions of low-emission cars and trucks over the next decade and a half.

title: Carmarthen Journal; A Nagging Pain in Britain: How to Find a Dentist
description: Nelson Kernahan, a dentist in this small Welsh-speaking town, was in his car still rubbing the sleep out of his eyes, easing himself out of his two-week vacation, when he spotted a line so long he could not pinpoint the end.

title: A 'Satire' of a Classic Fails to Amuse The August House of Herms
description: Steven Stolman, the purveyor of resort clothes on which ferns or Ming vases are typically emblazoned, went to Europe several months ago and made an observation. Enviably maintained women, he noticed, particularly those in and around Milan, were eschewing leather handbags for ones constructed of an even more quotidian substance: rubber.

CORP., Armonk, N.Y., said it had won an order from Lego A/S, Billund, Denmark, the maker of toy building blocks, to provide server computers, data storage networks, software and related services. Terms were not disclosed. The deal is one of the largest replacements this year of Hewlett-Packard machines with I.B.M. hardware.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Board Rules For Detainees
description: Ruling against the government, the nation's immigration appeals board ruled for three Haitians who were detained after their boat ran aground last year near Miami. The board upheld a judge's decision to grant asylum to one Haitian, Gabriel Joseph, 53, who was released last week. The board granted a new asylum hearing for Mr. Joseph's nephews, David and Daniel, who were denied asylum a few months ago. Acting earlier this year in David Joseph's case, Attorney General John Ashcroft directed that asylum seekers could be detained on national security grounds while their cases were being considered, even if they had no links to terrorism. Rachel Swarns (NYT)

description: We hope that both the members of Congress and the Bush administration were paying attention last weekend when Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, a tough-on-crime Reagan appointee, decried harsh and inflexible sentencing policies. Justice Kennedy was speaking for legal experts from across the political spectrum when he said the current rules misspent America's criminal justice resources by locking up people for irrationally long amounts of time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Farmingville: Teenagers Indicted In Firebombing
description: Three teenagers accused of setting fire to a Mexican family's home in a racially-motivated crime have been indicted on charges of arson and reckless endangerment, Suffolk County prosecutors said yesterday. The three will be tried in Suffolk County Criminal Court. A fourth, age 15, was charged as a minor. A fifth teenager, Derek Brandafino, 17, will not be charged because he is cooperating with prosecutors. The three indicted teenagers -- Kyle Mahler, 17; Scott Soucek, 16; and William Lutz, 16 -- have pleaded not guilty in the July 5 firebombing of a Mexican family's home in Farmingville. The family, including two children, escaped. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Contrarian's Contrarian: Galileo's Science Polemics

description: Clues to the cause of disease are sometimes found in odd places, but rarely as odd as in the dried skin of a 50-year-old museum specimen of a flying fox from Guam.

description: GOLDMAN--Abraham L. Beloved husband of Miriam. Adored father of Dr. Rosalind Ramsey-Goldman (Dr. Eric Ramsey), and Dr. Myla LaiGoldman (Dr. Glenn Lai). Cherished grandfather of Breana, Ethan, and Caitlin. Dear brother of Sylvia Goldman. Graveside services today, 2 PM, at the New Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. For info. contact Wandy Memorial Chapel 631-427-7700

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, DAVID LEE
description: ROSEN--David Lee, February 16, 1938-August 10, 2003, the most beloved and devoted husband of Martha for 43 years, cherished father of Mark (and Ilene) and Janet (and Tim) and the proud, adoring grandfather to Pamela, Alison, Ruthanne, Caroline and Julia, passed away on Sunday, August 10, 2003 unexpectedly at his summer residence in Stockbridge, MA. Brother of the late Joel (and Joy) Rosen and Rhoda (and Paul) Redleaf, David will be sorely missed by his loving family, his friends and his patients whom he was so dedicated to helping. Magna Cum Laude graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Medical School, David began his career in the Public Health Service in St. Paul, Minnesota. Most of his work, specializing in general medicine and oncology, was in White Plains, NY. David touched so many hearts with his abounding energy, his never-ending optimism, and his zest for life. His greatest joys were in his relationships with the people he loved--a close family and a wealth of dear friends. He will be deeply missed by all who were fortunate enough to know and love him. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, August 13, at 10 AM at Woodlands Community Temple in Westchester County. The immediate family will be sitting Shiva at their home in Ardsley, New York Wednesday and Thursday from 3-5PM and 7-9PM. Donations in honor of David L. Rosen can be made to Woodlands Community Temple, White Plains Hospital, or The American Cancer Society.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Avnet Will Lay Off 500 Workers
description: Avnet, a computer-parts distributor, will lay off about 500 workers, or 5 percent of its employees, by the end of the year because of slumping sales. After the cuts, Avnet will employ about 9,500, the chief executive, Roy Vallee, said yesterday. The company has been cutting jobs and costs since it had seven consecutive quarterly losses, beginning in 2001. Avnet returned to a profit because its work force has been cut from 15,500 in 2000, Mr. Vallee said. Avnet shares rose 34 cents, to $13.20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENSTEIN, NEIL
description: ROSENSTEIN -- Neil. My friend, Neil, no my buddy, Neil, for over 50 years saw cancer sneak up on him like a cat burglar. It foreshortened his life so abundant in family relationships and business successes. Neil started off as my accountant and for my entire business life, always pitched in on the big judgement calls in my career. He built a mini conglomerate and later a gaming enterprise in Nevada. An aficionado of financial markets, the contemporary art world, travel and politics--you rated many more years, Kimosabe. I will be telling stories of our adventures in the years to come. You faced your aggressor head on when others would have curled up in a ball. I will always remember your last days, when your body had quit but your mind wouldn't stop its inexorable probing. Would the Democrats run Hillary? Where was the stock market headed? What was the last painting I bought, why and how much? With all my love, Martin T. Sosnoff

title: METLIFE DISMISSES 4 FOR ACCOUNTING PROBLEMS
description: MetLife, a leading life insurance company, has dismissed the president of one of its main sales units and three other executives after discovering that $31 million in operating expenses after taxes had been understated over five years at its New England Financial subsidiary in Boston. As a result, MetLife revised yesterday the second-quarter earnings report that it issued last week, adding $31 million in expenses to reduce operating earnings for the period to $620 million. David M. Monfried, a spokesman for MetLife, said the underreporting, which had the effect of making New England Financial's performance look better than it really was, was tiny in comparison to MetLife's $34 billion in revenue and $1.7 billion in operating income in 2002. He said MetLife was confident that ''this was an isolated incident.'' Andrew S. Kligerman, an analyst for UBS Securities, said, ''I don't think this is a major issue. You never know, but it appears that MetLife took the appropriate actions here, not only to report it to regulators but to admit it. This does not appear to be the tip of an iceberg.'' Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Fire Department Says It Erred In Describing Data on Closings
description: The New York City Fire Department acknowledged yesterday that it had incorrectly described data last week about the arrival times of emergency vehicles in neighborhoods where six engine companies were closed in May. A department spokesman, Francis X. Gribbon, called it an ''honest mistake.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Conviction Overturned In One Of Three Murders
description: A man convicted of killing a fellow drug dealer had the conviction overturned yesterday when the State Supreme Court ruled that he was denied his constitutional right to counsel. In the 2000 case, the man, Russell Peeler Jr., was also convicted of ordering the killings of an 8-year-old witness to the slaying of the drug-dealer and the witness's mother. The high court ordered a new trial for Mr. Peeler because his lawyer was barred from representing him. The testimony of the lawyer, prosecutors contended, was essential in the trial for the 1999 killings of Leroy Brown Jr. and his mother, Karen Clarke. But the high court disagreed and ruled that Mr. Peeler was entitled to a new trial and counsel of his choice. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 27 Feared Dead In Copter Crash
description: Three people died and 24 were missing in a helicopter crash in the Arabian Sea near Bombay. The Russian built MI-172 helicopter was ferrying employees of the state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Commission to an oil rig when it went down three minutes after takeoff. Rescue teams saved two people, but operations were hampered by high waves and darkness. Workers at the oil company have questioned the safety of its helicopters. Hari Kumar (NYT)

Although it did close in 2000, it held an abbreviated season in 2002-03 and is planning four productions for its 25th anniversary season, in 2003-04, in partnership with the Kennedy Center. title: KOCH NAMED LIKELY BUYER OF DUPONT UNIT
description: The DuPont Company, which last winter put its textile-related businesses into a stand-alone unit that it said it would sell or spin off, identified Koch Industries as the probable buyer yesterday. Analysts figured that Koch, a privately held company that makes ingredients used in synthetic fibers, would pay about $5 billion for DuPont Textiles and Interiors, which had $6.3 billion in sales last year and has such noted brands as Lycra, Teflon and Stainmaster. ''This is the last major step in the successful transformation of DuPont from an unwieldy $45 billion cyclical conglomerate to a less cyclical, higher-growth $20 billion innovative science company,'' said Frank J. Mitsch, a chemical-industry analyst with Bear, Stearns. Steven McCracken, the textile unit's president, said that his unit was profitable and brimming with new products, but conceded that the divestiture made sense. ''DuPont wants to concentrate on businesses that grow at multiples of the gross domestic product, and that's just not us,'' he said. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: AMERITRADE DISCUSSING SETTLEMENT OF CHARGES
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, the online trade broker, said the NASD has made a preliminary decision to discipline it for letting clients buy securities without having enough cash in their accounts. The broker said in a regulatory filing that it was discussing a possible settlement of the year-old charges that could involve censures, fines, suspension or other sanctions. Ameritrade previously announced the investigation but not the likely disciplinary action. The investigation involved cash-account clients of Ameritrade and its iClearing subsidiary who bought securities using proceeds of stock sales before the money was received. In its filing, Ameritrade said it had changed procedures to prohibit future violations.

description: Plants and animals that can quickly become environmental pests and damage or even ruin lakes, wetlands and other ecosystems will be the targets of a new task force announced yesterday by Gov. The task force will try to avoid environmental ''quick fixes,'' like overuse of herbicide, that can harm ecosystems. The 17-member group, called the New York State Invasive Species Task Force, will examine how such species spread and identify effective countermeasures. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORTON, THOMAS R.
description: HORTON--Thomas R., died on August 8 in DeLand, FL. Born in 1926 in Fort Pierce, FL, to Charles M. and Ruby S. Horton, he graduated from the Bolles School in Jacksonville and immediately joined the U.S. Army, where he served as a technical sergeant in Germany during World War II. He and his wife, Marilou Deeming Horton, both graduated from Stetson University, of which he was trustee emeritus. Horton earned his Ph.D. in mathematics at the University of Florida and held several honorary degrees. After teaching for two years at Bolles, Mr. Horton spent 28 years with the IBM Corporation where, among other things, he led the teams that located the Russian sputnik and guided the first U.S. man-in-space effort, later directing IBM's largest development activity, the worldwide $5 billion System/360. After retiring from IBM he became CEO of the American Management Association and later its President Emeritus. He was the author of many books, including The CEO Paradox: The Privilege and Accountability of Leadership (AMACOM, 1992). Horton served on the boards of seven corporations, two banks, five colleges and universities, and numerous nonprofit organizations. He was advisor to many organizations, including Marquis Who's Who in America and is listed in its centennial edition, Who's Who in 20th Century America. A member of the First Baptist Church of DeLand, Mr. Horton is survived by his wife Marilou Horton of DeLand and their three daughters, Susan Polos of Katonah, NY, Jean Horton of San Rafael, CA, and Marilyn Horton of Bronxville, NY, two grandsons, and two granddaughters. He is also survived by three nieces, two nephews and many friends. A private memorial service will be held. The family requests no flowers and that any donations be made to The Thomas R. Horton Scholarship Fund at Stetson University, Office of the President, 503 N. Woodland Boulevard, DeLand, FL 32720.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gang Member Is Sentenced
description: Dushon Foster, a member of the Bloods gang who was convicted of racketeering and gun charges in March, has been sentenced to 18 years in prison. Mr. Foster, 31, could have received a life sentence. His lawyer, Roger L. Stavis, said Mr. Foster was appealing the case. The case came to brief attention because former President Bill Clinton had been listed as a prospective juror but was not picked for trial.
