title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAMM, HELEN POWERS
description: LAMM--Helen Powers. 98, died August 8, 2003, at her home in Greenwich, CT. Born in Cleveland, OH, she was the daughter of William Powers and Jennie Moran Powers. She graduated from Ursuline College in Cleveland. Married James E. Bourne of Havre, MT, in 1929. They lived in Phillipsburg, NJ, for 14 years. Her husband died in 1941. She then married Harold J. Lamm of Riverside, CT, in 1943. She is survived by two sons, James Edelin Bourne of Greenwich, CT and William Powers Bourne of New York City; two stepdaughters, Alice Lamm Ryan of Bridgehampton, NY, and Irene Lamm Haskell of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; 14 grandchildren and 25 great - grandchildren. Funeral Mass August 13, 2003, at 11:30 a.m. at St. Michael's Church, 469 North St, in Greenwich, CT 06830. In lieu of flowers donations in memory of Helen P. Lamm for the support of CCD at St. Michael's Church.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Phone Acquisition
description: The Vodafone Group said it would buy Singlepoint, a British mobile phone service provider, for 405 million ($651 million). The acquisition will give Vodafone access to the 1.9 million customers of Singlepoint who have signed on through Phones 4 U stores in Britain. Singlepoint and the Phones 4 U chain are owned by John Caudwell, a British entrepreneur. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about experiments with automated pay toilets in New York City misidentified the organization that operates the more traditional public toilet at Bryant Park. It is the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation. (The 34th Street Partnership's president, Daniel A. Biederman, who discussed both locations, is also executive director of the Bryant Park group.)

title: Hevesi Out of Step With Fellow Democrats on Bond Issue
description: For days now, New York City Democrats have seized on the fight over a bond deal between Albany and City Hall as the latest attempt by Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, to hurt the financially struggling city.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON DISCLOSES INVESTIGATION OF DRUG UNIT
description: Johnson & Johnson said the United States attorney's office in New Jersey was investigating marketing practices at the company's Centocor unit, which makes Remicade, a rheumatoid arthritis drug. Prosecutors asked for information and documents on July 2, the company said in a regulatory filing. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., declined to comment on the investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANZER, JANE
description: TANZER--Jane. On August 11, 2003. Surrounded by her family in her special place, Lake Placid. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted sister to Irene. Loving mother of Debbie, Bobby and Steven, devoted grandmother to Allison, Sarah, Adam, Dean, Jamie and Matthew. Beloved mother-in-law to Tom, Brenda and Nancy. Cherished aunt to Nina and Lillian. A woman of amazing spirit and strength, a lover of life and family. She will be greatly missed by all of us. Services on Wednesday, 1:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Contract Ban May Cut WorldCom Profit
description: WorldCom, which had filed the largest United States bankruptcy, said yesterday that its earnings might be reduced by $250 million through 2005 by the federal government's plan to bar the company from new phone and data contracts. WorldCom, sent into bankruptcy by an $11 billion accounting fraud, was suspended last month from winning new federal orders for a period that could last three years. The federal government is WorldCom's biggest customer, generating about $1 billion in annual sales, or 6.3 percent of total revenue. The company is changing its name to MCI.

title: Westchester Keeps Bond Rating, Now Coupled With a Warning
description: Westchester got its usual Aaa top rating on its general-obligation debt from Moody's Investors Service yesterday, but it also got something it is not used to. When looking forward at the county's $504 million in outstanding general-obligation debt, the rating agency revised its outlook to negative from stable. Such shifts are taken seriously by financial markets.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Partnership Ends
description: United Microelectronics will buy back the stake held by Infineon Technologies in a Singapore chip-making venture for $100 million to $130 million, a United official said. With the deal, a manufacturing and technology partnership between the companies will end. United, which is based in Taiwan, and Infineon, based in Germany, agreed in late 2000 to build a $3.6 billion advanced-chip factory in Singapore through a joint venture.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: New Computer Virus
description: A computer virus is spreading across the Internet. The rogue program, known as Blaster, is aimed at high-speed Internet users and takes advantage of a vulnerability in most recent Microsoft operating systems, including Windows 2000, NT and XP. A patch that blocks the virus has been available for weeks, but millions of users still have not gone to the www.windowsupdate.com site to download it. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Lawyers Ease Code
description: The American Bar Association narrowly approved a change to its model code of conduct that would allow -- but not require -- lawyers to disclose clients' confidences to prevent or rectify crime or fraud causing financial injury. Business Day, Page C2.

title: A Caribbean Party With a Hip-Hop Beat
description: Reggaeton, Puerto Rico's fast-spreading rap and dance music, drew 12,000 dancing fans to Madison Square Garden on Saturday night for the first Reggaeton Summerfest: more than a dozen of the genre's top stars in a nonstop three-and-a-half-hour concert. The headliner and most forward-looking performer was Tego Caldern, but huge roars and singalongs also greeted Don Omar, Hector y Tito, Daddy Yankee, Rey Pirin and the lone female rapper on the bill, Ivy Queen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHARGEN, HARRY
description: SCHARGEN--Harry, 96. Beloved husband of the late Ceil, loving father of Arlene, Audrey, Norman, and Barry, grandfather of Gale, Peter, John, Jeff, Sari, Robert, Marci, David, Lisa, Richard and Lauren, great-grandfather of Jamie, Adam, Ryan, Alison, Melissa, Jessica, Michael, Jordan, Jayson, Justin, and Rachel.

title: Sports of The Times; While Coaches in Other Sports Have a Say, Fassel Has Real Clout
description: Shockey and Dixon have gotten earfuls recently.THEY must watch in wonder as the man with the whistle fixes his seagull eyes on a targeted player, allowing his neck veins to bulge like tree roots, all in full view.

title: Iraqis Name Team to Devise Way to Draft Constitution
description: In one of its first major decisions, Iraq's interim government appointed a 25-member team today to draw up a procedure to produce a new constitution. Ibrahim Jafari, president of the Iraqi Governing Council, said at a news conference that the committee would not write the constitution itself, but rather devise the mechanism by which it would be drafted.

title: Generics Shake Up a Drug Industry
description: After four years of chronic recession, few Argentine companies can boast a clean bill of financial health. But for the generic drug maker Fada Pharma, the country's economic crisis has been nothing short of a tonic.

title: New Activism by African Nations: Joining Forces to Referee Their Own Disputes
description: There was a time when Africa might have condemned what happened in Liberia today as inappropriate outside meddling.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: That 7-Year-Old Is Now Our Hamptons Stringer

title: String, and Knot, Theory of Inca Writing
description: Of all the major Bronze Age civilizations, only the Inca of South America appeared to lack a written language, an exception embarrassing to anthropologists who habitually include writing as a defining attribute of a vibrant, complex culture deserving to be ranked a civilization.

title: Beneath Faults Of Foster Care In New Jersey, A Grim Burden
description: In the thousands of pages of foster care records that a federal judge has forced New Jersey officials to make public in recent months, the state's failures to protect children are widespread, recurring and dramatic. The documents are a record of botched abuse investigations and the often utter lack of oversight of troubled households.

title: Bar Association's Guidelines On Client Secrets Are Eased
description: The American Bar Association approved changes to its model code of conduct today, allowing lawyers greater discretion to reveal clients' confidences.

title: Order Lacking on a Court: U.S. Appellate Judges in Cincinnati Spar in Public
description: Federal appeal courts, just one step below the Supreme Court, have enormous power and prestige. When the judges who sit on them disagree, they ordinarily address each other with elaborate courtesy.

title: Summer, Minus the Air-Conditioning (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Costs of a Healthy Smile
description: To the Editor:

title: To Fox, 'Fair and Balanced' Doesn't Describe Al Franken
description: In the dry corner of business law called trademark litigation, Fox News Network v. Franken is an unusually lively document. Along with mundane accusations of unfair competition, the lawsuit includes some especially derisive remarks about the defendant, Al Franken, the political satirist.

title: The New Yorker Who Changed the Diet of the South
description: Much of the knowledge about the relationship between diet and disease has been developed over the last century. In those decades, many health experts devoted their lives to conducting research on the new science called nutrition and the task of teaching others how to avoid deadly illnesses by altering their diets.

title: FIRST NIAGARA TO BUY TROY FINANCIAL FOR $356.6 MILLION
description: A bank holding company, the First Niagara Financial Group, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Troy Financial Corporation for about $356.6 million. The acquisition will allow First Niagara to expand eastward into New York's capital region.

title: The Carnegie-Philharmonic Ballet; You Can't Tell the Players Without a Program
description: As the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall hammer out the details of a merger, inevitable conflicts over artistic, managerial and financial control may only be intensified by the many strong personalities involved.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Color Them Old

title: Japan's Economy Grew 2.3% in Quarter
description: Japan's economy expanded at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in the second quarter, compared with the previous one, the beneficiary of growing corporate capital spending and rising exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLAMY, ROGER
description: BELLAMY--Roger. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater mourns the loss of Roger Bellamy, a passionate performer who joined his brother, Don, as a member of the Company from 1992-1997. We will miss his elegance, exuberant spirit and joyous laughter. A memorial service is planned for August 13 at 7:30 PM at the Ailey Studios.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Police Buy Riot Gear
description: The police placed an order for 13,000 rounds of tear gas ammunition after 500,000 people marched peacefully on July 1 to protest the government's plan for stringent internal security laws. The police have also ordered 9,400 riot-control helmets, and said the helmets were to replace gear dating as far back as 1967 while the unusually large order for gas ammunition was to replace rounds that had reached their expiration date. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Liar, Liar, Pants on Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Aims to Back Nigerians, Without Sending In More Marines
description: The decision to move three Navy warships carrying 2,300 marines within sight of the Liberian capital of Monrovia was intended to help calm the city and show support for West African peacekeepers without committing more American ground troops to the mission, senior Pentagon and military officials said today.

title: A Breast Cancer Reassurance
description: Many women of childbearing age who develop breast cancer worry that the stresses and hormonal changes of pregnancy will be dangerous. But a new study released yesterday in the journal Cancer found that becoming pregnant after a diagnosis does not raise the risk of dying.

title: From Hewlett, Digital Cameras, Bells and Whistles
description: Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, traveled 2,500 miles to do a pretty nifty imitation of Steven P. Jobs of Apple Computer, one of her Silicon Valley counterparts whose showmanship has made him even better known than Ms. Fiorina despite the fact that he runs a far smaller company.

title: Warnaco Posts Narrower 2nd-Quarter Loss
description: Warnaco Group Inc., the maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Olga bras, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed to $8.46 million after emerging from bankruptcy in February. The company is closing its two remaining plants in the United States and laying off about 430.

title: U.S. Arrests British Man Accused of Plotting to Sell Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  A British citizen was arrested today in Newark on charges that he attempted to sell a Russian-made, shoulder-fired missile to American undercover agents posing operatives of Al Qaeda, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Lawyer Pleads Guilty In Conspiracy Case
description: A Queens lawyer and lobbyist, Ronald F. Harnisch, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to conspiracy for his role in funneling public grant money to driver training schools, the United States attorney's office for the Southern District of New York said. Mr. Harnisch, 60, admitted that he had created a fictitious company to move grant money from the State Department of Labor to himself and to John Segreti, who owns driving schools. Mr. Harnisch also admitted that he knew that Mr. Segreti and a former state labor commissioner, James J. McGowan, had struck a deal giving Mr. McGowan a secret interest in Mr. Segreti's company. Mr. Segreti and Mr. McGowan have been indicted in a separate bribery case. Mr. Harnisch faces a maximum of five years in jail and a fine of at least $250,000. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Newfound Moons Tell Secrets of Solar System
description: Not too long ago, it was easy for an armchair astronomer to keep up to speed on the moons of the solar system. There was the Moon, of course, and the four Jovian satellites spotted by Galileo, those two around Mars, and some odd ones here and there -- that weird fractured cue ball orbiting Uranus, for instance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUDA, JOHN L.
description: DUDA--John L., 91, Founder of John's Boys Club in Brooklyn, died Saturday, August 9th in Waldoboro, Maine. A graveside service will be held 10 AM today at Village Cemetery in Friendship, ME. Contributions may be made to Friendship Ambulance Service, P.O. Box 40, Friendship, ME 04547. For information Hall Funeral Home, Waldoboro, Maine.

title: Fish in Other Forms
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a meeting of an Islamic militant group in Indonesia misidentified the headquarters city of the International Crisis Group, which focuses on crisis prevention. It is Brussels, not Geneva.

title: Tangled Text
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bringing India Into the 21st Century
description: Jagadish Shukla has set aside 10 percent of his income to helping his family's village.

title: Face Value at the Capitol
description: A look at the United States Capitol's art collection, which has a small number of images of women and members of minorities. An effort to change this is under way.

title: An Agriculture Boomlet on the Sound
description: Farmers in Riverhead, N.Y., on the southeastern edge of the Sound, are jostling with developers and conservationists to plan the future of their part of the Long Island Sound.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: HOT, HOTTER, HOTTEST Meteorologists reported Switzerland had its hottest day on record on Monday, a roasting 106.7 degrees recorded in the eastern canton of Grisons, as a heat wave continued to grip Europe. Firefighters in the canton gained control of a blaze around 6,500 feet up a mountain that has consumed more than 74 acres of forest, and officials lowered speed limits to 50 miles per hour from 75 m.p.h. on the main north-south route through the country in an effort to ease air pollution. Doctors in France have blamed the heat for at least 100 deaths, while outside France at least 45 heat-related deaths have been recorded, according to The Associated Press. Forest fires have also hit Italy, France, Greece, Spain, Portugal, Croatia and the Netherlands. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORWITZ, LILA (NEE BARBASH)
description: HORWITZ--Lila (nee Barbash) of West Orange, NJ on Tuesday, August 12, 2003. Beloved wife of Bernard, loving mother of Barbara, James and Nancy Horwitz, adored mother-in-law of Sandy Allison and Jerry Banks, dear sister of the late Ira Barbash, cherished grandmother of Benjamin, Allison and Evan. Funeral services Thursday, August 14, 2003 at 11:30 at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, New Jersey. Interment at B'Nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey. For additional information please call 1-800-437-5151

title: Schools Open More Inquiries On Misconduct By Workers
description: The special commissioner of investigation for the city school system opened more inquiries into misconduct cases in the last fiscal year than in the preceding one, leading to 50 percent more recommendations that employees be dismissed.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: U.S. OFFICER HELD AFTER BODY FOUND The police said they detained a United States Army officer after he threw a bag containing a woman's body from a bridge along the highway that connects Seoul with the international airport at Inchon. The police who retrieved the bag from the sea said it contained the remains of a "foreign woman in her 30's." The American, whose name has not been released, was assigned to Yongsan base in central Seoul. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Dressing Carrie, Right Down to Those Manolos
description: HERE we are this morning in the cavernous wardrobe room of HBO's ''Sex and the City'' at Silvercup Studios in Long Island City, Queens: walls of clothes grouped not by size but by character -- ''Samantha,'' ''Miranda,'' ''Charlotte,'' ''Carrie.'' A mournful yip of longing rumbles in the throat. Racks of -- sob -- exquisite, impossible shoes. Over there? Ah, the ecstasy of accessories!

title: Police Suspect Link Between Assaults On Two Young Girls
description: Detectives are investigating whether a man who dragged an 8-year-old girl into a Bronx stairwell last week and attacked her was the same man who raped a 9-year-old in a Manhattan building stairwell in July, officials said yesterday.

title: Use of Old Maps Is Faulted In Pennsylvania Mine Drama
description: The accident that flooded the Quecreek Mine in Pennsylvania last summer, trapping nine miners whose televised rescue riveted the nation, could have been avoided if the mining companies had realized they were using outdated maps, federal safety investigators said today.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Suit Backs Mentally Ill Inmates
description: A prisoner advocacy group filed a lawsuit in federal court accusing Cook County of denying services to mentally ill inmates. The group, Equip for Equality, says such inmates are categorically denied access to community release programs that could help them gain favor with judges before sentencing. The suit says the county should provide medication for newly released prisoners with mental problems rather than have them wait weeks to find a job and buy their own medication. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Yanks Enjoy Nice Game of Pitch and Catch
description: Jorge Posada spent 90 minutes before batting practice tonight escaping to the past. The clubhouse TV was showing a replay of the fifth game of the 1977 American League Championship Series, when the Yankees clinched the pennant at Royals Stadium. Posada was riveted, cheering and chirping at a game that took place when he was 6.

title: New Operas Remember The Agony Of Lovers Left Behind
description: The opera program at the Tanglewood Music Center, the training institute run by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at its summer home here, attracted international attention early on. In 1946 it presented the American premiere of Britten's ''Peter Grimes,'' a work commissioned by the conductor Serge Koussevitzky. That performance was conducted by a promising Koussevitzky protg, Leonard Bernstein, and opera continued to be a major component of the center for 20 years.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: METRO-NORTH STUDY RELEASED It could cost more than $11 million to upgrade rail stations along the Metro-North Railroad's New Haven line, according to a preliminary study released yesterday. Much of the expense would be for parking-area improvements, like paving lots and better lighting. Some platforms and stations also need to be upgraded, according to the Connecticut Rail Station Governance Study. The consultants will probably hold public meetings on the first phase of the study in September or October. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, DAVID
description: SCHWARTZ -- David. We mourn the loss of a wonderful man, Dvaid Schwartz, father to our dear friends, Susan and Ricky Etra. May he rest in peace. Helen and Harold Bernstein Jill and Jay Bernstein Ellen and Harvey Sanders

title: No Angst, No Modernism, No Mozart
description: The Juilliard Quartet's program for its Mostly Mozart recital in Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday was the chamber music equivalent of a summer beach read. No angst, no austere modernism, no need to challenge the ears. One could just sit back and take in the lapping sounds of Haydn, early Beethoven and Dvorak. It was a lazy afternoon of August decadence, without the sand.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about new restrictions on lawyers' ability to protect the confidences of clients referred incorrectly to a dispute involving the Federal Trade Commission. The American Bar Association and the New York State Bar Association have sued the commission, challenging whether a 1999 law on disclosing privacy policies to clients applied to lawyers. The commission did not file suit to force law firms to comply.

title: Raising a Glass to Himself: Jeremiah Tower Grills His Peers
description: ALL revolutions need a symbolic beginning. In France, it was the storming of the Bastille. In Russia, it was the capture of the Winter Palace.

title: Mets and Top Pick Close In on Deal
description: The Mets and Lastings Milledge, their first-round draft pick this year, have agreed in principle on a signing bonus exceeding $1.9 million, but the team wants to meet with Milledge and his family this week before completing the agreement, two people involved in the negotiations said last night.

title: Survivors, Not Heroes Or Villains, In Occupied France
description: MARIANNE IN CHAINS

title: The 'Zero Dropout' Miracle: Alas! Alack! A Texas Tall Tale
description: ROBERT KIMBALL, an assistant principal at Sharpstown High School, sat smack in the middle of the ''Texas miracle.'' His poor, mostly minority high school of 1,650 students had a freshman class of 1,000 that dwindled to fewer than 300 students by senior year. And yet -- and this is the miracle -- not one dropout to report!

title: Record Can't Obscure Yanks' Pitching Troubles
description: The Yankees have the best record in the American League. That is the good news. The bad news is that despite an enormous payroll, many in-season changes and the demands of their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, they are not perfect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUDGIN, CHESTER
description: LUDGIN--Chester. New York City Opera deeply mourns the passing of Chester Ludgin, leading baritone with our company from his debut in 1957 as Dr. Falke in ''Die Fledermaus'' until his 1991 engagement as Tony in ''The Most Happy Fella''. He sang all the leading Verdi and Puccini roles here, but is perhaps best remembered as a passionate advocate of new American opera, creating leading roles in NYCO world premieres including ''The Crucible'', ''The Golem'', and ''The Good Soldier Schweik''. Though his busy career also took him to the opera companies of San Francisco, Houston, Boston, Vienna, La Scala, and Rome, as well as numerous orchestras and musical theatre stages, we are proud that NYCO was always his artistic home. His unforgettable voice, powerful stage presence, unfailing collegiality, and infectious joie de vivre endeared him to all of us. We have lost a great artist and a great friend, and we will miss him. Contributions in his name can be made to Opera New York, 205 West End Avenue, NY, NY 10023, earmarked for the Chester Ludgin Memorial Fund. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: World Briefing | Europe: Hot, Hotter, Hottest
description: Meteorologists reported Switzerland had its hottest day on record on Monday, a roasting 106.7 degrees recorded in the eastern canton of Grisons, as a heat wave continued to grip Europe. Firefighters in the canton gained control of a blaze around 6,500 feet up a mountain that has consumed more than 74 acres of forest, and officials lowered speed limits to 50 miles per hour from 75 m.p.h. on the main north-south route through the country in an effort to ease air pollution. Doctors in France have blamed the heat for at least 100 deaths, while outside France at least 45 heat-related deaths have been recorded, according to The Associated Press. Forest fires have also hit Italy, France, Greece, Spain, Portugal, Croatia and the Netherlands. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Going Against Governor, Mayor Plans to Sell Bonds
description: Defying Gov. George E. Pataki, the Bloomberg administration announced plans yesterday to sell $556 million worth of bonds to refinance its remaining debt from the 1970's fiscal crisis and said it would go to court to force the state to repay the new bonds.

title: GILLETTE FILES PATENT SUIT OVER RAZOR DESIGN
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, filed a patent-infringement suit in Federal District Court in Boston yesterday against Energizer Holdings, which owns Schick-Wilkinson Sword. The suit charges that Schick's new four-bladed Quattro razor uses Gillette technology that enables each blade in a multiblade razor to go closer to the skin without increasing the risk of nicks. The technology is part of Gillette's Mach3 and Mach3 Turbo razors, three-blade razors that together generated sales of more than $2 billion last year. Gillette is seeking an injunction against Schick and triple the amount of profits it says it has lost. An Energizer spokeswoman, Jacqueline Burwitz, declined to comment, saying the company had not received the complaint. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: Clorox Profit Rises 2.8%
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that profit rose 2.8 percent in its most recent quarter as it reduced expenses and sold more Glad trash bags and Hidden Valley dressings.

title: Proposal for Kosovo Autonomy Offered Instead of Independence
description: The Serbian government rejected calls for the independence of the United Nations-administered province of Kosovo today and instead adopted a draft document proposing substantial autonomy, but within the federation of Serbia and Montenegro.

title: Atlanta Is Divided Over Renaming Airport for Former Mayor
description: From the grave now, Maynard H. Jackson is stirring things up once again in this city he led and loved.

title: It's Circus Time in California
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Extends Sales Pact With Target
description: Amazon, the world's biggest Internet retailer, yesterday extended its five-year Internet-sales agreement with the Target Corporation, a discount retailer, until August 2008. Under the agreement, Amazon provides order fulfillment and customer service for the Target store at Amazon.com, as well as for Target's online properties, the company said in a statement. Shares of Amazon rose 92 cents, to $39.85. Target shares rose 85 cents, to $40.

title: Shuffling Off a Mortal Coil, But Not Without a Fight
description: The theater was as hot and stuffy as the weather outdoors. The set had the heart-sinking look of impromptu attic-drama, a matter of crumpled strewn newspapers and a few homemade-looking props and costumes. But if theater is the creation of a believable, compelling discrete world, then the KyoRyuKan Theater Company of Kyoto delivered in ''Smoke,'' on Saturday afternoon at the Washington Square United Methodist Church in Greenwich Village, in the New York International Fringe Festival.

title: Windfall Publicity for Al Franken's Book
description: So, the satirist Al Franken writes a book making fun of the Fox News Network, mocking Bill O'Reilly and the gang, and its response is to sue him? The publisher of Mr. Franken's new book -- ''Lies, and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right'' -- must be having heart flutters. You can't buy this kind of publicity.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Profit
description: The mobile telephone company China Mobile (Hong Kong) posted a 13 percent increase in first-half profit, reflecting phone network purchases that catapulted it ahead of Vodafone as the world's biggest mobile-phone company by users. China Mobile had net income of 17.5 billion yuan ($2.1 billion), or 0.89 yuan a share, from a revised 15.5 billion yuan, or 0.83 yuan, a year earlier. Sales rose to 76.7 billion yuan from 55.1 billion yuan, after the company added customers and bought eight wireless networks in July 2002.

title: 2 ISRAELIS KILLED IN SUICIDE ATTACKS BY ARAB BOMBERS
description: Two Palestinian teenagers blew themselves up today in separate suicide bombings, killing two Israelis and inflicting another serious blow to the fragile American-led plan to forge peace between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: Gershwin in Gloom and Sunlight, With Boundless Energy
description: Michael Smuin loves to fill the stage with big bold steps. Energy abounded in the two works his Smuin Ballet, based in San Francisco, presented at the Joyce Theater on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, JULES
description: GILBERT--Jules. On August 12th, 2003, of Woodbury, L.I. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Andrew and Renee, Scott and Carolyn and Billy. Adored grandfather of Matthew, Monica, Mara and JaiSean. Services are today 2:30 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: T-Online Narrows Net Loss
description: Germany's largest Internet service provider, T-Online International, an arm of Deutsche Telekom, said yesterday that it had cut its net loss for the second quarter as it increased its share of subscribers to its broadband product, T-DSL. The company had a net loss of 16 million euros ($18 million), compared with a loss of 46 million euros a year earlier. The company, based in Darmstadt, Germany, said it might post a profit in 2004. T-Online reported 3.01 million broadband customers at the end of June, up from 2.19 million in the period a year earlier, with 1.82 million paying a flat rate. It raised its forecast for full-year earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, saying it would reach 250 million to 300 million euros ($282 million to $339 million) instead of the previous estimate of 180 million to 210 million euros ($203 million to $237 million). Victor Homola (NYT)

title: PENTHOUSE MAGAZINE'S PUBLISHER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: General Media Inc., the publisher of Penthouse Magazine, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday after competition from other outlets left the company unable to pay its creditors. The company missed payments on $41.8 million of bonds in April. General Media, a unit of Penthouse International, is 85 percent owned by Bob Guccione, who founded Penthouse in 1965. The company said it had from $50 to $100 million each in assets and debts in papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. General Media, which is based in New York, said it closed a $5 million bankruptcy credit line. Penthouse International did not file for bankruptcy protection.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Talks With Rebels To Resume
description: The government and Maoists rebels have agreed to a third round of peace talks on Sunday in the midwestern town of Nepalgunj, about 260 miles southwest of Katmandu, the government's negotiator, Kamal Thapa, said at a news conference. The government last month released three Maoist leaders in an effort to revive the negotiations, which have been stalled since May. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: Mom's a Pepper, Dad's a Tomato: Baby Is a Sweetie, If a Tad Unlovely
description: The toma bella is the aptly named offspring of a tomato and a bell pepper. This hybrid, which originated in Japan, is now being grown in Mexico, California and Michigan and is sold with the Frieda's Finest label in supermarkets, including Food Town in New Jersey. Bright red and squat like a tomato, it has a somewhat milder, sweeter flavor than a bell pepper. But inside it is just like a pepper, so once the seeds and core have been scooped out it's ideal to stuff and bake. It can also be baked empty until the flesh softens, about 20 minutes at 400 degrees, then filled and served cold. Or it can be used raw to hold dips and sauces. In markets, toma bellas, which will be available through September, are about $6 a pound; they are $65.55 for five pounds, including two-day shipping, from Frieda's, at www.friedas.com or (800) 241-1771.

title: Power and Peril
description: I tagged along the other day with Bernard Kerik, the dynamo former New York City police chief who is in Baghdad retraining the Iraqi cops. We sat in on a class where a U.S. police trainer and his translator were going through the basics of how to start an interrogation. The Iraqi policemen, who four months ago thought removing a suspect's fingernails was how to start an interrogation, dutifully took notes in their U.S.-provided notebooks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Detective Is Charged With Rape
description: A narcotics detective was arrested yesterday and charged with rape, sodomy and sexual abuse, the police said. The detective, Ray Williams, who has been on the force for 12 years and was assigned to Brooklyn North Narcotics, was accused of attacking his girlfriend, Officer John Sullivan said. The police did not say when or where the attack took place. The detective was suspended without pay for up to 30 days, Officer Sullivan said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A Memphis Aroma, Wafting Upstate
description: BARBECUE happens. One minute you're driving down Route 22 in Dutchess County, and suddenly, as fast as you can say western Tennessee, there's the scent of hickory smoke in the air and a truck on the side of the road with a picture of a smiling red pig holding an oversized fork.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Fatally Shoots Herself
description: An off-duty police officer apparently shot herself to death at the entrance of Isham Park in Inwood yesterday, a police official said. The officer, Jacqueline Kneafsey, 36, worked in the Central Park Precinct. Ms. Kneafsey shot herself in the head near West 213th Street and Broadway around 3:15 p.m. Ms. Kneafsey's service weapon was recovered at the scene, the official said. The officer had been on the force for nine years, Sgt. Kevin Hayes said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: TELECOM PROFIT The mobile telephone company China Mobile (Hong Kong) posted a 13 percent increase in first-half profit, reflecting phone network purchases that catapulted it ahead of Vodafone as the world's biggest mobile-phone company by users. China Mobile had net income of 17.5 billion yuan ($2.1 billion), or 0.89 yuan a share, from a revised 15.5 billion yuan, or 0.83 yuan, a year earlier. Sales rose to 76.7 billion yuan from 55.1 billion yuan, after the company added customers and bought eight wireless networks in July 2002.

title: Radio Ad Revenue On the Rise Again
description: Advertising revenue for radio networks and stations is picking up again after a sluggish May, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported.

title: Speak, O Muse, Of Strategic Synergy
description: The language of modern business is under attack yet again. Assailing such fashionable terms as ''high-performance culture,'' ''alignment,'' ''rightsizing'' and scores of other bits of biz-buzz, social critics are going so far as to attribute the recent spate of corporate scandals to a business culture in which opaque language represents the broad acceptance of hidden, often amoral activities.

title: Squid In a Pinch
description: INEVITABLY, there are a few days each summer when about all I can do is put together a salad. That's when I turn to the grill and convert a bunch of greens into something I consider a main course. (Restaurants that charge $15 for ''grilled chicken Caesar'' have also figured this out.)

title: Higher Gas Prices Give Williams a Lift
description: The Williams Companies, a pipeline owner that is selling assets to stay solvent, said yesterday that it had its first profit in five quarters as higher natural-gas prices increased the value of contracts left over from a failed energy-trading business.

title: Looking for Calm, Merrill Rehires Popular Executive
description: Merrill Lynch moved yesterday to repair the damage from its latest burst of management turmoil by rehiring Robert J. McCann as a vice chairman overseeing its brokerage and money-management operations.

title: Libya Set to Take Responsibility for Pan Am Blast, Envoys Say
description: Libya is expected to end 14 years of resistance this week and accept responsibility for the downing of Pan Am Flight 103, while paying $2.7 billion into a fund for the victims' families, two Security Council diplomats said today.

title: About New York; Remembering What a City Can't Forget
description: TODAY is not the anniversary. It is just one of the 364 other days of the year on which this city remembers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKEAN, ELIZABETH L.
description: McKEAN--Elizabeth L., 74, of New York on August 1, 2003 at New-York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. Though slight in stature, Bette McKean was large in courage, independence and heart. Born in Dixon City, PA. on June 10, 1929, Bette grew up during the Depression and World War II. After graduating from Hunter College, she moved into an apartment on East 37th Street with several girlfriends. Bette became a successful and well-paid executive assistant in Lennen and Knewell, but did not feel her worklife was satisfying. So, during Mayor John Lindsay's administration, when she read in the newspaper that the city needed teachers, she applied for a job and became a kindergarten teacher in the South Bronx for many years. Bette eventually moved to Tudor City, where she lived for more than three decades. There she met and in 1974, married John F. McKean, a retiree and leader in the tenants movement. During the 1980s, John and Bette led the successful fight to prevent Harry Helmsley from erecting high-rises on the Tudor City parks including one famous episode where they went out with bullhorns at 7 A.M. to rouse their neighbors and stop the bulldozers. After John died in 1993, Bette continued to live in their apartment overlooking the parks. Though her mobility was limited in recent years, she never lost her sharp eye for deceit nor her keen sense of humor. She is survived by her sister-in-law, Cornelia Bowe of Summit, NJ; her niece, great niece, and great-great niece Amy, Marisa and Giana Ross, all of NY; great niece Julia Ross of Suffern, NY; great nephew, Chris Harris of FL; stepdaughters Sandy McKean Ogden and Susan McKean Lewallen of CA, and step grandchildren Charles and David Ogden and Julie and Coe Gibbs, all of CA and WA. Memorial service will be at the Church of the Covenant, 310 East 42nd Street at 2 P.M. on Saturday, August 16th. Interment beside her husband at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, friends and relatives may send memorial contributions to their favorite charities.

title: Investigators Say Fraud Ring Staged Thousands of Crashes
description: Law-enforcement officials said today that they had cracked an insurance-fraud ring that staged thousands of car accidents and then employed its own network of doctors, acupuncture therapists and fake medical clinics to bilk an insurance company out of $48 million.

title: On the Road to Morocco, by Way of Disney World
description: MOROCCAN and Middle Eastern cuisines are often lumped together, a confusing categorization that does neither justice. In fact, Morocco is as distinct from the Middle East culinarily as it is geographically.

title: Bar Association in a Shift on Disclosure
description: The American Bar Association approved a change today to its model code of conduct to allow a lawyer advising a company to disclose client confidences to protect the company from harm caused by an employee's crime.

title: U.S. Overseer Defends Occupation of Iraq
description: After one of the worst weeks of the four-month-long occupation of Iraq, the top American administrator here, L. Paul Bremer III, offered an impassioned defense of it today while acknowledging that ''mistakes'' had led to the deaths of innocent civilians and that finding the money to repair Iraq's crumbling infrastructure was a ''substantial problem.''

description: ''I hope we'll have peace, but I don't believe in it anymore.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Reports 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: Applied Materials, the world's biggest maker of computer-chip production equipment, had a fiscal third-quarter loss because of costs of laying off workers and writing off inventory and a 25 percent drop in sales. The net loss in the quarter ended in July was $36.8 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with net income of $115.2 million, or 7 cents, in the same period a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales fell to $1.09 billion from $1.46 billion. Applied Materials is experiencing its worst two-year slump as Intel and other customers cut spending on factories to cope with their own revenue shortfalls. Businesses and consumers are buying fewer computers and other electronic devices, leaving chip makers with all the resources they need, investors said. ''Semiconductor guys are being a little more cautious in investing in plants and equipment,'' Jim Grossman, a chip analyst at Thrivent Financial, which oversees $57 billion and owns Applied Materials shares, said before the company reported its results. ''It really, really hurts when you have excess capacity.'' Applied Materials' shares fell 17 cents in extended trading after the announcement. The stock gained 11 cents, to $18.45, in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SERE, MELISSA D.
description: SERE--Melissa D., beloved wife of Patrick Etienne and devoted mother of Tatiana Leigh; daughter of the late LeRoy and Freda Gould; survived by many loving aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. A private service will be held.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Church-in-theGardens ''Richard W. Seeler Memorial Music Fund''.

title: SCHWAB TO LAY OFF SOME WORKERS AND CLOSE OFFICES
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount broker, said yesterday that it was laying off about 250 employees and closing about 20 branch offices in a restructuring that would cost $35 million to $50 million before taxes in the second half of the year. Schwab has already cut about 9,000 jobs and closed 23 branches since 2001 to save money as three years of declining markets cut revenue. The company, based in San Francisco, ''continues to evaluate its work force and facilities requirements in response to the market environment,'' it said in a regulatory filing.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Former Minister Arrested
description: In an acceleration of an official campaign against corruption, Mara Julia Alsogaray, a flamboyant former cabinet minister, has been detained on charges of misappropriating government funds. A close associate of the former president Carlos Sal Menem, Ms. Alsogaray supervised the widely criticized privatization of utility and steel companies early in Mr. Menem's administration but for the moment is formally accused only of improper conduct during her later tenure as environmental affairs minister. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rabbi Pleads Guilty To Indecency
description: A rabbi who is an ethics expert pleaded guilty yesterday to attempting to arrange a sexual encounter with an undercover police officer who he thought was a 13-year-old girl. The rabbi, Israel Kestenbaum, of Highland Park, N.J., pleaded guilty to the attempted endangerment of a child and the attempted dissemination of indecent material to minors. The rabbi was an ethics watchdog for a national association of pastors, and was honored as a chaplain of the year for his work with recovery workers at ground zero. He withdrew his not-guilty plea as part of a plea deal. He could have faced four years in prison, but is expected to be sentenced in October to five years' probation with treatment and registration as a sex offender. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Albert Field, the designated authenticator of the artwork of Salvador Dal, misstated the year of the World's Fair at which Mr. Field admired Dal's ''Dream of Venus'' installation. It was 1939, not 1930. The obituary also misstated the meaning of a mark made by Dal on photographs of fakes. ''Fals'' is the Catalan word for fake or false, not a truncation of the English word.

description: WHILE we were getting our first titillating fix of Kobe in a courtroom last Wednesday in the Colorado mountains, a sports-related trial far less sexy but reeking of its own rapacious character was winding down that very afternoon in Sacramento.

description: The Jets' president, Jay Cross, said the team's new policy of charging fans who want to be on the waiting list for season tickets $50 a year was a way for the team to find out which fans were serious about wanting tickets, not merely another way for the team to make money.

title: New Low-Cost Airline Giving Staff a Designer Look
description: Kate and Andy Spade, whose company is known for tiny striped pocketbooks, will now be dressing the flight attendants for Song, the new low-fare carrier of Delta Air Lines. Ms. Spade will design the outfits for women; Mr. Spade, designing for the Jack Spade brand, will create the men's.

description: A British arms dealer was arrested today in Newark on charges that he tried to sell a Russian-made surface-to-air missile to an American undercover agent posing as an operative for Al Qaeda, law enforcement officials said.

description: Struggling to gain a playoff spot, the Liberty staged one of its greatest comebacks, scoring a franchise-high 53 points in the second half tonight to beat the Connecticut Sun, 74-73.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: TV Concern Posts Loss
description: Britain's largest cable television company, NTL Inc., said yesterday that its net loss for the second quarter shrank to 159 million ($255 million) from 284.8 million ($456 million) a year ago, and that its founder and chief executive, Barclay Knapp, would step down on Friday. Revenue at NTL, which is run out of New York but serves Britain and Ireland, was 551 million in the second quarter, about even with a year ago. The company emerged from bankruptcy in January. Simon Duffy, above, hired as chief operating officer in February, will succeed Mr. Knapp, who founded the company 10 years ago and led it through a series of acquisitions during the telecommunications boom in the late 1990's. He will receive a $2.1 million one-time payment as he leaves NTL. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: A Man Who Can Tell Stone Crabs From Chaff
description: South Carolina's crabbers look for blue crabs and usually toss back the stone crabs that wander into their pots. But Jerry Gault, above, a crabber from Florida who now lives in Beaufort, S.C., knows the value of fresh stone crab claws. The season for claws from Florida, the dominant source, closes between April and October to protect the spawning crabs. In South Carolina, where the annual harvest is about 1 percent of the more than one million pounds that come from Florida, the fishery is open all year. And that's good for stone crab lovers, because it makes the delicacy available in summer, a season for cold seafood. Mr. Gault is now shipping his meaty stone crab claws north, where they are being sold at Citarella stores for $19.99 a pound (four to six).

title: DIRECT GENERAL RISES 12% AFTER INITIAL OFFERING
description: Helped by the renewed interest in new stock issues from profitable companies, Direct General Corporation, an insurer, rose in its first day of trading yesterday. Its stock closed at $25, up $4 from its offering price of $21. The initial offering of 6.9 million shares, led by Keefe Bruyette & Woods Inc., was priced at the high end of estimates. Direct General, based in Nashville, Tenn., specializes in insurance for consumers who might have trouble getting traditional coverage.

The New York-based troupe was performing on an alternative, hollow-based stage in Damrosch Park and the tinny clatter of the performers' feet detracted greatly from the whole, though the reverberations from the band shell to the west were interesting.

description: The police said they detained a United States Army officer after he threw a bag containing a woman's body from a bridge along the highway that connects Seoul with the international airport at Inchon. The police who retrieved the bag from the sea said it contained the remains of a ''foreign woman in her 30's.'' title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Posts Profit
description: A leading European insurer, AXA, reported an unexpected increase in operating earnings in the first half as higher premiums and cost-cutting increased profit in its property and casualty business. Operating profit, which excludes one-time items and acquisition-related costs, increased 6 percent from the period a year earlier to 1.09 billion euros ($1.24 billion), the chief executive, Henri de Castries, said at a news conference in Paris. Net income fell 75 percent to 209 million euros, hurt by losses on equity investments.

title: U.S. Troops in Liberia Not 'Peacekeepers,' Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  The Pentagon said today that about 200 more United States troops could soon go ashore in Liberia  but officials emphasized that their mission was not peacekeeping in the usual sense.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 — The State Department reiterated its warning this evening on travel to Saudi Arabia, urging Americans to put off non-essential trips to the kingdom because of its increased concerns about potential terrorist attacks.

description: Jeanette Brown is working hard to reduce the amount of nitrogen pollution into Long Island Sound. It is something, she said, that she fervently believes in, and as executive director of the Stamford Water Pollution Control Authority, which is building a $105 million system for nitrogen reduction, she likes to think that she's making a real difference.

title: Saving the Farm On Long Island Sound; Agriculture Boomlet Revives Debate
description: One of the constants of life on Long Island for the last half-century, so relentless as to seem almost a motor of history, has been the steady swallowing up the farmland. Suburban development, roaring east from New York City, changed the quality of the air and water, overwhelmed old patterns of transportation and transformed the connections between people and the land.

title: Tyson and King Delay Trial

description: Marvel Enterprises Inc., publisher of the ''Spider-Man'' and ''X-Men'' comics, said earnings for the second quarter rose almost fourfold as ''The Hulk'' and other new movies increased sales.

description: DECHTER--Helen. Beloved wife of the late Martin Dechter, loving mother of Phyllis and Steve Rafel and Warren Dechter, grandmother of Ellen, Tony and Kristina and great-grandmother of Jesse, Emily and Molly. Her incredible spirit and courage will be missed.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Cameras Bring Marijuana Arrest
description: A West Side man smoking marijuana in his car became the first person to be arrested as a result of newly installed surveillance cameras set up last month to deter violent crime in Chicago's most troubled neighborhoods. The cameras, contained in bulletproof encasements, are mounted on telephone poles and are meant to be highly visible. Marcus Jackson, 22, was charged with possession of cannabis and Ecstasy, a felony. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: CABLE--Fran. August 2, 1931August 11, 2003. An outstanding woman we all respected and loved. We will miss her. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEIPMAN, DORIS J.
description: LEIPMAN--Doris J. of Largo, FL, beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend, died of breast cancer on August 9, 2003 at the Fountains at Rivervue in Tuckahoe, NY. She was 80 years old. She is survived by her son, Ken Leipman of Marietta, GA; her daughter, Debra LeipmanYale of Armonk, NY; and her beloved six grandchildren. description: The American military's inquiry into the shelling that killed two foreign journalists at a Baghdad hotel in April has found that troops were justified in firing at what they had reason to believe was an enemy position, according to an official summary.

title: Inaction on Dutch Aid Worker Missing in Caucasus Criticized
description: Doctors Without Borders accused Russian and Dutch officials today of dragging out their investigation into the disappearance of a Dutch aid worker seized a year ago in a region bordering Chechnya. The stalled inquiry is hampering further assistance to war refugees, officials of the group said at a rally here.

title: Adu, 14-Year-Old Striker, Leads U.S. Against the World
description: Less than a year ago, Freddy Adu was not an American citizen. Tomorrow, the 14-year-old Adu, who was born in Ghana but now lives in Bethesda, Md., will lead the United States team in the FIFA under-17 world championships in Lahti, Finland.

title: A Day at the Office: From Photography to Fishing
description: Brad Pitt can be such a nice guy. The finest moment in last week's premiere episode of ''Take This Job'' is when Mr. Pitt, pursued by a young photographer who has walked out into traffic to get a good angle, warns him: ''Watch your back! Watch your back!'' He effectively saves the man from being run over so he can live to enjoy the $25,000 he gets for his shots of Mr. Pitt and his wife, Jennifer Aniston, leaving a sushi restaurant that night.

description: In much the same way as the Russian invasion of Afghanistan stirred an earlier generation of young Muslims determined to fight the infidel, the American presence in Iraq is prompting a rising tide of Muslim militants to slip into the country to fight the foreign occupier, Iraqi officials and others say.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: DETECTIVE IS CHARGED WITH RAPE A narcotics detective was arrested yesterday and charged with rape, sodomy and sexual abuse, the police said. The detective, Ray Williams, who has been on the force for 12 years and was assigned to Brooklyn North Narcotics, was accused of attacking his girlfriend, Officer John Sullivan said. The police did not say when or where the attack took place. The detective was suspended without pay for up to 30 days, Officer Sullivan said.

title: Panel Urges Shift of Focus In Preparing For Smallpox
description: A panel of scientists said today that the focus of the nation's smallpox preparedness program should move away from vaccinations and toward measures to improve coordination and quicken response time to any public health threat.

title: Face Value at the Capitol; Senator Wants to 'Promote Some Diversity' in Congressional Artwork
description: There is not much to distinguish the painting of Senator Blanche Kelso Bruce from the countless other official portraits that line the corridors of the United States Capitol. The senator, who represented Mississippi in the late 1800's, is dressed in a dark, three-piece suit, a watch chain of gold stretched across his ample belly. His face bears a look of calm seriousness, befitting a man of power.

description: STIGUM--Marcia. August 7, 2003. Beloved mother of Tove and Erik and loving wife of the late Allan Fox. A contribution in her honor can be made to the Pine Ridge School, 9505 Williston Rd, Williston, VT. 05495.

description: ''I need to get my raft back,'' Joel Phagoo said to the police officer at Kennedy International Airport yesterday evening.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Elizabethtown: 4 Camp Counselors Drown
description: Four camp counselors drowned yesterday afternoon while on their day off from a camp in Minerva, the state police said. The Associated Press reported that all four were men, ages 18 and 19, and at least three were from Hewlett, on Long Island. The accident occurred at Split Rock Falls near Elizabethtown in the Adirondacks, when one fell into the water and the other three tried to rescue him, the state police said. Only one body was recovered last night, and the search was suspended until this morning. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about salad greens misstated the name of the New Jersey town in which Yuno's Farm, a producer of immature whole lettuce heads, is located. It is Bordentown, not Bordertown.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Brewer Selling Pubs Unit
description: The country's biggest brewer, Foster's Group, will sell at least 1.4 billion Australian dollars ($920 million) in shares in its pub business, stoking speculation the company will use the money to expand its wine division. Foster's, which makes Australia's top-selling Victoria Bitter, is buying wine businesses to improve earnings as beer sales slow. Income from the pubs unit fell after the Victorian government banned smoking in gaming rooms and New South Wales restricted opening hours for slot machines. Foster's bought Beringer Wine Estates of Napa Valley, Calif., in 2000. The company said it might cut debt or return money to shareholders if it did not find ''appropriate value creating investment opportunities.''

title: ENTERGY TO TRIM WORK FORCE WITH RETIREMENT OFFER
description: The Entergy Corporation, which owns utility companies, said yesterday that it would try to cut 1,000 jobs, or more than 6 percent of its work force, by offering voluntary retirement packages to employees. The majority of job cuts will come in Entergy's nuclear-power operations. The company, based in New Orleans, expects fewer than 1,000 employees to accept the packages, a spokesman said. Entergy said last month that it was seeking increases in worker productivity that would reduce costs by $145 million through 2007.

title: Second-Quarter Losses at Power Companies
description: The power producers Reliant Resources, the CMS Energy Corporation and Aquila had second-quarter losses as the companies left certain markets, sold less electricity because of milder weather and faced higher fuel costs.

title: BBC Reporter's Casts Colleague's Iraq Report in New Light
description: LONDON, Aug. 13  On the third day of an inquiry into the death of a leading British weapons experts, a BBC journalist raised new doubts today about a colleague's report that the Blair government had deliberately "sexed up" a dossier on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction to build support for going to war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, LOUISE
description: STRAUSS--Louise. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Michael S. Strauss, chairman of the New York board, and Judy Levi on the loss of their beloved mother. Mrs. Strauss was a dignified and elegant woman whose life was dedicated to Jewish tradition and ethics, and who personified the values of chesed and devotion to Klal Yisrael. She served as a role model par excellence to members of her family and to others who had the privilege of knowing her. May Michael, Judy, and their entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Div Paul Glasser, Nat'l Dir Morrie Libman, Regional Dir

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, CAL (CALVIN JOSEPH)
description: BERNSTEIN -- Cal (Calvin Joseph). Cal Bernstein, loving husband of 53-years to Roz, caring father to Josh (and Yolanda Ramirez) and Jonine (and Randy Mastro), proud grandfather to Arianna Mastro, adoring brother to Claire Koslow, fond uncle to his nieces and nephews, and loyal friend to many, died in Los Angeles of pancreatic cancer on August 10. He would have been 78 years old on August 30. Cal was an award-winning photojournalist who chronicled the civil rights movement among other stories in the 50's and 60's, and later produced and directed television commercials at his company, Dove Films. He was passionate and appreciative about the best that life has to offer, from food (he wrote a restaurant guide) to Italian design to politics to his granddaughter's smile. His two dogs, Jazz and Evie, were show dogs, but he loved them as pets. In recent years, he offered and photographed stunning CD ROM guides to wine and race horses. He was a great artist, taking photographs and making beautiful prints until his last days. He was utterly devoted to his friends and family. With a mail order license, he performed moving wedding ceremonies, not for profit but for friendship. A generous being, overflowing with life and understanding. He was easy to love. Family can be contacted at 323-461-3737

description: The Burger King Corporation said yesterday that the Coca-Cola Company had agreed to pay up to $21.1 million for rigging a marketing test at its restaurants.

description: Everyone agrees that this recently rural township, its sleepy streets fringed by old farms, is a fine place to rear children. And in just a few years, hundreds of children have arrived, each like an invoice addressed to taxpayers.

title: Anything You Want, as Long as It's Meat
description: HACIENDA DE ARGENTINA gets the atmospherics right. The small dining room, enveloped in a thick layer of darkness, is crowded with heavy Old World oak furniture, burnished candelabra, gilt mirrors and, inexplicably, a full suit of armor back near the kitchen. The oversize menus are wrapped in cowhide, and what the wine list lacks in depth it makes up for in weight. It took all my feeble strength to hold it upright long enough to select a bottle. The prevailing style in restaurant design is modern and minimal. Hacienda de Argentina is archaic and maximal. Eating there is like sitting down to dinner with Don Diego in an episode of ''Zorro.''

title: Justice Roy Moore's Lawless Battle
description: Chief Justice Roy Moore of Alabama has built his career on demagoguing about the Ten Commandments. As an obscure state court judge, he posted the commandments on a wall behind his bench, and used the controversy over the display to get himself elected to Alabama's highest judicial post. Once in office he installed a two-and-a-half-ton Ten Commandments monument in the rotunda of the main judicial building in Montgomery. When two federal courts ordered him to remove it, he resisted, claiming that he is an independent constitutional officer. Now that he is facing a court deadline of Aug. 20, he is milking the drama for all it's worth. He says he will announce tomorrow whether he will comply.

title: How Ben-Gurion Did It: Is Everyone Listening?
description: The official offered his prisoners a deal: he might let them go if they agreed to halt their ''terrorist activities'' and to use only political means to pursue their dream of statehood.

title: Uneasy Calm in Basra as British Stand Ready for New Unrest
description: BASRA, Iraq, Aug. 13  British troops remained on edge today in the wake of the riots that shook this city on Saturday and Sunday, and some police and military and civil officials say there could be more unrest if the supply of fuel and electricity does not improve quickly.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Posts $62 Million In Costs
description: AT&T Wireless Services Inc., the nation's third-largest mobile-telephone company, will have $62 million in pretax costs this quarter because the value of its stake in a Taiwanese carrier has declined. A charge for early debt retirement would reduce third-quarter profit by another $39 million, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing late Monday. AT&T Wireless is writing down its investment in Far EasTone Telecommunications, Taiwan's No. 3 mobile-phone operator. Far EasTone's shares have plunged about 40 percent from a 2001 high amid competition. AT&T Wireless had a 23 percent stake in the company, based in Taipei, at the end of last year, according to regulatory filings. AT&T Wireless is expected to earn about 6 cents a share this quarter, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Based on current shares outstanding, that equates to $163 million. In the third quarter of last year, AT&T Wireless had a loss of $2.04 billion, or 76 cents, in part because it wrote down the value of other assets. Shares of AT&T Wireless rose 20 cents to $8.03.

title: Bush Choice to Head E.P.A. Asks Clinton Administrator for Reference
description: By 6 o'clock this morning, Utah time, Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, President Bush's choice for administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, had called Carol M. Browner, the administrator under President Bill Clinton. He asked if he could use her as a reference as he prepared for his confirmation hearings, which are bound to be rife with Democratic dissent.

title: Off the Menu
description: JOHN VILLA, left, has turned Pico, his former Portuguese restaurant at 349 Greenwich Street (Jay Street), into DOMINIC RESTAURANT/SOCIAL CLUB, serving Italian-American fare. The food will be discounted 20 percent through Labor Day, perhaps because Mr. Villa is not at the stove -- he's on vacation in Italy until next week.

description: Randgold Resources Ltd., the mining company in the Isle of Jersey that made a surprise bid last week for a larger competitor, reported strong second-quarter results today and indicated that it would appeal to an influential shareholder to complete a deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, WALTER FORBES
description: SLOAN--Walter Forbes, age 91, died on August 5, 2003 of cancer. He retired as General Tax Counsel of Caltex in 1977. Beloved husband of Margaret O'Brien Sloan for 64 years, loving father of Tina Sloan McPherson, John Sloan, and the late Margo Sloan Pearson. He leaves six grandchildren. Born in Niles, Michigan, he was a graduate of the University of Illinois, and of Harvard Law and Business Schools. He served in World War II as a Lieutenant in the US Naval Reserve in the Mediterranean. He lived for 65 years in Bronxville, NY and was a member of the Bronxville Field Club and The Siwanoy Country Club where he served on the Board of Governors and as Secretary of the Board. A Memorial service will be held on Monday, August 18 at 11:00 AM in the Chapel at The Osborne, 101 Theall Road, Rye, NY.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: APPLIED MATERIALS REPORTS 3RD-QUARTER LOSS Applied Materials, the world's biggest maker of computer-chip production equipment, had a fiscal third-quarter loss because of costs of laying off workers and writing off inventory and a 25 percent drop in sales. The net loss in the quarter ended in July was $36.8 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with net income of $115.2 million, or 7 cents, in the same period a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales fell to $1.09 billion from $1.46 billion. Applied Materials is experiencing its worst two-year slump as Intel and other customers cut spending on factories to cope with their own revenue shortfalls. Businesses and consumers are buying fewer computers and other electronic devices, leaving chip makers with all the resources they need, investors said. "Semiconductor guys are being a little more cautious in investing in plants and equipment," Jim Grossman, a chip analyst at Thrivent Financial, which oversees $57 billion and owns Applied Materials shares, said before the company reported its results. "It really, really hurts when you have excess capacity." Applied Materials' shares fell 17 cents in extended trading after the announcement. The stock gained 11 cents, to $18.45, in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAVAY, VICTOR HERBERT
description: LAVAY--Victor Herbert, CEO and co-founder of Vending Times, died August 11th, 2003 after a brief illness. He was 78. Mr. Lavay served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. After attending college under the GI Bill, he pursued a career in advertising, leading him to the trade journalism field. In 1962, he became part owner of a corporation established to publish Vending Times which first appeared in that year. In the early 1990s, he acquired full interest. Mr. Lavay is survived by his wife of 59 years, Fay, and five daughters. Services today, 2 PM, at Gutterman's Chapel, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: In Spite of All Those Sidewalks, the City Finds Itself Flabby
description: It comes as no great shock that far too many people in New York City weigh far too much, but a city report released yesterday offered some eye-catching details about the dimensions, causes and particulars of the problem.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Medical Examiner Resigns
description: A medical examiner, suspended in February after an admitted error in an autopsy led to the murder indictment of an innocent man, said he planned to retire as coroner in both Cape May and Cumberland Counties, where he worked. In a letter to Cape May officials on Monday, the doctor, Elliot Gross, said he planned to continue to fight charges of incompetence. Dr. Gross was ordered to take a series of re-examination tests, one of which he failed. Last month, the acting state medical examiner, John Krolikowski, described Dr. Gross's work in the remedial tests as shoddy. Dr. Gross, 69, has been under fire since December, when he concluded that Ellen Andros of Pleasantville, died of suffocation. Two forensic pathologists who reviewed Dr. Gross's work concluded that she died of a rare cardiac condition. Her husband, James Andros, a police officer, was wrongly indicted for murder. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Millions Left In 9/11 Fund
description: A fund established for families of Sept. 11 victims has $7 million in undistributed donations, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. Those who are eligible have until Sept. 30 to submit applications. The remaining money in the New York State World Trade Center Relief Fund is being held for 400 designated families whose members are eligible but have not yet applied for the aid. The fund has distributed slightly more than $63 million to 2,500 families. Notices were mailed yesterday to the 400 families. Those eligible include victims' spouses, domestic partners and fiances and fiancs, along with children 21 and younger. Parents are eligible if there is no spouse, domestic partner, fiance or child. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: Sanitation Department officials said yesterday that they would spend more money to clean up city streets, following reports of garbage piling up and street corner wastebaskets going unemptied.
