description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Dendrite Will Cut 300 Jobs and Close 10 Plants
description: Dendrite International, whose software is used by drug makers, said yesterday that it would close 10 plants and eliminate about 300 jobs as a result of its acquisition in May of Synavant. Dendrite said it expected the cuts to save about $30 million a year. Synavant provides customer-care management services for pharmaceutical companies. Dendrite said its second-quarter net income rose 29 percent to $5.92 million, or 14 cents a share, from $4.60 million, or 11 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed to $69.5 million from $57.6 million a year ago. The company expects to earn 26 cents to 27 cents a share on revenue of $190 million to $195 million in the second half of 2003, Dendrite's chief financial officer, Kathleen Donovan, said in a statement. A company spokesman, Erik Kopp, did not immediately return a telephone message. Shares of Dendrite rose as high as $14.16 in after-hours trading on the Nasdaq Stock Market, after gaining 16 cents, to $13.30 in regular trading.

title: Far From Liberia
description: With civil war raging, the government of Liberia had more pressing issues last month than sending the national soccer team to an international match in Ghana.

title: They Finally Figured Out How to Bottle Summer
description: Pineapple, mango, raspberry and peach are among the flavors of syrups in tall glass bottles beckoning shoppers this summer. Dilute them with sparkling water, lemonade or iced tea for a quick refresher; add them to still or sparkling white wine for an aperitif; mix them with vodka at cocktail time; or pour them, chilled, over ice cream or sorbet.

title: Cheer and Challenge, Far From Home
description: The five sophomores had plenty of advice for the new students today at a special orientation here at Roger Williams University: When you feel overwhelmed by the strange foods in the cafeteria, go for the French fries. And when you miss your family so much you can't bear it, read the Koran, have a good cry and remember why you came.

title: Japan Apologizes to China for Injuries From Remnants of War
description: Japan apologized to China on Tuesday after acknowledging that chemical weapons left in northeastern China by Japanese troops at the end of World War II caused 36 people to get sick early this month.

title: EMERSON SHARES PLUNGE ON WARNING ABOUT SALES
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation, a designer and seller of home electronics, said sales in the quarter ending in September would be less than in the same period a year ago because of slower consumer spending. The shares fell 49 percent. Emerson has too much inventory for the second quarter, which ends Sept. 30, because sales in Asia fell in the previous period, and fewer Kmart stores were selling its microwave ovens, Laura Boorn, a spokeswoman for the company, said. Revenue in the second quarter of last year was $115.6 million. Stock in Emerson, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., fell $3.24, to $3.35.

title: U.S. Envoy in Indonesia Warns Americans of Future Attacks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 13  The American ambassador here called a meeting of American residents this morning and warned them that future terrorist attacks, like the one at the J. W. Marriott Hotel last week, were likely.

title: It's Bonds's Show, but Mets' Victory
description: Barry Bonds was seated on a leather sofa in the cramped visitors' clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon, speaking to two visitors, when a horde of reporters and security personnel flooded the room following one man. Former President Bill Clinton shook hands with Giants catcher Benito Santiago, was told that Bonds was ready to speak, and slowly approached Bonds, who rose from the couch and shook hands.

title: Asian Journey; Looking Up an Old Love On the Streets of Vietnam
description: SHE used to walk past my little villa in Saigon, not far from the American embassy, her conical straw hat on the back of her head, white pajamas flapping as she loped down the street, soup makings dangling from the wooden yoke across her frail shoulders. She came early every morning, repeating the monosyllable with an inimitable inflection.

title: PeopleSoft Expands Its Suit Against Oracle
description: PeopleSoft Inc., which is fighting a hostile takeover offer from Oracle, has added accusations to its lawsuit, asserting that Oracle tried to disrupt its customer relationships and engaged in other unfair practices.

title: Bear Did Not Try to Eat A Hiker, an Official Says
description: New Jersey's environmental commissioner today disputed his department's report on Monday that a black bear had tried to eat a teenage hiker whom the animal knocked down on Sunday afternoon in Wawayanda State Park here.

title: A Singer Dares the Fans To Take Her Seriously
description: Liz Phair sings almost everything with a sneer and a smile, usually at the same time. It can be hard to tell if she's flirting with her listeners or laughing at them. Her look matches her songs, which find common ground between obsession and cynicism. She dares you to take her seriously, then dares you not to.

title: Report Says Facility Beheaded Williams
description: After Ted Williams's death last year, his head was surgically removed from his body at a cryonics facility in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sports Illustrated reported on its Web site yesterday. The head and body are preserved separately in liquid nitrogen.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Leucadia To Acquire Remainder Of Wiltel
description: The Leucadia National Corporation yesterday agreed to buy the remaining 52.6 percent of WilTel Communications, the fiber-optic network operator that emerged from bankruptcy protection last year, for more than $420 million in stock. Leucadia, whose businesses include insurance, mining and telecommunications, will pay WilTel shareholders 0.4242 of a Leucadia share for each share held, the company said. Leucadia stock climbed 34 cents to $37.90, and WilTel shares rose 1 cent to $14.07 in regular trading yesterday. The agreement will leave former WilTel shareholders owning 15.8 percent of Leucadia, the company said. WilTel sought bankruptcy protection in April 2002, listing $7.2 billion in debt amid a surfeit of fiber-optic capacity. Leucadia agreed in July to invest $150 million in cash and buy $180 million of debt held by WilTel's former parent, the Williams Companies. Leucadia said last week it made two proposals to acquire the rest of WilTel. In July, the company withdrew a $365.1 million offer after WilTel's board decided to seek other offers.

title: Renovation of Pabst Brewery Aims to Revitalize Downtown Milwaukee
description: Two developers have teamed up to purchase and renovate the sprawling historic but long-vacant Pabst Brewery complex here into an entertainment and residential complex.

title: ASTRAZENECA CHOLESTEROL DRUG WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: AstraZeneca won Food and Drug Administration approval of its Crestor cholesterol-lowering drug, increasing competition for the world's top-selling medicine, Lipitor from Pfizer. AstraZeneca is preparing a marketing campaign for Crestor that Datamonitor, a research company, estimates will cost about $1 billion. With approval in the United States, Crestor's annual sales might surpass $3 billion by 2007, analysts said.

title: Europe Decides Air-Conditioning Is Not So Evil
description: About five years ago, Jacques Cazaban decided he couldn't take the heat. Yet he wanted to stay in the kitchen all the same.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Commuter Rail Hub May Help Energize the Economy
description: After the Secaucus transfer station of New Jersey Transit's commuter rail system goes into full operation by the end of the year, it could pump almost $1 billion into the state's economy, according to a study of the effects of transit improvements by a transportation research center at the City College of New York.

title: Chocolate Curry? Don't Turn Up Your Nose Just Yet
description: Katrina Markoff's chocolates are often offered at the end of dinner in top restaurants in Chicago, where her company, Vosges Haut-Chocolat, has two shops. Now Ms. Markoff, a Paris-trained confectioner, has opened a shop at 132 Spring Street (Wooster Street) in SoHo that is aglitter with crystal chandeliers. It also has a white marble ''sensory tasting'' table, right, where her signature seasonings like curry, pollen, chilies and kumquat can be sampled for $12 with espresso or hot chocolate. Her specialty is truffles made in these intriguing flavors, and others like olive oil and cheese. Traditionalists will also find caramel, nut, mint and coffee flavorings. The truffles are $65 a pound (32 truffles) or in boxes of 9 for $21 and 16 for $35.

title: Moscow Machinations
description: Russian politics is almost as incomprehensible to Russians as it is to outsiders. So it is not surprising that nobody knows for sure whether President Vladimir Putin is personally behind the sudden crackdown on the giant oil company Yukos, or really why it is happening. What is clear is that the Kremlin's strong-arm tactics have little to do with battling economic crime and a lot to do with power and the coming elections in Russia. They are also of little help to Russia's tenuous democracy.

title: McDonald's Plans Olympic Campaign
description: The McDonald's Corporation will undertake its first worldwide campaign to promote its global Olympic sponsorship, the company said yesterday.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

description: To the Editor:

description: Is the Internet over?

title: New Casino Helps Produce Revenue Gain At the Shore
description: The opening of the first new casino in Atlantic City in 13 years, the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa, helped increase the city's gambling revenues in July by 4.4 percent from a year ago, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLECH, MEYER
description: BLECH--Meyer, 77, served for 25 years as a Jewish chaplain at the Brooklyn and Manhattan Veteran's Hospital. During the Korean War, Rabbi Blech served as a chaplain to the troops. During the 1980s, he was a founder of several biotechnology companies working on products for cancer and AIDS. Beloved husband of Esther, father of Isaac, David, Mashi and Rina.

title: HALLIBURTON MAY NEED TO RENEGOTIATE ASBESTOS DEAL
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that its proposed settlement of asbestos-related lawsuits might need to be renegotiated because of a rising number of cases. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said that there could be more claims than it expected and that the $2.78 billion in cash it agreed to set aside to pay them might not be sufficient. In that case, the company, based in Houston, said it would need to decide whether to pay less for each claim or increase the amount in its fund. If Halliburton seeks lower payments, plaintiffs' lawyers ''may not proceed with the settlement or may attempt to renegotiate the settlement amount,'' it said in the filing. ''Conversely, an increase in the amount of cash required may make completing the proposed settlement more difficult.'' Under the proposed settlement, announced in December, Halliburton agreed to pay a total of $4 billion in cash and stock to resolve 300,000 cases.

title: It's Circus Time in California
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASS, GERTRUDE BUCKWALD
description: GLASS--Gertrude Buckwald. Died August 11, 2003 at age 84. Survived by a daughter Susan Glass of Rye Brook, a brother Sidney Buckwald of NYC and Sunrise, FL., and a nephew Steven Buckwald. Donations in memory of Gertrude to United Cerebral Palsy Assn., 1186 King Street, Rye Brook, NY 10573. For information Zion Memorial Chapel call 914-381-1809.

title: The Air After 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: A Get-Along Voice at the E.P.A.
description: Gov. Michael Leavitt's nomination to succeed Christie Whitman as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency means that the country will be not be treated to a rerun of the political soap operas that marked the Whitman years. That is bad news. Mrs. Whitman almost always lost her internal battles on behalf of the regulatory framework that for 30 years has brought the nation cleaner air and water. But the country was better off for having her in Washington, a solitary if increasingly faint voice against the ideologues and lobbyists who occupy every other important environmental job. Mr. Leavitt, by contrast, is at one with the administration: a Westerner, unlike Mrs. Whitman, and an antiregulatory one at that. He should fit right in.

title: Jets' Rookie Hasn't Been in a Rush
description: In the weeks before the N.F.L.'s college draft, the analysis was unanimous: Dewayne Robertson was a great defensive tackle, blessed with speed and size, the top prospect at his position.

title: Computer 'Worm' Widely Attacks Windows Versions
description: A malicious computer program aimed at the most recent versions of the Microsoft Windows operating system rapidly spread around the world over the Internet yesterday, infecting tens of thousands of home computers and corporate networks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FISHMAN, MICHAEL
description: FISHMAN--Michael Aug. 19, 1963--Aug. 13, 1995 Until we meet again. Lovingly remembered. Family and Friends.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: People Smugglers Sentenced
description: A court sentenced 23 people traffickers to up to eight years in prison for having smuggled more than 10,000 Albanians to Britain during the past two years. The European Union estimates that up to half a million people a year are smuggled into its 15 member states. In June, a Dutch court sentenced seven people for organizing the trafficking of the 58 Chinese migrants who suffocated in the back of a sealed truck at a British port three years ago. Those deaths prompted countries of the European Union to cooperate better; since then they have harmonized jail terms for human traffickers and have tightened border controls. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: When Will the Killer Bikes Come for Chuwit?
description: These days the big money here is all on when not if -- they will whack Chuwit Kamolvisit, the massage parlor tycoon. After all, this is a gambling town. We already know the probable method: a two-man team on a motorbike (the traffic jams make getaway cars something of a joke, and even big motorcycles are risky -- they're hard to control when you jump them up on the sidewalk and weave between lamp posts).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULDOON, SYLVIA
description: MULDOON -- Sylvia. The Board of Trustees of Saint Vincent de Paul Residence, Kateri Residence and Saint Teresa's Nursing Home mourn the passing of their dedicated Trustee. Mrs. Muldoon was instrumental in the creation of Saint Vincent de Paul Residence and was a founding member of the Boards of both Saint Vincent de Paul and Kateri Residence, and had long been involved with the work of the Catholic Health Care System (CHCS), Padre Pio Shelter and Saint Anthony's Residence. In addition, she served on the Board of Catholic Charities of the Archdioces of New York and was the inaugural recipient of the Msgr. Raul del Valle Award from Saint Vincent de Paul, for her tireless efforts on behalf of those the Residence served. We are deeply saddened by her passing and offer our prayers and condolences to her family. She will be sorely missed and long remembered with respect and affection. Karl P. Adler, M.D., Chairman, CHCS, Board of Trustees of Saint Vincent de Paul Residence Saint Teresa's Nursing Home Kateri Residence

description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Chase, 75, a Researcher Who Aided in DNA Experiment
description: Martha Chase, who was half of a scientific team that in 1952 used a kitchen blender to help prove that DNA is the molecule that carries genetic information, died on Aug. 8 in Lorain, Ohio, a suburb of Cleveland. She was 75.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, two letters published Monday referred incorrectly to a class of antidepressants. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.'s, enhance the neurotransmitter serotonin; they do not inhibit it.

title: Terror Threat Spurs British Airways to Suspend Saudi Flights
description: British Airways , the largest European air carrier, suspended all flights to Saudi Arabia today after the British government said it had "credible intelligence of a serious threat" to the nation's aviation interests there.

title: Sara Lee Changes Agency for Deli Line
description: Sara Lee Foods in Cincinnati, part of the Sara Lee Corporation, has named Publicis in Mid America in Dallas to handle the account of its deli products that carry the Sara Lee brand, which had been handled by PGC Advertising in Dallas, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $12 million.

title: Bail Is Denied for Pakistani Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda
description: A federal magistrate judge in Manhattan refused to grant bail yesterday to a Pakistani man charged with assisting Al Qaeda, despite his lawyer's offer of a $2.5 million bond and arguments that his client had family ties in the New York area and did not pose a threat.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shooting Suspect Surrenders
description: A teenager who was a suspect in the shooting of six people on Sunday night in Canarsie, Brooklyn, turned himself in the next morning, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Tony Lopez, of Shore Parkway in Brooklyn, is accused of shooting six young men, ages 14 to 32, near Rockaway Parkway. None of the injuries were life-threatening. Mr. Lopez walked into the 28th Precinct station house in Harlem and surrendered at 11 a.m. Monday, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Critic's Notebook; A California New Music Festival, But Not All New or All California
description: For more than 40 years, the Cabrillo Festival of Contemporary Music has been a notable West Coast outpost for new classical music. But the festival, which has had a series of distinguished music directors, has evolved, and new music then is not new music now.

title: Firm Named to Help Police Install System to Find Cellphone Callers
description: A communications consulting firm announced yesterday that it has been selected to help set up the wireless 911 system for New York City police dispatchers. Plans for the installation of a new system, which will pinpoint the location of callers who make emergency calls from cellphones, were accelerated after four teenagers drowned in January off City Island. They had called 911 from a boat whose location could not be found.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: FORMER MINISTER ARRESTED In an acceleration of an official campaign against corruption, Maria Julia Alsogaray, a flamboyant former cabinet minister, has been detained on charges of misappropriating government funds. A close associate of the former president Carlos Saul Menem, Ms. Alsogaray supervised the widely criticized privatization of utility and steel companies early in Mr. Menem's administration but for the moment is formally accused only of improper conduct during her later tenure as environmental affairs minister. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Judge Won't Revive 2 Suits Against Merrill
description: A federal judge in New York refused yesterday to revive lawsuits by investors who had accused Merrill Lynch and its former top technology analyst, Henry Blodget, of biased research.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Automotive Profits
description: Two major affiliates of the Hyundai Automotive Group reported increased first-half profits. Hyundai Mobis, the group's parts-maker, said its net profit for the first half was 288.4 billion won ($245 million), compared with 213.1 billion won ($181 million) in the first six months of last year. Kia Motors reported a net profit of 328 billion won ($279 million) for the first half, compared with 279.2 billion won ($237 million) a year earlier. Kia's second-quarter profit of 186 billion won ($159 million), compared with 180 billion won ($153 million) a year earlier. Hyundai Mobis and Kia posted their reports a day after Hyundai Motor, the centerpiece of the group, reported an 86 percent increase in net profit for the second quarter. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Violence Spreads Through Afghanistan, Killing Dozens
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 13  In the most violent day in Afghanistan in nearly a year, 15 people, including six children, were killed when a bomb exploded on their bus in southern Afghanistan, and another 20 people were killed in fighting in the country's east.

description: During his sophomore year at Virginia, Tiki Barber strolled around campus toting a football in one arm and books in the other, not as a balancing act but as a reminder.

description: David Duval sat calmly in front of his locker, talking about his struggles as if the discussion were almost cathartic.

description: IT looks simple, doesn't it? Buy large pork chops. Build a big fire. Grill the chops over the fire and serve. Cooking doesn't get more elemental.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: LEGISLATORS BACK AMNESTY REPEAL The lower house of Congress approved a bill to revoke two amnesty laws that have benefited hundreds of military officers accused of abusing human rights during the dictatorship that ruled the country from 1976 to 1983. The measures were approved in the 1980's under intense pressure from the armed forces, but the new president, Nestor Kirchner, has said that they are unconstitutional and that he wants to see those responsible for the deaths of as many as 30,000 people brought to justice. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Boy Is Stabbed To Death
description: A 13-year-old boy was stabbed to death last night in East Harlem, the police said. About 8:15 p.m. a 911 call brought officers to 2075 Second Avenue between East 105th and East 106th Streets, where they found a large fight in progress in front of the building, said Detective Kevin Czartoryski. The boy, Julian Feliciano, 13, of East 106th Street, was found with two stab wounds to the chest, and was taken to Metropolitan Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 8:28 p.m. Another boy, 16, had been stabbed in the torso and forearm, and his lung was punctured. He was also taken to Metropolitan Hospital, and his injuries were not considered life-threatening, Detective Czartoryski said. A third boy, 16, had cuts on his forehead and was also taken to Metropolitan Hospital. The suspect, a teenager, fled on foot. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: To Each, His Own: Sharing a Family PC
description: FOR the family with just one, a computer can rival toothpaste-tube etiquette as a source of disagreement. I don't share my youngest son's view, for example, that a Web site about the arcane world of Yu-Gi-Oh! cards makes a useful browser home page. His older brother and I similarly disagree about what makes a pleasing computer desktop. And my wife, who works all day on a Windows-based computer, seems to approach the family Mac with despair after the rest of us have had our way with it.

title: Judge Rules Couple Own A Disputed Lottery Ticket
description: A judge awarded a $25.4 million lottery jackpot to an Englewood couple today, after rejecting claims by hospital workers who said one of their co-workers had conspired with the couple to defraud them of the winning ticket purchased with their money.

title: Rochester Goes for Green, On and Off Championship Course
description: The homicide rate is up. The main employer, Eastman Kodak, is laying off people -- again. And the candidates for the region's top offices are sniping at one another almost daily in bitter election campaigns.

title: In Defense of a Squawk
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Sciences To Add Jobs In India
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, which manages computers for corporate clients, plans to double its work force in India, company executives said. Computer Sciences expects to hire 1,000 employees in India this fiscal year, officials said in a conference call on Tuesday. The extra employees will provide the company, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., with highly educated, lower-wage employees to sell services more cheaply. Shares fell $3.22, to $40.40.

title: El Paso Records $272 Million Loss for Quarter
description: The El Paso Corporation, the nation's largest pipeline operator, had a $272 million loss in the second quarter as the company wrote down the value of its telecommunications business and settled accusations that it manipulated natural gas prices.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Cranbury: Large Cache Of Marijuana Seized
description: A tractor-trailer stopped for a routine traffic offense was discovered to have more than three-quarters of a ton of marijuana valued at $1.6 million hidden inside, the State Police said yesterday. The driver, Baron Bailey, 46, of the Bronx, and his passenger, Desmond Richards, 40, of Richmond Hills, Queens, were arrested on drug possession and distribution charges. They were being held with bail set at $250,000 each. The tractor-trailer was stopped on Monday evening for a broken tail light, the authorities said, and a trooper opened boxes labeled Home Depot that contained the drugs. The state police said that they did not know where the tractor-trailer had come from but that it had been rented from a Mississippi company and appeared to be headed toward New York City. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Prostitution Ring Charges
description: The owner of an Anniston nude dancing club who had sued to overturn the state's 1998 ban on nude entertainment pleaded guilty with his wife to conspiracy charges relating to a prostitution ring at the club. The owner, Harvey Bowman, lost his suit in 2001, but the court delayed enforcement of the law while he appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit. Federal authorities investigating the prostitution charges closed Mr. Bowman's Platinum Club in January 2002, Steven Sadow, Mr. Bowman's lawyer, said. Mr. Bowman was sentenced to 18 months in prison, and his wife, Bobbie Bowman, to two years for conspiracy. Two employees were sentenced to home detention and probation for obstruction of justice. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Actor's Ex-Business Partner Admits Extortion
description: A former business partner of the martial arts movie star Steven Seagal pleaded guilty yesterday to extortion conspiracy, ushering a case that had brought high drama to federal court in Brooklyn into its final act.

title: HANCOCK ORDERED TO PAY $2 MILLION TO INSURANCE AGENCY
description: John Hancock Financial Services was ordered to pay a New Jersey insurance agency $2 million for failing to issue life insurance policies marketed to millionaires in 1999, the agency's lawyer said. A ruling by an arbitration panel compensates Owr Opinion for about 35 unissued policies representing more than $100 million in death benefits, according to Sanford Young, the New York lawyer that represented the agency. John Hancock is evaluating its options, said Roy Anderson, a spokesman at John Hancock, in Boston. Owr Opinion, which helps brokers find insurance for wealthy clients, said Hancock reneged on a pledge to grandfather some pending applications after deciding not to offer a certain combination of features on some policies.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: STEER FAILS DRUG TEST A 1,294-pound steer named Mongo that won the junior grand championship at the Illinois State Fair was disqualified because he failed a post-competition drug test. The steer, which could have netted his handler, 14-year-old Whitney Gray of Iroquois County, more than $30,000, had been given an anti-inflammatory drug called Banamine Paste. The animal was disqualified on the ground that he was not market ready, meaning he was not fit to be slaughtered. The prize was given to a runner-up, a 1,315-pound steer named Scooby. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Lady Diana Mosley, Fascist Who Dazzled, Is Dead at 93
description: Lady Diana Mosley, one of the famous Mitford sisters and a glamorous 1930's socialite who scandalously abandoned her husband, embraced fascism and married Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of the British Union of Fascists, died in Paris on Monday, her family said. She was 93.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: How to Prevent the Next Energy Crisis
description: The world needs both more electricity and less pollution. The goals are not incompatible, but the solution will require better management of demand, smarter use of coal as well as renewable energy sources, and increased use of nuclear power.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ECONOMIC OUTLOOK The Bank of England predicted yesterday in its quarterly inflation report that both inflation and growth in Britain would be lower than original targets in 2003. The central bank cut its growth forecast for this year to about 1.8 percent from the 2.25 percent forecast in May, and said that inflation might not pick up until 2004. Based on this, rate cuts are not likely, economists said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Will Calgary Be the Next Kuwait?
description: America has many reasons for its risky involvement in Middle East politics, but there is no question that dependence on imported oil plays a very large role. The fact is, however, that the largest deposits of oil in the world are not in the Middle East -- or in Russia or off West Africa or in the Caspian Sea area, for that matter. They are in two Western Hemisphere countries: Venezuela and Canada.

title: Officials Say Shortages Could Cause More Riots in Basra
description: British troops remained on edge today in the wake of riots that shook this city on Saturday and Sunday, and some police and some military and civil officials said there could be more unrest if fuel supplies and electric service did not improve quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, NETTIE (NEE ZIMMERMAN)
description: SILVER--Nettie (nee Zimmerman), 93, of New Rochelle, NY, died on August 12. Born in 1910 in Brooklyn, a longtime resident of New Rochelle. Graduated from New Rochelle High School in 1927. Married Murray Silver in 1938, they lived in New Rochelle for over 50 years. Her husband Murray died in 1994. She is survived by two children, Susan Wisan (Robert) of Rye Brook and Martin Silver (Linda) of New Rochelle. Devoted grandmother of four grandchildren and their spouses along with three great - grandchildren. Along with her husband, she founded Bel-Aqua Pool Supply, Inc. of New Rochelle, NY in 1955. A longtime member of Beth-El Synagogue in New Rochelle and a contributor to the Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Israel. Donations in memory of Nettie Silver may be sent to OPUS (Organization of People Undaunted by Stroke), 101 N. Central Ave, Hartsdale, NY 10530.

title: Microsoft to Change Distribution of Vulnerable Software
description: Microsoft acknowledged today that it planned to change the way it distributes its flagship Windows XP operating system software, in response to a malicious software ''worm'' that has spread over the Internet in recent days attacking tens of thousands of personal computers by exploiting vulnerabilities in Windows.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about President Bush's choice of Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency misspelled the surname of a former deputy who has been acting administrator. She is Linda Fisher, not Fischer.

title: For Luscious Laptop Listening, A Wireless Link to the Hi-Fi
description: Laptops may be handy for students who are on the move between classes and libraries. But back in the dorm, they fall short in one area: their tiny speakers take sound quality back to the earliest days of transistor radios.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHRER, ROY
description: LEHRER--Roy, 87, died on August 13th, 2003. Beloved husband of Cecille Davis. Loving father of Noel and Esther, Peter and Harriet, and Sande and Marilyn and stepfather of Eric and Pamela Davis. Proud and adoring grandfather of Dana, Alison and Carly Lehrer and Jonathan Davis. Brother of Blossom Kramer and the late Mort and Jerry. Born 1915 in Brooklyn, he attended Erasmus Hall High School and Cornell. He was a consummate New Yorker and sports enthusiast. He pitched Sunday softball into his 70's in Woodstock, NY. Services Thursday 1 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Wall St. Misses Blackout; Some Companies Shut Down
description: Wall Street was shutting down for the day when the lights went out from lower Manhattan to the uptown towers that house the nation's biggest banks. But bonds were still trading in Chicago, where traders were initially spooked by fears that the blackout was the result of terrorism.

title: Wells to Miss Only One Start; Hitchcock Will Replace Him
description: The Yankees received encouraging news about the left-hander David Wells today, learning that he will miss just one start because of his back problems. Sterling Hitchcock will start for Wells on Saturday in Baltimore, and for now the Yankees expect Wells to return to the rotation on Aug. 22.

title: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING METLIFE MUTUAL FUNDS
description: MetLife Inc. said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the handling of mutual fund accounts at its New England Securities Corporation investment advisory unit. The company said that it estimated it would have to pay $3 million to $11 million to compensate about 6,000 accounts. The money would come from reserves, it said. Clients' money was improperly allocated because of a failure of software controls intended to match investments to the risk levels authorized by customers, a MetLife spokesman, John Calagna, said.

description: Comcast Considers Offer For Vivendi Businesses

title: No Charge; Miss Mom? A Hometown Honey? Calls Are On the House
description: Anyone on the Dartmouth College campus who picks up a phone and makes a long-distance call anywhere within the United States will find that the call is on the house. On July 1, the school stopped charging for all long-distance calls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMMERMAN, SAMUEL
description: ZIMMERMAN--Samuel. On July 26, 2003. Beloved brother of Beatrice Amontree and the late Jack Zimmerman and Frances Braverman. Adored uncle of Carol and Lewis Schnapp, Stanley and Marlyne Braverman, James and Kim Amontree, and Martin Amontree. Step grandfather of Amanda and Samantha. Services Friday, 11:30AM ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Buffett Takes A Bigger Role As Consultant To Candidate
description: Warren E. Buffett is far better known for his investment acumen and his sometimes tart opinions of what other companies do than he is for his support of political candidates.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: HEAT WAVE EXPOSES OLD BOMBS The extreme heat that has set records across Europe has caused the level of Lake Constance to fall, exposing eight unexploded World War II bombs submerged for more than half a century. German explosive experts removed the live bombs. "We have found four phosphorous bombs of British origin, several 200-pound American bombs and a 500-pound high-explosive bomb, also an American bomb," said Klaus-Peter Olsen, an explosives specialist. Local officials said a number of hand grenades from the two World Wars were also exposed. The lake covers 220 square miles and is bordered by Germany, Austria and Switzerland. (Reuters)

ONLINE DIARY
description: Can Johnny Blog?

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS AGREES TO BUY PART OF CUMBERLAND GAP
description: Smithfield Foods, the pork processor, agreed to buy a 90 percent stake in the Cumberland Gap Provision Company for about $56 million to expand its business in value-added products. Cumberland reported net sales of $70 million in 2002, Smithfield said. The founder of Cumberland, Ray McGregor, and family members will own the remaining 10 percent of the company. Smithfield is trying to focus more on prepared foods, which carry higher profit margins.

title: Conference Call; Helping Hands For Homework
description: Online technology enables students to exchange work, review papers for writing and comprehension problems and collaborate on solutions. Here are a few networks, Web sites and software programs that were built with peer exchange in mind.

title: Armand Borel, 80, a Leader In 20th-Century Mathematics
description: Armand Borel, a Swiss-born mathematician who became a towering figure in the development of modern mathematics, died on Monday in Princeton, N.J. He was 80.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Monday about new productions this summer at the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., included an erroneous identification from the program for the librettist of ''The Good Soldier Schweik.'' He is Lewis Allan (the name is a pen name for Abel Meeropol); Robert Kurka was the composer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXELON CORP., Chicago, a utility company, said it would sell a 50 percent stake in Sithe Energies, which owns stakes in power plants, to the Reservoir Capital Group for $75.8 million in cash.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brocade Posts Decline In 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: Brocade Communications Systems said yesterday that third-quarter profit dropped 90 percent as both sales and prices of its products declined. Net income fell to $1.91 million, or 1 cent a share, from $18.3 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier, the company, based in San Jose, Calif., said in a regulatory filing. Sales in the quarter that ended on July 26 fell 12 percent, to $133.5 million from $151.2 million. Competitors like the McData Corporation and Cisco Systems may be cutting prices to gain market share, forcing Brocade to do the same, analysts have said. Lower prices narrowed Brocade's gross margin, or the percentage of sales left after manufacturing costs are subtracted, to 54 percent from 60 percent a year earlier. Operating expenses rose by $1.88 million. Shares gained 4 cents, to $5.51.

title: Tag Sales, Auctions and, Well, eBay
description: WHAT'S the best way to sell belongings you don't want or have no room to keep? It depends on the collection. Here are three hypothetical situations:

title: Mets' Diaz Dreaming Major League Dreams
description: Beyond the center-field fence at the Binghamton Mets' ballpark is a backdrop known as the Blue Monster. Not long after joining the team, Victor Diaz smacked a 450-foot home run that nearly hit it.

title: Making War Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: An Appreciation; Gregory Hines: From Time Step To Timeless
description: Gregory Hines was admired as a gracious and charming performer onstage, in film and in television. But he was also a dance revolutionary who took the upright tap tradition, bent it over and slammed it to the ground. Hines would have been the last to call himself radical. He simply said: ''I am a tap-dancer. That's how I express myself.'' As a tap-dancer from the age of 2 he expressed the idiosyncrasies of his imagination most easily in his dancing.

title: Thompson Is Naming Leaders of New Unit
description: J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, is naming top executives to head a division, Health@JWT, that is being formed to oversee the agency's health care accounts with total billings estimated above $500 million.

title: Goodnight for 'Gracie'
description: ''Say Goodnight Gracie,'' the one-man play with Frank Gorshin, is to close after the matinee on Aug. 24 at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The play, written by Rupert Holmes and directed by John Tillinger, will have run for 364 regular performances and 27 previews.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Seeking Senate Seat
description: Inez Tenenbaum, a two-term state education superintendent, said she would run for the United States Senate seat that a fellow Democrat, Ernest F. Hollings, is vacating in 2005. Ms. Tenenbaum, 52, won her second election to state superintendent in 2002 with 59.3 percent of the vote in a four-way race. A Democratic poll released showed Ms. Tenenbaum ahead of three Republican candidates by double digits. Ms. Tenenbaum is a former elementary school teacher and Columbia lawyer. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; It's not just about price and performance. Intangibles are increasingly important.
description: OSCAR WILDE defined a cynic as someone who ''knows the price of everything, and the value of nothing.'' To many people, that sounds like an economist or an executive.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless Walkie-Talkie Service
description: Verizon Wireless is expected to introduce today a phone with walkie-talkie functions to compete with the popular Direct Connect service of Nextel Communications, according to a report yesterday in RCR Wireless News, a trade publication. Verizon Wireless will initially sell handsets made by Motorola for the service, but will introduce others made by Samsung shortly afterward, the article said. It listed the handset price at $150 to $330, depending on the length of the contract. Executives from Verizon Wireless, Motorola and Samsung were not immediately available for comment.

title: Perplexing New Routes To the Indies, Via Brooklyn
description: Does a good indie-rock band have to be inscrutable? Maybe not, but it certainly helps. Indie-rock audiences usually like feeling a bit baffled, and on Monday night at Northsix in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the record label Rough Trade brought together three acts that were happy to oblige.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They call it a drowning machine. The water was so turbulent and aerated that there was no way they could stay above water. Even the strongest swimmer in the world couldn't have survived it.''

title: Sports of The Times; Watson Plays Well In His Spiritual Year
description: WHEN Tom Watson was a youngster, his father suggested he should try to emulate Sam Snead's syrupy swing. Watson grew up to win eight major championships -- five British Opens, two Masters and one United States Open. As the 85th P.G.A. Championship begins today at Oak Hill, Watson, at age 53, is having one of the best years a 50-something golfer has had since Snead, at 52, was the oldest to win a PGA Tour event, the 1965 Greater Greensboro Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EATON, HARRIET
description: EATON--Harriet. On August 11, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Morton, loving mother of Jonathan and Emily, dear mother-in-law of Diane, adoring grandmother of David. Service Friday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 3 Agency Finalists For Popeyes Account
description: Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits, the fast-food chain owned by AFC Enterprises, has narrowed a review for its account to three finalists. The New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, had handled the account. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Keeping The Adventure Without Getting Lost
description: There are now three more ways to look at Manhattan. Ian White, the chief executive of Urban Mapping, a New York company, had the bright idea of taking three separate maps of the borough from Battery Park to 70th Street -- one of the streets, another of the subways, and one of neighborhoods and landmarks -- and digitally recombining them into a triple-decker guide.

title: False Identity Yields Sentence Of Six Months
description: A Chinese immigrant who assumed the identity of a dead man to reap the benefits of his American citizenship was sentenced to six months in prison yesterday by a federal judge in Manhattan who described his fraud as elaborate and carefully planned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, JUDITH M.
description: RUBIN--Judith M. Of Albany, N.Y., died August 9, 2003. Beloved wife of Robert T. Rubin. Devoted mother of Daniel S. Rubin and Jill S. Rubin. Contributions in Judy's memory may be made to Rubin Dialysis Center, 1850 Peoples Ave., Troy, New York 12180.

title: From Sir With Love: Fabrics to Suit the Furniture
description: Wool upholstery fabrics by Maharam and the London tailor Sir Paul Smith incorporate peacock flashes of blue violet, apple green and fuchsia. The multicolored satin stripes are distributed at irregular intervals across the 55-inch-wide textiles, for a random effect. Backgrounds have chalk-stripes inspired by Sir Paul's suits and come in men's wear colors like tobacco and charcoal heather, left.

title: Indonesian Art With Attitude; Engaging the Community and Upsetting the Establishment
description: Nindityo Adipurnomo and Mella Jaarsma artists and co-founders of a prominent gallery here -- have been at the frontier of Indonesia's spirited contemporary art scene for more than a decade. Some say this Indonesian and Dutch couple created the frontiers, then kept pushing them forward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, LOUISE
description: STRAUSS--Louise. Park East Synagogue, Sisterhood and Men's Club mourn the passing of Louise Strauss, beloved mother of our devoted members, Michael and Anne Strauss. May the bereaved family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEELER, RICHARD W.
description: SEELER--Richard W., 84, on August 7, 2003 of Forest Hills Gardens, New York. Born March 20, 1919 to Fred and Tillie Seeler. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Elizabeth Pretlow; father of Anne Carter Seeler & Evelyn Seeler McKay; grandfather of Jack and Elizabeth McKay; father-in-law to John F. McKay, III. At the time of his death he was vice chairman of Grubb & Ellis New York. A Memorial Service to be held on Thursday, August 14th, 5:00 P.M. at The Church-inthe - Gardens, 50 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills Gardens, New York 11375. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Church-in-theGardens ''Richard W. Seeler Memorial Music Fund''.

title: At Split Rock Falls, Deceptive and Dangerous Waters
description: The clear, cold waters of Split Rock Falls cascade through groves of hemlock and spruce, lope down natural steps of granite and slate, then plunge 40 feet into deep swimming holes, where trout sometimes lurk.

title: Helping Students Find the Auteur Within
description: LIKE any good filmmaker, Savannah Keller can succinctly pitch her animated short film ''The Dino Fight'': ''There is a herbivore minding his own business, and a T-Rex comes by and tries to annoy it. Then they get in a big fight, and the herbivore beats up the T-Rex, and the T-Rex loses and the herbivore wins.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: United Nations: Small Fire Prompts Evacuation
description: A small electrical fire in a basement of the United Nations forced the evacuation of dozens of workers from the lower levels of the organization's main building at lunchtime yesterday. No injuries were reported. The areas evacuated included a mail-sorting space, maintenance facilities and a series of conference rooms that remain largely empty during the summer. Three New York City Fire Department trucks responded, and firefighters with hoses over their shoulders walked past a lunchtime crowd. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: Among the Ivy, a Campus Tour Guide That Beeps
description: ITHACA, N.Y.

description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 14 - Phil Mickelson entered the P.G.A. Championship attracting far less attention than usual.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the opening of a musical, ''Lost,'' composed by Jessica Grace Wing, who died of cancer last month at 31, misstated the given name of the director. He is Rob Urbinati, not Ron.

title: Students and Palmtops
description: In today's edition of Circuits, I reviewed palmtop software for the college-bound. But the man who originally turned me on to the notion of palmtop software for students was Elliot Soloway, a professor of engineering, education, and information at the University of Michigan. He runs a unique program called the Center for Highly Interactive Computing -- Hi-Ce for short -- that is funded by the National Science Foundation, corporate backers and others. Its mission is to develop palmtop software expressly for the kindergarten-through-12th-grade classroom.

title: Doughnuts For Fans And Yanks' Offense
description: The owners of Krispy Kreme doughnut shops in greater Kansas City were probably cursing Jeff Weaver tonight. With another unsightly performance, Weaver, the Yankees' right-hander, made them work overtime.

title: China Allows Sale of Animal Tied to SARS
description: Chinese agriculture officials in Beijing have allowed farms to resume selling masked palm civets, a species that may have been the source of the SARS virus, and 53 other exotic species, although Chinese provinces retain the discretion to bar human consumption of these animals.

title: Corrections
description: A list of American military deaths on Tuesday identified the units of two soldiers incompletely. Pvt. Matthew D. Bush was with the First Squadron, 10th Cavalry, Fourth Infantry Division. Specialist Levi B. Kinchen was with the Howitzer Battery, Second Squadron, Second Armored Cavalry Regiment.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: CHILD SHOT BY COUSIN DIES A 3-year-old Brooklyn boy who was accidentally shot on Friday by his 9-year-old cousin died yesterday, the authorities said. The 9-year-old had been playing with a gun he had found under an older cousin's bed in the apartment where they lived at 315 Sutter Avenue in Brownsville. The 3-year-old, Darrell Williams, died from head wounds about 10 a.m. at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. On Tuesday, the police charged another cousin, 17-year-old Anthony Rodriguez, in connection with the death. The police said he had brought the gun into the apartment where the two boys lived and where he sometimes stayed. Mr. Rodriguez was charged with criminal possession of a weapon and endangering the welfare of a child, the police said.

title: Panel Monitoring Police Corruption Is Revived
description: A commission created to look out for police corruption whose six seats had been vacant for 20 months was revived yesterday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed six commissioners.

title: It's Preseason, but Giants Feel Need to Impress
description: ALBANY, Aug. 14 - Some Giants players said they were disappointed by their poor showing at New England in the team's first preseason game last Thursday night. Others said they were embarrassed.

title: For Water Bed Holdout, California Dreaming
description: ROLAND FORMICA is a lonely soldier. His beard has whitened during his long battle. Allies have surrendered to his shrewd enemy. Negative propaganda has assaulted him. But the last real water bed salesman in the San Francisco Bay Area stands his ground, powerfully worded full-color brochures holstered at the ready.

title: Suicide Inquiry Hears Conflicting Testimony on Intelligence Report on BBC
description: On the third day of an inquiry into the death of a leading British weapons expert, a BBC journalist raised new doubts today about a colleague's report that the Blair government had deliberately ''sexed up'' a dossier on Iraq's unconventional weapons to build support for going to war.

title: Death Toll in Europe's Heat Wave Is Continuing to Climb
description: PARIS, Aug. 14 — You could call it a surfeit of death. So many bodies were delivered in recent weeks to the Paris morgue that refrigerated tents had to be erected outside the city to accommodate the bodies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOSHING, HENRY
description: HOSHING--Henry. First Anniversary in Heaven. Always in our hearts and prayers. Love, Your Family.

description: ROCHESTER

title: DYNEGY LOWERS FORECAST BECAUSE OF REFINANCING COSTS
description: Dynegy, a utility owner and power producer, lowered its earnings forecast for 2003 because of costs associated with refinancing its debt. Results for the full year will range from a loss of 7 cents a share to profit of 1 cent. Dynegy said in April that it expected 2003 profit of 10 cents to 18 cents. Both estimates excluded losses from discontinued operations like energy trading and communications, the company said. Also excluded were implied dividends on $1.5 billion in preferred stock that had been held by ChevronTexaco and benefits from a restructuring of that debt. Including the losses from discontinued operations and gains from refinancing, the company said it expected 2003 profit of $780 million to $835 million, or $2.10 to $2.24 a share.

title: And in Other News
description: President Bush is used to being America's most important politician and the center of attention wherever he goes. So today, when a reporter told Mr. Bush that the California governor's race was ''the biggest political story in the country,'' the president got cranky.

title: What's 50, Curvy And Full of Air?; It's the Wiffle Ball, Still Popular, Holes and All
description: It was just another summer evening in 1953. A man, down on his luck but hiding his difficulties from his family, came home, as he always did, to find his boy and some friends playing ball in the backyard, as they always did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBELL, RUBY
description: LUBELL--Ruby. Ours was a lifelong friendship. You will be missed. Shirley and Danny

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil declined after the Energy Department reported that nationwide inventories rose last week. In New York, crude oil for September delivery fell $1.14, or 3.6 percent, to $30.78 a barrel.

title: 2 Suicide Bombers Fulfilled Their Fathers' Worst Fears
description: After the horror of a suicide bombing, the parents of the bombers almost always say that they were shocked, that they had no clue their child was prepared to do such a thing. But Yousef Iktaishat admitted today that he saw the signs as long as a year ago in his teenage son, Islam. He says he even tried to talk him out of it.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Delmont: Fire Destroys Part Of Prison
description: A medium-security prison in Cumberland County was evacuated yesterday when a fast-moving fire destroyed inmates' quarters. No injuries were reported, officials said, and the fire does not appear suspicious. The 120 inmates at Southern State Correctional Facility were sleeping at 2 a.m. when a fire broke out in their dormitory-style trailers. Firefighters from 14 departments could not quell the fire until several hours later, Matt Schuman, a State Department of Corrections spokesman, said. Most of the displaced prisoners will be moved to a new minimum-security area in Southern State, while others will likely be moved to nearby Bayside State Prison. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Newspaper Ad Sales Edge Up in Quarter
description: Advertising spending in newspapers increased 1.6 percent in the second quarter, to $11.1 billion, compared with the period a year earlier, according to preliminary estimates yesterday from the Newspaper Association of America in Vienna, Va.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: On the Road Again
description: Democratic legislators in Texas have once more fled the state to foil a brazen effort by Tom DeLay to add six more seats to his Republican House majority through an extraordinary gerrymandering of Democratic Congressional districts. Eleven Senate Democrats flew to New Mexico two weeks ago after Republicans changed the rules to dilute the Democrats' power to oppose the DeLay gambit in the Legislature. In May, Democrats from the Texas House fled to deny Republicans a quorum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BATSCHA, ROBERT M.
description: BATSCHA--Robert M. A memorial service for the family and friends of Robert Batscha, President of The Museum of Television & Radio, who died on July 4, will be held on August 20 at 5 PM at The Graduate Center, The City University of NY, Proshanky Auditorium, 365 Fifth Avenue (at 34th Street).

title: Israelis Kill a Militant Leader, Prompting Vow of Retaliation
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 14  Israeli troops killed a local commander of Islamic Jihad today, prompting a vow of retaliation from the group and providing a further sign that the pattern of strike and retaliation is reasserting itself between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: A Consultant Helps Navigate The Path to the Armani Home
description: For those who want to live as chicly as Giorgio Armani, there is the Armani Casa Interior Design Studio in New York, where Cristina Benardeau, an interior designer, conjures the master's pared-down look, using his Art Deco and Japanese-minimalist-inspired furniture. (Her fee is 15 percent of a project's budget.)

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday listing entertainers who have been involved in politics misidentified the candidate who defeated Ben Jones, a star of ''The Dukes of Hazzard,'' for re-election to Congress from Georgia in 1992. It was Don Johnson, in a primary election. (Newt Gingrich defeated Mr. Jones in 1994.)

title: Race Officially On: 135 Are Candidates In California Recall
description: The actor Arnold Schwarzenegger was officially certified today to run in the Oct. 7 recall election on Gov. Gray Davis of California. But so were 134 other people, creating what will be the most congested ballot in state history and setting the stage for an election night count that could drag on for weeks.

title: A Starter for a Night Hopes the Stuff Works
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 - When the Yankees clinched the American League East title in Detroit last September, Sterling Hitchcock had an empty feeling. The only thing he had done for the team, he figured, was give up three runs to the Twins in the 14th inning to set up Jason Giambi's memorable game-winning grand slam in May. ``Everyone was like, `Let's go out and celebrate,' '' Hitchcock said. ``I felt like staying back and washing the uniforms or something. I didn't have anything to do with it.''

title: Wal-Mart, Aware Its Image Suffers, Studies Repairs
description: Wal-Mart, concerned about its public image, is using a consultant to analyze that image and has commissioned radio and television ads to try to reverse criticism from local officials, consumers and others.

title: Lip-Reading Epics That Fly Thick and Fast
description: When Keats wrote, ''Bright star, would I were steadfast as thou art,'' he wasn't thinking of the show business firmament, where shining takes a lifetime of hard labor. Of course those stars aren't steadfast, they move, and many of them aren't solitary, but bunched in clusters.

description: HINES -- Gregory. Heartfelt condolences to the Hines family on the passing of Gregory. His warmth, kindness and fantastic sense of humor will be greatly missed. Skipper, David & everyone at Skipper's Place

title: Court Blocks City's Plans For Bond Sale
description: The Pataki administration sued New York City yesterday and won a court order temporarily blocking a bond sale the city had planned for next week, escalating a battle between the governor and the mayor over a deal to save the city $500 million a year.

title: As Belated Converts, Schools Keep Vigil for Internet2
description: IN its early days, the Internet was essentially the domain of the government and universities. Few elementary and secondary schools were connected to the worldwide computer network by the time the Internet spread to the masses as a commercial enterprise in the mid-1990's. Even today, many public schools log on to the Internet through sluggish dial-up connections.

title: Upset of Hewitt Leading to Bigger Things
description: Six weeks ago, after pulling one of the biggest upsets in Wimbledon history, Ivo Karlovic barely broke a smile. After his stunning four-set victory over Lleyton Hewitt, Karlovic raised his fists and looked as if he had known he would defeat Hewitt, the world's top-ranked player. ``I was very confident heading into that match,'' he said yesterday at the Bronx G.H.I. Classic, a Challenger Series event. ``I knew I was playing well and if I did that I could win.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURWICK, MARTIN I.
description: BURWICK--Martin I. Born December 24, 1917, died August 8, 2003. Beloved husband to Florence. Devoted father to Bruce, Sanford and father-inlaw to his wife Neila. Loving grandfather to Lance, Myles, Max, Rachel and Sara. Caring brother and uncle. A loyal friend. He will be dearly missed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Outlook
description: The Bank of England predicted yesterday in its quarterly inflation report that both inflation and growth in Britain would be lower than original targets in 2003. The central bank cut its growth forecast for this year to about 1.8 percent from the 2.25 percent forecast in May, and said that inflation might not pick up until 2004. Based on this, rate cuts are not likely, economists said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Citing Upturn, Bush Rejects More Tax Cuts As Vote Nears
description: President Bush said today that the sluggish American economy was on the road to recovery and that he would not push for a new round of tax cuts as he heads into his re-election campaign this fall.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Stricter Rules For License Renewals
description: New Jersey residents planning to renew their driver's licenses must now supply more personal identification under new rules adopted on Tuesday by the state's Motor Vehicle Commission. Two of the Sept. 11 hijackers were reported to have counterfeit New Jersey driver's licenses. Starting next month, applicants must present three of four forms of identification, up from one, a Social Security card. Citizens must provide two forms of approved identification, such as a birth certificate and student ID, as well as a copy of a current bill, such as an electric bill, to prove residence. In addition, noncitizens must provide a passport or alien registration card. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Used to Adversity, New Yorkers Cope With the Blackout
description: There is something about a New Yorker that welcomes adversity, and today an eerie blackout provided yet another test of New York mettle.

description: MANGINI--Chris, died of liver cancer on August 12, 2003. He is survived by his life partner, David Rankin. Services will be held at Redden's Funeral Home, 212-242-1456. Visiting 25 & 7-9pm, Friday, August 15.

Devens of New York, eight grandchildren and one great grandchild. His wife of 64 years, Edith Wolcott Devens, died in 1998 and a son, William L. Devens, died in 1968. A private service will be held.

description: BOSSINGER--Alan L. On August 9, 2003. Beloved husband of Julia, devoted father of the late Gary, loving stepfather of Frederick, Stephanie and Deborah. Dear brother of Ann Bonnell, uncle of Sharon and David. Graveside service Locust Valley Cemetery, Thursday 1 PM.

title: Rusticles on the Titanic
description: A man and woman were wed this week while he was in space and she was flatfooted on the ground. Hordes now flock to climb Mount Everest -- which used to be as hard to get on top of as it was to get into orbit. There is almost no limit to the places modern travelers manage to go, or the range of activities they expect to perform once they get there. So when it was reported that the Titanic -- two and a half miles down in the North Atlantic -- is going to pieces faster than predicted, in part because of tourist traffic, the only surprise was that it was no surprise.

title: Security Council Approves U.S. Resolution on Iraqi Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 14  The United Nations Security Council voted 14 to 0 today to adopt a resolution welcoming the creation of Iraq's new Governing Council, with Syria, the council's sole Arab nation, abstaining.

title: Seven Airlines Get Clearance For Flights To South Iraq
description: Travelers looking to kick back on a hot stretch of sand could soon be applying their sunscreen in southern Iraq.

title: Iran's Hard-Liners Reject Reform Bills Approved by Parliament
description: Iran's hard-line watchdog council rejected three bills approved by Parliament today that could have expanded civil rights. The move is another blow against the reform movement that has been limping along since 1997.

title: Turn On, Drop Out, Dig In
description: ON July 17 in Wainscott, on Long Island, 30 top design teams gathered, lugging pounds of sod, yards of ribbon and boxes of artificial orchids. Their mission? To dress outdoor tables for Elle Decor's Dining by Design, a gala dinner and two-day exhibition to benefit Diffa, the Design Industry Foundation Fighting AIDS.

title: Homestore Settles Suit Over Its Accounting
description: Homestore, an online real estate services company that provides listings to America Online, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay about $70 million in cash and stock to settle a class-action lawsuit over accusations of accounting fraud.

title: Pirates Attack Ships in Malacca Strait and Hold 3 for Ransom
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 14  Heavily armed pirates have attacked two ships in the Strait of Malacca in the last week and are still holding the captain, chief engineer and an assistant engineer from one of the vessels as hostages, a sign of continued security problems in one of the world's busiest sea lanes.

title: The Spanish Revolution
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including superlatives about Spanish food and a look back at Herb Brooks's victories.

title: Arafat's Sister, 77, Dies in a Cairo Hospital
description: Yousra Abdel Raouf al-Kidwa, the sister of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, died at the Palestine Hospital in Cairo today after a month of treatment for various disorders associated with old age, said the Palestinian ambassador to the Arab League, Muhammad Sobeih. She was 77.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Gun In Oven Wounds Woman
description: A 22-year-old woman was shot three times when a loaded pistol hidden inside a hot oven suddenly fired, the police said yesterday. The woman, whose name was not immediately released, did not appear to have suffered life-threatening injuries, the police said. Two men took the woman to the hospital, where doctors examined the injuries, suspected they were bullet wounds and alerted the police. One of the men, Colsaun Bailey, 17, was later arrested and accused of owning the weapon. On Monday night, the woman noticed smoke in the kitchen and opened the oven, where at least one pistol was wrapped inside a duffel bag. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Ted Williams Tale Gets Stranger by the Day
description: The executive who disclosed that Ted Williams's head was removed after his death and frozen said yesterday that he came forward because of ''horrific'' and ''unethical'' practices by the company, the Alcor Life Extension Foundation.

title: Pine Barrens Land Deal To Preserve 9,400 Acres
description: The New Jersey Conservation Foundation announced yesterday that it had entered into formal agreement to buy 9,400 acres in the heart of the Pine Barrens, representing what it said would be the largest private land preservation deal ever undertaken by a nonprofit organization in the state.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a plan to build a condominium complex near a landmark Modernist house designed by Rudolf Schindler in West Hollywood, Calif., misspelled the name of the original owner of the Hollyhock House, another project involving Schindler. She was Aline Barnsdall, not Barndsall.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airlines' Ratings Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service cut the credit ratings of Japan's two largest airlines to Ba3 from Ba1 because of the war in Iraq, the SARS virus, the weak economy in Japan and growing competition. The outlook for the two carriers, the Japan Airlines Company and the All Nippon Airways Company, remained negative. Moody's said the airlines would probably not see a meaningful increase in revenues in the short term to offset the damage to their balance sheets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: On July 9 and Feb. 10, The Times published letters from a correspondent identifying herself as Sister M. Immaculata Dunn of Valley Forge, Pa., criticizing the Catholic bishops' handling of cases of sexual abuse by priests. Catholic officials in Pennsylvania say she is not a nun. The Times regrets the error.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Legislators Back Amnesty Repeal
description: The lower house of Congress approved a bill to revoke two amnesty laws that have benefited hundreds of military officers accused of abusing human rights during the dictatorship that ruled the country from 1976 to 1983. The measures were approved in the 1980's under intense pressure from the armed forces, but the new president, Nstor Kirchner, has said that they are unconstitutional and that he wants to see those responsible for the deaths of as many as 30,000 people brought to justice. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: A Palmful of Goodies For the Undergrad
description: IF you're college-bound, you've probably already figured out what computer you'll be packing this fall. But if you're also techno-savvy, you may have figured out something else, too: that these days, a PC isn't necessarily the ideal (or only) computing machine for campus use.

title: Sports of The Times; There's the Hall of Fame, Then There's Barry Bonds
description: A FEW feet from where a crowd of reporters was forming to hear 34-year-old Mike Piazza talk about his return to the Mets as ''a rebirth type of thing,'' Bobby Bonilla was holding court on the subject of the man who recreated himself at 35, as no other player has at such an advanced baseball age. Who redirected his career path from certain Hall of Famer to what is now looking like an eventuality of his being the greatest home run hitter in the history of the game.

title: Daughter of Controversial Poet Is Killed at Her Sister's Home
description: The 31-year-old daughter of Amiri Baraka, the poet, playwright and civil rights activist, and a friend were found murdered late Tuesday night in the home of another of Mr. Baraka's children in Piscataway, N.J., the authorities said yesterday.

title: Security Council Approves U.S. Resolution on Iraqi Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 14  The United Nations Security Council voted 14 to 0 today to adopt a resolution welcoming the creation of Iraq's new Governing Council, with Syria, the council's sole Arab nation, abstaining.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile last Thursday about Adolfo Carrin Jr., the Bronx borough president, misstated the name of a city department for which he once worked. It is the City Planning Department, not Urban Planning.

title: NOMINEE FOR E.P.A. DEFENDS HIS JOB AS UTAH GOVERNOR
description: Gov. Michael O. Leavitt today defended his environmental record in Utah against critics of his nomination to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, saying that under his stewardship, the quality of air, water and public lands in Utah had indisputably improved. As he described it, the success had been achieved by seeking collaborative solutions involving public as well as private interests.

title: Friendship Drew 4 to Raging Falls, and Death
description: To four teenagers from city and suburb, Split Rock Falls was a magical place -- cool water rushing between the granite walls of a mountain ravine, forming pools for hours of lazy summertime swimming.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Names New President
description: WorldCom, which changed its name to MCI after the biggest bankruptcy filing in United States history, said yesterday that it named Richard R. Roscitt president and chief operating officer. Mr. Roscitt, left, who will report to Michael D. Capellas, the chairman and chief executive, will oversee MCI's operations and will be based at the company's headquarters in Ashburn, Va., MCI said in a statement. WorldCom, sent into bankruptcy in July 2002 by an $11 billion accounting fraud, may emerge by October and be owned by its creditors, which were owed $41 billion at the time of the Chapter 11 filing. Mr. Roscitt, 52, worked at AT&T for 28 years before joining ADC Telecommunications as chairman and chief executive in 2001. The Wall Street Journal reported the appointment earlier yesterday.

title: Jaguars Finally Sign Leftwich
description: At 1:30 a.m. yesterday, the N.F.L.'s last unsigned first-round draft choice, quarterback Byron Leftwich, signed with the Jacksonville Jaguars. At 7 a.m., he had a physical examination. At 8 a.m., he attended a quarterbacks meeting. At 9:30 a.m., he was on the practice field, trying to catch up after missing the first 19 days of training camp.

title: In the Upstate Hills, TriBeCa Fields Forever
description: WITH his blunt-cut hair, horn-rimmed glasses and weakness for design speak (''ramping spatial organization,'' ''two dimensionality'') Peter Franck fits the profile of a young architect on the make. Except, of course, for the electric blue flip-flops.

title: Supersize Animals and Bold Colors Brighten Up the Classroom
description: For children, a cabinet is not necessarily just a storage space. When it is emblazoned with animals like a giant moose, right center, it can become a stimulus.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Murder Charge In June Beating
description: A homeless man has been accused of fatally beating a Long Island man who had invited him into his apartment to make a telephone call, Suffolk County Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick said yesterday. The victim, Ronald J. Bottjer, 61, died in June after being repeatedly struck with a blunt object, Lt. Fitzpatrick said. The homeless man, Paul Himes, 39, was charged with murder and yesterday pleaded not guilty at his arraignment. Mr. Himes's lawyer, George Duncan, said his client was not guilty and was ''shocked at the charges.'' Mr. Himes, who knew the victim, told the police that he and the victim had argued, Lieutenant Fitzpatrick said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; Making Light Of the Season Of Absurdity
description: IN California, people are annoyed with the governor they just re-elected, so they are threatening to replace him with an actor or a columnist or a former child star. In New York, the senior senator is so popular he could run for re-election with negligible competition, so a political critic tried to stir up opposition by accusing him of religious bias. And in television land, a network that labels itself ''fair and balanced'' is suing a comedian for using those rare words in a book title.

title: Judge Fred I. Parker, 65; Served on the Second Circuit
description: Judge Fred I. Parker, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Burlington, Vt., died in Burlington on Tuesday, his office said. He was 65.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: SEEKING SENATE SEAT Inez Tenenbaum, a two-term state education superintendent, said she would run for the United States Senate seat that a fellow Democrat, Ernest F. Hollings, is vacating in 2005. Ms. Tenenbaum, 52, won her second election to state superintendent in 2002 with 59.3 percent of the vote in a four-way race. A Democratic poll released showed Ms. Tenenbaum ahead of three Republican candidates by double digits. Ms. Tenenbaum is a former elementary school teacher and Columbia lawyer. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Internet Survives Power Failure
description: Internet performance tracker Keynote Systems said the outage has not slowed the Internet.

title: Authorities Seize Times Newsmen Off J.F.K.
description: A reporter and a photographer for The New York Times and the captain of the boat they were riding in were detained by the authorities yesterday and were accused of violating the security around John F. Kennedy International Airport, the Coast Guard said.

title: A Twofer for the Bedroom
description: STACK them up. For families seeking ways to maximize sleeping space in a child's room, loft and bunk beds combine efficiency and fun.

title: Officials Say Charge Against Man With 23 Guns May Expand to Hate Crime
description: Law enforcement officials said a man who may have been associated with the Ku Klux Klan offered an undercover agent money and a gun to burn down a house in his neighborhood to prevent it from being rented to black people.

title: White House Fantasies on Iraq
description: Someday, in the months ahead, there may be an Iraq where a smoothly run American occupation authority has dealt devastating setbacks to terrorism, brought security to most of the country, improved infrastructure and basic services, and elicited encouraging signs of democracy, economic renewal and cultural rebirth. Unfortunately, right now that Iraq exists only in the pages of the implausibly upbeat 100-day progress report recently issued by the White House.
