title: About 200 U.S. Marines Land in Liberia to Back Aid Mission
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Aug. 14  About 200 United States marines landed in Liberia this morning on a mission to help West African peacekeepers secure the flow of food and aid to that starving nation, American officials said.

title: Giants Linebacker Crew Has Depth if Not Fame
description: From Sam Huff in the 1960's to Brad Van Pelt in the 70's to Lawrence Taylor in the 80's to Jessie Armstead in the 90's, a Giants staple has been star quality at linebacker. Think Giants, think linebackers. It has been a cornerstone of the franchise.

title: Kovalev and Rangers Agree
description: When right wing Aleksei Kovalev opted not to file for arbitration last month, there were doubts about whether he would be signed in time for the opening of the Rangers' training camp, which runs Sept. 11 to 16 in Burlington, Vt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDIS, HOWARD (BORN HOWARD LEFKOWITZ, BROOKLYN, NY)
description: LANDIS--Howard (born Howard Lefkowitz, Brooklyn, NY). Passed away August 12, 2003 at age 82 at his home in Valley Stream, NY. Attended Brooklyn College and met his late wife Carol of 57 years. He was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy and held management positions with Fairchild Publications, Welbilt Corp., Tadiran Corp., and Slant Fin Corp. Devoted father of Paul, Larry, Don and Sally Laufer. Loving grandfather of Sivan, Sharon, Dalia, Leia, Adam, Steven and Alanna. Stepgrandfather of Peter and Jacob. Services today at 1:30PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 516-295-3100.

title: Report Says Bad Supervision Helped F.B.I. Spy Flourish
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14  Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent who spied for Moscow, was able to avoid detection for more than two decades not because he was so good but because his bureau supervisors were so bad, an internal report said today.

title: Investors Keep Trading After Wall Street Power Outage
description: SAN FRANCISCO -- The power outage that darkened Wall Street Thursday caused little disruption or panic in the financial markets, with back-up generators and technology helping to keep the money flowing.

title: Company Plans Power 'Valve' Employing Superconductors
description: Superconductors are usually thought of as materials that lose all electrical resistance when chilled to a low enough temperature. But a company in Latham, N.Y., intends to announce on Thursday plans to turn the concept on its head by using superconductors as valves on the electric-utility power grid, letting their temperature rise to choke off the flow of power.

title: Among the Ivy, a Campus Tour Guide That Beeps
description: ITHACA, N.Y.

description: Two Congressional critics of Pentagon initiatives like the terror futures market said today that they would continue to try to block spending on such efforts even though an architect of the program, John M. Poindexter, a retired rear admiral, will leave the agency on Aug. 29.

description: HARRINGTON--Helen. August 14, 2002. When you left, the world didn't stop turning, the sun still shone and life went on, but not for me. Muriel and Renard

title: Mentor Leads Basketball Player Away From South Bronx
description: Larry Ayuso thinks he has finally outsmarted her. She left her huge, deafening cowbell in Greece, and now he has it. He knows she will ask for it before he faces a team of N.B.A. stars tonight at Madison Square Garden, but he will hand it over only on one condition: that she doesn't embarrass him by ringing it with all her might every time he scores a point. ``She goes crazy with that thing,'' Ayuso said. ``It's so loud you can hear it all over the building.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNALLY, JOHN F.
description: MCNALLY--John F., 77, of Wellington, Florida, passed away at home on Thursday, August 7, 2003. He was born in New York City on June 16, 1926. John attended Fordham University in New York and was a US Army Veteran. He was a Supervisor of Investigations for the Corp Counsel Office for the City of New York, retiring in 1991. John and his beloved wife of 51 years, Mary ''Maura'' moved to Wellington, FL in 1992. He was also a past-president of a local New Jersey chapter of AARP and the first vice president of Wellington's Senior's Club. John is survived by his wife Mary ''Maura'', son Stephen McNally of Edgewater, NJ and daughter Linda McNally of Houston, TX. Interment will be Friday, August 15, 2003, 1:00PM, at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Heart Association, P.O. Box 21475, St. Petersburg, FL 33742.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose after a government report showed United States retail sales increased in July by the most in four months. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.20 yen, up from 118.45 yen on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: General Strike
description: The first general strike since the restoration of democratic rule more than a decade ago has been carried out by the country's leading labor federation, with the police arresting some demonstrators and using tear gas to disperse others. The work stoppage, which failed to paralyze activity as leaders had hoped, was called by the 640,000-member Central Workers Union to protest what it describes as poor working conditions and inadequate health-care coverage in what has been South America's fastest-growing economy. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMIRNOFF, ALEXANDER G.
description: SMIRNOFF--Alexander G. Director of Telecommunications and Broadcasting at the Empire State Building. Died August 11, 2003. Born 1940 was 62 years old, wife Susan, one son, two daughters, two grandchildren, mother and sister. Funeral services, 10 AM, Saturday, August 16 at Noroton Presbyterian Church, Post Road, Darien, CT. Mr. Smirnoff was responsible for the 15 television stations and 20 radio stations broadcasting from The Empire State Building. He joined The Empire State Building in 1991. Helmsley-Spear, Inc. and Empire State Building Company LLC mourn the passing of Alexander G. Smirnoff. He will be greatly missed by his friends, colleagues and the community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORIOL Y URQUIJO, LUCAS MARIA
description: ORIOL y URQUIJO--Lucas Maria. We mourn with our friends Jamie, Leyla, Barbara and Kurt Oriol and the entire family on the passing of Senor Lucas Maria de Oriol y Urquijo in Madrid, Spain. Fran Nelson, Elisa Wagner, Mimi Trujillo, Grant Ruthizer

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Tuesday about President Bush's choice of Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency misspelled the surname of a former deputy who has been acting administrator. She is Linda Fisher, not Fischer.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Steer Fails Drug Test
description: A 1,294-pound steer named Mongo that won the junior grand championship at the Illinois State Fair was disqualified because he failed a post-competition drug test. The steer, which could have netted his handler, 14-year-old Whitney Gray of Iroquois County, more than $30,000, had been given an anti-inflammatory drug called Banamine Paste. The animal was disqualified on the ground that he was not market ready, meaning he was not fit to be slaughtered. The prize was given to a runner-up, a 1,315-pound steer named Scooby. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: A Tutor With the Textbook Key Unleashes Your Inner Einstein
description: ''Parental control'' of children's Internet use usually implies barring the door to Web sites that are inappropriate. But parents may want to exert the opposite influence when it comes to www.hotmath.com. At the site, students in grades 6 through college can get help solving the odd-numbered homework problems from more than 30 widely used mathematics textbooks. A student clicks on the proper textbook, goes to the appropriate page, selects a problem and begins to solve it. Hints are available, and it is easy to backtrack.

title: Charter Panel Defends Push For Nonpartisan Elections
description: The Charter Revision Commission, confronting criticism of its push for nonpartisan elections, issued a 42-page rebuttal yesterday to claims that the switch would lower voter participation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 5 about the appointment of a director of the Frick Collection misspelled part of her name. She is Anne Litle Poulet, not Little.

description: MINSKOFF--Nancy Lee. 8/6/55--8/14/02. Precious daughter, treasured friend, deeply missed. Mo

description: Millions of people across a broad swath of North America were reminded this afternoon of a simple fact that they usually do not have to think about.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Desegregation Lawsuit
description: Judge Dean Whipple of Federal District Court ruled that the Kansas City School District had cleared the last hurdle in a 26-year-old court desegregation lawsuit, ending supervision of the district. Last year the judge said the school had already fixed racial problems in facilities, budget and transportation, but an unacceptably large achievement gap between black and white students kept the district under court supervision. Arthur Benson, a lawyer for the plaintiff's schoolchildren, said he would appeal. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss At Lufthansa
description: The German airline Lufthansa posted a smaller-than-expected second-quarter loss, helped by lower fares and cost cuts, and said the industry might be recovering. The net loss was 34 million euros ($38 million), in contrast to a profit of 159 million euros in the period a year earlier, Lufthansa said. Second-quarter sales fell 11 percent, to 3.9 billion euros. ''The aviation industry is still operating in a difficult economic environment,'' the chief executive, Wolfgang Mayrhuber, said. ''But it looks like we have now come through the worst.''

title: Framework Set For Reduction Of Subsidies
description: In an effort to breathe life into global trade negotiations, the United States and the European Union said today that they had agreed on a way to reduce the subsidies and import duties used to protect their farmers.

title: U.S. Envoy Issues Alert About Threats In Indonesia
description: The American ambassador here called a meeting of American residents this morning and warned them that future terrorist attacks, like the one at the J. W. Marriott Hotel last week, were likely.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: STRESS ON THE BALLOT Stress, or efforts to reduce it, will be on the ballot for Denver voters this fall. Jeff Peckman, 49, collected enough signatures to force the city council to either pass his initiative, which would require the city to study ways to alleviate stress, or send it to the voters. Mr. Peckman said he believed that soothing music in public places could help lower crime and improve the economy. Council members say they regard the measure as frivolous, with one calling it lunatic and another saying it was causing her stress. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Edwards Wants 40,000 Yards For Testaverde
description: Somehow, some way, Jets Coach Herman Edwards is going to get Vinny Testaverde some throwing time this season.

description: To the Editor:

title: Cleaner Air, Courtesy of California
description: At a time when neither Congress nor the administration seems interested in significantly improving automobile efficiency, California has kept up the good fight and has now won an important victory. The Times's Danny Hakim reported this week that General Motors and DaimlerChrysler had agreed to drop their lawsuits against a California rule requiring automakers to produce millions of cleaner, more efficient ''hybrid'' vehicles -- cars powered by a combination of gasoline and electricity -- over the next 15 years. Since other states, like New York, often follow California's lead in these matters, such vehicles may in time be available everywhere. This, in turn, could lead to progress not only on cleaner air but also on global warming and the nation's growing dependence on foreign oil.

title: Bush Says There Is No Sign of Terrorism
description: Ahuge power failure swept through parts of the Northeast, Midwest and Canada late Thursday afternoon, snarling traffic and causing major disruptions in the lives of hundreds of thousands of people, but by 9:30 p.m. power gradually was being restored.

title: Air Industry Backs a Bill To Privatize Control Jobs
description: Airport and airline officials today gave strong support to a bill that would allow the Federal Aviation Administration to contract out the jobs of more than 2,000 controllers, saying the move would save money without harming safety.

title: Swing Your Partner: A Square Dance of Synonyms and Antonyms
description: Search for the word ''plain'' in a conventional book-bound thesaurus, and you will find an unadorned and featureless list of synonyms on the printed page. Search for the same word with Visual Thesaurus 2.0, and the program generates an animated three-dimensional constellation in which ''plain'' is at the center, surrounded by synonyms and other related words. Click on the antonym ''fancy'' and that word drifts to middle of the screen, where synonyms rush to encircle it in an elaborate, showy and -- the people who came up with it hope -- thought-provoking display.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; A Street Battle Rages in Argentina's 150 Years War
description: Though Juan Manuel de Rosas dominated Argentina for much of the first half of the 19th century, no street here in the city of his birth bears his name. If the descendants and admirers of his eternal adversary, Domingo Sarmiento, get their way, that will forever remain the case.

title: A Patron of the Arts, as Seen in a Sponge
description: THE designer Cynthia Rowley's favorite stretches of sidewalk in New York City are the ones where some aesthetically progressive urban engineer mixed shiny mica into standard concrete and rolled out sidewalks that twinkle, melding magic and the mundane. So she was intrigued, not offended, when the Parsons School of Design tapped her to mentor and judge a summer design course for underprivileged high school students where the objet d'art could not be more utilitarian: the humble sponge.

title: Several Events Postponed Due to Power Outage
description: JERSEY CITY, N.J. (SportsTicker)--The massive power outage that struck parts of the eastern United States and Canada forced the postponement of a handful of sporting events scheduled for Thursday night.

title: Everything for the Pointy-Pencil Crowd
description: MAYBE your summer was relaxing. But after being bombarded by bossy letters from sleepaway camp, I am frankly relieved that a certain detail-oriented preteenager I know will soon be headed back to school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSES, HENRY
description: MOSES--Henry. The partners, associates and staff of Goldberg Weprin & Ustin, LLP express our profound sadness at the passing of our friend Henry Moses. He touched us all with his insightful, analytical mind, his devotion to his family, and his cheesecakes. This successful, gentle and caring man will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ann, and his sons Henry Moses Jr., Robert Moses and their families.

title: In Paris Heat Wave, A Race for the Last Fan
description: RECORD heat this week may be doing great things for movie theaters on the Champs-lyses, but on the home front the picture is considerably darker.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Singapore's three domestic commercial banks have raised their mortgage rates, ending a competition for borrowers that had eroded their profits. The banks, United Overseas Bank, DBS Group Holdings and Oversea-Chinese Banking, all lifted the rates they will charge for home loans to about 3 percent. United Overseas had been offering borrowers no interest for the first year of their mortgage. It will now charge them 1.5 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

That happens three times in a billion deals, and one immediately suspects imperfect shuffling or perhaps a practical joke. Those who play goulashes, involving dealing in groups of three and four, are more likely to produce this result.

description: RAYA ALLEN is a 10-year-old reading fanatic, according to her teachers at Kimbark Elementary School in San Bernardino, Calif. But until recently, she was far less enthusiastic when it came to writing papers for class.

description: METZ--Eleanor (nee Diener). We mourn the loss of our dear friend of forty years. Her life was a tribute to family and friends, Jewish values, love of community, teaching and mentoring, courage and making a difference. A woman of valor--we will miss you dearly. Our love to Gary, Stephen (Andra & Caleb), Felicia, Jerry (Doris), Blossom, Ed (Ruth) and their families. Gail, Gayle, Ceal, Leona

description: It is a certain kind of urban vertigo: the feeling, during rush hour on a crowded subway platform, that it would be all too easy to end up on the tracks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Outlook For Advertiser
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that it had lowered the outlook on the credit rating of Dentsu Inc., the advertising agency, to negative from stable because of growing debts and investments in noncore businesses. Standard & Poor's affirmed the company's AA- long-term rating, but said it would be lowered if ''Dentsu experiences a delay in improving its finances.'' Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sam's Club Bolsters Wal-Mart; Federated Says Its Net Is Halved
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that fiscal second-quarter operating profit climbed about 15 percent after earnings rose at its Sam's Club warehouse-store chain and overseas sales surged. Federated Department Stores, the owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, said net income fell by more than half.

title: CIRCUIT CITY IS PLANNING TO SELL ITS BANK CARD BUSINESS
description: Circuit City Stores, the electronics chain, said yesterday that it planned to sell the bank card part of its financing unit amid rising defaults and that it would focus on its retail stores, where sales have been dropping. Circuit City expects a $200 million loss on the sale, most of which will be recorded in the current quarter, its second. The company said the bank card business, equal in size to its private-label cards, with about $1.5 billion in receivables, had a default rate of about three times as much in the last year. Selling the business can free cash for its retail business, where sales at stores open at least a year fell 8 percent in June and July.

title: Anger Over Car Insurance Rates in Canada
description: Canada's auto insurers, squeezed by soaring injury claims, falling investment income and slow-moving regulators, are hitting drivers with huge increases in premiums.

title: Kentucky Race Is Test For Bush on Economy
description: Improbable as it sounds, the first major test of President Bush's vulnerability on the weak economy may come this November in a state that he won handily in 2000, where his favorable ratings are still high and where Republicans hold seven of eight Congressional seats.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: EchoStar Profit Triples On New Subscribers
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter profit more than tripled after the company signed up additional subscribers for its Dish Network service. Net income climbed to $128.8 million, or 26 cents a share, from $37 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a regulatory filing. Revenue rose 21 percent, to $1.41 billion. The company added fewer new subscribers than some investors had expected and lost more of its existing customers, sending the shares down as much as 6 percent. The satellite television provider gained 270,000 subscribers to end the quarter with 8.8 million, an increase of about 18 percent from a year earlier. Analysts had expected the company to report a profit of 19 cents a share, according to a poll by Thomson Financial. Shares of EchoStar fell $1.85, to $34.27.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: YALE AND UNIONS RESUME TALKS Yale University and two labor unions representing 4,000 clerical and maintenance workers began contract negotiations on Tuesday, in an effort to avert another strike. The unions have said they will strike Aug. 27  as students are returning to campus  if no contract agreement is reached by then. The unions walked off the job for five days in March. The unions and the university remain far apart on issues including wages and pensions for the members of Local 34 and Local 35 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International. (AP)

title: SOUTHWEST BEAT RIVALS IN PASSENGER TRAFFIC IN MAY
description: Southwest Airlines flew more passengers in May than any other domestic airline, according to a government report released Tuesday. It was the first time that a low-cost airline had surpassed traditional network carriers in the number of passengers flown in a one-month period. Southwest flew 6.54 million passengers in May, down from 6.61 million passengers in the same month last year, but still ahead of any rival carrier, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics. The second-highest was Delta Air Lines, with 6.34 million passengers. In May 2002, Delta flew 7.07 million passengers, the most of any airline. American Airlines was third this May and second in May 2002, while Southwest was third in May 2002. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: W.H.O. Finds Use of Antibiotics in Animal Feed Can Be Reduced
description: Denmark has proved that the pork and poultry industries can thrive without using antibiotics to promote animal growth, the World Health Organization said yesterday, in a report suggesting that other countries may also be able to cut back on the drugs. Denmark stopped their use in 1999.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Climate Linked To Drop In Fish Population
description: Catches of two herring species have dropped about 40 percent since the 1970's in the 400-mile-long Lake Tanganyika in central Africa, and scientists now say they have linked the problem to rising temperatures and falling wind speeds in the region. The fish depend on a food web that is enriched as the deep fresh-water lake is stirred by seasonal shifts in winds and other conditions. That cycle has been disrupted by the warming, which matches the global trend scientists have linked to rising concentrations of heat-trapping greenhouse gases, the researchers said in a paper in the journal Nature. They said there were ''potentially dire'' consequences for the four countries bordering the lake -- Burundi, Congo, Tanzania and Zambia -- which get up to 40 percent of their animal protein from its fish. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Medical Acquisition
description: A Swiss company that makes medical implants, Synthes-Stratec Inc., has bought a family-owned company, Mathys Medizinaltechnik, for 1.5 billion Swiss francs ($1.1 billion) in cash and stock. The acquisition of Mathys, which produces instruments used to implant trauma, spine and orthopedic devices, makes Synthes the global leader in osteosynthesis. Synthes-Stratec will buy all Mathys shares for 1 billion francs ($730 million) in cash and 500 million francs ($365 million) in stock. Synthes-Stratec, which gets more than three-quarters of its sales in North America, had a $75.6 million net loss in the first six months because of one-time charges. In the period last year, net profit was $117.3 million.

The banks, United Overseas Bank , DBS Group Holdings and Oversea-Chinese Banking, all lifted the rates they will charge for home loans to about 3 percent. United Overseas had been offering borrowers no interest for the first year of their mortgage. It will now charge them 1.5 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Militants Strike Kashmir
description: Two civilians and a policeman were killed and 39 people, mostly civilians, were wounded when Islamic separatists detonated a bomb in a crowded market in Indian-controlled Kashmir. A little-known militant group, Al Mansoorin, took responsibility for the explosion, in the town of Bandipore, 20 north of Srinagar. The blast came as security was being tightened for India's Independence Day celebrations on Friday. David Rohde (NYT)

Extreme Logic has about $45 million in annual sales, the chief executive, Wain Kellum, said. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Arrest In Rape Case
description: The police arrested a man for rape yesterday less than two hours after the attack, and he is also charged with committing another rape last month, the police said. The victim, a 20-year-old woman, was walking near East 137th Street and Willis Avenue in Mott Haven about 3 a.m. yesterday when a man punched her in the face, took her purse, forced her to the rear of a building and raped her, the police said. At 4:45 a.m. the police arrested Ramon Berrios, 33, who is also known as Michael Medina and who lives at the Wards Island shelter. He was charged with rape and robbery. He was identified through forensic evidence for a rape on July 31, when he entered the home of a 52-year-old woman in the Bronx and raped her, according to the police. Tina Kelley (NYT)

The company produces 80 percent of India's crude oil output of more than 650,000 barrels a day. Unions have demanded the resignations of India's petroleum minister, Ram Naik, above, and the chairman of the company, Subir Raha. They said safety standards on offshore rigs were abysmal. title: TYSON WILL TAKE $10 MILLION CHARGE FOR PLANT CLOSING
description: Tyson Foods said it would take $10 million in charges over the next two quarters to close a poultry processing plant in Berlin, Md. The company said it expected to charge $6 million in costs in the current quarter and $4 million in the next three-month period. Tyson made the disclosure in a regulatory filing. Tyson recorded $19 million in charges in its third quarter, which ended June 28, with $4 million related to closing the plant and $15 million in impaired asset charges, the filing said. Tyson in April said it estimated $30 to $35 million in charges to close the Maryland plant with the loss of 600 jobs.

title: Bookstore Stays Open

The store was one of the few open on 42nd Street, thanks to the fact that its building -- 11 West 42nd Street -- has its own power generator. ''Business is holding steady,'' said Ron Kolm, an assistant night manager. ''The cafe is obviously doing about 500 percent its normal business. But it's not as if people are rushing in on their way back to their hot apartment to buy a book.'' title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Love, Dears
description: Receptionists and the security staff at government headquarters in Bristol have been told to stop calling members of the public ''dear'' or ''love,'' and to address them as ''sir'' or ''madam'' instead. The order came from Barbara Janke, the new leader of the City Council, who said that some visitors to city offices had objected to the informal way they were greeted. But in a city known for its use of endearments, the move has not been universally popular. ''I think the majority of visitors prefer a friendly welcome, rather than being confronted by faceless bureaucracy,'' Richard Eddy, a council member, told The Times of London. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

Excluding gains and losses on stock investments and a 483 million-euro gain in the second-quarter last year, Profit rose 15 percent to 1.17 billion euros from 1.01 billion euros. Not to be confused with the surrounding sprawl known simply as Forest Hills, this 147-acre enclave has a population of about 4,500. It remains, almost a century after its founding, the most successful and durable American example of the ''garden city'' movement, which took hold in England in the late 19th century as an antidote to the grimness of factory towns.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics Will Acquire Microsell
description: Flextronics International Ltd., the world's largest maker of electronics for other companies, yesterday agreed to buy Microcell Group for about $80 million in cash or stock to win more business from mobile-phone makers. Flextronics will also assume about $120 million in debt, the company said in a statement. The acquisition of the cellular-phone components maker, a so-called original design manufacturer, will increase operating profit in the year ending March 2005, Flextronics, based in Singapore, said. The purchase will bolster Flextronics' share of an industry that is challenging leading handset makers like Nokia and which might control 40 percent of the $100 billion mobile-phone market by 2005, four times its share, the researcher Northstream said. Flextronics also has offices in San Jose, Calif. Under certain unspecified circumstances, Microcell shareholders may elect to receive a portion of the purchase price in Flextronics shares rather than in cash, Flextronics said. Sales at Microcell last year jumped to 227.9 million euros ($258 million) from 17.4 million euros in 2001. Pretax profit rose to 2.7 million euros from 2.5 million euros, according to a statement on Microcell's Web site. Microcell has struck agreements with Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications Ltd. and Siemens A.G. for designing and developing mobile-phone handsets.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ATI And Microsoft Sign Pact On XBox Components
description: ATI Technologies said yesterday that it had signed a contract with Microsoft to produce components for future versions of the Xbox game console, beating out the market leader, Nvidia. ATI said it had entered a technology agreement with Microsoft to develop ''custom, leading-edge graphics technologies'' for the console. ''We selected ATI after reviewing the top graphics technologies in development and determining that ATI's technical vision fits perfectly with the future direction of Xbox,'' Robbie Bach, senior vice president of Microsoft's home and entertainment division, said. The announcement ends months of speculation over whether Nvidia, the leading maker of graphics processors for PC's, would renew its troubled partnership with Microsoft on the Xbox. The graphics processor is the most expensive component in the Xbox, and Nvidia stood poised for a major windfall after the chipmaker won the contract shortly after the Xbox was announced three years ago. But sales problems and hardware changes left Nvidia with piles of unsold and unusable chips, putting it in a position where it could have lost money on the console if it had not submitted the Microsoft contract to arbitration. The Xbox deal has accounted for 15 percent to 20 percent of Nvidia's sales the last two years, and company executives credited Xbox-related business for a surge in profit during Nvidia's most recent quarter. Analysts had predicted the contract for the next Xbox might go to ATI, which also makes the graphics processor for Nintendo's GameCube. Microsoft has yet to set a date or reveal details on the successor to the current Xbox, despite rampant speculation from fans and game makers. While Microsoft will need to deliver new technology that can compete with Sony's successor to the PlayStation 2, it is also probably looking for ways to cut costs after after taking significant losses on the Xbox. (CNETnews.com)

title: Harvesting Poverty; Inching Toward Trade Fairness
description: Poor and developing nations have long -- and rightly -- complained that while the richest countries want open markets for their manufactured goods, they rig the game when it comes to agricultural products. Now it appears that the United States and Europe are beginning to get the message. Their trade negotiators have agreed to try to reduce their farm subsidies and other barriers to agricultural imports. The vague agreement, announced on Wednesday, falls short of what is needed and raises as many questions as it answers. The numbers are yet to be filled in. Still, the effort is a heartening sign that on the eve of next month's critical World Trade Organization meeting in Cancn, pressure is mounting on developed nations to make the global trading system more fair.

description: A warden who supervised the teenager sentenced to life in prison for beating a playmate to death when he was 12 told aides to Gov. Jeb Bush today that the teenager deserved clemency.

title: After Assuming the Worst, City Tries to Make the Best of It
description: When power went out across vast pockets of the Northeast yesterday, the New York Police Department initially responded as it would to a major terrorist attack, officials said yesterday. A special command center was activated, the police in each borough began to operate as independent departments and heavily armed teams were deployed to potential targets.

title: Editors' Note; To Our Readers
description: Because of production problems caused by the power failure yesterday, SportsFriday appears today inside The Metro Section and begins on Page B5. Some copies of Weekend, Escapes and World Business were not available for delivery with this issue, and will be distributed over the weekend. The Movie Clock may carry listings intended for an incorrect region. The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

title: Suspect in Indonesia Bombings Is Captured in Asia
description: A top lieutenant of Osama bin Laden who the authorities said was the mastermind of the deadly Bali bombings in October 2002 and the attack last week on the J. W. Marriott hotel in Jakarta has been captured in Southeast Asia, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Israelis Kill a Leader of Islamic Jihad, Which Vows Revenge
description: Israeli troops killed a local commander of Islamic Jihad today, prompting a vow of retaliation from the group and providing a further sign that the pattern of strike and retaliation is reasserting itself between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: Ferguson to Join Temerlin McClain
description: Jim Ferguson, a longtime creative executive at several agencies, is joining Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies , in the new posts of chairman and chief creative officer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Oil Tanker Breaks Up
description: A Greek oil tanker that ran aground off a popular beach in the southern port city of Karachi three weeks ago split into two pieces and leaked an estimated 12,000 metric tons of oil, officials said. They played down the risk of further leaks from the stricken ship, but environmental groups called the situation an ''environmental, ecological and economic catastrophe.'' Roughly 35,000 metric tons is believed to remain on the ship, which officials say should hold, but local environmental groups fear it will not. A Pakistani television station reported that more than 100 people had been treated for respiratory and eye infections. Last night, oil washed ashore, and residents complained of dead fish, stinging vapors and pungent smells. Zulfiqar Shah (NYT)

title: Time to Freshen Up
description: At least one car yesterday was turned into an impromptu dressing room, in preparation for a special night out. Amy Rosenthal of Appleton, Wis., was able to use her curling iron by starting up her friend's Ford pickup truck and using a converter plugged to the car's cigarette lighter.

title: Retirement Weakens Jets' Offensive Line
description: It was once a bastion of stability, the solid foundation on which the Jets' offense rested. But over the last two seasons, the offensive line has endured some cracks, and today, a new fissure developed.

title: Down on Her Guccis but With a Heart of Platinum
description: ''Uptown Girls'' is the latest rhinestone-crusted fantasy in the booming Junior Miss niche market that might be called Princess because of its fawning adoration of overprivileged young bachelorettes and the luxuries their credit cards can fetch. Its bratty 22-year-old heroine, Molly (Brittany Murphy), is the orphaned daughter of rock royalty (her parents died in a plane crash), who lives in Manhattan in palatial squalor with her pet pig, Moo, and her dead father's guitar collection.

title: Swimming to Montana
description: Warm weather in Montana if you don't count the week every February with highs in the 50's, when people drive with the windows down and wear shorts to school -- lasts from June to August. More or less. June can be cloudy and cold, and August has thundershowers, but those are the months when it's least likely to snow.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Parrots Wanted, Dead Or Alive
description: Wildlife officials on Maui are asking the federal government for $52,000 to trap or kill beautiful but destructive nonnative parrots that could injure Hawaii's native forests and birds, as well as crops. About 120 to 200 of the red-and-green parrots, or mitered conures, have roosted in Huelo in East Maui. These are probably the progeny of pets released to the wild, Michael Walker of the Maui Invasive Species Committee said. Mr. Walker said the parrots could carry avian diseases that could wipe out native birds and spread the seed of aggressive alien species far into native forests. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Following in Small Footsteps: Children Go to Parents' Camp
description: Gary Tucker could hardly wait to get to summer camp. He was looking forward to playing roller hockey and seeing his old buddies again.

title: When Baseball Is the Stuff of Dreams (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Comcast Drops Out of Bidding for Vivendi Entertainment Units
description: Comcast said yesterday that it had dropped out of the auction for Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets, though it said it planned to explore creating a joint venture to combine both companies' cable channels.

title: Cape Cod by Bike, A Family Trip
description: THREE miles into the trail, I break out the gummy bears. My son, who has spotted some children splashing in the shallows of a glistening pond, has steered his bike off the path and wants to join them. I've got to coax him back on track -- this is supposed to be a biking trip, after all. My husband and I and our two children have come to Cape Cod to ride the paved path that runs from South Dennis to South Wellfleet on the bed of the Old Colony Rail Road.

title: Bush Doesn't Let Blackout Upset Lunch With Troops
description: President Bush was having lunch with troops at the Miramar Marine Corps Air Station when Joe Hagin, his deputy chief of staff, told him of the massive blackout on the East Coast.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Donations For Congressional Defense
description: Members of Congress may accept donations from corporations and unions for legal defense funds, the Federal Election Commission has ruled. The campaign finance law that was passed by Congress last year barred lawmakers and candidates from raising unrestricted money from corporations and unions. But the commission ruled that legal defense funds were not covered by the law. The commission decided to consider the issue after Representative Denise L. Majette, Democrat of Georgia, sought donations to help pay legal costs from a lawsuit filed last year by Cynthia McKinney, the House member she defeated. The suit was dismissed this week.

title: Sleeping Porches: Use as Intended or Convert Into an Extra Room
description: WHO -- Robin Turner Oswald, 32, a programming and production coordinator for the Biltmore Estate, shown with her husband, John, 33, and twins, Harrison and Carson, 18 months

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERMAN, ARLENE T. (NEE TOFFEL)
description: BERMAN--Arlene T. (nee Toffel) of Paramus, NJ, also of Nokomis, FL. Beloved wife of 45 years of Adolf N. Cherished daughter of Samuel Toffel and the late Gertrude. Devoted mother of Jeffrey and Elisabeth, Robert and Danielle, and Douglas and Nancy. Dear sister of Judith Julius. Loving grandmother of Sarah, David, Alexandra and Gabrielle. Services Friday at Noon, The Jewish Community Center of Paramus, 304 Midland Ave., Paramus. Contributions to the Arlene T. Berman Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 702, Paramus, NJ 07653-0702. For information ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: Con Ed in the Dark
description: The lobby of the Consolidated Edison headquarters was almost pitch black yesterday evening -- and company officials sounded almost as in the dark about the causes of the power blackout that left 3.1 million customers without electricity. Or perhaps they were just not saying.

title: A Comics Guy, Outside the Box
description: ''From off the streets of Cleveland comes 'American Splendor' '' screams the cover of every issue of the writer Harvey Pekar's surly and open-eyed autobiographical comic-book series. The towering, action-packed logo is a further sardonic comment on the lack of activity in the protagonist's life.

title: Power Failure Keeps Mets Off the Field
description: When the area's power failure struck at Shea Stadium yesterday, emergency lighting let the Mets players see one another inside their clubhouse.

title: Floyd Will Have Surgery on Heel
description: Mets left fielder Cliff Floyd said yesterday that he would play his last game of the season on Monday, then prepare for surgery on his right heel later this month.

title: Good and Evil Shoot It Out
description: Boss Spearman (Robert Duvall) is the leader of a small band of cattlemen driving a herd across the West. He's gruff and impatient, but he's a good man. His sidekick, Charley Waite (Kevin Costner), is haunted by a violent, lawless past, but deep down, he's a good man, too. The two junior members of the crew, the burly Mose and the runty Button (Abraham Benrubi and Diego Luna), are rambunctious fellows, but they're both good men. Their canine companion, Tig, sure is a good dog.

title: Giving Life to the Debris of a Mechanized World
description: The exhibition of Richard Stankiewicz's charmingly vigorous welded scrap-metal sculpture at the AXA Gallery is the artist's first retrospective in New York, but it has a comforting, even stuffy air of familiarity.

title: When Baseball Is the Stuff of Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Panic Leads to a Rush on Emergency Rooms
description: The heat, panic and blackness that settled over the city in yesterday's blackout caused ailments and injuries, sending large numbers of New Yorkers to the city's hospitals and overwhelming some emergency rooms.

title: BLACKOUT OF 2003
description: Disruption in the Air . . .

title: Twilight Zone Economics
description: For about 20 months the U.S. economy has been operating in a twilight zone: growing too fast to meet the classic definition of a recession, but too slowly to meet the usual criteria for economic recovery. There's nothing particularly mysterious about our situation. But recent news coverage and commentary -- in particular, the enthusiastic headlines that followed a modest increase in growth and a modest decline in jobless claims -- suggest that some people still don't get it. So here's a brief refresher course on twilight zone Economics 101.

title: F.B.I. Failed To Act on Spy Despite Signals, Report Says
description: F.B.I. officials knew as far back as the mid-1980's that Robert P. Hanssen, the longtime agent and convicted Russian spy, had repeatedly mishandled classified data and violated procedures but did nothing to prompt an investigation, a Justice Department report released today states.

title: Aide Is Said to Have Ordered Scientist Testimony
description: At the inquiry into the apparent suicide of a top British weapons expert, Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon was said today to have overruled advisers and personally ordered that the scientist David Kelly face a public interrogation about his media contacts just days before his apparent suicide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOKE, VIRGINIA
description: COOKE--Virginia of Remsenburg on August 14, 2003. Mother of Jane Brynn, John N. Cooke, Virginia Arvay, Paul Cooke, Roger Cooke, Hilary Cooke, Linus Cooke and the late Mary Flynn. Also survived by nineteen grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Reposing Sunday 24 and 7-9pm at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Rd, Westhampton Beach, NY. Mass of the Resurrection Monday, 10am, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Joseph's College, 245 Clinton Ave, Brooklyn, NY, 11205.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Wal-Mart Stores to improve its public image misidentified the city where a federal suit filed against the company alleging sex discrimination. It was San Francisco, not Washington.

title: The Art of Skateboarding, With Hormones Ascendant
description: Buried somewhere under the gross-out jokes and the wet-lipped ogling at an endless parade of jiggling bikini-clad flesh in ''Grind'' is the kernel of a cheerful little movie about the world of competitive skateboarding.

title: Directing Traffic
description: At the intersection of 34th Street and Lexington Avenue, Edward Andrew Keane, a 60-year-old regional sales manager for a company that sells radio advertising, was directing traffic in a red and blue striped dress shirt and silk necktie, his top button undone, sweat saturating his torso from the shoulders down, a cellphone clipped to his waistband. In place of a traffic officer's baton, he was waving a half-empty plastic bottle of Poland Spring water.

title: In Frustration, Humor and Greed, A Powerless New York Endures
description: A Times Square with no working traffic lights is not a pretty sight.

title: Funny Cide Is Still On Fence
description: The trainer Barclay Tagg said today that he has still not decided whether to run Funny Cide, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, in the Travers Stakes here on Aug. 23.

title: Boy Seen as Easy Target Dies in East Harlem Melee
description: Aug. 13 of Julian Feliciano's 13th summer began, more or less, at 10 a.m. when he rang the buzzer at a friend's apartment building to see if the friend would come down to play basketball.

title: 36 Hours | Newburyport, Mass.
description: BLOCKS of refined red brick Federalist and Georgian mercantile buildings and dazzling centuries-old white mansions announce that Newburyport, now the smallest coastal city in Massachusetts, with just 17,000 residents, was once a much more prominent place. And so it was: a rival port to Boston, 40 miles to the south, in the 1700's and a cosmopolitan center of shipbuilding, commerce, craftsmanship and letters. Now, relieved of the burden of so much importance, it can afford to be easygoing and charming, reverent of its history while reveling in its salty side with public beaches, whale watching trips, lobster dinners and lots of fine bakeries. SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

title: Fixing Albany; Off to the Races
description: Horses have an awful lot of muscle in Albany. The New York Racing Association, one of New York's many phantom private-public operations, probably has more clout than any union or business, certainly more than any mere citizen trying to get relief on issues closer to the human condition.

title: Credit Card Division Helped Lift Target's Second-Quarter Profit
description: The Target Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter profit increased 4.1 percent, helped by its credit card unit. Sales growth slowed as an expanded selection of clothing at Wal-Mart Stores attracted shoppers.

title: Stonington, Conn.
description: ARATHER affluent, rather literary little village." That characterization of the borough of Stonington, Conn., by Uday Mehta, a professor of political science at Amherst College, may be something of an understatement. For years Stonington, on a quiet peninsula that juts into Long Island Sound, has lured intellectual, wealthy urbanites drawn by its almost islandlike feeling.

title: Soccer Team of Century Enters Age of Marketing
description: No soccer club in the world has won as many laurels as the 101-year-old Real Madrid, named Club of the 20th Century by the sport's international governing body, FIFA. But only since 2000 has it begun to turn sporting triumph into business glory.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about accusations of unnecessary heart procedures and surgery at Redding Medical Center in California misidentified the surgeon who performed an operation on Shirley B. Wooten, a former patient who has filed a lawsuit. The surgeon was a partner of Fidel Realyvasquez, not Dr. Realyvasquez himself. Federal investigators are examining the practices of several heart specialists at the hospital.

title: ImClone Files New Request For Approval Of Cancer Drug
description: Dogged by scientific missteps, securities fraud and management miscues, ImClone Systems announced yesterday that it had re-applied electronically to sell its cancer drug, Erbitux. And then the lights went out.

title: Afghanistan Speeds Up Purge of Officials After Bomb Attack
description: After more than 50 people were killed in clashes and a bomb attack on Wednesday, the central government speeded up a sweeping purge of provincial officials today, firing three governors and six security chiefs in the regions hardest hit by an intensifying pro-Taliban insurgency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGOVIN, IRA
description: ROGOVIN--Ira. The law firm of Dinkes and Schwitzer mourns the untimely death of our dear friend, Ira. He was one of a kind. Our deepest condolences to his family. Bill Dinkes and William Schwitzer

description: Phil Mickelson entered the P.G.A. Championship attracting far less attention than usual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LORBER, MARTIN A.
description: LORBER--Martin A. Of Sands Point, NY. Born August 15, 1940, passed away August 13, 2003. Loving husband of Annette, and devoted father of Stephanie and Fred Rigos, Jacqueline and Gaetano Scannavino, Jonathan, Victoria and Marc Shapiro, Lisa and Gregory Fortunoff, and Eve and Jonathan Winston. Proud and adoring grandfather of Jacob, Gaetano, Alexandra and Paris. Founder, owner and chief operating officer of Worldwide Footwear, Inc., Merrick, NY. Throughout his entire life, he demonstated an infallible strength of character with his family, his business and throughout his illness. This successful, generous and caring man will be dearly missed by all who knew him. Services Friday, 11AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: U.S. Reports Arrest Of Al Qaeda Chief For Southeast Asia
description: Riduan Isamuddin, 39, an Indonesian better known as Hambali, who is thought to be Al Qaeda's main organizer in Southeast Asia and to have led the deadly bombing in Bali last year, has been captured, the White House said yesterday.

title: Baghdad on the Hudson
description: BAGHDAD, AUG. 15  Imagine that the blackout that struck the United States on Thursday was a daily phenomenon. And imagine that the New York City police force was only a third its authorized strength, that criminals walked the streets and that gun battles could be heard at night.

title: Recovery Without Jobs? No Way
description: To the Editor:

title: From Small Sculptures to Glimpses of Signs, a Mix of Works in the Bronx
description: No one ever said it would be easy to achieve a self-sustaining art career in New York. Even artists who have lived in the city for years remain mystified by the commercial system's apparent impenetrability. Yet there are lots of artists who do manage it. How do they do it?

title: World Briefing | Europe: London: Security Report Criticizes Police
description: British officials said the Army and undercover agents might be called on to protect the Royal Family after an inquiry highlighted a series of security lapses by the police at a 21st birthday party for Prince William at Windsor Castle in June. The report said an intruder, Aaron Barschak, dressed up as Osama bin Laden, set off seven alarms and was seen on closed-circuit television five times before the police realized he had not been invited to the party. Mr. Barschak even entered a room where virtually the entire Royal Family was having dinner, the report said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Experts Urge a Reprieve for the Hubble Space Telescope
description: The Hubble Space Telescope, astronomy's vaunted time machine, was granted a conditional reprieve yesterday when an expert panel recommended that NASA consider sending a crew of astronauts at the end of the decade to extend its career, rather than dropping it out of orbit, as has been planned.

title: Matching Classical Mozart With 'Classical' Prokofiev
description: Delving into the sounds of a historical era is one way that composers can temporarily dodge the confines of their own. This was arguably the case with Prokofiev's ''Classical'' First Symphony, an ingratiating work whose delicacy, refined textures and transparent scoring for small orchestra call to mind Mozart and Haydn much more than they do the enfant terrible of Russian music.

title: Letting Nature Run Its Course, and Making Money From It
description: Brutal heat in Europe has caused power prices to soar and has robbed the profits of bakeries and chocolate makers. Meanwhile, rain in the northeastern United States has left amusement parks and beach resorts empty.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; A Western With Echoes Of the Blacklisting Days
description: The time is ripe for a reconsideration of Nicholas Ray's terse, paradoxical and fascinating 1954 western ''Johnny Guitar,'' which begins a revival run today at Film Forum.

description: An article on Wednesday about economic problems in Hungary misstated recent changes in the operations of Flextronics, an electronics company. While it has moved some manufacturing to China, the company has not closed Hungarian plants.

title: Absence of Lights Fails to Stifle Nightlife
description: Bars throughout Manhattan lost power just before happy hour yesterday, but many remained energized throughout the night with overflow crowds.

title: Believe It, Or Not
description: Today marks the Roman Catholics' Feast of the Assumption, honoring the moment that they believe God brought the Virgin Mary into Heaven. So here's a fact appropriate for the day: Americans are three times as likely to believe in the Virgin Birth of Jesus (83 percent) as in evolution (28 percent).

Diners headed to hot spots like Moutarde and Al Di La can easily pass right by Convivium Osteria, a small, unassuming restaurant, just a few blocks south of Flatbush, with serious intentions.

description: Shares of BearingPoint, the consulting firm formerly known as KPMG Consulting, fell by more than 23 percent yesterday after it announced that it would revise its earnings downward for the first nine months of its fiscal year.

description: The economic harm caused by the blackout will be enormous, and lawsuits are certain to be filed. But plaintiffs will face substantial hurdles.

Cliff Foster, a third-generation potato farmer and an antique-tractor buff, had asked fellow members of the Long Island Antique Power Association to show their prized pieces at his farm.

title: Sports of The Times; Mickelson, Annoyed, Talks on His Terms
description: BEFORE any of the four major golf championships in recent years, Phil Mickelson has invariably and willingly been on display in the news media interview area along with the sport's other notables. But before this 85th P.G.A. Championship, at Oak Hill, he declined an invitation to be interrogated in the tented media center.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: QUOVADX TO BUY CARESCIENCE FOR $28 MILLION Quovadx Inc., the software company, said yesterday that it had a definitive agreement to buy CareScience Inc. in a $28 million cash and stock deal, bolstering its presence in the medical industry. CareScience provides technology to hospitals and drug makers that helps patient care, supporting more than 170 provider organizations in 34 states. Under terms of the deal Quovadx is offering $1.40 in cash and 0.1818 of its shares for every CareScience share held. This values CareScience at $14 million. The rest of the deal is in the form of cash in CareScience's balance sheet. Quovadx said the deal will bolster its 2004 earnings, with most of the benefits from cost savings and cross-selling products. First Albany is advising Quovadx while William Blair acted as financial adviser to CareScience. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEVENS, CHARLES
description: DEVENS--Charles. Of Milton, MA died on August 13, 2003, at age 93, in Prouts Neck, ME. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Chace Emmet, three children, Charles Devens, Jr. of Essex, MA, Edith D. Iler of Beverly, MA and Robert S. Devens of New York, eight grandchildren and one great grandchild. His wife of 64 years, Edith Wolcott Devens, died in 1998 and a son, William L. Devens, died in 1968. A private service will be held.

title: Stinking Garbage, How I Miss It
description: NOSTALGIA knows no bounds. People get all misty eyed over itchy school uniforms, repulsive camp food or a childhood bout with the measles. Find a scourge that's been eliminated, and you are sure to find someone waxing nostalgic. Which is, I admit, the way I feel about garbage dumps.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rights Office Robbed
description: Two men broke into a St. Petersburg office of Memorial, Russia's leading human rights organization, in what the group said appeared to be a politically motivated attack. The men bound three people, locked them in a closet and stole computers, a Memorial director, Irina A. Flige, said in a telephone interview. Vladimir E. Shnidke, one of those in the office, told the radio station Ekho Moskvi that the men claimed to represent a group supporting Col. Yuri D. Budanov, an Army colonel convicted last month of murdering a woman in Chechnya. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Data Show Recessions In Germany And Italy
description: Germany and Italy slipped into recession in the second quarter, as the economies of the 12 nations that share the euro stagnated, according to government reports published today.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Dam Plan Pullout
description: The world's largest independent power producer, the AES of Arlington, Va., said that it would not build a $500 million dam at Bujagali Falls on the Nile. Frustrated by protests and a nearly decade-long delay, the company pulled out of what would have been the largest foreign investment project ever in East Africa. Environmental advocates celebrated but the World Bank said that it continued to thing that the dam is the best way to increase Uganda's power supply. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Power Failure Keeps Mets Off the Field
description: When the area's power failure struck at Shea Stadium yesterday, emergency lighting let the Mets players see one another inside their clubhouse.

title: A Land Governed by Film Stars
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger has farther to go than he thinks. He may become governor of California, but he can't become God. That privilege is reserved for the Indian movie-star-turned-politician N. T. Rama Rao, who played so many mythological heroes in so many hit films that fans built a temple to him.

title: With Plumbers' Candles and Guest Traffic Cops, Region Perseveres
description: Rob Latoff tried to get a ride to New Jersey by waving a $50 bill at the Lincoln Tunnel and having his 9-year-old daughter smile at passing cars.

title: Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: ATI AND MICROSOFT SIGN PACT ON XBOX COMPONENTS ATI Technologies said yesterday that it had signed a contract with Microsoft to produce components for future versions of the Xbox game console, beating out the market leader, Nvidia. ATI said it had entered a technology agreement with Microsoft to develop "custom, leading-edge graphics technologies" for the console. "We selected ATI after reviewing the top graphics technologies in development and determining that ATI's technical vision fits perfectly with the future direction of Xbox," Robbie Bach, senior vice president of Microsoft's home and entertainment division, said. The announcement ends months of speculation over whether Nvidia, the leading maker of graphics processors for PC's, would renew its troubled partnership with Microsoft on the Xbox. The graphics processor is the most expensive component in the Xbox, and Nvidia stood poised for a major windfall after the chipmaker won the contract shortly after the Xbox was announced three years ago. But sales problems and hardware changes left Nvidia with piles of unsold and unusable chips, putting it in a position where it could have lost money on the console if it had not submitted the Microsoft contract to arbitration. The Xbox deal has accounted for 15 percent to 20 percent of Nvidia's sales the last two years, and company executives credited Xbox-related business for a surge in profit during Nvidia's most recent quarter. Analysts had predicted the contract for the next Xbox might go to ATI, which also makes the graphics processor for Nintendo's GameCube. Microsoft has yet to set a date or reveal details on the successor to the current Xbox, despite rampant speculation from fans and game makers. While Microsoft will need to deliver new technology that can compete with Sony's successor to the PlayStation 2, it is also probably looking for ways to cut costs after after taking significant losses on the Xbox. (CNETnews.com)

title: Trying On the Familiar, and Liking It
description: At Brooks Brothers last week, a clutch of designers and buyers leafed through catalogs from the store's more glorious past. There was the camel's hair coat with the belt in the back (1956). The sack suit that John F. Kennedy loved (1961). The cordovan lace-ups, made of special hide from the rear end of a horse (1954). And what about that heavily starched evening shirt, with cotton piqu front and a detachable collar almost as hard as a ruler (1904)?

title: Westchester Ordered to Pay $2,500 to Pedophile Clown
description: Westchester County must pay a convicted pedophile $2,500 for barring him in the past from performing as a clown at the county-owned Playland Amusement Park in Rye, under a federal court ruling this week.

title: Guilt and Doubt Cast Shadows on a Sunny Future
description: Richard Dreyfuss and Jill Clayburgh are actors whose screen roles have associated them with intelligence and wit. From ''The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz'' to ''American Graffiti'' to ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' to ''The Goodbye Girl'' to ''Mr. Holland's Opus'' to the recent, short-lived television series ''The Education of Max Bickford,'' Mr. Dreyfuss has portrayed brainy, or at least smart-alecky characters: fast-talking and clever or well educated and thoughtful.

title: U.S. Will Keep Penalties Against Libya, Officials Say
description: Bush administration officials said today that even if the United Nations lifted sanctions against Libya the United States would keep its own in place because of Libya's lethal weapons programs and other activities.

title: Introduction of Nonnative Oysters Into Bay Should Wait, Study Says
description: The National Academy of Sciences issued a long-awaited report today recommending that Maryland and Virginia conduct more extensive studies of a species of Asian oyster before introducing them in large numbers into the Chesapeake Bay for breeding.

title: Get the H2 To Church On Time
description: A VAN was blocking the circular driveway at the Stamford Marriott in Connecticut as the bridegroom, Colin Arsenault, and his groomsmen climbed aboard the 28-foot-long, 22-passenger Hummer H2 limousine that would carry them to the wedding in Fairfield. ''No problem,'' someone said. ''Just drive over it.''

title: The Movie Set
description: Much of the business in the courthouses around Foley Square in lower Manhattan came to a standstill, but one thing did not stop: a movie called ''Laws of Attraction'' that was filming in front of the State Supreme Court at 60 Centre Street. The film, a romantic comedy set in the world of divorce lawyers, starring Pierce Brosnan and Julianne Moore, was in its first day of shooting, said the director, Peter Howitt.

title: Where Small Shows Offer Big Ideas
description: IF I had to choose between a steady diet of big shows or small ones, I'd go for small. I know what's good about blockbusters. They give museumgoers a certified bang for their buck, institutions a chance to flex some muscle and curators an excuse to go a little wild with a budget. But too many big shows exist on carbohydrates, bulked up for size rather than agility. Slogging through hundreds of paintings, even by an artist you love -- I'm thinking of Vuillard in Washington last season, but I would include Picasso-Matisse at the Modern -- can leave you wondering what the attraction ever was.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Trade Proposal Criticized
description: Japan, Australia and India criticized proposals made by the United States and the European Union to remove barriers to global trading in farm products. The proposal, presented Wednesday as a framework for discussions at the World Trade Organization meeting next month in Cancn, Mexico, sets out a framework on farm subsidies, tariffs and export aid. Japan, which wants to maintain its tariff on rice and reduce the amount of rice imports, will insist that its stance be reflected in the negotiations, Japan's farm minister Yoshiyuki Kamei, said. The Australian trade minister, Mark Vaile, above, said the proposals cause serious concerns, primarily because they lack specific figures. India's ambassador to the trade organization, K.M. Chandrasekhar, said, ''I think it isn't feasible for us. It doesn't take account of the needs of our farmers.'' Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Rate Cut

The bank cut the rate to 11 percent, well above comparable rates in the United States and Europe, and analysts said the South African currency, the rand, is unlikely to retreat from a recent rally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENSTEIN, NEIL
description: ROSENSTEIN--Neil. It is with great sadness that the family of Neil Rosenstein reports his death. Neil was courageous, optimistic and determined in his sudden and brief battle with pancreatic cancer. He died Saturday, August 9th, at home in Carmel, CA at the age of 77. Born in The Bronx in 1926 to Adele and Arnold Rosenstein, Neil was a proud alumna of the City College of New York, class of 1942 (BBA). An enthusiastic and proud New Yorker for 43 years, Neil resided in Manhattan and Long Island before relocating to Beverly Hills,CA in 1969. He lived in Beverly Hills for 25 years until his retirement to Carmel, CA. Neil had a varied and successful business career, including being Chairman of the Board of National Sugar Refining Company (1969-1971), and Founder, Chairman and President of Jackpot Enterprises, Inc from 1980-1993. He is deeply loved by his family and will be remembered as a kind and generous man with an extraordinary sense of humor and charismatic charm. He was a student of history, a patriot, an avid reader, an indefatigable sports fan, a world traveler, art collector, lover of opera, poker and backgammon and a below average golfer. Neil was a brilliant man who left us too soon. Beloved husband of Miriam, his wife of 53 years; devoted father to Arnold Rosenstein, Carol Rosenstein, and Diane Rosenstein; loving grandfather of Brian Rosenstein and Katharine Rose Polk. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Community Hospital of Monterey Peninsula or the Jules Stein Eye Institute at UCLA.
