description: For some families of those killed in the downing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, Libya's acknowledgment today that it accepted responsibility for the bombing brought measured expressions of relief that at least part of their 14-year quest for justice had ended.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Skewed Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Politics: Money Flows To Dean Camp
description: Howard Dean said that his Democratic presidential campaign, flush from unexpectedly strong fund-raising this spring, was considering whether to drop out of the federal campaign finance system, which provides money to presidential campaigns in exchange for spending limits. Mr. Dean said it was unlikely that his campaign would ultimately take this approach. He said it had been under discussion by senior advisers after his aides realized, to their surprise, how much money Mr. Dean appeared to be capable of raising. Adam Nagourney (NYT)

title: Rumpled and Groggy, Wall Street Resumes Trading
description: Wall Street traders are not known for their sartorial splendor on their best days and yesterday certainly was not one of them. On the morning after a blackout that left the hub of the financial markets without power, hundreds of traders, many unwashed and most of them groggy from lack of sleep or arduous commutes, staggered to their posts at the New York Stock Exchange and brokerage firms around the city.

title: An Extended Extension for Filing Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it had extended for one week the Aug. 15 deadline for people and businesses in the blackout areas who obtained an extension to file their 2002 income tax returns.

title: Libya Admits Attack On Jetliner in 1988
description: Libya formally accepted responsibility for the bombing of a jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, pledging compensation to families of the 270 victims and opening the way for the lifting of U.N. sanctions.

title: Colleagues Shiver From Chill of Bid to Recall Davis
description: Gov. Mike Johanns of Nebraska seems torn when it comes to the recall election that is taking place in California, half a country away.

title: A Treasure Hunt For Lost Memories
description: Twenty years ago, an anthropologist named Teresa Porzecanski placed an advertisement in a Jewish newspaper serving this distant compass point of the Diaspora. She was looking for the residue of an unrecorded history, the letters and snapshots of tens of thousands of immigrants from Eastern Europe and the Ottoman Empire.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Allows Nazi Rally
description: Citing the right of freedom of assembly, the Constitutional Court ruled that neo-Nazis be allowed to march today near the tomb of Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy. The authorities in the Bavarian town of Wunsiedel had banned the rally out of fear that it would attract counterdemonstrators and turn into a riot. Last year, nearly 2,500 far-right sympathizers gathered near Wunsiedel's cemetery to mark the anniversary of Hess's death. Hess, sentenced to life in prison at the Nuremberg trials, committed suicide in Spandau prison in Berlin in 1987 and is regarded by the far right as a martyr. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: How India's Mother of Invention Built an Industry
description: LIKE father, like daughter, Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw thought in the 1970's, when she set out to become a brew master just as her father had been. She left India to train in Australia, then returned home to find that daughters were not welcome in India's breweries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIELICH, EDITH
description: FRIELICH--Edith on August 15, 2003 in her 93rd year. Beloved wife of the late Lester Deutsch and Meyer Frielich. Devoted mother of Jay and Rose Deutsch. Loving grandmother of Ellen Diamond and Karen Lustig. Cherished great-grandmother of Trevor and Phoebe Diamond and Lily Lustig. Services Sunday August 17 at 11 A.M. at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels at 152 Second Avenue (at 10 Street) New York, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGLER, BERL
description: ENGLER--Berl. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of it's devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Amy Lemle, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

title: This Time, Fewer Arrests As the City Stayed Dark
description: New York City was a crime scene waiting to happen, the imposed darkness offering a nearly perfect opportunity for those inclined to help themselves to whatever their neighborhoods had to offer: computers, jewelry, groceries, cellular phones. No cash, just carry.

title: Dana Accuses Suitor Of Violating Pact
description: The Dana Corporation filed a lawsuit yesterday against the ArvinMeritor Corporation, accusing it of violating a 2001 confidentiality agreement between the companies.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; A Class Act
description: To the Editor:

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Simplify, Simplify
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Debt Extension
description: The Elan Corporation, the Irish drug maker, paid to get a third extension from creditors as it tries to avoid defaulting on as much as $2 billion in debt. Elan paid debtholders $2.1 million to waive their right to demand early repayment until Aug. 22, giving it more time to file its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said. This is the first time that the Dublin-based company has had to pay investors for an extension. Elan failed to file its annual report by the June 29 deadline, allowing certain investors to ask for repayment sooner than expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKLAR, BERNARD
description: SKLAR--Bernard, 81, died on August 14, 2003. Dear husband, father, grandfather and brother. Services Sunday 10AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Which Party Gets the Blame? They Agree: It's the Other One
description: With tens of millions of Americans left powerless, the blackout gave Democrats what they hoped would be a huge new political opportunity -- and they wasted little time in seizing it.

title: Shiite Group Plans Militia to Protect Holy Sites From G.I.'s
description: The most combative group of Shiite Muslims announced during their main prayer sermon today that they would proceed with a proposal to form their own militia to safeguard holy sites from any transgressions by American troops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARNEDOE, KIRK
description: VARNEDOE--Kirk. The International Council of the Museum of Modern Art is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Kirk Varnedoe. Kirk was a cherished friend who generously shared his extraordinary knowledge, his inspired passion for art, and his incredible gift for life with people around the world. He will be sorely missed. We extend our profound sympathy to his wife Elyn Zimmerman, his brothers Samuel and Gordon Varnedoe, and his sister Comer Meadows. Sir Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: CREDIT CARD LOSSES The country's nine credit card companies lost three trillion won ($2.6 billion) in the first six months as a result of rising household debts, according to the Financial Supervisory Service, the agency that regulates the financial industry. The biggest loser was LG Card, which reported a loss of 747 billion won ($642 million) in contrast to a net profit of 356 billion won in the first six months of last year. Samsung Card lost 643 billion won and Kookmin Credit lost 487 billion won. Nine percent of Korean cardholders were delinquent on payments as of June 30, compared with 6.6 percent as of Dec. 31, 2002.   Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Crisis Gives Mayor a Stage To Show Leadership Skills
description: There he was again. On the television, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was advising New Yorkers to drink lots of water and check on their pets. On the radio, he was explaining the breakdown of the power grid.

title: In a River in Louisiana, Sharks Love Cajun Food
description: Near the beginning of ''Red Water,'' tomorrow night on TBS, two winsome nymphs in bikinis are swimming in a Louisiana river. One says: ''I feel something. Shark. Shaaaark! Aaaah! Aaaaaah! Aaaaaaaaah!'' She vanishes below the surface, pops up again covered with blood, then drops out of sight permanently.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Why Did It Happen?
description: To the Editor:

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Exit in the Bronx For an Aspiring Star
description: Bethanie Mattek is not arrogant when she talks about her abilities on the tennis court, but she said it is not a stretch to think that in only four years she will be one of the top players in the world with a handful of Grand Slam titles. Then again, she's only 18.

title: Depression Alert
description: A young woman who said her name was Cassie stood on the corner of 32nd Street and Second Avenue outside LaBella's Restaurant on Thursday night, where she held up a sign written on the inside of a torn pizza carton. It said: ''Need Effexor.'' She said she had left her antidepressant in her handbag at her office, and first wanted to try her luck on the street corner before heading over to the New York University Medical Center emergency room a block east. ROSALIE RADOMSKY

title: Interest-Only Plans Catch On As Curb to Mortgage Payments
description: Rising mortgage rates are driving borrowers to take out loans in which their monthly payments for the first few years are used to pay only the interest, according to lenders, brokers and real estate agents nationwide.

title: Melted Ice Cream Is Just the Beginning
description: Grocery companies reported dozens of stores closed and products from ice cream to fish filets ruined as the power failure wore on yesterday. It was not possible to calculate the full cost of the losses yesterday -- although they are expected to reach the millions -- as store managers and company executives scrambled to assess the damage.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Blackout's Greatest Cost May Be Just Inconvenience

title: Study Finds Atmospheric Decline in Pesticide Harmful to Ozone
description: Government scientists have measured a significant drop in atmospheric levels of methyl bromide, a versatile pesticide that is being phased out of use because it damages the planet's protective ozone layer.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Science Times on Tuesday about the possibility of a connection between bats and a form of dementia misstated the affiliation of a researcher, Dr. Paul A. Cox. He is director of the National Tropical Botanical Garden in Hawaii. (His co-author, Dr. Sandra Anne Banack, is at California State University, Fullerton.)

title: Warnings Long Ignored On Aging Electric System
description: For years, the nation's electrical engineers and planners have warned that the North American system of transmitting electricity was becoming the orphan of the digital era, approaching a serious failure if not significantly upgraded.

title: Enough Troubles
description: Albert King, an immigrant from Liberia, came into the city on Thursday from his home in East Orange, N.J., to attend a meeting at the Catholic Center on his immigrant status and to look for a job. When the lights went out, he headed straight to the Port Authority. But none of the jitney bus drivers were going to New Jersey. There were no other options. He fell into a bar near Bryant Park and stayed there until he and others were kicked out, and then got a fitful night's sleep in Bryant Park.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; What Did We Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bright Dawn for Some, Hangover for Others
description: The new day dawned for the fortunate in New York City like a found holiday in August: a mayor-mandated snow day, fully air-conditioned and blessed with a blazing blue sky. For the unlucky, alas, it was nothing of the sort. It was the maddening epilogue to a bad dream from which they could not seem to escape. It was a hangover, no coffee in sight.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Card Losses
description: The country's nine credit card companies lost three trillion won ($2.6 billion) in the first six months as a result of rising household debts, according to the Financial Supervisory Service, the agency that regulates the financial industry. The biggest loser was LG Card, which reported a loss of 747 billion won ($642 million) in contrast to a net profit of 356 billion won in the first six months of last year. Samsung Card lost 643 billion won and Kookmin Credit lost 487 billion won. Nine percent of Korean cardholders were delinquent on payments as of June 30, compared with 6.6 percent as of Dec. 31, 2002. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Comatose Transit System Awakens, Slowly
description: In fits and starts, the region's transportation system began to stagger back to life yesterday, as traffic lights suddenly picked up where they had left off, cabbies switched their meters back on, packed buses substituted for subways and roaring diesel trains rolled to the rescue on powerless commuter lines.

title: Beliefs; A divided Episcopal Church? Yes indeed, a study says, but in ways perhaps unexpected.
description: Is the Episcopal Church tottering on the brink of schism or even self-destruction, theologically and ideologically fractured, like many American religious groups, over homosexuality and other issues prominent in the nation's culture wars?

title: National Briefing: New England
description: FLORIDA: LAW LIMITS MALPRACTICE DAMAGES Gov. Jeb Bush signed into law a bill that caps damages in medical malpractice cases as a way to lower insurance rates and to help the state retain doctors. The Legislature approved the measure on Wednesday. Republican legislative leaders agreed to it last week after months of fighting over how to set caps on noneconomic damages like pain and suffering. The measure limits a doctor's liability for noneconomic damages in most medical malpractice cases to $500,000. A medical facility's liability is limited to $750,000 in most cases.   (AP)

title: Navigating Rails, Streets And the Air
description: Air travel and mass transit continue to be affected by the blackout. Commuters can contact their local bus or transit lines for updates on service.

title: Anywhere Free
description: Near the end of Shore Road in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the express buses were arriving at a stop every few minutes yesterday morning, ferrying passengers from near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Downtown and Midtown Manhattan. A little before 8 a.m., about a dozen people suddenly appeared. A dispatcher asked their destination but got no reaction. As he added that the normally $4 ride would be free, several people surged forward, still unsure of which bus to take.

title: Restoring Lost Voltage Takes Time, and a Complex Choreography
description: If only it were as simple as flipping the switch.

title: The Day the Lights Went Out; We're All On the Grid Together
description: Once power is fully restored, it will take little time to find the culprit: most likely, it will be a malfunctioning switch or fuse, a snapped power line or some other local failure. Somebody will be fired, promotions and raises denied, and lawmakers will draw up legislation guaranteeing that this problem will not occur again.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Communications Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURSI, NOEL
description: TURSI--Noel. On August 12th, 2003. Active and brilliant in real estate and investments. Adored husband of Celeste Martin, dear friend of Stephen Leung, devoted father of Genevieve Leahy and Noel Tursi, Jr. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Beloved uncle of Betiayn Tursi, dearest brother-in-law of Francine Tursi. Reposing at Guidetti Funeral Home, 33 Spring Street, NYC on Friday, 7-9PM and Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Edmund's Church (Avenue T and Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn) on Tuesday, 10:15AM. Entombment, Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Lawsuit Opposes Expansion Of School for Gay Students
description: State Senator Ruben Diaz Sr. of the Bronx has filed a lawsuit to block the expansion of a small public high school for gay students, arguing that the school violates the City Department of Education's antidiscrimination policies and the constitutional rights of heterosexual students.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Evicted Hotel Guests
description: To the Editor:

title: Camp Marriott
description: The New York Marriott Marquis proved to be heartbreak hotel for a group of 125 State Farm Insurance representatives from New England and upstate New York. They were the lucky winners of a three-day ''reward trip'' to Manhattan, but after the blackout their prize was eviction from the hotel Thursday at 7:30 p.m., with more than 1,500 other guests.

title: Getting Off the Ground Remains a Big Challenge
description: Airports from New York to Los Angeles turned into campgrounds yesterday as passengers struggled, often unsuccessfully, to satisfy weekend plans or simply return home.

title: Baghdad on the Blackout: A Path to Enlightenment?
description: For people who woke up this morning, as usual, without electricity for their televisions, it took a while to hear the news of the lightning bolt or whatever gremlin turned out the lights in America. But by noon the word had spread, and Baghdad was a city awash in schadenfreude.

title: Editors' Note; The Blackout
description: Coverage of the power failure and its effects will be found today in a special section, starting on Page B1.

title: U.S. Team Loses Champion On Eve of World Meet
description: On the eve of the world gymnastics championships, the United States women's team lost a star today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am embarrassed.''

title: Scouts Looking at Rejects for Talent
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 15  They came equipped to Giants Stadium tonight with binoculars, stop watches, tape recorders, charts, graphs, color-coded sheets, an array of colored pens and keen eyes. They were bunched together in far corner of the stadium press box that was hard to see inside  but they could certainly see outside.

title: Harold Altman, 79, Printmaker, Painter and Professor of Art
description: Harold Altman, a painter, printmaker and lithographer whose work was shown internationally and in major American museums including the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art, died on July 28 in State College, Pa. He was 79.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: New President Pledges Corruption Fight
description: Pledging to combat the endemic corruption that has made his country one of the poorest in Latin America and led American officials to describe it as a haven for Islamic terrorists, Nicanor Duarte Frutos, a 46-year-old journalist, was sworn in as president. On Thursday, a judge barred his predecessor, Luis Gonzlez Macchi, from leaving the country until the conclusion of a judicial investigation into several accusations of corruption, including a suspect $16 million bank transfer. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Known to Everyone and No One
description: Note to self: ''Did he ever see the ocean?'' I scribbled this sometime in 1999, as I was beginning work on a biography of Isaac Newton. In due course such obscure questions accumulated, possibly trivial but increasingly disturbing. When did the architect of the clockwork universe first encounter a clock? Did he ever make love?

title: Journeyman Leads as Oak Hill Has No Mercy
description: The year's final major tournament may end up being the most grueling. Through 36 holes of the P.G.A. Championship, only three players remained under par -- barely. Oak Hill Country Club has punished the field, with rough that feels like handcuffs and greens that are getting firmer by the second.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: When You Get Caught Between a Clear Moon And New York City . . .
description: In a New York blackout, a leisurely gaze at the twinkling heavens comes at a price.

title: THE BLACKOUT OF 2003
description: Opportunity Spikes

title: Coke Equipment Supplier Cooperating in U.S. Inquiry
description: The Lancer Corporation, a major equipment supplier to the Coca-Cola Company, said today that federal prosecutors in Atlanta had sought information from the company in connection with a criminal investigation involving Coke.

title: Uncertainty Leaves Many Factories Shut
description: Even as power was restored in some places yesterday, many companies resisted opening plants until they could be certain that power was not just available, but reliable.

title: Experts Asking Why Problems Spread So Far
description: The power collapse that stilled a large swath of North America Thursday apparently began with a failure in the Midwest that cascaded into Canada, and from there into New York, power industry officials said yesterday. They said they were trying to determine why it spread so far.

title: One Good Thing About the Darkness: It Hid All the Trash
description: With offices, stores and restaurants remaining shut yesterday, New York did not produce much of anything but garbage, titanic mountains of pungent trash that baked in the summer sun as sanitation crews tried to clean up the streets before things got worse.

title: Midwest Police Face Trouble With Traffic, Not Looting
description: The widespread power blackout offered a challenge to police departments across the Midwest, which had to contend with snarled traffic, answer false calls from security alarms on the blink, and keep order at gas stations where desperate motorists tried to fill their tanks.

title: James Romano, 56, Curator Of Egyptian Art at Brooklyn
description: James F. Romano, a longtime curator at the Brooklyn Museum of Art who recently finished the reinstallation of the museum's famed Egyptian collection, died on Monday morning in Lynbrook, N.Y., when the car he was driving veered off the road and hit a metal fence. He was 56 and lived in the nearby town of East Rockaway.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Facing Our Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway Is Back, but Many Museums Stay Dark
description: Broadway and the city's other cultural institutions slowly crept back to life yesterday after across-the-board cancellations caused by Thursday's blackout.

title: Lawyers Take Aim Again at Connecticut's Foster Care System
description: Lawyers who sued Connecticut's child welfare agency for negligence more than a decade ago said today that they were considering taking further action against it after several reports cited failures to meet court-mandated goals.

title: California Voters Wonder: Is Anyone Not Running?
description: Bill Simon walked in from the broiling afternoon to the cool onion-scented air of an In-n-Out Burger, a couple of aides at his elbows, on Tuesday. Smiling, he surveyed the clusters of people hunched over their thick, dripping sandwiches. ''How are you?'' Mr. Simon said, holding out his hand to a wary-looking Jesse Young, seated at a table facing the freeway in Stockton, just over 300 miles north of Los Angeles. ''My name's Bill Simon, and I'm running for governor.''

title: Power Virtually All Restored Across State, Hartford Says
description: The blackout of 2003 was more an inconvenience in Connecticut, leaving only fewer than 500 customers still without power as of 11 p.m. today, state officials said. In all, more than 250,000 homes and businesses lost power during the blackout.

title: Glavine (250th Victory) And Mets Looking Sharp
description: For one night, a night sure to be lost among a gloomy year that long ago stopped being important, the Mets played like a good team, won their third straight and were led by a strong outing from Tom Glavine. This was supposed to be the backdrop to many a Met victory at Shea Stadium this season, but it has not been that way. But good news is always welcome, even the kind that is an aberration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, BRONSLOW S.
description: STEVENS--Bronslow S. On August 12, 2003 (formerly of Malverne Oaks) former V.P. of Guy Carpenter Co. Husband of the late Celia. Father of Richard F. and Frances Stevens. Also survived by three grandchildren. For information Malverne Funeral Home, (516) 593-7230.

title: The Giants' First Teams Show Life In Defeat
description: The Giants were pleased that their offense finally kicked into gear, that their defense showed sparks and that their overall effort increased in tonight's preseason game against the Carolina Panthers.

title: Corrections
description: A quotation yesterday serving as the picture caption for the Public Lives profile of Kathy Bronander, a real estate agent in Montclair, N.J., carried an erroneous attribution. As the article reported, it was Burt Bronander, the agent's husband, not she herself, who said, ''When you get the call that says you're not going to get the house, you start to cry and pour yourself a Scotch.''

title: The Day the Lights Went Out; Blackouts, A Rite of New York
description: I never miss a blackout, especially the big ones in 1965, 1977 and that humdinger in 2003. (Well, I have to explain '03.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GITTLESON, ALLAN TOD
description: GITTLESON--Allan Tod. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Chairman Emeritus Allan Tod Gittleson. A generous and dedicated member of the Hofstra University Board of Trustees from 1967, he served as Chair from 1973 through 1975. He was named Chairman Emeritus in 1992. He was founder and CEO of the Hofstra Health Dome. Allan Tod Gittleson Hall, Hofstra's life science building was dedicated in 1979. Mr. Gittleson's concern for the needs of students was evident. He was the creator and a major benefactor of the University's Distinguished Academic Scholar Program, an active supporter of Hofstra's NOAH program for under-represented student populations and of the program for Higher Education of the Disabled. He also helped found the Hofstra School of Law. He is survived by his beloved wife Mildred; daughters June and Nancy, her husband Michael; 3 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. In tribute to the memory of Chairman Emeritus Gittleson, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. A memorial celebration will be held at Hofstra University in September, 2003. Board of Trustees and the President HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Judge Blocks Pledge Law
description: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a Colorado law requiring public school students to recite the Pledge of Allegiance. In issuing an injunction, Judge Lewis Babcock of Federal District Court called the law discriminatory and divisive. It took effect on Aug. 6, and the Colorado chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union later filed a lawsuit on behalf of nine students and teachers. Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican, said he looked forward to ''establishing the constitutionality of this simple and common-sense law'' at trial. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Still Hope for Yankees
description: Trades and injuries have set back the Yankees' once proud minor-league system. JASON ARNOLD, JASON ANDERSON, BRANDON CLAUSSEN and JOHN-FORD GRIFFIN have all been shipped out. Injuries have slowed JON SKAGGS, SEAN HENN and CHIEN-MING WANG. JUAN RIVERA does not appear to be an impact player and DREW HENSON might wear shoulder pads before he plays at Yankee Stadium. And the big-money investments, ADRIAN HERNANDEZ and JACKSON MELIAN, have not panned out.

title: Israel Agrees to Turn Over 2 Cities In West Bank, Aiding Peace Plan
description: Israel agreed tonight to hand over control of the West Bank cities of Jericho and Qalqilya and to allow Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to leave his wrecked compound for the first time in more than a year.

title: Feeling at Home, Fleisher Surges Ahead on Long Island
description: Bruce Fleisher likes playing golf in the New York area. He is intrigued by courses with trees and narrow fairways, and it shows; Fleisher has had more success in the area over the last few years than any other golfer on the Champions Tour.

title: Blackout Trips Up Plans To Promote New Movies
description: Kevin Costner cannot seem to catch a break.

title: Economic Toll 'Devastating,' A Troubled McGreevey Says
description: Electrical service was restored to nearly all New Jersey homes by this afternoon, but the state's roadways, beaches and tourist destinations were still coping with serious disruptions from Thursday's blackout.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Power for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Cellphone Failures Cause Many to Question Systems
description: As cellular telephone carriers labored to restore service yesterday, voices of concern were raised in Washington and elsewhere about the continued fragility of the nation's wireless networks even as the public grows more dependent upon them.

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Getting the Paper Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbecue Heroics
description: The night was looking like a total washout on Thursday at the restaurant Minnow, on Ninth Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, said Aaron Bashy, the chef and owner. The electricity was out, the cooks were icing down the fish to prevent spoiling, and some of the waiters had gone home to check on their cats and dogs. When they returned, Mr. Bashy joked that he ought to just go home and get his barbecue. Someone suggested that that was not such a bad idea.

title: Insurers Say Most Policies Do Not Cover Power Failure
description: Insurance experts said yesterday that there probably was no coverage for most of the business losses resulting from Thursday's power failure, which forced tens of thousands of shops, restaurants and factories to close and widely disrupted airlines and other transportation companies.

title: New York Fraud Ring No Surprise to Russian Drivers
description: New Yorkers may have been shocked on Tuesday by news of a $48 million insurance scheme that involved thousands of fake car crashes. But in Russia, where laws are regularly bent, overlooked or simply ignored, fraud is a rule of the road.

title: About New York; Bright Birds, Dark City? Not This Time
description: SOME of the residents of Avenue I sat on front stoops Thursday night, chatting in the glow of flashlights about the blackout that had enveloped their corner of Brooklyn. But even in this precious moment of conviviality, Janelle Barabash could not help herself; she had to say it.

title: Sports of The Times; Andrade Makes the Best of a Late Invitation
description: BILLY ANDRADE doesn't believe in fate, but he feels there's a reason why he's in this 85th P.G.A. Championship.

title: Lottery Numbers
National Briefing: South
description: COLORADO: SHAM CHECKPOINT RULING Fake police checkpoints can be used to find illegal drugs, a state court of appeals has ruled. The decision reversed a lower court ruling in the case that began in 2000 outside Telluride, where police posted signs warning of a narcotics checkpoint near a bluegrass festival. The police hid and then pulled over anyone who appeared to dispose of narcotics before reaching the checkpoint. Although the appeals court said that drug checkpoints are illegal, it held that in this case the initial cause for the vehicle search was legitimate because Stephen Roth, 60, threw a marijuana pipe from his vehicle and was stopped for littering. Additional narcotics were found in his car.

title: After 2 Years, Energy Bill Is Getting New Urgency in Congress
description: The blackout will give new urgency to an energy plan that has languished in Congress for more than two years, lawmakers said today, and they asserted that elements of the plan aimed at upgrading the power grid will gain in importance.

title: Bard's 9th-Inning Single Leads Indians to Victory
description: Josh Bard hit a one-out, run-scoring single in the ninth inning last night, lifting C.C. Sabathia to his first career shutout as host Cleveland beat Tampa Bay, 1-0.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bank Suspensions Challenged
description: The governor of the Philippine central bank, Rafael Buenaventura, plans to appeal a court's decision to suspend him for a year without pay, his lawyer said. The Philippine Court of Appeals ordered the suspension of Mr. Buenaventura and four other central bank officials after ruling that they were too hasty in closing a local commercial bank in 2000. The officials will be allowed to serve pending their appeals, a process that in the Philippines typically lasts much longer than Mr. Buenaventura has left to serve as bank governor. His term ends in mid-2005. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Congress's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; Calm Prevailed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PASTOR, NINA L.
description: PASTOR--Nina L. Beloved wife of Andrew Brogan, loving mother of Jonathan (Allison) and Michael (Kim-thu), dear sister of Beth Shapiro, devoted aunt of Lisa, beloved cousin of Linda, Marsha, Vita, David and Imani. Services Sunday 12 noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, L.I.

title: Poll Finds Governor's Support Still Eroding and Likens Him to Nixon in '74 Resignation Crisis
description: A new statewide opinion poll shows that Gov. Gray Davis of California continues to lose support in his effort to keep his job, while Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante and Arnold Schwarzenegger, the actor, are at the top of the list of possible successors.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Sham Checkpoint Ruling
description: Fake police checkpoints can be used to find illegal drugs, a state court of appeals has ruled. The decision reversed a lower court ruling in the case that began in 2000 outside Telluride, where police posted signs warning of a narcotics checkpoint near a bluegrass festival. The police hid and then pulled over anyone who appeared to dispose of narcotics before reaching the checkpoint. Although the appeals court said that drug checkpoints are illegal, it held that in this case the initial cause for the vehicle search was legitimate because Stephen Roth, 60, threw a marijuana pipe from his vehicle and was stopped for littering. Additional narcotics were found in his car.

title: The Day the Lights Went Out; An Industry Trapped by a Theory
description: In the search for the source of Thursday's blackout, the underlying cause has been all but ignored: deregulation. In principle, deregulation of the power industry was supposed to use the discipline of free markets to generate just the right amount of electricity at the right price. But electric power, it turns out, is not like ordinary commodities.

title: Carried Away on the Wings of a Bird
description: At this festival's midpoint, a new opera by Hans Werner Henze provides a cool moment of charm. Mr. Henze, at 77, has announced that ''L'Upupa'' -- ''The Hoopoe, and the Triumph of Filial Love'' -- will be his last opera -- his swan song, or rather his hoopoe song, since this is the bird of the Italian title, the bird brought into the music by electronic clatterings of wings that interrupt the orchestral score every now and then.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Black-Market Passports
description: The Foreign Ministry announced the recall and arrest of two officials at the Argentine Embassy in Havana, charged with selling Argentine passports on the black market to Cubans seeking to emigrate to the United States. Until recently, Argentines could enter the United States without visas, which made Argentine passports highly valuable to Latin Americans without that right. Larry Rohter (NYT)

One person's spontaneous candlelight dinner is another's nightmare commute. New Yorkers are perhaps best prepared for this phenomenon, since they know from experience that a giant parade or the Independence Day fireworks can mean the best day of your life (the people! the spectacle! the music!) while someone on the next block is going through hell on earth (the crowd! the noise! what happened to my purse?). It's all a matter of luck and temperament.

title: The Great Blackout; Rippling Down the Grid
description: It seems almost unbelievable that an electrical grid whose reliability had supposedly been bolstered after severe blackouts in 1965 and 1977 nevertheless failed in a matter of seconds on Thursday, leaving much of the Northeast, upper Midwest and Canada without electricity. Whatever the initiating event may prove to be -- experts think the collapse started in the Midwest -- the most disturbing failure was the inability of the system to isolate the damage before it could spread. It is not enough to dismiss the blackout as a rare event or a freak accident. The grid clearly needs better protection against catastrophic failures or, in an age of terrorism, against a deliberate act of sabotage.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: MOROCCO: SEPARATISTS TO RELEASE PRISONERS The Polisario Front, a guerrilla group that has been fighting a 30-year war for independence of the contested territory of Western Sahara, said it would release 243 Moroccan prisoners at the "renewed urging of the Spanish president, Jose Maria Aznar, as a humanitarian gesture," the Spanish news agency EFE reported. The move follows a call by the United Nations Security Council last month for a referendum on the future of Western Sahara, a former Spanish colony. Almost 1,000 Moroccan soldiers and officers are still being held by the Polisario, human rights groups estimate. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: ANDY LAND
description: 'The childlike, gum-chewing navet, the glamour rooted in despair, the self-admiring carelessness, the perfected otherness, the wispiness, the shadowy, voyeuristic, vaguely sinister aura, the pale, soft-spoken magical presence, the skin and bones.'' So goes the oral self-portrait that Andy Warhol treated a pal to in a sometimes hilarious, sometimes touching, always spellbinding phone call that he recorded and then printed in his ''philosophy'' book. The descriptions are, of course, his own appropriation of the ways in which he was portrayed in the media. Someone else might have been angry to be depicted as a kind of weirdo, but you never heard Warhol griping about his image. He went at it like a cat to a piece of string. He even told his telephone buddy, ''I'm everything my scrapbook says I am.''

title: The Agony Of The Ecstasy And The Ecstasy Of The Agony: The Game

Either way -- Guilty Pleasure or Righteous Pain -- we feel awful. That, evidently, seems to be the side effect of 2/3 well, life. With this in mind, we invite you to play the Agony of the Ecstasy and Vice Versa. The object of the game is to be the first to reach Moderate Satisfaction. title: What a Year a Win Can Make
description: Almost exactly a year ago, a 5-foot-8, brown-haired 32-year-old golfer from El Paso, Tex., named Rich Beem altered the course of his life by completing eight days of tournament golf better than anyone in the world. On Aug. 4, he shot a final-round 63 to win the International, took a week off, then returned Aug. 15 to the P.G.A. Championship, the year's final major event, which he won three days later by beating a field that included 98 of the world's Top 100 players. Last month, as two unknowns jumped into golf's limelight with unlikely victories at other major championships -- Hillary Lunke's playoff victory at the U.S. Women's Open and Ben Curtis's breakthrough at the British Open -- it was impossible not to think of Beem's surprise triumph and, as he prepared to defend his P.G.A. starting this past week at Oak Hill Country Club in Rochester, N.Y., the yearlong whirlwind it created.

It's a cheerleader movie or, better yet, a comic book. It's a round restaurant that rotates, a trampoline, ice cream with sprinkles, chick lit, spike heels. So we asked Andrea Sachs -- the heroine in Lauren Weisberger's roman  clef, ''The Devil Wears Prada'' -- to illuminate the phenomenon, which has every editor in 4 Times Square bent over a laptop at Starbucks.

title: Honky-Tonk Angels
description: Deana Carter: Deana is not from the dynasty where Mother Maybelle Carter ruled the roost, but she is a real live Nashville native nonetheless. Her dad is the guitarist Fred Carter Jr., who played with Dylan, Elvis and many, many et ceteras. But it's Deana who asked the musical question that has burned in women's brains since the dawn of time: ''Did I Shave My Legs for This?'' Roberto Cavalli paillette sequined dress, $1,495, to order. At Roberto Cavalli, 711 Madison Avenue. Erickson Beamon earrings. Stephen Dweck ring.

title: At the Top, Pay and Performance Are Often Far Apart
description: Chief executives, be warned: Graef Crystal's calculator is humming again. And the latest statistical salvo from Mr. Crystal, that relentless tallier of corporate pay, could give them red faces to match their bulging wallets.

title: New Building Proposal By Great Neck Hasidim
description: Chabad Lubavitch of Great Neck, the Orthodox Hasidic Jewish group that wants to build a sanctuary and community center on land it owns in Kings Point, submitted a scaleddown proposal to the village but was issued a lengthy list of additional restrictions in return, said Charles Segal, Chabad's general counsel.

title: Talks Stall on the Security Transfer of 2 West Bank Cities
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, Aug. 18  Israeli and Palestinian commanders failed to reach an agreement late Sunday night over Israel's planned transfer to Palestinian security control of two West Bank cities, even though both sides had shown some new flexibility to try to thwart a feared outbreak of violence.

title: Business People; A Designer Ponders A Show on Clothes, On and Off the Models
description: Nicole Miller, the fashion designer, is not exactly a reality-TV fan. (She watched about five minutes of ''The Osbournes,'' which, she said, was enough.) But she has respect for Rocco DiSpirito, the chef whose struggle to open a restaurant is the subject of an NBC show.

title: Subways Run, Planes Fly, As Bloomberg Shifts Focus To Communication Lapses
description: After more than 30 hours of sitting where the blackout had stranded them, subway trains began rolling again early yesterday morning, among the last holdouts as the metropolitan region regained electrical power and life returned mostly to normal.

title: Far Beneath the Waves, Salvagers Find History That's Laden With Gold
description: It sailed from New York on Oct. 18, 1865, carrying 59 passengers and a cargo of hope bound for a once-confident New Orleans now recovering from Civil War traumas. The storm hit off Georgia. For two days, the steamship battled hurricane winds and giant waves. Then the engine failed and the paddle wheels went dead. The crew and passengers heaved cargo overboard to lighten the ship. But the pumps failed and seawater poured into the hold.

title: Call of the Census
description: THE first question one might have about Zoe's by the Lake is ''Where's the lake?''

title: An Old Diamond in the Rough Faces a Possible Makeover
description: Gramercy Park, with its wrought-iron gates and leafy trees, oozes with sleepy, old-world charm. But residents may soon get a hip new neighbor.

title: With Piazza in the Lineup, The Mets Continue Their Roll
description: Now that Mike Piazza is ahead of him in the Mets' batting order, Cliff Floyd is very tempted to keep playing baseball. But he has decided he will end his season tomorrow to have his Achilles' tendon fixed. A full season with Piazza is even more tempting.

title: Navigating The New Mortgages
description: AFTER steadily declining over the past few years, mortgage interest rates are now moving upward, and mortgage lenders eager to maintain market share are beginning to offer novel ways to attract new customers.

title: Visiting Israel
description: To the Editor: Notwithstanding Ms. Zaslowsky's decidedly rose-colored account of her recent trip to Israel, until such time as the Palestinian people enjoy a recognized sovereign state, no one, Jew or non-Jew, should visit Israel -- not out of fear, but out of a sense of justice. In the meantime, her Rodney King-like ''Why can't we all just get along?'' outlook is misplaced.

title: Kathleen Heins, Peter Watson
description: Kathleen Marie Heins and Peter John Watson were married yesterday in Sooke, British Columbia. Kerry Fedosenko, a marriage commissioner for British Columbia, officiated at the Sooke Harbour House, an inn on Vancouver Island.

title: POSTINGS: Mormon Chapel Planned for East 87th; A 60's Paragon Of Brutalism To Be Replaced
description: Seemingly unusable and somewhat unloved, one of New York's most arresting works of 1960's Brutalist architecture -- a forceful, concrete-clad evocation of Le Corbusier -- is about to be demolished.

title: Pennington Looks Sharp as First Team Clicks
description: There will be plenty of time when the games start to count to determine how well the Jets' offense will survive the loss of Laveranues Coles to the Redskins. But tonight, in a preseason game against the New Orleans Saints, quarterback Chad Pennington looked as if he had moved on just fine.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: In Spanish

title: Dog Days
description: Back in the day, an expression that according to my son can mean either last week or the moment in 1517 when Martin Luther nailed his 95 theses to the cathedral door and began the Reformation but that in this case refers to the mid-1950's, hamburgers had underground cachet. The elite never admitted to eating them, but everybody cool did, from Jughead (America's first slacker) in the Archie comics to Kerouac and Cassady. Hot dogs were nowheresville, eaten only by baseball umpires. In the semi-holy war of hamburgers versus hot dogs, you could choose your friends by their preference: burgers were for winners, dogs were for also-rans.

title: For the First Time, A Casino Balks at a Project
description: Since its establishment in 1984, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority has awarded grants totaling $960 million to projects of all sorts around the state though primarily in the Atlantic City area. Its mission is to take between 1.25 and 2.5 percent of the gross revenue of the Atlantic City casinos and invest it in projects that enhance the quality of life in New Jersey.

title: Mortgage Markets Are Out Of Control
description: SINCE interest rates began surging a few weeks back, the folks wearing the rose-colored shades have said the climb is proof that an economic recovery is nigh.

title: Some Health Discounts May Be No Bargain
description: WHEN Mary Crownover saw a flier for a program called MediSavers that advertised savings of up to 80 percent on medical care and prescription drugs, for a one-time broker fee of $29, she thought it was too good to pass up. It was late 2001 and Ms. Crownover was uninsured and more than a year away from qualifying for Medicare. Her MediSavers card sat in her wallet until one evening last April, when chest pains sent her to the hospital emergency room near her home in St. Charles, Mo. She presented her card and then spent the night undergoing tests at the hospital.

title: Protecting Commercial Aircraft
description: Much has been done to tighten aviation security in the United States since Sept. 11, including the hardening of cockpits, more meticulous passenger screening and the posting of armed marshals on many domestic flights. Yet dangers persist. That was highlighted last week by the F.B.I.'s arrest of a man who was charged with trying to sell a shoulder-fired missile to a bureau informant who posed as a terrorist wanting to down a commercial jetliner.

title: 2 Killed in Queens Crash
description: Two men were killed Friday night when the speeding car they were in ran a red light in Hillside, Queens, swerved to avoid another vehicle and slammed into a wall, the police said.

title: Reagan Airport: Trying To Make It Handier
description: FOR lawmakers and lobbyists and anyone else with business to do in the nation's capital, no airport is more convenient than Reagan Washington National Airport, four miles from the White House and just across the Potomac from much of the rest of the federal government.

title: Sex, Lies and Octane
description: NEWLY settled residents of New Jersey learn to accept our state's full-service fueling law with the same type of oh-well resignation that new Bostonians reserve for that city's no-selling-liquor-on-Sundays regulation: At first it seems a senseless antiquity. Then it settles into a minor, wholly manageable quirk. And finally it fails to merit notice at all.

title: City Slickers
description: 'Green Acres' is not the only place to be in sophisticated furs and feathers. But these Tinseltown transplants, Seann William Scott and Estella Warren, sure look swell for fish out of water.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: TYRONE POWER is the handsome, serious man accused of an elderly woman's murder in Billy Wilder's splendid courtroom drama WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION (1957). The two met when he advised her on hats, suggesting that the word of the month ''metrosexual'' may be new but the type isn't. Charles Laughton is his ailing but determined lawyer. Elsa Lanchester is the nurse who chases him around to give him calcium injections and restrict his brandy intake. Marlene Dietrich is the accused man's wife, who is strangely unsupportive. But just when you think you have everything figured out, there are new plot twists, in the manner of Agatha Christie, whose play is the film's source -- Monday at 8 p.m. on TCM.

title: The Nation: Hollywood Hypesters; Los Angeles Hogs the Ballot and the Spotlight
description: JAY LENO has invited all 135 contenders in the California recall election to appear next month on his late-night show.

title: The Big Mo in Stocks Hits a Wall of Trading Costs
description: MOST researchers accept that momentum exists in the stock market. Stocks that have outperformed the market over the last 6 to 12 months tend to continue to outperform it for several months more, while lagging stocks tend to continue lagging.

description: LUBELL--Ruby. August 12, 2003. She is survived by her beloved husand of 62 years, Nathan Lubell. Mother of Sharon (Ken) Bolog, Gail (Lyle) Gillis, Kathy (Martin) Randell and the late Ronnie Itzler (Ronald). Grandmother of Richard, Erik, Jason, Nicole, Felice, Jane, Hy, Heather, Corey and Bret. Greatgrandmother of ten. Funeral services were private.

title: Brooks Is Remembered, as Coach and as Friend
description: The pull that Herb Brooks had on his fellow Minnesotans could be seen in the presence of Tom Flynn outside the Cathedral of St. Paul this morning. Although he is not much of a hockey fan, Flynn -- a 56-year-old letter carrier from the Minneapolis suburb of Minnetonka -- stood near the cathedral where Brooks's funeral Mass was celebrated this morning.

description: AFTER Richard M. Nixon faced John F. Kennedy in televised debates, people said television had changed campaigns forever. Forty-three years later, some people have begun saying the same thing about Meetup.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREGER, RACHEL
description: PREGER--Rachel. On August 8, 2003 in her 96th year. Survived by her adoring children, Barbara and Lou Kahn, Teaneck, NJ, Mickey and Judy Preger, Camden, SC, grandchildren and great-grandson. Devoted wife of the late Paul D. Preger. Teacher, mentor. Woman of great strength, integrity and generosity; who shared her love and wisdom with so many. Contributions to the Arthritis Foundation, 122 E. 42nd St., NY, NY 10168.

title: David Byrne's Alternate PowerPoint Universe
description: POWERPOINT, the ubiquitous Microsoft business application, is not meant to be looked at too closely. People aren't supposed to notice its simplified graphics, ready-made templates, pie charts, arrows and icons; they're only supposed to notice the ideas that these features help organize. What's not hard to notice, however, is that in addition to organizing ideas, the software has a tendency to homogenize them, translating a Babel of voices into a single, droning voice of corporate culture. The experience of watching a PowerPoint presentation is meant to be the same in a San Francisco conference room as it is in a Chang Mai Internet cafe. And in either setting, PowerPoint's graphic identity might not literally be invisible, but like the buzzing fluorescent light that office workers eventually tune out, after a while you just don't see it.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Lance Cpl. Troy Merrell, Echo Company, Second Battalion, 25th Marines, Shatrah, Iraq, June 22, 2003

title: Thorpe's Shortened Putter Helps Him Tie Tour Record
description: Taking a few inches off the grip of his putter was a revelation for Jim Thorpe. He had been an average putter for most of his career, but his new grip changed his outlook, especially today in the second round of the Long Island Classic.

title: Take Heart: Top Players Make Lots of Blunders, Too
description: When you see one finely played game after another, you might despair of ever reaching such a stage in your own play, but for a proper perspective, it is important to see that even top players produce boo-boos. The most awful example of a great player doing himself in was Mikhail Chigorin's blundering into a checkmate against Wilhelm Steinitz when he was a knight ahead with a dead-won game. It cost him the 1892 World Championship Match. And David Bronstein still bemoans a blunder that cost him a game in the 1951 World Championship with Mikhail Botvinnik. Botvinnik went on to hold a tie and retain the title.

title: As Factories Move Abroad, So Does U.S. Power
description: MANUFACTURING is slowly disappearing in the United States. That does not mean we should rush to preserve the remaining factories as historic landmarks. America will still be a manufacturing power in our grandchildren's lifetime, but that status is gradually eroding.

title: Janacek's 'Vixen' Captured On a Cunning Little Disc
description: FOUR milk-white doves circle gracefully in the deep blue sky; the Vixen and her dream lover embrace in the starry firmament; a motley assortment of balletic insects waltz to the tune of a barrel organ, all accompanied by some of the most luscious music written in the 20th century or any other time. Geoff Dunbar's animated version of Janacek's opera ''The Cunning Little Vixen,'' on DVD from BBC/Opus Arte, offers this and much more (including a raunchy view of the heroine urinating on a capitalist badger).

title: Lauren Bettman, Brian Gershengorn
description: Lauren Gayle Bettman, a daughter of Shelli and Gary Bettman of Saddle River, N.J., was married last evening to Brian Jeffrey Gershengorn, the son of Renee Gershengorn of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald S. Mass officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: The Probability That a Real-Estate Agent Is Cheating You
description: Steven Levitt may be right that drug dealers often live with their mothers and also make low salaries from their occupation. But if it's true that drug dealers tend not to leave the nest, more plausible explanations abound. Young men without any legal source of income or credit history will have trouble renting, let alone buying, their own apartments. If they are themselves substance users, the challenge of finding a place could be insurmountable. As predators on society, making the easy buck, is it any wonder that they mooch off their mothers? Numbers may not lie, but they hardly tell the whole story.

title: Health Club to Top White Plains Complex
description: The developer Louis Cappelli has decided to add a 60,000-square-foot rooftop health club, with a swimming pool and tennis courts, to the top of a seven-level garage that is part of his $330 million City Center project in White Plains.

title: THREE HELD IN MISSILE PLOT
description: Federal investigators arrested a British citizen in Newark last week and accused him and two other men in a plot to sell Russian-made shoulder-fired missiles to terrorists. Hemant Lakhani, 68, was taken into custody shortly before he was to give the first of 50 missiles to a federal informant posing as a middleman for terrorists, the government said. It also said the informant had told Mr. Lakhani that the weapons would be used to shoot-down commercial airliners. The two other suspects in the case, arrested in Manhattan, are Yehuda Abraham, 76, and Moinuddeen Ahmed Hameed, 38. Richard Lezin Jones

description: The Chens of Yongding County, all 20 generations of them, in an arc that continues after half a millennium, are chronicled in a local genealogy, a book of more than a thousand pages.

title: Slow. Quiet. Courtly. You Say It's in New York?
description: There are many places to escape within New York City's limits. The Cloisters take you to another time; the Hayden Planetarium, to other worlds. The Noguchi Sculpture Garden can transport you to another culture and another state of mind.

title: Arms and the Man
description: Victor Bout, by most accounts the world's largest arms trafficker, had agreed to meet me in the lounge of the Renaissance Hotel in Moscow, a monolithic post-Soviet structure populated by third-tier prostitutes and men in dark suits. Bout's older brother, Sergei, waited with me, as did Richard Chichakli, a Syrian-born naturalized American citizen who lives in Dallas. Sergei helps run Bout's many air-cargo companies. Chichakli, an accountant, calls himself a former business associate of Bout and his ''friend and brother.''

title: Fiddling With the Reception
description: Five days into the Iraq war, Connie Chung was standing in Jim Walton's office at CNN's headquarters in Atlanta with a request. At the war's outset, Walton, who had just taken over as head of CNN, put Chung's prime-time program on temporary hiatus to make room for the network's round-the-clock war coverage. Now Chung was asking Walton to return her program to the air right away.

title: Father's Obsession Gives French Pause
description: It was strange and alarming when the father of a young French tennis player was caught tampering with his opponent's water bottle before a semifinal match in a local tournament on June 28.

description: IT has been a very good summer if you have been in New Jersey with no place to go. Otherwise, it has been a bumpy ride.

description: In 1943, women were feisty. Remember Rosie the Riveter? Who better to symbolize that kind of gumption than Lauren Hutton, supermodel, photographer, aviatrix and adventurer, born 60 years ago and still going strong?

title: Business People; Lawyer Gets Inside Look At War Crimes Tribunal
description: For Petal Modeste, the work was a far cry from her specialty of bank finance law. Ms. Modeste, a third-year law associate at Shearman & Sterling's New York office, spent six weeks in Tanzania this summer helping to prosecute those accused in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

She was also in a very different New York from the one she lived in when the last major blackout in 1977 turned her South Bronx neighborhood into a harrowing zone of plunder and mayhem.

title: Appetizing Art
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Portland with Umbrella Unopened'' (July 20), Hope Reeves might not have liked her accommodations at the Kennedy School, but the building is whimsical and filled with art. Go for dinner or just drinks (or to the movies) and you will be entertained by the artwork that the McMenamin Brothers commissioned to fill the halls of this elementary school built in 1915. Some are portraits of teachers and children who attended the school, some designed to crazily loop in and out of the pipes and around corners.

It is most famous for having been a camp for P.T. Barnum's circus, but that story, while still popular, has been debunked.

description: SUMMER is not usually a season that is associated with important investment decisions.

title: To Replace Paint and Page, Artists Try Pixel Power
description: ARTISTS have experimented with new technologies ever since they left the cave wall for the canvas. Now, with computers (and flat-screen monitors) in nearly every gallery and studio, the DVD is becoming more than just a cheap way to archive or display images transferred from other media. Even with the technology for viewing images constantly changing (remember laser discs?), several projects currently under way or already available suggest that the DVD and, to a lesser extent, the interactive CD-ROM and DVD-ROM (see box on Page 27), is coming into its own as a new kind of artists' multiple, similar to limited-edition books and prints.

description: A man that the police believe was responsible for the rapes of four young women in the Bronx was arrested early yesterday after he tried to attack another victim, the authorites said.

title: Blackout Is Testing Power Of Another Kind in Albany
description: The lights had not come back on in Midtown Manhattan on Friday morning when Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, announced that its Democrats would be holding hearings into what caused the blackout of 2003.

title: Arts Institutions Suffer Growing Pains
description: ONLY two years ago, three major Hartford cultural institutions had big plans for renovation and expansion projects involving superstar architects. But two of the three projects -- at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art and the Connecticut Historical Society -- have been canceled, victims of a lackluster economy and the leadership's second-guessing of the original plans. Directors at the institutions say some form of renovation and expansion will go forward, but no specific plans have been made.

title: Unlikely Co-Leaders Could Cap an Unlikely Season
description: In the year of first-time major winners, the P.G.A. Championship is being led by two players who have never even won on the Tour.

title: Slain Councilman Honored At Rally Against Violence
description: The marching band, the words of gospel and the rousing speeches about the need to stop black-on-black violence, all of these traditional highlights of the annual ''Love Yourself, Stop the Violence'' rally in central Brooklyn were there again yesterday. But one critical ingredient was missing: City Councilman James E. Davis, the Stop the Violence founder, a black man shot dead by a black man less than a month ago.

title: Some Advice From Ventura
description: Jesse Ventura, the professional wrestling bully boy who parlayed his celebrity into one term as Minnesota's governor, has some advice for a fellow entertainer-turned-politician, while offering this opinion on the California recall drive: ''It's ridiculous. It's absurd.''

title: Drama for the Ear and the Imagination
description: THE next time a klatch of aspiring playwrights or filmmakers gets into a complaint session about lack of opportunity in the industry or the vagaries of public taste, they might do well to consider the plight of the radio dramatist. Yes, such creatures still exist, laboring in cultural obscurity for an art form that many assume died quietly decades ago. And yet far from being a quaint, closed chapter of Americana, radio drama is alive and -- well, it's definitely alive.

title: When Fans of Pricey Video Art Can Get It Free
description: MATTHEW BARNEY had long since captured the attention of art world insiders, but this year he was catapulted into mainstream cultural awareness, largely by ''The Cremaster Cycle,'' his spectacular five-film opus. At the Guggenheim Museum last spring, over 300,000 people came to see a huge exhibition of his work, including a continuous display of his videos. The final and most elaborate of his films, ''Cremaster 3,'' screened at this year's Sundance Film Festival. Palm Pictures is currently releasing the entire seven-hour-plus cycle in movie theaters around the country.

title: Streetscapes/Rex Cole's General Electric Appliance Buildings, Designed by Raymond Hood in the 1930's; Master Architect's Showy Refrigerator Showrooms
description: WHEN Charlotte Storper renovated her 1911 apartment house on the northwest corner of Fifth Street and Second Avenue two years ago, she did the usual things: she painted, put in new windows, had the facade cleaned and removed the miscellany that accrues with time. But she carefully preserved two items that another owner might have taken down: decades-old enamel signs on the building's facade that advertised Rex Cole's General Electric refrigerators.

title: Not All in the Family
description: We are in my home office one night, my son and I. He's living with us again, trying to regroup after the loss and humiliation of California. There is a computer for each of us, and until moments ago, we were both intent on our respective monitors. Graig, headset on, was stringing together the digital rock music he writes in the hope of being discovered. It's the latest in a long series of attempts at validation on his part; the others were undone by the bad luck that clings to him like some malevolent shadow. My son, 26, has an uncanny knack for getting in his own way.

title: Wash Your Hair With Borax
description: Sheri Holman's lovely, disarming third novel, THE MAMMOTH CHEESE (Atlantic Monthly, $24), begins with the media circus surrounding the birth of 11 infants to Manda Frank, a hapless young dog breeder living in the rural Virginia town of Three Chimneys. It's a situation ripe for satire or social commentary, but Holman isn't interested in anything so obvious. Her focus quickly widens to encompass a handful of Frank's neighbors and their ordinary, deeply eccentric lives. The emotional center of the book is Polly Marvel, an eighth grader with a wild, possibly requited, crush on her cynical and magnetic 33-year-old teacher. It's easy to understand why Polly is desperate for love. Her roguish father (who cheerily describes himself as not ''the sort of man a woman should ever get cancer on'') has decamped after an affair with his secretary. Her mother, Margaret, is an artisanal cheesemaker who wants to protect Polly from every modern peril, from storebought bread to synthetic fibers. (Holman is particularly funny when describing the antics of this puritanical woman, who washes her hair with borax and egg yolk and is gradually ridding her house of appliances.) But there isn't a caricature in this book, and even Margaret is a sympathetic figure, capable of change and of being loved -- in this case by her farmhand, August, who moonlights as a Thomas Jefferson impersonator. The cheese of the title is a 1,235-pound Cheshire that Margaret makes for the president of the United States, a replica of a gargantuan cheese once presented to Jefferson. The story line is droll, but the book is also tough, sad and surprisingly sweet. Jennifer Reese

However, unlike ''Rashomon,'' ''8 1/2'' or ''The Seventh Seal,'' ''There's Something About Mary,'' starring Cameron Diaz, grossed $178 million, was ranked by the American Film Institute as the 29th funniest movie in human history and has a fab singalong of ''Build Me Up, Buttercup.''In a perfect example of the excessiveness and self-indulgence that is DVD commentary, a new two-disc package, ''There's Something More About Mary,'' contains ''over six hours of outrageous new stuff,'' including the original theatrical version, a new extended version with 13 previously deleted or shortened scenes, a commentary by its directors, Peter and Bobby Farrelly, a commentary by the original screenwriters, cast interviews, unedited on-set footage, music videos, trailers, commercials and an interview with the guy who made the fake dogs, plastic breasts and ersatz ejaculate that were used so memorably in the movie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOHMER, ABRAM, MD
description: SOHMER--Abram, MD. A much-admired and beloved family doctor for more than fifty years, Abram Sohmer died in his sleep on August 6th after a long illness patiently suffered. His wife was at his side. Abram Sohmer earned his M.D. in 1939 at Emory University, Atlanta, and served as a Lieutenant Colonel flight surgeon with the Ninth Air Force in Egypt, England, and France during the Second World War. He was decorated with the Bronze Star Medal and served on General Eisenhower's staff during the Battle of Bulge. After the war, he entered private medical practice in Jamaica, New York. His brilliance as a diagnostician, his kind and caring manner, his optimism and gentle humor brought him a large practice, more than ten thousand persons. He loved being a family doctor and spurned offers to specialize. He routinely treated more than sixty patients a day. He began his hospital rounds at 6AM, held office hours from 10AM to 9PM, and rarely completed his house calls before midnight. He delivered more than two thousand babies. He saved many lives. He was old school. He was loved, honored and cherished by the community to which he devoted his life. A humble man, he turned from praise. Abram is survived by his wife of sixty-three years, Millie; two sons, Steve and Paul; a brother, Hy Sohmer; a sister, Martha Zuckerman; and seven grandchildren. Condolences and reminiscences welcome at drshomer@aol.com

After years of watching from the sidelines as a reporter, I have been invited by Bobbi Brown to join her august guild of makeup artists, if only for a night. Bobbi, a small, contained dynamo, communicates the assurance that comes from being the founder of her wildly popular eponymous cosmetics line. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHLAND, W. BERNARD
description: RICHLAND--W. Bernard. August 14, 2003. Born in Liverpool, England, March 25, 1909. Predeceased by his wife Pauline and seven brothers and sisters. Survived by his sister Gladys Sarony Frye, his beloved and adoring family, daughters Robin Silverton and Lisa Richland, grandchildren Seth Silverton, Alexandra Uhll and Rafael Maciejak, great-grandchildren A.J. and Emma Silverton, Hannah and Jack Richland Uhll and his beloved and devoted companion Barbara Carroll Weiler. Mr. Richland was associated with Judge Samuel Seabury from 1925-1943, and was admitted to the Bar in 1937. He was the Chief of the Opinions and Legislation Division of the New York City Law Department and Acting Corporation Counsel from 1943-1958, New York City's Corporation Counsel from 1975-1977. He was an expert in municipal government, legislation and regulations, and he lectured and litigated in these fields extensively. He drafted the New York City Charter, adopted in 1961, and was Commissioner, New York City Charter Revision Commission, 1973-1975. He was Special Master for Appeals (Agent Orange Administration) U.S. District Court Eastern District New York from 1988-1996. Mr. Richland was Adjunct Professor of local government law, New York Law School from 1978-1988. His book, ''You CAN Beat City Hall'' was published in 1980. In private practice he was partner in the law firm Baer Marks and counsel to the firm of O'Dwyer and Bernstein and to Botein Hays Sklar. Mr. Richland was mentor to many young lawyers, giving them his time, counsel and friendship with enthusiasm. He took pleasure and satisfaction from their subsequent success, and remembered each one fondly. His family and friends mourn his passing but celebrate his long, productive and happy life. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY, on Monday, August 18, at 3:30 p.m. Burial private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Metropolitan Hospice of Greater New York, 6323 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11220-4711.

Baby One More Time'' on MTV, the sun had truly set on the Decade of the Diva (Madonna, Mariah, Whitney et al.). Since then, the cradle has been rockin'. The tabloids christened the young ones ''pop tarts'' after those beloved, additive-rich sweet nothings one slides furtively into the toaster whilst the righteous choke down spelt muffins. In fact, Pop-Tarts, which turn a venerable 40 next year, are among America's most entrenched guilty pleasures: in 2001, the number of Tarts sold (2 billion) would have reached halfway to the moon. Psssst: 40 percent were consumed by adults. Metaphorically, our Top 40 tarts are consistent with the pastry originals: they're better when they're a little flaky, their visuals are candy-colored, the lite lyrics melt in your mouth. title: The Cone Heads
description: The first time I came in contact with cycads, I was gripped by an urge to steal. It happened more than a year ago, while taking a guided tour of Lotusland, a fantastical garden in Montecito, Calif. Lotusland, founded by Ganna Walska, has more than 1,000 cycads on its 37 acres, and our tour guide was quite taken with this distinctly odd group of plants, many of which look like squat palm trees on steroids. Cycads, he pointed out, bear cones, as conifers do. They are ancient, predating dinosaurs by some 75 million years. Intriguingly, cycads are also dioecious, meaning that they are either male or female. When a plant puts out cones, this becomes as plain as day. Male cycads generally produce long, phallic cones, while female cones, which hold the seeds, tend to have a fuller, rounder shape. There are even transsexual cycads -- a few specimens have been documented to change gender under environmental stress.

title: Politics and the Everglades

There is, however, one urgent matter that he could do something about while winning points in the process. The $8 billion plan to restore Florida's threatened Everglades is at a critical point. Decisions taken in the next few weeks may determine whether it lives up to its promise of reviving the South Florida ecosystem or whether it becomes just another water supply project for Florida's booming cities and suburbs. Mr. Bush's personal intervention could keep the project from veering off course. It might also send a useful warning to his brother Jeb, whose commitment to restoration has wavered since his re-election as Florida's governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN RENSSELAER, ALEXANDER
description: VAN RENSSELAER--Alexander. Artist and creative visionary, died Sunday, July 27, 2003 in Marina del Rey. He was 35 years old and had been a resident of California for the past 4 years. A native of Westport, CT, Alex was a direct descendant of Kiliaen Van Rensselaer (1580-1643) of Amsterdam, Holland who was Director of the Dutch West India Company, 1st Patroon, colonizer and forefather of the Lords of the Manor of Rensselaerswyck in the New Netherlands, comprising the present day counties of Albany, Rensselaer and Columbia, NY. He attended Fairfield Country Day School, St. George's School, Parsons School of Design and The School of Visual Arts. Van Rensselaer began his career painting oil on canvas in several different abstract genres while living in Greenwich Village, NY. In 1997, his passion for fine arts and music took him to the West Coast where he continued painting and maintained various collections including one of rare music. An avid competitor in both chess and billiards, he was known for his patience and strategic play. While in Marina del Rey, he became a rated tennis player and joined the U.S. Tennis Association team at the Marina del Rey City Tennis Club. A loving son and brother, Alex Van Rensselaer is survived by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander T. Van Rensselaer, his mother and father of Hobe Sound, FL; Kiliaen Drackett Van Rensselaer, his brother of New York City; Mrs. Roger Drackett, his grandmother of Naples, FL; and by several aunts, uncles and cousins. A family interment at The Albany Rural Cemetery, in Albany, NY will be held on Monday, August 18th, followed by a private reception at the Van Rensselaer home in Westport, CT on Tuesday, August 19th.

But my dad had taught me well, and I knew that he would be proud to see that I had fit a good 20 percent of the words into the theme, that I had had to resort to only two instances of crosswordese and that my diagram did not have more than 38 black squares. And how could he not be pleased by the definition of Nos. 1 and 2 Across: ''World's best dad.'' title: The Probability That a Real-Estate Agent Is Cheating You
description: As a real-estate broker, I was intrigued by the title of your article. As for the results of Levitt's investigation indicating that properties sold by real-estate agents on their own behalf stayed on the market for an average of 10 days longer and sold for 2 percent more than properties of sellers they represented, there may be a simple and less cynical explanation. Most sellers are doing so to move on to another house or to another location and often have serious time constraints. Included in the data that Levitt collected were, in all probability, properties owned by real-estate agents for investment or, God forbid, speculation. title: Civil War Echoes
description: To the Editor: ''Chattanooga's Quirky Charm,'' by Susan Harb (July 27), is entertaining, with its mention of the Chattanooga Choo-Choo Hotel and the tow-truck hall of fame. But while it mentions that the city was the starting point of the Cherokee Trail of Tears, it ignores Chattanooga's significance in the Civil War. The capture of Chattanooga in November 1863 (including the battles of Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge, with 13,000 casualties) marked the beginning of the end of the Confederacy, the ascendancy of Grant to full command of all United States forces, and the launching pad for Sherman's march to Atlanta and the sea.

Yet an investigation by the Division of Youth and Family Services did not substantiate abuse or neglect. The 2,900 pages of once-confidential records were the last of four sets of files that had been given to Children's Rights Inc., a Manhattan-based advocacy group that sued the state over the quality of its foster care system. In June, the suit was settled with an agreement that called for a sweeping overhaul of the state agency. Richard Lezin Jones
