title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARNEDOE, KIRK
description: VARNEDOE--Kirk. It is with the greatest saddness that the Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the untimely death of their dear friend and former colleague, Kirk Varnedoe, who was for many years the Museum's Chief Curator in the Department of Painting and Sculpture. Kirk leaves and extraordinary legacy, for he was a man of many talents--a brilliant curator, writer, teacher, lecturer, scholar, and mentor to younger colleagues during his 15year association with MoMA. An astute historian of the Museum's collection and of modern and contemporary art, he negotiated crucial acquisitions and organized landmark exhibitions. His deep friendships with artists greatly benefited the Museum in myriad ways. Some of these friendships developed out of the artist-organized exhibitions, ''Artist's Choice,'' which Kirk created and directed. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elyn Zimmerman, to his brothers Samuel and Gordon Varnedoe, and to his sister Comer Meadows. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art

title: Help Wanted

Given that the current jobless rate hovers a little above 6 percent (a good 2 points higher than when Bush took office), the cabinet members' choice of transportation was a thoughtful touch. If the jobless rate were much higher -- say, 8 or 9 percent -- old bicycles would have been more appropriate, or maybe even a walking tour, but as things stand motor coaches were just right, evoking a nation that's still on the move but just not quite as quickly as it might be.

title: What's A Nice Girl Like You . . .

She'll tell you everything, but most of it will be off the record, and I'll go to my grave with her dark secrets. ''I last came here three years ago,'' she reveals, ''and I loved it.'' We proceed to order almost everything on the menu -- that's four pieces of chicken, chicken strips, an order of popcorn shrimp, a fried fish po' boy, Cajun fries, redders and rice, ''dirty rice,'' mashed potatoes and pepper gravy, coleslaw, mac and cheese, a fried apple pie, a slice of speckled cheesecake and a handful of buttermilk biscuits, along with 16 paper napkins. title: Double Lives on the Down Low
description: I have worked with men of all races and from all walks of life in a clinical setting for more than 20 years and have seen a wide spectrum of sexual orientations and behavior. I came away from your article dismayed and saddened. What was the purpose of this report? To build compassion and understanding for a marginalized group within a marginalized group? To suggest new avenues of public policy for H.I.V. prevention in a population decimated by H.I.V.? I think not. Rather, it seems to me that your treatment of poor and working-class bisexual black men only sensationalizes, demonizes and further marginalizes. One way to rectify this lopsided picture would be to give the lowdown on middle- and upper-class bisexual white men who are married and who frequently tryst with their boy toys.

title: CASH AT THE BORGATA
description: The opening of the first new casino in Atlantic City in 13 years, the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa, helped increase the city's gambling revenue in July by 4.4 percent from a year ago, the state Casino Control Commission said last week. It was the biggest single-month increase in Atlantic City, officials said, and it comes as the casinos are trying to respond to competition from nearby Indian casinos and Las Vegas, which adds new attractions often. The Borgata reported $46.9 million in revenue for July, but revenue at 7 of the other 11 casinos declined from July 2002. Some industry watchers said they had hoped that the opening of the Borgata would expand the market for Atlantic City. It was also expected, at least at first, that the new site would take away business from existing casinos. ''One month doesn't make a trend,'' said Marc Falcone, an analyst for Deutsche Bank. ''It's still very early in the stages of redeveloping and reinventing that market.'' Maria Newman

title: Bookies in Exile
description: Costa Rica is highly prized by the world's backpackers and sightseers for its unspoiled natural beauty, but it's easy to forget that when arriving in its grimy capital, San Jos. The newly remodeled airport is surrounded by chain hotels, freshly paved roads and shiny corporate plazas. After that it goes rapidly downhill. A dusty highway heading vaguely toward downtown takes you through the poorer suburbs of San Jos, packed with families in corrugated-tin-roof shacks. Above them, on the sides of the surrounding hills, Costa Rica's elite live behind high, fortified walls. The entire valley is blanketed with smog from auto fumes, brush fires and burned trash.

title: For Chaplin, This Is Just the Latest Of Modern Times
description: IT is time again to talk of Charles Spencer Chaplin, as it is every decade or so when the group of Chaplin films owned by his estate return to distribution. In the early 1970's, the occasion was the return of Chaplin's major features to American movie theaters, after he had withdrawn them in bitterness over his political persecution by the United States government in the 1950's for suspected Communist leanings. In the 1980's, CBS-Fox released the films on VHS and Laserdisc. And now, a first group of four Chaplin features -- ''The Gold Rush'' (1925), ''Modern Times'' (1936), ''The Great Dictator'' (1940) and ''Limelight'' (1952) -- has been issued on DVD by Warner Home Video in magnificently restored versions produced by the current license holder of the films, the French company MK2.

Mr. Gilinsky served as senior vice president/real estate in charge of expansion and development for the BATUS Retail Division, former parent of Saks Fifth Avenue and Gimbel Brothers. Mr. Gilinsky played an integral role in the complex and unique planning and development of the former Swiss Bank Tower behind Saks Fifth Avenue's flagship store. Following his retirement in 1983, Mr. Gilinsky was a real estate consultant to the BATUS Retail Division, vice-chairman of The Harlan Company, and president and chairman of the Board of the Peruvian Avenue Corporation of Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Gilinsky held degrees from Lehigh University and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. He met his wife, Gerry, while an attorney at Wolf, Block, Schorr and Solis-Cohen in Philadelphia. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBIN, MARIA E. DE BOURBON
description: DUBIN--Maria E. de Bourbon. Princess Ana Margarita Maria Elvira de Bourbon Dubin, daughter of the late Prince and Princess Filiberto de Bourbon of Paterson, NY, died Thursday, August 14, at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, CT. She was 61 years old and had been ill with cancer for several months. She was descended from the Bourbon dynasties of both France and Spain and was related to the Austrian Royal House of Hapsburg. Her maternal grandfather, the late General Alfredo Vasquez-Cobo of Bogota, Colombia, served his country as Minister of War and Minister of Foreign Affairs and as Ambassador to France. Surviving are her children David Dubin of Minneapolis, MN, Danielle Dubin Manion and her husband Peter of Cos Cob, CT, and Denise Dubin Parker and her husband Max of Cos Cob, CT; and her grandchildren Reilly Parker, Emily Parker and Angus Manion, all of Cos Cob, CT. She is also survived by her sister Anne de Bourbon Brown and her husband Stewart of Alexandria, VA, and her brothers James de Bourbon of Dallas, TX, Frank de Bourbon and his wife Elizabeth of Los Angeles, CA, Anthony de Bourbon and his wife Linda of Lansing, MI, Ferdinand de Bourbon and his wife Mary Jane of New Milford, CT, Philip de Bourbon and his wife Gwendolyn of Dallas, TX, and Charles de Bourbon and his wife Kim of Delaware Water Gap, PA. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, New Canaan, CT, on Thursday, August 21. Interment will follow at Putnam Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. Contributions in memory of Mrs. Maria E. Dubin may be made to the New Canaan Library, New Canaan, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARNEDOE, KIRK
description: VARNEDOE--Kirk. It is with the greatest saddness that the Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the untimely death of their dear friend and former colleague, Kirk Varnedoe, who was for many years the Museum's Chief Curator in the Department of Painting and Sculpture. Kirk leaves and extraordinary legacy, for he was a man of many talents--a brilliant curator, writer, teacher, lecturer, scholar, and mentor to younger colleagues during his 15year association with MoMA. An astute historian of the Museum's collection and of modern and contemporary art, he negotiated crucial acquisitions and organized landmark exhibitions. His deep friendships with artists greatly benefited the Museum in myriad ways. Some of these friendships developed out of the artist-organized exhibitions, ''Artist's Choice,'' which Kirk created and directed. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elyn Zimmerman, to his brothers Samuel and Gordon Varnedoe, and to his sister Comer Meadows. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art

title: Of Grids and Gridlock

The lights went on, the phones worked, the subways and trains ran more or less on time. Yet the nation's electricity problems are not over. The blackout alerted everyone to the frailties of America's doddering electrical grid. Washington must now move quickly to start fixing it. Instead of pushing stubbornly ahead with a couple of musty, misguided energy bills, Congress should act quickly on several excellent ideas that could help prevent a repeat of last week's nightmare.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: ADVANCED MICRO SHARES SURGE ON CHIP NEWS Shares in Advanced Micro Devices shot up more than 14 percent yesterday after comments from an influential technology stock strategist that Advanced Micro's new line of chips poses the biggest-ever threat to Intel . Fred Hickey, an investment newsletter publisher, said Advanced Micro had finally built a line of chips that could take a major market share from Intel, which makes the microprocessors that serve as the brains of most of the world's computers. Advanced Micro has for years struggled to gain more than a foothold against Intel despite lower prices and chips that some experts say are as powerful as Intel's. This year, Advanced Micro is coming out with two chips, the Opteron and the Athlon 64, which it markets as technologically superior to Intel's Itanium and Pentium chips. Advanced Micro shares rose $1.11, or 14.2 percent, to close at $8.91. It was among the most active issues traded. Shares in Intel, which declined to comment on competition from Advanced Micro, also rose yesterday, gaining $1.14, or 4.6 percent, to close at $26.19.   (Reuters)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Uncasville: Critical Injury In Bus
description: Thirty passengers were injured, one critically, when the roof of their bus collided with the parking garage at the Mohegan Sun casino, officials said. The passengers were taken to local hospitals and most were treated for minor injuries; one woman, whose age and name were not immediately released, suffered serious injuries to her arm and head. On Sunday, the bus, owned by Nate's Tours of Newark, N.J., was on its way to Foxwoods Resort Casino, less than 10 miles away in Mashantucket, said Severio Mancini, a spokesman for Mohegan Sun, which the driver apparently mistook for Foxwoods. State police said the driver, Willie Blaine, 58, of Irvington, N.J., may face charges. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge To Hear Fox V. Franken
description: A federal judge in Manhattan decided yesterday that he would listen to oral arguments in the lawsuit by Fox News Network against the comedian Al Franken, left. After the hearing on Friday, the judge, Denny Chin, will decide whether to grant Fox the injunction it seeks to stop Mr. Franken, and his publisher, Penguin Group, from selling his new book, ''Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right.'' In dispute is the title and cover design with the words ''fair and balanced.'' Lawyers for Fox argue that the network trademarked ''Fair and Balanced,'' and that Mr. Franken's use would ''blur and tarnish'' the phrase that the network uses to market its news coverage. A lawyer for Penguin, Floyd Abrams, stated in court papers that he planned to defend Mr. Franken's ''wordplay'' on free speech arguments and other grounds. In court yesterday, he questioned the timing of Fox's actions, noting that the first 50,000 copies of the book have already been shipped to bookstores nationwide. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Semiconductor Sales To Rise 11.2%
description: Sales of semiconductors will increase 11.2 percent this year to $173 billion as demand for computers and electronic devices gains, a research company said. Worldwide semiconductor revenue rose 1.4 percent to $156 billion in 2002, the research company, Gartner Inc., said. Increasing silicon demand, higher factory use and better prices indicate sales will accelerate this year, Gartner said. Companies will replace their old computers at slower rates than in previous years, it said. Gartner forecast in May an 8.3 percent increase in 2003 chip sales. In February, the company forecast 8.9 percent and in November it predicted a 12 percent gain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNES, KENNETH SILAS
description: BARNES--Kenneth Silas, of Levittown, New York died Friday, August 15, 2003 at New Island Hospital. He was 85. Beloved husband of Madaline A. Hime. Loving father of Jolee Zola of Cambridge, Massachusetts, Jane Victor of Pittsburg, Kansas and Amy Fowler of Renton, Washington. Devoted uncle to Penny Ferone of Whitestone, New York. Devoted grandfather to Allison Nephew and Clarissa Victor. He is also survived by three greatgrandchildren, a great-grandnephew and great-grandniece. Mr. Barnes was born in Belvidere, New Jersey and spent his youth in Ames, New York. He served in the United States Air Force during World War II, participating in boming missions over Germany and France for which he received the Distinguished Service Cross amony other honors. He also served in India. After the war, he acquired his Master's in Library Sciences at Columbia University on the G.I. Bill of Rights. He and his family moved to Levittown, New York in 1953 to accept a job as Director of the Hicksville Public Library, where he worked until his retirement in 1992. He was a member of the American Library Association and the New York Library Association. He loved books, jazz and animals. He was proud of having devoted his life to public service. Memorial services will be held at 1 PM on Friday, August 22, 2003 at Evergreen Cemetery, Fonda, New York. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association or to benefit libraries. For more information, Kobuskie-Konik Funeral Home 147 Bleecker St., Gloversville, NY 12078. (518) 725-5917.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Worm Variant Supplies Patch
description: A variant of MSBlast spread yesterday, but the new worm had an odd twist: It applied a patch for the vulnerability that it and other MSBlast worms used to infect Windows systems. The new worm appeared to properly download the patch for both Windows 2000 and Windows XP from Microsoft's Web site. Moreover, the variant will delete itself the first time an infected computer starts up in 2004. That does not mean that such worms are a good idea, said Joe Hartmann, North American director for antivirus research at the security software firm Trend Micro. Despite the apparent lack of malicious intent, the worm still sends a great deal of unwanted traffic, as it tries to spread to other computers. In addition, if several computers download the patch from Microsoft at the same time, it could slow network performance, Mr. Hartmann said.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Mapping a Town in Neil Young Land
description: Musicians tend to judge themselves by different criteria than their audience does. When a guitarist breaks a string in the middle of a concert, for example, and perseveres in playing a hit with a missing G string, he may leave the stage upset and disappointed. Most of the layoffs will occur by the end of the year, Sonoco said, and will cost about $22 million before taxes. The moves will save as much as $60 million before taxes. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, JULIUS OCHS
description: ADLER--Julius Ochs, 78, died on August 18, 2003 after a long illness. Mr. Adler is survived by his wife, Deirdre Spencer Adler, a son, Douglas O. Adler, two daughters, Anne A. Tarbell and Mary B. Malhotra, as well as an aunt, two sisters, three step children, 13 grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Mr. Adler was the son of Barbara Stettheimer Adler and Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President, General Manager and Treasurer of The New York Times from 1914 to 1955. From 1977 until 1992, Mr. Adler and his wife owned and operated the Canterbury Bookstore in Manhattan. Earlier in his professional career, Mr. Adler was affiliated with Interpublic, the New York Mets and The New York Times. Mr. Adler served in the United States Air Corps during WWII. He attended Princeton University. Mr. Adler's funeral will be private. Donations in his memory can be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: The Ancient Art Of Monopoly
description: The labor minister, Ahmed al Amawi, canceled work permits for foreign belly dancers working in Egypt, according to the state-run newspaper Al Gumhoria, which described the decision as ''belated.'' In the last decade, thousands of dancers, mostly from Russia and Eastern Europe, have come to Egypt to work as belly dancers in resorts and nightclubs at lower wages than their Egyptian competitors. Egyptian belly dancers have repeatedly demanded that the government enforce stricter regulations on foreign dancers. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCBRATNEY, R. BRUCE
description: McBRATNEY--R. Bruce. Of Beaufort, S.C., formerly of Montclair, N.J. Husband of Audrey Carroll McBratney. Died August 18, 2003.

title: Israelis Worry About Terror, By Jews Against Palestinians
description: Two and a half years ago, a 10-month-old Israeli girl, Shalhevet Pas, was shot to death in her stroller by a Palestinian sniper here in Hebron, a city where the competing claims of Jews and Palestinians to the land, holy places and the past grind together with particular pain. Last month, her father, Yitzhak Pas, a settler who lives here, was arrested with almost 10 pounds of explosives in his car.

title: Bloomberg and City Unions Draw the Lines, Far Apart
description: John V. Lindsay's tenure was defined by strikes, the first one hitting only hours after he was sworn in. Edward I. Koch and Rudolph W. Giuliani started off talking tough, but ended up awarding hefty raises to municipal workers that left the city in a bind when recessions hit. David N. Dinkins squeezed some of the same unions that had helped elect him and then never got a chance to serve a second term.

He worked at LILCO 1938-1960, was vice president of Columbia University 1960-1965, and president of Adelphi University 1967-1969. He leaves his wife Mary, his children Nancy and Robert, two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Donations to United Methodist Foundation of Western PA for Olmsted Manor Retreat Center.

title: At This Play, Everyone Is in the Bathroom Line

So as other visitors to the Museum of Contemporary Art here were rerouted to nearby bathrooms, ''Downsize'' ticketholders waited outside the men's room for its last occupants to emerge.

We all have stories to tell about this special, spiritual, quirky and caring being. Rest in peace. Gary and Judi Gladstein.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Reduces Employee Options
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, which makes chips used in cellphones, said yesterday that it had reduced the number of stock options for employees and that it would study how it pays its executives. The amount of shares set aside for employee stock options fell to 3.9 percent of the shares outstanding in the fiscal year that ended on May 25, from 5.4 percent in 2002 and 6.6 percent in 2001, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Stock options, which give the holder the right to buy a share of stock within a particular time period at a specific price, are used to give employees an incentive to increase the value of the share price, the company said. The move to limit the number of shares is intended to help prevent dilution in the value of existing National Semiconductor stock.

description: The Air Transportation Stabilization Board, set up by Congress to give financial aid to the airline industry after the Sept. 11 attacks, said yesterday that its executive director was resigning.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gotti Accused Of Murder Plot
description: Peter Gotti was indicted yesterday and accused of taking part in a 1999 plot to kill Salvatore Gravano, the Mafia turncoat known as Sammy the Bull who was instrumental in convicting Mr. Gotti's brother, the late crime boss John Gotti. The authorities have said that Mr. Gravano narrowly escaped a murder attempt when he was arrested in 2000. From October 1999 to May 2000, Peter Gotti, who federal prosecutors say was acting boss of the Gambino crime family, plotted the murder with Mr. Gravano's brother-in-law, Edward Garafola, and Thomas Carbonaro, a Gambino soldier, the indictment says. Mr. Gotti, who is awaiting federal sentencing on an unrelated conviction, is also charged with extortion. If convicted of the charges, he faces up to 70 years in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Producer Sentenced To 25 Years
description: An independent film producer who admitted killing and dismembering his business partner, an Afghan filmmaker, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison, 5 more years than what a Nassau County judge had agreed to as part of a plea arrangement. In June, the producer, Nathan C. Powell, pleaded guilty to manslaughter and admitted that he had killed Jawed Wassel, whose film he had helped produce. Mr. Powell had planned to argue that the trauma of Sept. 11 contributed to the October 2001 killing, but instead he entered a plea deal.

The previous record was 281,581 dominoes. Ms. Ma said she put in 13-hour days for nearly seven weeks to lay out the dominoes. It took just four minutes for them to fall. (AP)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Aides Charged In Beating
description: Capital murder charges were filed against two nursing home aides in the beating of an 81-year-old resident. The victim, Willie Mae Ryan, never regained consciousness after she was beaten with brass knuckles on July 30 and died on Aug. 14. An affidavit filed by detectives quoted one of the aides, Shermika Rainey, 17, as saying that she was recruited by Gayla S. Wilson, 44, to restrain Ms. Ryan while Ms. Wilson pummeled her ''for being disrespectful.'' The two worked at the Dallas County Nursing Home in Fordyce, where Ms. Ryan was a longtime resident.

title: Sports of The Times; Office Is a Saddle, and the End Is a Misstep Away

Something, some shadow or movement that the horse had seen out of the corner of his eye, had spooked him, but Stevens had no time to figure out what. He was busy holding onto the reins as he flopped on the right side of the horse and a thundering pack of 12 other horses bounded toward him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
description: Joblessness edged up to 8.7 percent in the period from May through July, compared with 8.6 percent from April through June. Total employment shrank by 17,400 people. The increase in the unemployment rate would have been greater had 8,500 people not left the job market during the period, possibly after becoming discouraged by their bleak prospects. The latest figures show unemployment rising more slowly than in the spring, when the SARS virus crippled the economy. Restaurant employment in particular has been recovering as mainland China has eased restrictions on travel by its citizens to Hong Kong.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND/In Hartford; A City Seeks to Recapture Its Commercial Allure
description: Hartford, long eclipsed as a business destination by Boston and New York, recently proclaimed itself New England's rising star. The city, known as the insurance capital of America, the birthplace of the Colt revolver and the hometown of Katharine Hepburn, is intent on recapturing its commercial allure.

description: International journalists' groups and Reuters demanded today that the American military hold a full public inquiry into the death of a Reuters cameraman who was fatally shot by American soldiers in Iraq on Sunday as he filmed outside a prison.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19  Attorney General John Ashcroft today began the Bush administration's defense of the Patriot Act, saying that its provisions, however controversial in the ways they extend law enforcement powers, had proved central to efforts to thwart further terror attacks on United States soil.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm To Change Name After Spinoff
description: Palm, the world's biggest maker of hand-held computers, will change its name to bolster its brand after the company completes a spinoff of a software unit and buys Handspring. The new name will be palmOne, to convey that the company is a pioneer and focused on customers, Palm said in a statement. Products will use the new brand next year. Palm has agreed to buy Handspring, a smaller competitor, to gain a line of mobile phones that double as hand-held organizers. Palm is spinning off a software unit called PalmSource to attract more computer makers to its operating system as Microsoft tries to do the same with its software. Palm shares rose 7 cents, to $15.26.

J.P. Morgan Partners, a unit of J.P. Morgan Chase and Company, has teamed with the British private-equity firms Candover Investments and 3i Group to buy the assets, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal. ABB, which is based in Zurich, wants to raise $2 billion through disposals this year to cut its $8.3 billion in debt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Happy Hour Is Past
description: New laws intended to cut heavy drinking in pubs took effect, including a ban on happy hours and other pub promotions that encourage excessive consumption. The new laws also allow police officers in plainclothes to investigate bars and to fine owners up to $2,200 for allowing customers to get excessively drunk. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: BACK TO BUSINESS AFTER TRAGEDY The New York City Council will meet today for the first time since Councilman James E. Davis was gunned down in the Council chamber by a political rival on July 23. Council members plan to wear white carnations and read a resolution that will celebrate his life and mourn his loss, and an American flag and two red roses will be placed on the councilman's desk. The Rev. Clinton Miller of Brown Memorial Baptist Church in Brooklyn, who was a friend of Mr. Davis, will give the invocation, followed by statements from Council Speaker Gifford Miller and other members. Mr. Davis's family is expected to attend, including his brother, Geoffrey A. Davis, who is running for his seat. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nikkei Tops 10,000
description: The benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index closed above 10,000 for the first time in a year, thanks to the improved outlook for the economy and corporate profits. The Nikkei rose 1.7 percent, to finish at 10,032, putting it 32 percent above its 20-year low, which was reached at the end of April. Investors are encouraged by the economy's 2.3 percent annualized growth in the April-June quarter and some surprisingly strong earnings reports, including those from banks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Bronx Woman, 86, Is First Case Of Nile Virus in State for 2003

title: Disaster Plans Get New Scrutiny After Blackout
description: When Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said last year that the Big Board was considering a backup trading floor at a ''nuclear distance'' from New York City, it was treated as an ill-phrased gaffe. But after last week's power failure that blanketed an area stretching from the Northeast to the Midwest, companies are taking a harder look at whether their disaster recovery plans go far enough -- literally.

title: DRS TECHNOLOGIES PLANS TO BUY INTEGRATED DEFENSE
description: DRS Technologies Inc., which makes computer systems for the military, agreed to acquire Integrated Defense Technologies Inc. for $375 million. DRS, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., will pay $17.50 a share in cash and stock, 17 percent more than Integrated Defense's closing price Friday. DRS will also assume $175 million in Integrated Defense's debt. Shares of DRS declined 13 percent yesterday, to $25.30, on concerns about rising debt and whether the purchase would save the company money. Integrated Defense, based in Huntsville, Ala., makes electronic parts for the Army's Abrams tank.

The session opened the final weekend of the 14th annual Bard Music Festival at Bard College, devoted this year to Janacek and his world.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ironworker Dead In Midtown
description: An ironworker who appeared to have been on his way to a construction site was found dead, shot between the eyes, on a Midtown street just before 7 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The motive for the killing was a mystery and the man did not appear to have been robbed, the police said. The man, Vincent Gargiulo, 34, was working for a subcontractor on the site of the next Consolidated Edison substation at West 31st Street, and he was found around the corner at 30th Street and Broadway, the police said. Mr. Gargiulo had a criminal record and had been arrested for assault and possession of stolen property, an investigator said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

description: It doesn't take long for passengers boarding the new Hooters Air planes in Newark, Baltimore or Atlanta for flights to Myrtle Beach, S.C., to realize that this will be no ordinary flight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENFIELD, RUSSELL
description: ROSENFIELD--Russell. Born August 19, 1925, passed away on August 17, 2003. Beloved husband of Mildred, father of Barbara, Phyllis and Steven, loving grandfather of Chrissy, Joseph and Nick. Russ helped to found Swavelle Fabrics 34 years ago and was a respected executive in the US textile industry. A memorial service will be held for family and friends on August 19, 2003 at Sinai Chapels, 12 PM, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, 800-446-0406.

title: Political Money Put to the Test
description: President Bush has lately engaged in some prodigious midvacation fund-raising: two 20-minute speeches netting $2 million from enthusiastic supporters. This put his re-election drive at $42 million and counting. His success in stretching the rules governing legal donations to their limits serves as a reminder that there is no need to return, as many politicians would, to the days of unlimited ''soft money'' contributions, by which corporations, unions and fat cats made a crass mockery of the political system. Plenty of money remains in politics. Mr. Bush, free of any primary challenge, is still aiming to raise as much as $200 million by way of the newly relaxed ''hard money'' restrictions that let him seek $2,000 maximums from the individuals he and his Democratric rivals are wooing.

title: UNION WILL REVIEW CONTRACT OFFER FROM GOODYEAR
description: Goodyear Tire and Rubber gave its biggest union a new contract offer after three days of nonstop negotiations, and union leaders were reviewing the proposal. A Goodyear spokesman, Charles L. Sinclair, said the company made the new proposal on Sunday and both sides agreed to suspend bargaining. Goodyear and the union, representing 16,000 active workers and another 3,000 on indefinite layoff at 14 factories, resumed talks in Cincinnati on Aug. 6 after a month's hiatus. Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, and the union bargained past a Friday deadline.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ICELAND: FIRST WHALE HARPOONED Whalers harpooned their first whale in 14 years, said the scientist in charge of the hunt, Gisli Vikingsson. The minke was caught by whalers on board the ship Njordur, one of three vessels taking part in what the authorities have described as research, primarily about the whales' effect on fish stocks. A State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said that the United States was "extremely disappointed" and that the hunt could bring about a trade embargo on Iceland. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Chechnya: Russia Invites Observers To Republic's Vote
description: A senior official in Chechnya said Russia had invited a dozen international organizations to observe the republic's presidential election, scheduled for Oct. 5. The election, following a constitutional referendum in March, is part of the Kremlin's effort to bring stability to the republic after nearly four years of war. Sixteen candidates have announced plans to run, but two have already been disqualified for technical violations of campaign laws. So far only one candidate, the head of the Kremlin-appointed administration in Chechnya, Akhmad Kadyrov, has submitted the required number of voters' signatures. The deadline for submitting those signatures is tomorrow. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Investigators In Sniper Case Join Inquiry In W. Virginia
description: With three people dead in similar single-shot sniper attacks in West Virginia last week, federal agents who investigated the serial sniper case in the Washington area last year have joined the investigation, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATCHER, STANLEY
description: KATCHER--Stanley, 68, of Pelham Manor, New York died August 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Evelyn, father of David and Paul, brother of Gary, brother-in-law of Sharon & uncle of Jason, Stacey & Jamie. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, BENTON
description: GREENE--Benton. Devoted husband of Harriet, beloved father of Robyn Chwatt and Linda Rosenberg. Adored grandfather of Brian, Keith, Michelle and Joy. Our hero who was bigger than life, passed quietly in his sleep to look over us all. Your presence will be within us forever. Richard & Robyn Chwatt

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Another Bank Bidder
description: The Westpac Banking Corporation is in talks to buy the New Zealand banking unit of Lloyds TSB Group, pitting it against its main Australian rivals in bidding for New Zealand's biggest bank, which analysts have valued at about $4 billion. Westpac sought approval from New Zealand's competition regulator to buy the Lloyds unit, the National Bank. Westpac, based in Sydney, is the second bidder for the New Zealand unit to approach the regulator after the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group applied last week. In addition, the chief executive of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, David Murray, has said that he may also be interested in bidding for the National Bank as well.

title: AVERY DENNISON AND BEMIS RECEIVE SUBPOENAS FROM U.S.
description: The Avery Dennison Corporation, the world's biggest label maker, and a competitor, the Bemis Company, received subpoenas on Friday from the Justice Department related to an investigation of competitive practices in the label industry. Avery, based in Pasadena, Calif., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it planned to cooperate. Melanie Miller, a spokeswoman for Bemis, which is based in Minneapolis, said her company was also providing documents. The government's investigation into the industry, which makes labels for food cans, wine bottles and price tags, was first disclosed in April. The Justice Department won a court ruling in July blocking the sale of Bemis's sticker unit to UPM-Kymmene Oyj.

title: Funk and Haas Are Named to Team
description: Fred Funk and Jay Haas were named to the United States team for the Presidents Cup yesterday, and K.J. Choi and Tim Clark were added to the International team.

title: Clothing the Vegan Star
description: On Sept. 26, Alicia Silverstone will make her debut in a new NBC series called "Miss Match," which the network hopes will permeate the fashion consciousness much in the manner of "Sex and the City," on HBO. Like that series, "Miss Match" counts Darren Star as one of its creators and covers the subjects of lust, love, misery and renewal, set in a world of overpriced drinks.

title: Ford Plant Finds Efficiency Is No Protector
description: The Ford Motor Company's assembly plant near Atlanta is one of the most productive car factories on the continent, but a top union official there said today that its future was in doubt.

title: Unconstitutional Procedure May Not Halt Execution
description: Mark Robertson, who is to be executed in Texas tomorrow, is a member of a small fraternity of death row prisoners there. They were sentenced from 1989 to 1991 by juries under a procedure that the United States Supreme Court has held to be unconstitutional.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Aren't There Drugs For This?

title: A Chance For Opera, The City and City Opera
description: The redevelopers of ground zero have a historic opportunity to enhance the cultural life of New York City by ensuring the arts a lasting presence at the site. But the agency planning the rebuilding effort, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, could easily make a mistake if it erects a proposed multiuse performing arts center in the hope that a diverse range of organizations will then fill it.

title: Users Discover Pros and Cons In Stair-Climbing Wheelchair
description: When Dr. Rich Barbara signed up to test the iBOT -- Johnson & Johnson's stair-climbing wheelchair -- in the summer of 2001, he thought he would be reluctant to give it back at the end of the two-week trial. But impressed as he was with its balancing abilities, Dr. Barbara, a 50-year-old paraplegic, found himself yearning for his manual wheelchair.

title: P.G.A. TV Rating Down by 41 Percent
description: This year's four major golf championships have been won by players more familiar to serious fans than to a wider sports audience accustomed to Tiger Woods winning or contending. The television ratings have reflected Woods's struggles and the four victories by first-time winners of majors.

title: Ruling Expected Wednesday on Effort to Delay California Recall Election
description: A federal court judge promised today that he would rule by Wednesday on a lawsuit seeking to delay California's Oct. 7 recall election because some counties will still be using outdated punch-card machines.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Venture
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Unocal Corporation will sign an agreement in Beijing today, valued at an estimated $1 billion, to drill offshore Shanghai as they try to tap the world's second-largest energy market, a partner in the project said. Shell and Unocal will each take 20 percent in a venture in the Xihu Trough, 450 kilometers (280 miles) southeast of Shanghai. The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation and CNOOC Ltd., China's second- and third-largest oil producers, will split the rest. ''The gas discoveries will be piped to provinces and cities in east China, including Shanghai and Zhejiang,'' said Zheng Bin, a spokesman at CNOOC's parent, the China National Offshore Oil Corporation. The project, said to involve one of China's largest known offshore gas reserves, would give Shell a second supply of gas to sell to China's eastern coastal cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALAZZO, JOSEPH J.
description: PALAZZO--Joseph J. Age 52. On August 14, 2003. Loving and cherished father of Melissa and Joseph. Beloved grandfather of Marissa. Life partner of Dean Steigauf. Also survived by his former wife and loving friend, Colleen Dubois. Joseph passed away of a heart attack on the Queensboro Bridge while walking home during the Blackout of 2003. He will be forever missed, loved, and always in our hearts. Family and friends may visit at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, N.Y. on Tuesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 10PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday Resurrection Ascension Church, 9:45AM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Bankruptcy Filings Increase to a Record
description: Bankruptcy filings by consumers soared to a record 1.61 million in the year that ended on June 30, as unemployment touched a nine-year high, court records show.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS TO ACQUIRE SPS TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Precision Castparts Corporation, a supplier of metal castings for jet engines, agreed to buy a tool and fastener maker, SPS Technologies, for $575 million in cash and stock to expand in the aerospace and automotive industries. Precision, which is based in Portland, Ore., valued the offer at $43.78 for each share of SPS, 28 percent more than SPS's closing price on Friday. More than half its $2.1 billion in sales last year were to the aerospace industry. SPS, which is based in Jenkintown, Pa., also sells mainly to aerospace companies. It made a quarter of its $830.3 million in sales last year to automotive companies.

title: I.B.M. to Cut 600 at Chip Unit and Give 3,000 Unpaid Leave
description: In a move to cut costs, I.B.M. said yesterday that it was trimming 600 workers from its semiconductor business. Another 3,000 employees in that division will be placed on furlough for one week without pay.

title: JARDEN AGREES TO BUY LEHIGH CONSUMER PRODUCTS
description: The Jarden Corporation, the maker of Ball jars, agreed to buy the closely held Lehigh Consumer Products Corporation for $155 million. Lehigh is the largest supplier of rope, cord and twine in the United States, Jarden said. Lehigh, which had about $130 million in sales in the 12-month period ended June 30, supplies products to home-improvement companies. Lehigh, based in Macungie, Pa., has about 500 employees. Jarden, which is based in Rye, N.Y., expects the purchase to add to earnings this year.

title: Aetna Settles Dentists' Suit Over Delays in Payments
description: Aetna, one of the biggest health insurers, plans to announce this morning that it has settled a lawsuit over billing practices with most of the nation's dentists.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS CLIMB. Soybean prices rose on concern that higher-than-normal temperatures in the Midwest might damage the crop. In Chicago, soybeans for November delivery rose 30.75 cents, or 5.6 percent, to $5.805 a bushel.

description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar surged against the euro on speculation that economic growth in the United States would outpace Europe's. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1153, down from $1.1256 on Friday.

It is the Nebraska Health and Human Services System, not the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: SOLUTIA CONSIDERS BANKRUPTCY FILING, CITING SUITS
description: Solutia, a chemical maker spun off from Monsanto six years ago, said it was considering a bankruptcy protection filing because litigation had tied up its cash. Monsanto said it could face millions of dollars in costs as a result. Lawsuits accuse Monsanto of dumping toxic waste into a creek and landfill near Anniston, Ala., more than 30 years ago. Verdicts in the first phase of cases totaled $100.5 million, Monsanto said in a regulatory filing last week. Solutia made its statement about bankruptcy in a regulatory filing last week. Both companies are based in St. Louis. Solutia has spent more than $50 million cleaning up a plant and surrounding area in Anniston. Monsanto said that the $100.5 million in verdicts related only to property damage claims. Personal injury and punitive damage claims have yet to be tried.

title: Not Perfect, but Trachsel and the Mets Will Take It
description: Steve Trachsel's pitching line consisted of nine innings, no runs, no walks and a single hit, a sparkling set of numbers, but one that does not necessarily describe how well he pitched. He was tantalizingly close to not only a no-hitter, but also to a perfect game, feats that escaped him only because the Mets' defense did not come through. Trachsel will have to settle for a brilliant performance, his second one-hitter this season for a franchise that has never had a no-hitter in its 41-year history.

title: Front Row; Burly Girl Power
description: Among the more surprising logos to be taken up by fashion over the last couple of years, there is little that compares to the mudflap girl. The retro trend that put socialites in trucker caps also transported this girl, a silhouetted nymphet with her Barbie physique and Farrah Fawcett hairdo, from behind the axles of tractor trailers and onto shirt fronts, belt buckles, sweat clothes and even Hollywood red carpets. Like the Playboy bunny, she was embraced for the very qualities that would once have made her anathema to feminists. What early bra-burners might have seen as a symbol of contemptible objectification now seems goofy and hip. If Kate Hudson likes the mudflap girl, she has to be cool, goes the thinking. And she is, in a Jane magazine kind of way.

description: For the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the blackout that deprived some 50 million people of power last week seemed to come at a fitting time.

title: World Briefing | South Pacific: Australia: New Post For Former U.N. Weapons Chief
description: Richard Butler, a former chief United Nations arms inspector who from 1997 to 1999 directed the hunt in Iraq for illegal weapons, will be the new governor of Tasmania, Australia's southernmost state. Mr. Butler, 61, a career diplomat who recently advocated that Australia cut its constitutional links to Britain, will take over the post on Oct. 1, when he is sworn in as Queen Elizabeth's representative on Tasmania. John Shaw (NYT)

description: FITZPATRICK--Thomas B. M.D., Ph.D. The Department of Dermatology at New York University School of Medicine notes with sorrow the passing of Tom Fitzpatrick, Chairman-Emeritus of the Department of Dermatology at the Harvard Medical School. At Harvard and the MGH, TBF trained many dermatologic leaders throughout the world. Through their efforts his passion for cutaneous biology and his dedication to dermatology and patients with dermatologic diseases will be perpetuated. Our condolences to his wife, Bea, and his children. Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D. MacKee Professor & Chair Ronald O. Perelman Dept of Dermatology New York University School of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINNERAN, JOHN BUCKLEY
description: FINNERAN--John Buckley, 69, passed away Monday, August 18, 2003 in Stamford, CT. Born on July 14, 1934, he grew up in Larchmont, NY and graduated from Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains. A 1956 graduate of Tufts University in Boston, Mr. Finneran served as a Commissary and Sales Officer aboard USS Antietam, and was the Material Division Officer at NAS Lakehurst, NJ. In civilian life, Capt. Finneran held the position of Vice President, Director of Marketing, Seagram Overseas Sales Company. Mr. Finneran earned a Masters of Business Administration degree from New York University, and was President of Chapter One Supply Corps Association. He resided in Europe for four years and traveled extensively in the Far East, Latin America and the Caribbean. Mr. Finneran came to reside in Stamford, CT., and for the last ten years has worked as a Realtor with the William Pitt Agency. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy Carpenter Finneran, daughter Kerry F. Gardiner, and son Jack T. Finneran, six stepchildren, four grandchildren and 17 step-grandchildren. He is also survived by is brothers Gerard B. Finneran, Thomas Rowan, William B. Finneran, and sisters Judith A. Finneran and Susan Ashley. A funeral mass will be held for family and friends on August 22, 2003 at 10:00 AM at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, 1200 Shippan Avenue, Stamford, CT. 06902, 203-324-4634. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Patrons Program, 1011 First Avenue, 14th Floor, NY, NY 10022, Att: Jill Kafka.

description: BONGIORNO--Eve, known to all as ''Gogie'', died August 17, 2003 at age 91. She had a capacity for love that brought something special into everyone's life. Her children, Marilyn and Joey, her grandchildren, Susan (and Max), Robert (and Barbara), Robert (and Susan), Lauren, and Howard (and Elyse), and her ten great-grandchildren, all felt especially loved. Her legacy of Love will never be forgotten. Joey & Joan/Alan & Marilyn

But why and when human body hair disappeared, together with the matter of when people first started to wear clothes, are questions that have long lain beyond the reach of archaeology and paleontology.

Whatever the initial cause, however, the current guess is that a local event turned into an epic blackout because the transmission network has been neglected. That is, the power industry hasn't spent enough on the control systems and safeguards that are supposed to prevent such things.

SHAREHOLDERS CANCEL SALE OF MEXICAN RAILROAD
description: Shareholders in Grupo TMM, a debt-burdened Mexican transportation company, voted to cancel the sale of a stake in Mexico's largest railroad to Kansas City Southern Industries, opposing a recommendation from TMM's board. In April, TMM agreed to take $200 million in cash and $212 million in stock for its 43 percent stake in Transportes Ferroviarios Mexicanos. The shareholder revolt came after a Mexican tax court ruled last week that the company may be eligible to recover as much as $900 million in back taxes dating back to 1997. TMM, which defaulted on a $177 million bond in May, may be able to use the cash from the award to pay off creditors. It has debts totaling $1.4 billion. Kansas City Southern owns 37 percent of Ferroviarios, but the rejection by TMM's shareholders might end its plan to merge it with two other railroads to create Nafta Rail, linking Mexico to Texas and the Midwest via 6,000 miles of track.

title: Iraqi Ex-Vice President Seized; No. 20 on Most Wanted List
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 19  One of Saddam Hussein's most loyal and ruthless aides, Taha Yassin Ramadan, has been turned over to allied forces in northern Iraq, American military officials said today.

title: The Two Cowards
description: In the Middle East, it is no longer a war between Israel and Palestine. Since the cease-fire began more than seven weeks ago, public opinion surveys both in Israel and Palestine consistently show that a clear majority on both sides endorses the cease-fire, supports the road map to peace and favors the idea of a two-state solution, Israel next to Palestine.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: BAIL DELAY IS APPROVED A man who prosecutors say attempted to sell shoulder-fired rockets capable of destroying American passenger jets has been granted another week for his lawyers to prepare his request for bail. The man, Hemant Lakhani, 68, of London, was scheduled for a hearing yesterday to request bail, federal prosecutors said. But his lawyer, Donald J. McCauley, said he needed more time to recommend a detailed bail request. In an international sting operation, Mr. Lakhani was arrested on Aug. 12 in New Jersey. Prosecutors said he was attempting to sell surface-to-air missiles to a man who he believed was a terrorist, but who was actually an undercover officer. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARNEDOE, KIRK
description: VARNEDOE--Kirk. It is with the greatest saddness that the Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the untimely death of their dear friend and former colleague, Kirk Varnedoe, who was for many years the Museum's Chief Curator in the Department of Painting and Sculpture. Kirk leaves and extraordinary legacy, for he was a man of many talents--a brilliant curator, writer, teacher, lecturer, scholar, and mentor to younger colleagues during his 15year association with MoMA. An astute historian of the Museum's collection and of modern and contemporary art, he negotiated crucial acquisitions and organized landmark exhibitions. His deep friendships with artists greatly benefited the Museum in myriad ways. Some of these friendships developed out of the artist-organized exhibitions, ''Artist's Choice,'' which Kirk created and directed. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Elyn Zimmerman, to his brothers Samuel and Gordon Varnedoe, and to his sister Comer Meadows. David Rockefeller Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art

title: Enola Gay Reassembled for Revised Museum Show
description: The Smithsonian Institution, skirting the controversy in 1995 that enveloped its display of the Enola Gay, the B-29 bomber that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, adopted a minimalist approach today as it displayed the plane in a new setting.

title: Administration Plans Defense Of Terror Law
description: The Bush administration, under increasing criticism over its terrorism policies, is beginning an unusual counteroffensive this week in an effort to shore up support for the prized legislation that grew out of the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Rapist Is Linked to Attacks On 4 Girls Over a Decade

They also said that, using DNA evidence, they have tied him to the 1993 rape of an 11-year-old.

title: The Baghdad Bombing; A Nation-Builder Slain

Among other things, he said, ''The United Nations' presence in Iraq remains vulnerable to any who would seek to target our organization.''

title: Magnet For Evil
description: The Bush team has now created the very monster that it conjured up to alarm Americans into backing a war on Iraq.

title: Dave & Buster's Selects Fallon's New York Unit
description: Dave & Buster's, a restaurant chain, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by divisions of One Square in Dallas. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: Job on the Line, Davis Promises To Fight Recall
description: In a fight for his political life, Gov. Gray Davis pleaded with Californians today to reject the attempt to recall him, describing it as part of a right-wing effort ''to steal elections Republicans cannot win.''

title: Pension Fund Presses Banks on Standards
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest pension fund in the nation, said yesterday that it would ask 90 investment banks and brokers that trade on its behalf to tighten rules intended to prevent conflicts of interest.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS. The dollar fell against the yen after an industry report showed consumer confidence unexpectedly fell this month. In New York, the dollar settled at 118.40 yen, down from 119.49 on Monday.

title: Shanghai Favorites With Some Hong Kong Flair
description: LET'S get one of the particulars of this column out of the way directly. At Joe's Ginger, which sits on Mott Street in Chinatown in the manner of a jewel set into concrete, four hungry souls can eat like ravenous hogs for around $100.

title: A High Quality of Life, A Strained Pension Plan
description: Amelia Antonetti retired nine months ago after 31 years as a high school teacher and now spends her days looking after her husband and three grown children. All the while, Mrs. Antonetti, 56, collects 90 percent of her last salary and will do so for the rest of her life.

title: Heroes, From Rappelling Officer to Sewage Savior
description: Some were honored for acts of derring-do, like Detective James Moran, who had rappelled down a shaft in the Empire State Building to rescue a passenger stuck in an elevator. Others got kudos for quieter acts of heroism, like Myra Miller, who had cared for some of the children in her Brooklyn day camp all night.

title: Tiger's Test
description: Tiger Woods went 0 for 4 in this year's major golf tournaments, and -- judging by the TV ratings alone -- this is clearly not good for the overall health of professional golf. Yet there may well be an upside to Tiger's downfall. With Woods winning so often and so routinely -- 7 of 11 majors from the 1999 P.G.A. Championship through last year's United States Open -- the competition had become less compelling, even if Woods himself had not. His decline has allowed new faces to emerge and given hope to older players, who kept coming in second. And watching Woods play catch-up may turn out to be more interesting than watching him sit alone at the top.

title: WINE CALENDAR
description: Toasts for the Ponies

title: A Star From Europe in U.S. College Football
description: On a recent hot afternoon, Tennessee offensive tackle Michael Munoz is battling one on one with defensive end Constantin Ritzmann, trying to keep him away from the quarterback. The battles are intense, the players, both of them team captains, demonstrating to their understudies the tenacity and toughness required at this level of college football.

title: A Bit of Vegemite For Your Brioche, Mate?
description: Cans of Foster's Lager and jars of Vegemite on the bar are clues that the Sunburnt Cow, 137 Avenue C (Ninth Street) has Australian loyalties and an Australian owner, Heathe St. Clair, far left. It's a fixer-upper of a place, with oil drums lined up to make a bar, an uneven tin ceiling spray-painted blue and kindergarten-height tables. But this cafe also makes finely crafted Australian and French pastries. Mr. St. Clair and his partners, Chris Johnson and Chris Andrews (second and third from left), all worked in top restaurants and that's how they met Eric Hubert, on the right. Now Mr. Hubert, the new pastry chef at Atelier on Central Park South, also supervises the making of the cafe's raspberry brioches, apricot Pavlovas and Anzac cookies, which are wheat-oat-raisin crisps that Australians made of army rations during World War I.

title: Weaver Does Nothing To Secure Roster Spot
description: Jeff Weaver made it clear yesterday how he would react if the Yankees sent him to the minors. Weaver, the scuffling No. 5 starter, responded testily when asked if anyone from the Yankees had approached him about the idea.

title: With Denial, Mendacity and Suicide, a Magnet for Biographers
description: ARSHILE GORKY

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Profit In Batteries
description: A leading maker of rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, the BYD Company of Shenzhen, said its profit rose 27 percent to 325 million yuan ($39 million) in the first half as salesrose 57 percent to 1.49 billion yuan ($180 million). The company said it planned to build a factory in Beijing to help it meet increasing demand for its batteries used in products like cellphones and power tools.

title: How America Created a Terrorist Haven
description: Yesterday's bombing of the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad was the latest evidence that America has taken a country that was not a terrorist threat and turned it into one.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merck Completes Spinoff Of Drug Benefit Manager

title: Under Fire, F.C.C. Chief Plans Study of Media 'Localism'
description: With his bid to ease media ownership rules under assault from consumer groups, members of Congress and others worried about the impact of consolidation, Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that he was appointing a task force to study the "localism" of individual radio and television stations.

title: The Exuberance of Bahia, The Sorrow of Birmingham
description: Cleo Parker Robinson is one of the most glamorously feisty company directors in American dance, and she has kept her Denver-based troupe going for 33 years, which is no small feat. The dancers are for the most part young and eager to please. But it was the older, more seasoned performers and the simpler pieces that worked best on Monday night at the Joyce Theater as the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble presented five pieces covering a fairly wide range of styles and themes.

title: Trading Barbie for Drugs, Sex and Halter Tops
description: The panic in the eyes of Tracy (Evan Rachel Wood), the barely teenage protagonist of ''Thirteen,'' will stay with you for a very long time. Both her fear and pleasure -- since they are inextricably entwined -- are almost always visible, especially in a harrowing scene about loss of control that is a pinnacle of performance. Tracy and her new best friend, Evie (Nikki Reed), try to lure a 20-something neighbor (Kip Pardue) into a threesome. With a hollow fervor Tracy goes through the motions of what she thinks she should be doing, imitating Evie's lead. Tracy's ferocious appetite gives this story of a 13-year-old girl's extended period of debauchery and misery a magnetic volatility; she moves through this mess slightly startled, as if she were trapped in a waking nightmare.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Luckily, Griffith Did Not Want a Musical

title: 'Altruism' and an Organ Donor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vegetable Sandwiches To Wrap Up the Summer
description: IN a sandwich, vegetables are capable of fine ensemble work. The trick is to create a pleasing group dynamic -- flickers of flavor, nuance of texture, bands of color -- and then select a type of bread to enhance the overall composition. The best part? You get to eat vegetables with your hands.

title: Italian Puzzle: The Land That Doesn't Seem to Fit
description: Italy has long occupied an odd place in Europe, too potent to be ignored but too peculiar to be embraced. It is a member of all the right clubs, with an undeniably awkward place at the table.

title: Stevens Released From the Hospital
description: The Hall of Fame jockey Gary Stevens, who sustained a collapsed lung and a broken bone in his back when he fell from his horse during the Arlington Million last Saturday, was released from the hospital yesterday morning, Arlington Park racetrack officials said.

title: Heat Death Toll Forces a Shocked France to Question Itself
description: PARIS, Aug. 20  The neighbors knew that Monique Taupin, heavyset and about 70, breathed fitfully. So few were surprised when she took a taxi one Saturday early this month to a hospital near her home in Paris's 13th arrondissement.

title: Military Explosives Used in Baghdad Blast, F.B.I. Says
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 20 — The F.B.I. team investigating the suicide bombing of the United Nations headquarters here determined today that some 1,500 pounds of explosives drawn from Iraqi military stocks, including a chunky old Soviet-made bomb, caused the massive explosion.

title: What the Bees Found in the Trees
description: The honey made by bees that buzz around sourwood trees in the hills of Georgia and the Carolinas is rich and deep amber, with overtones of maple and spice.

title: Questions About Role of World Agencies in Hot Spots
description: As grief at the devastating destruction of the United Nations compound in Baghdad cascaded through the organization's headquarters today, a few officials and diplomats began to raise troubling questions about the incident.

title: Creamy Avocado Tames Tequila's Fiery Bite
description: SOME people might be content with a dish of salt with tequila; a meal may never enter their minds. The rest of us actually need food when drinking tequila, so we do not topple off our chairs.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Armand Borel, a mathematician and a professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., misspelled the surname of another mathematician at the institute who helped inspire his work on the theory of numbers. He was Robert Langlands, not Langland.

title: An Author Gets Back At Knopf; She'll Teach Them To Drop Her
description: ''I was fired from Knopf!'' said the mystery writer Martha Grimes. ''Sonny didn't want the next Jury book,'' she said, speaking of Sonny Mehta, editor in chief of Alfred A. Knopf, and Ms. Grimes's 18-book series about an urbane British detective, Richard Jury, all named after English pubs, like ''The Blue Last'' and ''The Grave Maurice.''

title: Executive Departs Advice and Advisors
description: Alan L. Krinsky has left Advice and Advisors, the New York consulting company that helps advertisers manage agency reviews.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Orange: Woman Seriously Injured By Train
description: A New Jersey Transit train struck and critically injured a woman yesterday after she ignored repeated warnings to get off the tracks, officials said. The woman, whose name was not immediately released, was in critical condition at University Hospital in Newark, officials said. At 7:10 a.m., as the train approached the Orange station, the engineer noticed a woman walking on the tracks. He blew the train horn, but she continued to walk, officials said. The engineer applied the brakes but could not avoid hitting her, transit officials said. Train service was delayed for about 15 minutes. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: Housing Starts Hit 17-Year High in July
description: Starts on new homes unexpectedly surged last month to the highest level in 17 years, a new report shows, providing further evidence that housing remains remarkably robust.

title: Stranded Commuters
description: To the Editor:

title: Milwaukee Priests Seek Marriages in Clergy
description: More than 160 Roman Catholic priests in the Milwaukee Archdiocese have signed copies of a letter calling on the church to allow married men to join the priesthood.

title: 'Altruism' and an Organ Donor
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The goal is to deny the American occupation force the ability to pacify Iraq, to prevent the Americans from winning the hearts and minds of the people. If Iraq is in constant chaos, the United States can never move on to the next stage.''

title: As Talks Resume, Verizon Argues With a Union Over an Ad Phrase
description: While negotiators for Verizon Communications and its workers resumed bargaining yesterday over crucial elements like health benefits and job security, the two sides also swapped accusations over the appropriate use of the phrase, ''Can you hear me now?''

title: HUGE SUICIDE BLAST DEMOLISHES U.N. HEADQUARTERS IN BAGHDAD; TOP AID OFFICIALS AMONG 17 DEAD
description: A suicide bomber drove a gleaming new cement mixer full of explosives into the side of the United Nations compound here today and blew it up, killing 17 people and wounding at least 100 in an attack on one of the principal agencies in charge of rebuilding Iraq.

title: Political Memo; Bond Battle Could Blow Hole in City's Shaky Budget
description: New York State is suing New York City, but only because the city did not get to court first. The governor and the Legislature are at war. The city is fighting for an aid package it did not even want at first. Even by Albany standards, the battle over a state aid package to help New York City balance its budget is one for the books.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: GROUP TAKES BLAME FOR FIRE The Earth Liberation Front has claimed responsibility for a $50 million fire that destroyed an apartment complex under construction in San Diego two weeks ago. No one was injured in the three-alarm blaze on Aug. 3 on the city's fast-growing northern edge. Since 1996, the group has claimed responsibility for arson attacks against commercial interests that members say threaten or damage the environment. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Labor Demonstration
description: Members of the country's two major labor organizations, the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions and the Federation of Korean Trade Unions, demonstrated in Seoul against a bill for a five-day week. The unions say that the bill, although it would shorten the week from 44 to 40 hours, would deprive workers of holidays and reduce wages. About 25,000 workers at Kia Motors stayed off the job for several hours, demanding a five-day week and an 11.1 percent wage increase. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: The Roots of a Bond Fight

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Posts Narrower 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Intuit, the world's largest maker of tax-preparation software, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed as sales increased. But its shares fell as the company projected a wider-than-expected loss this quarter. The net loss shrank to $24.7 million, or 12 cents a share, from $31.8 million, or 15 cents, a year earlier, Intuit said in a statement. Sales rose 31 percent, to $245.1 million, in the three months ended July 31 from $186.9 million. Intuit, which makes TurboTax software and gets most of its sales during the tax season of January through April, will also buy back as much as $500 million worth of its shares. Shares of Intuit fell $1.12, to $44.12, in extended trading after the report. They had declined 29 cents in regular trading.

title: Old Guy, Young Guy, Giants' Two Return Guys
description: Delvin Joyce forms the dent in a Giants huddle. He is the dip between the N.F.L.-sized players. He walked into a huddle today at training camp, alongside fullback Charles Stackhouse, and came up to Stackhouse's chin.

title: Funny Cide Finally Works Out As the Travers Drama Increases
description: The intrigue surrounding the 134th running of the Travers Stakes thickened today when Funny Cide, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, turned in his first workout since falling ill 16 days ago. Meanwhile, rumors swirled that Empire Maker, the Belmont Stakes winner, might be a no-show.

title: In Tequila's Layers, Hints of Sea and Spice
description: THE margarita is an American staple, whether in its frozen-slush frat-party style or as a straight-up cocktail that can rival a martini for elegance. It's especially attractive in the summer, and so the Dining section's tasting panel decided to stray from the grape to taste tequilas.

title: Ed Townsend, 74, a Musician Who Co-Wrote 'Let's Get It On'
description: Ed Townsend, a singer and songwriter who with Marvin Gaye produced and wrote the 1973 hit ''Let's Get It On,'' one of the most enduringly erotic songs of the R&B era, died on Aug. 13 at a hospital in San Bernardino, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Sun City, Calif.

title: An Ambulance Corps in Need of Rescue
description: In its early years, the small fleet of roving white ambulances with ''The Rock'' emblazoned on the side was a small but crucial community ambulance service, helping to rescue swimmers and serving the elderly and high-crime communities in the Rockaways.

title: Back to Work Despite Tears, City Council Honors Davis
description: City Council members returned yesterday to the minutiae of governing, settling into their red leather seats at City Hall and seeking comfort in the routines that were interrupted a month ago when Councilman James E. Davis was slain by a political rival in front of their eyes.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: No-Confidence Vote Defeated
description: After two days of heated and chaotic speechmaking in Parliament, the coalition government survived a no-confidence motion by a vote of 312 to 186. The motion was sponsored by the opposition Congress Party and was seen as a stage-setter for crucial state elections this fall and general elections next year. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: In the war against warts, the latest over-the-counter weapon is a freezing technology.
description: IN the competitive world of American marketing, there are the cola wars and the movie wars, the cellular-service wars and the car wars, the fast-food wars and the cereal wars. Now the warfare is spreading to a new realm, products to freeze warts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bush Condemns Iraq Bombing And Vows U.S. Will Persevere
description: President Bush denounced the bombing in Baghdad today as the work of ''enemies of the civilized world,'' and vowed that the United States would not be deterred from confronting terrorism and bringing stability to Iraq.

title: Waiting for the Inevitable in Baghdad
description: It was bound to happen. Those of us who spent time in the United Nations compound in Baghdad predicted it would happen and nervously joked that it was just a matter of time. It was such a soft target -- a former hotel in an isolated part of town. Our only solace was the thought: who would want to hurt the United Nations?

title: Foes of Venezuela's President Take First Step Toward Recall
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 20  Venezuelan opposition groups presented elections officials today with 3.2 million signatures calling for the removal of President Hugo Chavez, the first step of a new effort to oust the leftist leader through a constitutional recall referendum.

title: Off to Freshman Year, a Perfect Score in Hand
description: SEEMED like that's all anybody wanted to know these last few weeks. ''When you leaving, Chris?'' asked Sean Howard, principal of Russell High. Most graduates in this small eastern Kentucky town of 4,000 attend the local community college or a state university. But each year a few, the brightest, like Chris Williams, go out of state to college.

title: Charter Panel Drops Opposition To Union Political Donations
description: The Charter Revision Commission reversed itself yesterday and voted to eliminate a provision that would ban donations to candidates from labor unions as well as political action committees. The provision had previously been part of the commission's proposal on nonpartisan elections to be presented to New York City voters in a referendum this November.

title: BOMBING KILLS 18 AND HURTS SCORES ON JERUSALEM BUS
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber killed at least 18 people, including children, when he detonated an explosive packed with ball bearings tonight aboard a city bus crowded with families, some of them returning from Judaism's holiest site, the Western Wall.

title: Old Virus Has A New Trick: Mailing Itself In Quantity
description: If the e-mail message offers ''details,'' ''That movie'' or ''Wicked screensaver,'' don't open the attachment. (And why are you still opening unsolicited attachments, anyway? Don't you ever learn?)

title: Outbreak Near Vancouver Resembles SARS
description: Medical authorities said today that early test results of a small portion of a virus that has spread through a nursing home outside Vancouver is genetically identical to SARS, but scientists are sharply divided over the meaning of the findings.

title: Welcome to the Big City. Beware the Dinosaurs.
description: New York can be a tough place for a couple of college kids from Tulsa, as Brian and Chris Harms learned this summer.

title: Swiss Airline Reports Smaller Loss After Cuts
description: Swiss International Air Lines narrowed its losses in the second quarter, benefiting from steep cuts in its work force and routes, the company said today.

title: China Takes Gold As U.S. Vaulter Errs
description: The United States, which had never won a men's team title in the world gymnastics championships, came close tonight. But as good as the Americans were, China was better, and the Americans hurt their cause when one of their gymnasts made a mistake and the team coaches reported it.

title: Afghan Powder Keg: Weeks of Violence
description: Violence remains commonplace in Afghanistan. These are among incidents in the last month.

title: U.S. Backs Colombia on Attacking Drug Planes
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, on a one-day visit to Colombia, said today that the United States would support Colombia in resuming a policy that allows Colombian fighter pilots to shoot down planes suspected of ferrying drugs or force them to land.

title: For Relatives Of Beaten Boy, Tears Trump Finger-Pointing
description: There was no second-guessing of a system that seemed to have failed again.

title: The Power Failure: Put Politics Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: OGE ENERGY OBTAINS STAKE IN OKLAHOMA POWER PLANT
description: The OGE Energy Corporation said yesterday that its Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company utility had agreed to buy a 77 percent stake in a power plant from a unit of NRG Energy Inc. for $159.9 million to cut electricity costs. Buying 400 megawatts of the capacity of the plant near Newcastle, Okla., is cheaper than buying the power or building a plant, OGE said. OGE plans to sell as many as 4.5 million shares of its common stock to pay for the acquisition and to reduce debt. It is buying the plant from NRG McClain L.L.C. NRG Energy, which is based in Minneapolis and is a unit of Xcel Energy Inc., filed for bankruptcy protection in May.

title: Reality of Little League
description: To the Editor:

title: Partisanship Showed
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Board Backs Retreat On Class Size
description: Florida's top education officials are seeking a partial repeal of a disputed plan to lower class size, a move that could cost state taxpayers billions of dollars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FOG CUTTER CAPITAL GROUP INC., Portland, Ore., an investment firm, said that it had acquired Magic Johnson's majority stake in Fatburger Holdings Inc., a chain of 49 hamburger restaurants, for a $6 million investment and financing package.

title: Blackout Leads to Conflicting Conclusions About Keeping Indian Point Reactors Open
description: Depending on whom you ask, the blackout of 2003 is evidence of two opposite conclusions about the Indian Point nuclear reactors that sit about 35 miles north of Midtown Manhattan on the Hudson River.

title: American Decides Old Style Fits Fine
description: Rajeev Ram might be the United States' most promising serve-and-volley player. He is also one of its few serve-and-volley players.

title: An Omelet Alternative
description: SUMMER is, generally speaking, a time of leaner food. At least we say that, and to some extent it's true: grilling uses minimal fat, we have an opportunity to cook with better vegetables, and one can always opt for a decent piece of fruit for dessert. But long summer weekends with guests seem to demand the occasional blowout breakfast, and after a few rounds of pancakes and waffles I broke down and assembled this extremely serious morning repast.

title: O'Reilly to Attend U.S. Women's Camp
description: Less than two months after breaking her left leg in an exhibition match, Heather O'Reilly has been named to the training camp roster as the United States women's national team begins preparations for next month's Women's World Cup.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Workers Will Not Be Docked
