description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg decided yesterday that city workers who did not show up for work last Friday, the day after the blackout, would not lose a vacation or personal day. Administration officials had considered charging employees for the day off, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did after a blizzard in 1996, officials of several public-employee unions said. But Mayor Bloomberg decided not to penalize workers who followed his advice to take the day off. Following the 1996 blizzard, Mayor Giuliani was forced to give back days to docked workers after unions raised objections. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cable TV Bills Exceed Those For Satellite
description: The average amount consumers spend on cable television service has risen above the average monthly expenditure on satellite TV, according to a report released yesterday. Consumers now spend an average of $49.62 a month for cable TV, compared with an average of $48.93 for satellite TV, according to the report, from J. D. Power & Associates. The higher spending on cable TV is a result of consumers buying new services, including digital TV, which offers more channels and a sharper image. Monthly spending on satellite TV has risen 8 percent in the last five years, compared with an increase of 41 percent for cable TV, the report said. The higher spending on cable TV comes as satellite television has been gaining market share. About 17 percent of United States households now have satellite subscriptions, compared with 7 percent in 1998. Households subscribing to cable TV declined to 60 percent from 68 percent in that period.

title: Amid Blood and Rubble, A Sense of Helplessness
description: Soon after Salim Lone, the spokesman for the special United Nations representative in Iraq, stumbled dazed and bleeding from the wreckage of the headquarters here, he learned that rescue teams were trying to get water to his boss, Sergio Vieira de Mello, trapped and wounded but still talking from beneath the rubble.

title: Suits and Pleas Look to Recoup Money Lost In the Blackout
description: From Albany to City Hall, from private law firms to a public power authority, New Yorkers are beginning to seek relief or a refund for money they lost in the blackout.

title: 60's Radical Convicted in Deadly Shootout Is Granted Parole
description: Kathy Boudin, the former radical fugitive who pleaded guilty for her role in a 1981 armored-car robbery and shootout that killed a guard and two police officers in Rockland County, was granted parole today after 22 years in prison.

title: Head of Mexico Rights Office Fears Its Closing May Block Reform
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19  The unceremonious closing of Mexico's high-level human rights office has sounded alarms with human rights and political groups who are taking the move as an sign that President Vincente Fox has begun to back off from his pledge pursue bold democratic reforms.

title: A Countertenor Ventures Into Stage and Folk Music
description: David Daniels decided long ago that he would not limit himself to the predominantly early music repertory that countertenors were expected to sing, but would perform anything he felt he could interpret persuasively. So while he has not jettisoned countertenor specialties, he has poached works by Beethoven, Brahms and Poulenc from the soprano, mezzo-soprano and tenor repertories. Because his voice has the roundness and power of a mature contralto, he has been able to make this repertory expansion work.

title: Trade and Self-Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Are Rolling; Red Sox Are Reeling
description: It has been a season of extremes for the Yankees, and now they have reached two more: 30 games over .500, with a six-and-a-half-game lead in the American League East. After brushing aside the Central-leading Kansas City Royals last night, 6-3, the Yankees seem to be on the verge of burying the Boston Red Sox again.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Police Catch Fugitive Minister
description: The Rev. Arthur Allen Jr., the leader of the House of Prayer who has been a fugitive for five months was arrested in a park near Atlanta, parked illegally with his wife and seven children. Mr. Allen, left, and two other church members failed to appear at a hearing in March to determine if their probation on child cruelty charges should be revoked for not attending court-ordered anger-management counseling, his lawyer said. Last October, a jury convicted Mr. Allen and four church members of whipping children in church. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Year After U.S. Debacle, So Much Has Changed
description: Jermaine O'Neal and Elton Brand were there when the international basketball landscape changed forever. They were there on the baseline appearing helpless against precision screens and backdoor cuts. They were there when dissension, cockiness and perhaps a lack of fundamentals caused a team of N.B.A. stars to lose for the first time to a foreign opponent.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Hospitals Prepare For SARS
description: As a precaution in case the respiratory disease SARS returns this winter, a government committee approved plans by public hospitals to turn 520 rooms with 1,290 beds into isolation wards. A separate panel of international health experts appointed by Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, said it had been given complete access to officials involved in the territory's response to the SARS outbreak this year and would assess individual responsibility. The panel said it would issue a report on Oct. 2. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: What You'd Expect at a Place Called the Ritz
description: AS a general rule, the better the restaurant, the longer it takes to hit its stride. When the place has lofty ambitions, as Atelier does, the general rule becomes an iron law. What is a critic to do? Common sense says to wait, say, six months before writing a review. Let the chef and the rest of the team find their footing. In the real world, however, common sense is nonsense. Readers cannot wait indefinitely, forks at the ready, to get the lowdown on an important new restaurant. The critic's job is to get a review to the table while it's still hot.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits on Thursday with an article about Dartmouth College's campuswide e-mail system misspelled the name of a campus building. It is the Collis Student Center, not Colis.

title: Like Huck, on a 'Big River' That Leads to 'Brooklyn'
description: JEFF CALHOUN happens to be the visionary behind the most egalitarian musical on Broadway -- the revival of ''Big River,'' with its innovative amalgam of deaf and hearing actors, of signing and singing -- but he has just been rejected for jury duty and can't imagine why. ''And I thought I was the smartest one in the room!'' he huffs, feigning a snit. He was also the best dressed; come to think of it, that may have been a strike against him. Maybe he upstaged the lawyers?

title: Brooklyn? Newark? Nets Don't Know
description: The principal owners of the Nets met yesterday to discuss the possible sale of the team and its eventual destination, which might be Brooklyn or Newark or its current address in the Meadowlands.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Postpones Rules On Unsolicited Faxes
description: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that it had decided to postpone regulations for unsolicited faxes generally used to send sales pitches and advertisements. The commission will not require companies to obtain written permission before they send such faxes, as required by the regulations, until Jan. 1, 2005. The fax regulations were set to take effect on Monday. The guidelines were passed in June along with other telemarketing rules, including those creating the do-not-call registry, which takes effect Oct. 1. The fax rules will require businesses to receive consent from individuals and other companies before they send unsolicited faxes; these faxes are often sent to hundreds of numbers at once.

title: In a Tyranny of Children, The Cook Can Be King
description: I AM always on the wrong side of the parental balance of power. As a child, I felt I lived in a totalitarian state run by adults; now I seem to live in a totalitarian state run by children.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: The Baghdad Bombing; A Mission Imperiled
description: Terrorists aim not just at inflicting death and devastation. They also hope to poison the emotional and political climate around their targets. Tragically, the truck bombers who blew up the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad yesterday have already succeeded on the first score, killing the chief U.N. representative in Iraq and at least 16 others, and disrupting desperately needed international relief efforts. They must not be allowed the second triumph, further deepening the psychological chasm between reconstruction efforts and Iraqi civilians.

title: Ambitious Bush Plan Is Undone by Energy Politics
description: President Bush stood at a gasoline station near his ranch in Texas today and said he had been calling for an energy bill to modernize the nation's electricity grid ''for a long time.''

title: Off the Menu
description: ALEX GARCIA, left, is a man with big plans, one of which will take up 14,000 square feet, in fact. Mr. Garcia, who was the chef at Calle Ocho and is a partner in Babalu, a Latin nightclub and restaurant, plans to open LQ, for Latin Quarter, in what had been Denim and Diamonds in the Radisson Hotel at 511 Lexington Avenue (47th Street). When it opens on Sept. 10, it will also have a nightclub and restaurant where Mr. Garcia will serve what he calls ''Latasian'' food, including his interpretation of sushi. Then, later next month, he plans to open ZONA ROSA, a Mexican restaurant at 40 West 56th Street. It will have a ceviche bar and a taqueria that will open onto the street for takeout. On the second floor there will be communal tables and a tequila bar.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about Judge Fred I. Parker of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Burlington, Vt., misidentified the president who named him to the federal bench in 1990. It was not the current president but his father, George Bush.

title: In a Heat Wave, an Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Seniors Weak In Math and Science Tests
description: Fewer than half of graduating high school seniors who took the 2003 ACT college entrance exams were adequately prepared for college-level algebra, and only about a quarter were prepared for college biology, according to the ACT results released yesterday.

title: Israeli Forces Tighten Hold on Ramallah After Attack
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Aug. 21 - Israeli tanks reinforced positions encircling the West Bank city of Ramallah Wednesday night as Israel ratcheted up pressure on the Palestinian leadership to strike against militant groups, after a suicide bomber killed 20 people aboard a bus here Tuesday.

title: Grocers' Strategy: Be What Wal-Mart Is Not
description: Bill Breetz Jr., a towering longtime grocer who runs the Southwest for the Kroger Company, was on the march. Crossing a vast expanse of peaches, melons and the rest of the produce aisle in a recently remodeled Kroger supermarket here, he checked on a woman cooking stir-fry meals-to-go at a kitchen set up near the back of the store.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''American Splendor,'' based on Harvey Pekar's autobiographical comic-book series, misspelled the surname of an artist whose drawings are shown in the film. He is Gary Dumm, not Dunn.

title: Deutsche Bank Settles Proxy-Votes Case
description: The investment advisory unit of Deutsche Bank agreed yesterday to pay $750,000 to settle accusations from regulators that it failed to disclose a conflict of interest as required when it voted its clients' proxies in favor of Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq Computer in 2002.

title: In a Heat Wave, an Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Blair Communications Chief Denies Altering Intelligence on Iraq
description: Alastair Campbell, Prime Minister Tony Blair's powerful communications and strategy chief, denied today having embellished government intelligence information on Iraqi weapons to help justify an unpopular war to the British public.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Anthrax Drug Gets Fast-Track Designation
description: Human Genome Sciences received a fast-track product designation yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration for ABthrax, a drug for the prevention and treatment of anthrax infections. In June, the company said it began a Phase I placebo-controlled, dose-escalation clinical trial of ABthrax in healthy adult volunteers to evaluate the safety, tolerability and the body's processing of ABthrax. For a new drug to be put on a fast track, the condition it is designed to treat must be serious or life-threatening, and the drug must fill an unmet medical need.

title: DIRECTV AND ECHOSTAR SUE TENNESSEE OVER SALES TAXES
description: DirecTV Inc. and the EchoStar Communications Corporation, the nation's largest satellite-television broadcasters, sued the State of Tennessee, claiming they are being unfairly taxed more than cable-TV companies. Tennessee places an 8.25 percent sales tax on satellite subscribers' bills, DirecTV and EchoStar said. The companies, which filed their lawsuit in state court in Nashville, claim the first $15 of cable customers' bills are exempt from the tax. In June, the companies sued to block Ohio from charging a 6 percent sales tax and requested a $30 million refund from North Carolina for a 5 percent sales tax. Cable operators are exempt from those taxes, they said.

title: No Red Barn, but That's a Farm in Red Hook; Two Acres, No Mule, but an Agricultural Education for Urban Teenagers
description: In the middle of a large, empty playground, just down the street from a strip of engineering businesses and industrial parts manufacturers in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a farm is beginning to take shape on top of the buckling pavement. It is not yet much to look at: just a few raised beds amid the weeds sprouting between the cracks in the ground.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom Shares Soar After Sales Forecast
description: Shares ofthe Broadcom Corporation, the world's largest maker of cable-modem chips, rose about 11 percent after the company increased its third-quarter sales forecast. Shares rose $2.50, to $25.35. The stock has increased 52 percent this year. The company also said yesterday that it expected to meet analysts' revenue and profit forecasts for next year. Broadcom will have sales of $416 million in the quarter ending next month, the chief financial officer, William Ruehle, said. It previously forecast third-quarter revenue of $400 million to $410 million. Sales in the period a year earlier were $290 million. For 2004, the company is forecast to have revenue of $1.84 billion and profit of 64 cents a share, excluding certain expenses and gains, according to the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

title: Another Trip Into Darkness for Many on Staten Island
description: For Jean Daggan, it was beginning to feel like the blackout that would not go away.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Tons Of Plutonium Removed
description: Crews have completed the removal of more than 12 metric tons of weapons-grade plutonium from the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons site as part of a $7 billion cleanup effort that is expected to be finished in 2006, 12 years ahead of schedule. The plant manufactured plutonium triggers for 40 years until it was closed in 1989 for safety violations. The plutonium has been shipped to South Carolina; lower-grade nuclear waste will be sent to New Mexico. The 6,000-acre Rocky Flats site is expected to become a wildlife refuge. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Valet Parking? That's So 2000. In Los Angeles, Strip Mall Food Is Way Cool
description: IN the back of a dingy strip mall in Hollywood, between a discount cigarette store, a coin-op laundry and a 7-11, sits one of Los Angeles's most revered restaurants: Zankou Chicken. Its walls are plywood, its tables are orange Formica, the floors are sticky, and the fluorescent lights are unflattering. The menu consists of a plastic-laminated poster with faded photographs of some suspiciously pink-hued meat on a rotating spit.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: American Jets In Air Show
description: An American F-15 fighter jet coursed over an airfield near Moscow, and no one was particularly troubled by it. Five American military aircraft, including the fighter and a B-52 bomber, a mainstay of the American cold-war arsenal, are to appear this week in the Moscow International Air Show. It is the first time the Air Force has sent its aircraft to the show. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Aug. 6 about Doris Abbate, an aviation pioneer honored at the Centennial of Flight exhibition at Rockefeller Center, misidentified what was later built on the original Roosevelt Field on Long Island, where another pioneer, Charles Lindbergh, began his famous flight. It was Roosevelt Raceway; Roosevelt Field Mall was built on the former Curtiss Field. (A correction last Wednesday misstated the historical significance of Lindbergh's trans-Atlantic flight; his was the first solo flight across the ocean, not the first flight.)

title: When Cellphone Service Fails
description: A maddening side effect of last week's power blackout was the failure of the cellphone system -- widely promoted as a safety net that can be relied upon in emergencies. The streets of New York were filled with frustrated people who could not get through to their loved ones -- or to cab companies, hotels or commuter railroads -- just when they most wanted to. By contrast, the traditional land-line telephone service was often the only utility still functioning in many households.

title: White House Urges Palestinian Leader to Quash Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 — The Bush administration demanded today, in the aftermath of the deadly bombing in Jerusalem, that Prime Minister Mahmoud Abbas and the Palestinian Authority intensify their efforts to stamp out terrorism against Israelis.

title: Market Place; U-Haul's Parent Finds Equity Gains in Bankruptcy
description: Stocks of companies that have filed for bankruptcy protection usually trade for pennies. But shares of Amerco, the company that controls U-Haul and its familiar orange-and-white moving vans, have nearly tripled since it sought Chapter 11 protection in June.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY DAMON FOR $46 MILLION
description: Thor Industries Inc., the maker of Airstream trailers, agreed to buy a motor-home manufacturer, the Damon Corporation, for $46 million. Damon, based in Elkhart, Ind., has about $200 million in annual sales and more than 400 workers, according to its Web site. Thor, based in Jackson Center, Ohio, estimated the purchase would add about 20 cents a share to earnings in its fiscal year, which ends next July. Thor, which expects to complete the purchase on Sept. 2, had $1.35 billion in sales of travel trailers and motor homes in its past fiscal year, trailing Fleetwood Enterprises Inc.'s $1.48 billion.

title: FirstEnergy's Cash Position Declines Sharply
description: The FirstEnergy Corporation, an electric utility holding company that has been buffeted by bad news this summer, reported yesterday that its cash position had fallen sharply during the second quarter. The company also warned that its loss of a pollution case in federal court could cost it a lot of money but did not estimate an amount.

title: Lost When Blackout Struck, Tourist Is Found in Hospital
description: A 66-year-old tourist who had been missing since he became separated from his wife at the Empire State Building during the blackout on Thursday was found last night in a Queens hospital, the police said.

title: Ashcroft Says Efforts to Weaken Terrorism Law Will Place Americans at Greater Risk
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft, in his most forceful defense of the Bush administration's antiterrorism efforts, said today that any attempt to strip law enforcement agents of their expanded legal powers could open the way to further terrorist attacks.

title: How We Got Our News
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Medi-Hut Executives Plead Guilty in Fraud
description: Three former executives of the Medi-Hut Company pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy to inflate revenue and earnings at the drug wholesaler and lying to investigators.

title: A Day to Wet a Toe or Two, but Not Much More
description: The view was nearly perfect: a sun-filled sky spread across Coney Island's surf and dipped into the glistening ocean.

title: Teacher Charged With Murder In a Woman's Stabbing Death
description: A New Jersey high school Latin teacher has been charged with the murder of a woman who the authorities said regularly shared crack cocaine with him in her apartment in the shore town of Ocean Grove.

title: Lottery Numbers
Dana Raymond, 89, Patent Lawyer, Dies
description: Dana Merriam Raymond, a patent lawyer who won or achieved settlements in 21 lawsuits filed by the inventor of FM radio against companies that had denied him credit and compensation, died on Aug. 3 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Columbia Adding Teaching Center
description: Teachers College at Columbia University will use its largest single gift, $10.8 million from the philanthropists Gerard and Lilo Leeds, to create a center to provide additional training and support for high school teachers, the college has announced. The center, to be called the National Academy for Excellent Teaching, will initially serve teachers and principals from low-performing city high schools. Over six years, it will expand to include educators from other school districts and states, according to a statement from Teachers College. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Hopping Freight Trains in the Pacific Northwest in the Twilight of Hobo Tradition
description: The scruffy, outspoken train-hoppers in Sarah George's exhilarating documentary, ''Catching Out,'' are a sure sign that the pioneer spirit still flickers in pockets of TV-wired America, especially in the Pacific Northwest, where much of the movie was filmed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Reuters cameraman who was shot to death by American soldiers in Iraq on Sunday misidentified the headquarters city of the Committee to Protect Journalists, a watchdog group that has called for a public inquiry. It is New York, not London.

title: Preseason Game Means Little to Jets and Giants
description: When New York had two football teams that actually played in New York, a fellow named Weeb Ewbank labeled their first meeting ''for the braggin' rights to New York.''

title: Recipe: Classic Margarita
description: Adapted from Dale DeGroff

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Permanent Use Of Power Line Is Urged
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer called yesterday for the federal government to order that the disputed Cross- Sound Cable, an electric power line that runs under Long Island Sound, be put in permanent use. The cable is intended to give extra power to Long Island residents and has been operating under federal order since last week's blackout. It had previously been prevented from carrying power by Connecticut officials, who say it does not meet construction-permit and environmental regulations. The line is available to the Long Island Power Authority until Sept. 1, but at least one Connecticut official has called for it to be closed sooner. A spokesman for Senator Schumer said Long Island came ''perilously close to the edge'' of its power needs without the line. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schrder Wants Justice For Hostages
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder said Germany would try to seize and punish the Islamic militants who captured 32 European tourists and held them for ransom in the North African desert. To bring them to justice was part of the wider fight against terrorism, he said. ''German security forces will support their Algerian and Malian partners in doing everything that is appropriate to catch the perpetrators and bring them to justice,'' Mr. Schrder said. ''It is now important to understand that this was the work of terrorists, and it is the duty of the international community of democratic states to fight terrorism.'' He spoke in Berlin following the release into Malian hands of the last 14 hostages who were held. They arrived last night in Bamako, the Mali capital, where German miltary planes were ready to take them home. Richard Bernstein (NYT)

title: Sentencing Is Scheduled Today In 1991 Crown Heights Slaying
description: Twelve years to the day after an Orthodox Jew died of knife wounds inflicted during racial unrest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the black man convicted of stabbing him, Lemrick Nelson, is to be sentenced in federal court in Brooklyn today.

title: 'Altruism' and an Organ Donor
description: To the Editor:

title: Valedictorian Settles Dispute With Schools For $60,000
description: The Moorestown School Board announced today that it had agreed to pay $60,000 to settle a lawsuit by Blair L. Hornstine, the high school senior who sued the district to be named sole valedictorian.

title: EchoStar Interested In Assets, Loral Says
description: Loral Space and Communications, the satellite maker, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, said yesterday that it had received an informal offer for its satellite assets from EchoStar Communications.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: COLUMBIA ADDING TEACHING CENTER Teachers College at Columbia University will use its largest single gift, $10.8 million from the philanthropists Gerard and Lilo Leeds, to create a center to provide additional training and support for high school teachers, the college has announced. The center, to be called the National Academy for Excellent Teaching, will initially serve teachers and principals from low-performing city high schools. Over six years, it will expand to include educators from other school districts and states, according to a statement from Teachers College.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NORTH KOREA: GAMES BOYCOTT DROPPED North Korea dropped its boycott of the World Student Games in South Korea after South Korea's president, Roh Moo Hyun, apologized for protesters who burned a North Korean flag at a demonstration in Seoul last week. Accepting Mr. Roh's apology, the North said it would send 500 athletes, trainers, journalists and cheerleaders to the games this week in Taegu. James Brooke (NYT)

title: The Power Failure: Put Politics Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hard Times, Tobacco Growers Consider the Unthinkable: Giving Up Price Supports
description: With foreign competition increasing and their income falling steadily, tobacco farmers along with the senators from tobacco country say they are prepared to do something that would have been unthinkable only a few years ago: give up the government crop limits and price supports they have enjoyed since the Depression.

title: In a Heat Wave, an Opportunity (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Ties Lingering, Medco Leaves Merck
description: Ending a 10-year corporate marriage after more than a year of stops and starts, Medco Health Solutions, the nation's largest manager of drug benefits, became independent yesterday in a spinoff to shareholders of Merck & Company.

title: One-Tenant Buildings Are Popular Investments
description: Earlier this month, Commercial Net Lease Realty, a publicly traded real estate investment trust based in Orlando, Fla., acquired WorldCom's headquarters in Arlington, Va., in a bankruptcy auction. The purchase price was more than $142 million, and the buyer agreed to spend another $28.9 million on improvements. The total expenditures will be about $68 million more than WorldCom, now known as MCI, had tentatively accepted from Tishman Speyer Properties only a year earlier.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Democratic Governors Torn by Recall
description: The political talk of the National Governors Association's four-day summer meeting, which ended today, concerned the events unfolding in California.

title: In Ruined Capital, Liberians Fear for Shaky Peace
description: When people here say that democracy is in ruins, that is no metaphor.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Reuters cameraman who was shot to death by American soldiers in Iraq on Sunday misidentified the headquarters city of the Committee to Protect Journalists, a watchdog group that has called for a public inquiry. It is New York, not London.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Smallpox Program Ends After Slow Start
description: The state has stopped vaccinating emergency and health care workers for smallpox after meeting worker resistance, Commissioner Clifton R. Lacy of the State Department of Health and Senior Services said yesterday. Since January, 671 doctors, law enforcement members and public health officials have agreed to the voluntary vaccinations, far fewer than the 1,000 who signed up. The program is designed to immunize medical and law enforcement personnel in the event of a terrorist smallpox attack. Some declined because of reported side effects, which in rare cases can include heart attacks and death. Others declined over uncertainty whether workers' compensation would pay for any ill effects. In New Jersey, nine people suffered ''minor adverse events,'' Dr. Lacy said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Rises
description: German investor confidence jumped to the highest level in more than a year, according to a survey released by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research. The institute's index that measures expectations for economic growth rose to 52.5 in August from 41.9 in July, gaining for an eighth month. The center said that the rise in optimism is likely a result of an accelerating economy in the United States, rising manufacturing orders, and solid financial results posted by some big German companies. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Tasting the Himalayas In a Bite of Yak Cheese
description: Unless you read the label, nothing about this lovely new semisoft cheese suggests that it comes from Tibet. Or that it is made from yak milk. The cheese resembles Gruyre, though a little less nutty and a bit muskier. Nomadic groups milk their yaks, which feed only on the natural grasses of the high plateau, and take the milk to cheesemaking factories, where it is made into 13-pound wheels, cured with red salt, aged six to nine months and sent to the United States. The project is sponsored by the Trace Foundation, a New York nonprofit organization that works to strengthen the culture and economy of rural Tibetan communities. All profits go to health and education programs. Yak cheese can be nibbled plain, layered in a sandwich or baked in a casserole or in a quiche. It is about $13 a pound at Whole Foods supermarkets, Ideal Cheese, Citarella and the Garden of Eden, at 162 West 23rd Street.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: British Bank Expansion
description: The British bank HBOS completed a 2.4 billion Australian dollar ($1.6 billion) takeover of the Bank of Western Australia, known as BankWest, despite claims by minority shareholders that the price was low. HBOS, which was formed in 2001 by a merger of Halifax Building Society and Bank of Scotland, required 50 percent of shareholder votes and achieved 80 percent. BankWest, founded in 1895 to provide farm loans, will be delisted but its headquarters will remain in Perth, Western Australia, under legislation accepted by HBOS, which is based in Edinburgh, was formed in 2001 by a merger of the Halifax Building Society and the Bank of Scotland. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the effect of DVD sales on the types of films produced in Hollywood misspelled the surname of the vice chairman of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., who commented on the increasing influence of the home video market. He is Chris McGurk, not McGuirk.

title: Dibos Captures Women's Met Open
description: Alicia Dibos, who formerly played on the L.P.G.A. Tour, parred the final two holes and finished with a second straight 72 for a 144 to win the Women's Met Open at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday.

title: Sergio Vieira de Mello, 55, of the U.N.: A Shining Reputation Built on Tough Tasks
description: Sergio Vieira de Mello, the top United Nations official in Iraq and the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, who had served the organization in trouble spots around the globe, died yesterday from injuries received in the bombing of the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad. He was 55.

title: Nevin's Homer Halts Mets' Streak
description: The Mets carried a six-game winning streak into Qualcomm Stadium tonight, a run of success that meant they would not be battling the San Diego Padres for the worst record in the National League.

title: Campaign Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Happening, No Matter What
description: CALL me slow, but I have just figured out that the United States Open is coming in five days -- without its charismatic, powerful, homegrown, put-the-bodies-in-the-seats defending champion.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Aug. 6 about Doris Abbate, an aviation pioneer honored at the Centennial of Flight exhibition at Rockefeller Center, misidentified what was later built on the original Roosevelt Field on Long Island, where another pioneer, Charles Lindbergh, began his famous flight. It was Roosevelt Raceway; Roosevelt Field Mall was built on the former Curtiss Field. (A correction last Wednesday misstated the historical significance of Lindbergh's trans-Atlantic flight; his was the first solo flight across the ocean, not the first flight.)

title: A Little Houseful of Performances
description: For many New Yorkers, the community gardens featuring the wooden shanties known as casitas, or little houses, have been centers of neighborhood life, good for relaxing, partying, performing and, every now and then, roasting a pig. Now, it seems, they are also good for a festival.

title: For Grandmas Whose Baking Is an Art Form
description: What was your grandmother's favorite dessert recipe? Here's a chance to make Grandma almost famous, by having her dessert served in the cafe of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford this fall and winter. What you have to do is enter the recipe in a contest that is being held in conjunction with the museum's exhibition of paintings by Grandma Moses, on view from Oct. 3 through Feb. 15. (Right, the artist's ''Old Times.'') The recipe does not have to be original, but an explanation of its source should be included.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Dutchess County, N.Y.; New Hotels on Hudson Valley Landscape
description: Developers are forging ahead with plans to build at least six new hotels in Dutchess County in an effort that local officials and real estate executives say is unusually active and that could cause significant changes to the county's lodging landscape.

title: Confused on Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: At Baylor, Problems Go Beyond Basketball
description: Only a few months after Coach Guy Morriss was lured to Baylor to revive its football program, the athletic director who hired him has resigned and the university is shrouded in bad publicity.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Chaos as a Strategy Against the U.S.
description: The bombing of the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad today provided grisly evidence of a new strategy by anti-American forces to depict the United States as unable to guarantee public order, as well as to frighten away relief organizations rebuilding Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Games Boycott Dropped
description: North Korea dropped its boycott of the World Student Games in South Korea after South Korea's president, Roh Moo Hyun, apologized for protesters who burned a North Korean flag at a demonstration in Seoul last week. Accepting Mr. Roh's apology, the North said it would go ahead with plans to send 500 athletes, trainers, journalists and cheerleaders to the games this week in Taegu. James Brooke (NYT)

title: National Briefing: New England
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE: FAKE OBITUARY IS PUBLISHED The police are trying to determine who submitted a fake obituary for the wife of a local teacher to a weekly newspaper in Milford. The obituary was published in the Cabinet Press, although the woman, Kathleen Connor-Allwarden, was alive. "It never occurred to us that someone would be sick enough to do this," said the newspaper's editor, Michael Cleveland. Police Chief Fred Douglas said his investigators had sent the material submitted to the newspaper to the state police forensics laboratory for examination. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker Penalty Sought
description: Financial regulators have recommended that the Mizuho Investors Securities Company be penalized for misleading clients about its products. The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission has asked the Financial Services Agency to take action against the brokerage after an investigation found that Mizuho marketed products without telling customers how its exchange traded funds worked. Mizuho Investors is a division of Japan's largest bank by assets, the Mizuho Financial Group. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on July 27 about Harold C. Schonberg, former chief music critic of The New York Times, misspelled the surname of a pianist he championed. The pianist was Raymond Lewenthal, not Lowenthal.

title: SAMSON PAYS OVER $140 MILLION FOR CONTOUR ENERGY
description: The Contour Energy Company, an oil and natural-gas exploration company that also develops wells, was bought by Samson Investment Company for about $146 million, including the assumption of debt. Contour has operations in Louisiana and in the Gulf of Mexico. Samson is based in Tulsa, Okla. Samson, which explores for and produces oil and gas in the Australia, Canada, Russia, the United States and Venezuela, is seeking to expand through acquisitions in Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas. The acquisition includes five fields and six platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, Samson said in the statement.

title: Injury to Vick Changes Outlook for the Falcons
description: Michael Vick shook his head in dismay today as he recalled his conversation with Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis before Saturday's National Football League preseason game at the Georgia Dome.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Governor of California About the Recall Election
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Gov. Gray Davis of California about the recall effort, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Phoenix Tempers Fray In the Quest for Gasoline
description: Tempers are beginning to fray in Phoenix, where a severe gasoline shortage now in its third day has forced thousands of motorists into round-the-block lines at filling stations.

title: 9 Afghan Police Officers Are Killed in Attack by Insurgents
description: In the fourth reported attack on Afghan government employees or aid workers in two days, suspected Taliban fighters killed nine police officers in eastern Afghanistan on Monday, government officials announced today.

title: Hewlett Profit For Quarter Falls Below Expectations
description: Hewlett-Packard's road to recovery took a detour yesterday as the giant computer company reported that its profit for the quarter ended July 31 fell short of analysts' predictions.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans assigned to the Iraq theater of operations:

title: Florida Seeks Agencies For Safe Driving Ads
description: The Florida attorney general, Charles Crist, will soon begin a review for an agency to create a national safe driving campaign aimed at owners of sport utility vehicles. Spending on the campaign, a one-time assignment, will be $30 million.

title: Venture to Drill for Gas and Build Pipeline Off China
description: Two big Chinese energy companies and two multinationals agreed today to set up what could become China's largest offshore natural gas project, linking several fields in the East China Sea by pipeline to Shanghai.

title: Iraqi Ex-Vice President Caught, One of Hussein's Trusted Aides
description: One of Saddam Hussein's most loyal and ruthless aides, Taha Yassin Ramadan, has been turned over to allied forces in northern Iraq, American military officials said today.

title: MCDONALD'S TO PAY SIMON $16.6 MILLION SETTLEMENT
description: The McDonald's Corporation agreed to pay Simon Worldwide Inc. $16.6 million to settle a lawsuit over promotional games. McDonald's will pay Simon $6.9 million and also assign it the rights to insurance proceeds, which are expected to be about $9.7 million, Simon said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The two companies ended their relationship in 2001 after the arrest of a former Simon employee, who pleaded guilty to taking winning game pieces. Simon and McDonald's sued each other in October 2001 for breach of contract. In September 2001, a federal judge threw out McDonald's claims that Simon broke a contract with McDonald's.

title: Young Player Battled Some Old Notions on Way to N.H.L.
description: When the threat of a failing grade came from a high school gym teacher, Gerald Coleman did not believe it. So, as he had been taught when the taunts and threats came, he ignored it.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fort Monmouth: Gas Line Breach
description: A contractor ruptured a gas line with a backhoe yesterday, forcing the evacuation of scores of patients and employees at a hospital and two other buildings as a precaution, a spokeswoman for the gas company said. No one was injured, and the line was repaired by 4:30 p.m., about an hour after the incident, said Roseanne Koberle, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Natural Gas. The contractor had been installing electrical conduit outside the Patterson Army Health Clinic, which is at Fort Monmouth, the Army base, she said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Saving an Opera House For a Hamlet in Maine
description: If you ask Linda L. Nelson why she and three other women from New York bought and restored a dilapidated 91-year-old opera house in a remote fishing village on Penobscot Bay, the word democracy comes up.

title: COMPETITOR TO VIAGRA RECEIVES F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: GlaxoSmithKline and Bayer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration for their Levitra impotence treatment, an F.D.A. spokeswoman, Laura Bradbard, said yesterday. Bayer and Glaxo have estimated that annual sales of Levitra, which will be the first United States competitor for Pfizer Inc.'s $1.7 billion-a-year Viagra drug, will reach $1.1 billion. About 30 million men in the United States experience impotence, the National Institutes of Health said. It is more common as men age, and occurs more often in those with diabetes and hardening of the arteries. Bayer of Germany, which introduced aspirin in 1899, developed Levitra and then teamed up with Glaxo.

title: Neither Hot Nor Cold, but Perfect
description: AS viewers of ''The Restaurant,'' the painfully contrived reality television show, learned in a recent episode, serving cold food does not go over well with diners.

title: Congress Prepares for a Beyond-the-Beltway Fight
description: As they move to strike an agreement on energy issues in the coming weeks, members of Congress will be reminded anew that such fights often break more along state lines than party lines.

title: Top Pick Signs After Investigation
description: Lastings Milledge is officially a Met, 11 weeks after the team made him its first-round pick in the amateur draft.

title: ADVENT PAYS $40 MILLION FOR MAJORITY STAKE IN TERAPIA
description: The Advent International Corporation, a buyout firm based in Boston, has paid $40 million for a majority stake in Terapia S.A., Romania's No. 4 drug maker. Advent, which bought Viatris GmbH last year, paid more than 1.3 trillion lei ($40 million) to acquire a 91-percent stake in Terapia, said Dragos Neacsu, chief executive of Raiffeisen Capital and Investment Romania, which managed the purchase. Advent's public offer to buy Terapia shares expired last Friday.

title: In Widow's Civil Suit in 1958 Killing of Police Officer, the Accused Defends Himself
description: Almost 45 years after Police Officer Charles Bernoskie was shot and killed while interrupting a burglary at a car dealership, his accused killer took the stand today to defend himself in a wrongful death trial brought by the officer's widow, Elizabeth Bernoskie.

title: Helicopter Carrying Russian Governor and Aides Disappears
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20  A helicopter carrying the governor and other senior officials from the Pacific region of Sakhalin disappeared today while flying toward the Kurile Islands.

title: F.B.I. Accused Of Corrupting Surveillance
description: A defense lawyer in a New York terrorism prosecution has accused the government of mishandling the computerized surveillance records of thousands of phone calls, faxes and computer data collected in the case, a secret filing shows.

title: U.S. Seeks More Data on Trucking Merger
description: The Yellow Corporation, the trucking company, faces more federal scrutiny of its plan to buy its larger rival, the Roadway Corporation, because regulators have questions about the effect on competition, lawyers and industry officials said.

title: The Power Failure: Put Politics Aside (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Julius Ochs Adler Jr., 78, Businessman, Publicist and Bookseller
description: Julius Ochs Adler Jr., a business executive and public relations consultant who ran a popular independent bookstore in Manhattan for 16 years, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Court Stops Execution
description: A state appeals court halted the scheduled execution today of Mark Robertson, who was convicted of murder in 1991. Mr. Robertson argued that the unusual jury instructions in force in Texas at the time did not allow the jury determining his sentence to take account of the abuse he said he had suffered as a child. The federal court of appeals in New Orleans rejected that argument in March. The state court, the Court of Criminal Appeals, will hear arguments on it in the fall. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: You've Seen the Web Site. Now See the TV Show.
description: Television is an efficient biosphere where the perfect predator evolves for every species in the food chain. If reality shows are the coral reef of prime time, then the television-oriented Web site, the Smoking Gun, is its crown-of-thorns starfish.

title: Dave & Buster's Selects Fallon's New York Unit
description: Dave & Buster's, a restaurant chain, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe , as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by divisions of One Square in Dallas. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT FALLS. Wheat prices plunged as rainfall in parts of the Midwest increased prospects for the crop. In Chicago, wheat for December delivery fell 13.5 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $3.8125 a bushel.

title: 2 New Fronts in Heartburn Market Battle
description: Cracks appeared yesterday in a pillar of drug industry profits with twin announcements that users of a huge-selling heartburn drug will soon have alternatives that will be cheaper and easier to buy. As a result, the biggest fight ever seen between managed-care companies and drug makers could soon begin.

title: Corrections
description: The New Economy column in Business Day on Monday about 64-bit processors for desktop computers misstated the theoretical maximum amount of memory that a 64-bit processor can handle. It is 18 quintillion bytes of RAM (that is, 18 billion billion), not 16 quintillion.

title: Long on Time, Not Details
description: This 60-second commercial, titled ''Initial,'' will be shown starting today by Californians for Schwarzenegger, whose main contributor is Arnold Schwarzenegger himself, at $1 million, state election records show.

title: Profits Up at Home Depot, but Saks Loss Widens
description: Home Depot Inc., the home improvement chain, posted a 9.9 percent increase in second-quarter profit yesterday, but its shares fell because sales at older stores rebounded less than some investors expected. Saks Inc. reported a wider second-quarter loss.

title: A Summer Wardrobe for Risotto
description: CORN, sweet peas, fresh herbs -- in a city obsessed with seasonality, these are the summer guests that everyone expects and welcomes. Less expected, however, are the summer risottos, adjusted for August temperatures, that many chefs are using as a showcase for the spoils of the season.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Executive Selected
description: Jung Man Won, in charge of energy sales for SK Global, the troubled trading firm in the SK Group, the country's third-largest conglomerate, was selected to take over as the company's chief executive officer. Creditors chose him to succeed Son Kil Seung, who resigned Sunday from the top post at SK Global but remains as chairman of the SK Group. SK Global, burdened with more than $9 billion in debts and liabilities, reported a loss of $3.2 billion for the second quarter. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: CTI MOLECULAR ACQUIRES MIRADA FOR $22 MILLION
description: CTI Molecular Imaging Inc., a maker of imaging equipment that helps doctors detect cancer and other diseases, said it had acquired Mirada Solutions Ltd. for $22 million in cash and notes. Mirada develops software and tools that improve detection and diagnosis at medical imaging workstations. Mirada's investors include Oxford University and Comvest Ltd. The company is based in Oxford, England. CTI Molecular said it would take a charge of about $1.3 million related to research and development expenses at Mirada. CTI is based in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: No Time To Lose In Iraq
description: I was stopped the other day at the U.S. Army checkpoint on the July 14 Bridge in the heart of Baghdad and told by the sergeant on duty that I didn't have the proper ID to enter the U.S. compound, which clogs the heart of the capital. So I called the U.S. Army officer I had an appointment with, and he offered to drive out to escort me in. To make certain he found me, I asked the sergeant who was running the checkpoint to take the phone and tell the officer exactly where we were standing. ''Sir,'' the sergeant said, ''we're on the enemy side of the July 14 bridge. . . .''

title: Gehry's Music Palace (Aug. 2003)
Garden Storage
description: For gardeners, storage is summer's last chore.

title: Beyond Western Clichs
description: Documenting how average Arabs live.

title: Indoor Water at Last
description: For some of Virginia's most deprived, indoor running water at last.

title: Public Displays of Contention
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: No Osbourne at Ozzfest, But the Bands Play On
description: It was 10:45 in the morning at the PNC Bank Arts Center here, and Anthony Martini, the lead singer of E. Town Concrete, was calling the dazed crowd ''weak'' and ''a disgrace.'' He urged people to ''get focused,'' and then he barked out another song as audience members began their daylong journey from sleepy to drunk and back again.

title: Broadway Sets Three Closings
description: Three Broadway plays are to close on Aug. 31. For ''Enchanted April'' and ''Man of La Mancha'' the evening performance will be their last. ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' is to end its run after the matinee.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: COURT UPHOLDS DRUG CONVICTION The Connecticut Supreme Court yesterday upheld a drug-dealing conviction against a man who argued that eight bags of heroin he regurgitated after emergency medical treatment should never have been admitted into evidence. The high court ruled unanimously in rejecting the appeal of Vincent Betances, who received a 17-year sentence. Mr. Betances contended that police officers illegally seized the evidence from an ambulance after asking him if he swallowed heroin, but before informing him of his Miranda rights, including the right to remain silent. (AP)

title: Yankees Could Send Weaver to the Minors
description: The Yankees know this much about their pitching: Jos Contreras will start against the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday in his first game off the disabled list. Jeff Weaver might be in the bullpen then, or he might be sent to Class AAA Columbus. When Manager Joe Torre met with Weaver on Tuesday, he mentioned going to the minors as an option.

title: It's Not Exactly a Theater, But PC Viewing Has Its Perks
description: Watching movies on a computer can be a relaxing way to spend time between classes or on a plane, even though the audio and video experience is not exactly movie-theater quality. WinDVD Platinum 5 by InterVideo is a software program designed to enhance the PC theater experience, and it offers some features that the local multiplex lacks. When you pop a DVD movie into the computer, for example, the program's Movie Encyclopedia displays information about the director, the actors and the production that can be browsed at the viewer's pleasure.

title: Venezuelan Opposition Files to Seek Referendum on Chvez
description: Venezuelan opposition groups today presented elections officials with 3.2 million signatures calling for the removal of President Hugo Chvez, the first step in a new effort to oust the leftist leader through a constitutional recall referendum.

title: In Jerusalem, Derailed Hopes for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressman's Driving History Clouds Future
description: It was never much of a secret around South Dakota that Representative Bill Janklow liked to drive fast. He admitted as much in his 1999 State of the State address when he was governor, making a point about mandatory jail time as a strong deterrent for drug offenders.

title: Brrring! A Musical Reverie Yields to Cellphone Chatter
description: Cellphones have long been able to handle your list of contacts, and more recently they have added e-mail, games and even pictures to the mix. Now a Nokia cellphone wants to be your primary portable music player, too.

title: For Times When Your Subject Is Playing Hard to Get
description: The Dimage A1, a zoom-lens digital reflex camera that is to be released next month by Minolta, has the fastest shutter speed in its price range, 1/16,000 of a second, enabling photographers to freeze ultrafast action and to open up the lens to throw backgrounds out of focus no matter how bright the light.

title: A South Carolina Frame And Your Fabric
description: Don't judge a chaise longue by its upholstery. Chad Chaison, for example, wasn't dissuaded by a fake fur the color of Tang on a curvaceous 1950's chaise longue he spotted in an Atlanta flea market. ''It was the shape that got me,'' said Mr. Chaison, an owner of Vieux Carr, a vintage-furnishings boutique in Greenwich Village. Smitten by its generous scale (5 feet long by 36 inches wide), he and his business partner, Michelle Gautier, tracked down the South Carolina factory that made the frame and then upgraded the upholstery with Mies-mod button tufting. Priced at $1,800, if you yourself supply the required six to eight yards of fabric, the Chaison Chaise can be made in two weeks. Vieux Carr, 546 Hudson Street (Perry Street); (212) 647-7633.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAFFER, JACK A.
description: SHAFFER--Jack A. On August 18, 2003. Loving husband of Kelly Shaffer; cherished father of Andrea Collins, Stephi Wolff and Dana Hayden; fond brother of Nicole Rothschild; adored grandfather of Drew, Matt, Jack, Charlie, Aaron, Emily, Griffin, Levi, Isaac and Luke. Friends may call Thursday evening 69PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Services Friday, August 22nd 11:30AM at Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Avenue at 65 St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Jack A. Shaffer Scholarship Fund at St. Thomas Aquinas School, 1909 Daly Ave., Bronx, NY 10460.

title: Roxie C. Laybourne, 92, Used Bird Knowledge to Save Lives
description: Roxie C. Laybourne, whose scientific investigations into bird collisions with airplanes helped start forensic ornithology and enabled engineers to develop aircraft capable of withstanding such accidents, died on Aug. 7 at her farm in Manassas, Va. She was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAYMOND, EDWARD A., DR.
description: RAYMOND--Edward A., Dr. 88, died at his home in Scarsdale NY on August 18, 2003. He had been under home hospice care for several months after treatment for cancer. The son of Edward Raymond of Bedford, NY and Louise Hammond Raymond of Greens Farms, CT, he was raised in Scarsdale NY. He attended the Choate School, class of 1933, and then Yale College, class of 1937. He received his MD from Cornell Medical School in 1941. He was a captain in the US Army 1941-1946 performing medical operations, and he completed his residency at Memorial Hospital (now Sloan-Kettering) in New York in 1947. He carried on his practice of general surgery in Scarsdale, Hartsdale and White Plains, and had a 30-year association with White Plains Hospital. He performed surgery of all kinds, especially in emergency and accident cases. He was an early proponent of bone-grafting techniques and restored many seriously injured patients in the entire Westchester area. From 1956 to 1986 he was the School Physician for Scarsdale Public Schools. He attended most of the school football games, treating injuries himself or immediately referring the patients to other specialists. He was a regular member of the Scarsdale Volunteer Fire Dept and was frequently on hand at fires to assess and treat injuries. An avid tennis and platform tennis player, he was a long-time member of the Fox Meadow Tennis Club in Scarsdale, where he continued to play this year through the age of 87. He was an enthusiastic bridge player along with his wife Louise. The family had membership at the American Yacht Club in Rye, NY. In 1941 he married Louise Tanner of Portland, Oregon, who also attended Cornell Medical School and taught piano. She predeceased him, in 1991. Dr. Raymond is survived by his five children: Carol of Santa Fe, NM, Douglas of Blue Bell, PA, James of Las Vegas, NV, Edward of Blue Bell, PA, and Nancy of Eugene, OR. There are 11 grandchildren. Burial will be private and there is no funeral service. Donations are suggested in behalf of Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, New York 10601.

title: 3 Women, 3 Paths, 10 Years On
description: AFTER Ellen Spertus earned undergraduate and advanced degrees at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the 1990's, she could have set her sights on joining the faculty at a large, prestigious academic institution. Or, like many other young technologists, she could have found a lucrative job in the Internet-driven economic boom.

title: Internet Advertising Gains in Revenue
description: Internet advertising revenue in the United States is estimated to have increased in the first quarter, according to the Interactive Advertising Bureau in New York, the first time in two years that revenue had grown in consecutive quarters.

title: Bloomberg Shows Up, And Surprise! Loosens Up
description: There he is in Brooklyn, bearing a bouquet of red carnations and two boxes of chocolate-dipped cookies, making the rounds at the Bay Ridge Center for Older Adults. In Queens, strolling the streets of Flushing with reporters in tow. In the Bronx, chatting with almost everyone in the joint while having a seafood lunch yesterday on City Island.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Los Alamos Employee Wins Settlement
description: An employee of the Los Alamos National Laboratory who was fired last year after documenting theft and security breaches received a $930,000 settlement from the University of California, his lawyers said. The employee, Glen Walp, accused the university, which runs Los Alamos, of firing him and another colleague for raising security concerns in a report leaked to the news media. Eighteen top laboratory officials were later fired, demoted or transferred. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Fines In West Warwick Club Deaths
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has levied thousands of dollars in fines against the owners of a West Warwick nightclub where 100 people died in a Feb. 20 fire and the band whose pyrotechnics ignited it. Derco LLC, which operated the Station nightclub, faces $85,200 in fines. Violations include installing an exit door that did not open in the proper direction, having walls covered with flammable foam and not having a written fire prevention plan. Jack Russell Touring Inc., which operates the band, Great White, was fined $7,000 for failing to protect employees from pyrotechnics.

title: Critic's Notebook; Listening Carefully to Bard College's New Performing Arts Center
description: When the new Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College opened in April, architecture critics were almost all enchanted by Frank Gehry's undulating design. The music critics were friendly, too. Some expressed reservations about the sheer volume of the opening gala's centerpiece, Mahler's Third Symphony, in the 900-seat Sosnoff Theater, the largest hall in the complex. But basically, they said, the place sounded good.

title: Women Win Gold In First for the U.S.
description: The odds were against the United States women's team in the world gymnastics championships. Since Friday, injuries and illness had sidelined three of its six regulars, all of its previous world medalists, and its hopes for a medal seemed lost.

title: Lost in the Middle of Nowhere? Send a Radio Distress Signal
description: If the Skipper had only had a personal locater beacon, the world might not have had three years of ''Gilligan's Island.''

title: Dim Lights, Bright Ideas
description: AMONG the millions put out by the power loss last week, a select group at the New York Marriott Marquis in Times Square had good reason to take the disruptions and inconveniences personally.

title: 'Wall Street Week' Sponsors Signed
description: Maryland Public Television in Owings Mills said yesterday that it had signed two sponsors to underwrite the fall season of ''Wall Street Week With Fortune,'' which is being produced with Fortune magazine in New York, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner.

title: Tokyo Journal; At Long Last, the Salarymen Are Given Their Due
description: Every Tuesday evening, millions of Japanese are moved, often to tears, by the series ''Project X: Challengers,'' which documents successful projects undertaken by Every Salaryman.

title: Another celebrity takes on KFC over the treatment of animals.
description: RUSSELL SIMMONS, the hip-hop impresario turned social activist, is the latest celebrity foot soldier in the publicity war that People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals is waging against KFC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSPAN, PAUL M.
description: GREENSPAN--Paul M. Big brother, business partner, protector, role model. Mere words can never express my love and gratitude. Bud

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Inside Outsider, Still Fighting for Disenfranchised
description: HE was beaten by racists in Louisiana in 1965. He protested at segregated businesses in Ohio. Served as a leader of the Congress of Racial Equality, one of the leading civil rights groups in the 1960's. Worked in the trenches of antipoverty programs in the early 1970's.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Objection To Loan Deal
description: Middle Eastern banks that have extended loans to SK Global have objected to an agreement intended to allow the troubled trading company to repay loans at only 43 percent of their original value. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: When a Neighbor's 2 Cents Yield Quite a Bit More
description: CONGREGATION SHEARITH ISRAEL and Kobe Bryant are not typically mentioned in the same breathless breath. Yet there they were last week, sharing top billing on ''Celebrity Justice.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JIRANEK, DAVID
description: JIRANEK--David. It is with much sadness that we announce the death of David Jiranek, 45, who passed away Sunday, August 17. He was a Broadway producer, a writer, a photographer, a philanthropist and a family man. His passing will be deeply felt in the New York theater and in Old Greenwich, CT, where he and his family made their home. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Cricket Hooper Jiranek and their two daughters, Cat and Sailor, and an extended family that includes his mother Jen Jiranek and four half brothers: Theodore ''Teke'' Hoffman, R. Todd Hoffman, Robert H. Jiranek and James H. Jiranek.

title: Weapons Expert Talked of Being 'Found Dead,' Witness Says
description: LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The judge investigating the death of the weapons expert David Kelly was told today that months before his body turned up on a hiking path in the English countryside, he talked of being "found dead in the woods."

title: Publicis Adds to Stake In ZenithOptimedia
description: The Publicis Groupe in Paris said yesterday that it had acquired the 25 percent of the ZenithOptimedia Group, the media services agency in London, that it did not already own for 75 million ($119.5 million).

title: Israeli Military Raises Pressure After Bombing
description: Israeli forces reinforced positions around Ramallah and raided three other West Bank cities overnight Wednesday. The moves came as Israel ratcheted up pressure on the Palestinian leadership to strike against militant groups, after a suicide bomber killed 20 people aboard a bus here Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: NEW YORK STARTS OWN BLACKOUT INQUIRY The state will conduct its own investigation into last week's blackout, which left nearly 90 percent of the state without power. The investigation will be headed by the Public Service Commission and will focus on why various areas of the state were affected differently. All 3.1 million customers of Consolidated Edison , which supplies electricity to the five boroughs, lost power. But about 50,000 of the Long Island Power Authority's customers kept power. Gov. George E. Pataki, who asked the commission for the study, said investigators would also look into "why we were not protected as we were told we would be after '65 and after '77," the two previous blackouts. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Ward Bennett Made It Modern
description: THE designer Ward Bennett, who died Aug. 13 at 85, was famed for everything from hats to houses. But he remains an enigma. There are no monographs of his oeuvre, and though acclaimed as an American icon, he never became a household word.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARP, ROBERT
description: CARP--Robert. The American Heart Association, NYC Board of Directors, volunteers and staff mourn the loss of our NYC Board Member and philanthropist, Robert Carp, a dear friend, volunteer and generous benefactor of our mission to save lives from heart disease and stroke. In his commitment to our work, Bob strongly believed in the long term value of the investment in medical research. His vision lives on with the designation of the Endowed American Heart Association/Louis and Florence Carp Memorial Foundation Research Fellow. His steadfast dedication and enthusiasm for our work was an inspiration to others. Bob was a true New Yorker who was committed to helping organizations that made the city a better place. We were privileged to have benefited from his wise counsel and will miss his wit and zest for life. We extend our deepest condolences to his nieces and nephews and their families. Jane Chesnutt, Chair Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D., President Michael L. Weamer, Executive Vice President

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Volkswagen Wage Cuts
description: Senior management and other nonunion workers at the Mexican plant of Volkswagen will take an 8 percent wage cut after the union agreed to a shorter workweek to maintain profit as world demand for its cars drops. The company's 9,800 unionized workers have already accepted a reduced four-day workweek to prevent 2,000 job losses as the plant's production of new Beetles and Jettas has fallen 11.2 percent so far this year on fewer exports to the United States, its main market. Last week the union also agreed to a 5.25 percent increase in the daily wage, slightly higher than the 4.13 percent rate of inflation in the year that ended last month. The company said the reduction in salary for 3,800 nonunion employees, including the board and top management, was decided because ''if the union workers see lower wages then this should also extend to nonunion employees.'' John Moody (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, SYLVIA
description: FRIEDMAN -- Sylvia. The Board and Staff of The New York Association for New Americans (NYANA) are deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Sylvia N. Friedman, who served as President of the Board in the 1980's and was a valued Board member of NYANA for more than 25 years. Dr. Friedman was predeceased by her husband, Harold Friedman, and son, Judge Lewis Friedman, who also served on the NYANA Board of Directors. Sylvia's indomitable and tenacious dedication to NYANA's mission of providing resettlement and social services to refugees and immigrants was unsurpassed. During her tenure with NYANA, Sylvia was committed to giving new life to thousands of refugees fleeing oppression from the Soviet Union, Iran, Syria and South East Asia. She served many causes with distinction and dedication, giving her leadership to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), the UJA-Federation of New York, the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, the Council of Jewish Federations, the American ORT Federation, the Jewish Braille Institute of America and the Lexington School for the Deaf. We extend our sincere condolences to Sylvia's daughter, Dr. Diane Friedman, grand-daughter, Karen Friedman, daughter-in-law, Bernice Friedman and the entire Friedman family. Mark Handelman President and CEO Michael Loeb Chairman of the Board

title: F.C.C. Lifts Ban on Video For AOL Instant Messaging
description: The Federal Communications Commission has granted a request by AOL Time Warner to drop restrictions on adding video to its AOL instant messaging service until it allowed users to communicate with other services.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Former Iraqi Official Known as 'Chemical Ali' Is Captured
description: Ali Hassan al-Majid, a cousin and trusted adviser of Saddam Hussein who earned a reputation for ruthlessness by using poison gas to supress a Kurdish uprising in 1988, has been captured, the American military said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after an Energy Department report showed that nationwide inventories declined last week as refineries increased production. Crude oil for September delivery rose 25 cents, to $30.95.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Postal Inspector General Resigns
description: The inspector general of the Postal Service, Karla W. Corcoran, has resigned after her spending and management style came under question. She will be replaced by David Williams, who has been inspector general of the Internal Revenue Service, the Treasury Department and the Social Security Administration. In May, Senators Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota and Ron Wyden of Oregon, both Democrats, called for Ms. Corcoran's resignation after learning she had spent $1 million on three staff retreats.

title: SONOCO TO CLOSE NEW YORK PLANT WITH 130 WORKERS
description: The Sonoco Products Company, which makes boxes, plastic bags and food cans, will close a plant in Fulton, N.Y., that has 130 employees as part of a plan to reduce costs amid falling sales and prices. The plant will close by the end of next March, said Allan Cecil, a spokesman for Sonoco. The company, based in Hartsville, S.C., said this week that it would eliminate more than 300 jobs and close at least 20 plants as it seeks to cut costs. ''We don't know yet how many more plants will close, and they range in size from 30 people to 300 people,'' Mr. Cecil said. Sonoco expects to save about $6.5 million a year by closing the Fulton plant.

title: In Jerusalem, Derailed Hopes for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fund Measure Advances
description: The German cabinet has approved a bill to increase the country's investment fund industry, allowing hedge funds to be sold in Germany for the first time, starting in 2004. The Ministry of Finance said that the modernized bill would also give equal tax treatment to domestic and foreign funds as of 2004, a move that experts say could attract up to 150 billion euros ($167 billion) into the German capital markets in the next three years. The new measures still need the approval of the Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament, which is expected to make a decision in November. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Profit At Bank
description: Scandinavia's biggest bank, Nordea, said second-quarter profit almost quadrupled as it reduced loan losses and sold properties. Net income rose to 405 million euros ($450 million), from 106 million euros ($118 million) a year earlier when the bank took a charge to plug a pension deficit. Net interest income increased 2.8 percent, to 957 million euros ($1.07 billion) as low interest rates increased lending.

title: Lost Elvis Song Turns Up
description: Elvis lives. In a basement in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERMAN, BERTHA
description: BERMAN -- Bertha. Died peacefully on Monday, August 18, after a long illness. Survived by her beloved husband, Ralph, and their three loving daughters, Barbara, Heller and Teena. Devoted mother-in-law to Paul, Owen and Joshua and dear grandmother to Alex and Peter. Private burial on Thursday. Bertha devoted her life to her family and to the Lee Baumann Shop in Greenwich Village, of which she was the long time proprietress. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of Ralph Berman from 5-9 PM on Thursday and from 4-7 PM on Friday. If desired, contributions in Bertha's Memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 225 North Michigan Ave, Suite 1700, Chicago, IL 60601-7633.

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,200 Parents Prepare to Take On Role as Paid Liaisons in Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein welcomed 1,200 new parent coordinators yesterday, saying they were taking on ''one of the key levers for change'' in an overhauled school system.

title: Pentagon Sees Terrorism in Iraq as Greatest Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — Defense Department officials said today that terrorism had emerged as the most serious security threat in Iraq, but they asserted again that it was not necessary to send more United States troops to the country.

title: Officials Link Fatal Shootings To Drug Sales
description: Authorities investigating three shooting deaths last week at convenience stores in the Charleston, W.Va., region said yesterday that they suspected that at least two victims were not randomly chosen and that their shootings might be related to drugs.

title: Businessman to Lead Liberia's Interim Government
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 21  Liberia's warring parties today chose a mild-mannered businessman to lead an interim government until 2005.

title: A Hit in Kansas, Do-It-All Gadgets Venture Into Oz
description: IT seems to be a guiding principle of the modern age: anything that starts out black and white eventually gets colorized. Whether it's computers, TV screens, cellphones, old movies or even major news-papers, nothing stays monochrome forever. (As for the holdouts like piano keys, faxes and zebras, well, it's only a matter of time.)

title: OVERSIGHT GROUP WARNED UTILITIES ON POWER FLOWS
description: Three months before the biggest blackout in North American history, the agency charged with protecting the nation's electrical grid put industry officials on notice that the section of the grid covering Ohio and other parts of the Midwest was particularly vulnerable to the kind of ''cascading events'' that unfolded last Thursday.

title: Former Radical Granted Parole In '81 Killings
description: Kathy Boudin, the former radical fugitive who pleaded guilty for her role in a 1981 armored-car robbery and shootout that killed a guard and two police officers in Rockland County, N.Y., was granted parole yesterday after 22 years in prison.

title: Brazil Cuts Key Interest Rate In Bid to Revive Its Economy
description: In a sign that Brazil's left-leaning government is increasingly anxious to get the stalled economy growing again, the central bank today lopped 2.5 percentage points off its overnight interest rate, lowering the important lending rate to 22 percent.

title: Cheaper Than Buying A Whole New Kitchen
description: ''I try to remodel kitchens at a fraction of what a new one would cost,'' said Mike Masella, the owner of A Great Alternative, in Wallingford, Conn. He serves customers in Connecticut and Westchester, refinishing kitchen appliances, countertops and cabinets in the home with many colors of enamel. A refrigerator is $195 to $215; a dishwasher is $55 to $65. He works on bathroom tubs ($400) and tiled walls (which may cost $1,000 to $1,500). Mr. Masella is at (203) 265-9693.

title: Hong Kong Party Calls for Delay in Security Legislation
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 21  Fearing a setback in elections next year, the leaders of the main pro-Beijing political party here called today for the government to delay controversial internal-security legislation by more than a year, until the next session of Hong Kong's Legislature.

title: Nuclear Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond the Western Clichs: Documenting How Average Arabs Live
description: Long before the invasion of Iraq, the Vitra Design Museum Berlin studied the Middle East and North Africa.
