''Designers and architects have always had a great interest in these countries, and we wanted to follow the question: What do they offer that is so appealing?'' said Mateo Kries, a curator of ''Living Under the Crescent Moon: Domestic Cultures in the Arab World,'' a show that runs through Jan. 18. Events led Mr. Kries and another curator, Alexander von Vegesack, to expand the show, whose title refers to a symbol of Islam, from a salute to design to a Baedeker of Arabic home life. Films and photos document how average Arabs live: above left, nomads in Mauritania and, above right, interior of a house in Morocco. Everyday objects like a breadbox, left, are shown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIER, ELLA
description: MAIER--Ella. On August 20, 2003. Beloved wife of Nathan. Loving aunt, cousin and dear friend to many. Services Friday 11:30 AM at Hebrew Tabernacle of Washington Heights, 551 Fort Washington Avenue, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, C. HERBERT
description: FISHER--C. Herbert, 84, of Greenwich, CT & Quogue, NY on August 14, 2003. Husband of the late Wanda. Survived by his stepdaughter Patricia Owen of Los Angeles, CA, his niece Jano Nolette of Toledo, OH, his nephew Thomas Fisher of Stamford, CT., and his sister-in-law Jano Fisher of Riverside, CT. A memorial service took place in Quogue, New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the 50th anniversary of the Wiffle ball compared its weight imprecisely with that of a baseball. At two-thirds of an ounce, it is less than an eighth of the weight of a baseball -- not merely less than a third. (A regulation baseball weighs 5 to 5.25 ounces.)

title: New York Town Mourns a Generous Friend
description: The mother of 13 children who was killed in the suicide bombing in Jerusalem on Tuesday along with her 5-month-old baby was remembered today in this tight-knit Hasidic community as a magnetic woman whose life revolved around helping others.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rough road to a theme park / Tourism among land mines : Cambodia to restore Khmer Rouge sites
description: ANGLONG VENG, Cambodia  In a case of Disneyland meets the killing fields, Cambodia's Ministry of Tourism is drawing up grandiose plans to upgrade the final stronghold of the Khmer Rouge into a million-dollar theme park.

title: Fishing for Information? Try Better Bait
description: THE notion of a user's manual for search engines might seem counterintuitive. Give people an empty search box and a button to click on and somehow they know exactly what to do.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Posts Profit
description: Zurich Financial Services posted a $587 million net profit in the second quarter of this year, for a first-half profit of $701 million, reversing a loss of $2 billion in the first half of 2002. Premiums rose 26 percent, to $26.1 billion, up from $20.7 billion, a year earlier, helped by increasing prices on its property and casualty insurance policies. Investors focused on Zurich's $474 million provisions at the Centre Solutions unit, which offers companies reinsurance and asset management products. Zurich has stopped writing new contracts in that money-losing unit, but it must still honor commitments to its current policies. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Arrest In Threat To Poison Water Supply
description: The police in the western town of Einbeck arrested a 32-year-old man they say threatened to poison the town's water supply with 110 pounds of cyanide, prosecutors said. They said the poison was found in the basement of the man's home after the authorities traced two letters sent to them earlier this year. They said that the cyanide was ordered from a local delivery company under false pretenses and that the man planned the attack on the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: Two Studies Cite Confusion On Terrorism
description: Two private studies released this week have found that police officers, firefighters, public school safety officers and other emergency response workers believe that nearly two years after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, they are unprepared if terrorists strike again.

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now? (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Kick Field Goal, Team Gets Break
description: At the end of many practices at training camp, a group of large, hot, tired men gather around two small, less-tired men and apply the kind of peer pressure no one wants to face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REISS, MELVIN P.
description: REISS--Melvin P. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Sheryl and Kevin and Susan and Martin. Loving stepfather of Susan and Rob, Gary and Veronique and Amy and Rob. Adored grandfather of Justin, Yonaton, Jason, Chaya, Binyamin, Nicole, Matthew, Allison, Joshuha and Eric. Services Friday 10AM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAHAM, RITA (KALLUS)
description: ABRAHAM--Rita (Kallus). 77, passed away on August 15, 2003 in NYC. Wife of the late Roy, she is survived by her sons, Andrew of Jerusalem, Israel and Philip of NYC. Beloved grandmother of 13 grandchildren. Donations can be made in her name to the International Myeloma Foundation at www.myeloma.org

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Fatal Stabbing At Home
description: A 19-year-old man was found stabbed to death early yesterday in his family's home near the Bronx River Parkway, the police said. The man, Kirk Evans, was home alone at 679 East 232nd Street, officials said. Neighbors said Mr. Evans had lived there for a year with an aunt and uncle who had been vacationing in Florida for a week. He was last seen alive by neighbors on Sunday. When the aunt and uncle returned a little past midnight yesterday, Mr. Evans was dead of stab wounds. His body was found beneath a sheet inside the house, the police said. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A book review on July 7 about ''The Last Alchemist: Count Cagliostro, Master of Magic in the Age of Reason'' misstated the name of a television psychic to whom Cagliostro was compared in the review. He is John Edward, not Jonathan Edwards. A reader alerted The Times the day the error appeared; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: A Price Too High
description: How long is it going to take for us to recognize that the war we so foolishly started in Iraq is a fiasco -- tragic, deeply dehumanizing and ultimately unwinnable? How much time and how much money and how many wasted lives is it going to take?

title: Questions Haunt a Saddened Annan
description: As staff members prepared for a candlelight vigil in memory of their slain colleagues in Baghdad, two questions were asked repeatedly here today. Who should take responsibility for the security breach that enabled the bombing to happen? And how can the organization best protect workers who will continue the job of reconstructing Iraq?

title: 'We Don't Have Answers' for Deaths of 6 Children
description: The unfinished plywood board was about the right size for the frame of a go-cart. Resting on it, the small shape bundled in a black and white cloth jarringly reminded one mourner, Jeremy Gold, of ''a little gift.''

title: When Salsa Doesn't Satisfy
description: In the lobby of the Beverly Hilton here on Friday, a newly wed couple asked a group of people with laminated credentials hanging around their necks what the big event was in the hotel.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Ruling Opposes School Admissions Policy
description: A federal judge ordered the Kamehameha Schools to admit a 12-year-old student challenging its admissions policy. Admission to the schools, with a $6 billion endowment and heavily subsidized tuitions, is prized in Hawaii. But the schools give an essentially absolute preference to applicants of Hawaiian ancestry, which would exclude the student, Brayden Mohica-Cummings, though the judge, David Ezra of Federal District Court, indicated that he appeared qualified. Judge Ezra emphasized that his ruling was preliminary and that he was not deciding the legality of the policy. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: A Chip-Based Challenge to a Car's Spinning Camshaft
description: IF Henry Ford could see the engines now made by the company he founded 100 years ago, he would probably be puzzled by the electronics that control many operations. But the mechanical system operating the valves that bring fuel and air into the engine and let out exhaust would be very familiar.

title: A Top Mets Prospect May Find Path Blocked
description: The emergence of VANCE WILSON and JASON PHILLIPS and MIKE PIAZZAs role as the franchise player have created a problem for CRAIG BRAZELL, one of the Mets top prospects. Brazell is a first baseman. The crowd behind the plate at Shea Stadium has already forced Phillips to move to first part time while injuries, age and defensive problems could put Piazza there in the near future.

title: New Coach, Same Expectations
description: At first blush, the San Francisco 49ers look as sturdy and majestic as the mountains that are so evident behind the team's practice facility here.

title: Jack Shaffer, 73, a Broker Of Major Real Estate Deals
description: Jack Arnold Shaffer, a Manhattan investment banker who specialized in major real estate deals like the sale of the Plaza Hotel, died on Monday in Norwalk, Conn. A resident of the East Side of Manhattan, he was 73 and had a weekend home in Westport.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New York Starts Own Blackout Inquiry
description: The state will conduct its own investigation into last week's blackout, which left nearly 90 percent of the state without power. The investigation will be headed by the Public Service Commission and will focus on why various areas of the state were affected differently. All 3.1 million customers of Consolidated Edison, which supplies electricity to the five boroughs, lost power. But about 50,000 of the Long Island Power Authority's customers kept power. Gov. George E. Pataki, who asked the commission for the study, said investigators would also look into ''why we were not protected as we were told we would be after '65 and after '77,'' the two previous blackouts. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Familiar Domino Sugar Refinery Will Shut Much of Its Operation
description: The neon Domino Sugar sign looms over the East River like a beacon, visible for miles. Gleaming above the Brooklyn complex where sugar has been refined for more than a century, it has become a symbol of a rapidly fading industrial legacy, a reminder that the city known for high-tech finance and elegant living was built on ships and machinery, brawn and sweat.

title: Oregon, in Crisis, Finally Balances Budget
description: After the longest budget stalemate in its history, the Oregon Legislature, wrestling with a severe economic crisis and heavy infighting, finally balanced its budget yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 13 with an opera review about two productions at Tanglewood, in Massachusetts, misidentified the soprano shown singing Juana in ''Rage d'Amours'' by Robert Zuidam. She was Rochelle Bard; Lucy Shelton was one of two others who shared the role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALPERN, LLOYD
description: ALPERN--Lloyd. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted, long-time member, Lloyd Alpern. Our deepest sympathy is extended to all his dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

title: Penalty in Crown Hts. Case Means a Little More Jail Time
description: Expressing regret that he could not impose a harsher penalty, a federal judge sentenced Lemrick Nelson yesterday to 10 years in prison for the fatal stabbing of Yankel Rosenbaum in the Crown Heights racial unrest of 1991.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Economy Shrinks
description: France's economy shrank 0.3 percent in the second quarter, the national statistics office INSEE reported. The provisional figures show that the contraction was a result of lower consumer spending, companies running down inventory and decreased exports, INSEE said. After a wave of strikes in May and June, consumer spending fell 0.2 percent after having grown 0.5 percent in the first quarter. Exports, affected by the strength of the euro against the dollar, were down again in the second quarter, posting a 0.6 percent decline in the April-June period, after falling 1.8 percent in the first quarter. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: CONSECO RESOLVES OBJECTIONS TO REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: A reorganization plan for Conseco Inc. cleared another obstacle yesterday, setting the stage for the company to emerge from federal bankruptcy protection next month. Conseco, which is based in Carmel, Ind., reached an agreement resolving the United States trustee's objections to its reorganization plan, a company lawyer, Roger Higgins, said in court. The government agency had voiced concerns about the ''coercive'' nature of provisions included in a settlement between the company and holders of preferred debt. Conseco was to file a motion with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Illinois yesterday detailing the terms of an agreement with the trustee's office, Mr. Higgins said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURNION, MONSIGNOR PHILIP J.
description: MURNION--Monsignor Philip J. On August 19, 2003. Beloved son of the late Frances and the late William Murnion. Loving brother of William and Deborah Murnion, Rose Mary and Victor Gerdes and John and Kathleen Murnion. He was a dedicated priest of the Archdiocese of New York and founder and Director of the National Pastoral Life Center. An inspiration to the Church in America during the 40 years of his priesthood. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Mad. Ave, 81 St, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Friday at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, (Mott St, between Houston and Prince) commencing 4 PM with a prayer vigil 7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 AM at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: National Pastoral Life Center, 18 Bleecker St, New York, New York 10012.

title: Arthur Helton, 54, Refugee Advocate, Dies
description: Arthur C. Helton, a New York lawyer and human rights activist who devoted most of his professional life to the help and protection of refugees, died in the bomb attack on the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad on Tuesday, the Council on Foreign Relations announced yesterday. He was 54.

title: A Stroll Through the Ivy, With a Tour Guide That Beeps
description: FOR an arriving student, Cornell University is a daunting physical presence, with 745 acres sprawled across Finger Lakes ravines, and an intellectual challenge, with seven colleges, 21,000 students and a world-class faculty.

title: The Luck of the Draw Is a Problem for Roddick
description: Andy Roddick might be due for his first Grand Slam victory, but to get it he will have to make his way past a difficult first hurdle. In the draw for the United States Open, which begins Monday, the fourth-seeded Roddick drew a first-round match with Tim Henman, the only player who has beaten him on a hardcourt this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHASE, W. HOWARD
description: CHASE--W. Howard. Pioneer in the field of Public Relations and Issue Management, died on August 19, 2003 in Stamford, CT. He was 93. Visiting hours 4-8 PM on Friday, August 22, 2003 at the Nicholas F. Cognetta Funeral Home and Crematory, 104 Myrtle Ave, Stamford, CT. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, August 23, at 3 PM at the Unitarian Universalist Society, 20 Forest St, Stamford, CT.

title: People
description: * Murray Dudgeon, executive vice president and worldwide operations director at Universal McCann Worldwide, New York, was named to the new post of chief operating officer. He will be based in the London office of Universal McCann, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the case of Linda J. Calbi, who is accused in the beating death of her 14-year-old son, Matthew, misstated the response of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services to an earlier complaint involving her. Matthew and his younger brother were allowed to live with their father in an informal arrangement; they were not officially removed from their mother's home.

title: Corrections
description: Alisting of auctions and antiques shows last Thursday with an article about the sale of the contents of a house belonging to Remi Saunder in Glenco Mills, N.Y., misstated the dates of the next outdoor show in Brimfield, Mass. It runs Sept. 2 through 7, not Sept. 7 through 12.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about Sherry B. Ortner, an anthropologist who has written a book about her high school class, the class of 1958 at Weequahic in Newark, omitted a word in describing the school system at the time. There were five public high schools, not five public schools.

title: UBS Settles Charges on Broker Supervision
description: UBS agreed yesterday to pay $500,000 to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to supervise a broker who bilked clients out of more than $68 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have lived with a Democrat for 17 years.''

title: Facts? Probably. Fun? You Decide.; Things You Never Knew You Wanted to Know About New York, and More
description: ''Did you know'' may be the three sweetest words to collectors of fun facts. They lead to unusual foods of other nations, to batting averages, to the fact that Kennedy had a secretary named Lincoln.

title: Internet Advertising
description: Gains in Revenue Internet advertising revenue in the United States is estimated to have increased in the first quarter, according to the Interactive Advertising Bureau in New York, the first time in two years that revenue had grown in consecutive quarters.

description: Utilities in Midwest Alerted To Risks in Electrical Grid

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: North Korean Ferry To Resume Port Calls
description: A North Korean ferry, the lone link between North Korea and Japan, is to dock in Japan on Monday for the first time since January. Attempts to renew service since were thwarted by large right-wing protests and stringent application of safety rules by the Japanese authorities. Arriving at the port of Niigata two days before the start of six-country talks over North Korea's nuclear program, the ferry is to take 200 ethnic Koreans living in Japan, mostly college students, to North Korea.

title: Survey of School Offices Finds Answers Scarce
description: Officials at the Department of Education's 10 new regional offices are largely unprepared to answer even the most basic questions that parents might pose about school services, according to a survey by the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HYM, JEAN, LOUIS
description: HYM--Jean-Louis. In remembrance of Jean-Louis Hym who died 20 years ago in New York City, a murder still unsolved. From his family and friends. Helene Hym-Williams, 27 rue de la Pierre, 37100 Tours, France

title: Price of Treasuries Tumbles On Fear of Return of Inflation
description: The 10-year Treasury note had its biggest decline in a week in New York trading yesterday on speculation that job and manufacturing reports today would provide evidence of faster economic growth, and thus help ignite inflation.

title: International Aid Groups Withdrawing Staffs From Iraq
description: International organizations, led by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, began evacuating workers from Iraq today as they pondered the implications of the deadly truck bombing Tuesday at United Nations headquarters in Baghdad.

title: 45 Years Later, Jury Resolves Officer's Killing
description: After only about an hour and 45 minutes of deliberation, a jury found today that a man serving a 98-year term for murder had fatally shot a Rahway, N.J., police officer nearly 45 years ago. The jury awarded the officer's family $9.5 million in damages.

title: Republican Grand Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Padres Get the Best of the Mets Again
description: The National League's worst team continues to pester the Mets. Sean Burroughs's one-out single off Grant Roberts scored the winning run in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight, giving the Padres a 2-1 victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, SHIRLEY
description: SIEGEL -- Shirley. Beloved aunt of Paul, devoted psychotherapist. Condolences to all her friends, colleagues and patients. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 W 76 St, Sunday, August 24, 11:15AM. All are welcome to attend. Burial to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: In 'Little India' Neighborhood, Tactics of Ex-McGreevey Fund-Raiser Still Elicit Anger
description: Rukmini Pollepalli was merely annoyed at first. In the fall of 2000, a building inspector arrived at her jewelry store in the Little India section of Woodbridge Township and wrote her a $250 citation for building an illegal glass wall in the shop.

title: Cedeo Working to Regain Mets' Trust
description: Roger Cedeo smashed a sinking line drive to center field and sprinted for a double as the ball curled to left-center. It was a jolt of hitting and speed that Cedeo was once known for. Earlier in the game, Cedeo landed on his backside as he dodged his teammates in the Mets' bullpen while retrieving Mark Kotsay's triple.

title: SARS Keeps Foreign Students Home, Hurting Chinese Businesses
description: Most summers, Zhou Li does a brisk business selling soda and instant noodles to the enthusiastic foreigners studying Chinese next door. She sleeps on a bench in her convenience store, in case a student craves ice cream at 3 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATCHER, STANLEY
description: KATCHER--Stanley, 68, of Pelham Manor, New York died August 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Evelyn, father of David and Paul, brother of Gary, brother-in-law of Sharon & uncle of Jason, Stacey & Jamie. The funeral will be held on Friday, August 22, 11 A.M., Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: An Elite Contest For a Growing U.N.
description: A LITTLE more than 50 years ago, the United Nations brought together some of the world's most prominent architects, including Le Corbusier and Oscar Neimeyer, to design its headquarters on the East River. The result is a Modernist icon.

title: US Mid-Atlantic Factories Post Surge
description: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Factory activity in the U.S. Mid-Atlantic region jumped unexpectedly in August, a survey said Thursday, bolstering the view that the troubled manufacturing sector is poised for recovery.

title: U.S. Will Ask U.N. for Move to Widen the Force in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20  The Bush administration, seizing on the bomb attack on the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, is preparing a new Security Council resolution that would urge other nations to send troops and aid to secure Iraq, administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDY, STEPHEN
description: RUDY--Stephen. Professor and former Chairman of the NYU Department of Russian and Slavic Studies; died on August 13, 2003. He will be missed by many friends, colleagues, students and by his family. A Memorial Service will be held at Ireland House, 1 Washington Mews, NYC on August 25th at 7PM.

title: Talbots' Profit Falls 7.6%
description: Talbots Inc., a retailer of classically styled clothing for women, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings fell 7.6 percent, which was less than it had forecast, on higher sales of late-summer and early-fall merchandise.

title: In Frayed Networks, Common Threads
description: WHEN the United States entered World War I in 1917, its railroad system had just undergone three decades of torrid expansion after the adoption of a standard track width. While the expansion was unquestionably a boon, it also created the potential for new logistical problems.

title: This Is CNN?
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including strategic advice for CNN and opinions about Kevin Costners likeability.

title: Berkshire Loses Bid for Secrecy
description: Warren E. Buffett lost a bid for confidentiality from the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, meaning that the public may learn more about which stocks Mr. Buffett was buying last fall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORTHROP GRUMMAN CORP., Los Angeles, said it planned to repurchase as much as $700 million of its outstanding stock over the next 18 months to make use of its accumulated cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHANLEY, RICHARD N.
description: SHANLEY--Richard N., 86, of Oceanport, NJ, formerly of Rumson, NJ, on August 20, 2003. Former Sales Manager for Cook & Dunn Paints, husband of the late Rita nee McLoughlin, father of Richard N. Shanley, Jr. and Frank E. and his wife Jeanne Shanley, grandfather of Molly, Casey and Jack. No visitation. Memorial Mass Saturday 10AM from Holy Cross R.C. Church, Ward Ave, Rumson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to American Heart Association, 2550 Rte 1, N. Brunswick, NJ, 08902.

title: Japan Inc. Now Just a Memory, Toshiba Retools Its Image
description: As he tries to remake the Toshiba Corporation, Tadashi Okamura likes to turn to histories of the Meiji era for inspiration. Mr. Okamura, the chief executive of Toshiba, the world's third-largest maker of computer chips, finds sustenance in stories about the late 19th-century reformers who threw off the shackles of Japan's medieval sword fighters to create the first non-Western industrial power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAYWOOD, JOSEPH S.
description: HAYWOOD--Joseph S., 76, on August 20, 2003. Beloved and cherished husband of Joan, loving father of Peter, Betsey and Lisa, dearest father-inlaw to Jamie and Alyson, devoted grandfather of Lyndsay, Jack and Henry. Loved by all who knew him. Services Friday, August 22 at 10:30AM Scarsdale Synagogue-Tremont Temple, 2 Ogden Road, Scarsdale. Contributions may be made to Scarsdale Synagogue - Tre mont Temple.

title: Some Modest 'Family Friendly' Proposals for Jets' President
description: The Jets are charging fans $50 a year to stay on the team's season-ticket waiting list, a fee that will certainly live in infamy, along with the now common personal seat license, or payment for the right to buy a season ticket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, JULIUS OCHS
description: ADLER--Julius Ochs, 78, died on August 18, 2003 after a long illness. Mr. Adler is survived by his wife, Deirdre Spencer Adler, a son, Douglas O. Adler, two daughters, Anne A. Tarbell and Mary B. Malhotra, as well as an aunt, two sisters, three step children, 13 grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Mr. Adler was the son of Barbara Stettheimer Adler and Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President, General Manager and Treasurer of The New York Times from 1914 to 1955. From 1977 until 1992, Mr. Adler and his wife owned and operated the Canterbury Bookstore in Manhattan. Earlier in his professional career, Mr. Adler was affiliated with Interpublic, the New York Mets and The New York Times. Mr. Adler served in the United States Air Corps during WWII. He attended Princeton University. Mr. Adler's funeral will be private. Donations in his memory can be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY: 11 PEOPLE ARE DECONTAMINATED Eleven people, including two police officers, had to be decontaminated after a man suffered chemical burns last night, according to the police. The man was in serious condition, in isolation, at Jersey City Medical Center, where the emergency room was shut down briefly as a precaution, a hospital spokesman said. At around 10:15 p.m. the victim, who the police said was homeless, was taken to the hospital from a place near 44 Jewett Avenue, where officers found a chlorine-like substance. Some neighbors said the man, who the police did not identify, had tried to pull copper pipes off an abandoned refrigerator when he was injured, but the police said the incident was still under investigation.

title: Alabama's Top Judge Defiant On Commandments' Display
description: Midnight came and went, but the rock did not roll.

title: Chain of Events in the Middle East Conflict
description: About 2,400 Palestinians and 800 Israelis have been killed since Sept. 29, 2000, when a confrontation between Palestinians and the Israeli police turned deadly, initiating a new wave of conflict over Jerusalen that has been a battleground for Jews, Muslims and Christians for centuries. Here are important events during that time:

title: Powell and Annan's News Conference
description: Following is the transcript from the news conference held by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, on Aug. 21, at the United Nations, as recorded by e-Media.

title: Here Today and Gone Tomorrow (Intentionally)
description: David Stark, a partner in Avi Adler Inc., a party-planning firm in Brooklyn, is famed for his flower arrangements. Now he has done a limited-edition store interior: Isaac Mizrahi for Target, above, a clothing boutique from Mr. Mizrahi, right, which will open in Rockefeller Center on Sept. 4 and close on Oct. 15.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Crosswave Seeks Protection From Creditors
description: A joint telecommunications venture, Crosswave Communications Inc., filed court papers asking for protection from creditors. The 5-year-old company, which is listed on the Nasdaq, was undone by the continued downturn in demand for its high-speed data communications services. Japan's telecommunications market is dominated by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sampras Is Inching Closer To Announcing Retirement
description: Pete Sampras has not played in a tournament for almost a year, since his stirring triumph over Andre Agassi in the 2002 United States Open final. Now, people with knowledge of Sampras's plans say that there is a strong likelihood he will announce his retirement within days, and that there is a good possibility there will be a ceremony honoring him on Monday night at the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNES, NADIA
description: YOUNES--Nadia. In memory of our friend, lost in Baghdad, we shall always love and remember you. Tim and Christian

title: The Recall Debate Begins
description: The celebrity power of Arnold Schwarzenegger, the action-movie star who would be California's governor, was graphically clear yesterday as a corps of reporters worthy of Oscar night clamored to record his first substantial words on the state's crippling fiscal crisis. Through the glare and handsome set design of the event, the state's voters heard the candidate rule out tax increases and promise some sort of spending cuts as his solution to the state's rolling budget deficits. Critical if vague differences have thus begun emerging among the better known figures on the prodigious slate of 135 candidates. We hope the October recall vote will veer even further from the carnival grounds where it has been capering and beeping.

title: U.S. Official Tells Iraqis to Assert More Authority
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 20 — Sharp differences emerged today between the top American administrator in Iraq and the country's interim government as the United States sought to calm a city unnerved by the truck bomb that killed 20 people in the United Nations headquarters.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: NEW MEXICO: LOS ALAMOS EMPLOYEE WINS SETTLEMENT An employee of the Los Alamos National Laboratory who was fired last year after documenting theft and security breaches received a $930,000 settlement from the University of California, his lawyers said. The employee, Glen Walp, accused the university, which runs Los Alamos, of firing him and another colleague for raising security concerns in a report leaked to the news media. Eighteen top laboratory officials were later fired, demoted or transferred. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Argentine Congress Likely to Void 'Dirty War' Amnesties
description: Under prodding from the country's new president, the Argentine Congress is soon expected to revoke a pair of longstanding amnesty laws that have protected hundreds of military officers from prosecution for the kidnapping, torture and killing of opponents and critics during the ''dirty war'' here in the 1970's.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: AMP Posts A Loss
description: Australia's largest financial services group, AMP, reported a first-half loss of 2.2 billion Australian dollars ($1.44 billion) as a result of write-downs and restructuring costs. Excluding the one-time items, the company posted a profit of 317 million Australian dollars ($208 million), but the managing director, Craig Dunn, said the result was ''frustrating and disappointing.'' He promised further ''decisive steps'' to restructure the company, including the spinoff of failed units in Britain, where it paid 7 billion Australian dollars ($4.6 billion) to expand insurance operations. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Protecting Airliners
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: U.S. ANTIDRUG CHIEF PRAISES COOPERATION Karen P. Tandy, the new head of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, said that "an unprecedented collaborative effort" with the Mexican authorities has allowed them to go after drug cartels successfully. Ms. Tandy, meeting her Mexican counterparts on her third week into the job, said future efforts would focus on entire cartels. "We will have a great deal of difficulty disrupting and dismantling these organizations if we do not focus on them as the Fortune 500 of drug trafficking and eliminate them as a single business entity rather than taking out single pieces of their marketing side."    David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Pfizer Falls on Concern Over Generic Drug Threat
description: NEW YORK (Reuters) - Shares of Pfizer Inc. fell 3 percent Thursday after Smith Barney cut its rating on the world's largest drug maker amid concern its cholesterol drug Lipitor may face generic competition sooner than most people expect.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Five Crime Figures Indicted
description: Joseph Massino, who prosecutors said is the boss of the Bonanno crime family, was indicted yesterday on federal racketeering and murder charges. Four associates -- Robert Lino, Ronald Filocomo, Patrick DeFilippo and John Joseph Spirito -- were also indicted. Some of the men had already been charged with racketeering conspiracy and murder. The new indictment, announced yesterday by federal, state and city officials, charges the men with other killings, including slayings of members of their own crime family. Mr. Massino has been charged with the 1984 murder of Cesare Bonventre, at the time a defendant in what was known as the Pizza Connection case that charged members of the Bonanno family with importing heroin from Italy. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: TV Guidance on Putting Your Place in Order
description: Call it the ''Clean Eye for the Messy Guy.'' On Sept. 3 the television show ''Clean House'' will begin teaching slobs the joys of neatness. ''Honey, you would never believe how some people in America are living,'' said the host, Niecy Nash, second from left, below. (Her colleagues are, from left, Michael Moloney, Linda Koopersmith and Allen Lee Haff.) Personal belongings that get the heave-ho will be sold at an on-the-air yard sale, and the proceeds will go toward the household makeover. Do the lessons stick? Alas, ''Clean House'' doesn't do follow-up visits. ''I believe in happy endings,'' Ms. Nash said. ''I like to believe it's just like I left it.'' In New York, the show is on at 10 p.m. on the E! cable channel.

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Skateboard King Who Fell to Earth
description: For many in the world of skateboarding, it was a scab better left untouched. Publicly discussing the fate of Mark Rogowski, a legendary skateboarder in the 1980's now serving 31 years in prison for murder and rape, was long considered taboo. But privately, elaborate tales -- some near truth, some far-fetched -- have festered.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: We'd Prefer No Coat And a Decent Bathroom

title: In Blow to Pataki, Judge Approves City's Plan to Sell Bonds
description: A state judge approved New York City's plan to sell bonds to refinance its 1970's debt today, dealing a blow to Gov. George E. Pataki, who had tried to block the plan as fiscally irresponsible and unconstitutional.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Transplanting Golden Glow

title: Lottery Numbers
National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Assembly Will Try To Repair Schools
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee said he would convene the General Assembly in a special session to try to repair the state's school system, which the State Supreme Court declared in November to be unconstitutionally underfinanced and academically inadequate. The session will begin Dec. 8, less than a month before a Jan. 1 deadline the court imposed on the executive and legislative branches to devise a remedy. The governor's announcement followed the adoption by a legislative committee of a plan that would require $825 million in new taxes to finance an annual school budget of $3.1 billion.

title: A DVR Update, Reflections on the Blackout and Column Notes
description: This week, it's brain-cleaning time. Below, four mini topics, none of which would merit a full-length newsletter treatment, but which I thought you might find timely.

title: Death in Jerusalem
description: Palestinian leaders have been promoting the illusion that Islamic radical groups will ultimately transform themselves into peaceful political parties. That fantasy was shattered on Tuesday along with 20 innocent lives when a Hamas terrorist blew up a Jerusalem bus. The bombing occurred at the very moment the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, was meeting with Islamic radicals in Gaza. If anything positive is to come from this latest atrocity, it will be a conclusive realization by Mr. Abbas that organizations like Hamas and Islamic Jihad have no genuine interest in cease-fire agreements or two-state solutions and must be forcibly put out of the terrorism business. Only then will the American-sponsored road map for peace have a chance of delivering Palestinian statehood.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of auctions and antiques shows last Thursday with an article about the sale of the contents of a house belonging to Remi Saunder in Glenco Mills, N.Y., misstated the dates of the next outdoor show in Brimfield, Mass. It runs Sept. 2 through 7, not Sept. 7 through 12.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Tuesday about free jazz concerts in New York City parks included one event erroneously and misstated its closing date. The event, the CD 101.9 Jazz Festival in Hudson River Park, off the West Side Highway at 14th Street, charges $39 for each performance ($49 at the gate) or $140 for the weekend. It runs through Sunday, not Saturday.

title: Now, Lilies and Sedums Grow in Brooklyn
description: New Yorkers with cars have access to suburban nurseries that might stock something more than ho-hum impatiens and curbside petunias. Now the Gowanus Nursery, which has opened in a part of Brooklyn that could be called Carroll Gardens Adjacent, is drawing even suburbanites for its species lilies and bold variegated aralia with six-foot leaves. Michele Paladino, 33, who has worked for Martha Stewart and for the garden designer Edwina von Gal, has created a narrow oasis surrounded by a minimalist chain-link fence and complete with bluestone pavers found on the site. Her nursery is home to shade-tolerant golden sedums, feathery eight-foot-tall stipa grass and exotic annuals and perennials. Having designed brownstone gardens, Ms. Paladino, below, is aware of the limitations and tries to find inventive solutions. But sometimes customers want those petunias. ''I usually only stock the plants I love most,'' she tells them. ''But I will be happy to get that for you.'' The Gowanus Nursery is at 102 Third Street; (718) 852-3116; open Thursday through Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: Amap on Saturday showing the locations of power plants and transmission lines in the northeastern United States gave an incorrect name in some copies for the company that provided some of the information. It is PennWell MAPSearch, not PennWise.

title: An Ancient Game With Fresh Appeal
description: FOR most Americans familiar with the tile game mah-jongg, Sandy Wilson of Manhattan might seem to be a stereotypical player. She is 68, Jewish, retired and a not-so-high roller: her regular group of partners -- ''the girls,'' as she calls them -- vie for a $5 pot.

title: Strong Franc Helps Reduce Nestl's Profit
description: First-half profits at Nestl fell by half from the year-ago period, hurt by a strong Swiss franc and comparison with a one-time gain last year, the company said today.

title: Second Case Like SARS Turns Up In Canada
description: A relatively mild upper respiratory ailment that seems to be caused by a SARS-like virus has appeared in a second nursing home in the Vancouver area, Canadian health officials said yesterday.

title: After 5 Years, Rivals Emerge Ready to Give Viagra a Fight
description: Five years ago, hardly anyone had heard of erectile dysfunction, never mind wanting to discuss it. Pfizer's introduction of Viagra in 1998 changed that, and the debut in the next few months of two competitors will make the subject difficult to avoid.

title: US AIRWAYS STOPS DEFERRING PAY OF WORKERS
description: US Airways said in an employee newsletter released yesterday that it had stopped deferring 5 percent of workers' pay. The deferral had been in place for three months and was intended to help the company get back on its feet after restructuring under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. US Airways had said the deferral could last for up to 18 months. But in the newsletter, the company said it decided to stop the deferral this month after posting a net profit of $13 million in the second quarter. That profit included a one-time gain of $214 million from the federal government as reimbursement for security taxes and expenses. In the newsletter, David N. Siegel, the chief executive, said he ended the deferral with ''significant reservations'' because financial conditions remained difficult. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Reformer Resigns
description: Takeshi Kimura, left, a key adviser to Japan's banking czar, Heizo Takenaka, has resigned from an influential committee to help start a small lender. Mr. Kimura, who is also the president of KPMG International's Japan subsidiary, joined the Fiscal System Council board last October to help formulate a strategy for dealing with Japan's bad loans. Mr. Kimura frequently called on the government to take an aggressive approach. He will join a Japanese group that plans to set up a bank to lend to small companies. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about the Cleo Parker Robinson ensemble misstated the number of girls killed in the 1963 bombing of a church in Birmingham, Ala., the subject of a work on the program. It was four, not five.

title: INSIDE
description: F.C.C. Programming Study

title: Rivera Struggles, but the Yankees Manage to Survive
description: The last pitch of the game sizzled up and in, 95 miles an hour, and the Royals' Desi Relaford looked helpless. He struck out swinging, and the Yankees edged Kansas City, 8-7, to run their winning streak to seven games. In the Yankees' dugout, their pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, was especially relieved. Mariano Rivera, at last, had overpowered someone.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.T.C. Chief Doubtful Of Antispam Legislation
description: The head of the Federal Trade Commission says he is skeptical that several federal legislative proposals to reduce the growing flood of unsolicited e-mail messages could be successful. In a speech at an annual technology-policy forum in Aspen, Colo., on Tuesday, the chairman of the commission, Timothy J. Muris, said efforts in Congress miss the mark in addressing what he called a daunting consumer-protection problem. Unfortunately, he said, the legislative debate seems to be veering off on the wrong track. One proposal on Capitol Hill in particular, the idea for a national do-not-spam registry that would be similar to the do-not-call list for telemarketers, is likely to be ''a largely ineffective'' solution, Mr. Muris said. A do-not-spam registry would be impossible to enforce, he said, because the senders of such e-mail messages generally conceal their identities.

title: Economic Scene; Women are less likely to negotiate, and it can be costly to them.
description: MARS doesn't mind negotiating and is confident he deserves more; Venus is satisfied with what she is offered, unsure of what she deserves and fearful of bargaining. This is the message of ''Women Don't Ask,'' a provocative new book soon to be published by Princeton University Press.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro declined after a report showed that France's economy contracted in the second quarter, adding to concern the euro region is on the verge of recession. In New York, the euro fell to $1.1122 from $1.1128.

title: Sports of The Times; Waiting Too Long For the Inevitable
description: HANG the same Crayola-colored sunset over Arthur Ashe Stadium; reissue the seats for the fans who grasped the moment's perishable sweetness; allow Andre Agassi to retrace his steps to the net for an embrace of his longtime foil.

title: World Business Breifing
description: AMERICAS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Men Shot In Car
description: Two men were shot and seriously injured yesterday morning while sitting in their parked car in Sunset Park. The men, ages 25 and 22, were not immediately identified. They were taken to Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn and were listed in serious condition. The first was shot in the left arm, and the second was struck in both of his thighs and in his upper abdomen, the police said. Both were sitting in a gold Toyota Camry. Neighbors said they had heard what they thought were fireworks a few minutes before 4 a.m.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: Idi Amin's Exile Dream
description: The Idi Amin I met in 1997 was unchanged from the ''Big Daddy'' of Uganda who, in the 1970's, was proud of being the most feared leader in Africa. It was hot that day in Jidda, the Saudi Arabian resort city he had been living in since 1980. A big man with a raucous voice and strangely protuberant eyes, he was dressed in a white tunic, speaking loudly in his broken English. He talked just as he had ruled: walking the thin rope that separates madness from political satire, the tragic from the comic.

title: From PC to TV Screen, A Stream of Multimedia
description: Your PC is brimming with great photos, MP3's and videos. But your family and friends are glued to the television.

title: ABC News Executive Leaves for CBS
description: Victor Neufeld, a longtime producer and executive at ABC News, said yesterday that he was leaving the division to become the No. 2 producer of ''The Early Show'' on CBS.

title: A Virtuoso At Playing The Press In Italy
description: Europe has no leader more easily lampooned than Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, who recently made headlines by likening a German colleague in the European Parliament to a Nazi concentration camp kapo. This self-made media tycoon has always had an odd way with words.

title: Redskins Get Chase For Defensive Line
description: The Washington Redskins acquired defensive tackle Martin Chase from the New Orleans Saints in an attempt to fill a major hole on the defensive line.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the design of outdoor tables for Elle Decor's Dining by Design, a charity dinner and show last month in Wainscott, N.Y., misstated part of the name of the organization that benefited. It is the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS, not Industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEISAK, MARGOT
description: PEISAK--Margot. On August 20, 2003. Beloved wife of Manfred, daughter of Siegfried and Rosel, sister of Kurt, and mother of Steven. Interment at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Long Island Expressway and Flushing, NY, Friday August 22 at 11AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MIMRAN, ARMAND
description: MIMRAN--Armand. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of Sandra Smith. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: U.S. Antidrug Chief Praises Cooperation
description: Karen P. Tandy, the new head of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, said that ''an unprecedented collaborative effort'' with the Mexican authorities has allowed them to go after drug cartels successfully. Ms. Tandy, meeting her Mexican counterparts on her third week into the job, said future efforts would focus on entire cartels. ''We will have a great deal of difficulty disrupting and dismantling these organizations if we do not focus on them as the Fortune 500 of drug trafficking and eliminate them as a single business entity rather than taking out single pieces of their marketing side.'' David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about a gas line rupture that led to the evacuation of a hospital in Fort Monmouth, N.J., used a misspelled given name in some copies for a New Jersey Natural Gas spokeswoman who discussed the repair. She is Roseanne Koberle, not Roseann.

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 14th District -- Bronx; Fierce Race in the Bronx Has Some Personal Twists
description: Amid the bustle that overtakes the corner of Fordham Road and Jerome Avenue in the Bronx in the early evening, City Councilwoman Maria Baez stood this week with members of her campaign team, passing out literature, answering questions and trying to drum up support for her re-election.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NOKIA TO BUY GAMING ASSETS OF SEGA NETWORK The world's largest mobile phone maker, Nokia, which is planning an aggressive push into video gaming, said that it had agreed to acquire the multiplayer online games business of the Sega Corporation, the Japanese game maker. Nokia said late Tuesday that the deal related to assets of Sega.com Inc., including Sega's Network Application Package, or S.N.A.P., a computer server technology that is designed to form the core of networked game play. The value of the deal was not disclosed, but a Nokia spokesman said the price was "immaterial to Nokia." Nokia has some 10 billion euros ($11.14 billion) of cash and cash equivalents in the bank. Nokia will use S.N.A.P. for connecting and keeping scores for multiple gamers on its N-Gage phone-game deck combo device, set to be released worldwide on Oct. 7. It will take on Nintendo's Gameboy, which currently dominates the market for mobile gaming. (Reuters)

title: Facing Criticism, F.C.C. Is Thinking Local
description: With his bid to ease media ownership rules under assault from members of Congress worried by the prospect of greater consolidation, Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday that he would create a task force to study the ''localism'' of radio and television stations.

title: Governor of Russian Pacific Region and Aides on Missing Copter
description: A helicopter carrying the governor and other senior officials of the Pacific region of Sakhalin disappeared today while flying toward the Kurile Islands. An airborne search for the helicopter was suspended at nightfall, dimming hopes that the helicopter and those aboard would be found safe.

title: For Flailing Red Sox, Hope Is in Wild Card
description: A handful of Red Sox players were watching the Yankees begin their frenetic ninth inning against the Kansas City Royals this afternoon, but Kevin Millar refused even to glance at the two big-screen televisions in the middle of the clubhouse at Fenway Park. Millar was already weary of hearing and reading about the Yankees, so he did not need to see them, too.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Power Failure In Starrett City
description: The 15,000 residents of Starrett City lost electrical power twice yesterday for about two hours at a time, a spokeswoman for the private development said last night. The complex, which has 5,881 units and its own power station, remained brightly lit during the region-wide blackout last week. But from 11:15 a.m. to 1:20 p.m. much of the complex lost power, said Devorah L. Fong, the spokeswoman. From 4:05 p.m. until 5:30 p.m. the entire development lost power. Although about 10 people were trapped in elevators during each incident, there were no injuries, Ms. Fong said. The cause is under investigation. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Rates Curb Refinancings
description: Applications for mortgages fell for a second consecutive week to the lowest in more than a year as rising mortgage rates drove down refinancing, an industry report showed.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Morgan Stanley Seeks to Change Basis for Award In a Stock Case
description: In the years after the stock market peaked, Morgan Stanley worked overtime to persuade regulators that its research was fair and free of investment-banking-related conflicts. But the strategy failed, and the firm agreed to pay $50 million in fines last April to settle regulatory accusations that it issued biased research.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Judge Approves AT&T Wireless Settlement
description: AT&T Wireless Services Inc. yesterday won a judge's approval for a $47.5 million settlement of shareholder suits challenging its purchase of TeleCorp PCS Inc. last year. Judge Leo Strine Jr. of Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del., said the settlement offer by AT&T Wireless officials and former TeleCorp executives, amounting to about 40 cents a share for TeleCorp stockholders, was ''a very high-quality result.'' He awarded investors' lawyers $14.25 million in fees and expenses. TeleCorp shareholders said they were shortchanged in the buyout and accused former executives of getting $140 million in secret payments from AT&T Wireless to support the bid. AT&T Wireless paid about $4.6 billion in stock and assumed debt last year to acquire TeleCorp, its largest United States affiliate. AT&T Wireless denied in court papers that it had done anything wrong and said it resolved the case to ''avoid the substantial expense, inconvenience, risk and distraction of continued litigation.'' Shares of AT&T Wireless were unchanged at $8.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2nd Leader In Parish Is Suspended Over Abuse
description: A top education official for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has been suspended and barred from acting as an ordained deacon after he was accused of sexually abusing a minor 20 years ago, the archdiocese said yesterday.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: CLASS-ACTION SUIT AGAINST CEMETERIES A circuit judge has certified a class-action lawsuit against two cemeteries and their parent company, which are accused of desecrating graves and moving remains without family permission. The decision by Judge J. Leonard Fleet lets all people with burial plots or family members at the two cemeteries join the 2,000 plaintiffs already named in the suit against Menorah Gardens Funeral Homes in Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach and Service Corporation International of Houston. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALPERN, RUTH
description: ALPERN--Ruth. Died August 18, 2003. Wife of the late Max Alpern. Beloved mother of Laurie. Grandmother of Cynthia, Jessica and Michael. We will all miss you very much.

title: U.S. WILL ASK U.N. FOR MOVE TO WIDEN THE FORCE IN IRAQ
description: The Bush administration, seizing on the bomb attack on the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, is preparing a new Security Council resolution that would urge other nations to send troops and aid to secure Iraq, administration officials said today.

title: The City Life; North Toward Queens
description: Any Brooklyn native who saw the Dodgers abandon the borough 45 years ago for Los Angeles can find some succor these breezy summer evenings down at the edge of the Coney Island boardwalk, where the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets' Class A affiliate, reign in first place. The Cyclones play gritty, believable baseball and sell out each home game in a gemlike new park that tempts left-handed hitters as the blue Atlantic lazes beyond the right-field fence. The buzz is intimate, an echo of the old trolley-dodging days of Ebbets Field, as 8,000 fans pour in past immigrant-era relics: the skeletal parachute jump, the enduring Cyclone coaster. The grayheads in the crowd travel far in place and time, craving not so much baseball as purely Brooklyn baseball.

title: Baghdad's Rumor Mill Can't Agree on Culprit
description: Raad Hussein, who owns a fruit and vegetable market on Karrada Street, is used to living with fear. For months, he has had to close his shop before 10 p.m., when the nightly gun battles erupt in the alleys nearby.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: 11 People Are Decontaminated
description: Eleven people, including two police officers, had to be decontaminated after a man suffered chemical burns last night, according to the police. The man was in serious condition, in isolation, at Jersey City Medical Center, where the emergency room was shut down briefly as a precaution, a hospital spokesman said. At around 10:15 p.m. the victim, who the police said was homeless, was taken to the hospital from a place near 44 Jewett Avenue, where officers found a chlorine-like substance. Some neighbors said the man, who the police did not identify, had tried to pull copper pipes off an abandoned refrigerator when he was injured, but the police said the incident was still under investigation. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Relatives Of Victims Not Ready To Forgive
description: There were fresh-cut flowers left yesterday on a roadside memorial in Nyack, N.Y., dedicated to the victims of the Brink's robbery shootings in 1981.

title: Trainers Play Game Of Poker At Travers
description: Funny Cide is up for the rematch with Empire Maker in the 134th running of the Travers Stakes on Saturday. Or is he?

title: Town of Worn Bootstraps Lifts Itself Up
description: EARLY next month, a dozen families whose tar-paper shacks lack even running water will move into new homes here with heat, flush toilets and hot showers. ''It's going to be like a new world to me,'' said Solomon Burton, 74, who has spent decades hauling water in a bucket from a hand pump in his front yard. His privy sits beyond a sandy lane that winds through a low swale known as the Bottom.

title: In Jerusalem, Derailed Hopes for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwarzenegger Tries to Add Some Substance to Celebrity
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger came out from behind the curtain today to put some muscle in a campaign that until now was based on sheer celebrity, calling for a constitutional cap on state spending and making clear his distaste for new taxes.

title: The Hopes of Ireland Rest On a Player Rated 329th
description: Peter Clarke is the 329th-ranked tennis player in the world, but he still carries a nation's hopes.

title: Hollywood Ending For Music Palace; Gehry's Hall to Open (Cue Soaring Strings)
description: Lillian Disney, the widow of Walt Disney, favored the music of Lawrence Welk to Beethoven and Brahms. But that didn't deter her in 1987 from giving $50 million for a new music hall in Los Angeles. The gift was intended as not only a tribute to her husband, a classical music lover, but also as an expression of faith in the artistic and creative dynamism of 21st-century Los Angeles.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Ban On Pepper Spray And Mace At Clubs
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich has signed into law a bill that bans the use of pepper spray and mace inside a nightclub and prohibits the use of indoor pyrotechnics without the approval of the state fire marshal. The law comes six months after 21 people died in a stampede while trying to flee the E2 nightclub in Chicago when pepper spray and mace were used to break up a fight. Just days later, a fire ignited by pyrotechnics resulted in 100 deaths in a Rhode Island nightclub. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: No More Cursing The Dark
description: THE 36-unit Art Deco building at 895 Park Avenue has everything you would expect in a luxury co-op: 24-hour concierge, manned elevators, a wine cellar, squash courts and a gym. In a few months it can boast another amenity: a backup power generator.

title: HUSKY AND EOG TO BUY CANADIAN ASSETS FROM MARATHON
description: Husky Energy Inc., the Canadian oil and natural gas producer controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, agreed to buy the Marathon Oil Corporation's assets in western Canada for $588 million. Husky agreed to sell some of the Marathon properties to EOG Resources Inc. of Houston for $320 million, EOG said. Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., which is controlled by Mr. Li, holds about 35 percent of Husky stock. Including shares held by his family and at least one other company, he controls about 72 percent of Husky.

title: Commentators In Arab World Call Attack A Catastrophe
description: In the Arab world, which has never quite given up bruised hope that the United Nations will prove the agent to restore everything from lost land to lost pride, commentators today viewed the suicide bombing of the United Nations headquarters here as utter madness, yet more proof that the region is spiraling ever more out of control.

title: Onetime Gang Leader Is Shot in Chicago
description: Willie Lloyd, a man once known as the king of a notorious Chicago street gang who has in more recent years spoken publicly against violence and guns, was shot six times this morning on a street corner on this city's West Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKSON, ROBERT
description: JACKSON--Robert. Internationally known muralist and painter, died August 17, at home in Livingston, NY at 72. Painted murals in the U.S., England, Canada, Netherlands, France, Italy, including rooms in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, U.S. Department of State, White House, Blair House. His paintings have been displayed in one man shows in New York, Los Angeles, Toronto. Survived by his sister, Eleanor Warnock, of Newmarket, Ontario, three nephews and a niece, and longtime companion, Frederick Corke.

title: Baghdad Bombing: What Should We Do Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jets Kicker Is a Pigskin Purist
description: Doug Brien, the newest Jets place-kicker, is a man of integrity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Accused Of Stealing Millions
description: A city employee and her husband were charged yesterday with stealing $2.5 million from the criminal justice coordinator's office. The authorities said they spent the money on jewelry, lavish furnishings and gambling. The woman, Raimma Tagiev, 28, an office assistant, had written more than 400 fraudulent city checks to 17 fictitious payees since 2000, officials said. According to the complaint, her husband, Yan Blinder, 43, picked up the checks and cashed them, often on Avenue O in Brooklyn. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Mexico Beats Peru At Giants Stadium
description: Peru provided almost all the excitement last night and posted a 3-1 triumph over Mexico before a predominantly pro-Mexico crowd of 30,143 at Giants Stadium.

title: Medicare to Pay for Major Lung Operation
description: Medicare will begin paying for a major lung operation for certain people 65 and over who have severe emphysema with specific traits that make them likely to benefit from the surgery, the government announced yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Bid For PeopleSoft Delayed
description: The $7.25 billion hostile offer made by the Oracle Corporation to acquire PeopleSoft Inc. might not clear an antitrust investigation by the Justice Department until November, Oracle's executive vice president, Chuck Phillips, said yesterday. Oracle, one of the world's largest software makers, is still compiling information about the software industry and the markets it operates in, which the Justice Department has requested as part of its investigation, Mr. Phillips said. The department will have 30 days, he said, to review the information once it is submitted. The delay may mean that Oracle will have to extend its bid. On Friday, the company extended the deadline to Sept. 19 for PeopleSoft investors to decide whether to accept Oracle's offer to buy their shares for $19.50 each. Oracle shares fell three cents, to $12.12, while PeopleSoft rose eight cents, to $16.99, both on the Nasdaq.

title: Striking Back at Sellers Of Child Pornography
description: Q. I was very offended to receive junk e-mail inviting me to purchase child pornography. Is there anything I can do beyond complaining to my network administrator?

title: World Coffee Exports Rise
description: A surge in Brazilian exports lifted global coffee exports by 3.6 percent in the 12 months ended June 30, the International Coffee Organization said yesterday.

title: ALLEGHENY TO PAY $114 MILLION TO BLACK HILLS
description: Allegheny Energy Inc., a Maryland utility owner that is leaving the business of energy trading, agreed to pay $114 million to end a 15-year contract to buy power in Nevada from the Black Hills Corporation. The agreement allows Allegheny, based in Hagerstown, Md., to avoid paying $33 million a year to Black Hills, a utility owner and power producer based in Rapid City, S.D., through 2018, an Allegheny spokeswoman, Janice Lantz, said. The contract was for electricity from a plant near Las Vegas that went into service in January. The accord ''substantially achieves our goal of exiting the Western energy markets,'' Ms. Lantz said.

title: To Stow Plows, Trowels and Shovels
description: SUMMER is nearing its end, so why not get out of that hammock and clean up the yard? For most people, there are better ways of organizing and storing garden tools than tossing them onto the basement floor. New racks are perfect for the basement and the garage, and storage sheds come in many sizes and in weatherproof materials. You can also pack everything for a day's work into a special cart that has room for fertilizer, to spare your lower back.

title: Mars Approaches
description: We are so used to the routine circularity of our astronomical lives -- the Moon revolving around us as we spin our way around the Sun -- that we forget what a universe of singularities this really is. Some things happen every day, like sunrise and sunset, some only once a year, like annual meteor showers, and some occur on more elliptical schedules, like the return of certain comets. And then there are the rare conjunctions of heavenly bodies that would be starkly visible to us if we lived without artificial light, but that most of us have to admire intellectually instead. A case in point is the present proximity of Mars.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Backs Head Scarves
description: The Constitutional Court, Germany's highest, ruled that a Muslim shop assistant of Turkish origin was wrongly laid off by her employers for expressing her desire to wear a head scarf at work. The woman, who had worked for more than 10 years in a department store in Schlchtern, near Frankfurt, was dismissed when she announced that she would wear a head scarf as an expression of religious freedom. title: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Tests On Colas

Officials from Pepsi and Coca-Cola said they felt the new tests had vindicated their stance that the sodas sold in India were as safe as those sold elsewhere in the world. Sanjiv Gupta, president of Coca-Cola India, above, expressed his satisfaction with the news. Sales of soft drinks produced by both companies have dropped markedly since the environmental group released its tests this month. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Soft Drinks Cleared
description: India's government said tests of samples of Coca-Cola and PepsiCo products showed that they conformed to safety standards. The health minister, Sushma Swaraj, told Parliament that tests were conducted by state-run laboratories on 12 beverage samples. ''They were well within the safety limits prescribed for packaged drinking water at present,'' Ms. Swaraj said. The government ordered the tests after a group called the Center for Science and Environment charged that the drinks contained pesticide residue. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Seattle
description: IT'S a brilliantly clear day and you are walking along the waterfront, the faint scent of salt in the air. A string of verdant islands is off in the distance. Sailboats and pleasure craft glide by, sunlight bouncing off their hulls as they make their way through the choppy waters. You turn your face toward the summer sun, taking in its warmth, and start looking for a place to grab a cold beer. Wait. Could this be Seattle -- the land of constant cloud cover, the city where the weather is so wet and so chilly that it's a shock the locals aren't permanently shrouded in anoraks? But when the skies break -- as they do more often than legend would have it -- Seattle reveals itself as one of the most beautiful cities in the country. It's also a city of serious foodies, passionate coffee drinkers, innovative cultural institutions like the Seattle Opera (with its widely praised new auditorium), as well as unexpected delights, like the scene on a recent evening of a group of couples dancing outside a Fifth Avenue restaurant as a romantic ballad performed by the restaurant's singer drifted out on to the sidewalk. STUART EMMRICH

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: HELICOPTER NOT FOUND An air and sea search failed to locate a helicopter ferrying the governor and other officials of the Sakhalin region in Russia's Far East. The helicopter disappeared on Wednesday after taking off from an airfield on the Kamchatka Peninsula and heading toward the Kurile Islands. Seventeen aircraft and 40 ships searched a wide swath of the peninsula's rugged, volcanic tip and the waters around it. Konstantin Pulikovsky, the presidential envoy in the region, said the helicopter's crew violated safety procedures, the official Russian information agency reported. Among other things, he said, no passenger manifest was submitted. As a result, officials still do not know how many were aboard, though they believe there may have been as many as 21, including the governor, Igor P. Farkhutdinov.    Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: In the Cross Hairs
description: There were several warning signs that the United Nations could soon be in the cross hairs of the forces battling the American-led coalition in Iraq. In early hours of August 10, a small band of unknown assailants in a white and orange taxi zoomed past a United Nations compound in the northern Iraq city of Mosul and shot at the Iraqi security guards. A short time later a rocket-propelled grenade flew over a second U.N. site in the city. A patrol from the Second Brigade Combat Team of the 101st Airborne Division searched the building across the street from that U.N. facility but found no sign of the attackers.

Other Siemens research centers are in China, Denmark, Germany and the United States. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Indictments In Cuban Plane Downing
description: A federal grand jury in Miami indicted two pilots and a general in the Cuban Air Force on charges of murder and conspiracy in the 1996 downing of two civilian planes operated by Brothers to the Rescue, a Cuban exile group that was making mercy flights in search of rafters fleeing Cuba. All four men aboard the two planes were killed over international waters. Rubn Martnez Puente, then head of the Cuban Air Force, and the pilots, Lorenzo Alberto Prez-Prez and Francisco Prez-Prez, were each charged in the deaths of Armando Alejandre Jr., Carlos Costa, Mario de la Pea and Pablo Morales. The indicted men remain in Cuba. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Coke Signs Deal With N.B.A. Rookie

title: PRINCIPAL FINANCIAL IS BUYING 68% STAKE IN MW POST
description: The Principal Financial Group, a seller of 401(k) retirement plans, said yesterday that its asset management unit planned to acquire a majority stake in the MW Post Advisory Group for about $100 million in cash. The management unit, Principal Global Investors, will buy a 68 percent stake in MW Post. The transaction includes acquiring a 45 percent stake in MW Post from the closely held Metropolitan West Financial, a Principal Global spokeswoman said. The purchase allows Principal Global to offer more high-yield fixed-income investments to its clients, Principal Global said. MW Post, founded in 1992, has $3.4 billion in assets under management.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ferry Service May Expand
description: A ferry operator said yesterday that it planned to take over the East River routes of another operator, including stops on the Upper East Side, even though the current operator has said it is abandoning the routes because there are too few customers. The interested operator, New York Water Taxi, wants to take over the routes of New York Waterway, which announced on Aug. 15 that it would abandon certain stops on Sept. 1. The stops are at East 90th Street, East 34th Street and Pier 11 in Manhattan, and Hunters Point in Queens. New York Water Taxi said it applied for ferry landing slots with the Department of Transportation yesterday and would file with the the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey today. New York Waterway has estimated that fewer than 2 percent of its 65,000 daily riders use the East River service. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

His illness was diagnosed as meningitis and he was hospitalized for four days in early August. The state Department of Health and Senior Services said the man was recovering at home. description: A retired State Superior Court judge, already facing child pornography charges in state court, surrendered to the federal authorities yesterday on additional charges that he traveled abroad to have sex with a minor. The former judge, Stephen W. Thompson, 57, was charged with two felonies carrying total penalties of 25 years in prison. Federal prosecutors say a videotape shows Mr. Thompson having sex with a boy between 13 and 16 years old in Russia. The tape was seized in April as part of a raid on Mr. Thompson's home that state prosecutors said yielded child pornography. Mr. Thompson has pleaded not guilty to state charges and had been free on his own recognizance until his surrender to the federal authorities. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Good Supply Of Flu Vaccine
description: Enough influenza vaccine will be available for everyone who wants it this flu season, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. As a result, health care workers, the elderly and people with chronic medical disorders will no longer have priority for the shots. In recent years, a shortage of the vaccine prompted the agency to set up a vaccination schedule giving priority to those high-risk groups. The flu season typically begins in October or November. Each year, more than 36,000 people in the United States die from influenza infections, and 114,000 more are hospitalized. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Blackout Is Just Latest Woe For a Troubled Ohio Utility

That it has been idle for more than a year, though, makes it a testament to something else, according to former employees and the federal regulators who ordered it shut down.

title: A Martial Artist in Search of a Talisman

Mr. Chan now has his Hollywood career (a third ''Rush Hour'' is already in the works), aimed at an international English-language audience, and his Hong Kong career, producing Chinese-language films for the Asian market (like ''The Accidental Spy'' in 2001).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Sales To Go On
description: The engineering company ABB Ltd. said yesterday that it would push ahead with a plan to sell units and would not be hindered by an agreement to delay its $1.3 billion settlement of asbestos claims. ''Talks with potential buyers are going forward,'' Wolfram Eberhardt, a spokesman for ABB, said. ABB, based in Zurich, agreed to an order in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia delaying the creation of a trust to compensate victims until appeals by settlement opponents are concluded. The Swiss company is counting on the settlement to clear the way for the sale of an oil, gas and petrochemicals unit that is the target of some asbestos lawsuits. ABB needs proceeds from such sales to reduce debt that rose to $8.3 billion last quarter. A spokesman, Thomas Schmidt, said the court had put the appeal on a ''fast track'' to speed the process.

title: Freedom for Kathy Boudin
description: A chapter in the history of American radicalism apparently closed this week when New York State decided to grant parole to Kathy Boudin. Ms. Boudin was convicted in connection with a 1981 robbery of a Brink's truck that left two policemen and a Brink's guard dead. The parole board was correct in ruling that after 22 years as a model prisoner, Ms. Boudin had paid her debt to society. But it is important to remember just how great that debt was.

title: Man With a Mission: Saving Beauty, Saving Grace
description: THINKING of paving paradise and putting up a parking lot? If paradise includes an edifice over the age of 75, you may catch an irritable earful, and possibly worse, from David Goldfarb, a white-bearded lawyer who, at 55, blithely confesses to looking older than chronology deems him. Which perhaps accounts for his identification with old-timers, whether human (his specialty is elder law) or architectural (his voluntary avocation is landmark preservation). And yes, he resorts to litigation if prodded; can't expect ramshackle bungalows and Victorians to defend themselves.
