title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swatch Profit Falls
description: The world's largest watch maker, the Swatch Group, said yesterday that a drop in tourism worldwide, sluggish consumer spending and the continued strength of the Swiss franc had cut its income by almost 10 percent in the first half of the year. But the chief executive, Nicholas Hayek Jr., said strong sales over the summer had given him an optimistic outlook for the rest of the year. Swatch, which sells the Omega and Tissot brands along with the plastic Swatch watch, said net income was 186 million Swiss francs ($137 million) for the first half of the year, down from 206 million Swiss francs a year earlier. Sales for the first six months fell 6.6 percent, to 1.82 billion francs.

title: The Season De l'Amour
description: In the summer of 1984, I fell in love. I was 16 years old, but the object of my affection was no boy, fickle, impermanent, undeserving of my sleepless nights. That July I broke my heart and gave both halves to the city of Paris. I wish I could claim that I was a precocious old soul who understood even then that a city was a worthy beau and not a mere substitute for one, but that would be stretching the truth. I was a teenage girl, a growing mass of longing, and Paris was accommodating. That city took my awkward limbs and gave them the feeling of being at ease.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Ousted Candidate Reinstated
description: City Councilman Allan W. Jennings Jr. won a victory in court yesterday when his name was ordered reinstated on the Democratic Party primary ballot. He will face Yvonne Reddick, the district manager of Community Board 12 in Jamaica, in the Sept. 9 primary. Ms. Reddick is the candidate endorsed by the Queens Democratic Party, which Mr. Jennings has accused of instigating his removal from the ballot. Party officials deny the charge. The unanimous decision yesterday by a five-judge panel of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court reversed a ruling last week. The trial judge's decision cited irregularities in nominating petitions for Mr. Jennings, a first-term Democrat from Queens. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Jennings said he felt ''personally vindicated.'' He has charged that Queens party leaders punished him for his vote against the property tax increase that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council adopted last fall. Michael Reich, the Queens party's executive secretary, said Democratic leaders had not yet decided whether to appeal. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: LAGGING PUBLIC SCHOOLS LISTED The State Education Department yesterday listed 149 public elementary, middle and high schools, some in such affluent towns as West Hartford and Westport, that do not meet federal standards for basic subjects like reading and mathematics. More than half of the schools on the list are in poor urban areas. A complete list of the schools can be found at www.state.ct.us/sde. Under the federal No Child Left Behind law, 65 percent of students must meet minimum standards in math, and 57 percent must meet minimum standards in reading. To meet these goals by 2014, the state will administer the Connecticut Mastery Tests in grades three through eight beginning in 2006. It is now administered in only half those grades. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES FOR CHILDREN The Consumer Federation of America and the Natural Trails and Waters Coalition have urged the federal government to ban the sale of adult-size all-terrain vehicles for use by children. Fines should be imposed on dealers of the vehicles who violate the ban, the groups said. In addition, the groups called on the states to pass laws that would set a minimum age requirement for the vehicles and for guidelines on protective gear, including helmets. Injuries on the largest of the vehicles  those with engines over 400 cubic centimeters  increased, to more than 24,000 in 2001 from fewer than 4,000 in 1997, the groups said. (NYT)

title: KRISPY KREME REPORTS 47% INCREASE IN QUARTERLY PROFIT
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 47 percent after it opened more stores and operating costs fell as a share of sales. Net income in the quarter, which ended Aug. 3, climbed to $13 million, or 21 cents a share, from $8.86 million, or 15 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales increased 41 percent, to $161.8 million from $114.6 million. Sales at shops open at least a year increased 16 percent. Those sales exclude results from new and closed outlets.

title: Injustice in Guantnamo

The Defense Department should heed the calls of respected voices in the legal community, including that of the American Bar Association, and develop fairer procedures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REISS, FRANK RONALD
description: REISS--Frank Ronald. Died on Wednesday, August 20, 2003, at Morris Hill Elder Care Center in Morristown. He was 75. Born in West Orange, he lived in Warren Center, PA, before he moved to Rockaway Township in 1990. He served in the Army during World War II. He was the executive director of the YMCA in Johnson City, NY, for many years before retiring in 1994. After moving to Rockaway, he worked for Wells Fargo in Parsippany. He was an actor who starred on Broadway in ''Life with Father'' and also worked for CBS in New York City. He was also a soap opera star along with working directly under Hugh Hefner of ''Playboy''. Ronald was many great things, including a great father and grandfather, according to his family. He is survived by his daughters, Debra Webb of Madison, Rachel Villarreal of Montville, and Alessandra Lipari of Clifton; a son, Ethan of Rockaway Township; ten grandchildren; and his former wife, Sandra Striss of Binghampton, NY. Funeral services will be held Friday, August, 22, at 11 A.M. at the Norman Dean Home for Services, 16 Righter Ave., Denville, New Jersey, 978-627-1880, www.normandean.com. Friends may visit with the family from 9:30 A.M. until time of services.

His death out of time leaves a void in the lives of his producing partners, colleagues and friends as we contemplate a world without his unique personality. We are filled with sadness for Cricket, Cat and Sailor. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Jiranek and Hooper families. Anne Squadron & Eric Krebs

Henderson and Emilie Bourne Paschal, and by six grandchildren. Mrs. Paschal was the daughter of Edward Motley Weld and Barbara Merriman Weld. title: World Briefing | United Nations: Vote On Libya Delayed
description: The Security Council agreed to postpone a vote on a British resolution that would lift sanctions imposed on Libya for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, diplomats said. The delay, negotiated by Britain and France, allows France time to seek more compensation from Libya for the 170 people killed in the 1989 bombing of a French plane over Niger. In a 1999 settlement, Libya agreed to pay about $33 million in compensation for the flight. In its Lockerbie settlement, Libya has agreed to pay $2.7 billion. The Security Council vote is now expected next week. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: On a Remote Coast, A Gravel Path Leads Into the Present
description: IN the tiny seafaring towns on the coast of Labrador, in far northeastern Canada, the inexorable push toward the fall equinox is taking the daylight in big gulps now. The sun that stayed overhead from 5 a.m. to nearly 10 p.m. in June is disappearing by a little after 8, and everyone knows what's ahead as summer fades: the chill that creeps in during September and stays through May, the enclosing darkness. People who live this far north are used to adapting. But since last fall they have something new to help them cope: a road out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EWEN, WILLIAM H.
description: EWEN--William H., 90, beloved husband of Cathleen E. (Ryan) Ewen, of Westerly, RI died at the Westerly Hospital, August 19, 2003. Mr. Ewen was born in Yonkers, NY. Son of the late William C. and Marjorie Ewen. He was raised in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. He was a 1935 graduate of New York University. He was the corporate director of advertising for the Borden Company and managed Borden's first national radio program and its first TV advertising. In 1962, he revived Borden's famous trade character, Elsie the cow. He was Chairman of the audit bureau of circulations, 196567. He later helped established the National Advertising Review Board and was its first Executive Director. He retired to Westerly, RI in 1976. He was a life member of the Steamship Historical Society of America and held several offices, including President. He had been a founder and President of the Hastings-onHudson, NY Historical Society and President of the Westerly RI Historical Society. He was on the board and served as treasurer of Scenic Hudson Inc. He authored the book ''Days of the Steamboats'' and wrote numerous articles on maritime history, as well as advertising and marketing. He was also an experienced speaker and presenter. In addition to his wife, he is also survived by his son and daughter-in-law, William H. Ewen Jr. and Susan Ewen of Providence, RI. One daughter and son-in-law Barbara E. Ewen and Theodore Lyszczarz of Concord, MA. Two granddaughters, Chrystena Ewen of Derry, NH and Amy Ewen of Providence, RI. Funeral services will be held in the Gaffney-Dolan Funeral Home, 59 Spruce St, Westerly, RI, Saturday at 1:00PM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to be made to the Steamship Historical Society, 300 Ray Drive, #

He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | Washington: All-Terrain Vehicles For Children
description: The Consumer Federation of America and the Natural Trails and Waters Coalition have urged the federal government to ban the sale of adult-size all-terrain vehicles for use by children. Fines should be imposed on dealers of the vehicles who violate the ban, the groups said. In addition, the groups called on the states to pass laws that would set a minimum age requirement for the vehicles and for guidelines on protective gear, including helmets. Injuries on the largest of the vehicles -- those with engines over 400 cubic centimeters -- increased, to more than 24,000 in 2001 from fewer than 4,000 in 1997, the groups said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, JULIUS OCHS
description: ADLER--Julius Ochs, 78, died on August 18, 2003 after a long illness. Mr. Adler is survived by his wife, Deirdre Spencer Adler, a son, Douglas O. Adler, two daughters, Anne A. Tarbell and Mary B. Malhotra, as well as an aunt, two sisters, three step children, 13 grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Mr. Adler was the son of Barbara Stettheimer Adler and Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President, General Manager and Treasurer of The New York Times from 1914 to 1955. From 1977 until 1992, Mr. Adler and his wife owned and operated the Canterbury Bookstore in Manhattan. Earlier in his professional career, Mr. Adler was affiliated with Interpublic, the New York Mets and The New York Times. Mr. Adler served in the United States Air Corps during WWII. He attended Princeton University. Mr. Adler's funeral will be private. Donations in his memory can be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Power Plant Bidding
description: An independent board of directors of Drax, England's largest coal plant, will decide today whether to accept a buyout offer from International Power or Goldman Sachs. International Power, an energy company based in London, offered to buy the plant for 130 million ($205 million). The offer includes paying 64 pence for each pound of its senior debt. Goldman is offering one pence less on the pound for the debt. But Goldman's offer does not include a 2.5 million a year management fee that International Power plans to charge. The former owner of Drax, AES, walked away from the plant after debt holders refused to accept its restructuring plan. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: License Renewal Goes Online
description: The Department of Motor Vehicles is using the Internet to help reduce one of the legendary inconveniences of state government: waiting in a long line to renew a driver's license. Registration renewal and other routine chores are already done online. The agency has adapted its Web site to allow drivers' licenses to be renewed at www.nysdmv.com/licrenew/default.html. The fee, payable by credit card, is $45, the same fee paid by those who wait in line. An eye test is necessary to complete the renewal, which takes about four to six weeks to be mailed to the driver. The site, available now, allows a home computer to print a receipt that can be used as a temporary license. There are limitations: drivers cannot renew if their home address or other important information has changed. Stacy Albin (NYT)

Humana, based in Louisville, Ky., won a $2.1 billion contract in the south, the Pentagon said. The west region was won by the closely held TriWest Healthcare Alliance for $2.1 billion. Humana, the biggest participant in Tricare, and Aetna lost a joint bid for the north region.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: OUSTED CANDIDATE REINSTATED City Councilman Allan W. Jennings Jr. won a victory in court yesterday when his name was ordered reinstated on the Democratic Party primary ballot. He will face Yvonne Reddick, the district manager of Community Board 12 in Jamaica, in the Sept. 9 primary. Ms. Reddick is the candidate endorsed by the Queens Democratic Party, which Mr. Jennings has accused of instigating his removal from the ballot. Party officials deny the charge. The unanimous decision yesterday by a five-judge panel of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court reversed a ruling last week. The trial judge's decision cited irregularities in nominating petitions for Mr. Jennings, a first-term Democrat from Queens. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Jennings said he felt "personally vindicated." He has charged that Queens party leaders punished him for his vote against the property tax increase that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council adopted last fall. Michael Reich, the Queens party's executive secretary, said Democratic leaders had not yet decided whether to appeal.

title: The Bill of Rights Belongs in North Carolina

This theft 138 years ago has set off a legal battle between the state of North Carolina and the private collectors who had bought the document. It is unlikely that the Ohio soldier was aware of the price the people of North Carolina had paid for their claim to the document.

title: My Lesson From Mr. Olympia
description: In the early 60's, I washed out of minor-league baseball and took up writing. By the late 60's, I had gained 50 pounds, so I went on an obsessive diet and lost it all. Friends asked if I had an incurable disease. Finally, in the 70's I found a dirty iron gym filled with raucous bodybuilders and began to lift weights to regain some muscle tone. The guys in the gym grunted, sweated, cursed and shouted at one another. I loved the camaraderie of the place; it reminded me of a baseball clubhouse. I also loved the physical exercise of lifting heavy weights, the feeling of strength it gave me, the sense of control over my body, which was quickly becoming more muscular.

The bid, $26 a share, is 10 percent more than Cima's closing price Wednesday and tops AaiPharma's offer earlier this month of $23.61 a share in stock. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Power Failure Affects Ebay Service
description: A power failure in eBay's Web hosting center crippled the Web auction service for nearly three hours, the company confirmed. The failure on Wednesday night struck a Qwest Communications center in Santa Clara, Calif., that serves as a host for many of eBay's Web servers, said an eBay spokesman, Kevin Pursglove. While the Qwest problem lasted only 10 minutes, eBay technicians were forced to shut down and reboot their local systems, making the company's Web site inaccessible from 8:55 p.m. to 11:45 p.m. EBay said it would credit listing fees for sellers affected by the failure and would extend their listing time for an additional 24 hours. The company also will reimburse the ''10 cents for 10 days'' fee for auctions that were active during the power failure. In the past, eBay has experienced failures that crippled the site for hours at a time. In 1999, the company suffered a number of problems that sometimes made the site inaccessible for nearly a day. Since then, the company has strengthened its back-end systems to prevent prolonged power failures.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New West Nile Case
description: State health officials said yesterday that the second human case of West Nile virus in New Jersey this year had been reported. They said a 56-year-old Morris County man, whose name was not released, had visited Colorado, which has had an outbreak of the virus; he started showing symptoms on July 27, two days after returning from a weeklong trip to Boulder. His illness was diagnosed as meningitis and he was hospitalized for four days in early August. The state Department of Health and Senior Services said the man was recovering at home. On Monday, New York health officials reported that an 86-year-old Bronx woman was the first reported human case in New York State this year. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURNION, MONSIGNOR PHILIP J.
description: MURNION--Monsignor Philip J. On August 19, 2003. Beloved son of the late Frances and the late William Murnion. Loving brother of William and Deborah Murnion, Rose Mary and Victor Gerdes and John and Kathleen Murnion. He was a dedicated priest of the Archdiocese of New York and founder and Director of the National Pastoral Life Center. An inspiration to the Church in America during the 40 years of his priesthood. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Mad. Ave, 81 St, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Friday at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, (Mott St, between Houston and Prince) commencing 4 PM with a prayer vigil 7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 AM at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: National Pastoral Life Center, 18 Bleecker St, New York, New York 10012.

title: GENERAL MOTORS EXPECTS HUGHES SALE TO BE APPROVED
description: The General Motors Corporation, which is raising cash for its pension plans, said it expected shareholders to approve the $3.8 billion sale of its stake in Hughes Electronics to the News Corporation by early October. The Securities and Exchange Commission declared the proxy statement for the transaction effective Thursday, clearing the way for the vote, the company said. The News Corporation agreed in April to buy a controlling 34 percent stake in Hughes and its DirecTV satellite television service for $6.6 billion. General Motors owns 19.8 percent of Hughes's tracking stock.

title: U.S. Expects Informal Direct Talks With North Korea
description: The Bush administration will not offer any specific economic or diplomatic rewards to North Korea to abandon its nuclear arms program but will not stop other countries from making such offers, administration officials said today as they prepared for a new round of talks with North Korea.

title: Owners of Devils Complete Purchase
description: John McMullen, the former owner of the Devils, said the team's majority owners yesterday fulfilled their obligation to him on the final payment of the purchase of the team. But he refused to say if he had been paid in full.

title: Missing Boy, 4, Found Through Amber Alert
description: New Jersey's Amber Alert system flashed into action at 7 a.m. today, with radio stations and electronic message boards on highways across the state spreading word of the apparent kidnapping of a 4-year-old boy here by his baby sitter.

title: A Lesson in Giving
description: It was an unforgivingly hot day, and I was leaving the village where I lived in northeastern Burkina Faso, which meant an 11-mile bike ride to the nearest paved road. It was April, and I was serving as a Peace Corps volunteer in this small, land-locked country in West Africa. I set off on my Trek 800 mountain bike, dreaming of the distant town where I could eat the pizza I had been craving for a month, when I hit a bump in the road. When I landed, my pedals spun around wildly with no resistance. I pedaled furiously, but like a guinea pig in a wheel, I was going nowhere.

title: The Illusions Of Progress
description: ''Great and hopeful change is coming to the Middle East,'' President Bush declared on June 4, as he stood with the Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, and Mr. Sharon's Palestinian counterpart, Mahmoud Abbas. Appearing at a summit meeting in Aqaba, Jordan, they presented a picture of shared determination to achieve lasting peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWAN, WILLIAM E.
description: SWAN--William E. The Board of Directors and senior management of the Troy Financial Corporation express their profound sadness at the unexpected loss of Bill Swan. The Troy Savings Bank community will miss his energy and his wisdom. We will strive to build on his extraordinary values and vision. Daniel J. Hogarty, Jr., Chairman, President, CEO Board of Directors Troy Financial Corp.

title: 2-Truck Crash on Turnpike Kills Driver and Snarls Traffic
description: A car-carrying truck rear-ended a fuel tanker on the New Jersey Turnpike this afternoon, killing one person, spilling more than 2,000 gallons of diesel fuel and forcing the shutdown of a section of the state's most heavily traveled highway for several hours.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: WPP'S Profit Falls
description: WPP Group, the world's third-largest advertising concern, said pretax profit fell 11.6 percent, to 153.6 million ($241 million), in the first half of 2003 from the period a year earlier. Sales were down 1.6 percent, to 8.64 billion ($13.6 billion). The company, which beat Publicis of France in a bidding war for the British company Cordiant earlier this year, said that it expected a rebound in advertising revenue in 2004. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Ex-Priest Dies After an Attack in Prison
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 - John J. Geoghan, the defrocked priest at the center of the clergy sexual abuse scandal here, died this afternoon after being attacked at a Massachusetts state prison, a spokesman for the state Department of Corrections said. Mr. Geoghan, 68, was involved in a dispute with the inmate at the prison in Shirley, Mass., shortly after noon, the spokesman said. He was taken to Leominster Hospital, where he died. Mr. Geoghan was serving a 9-to-10 year sentence for indecent assault and battery. He was found guilty last January of sliding his hands down a boy's bathing suit in 1991 at a suburban pool.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Telecom Profit
description: Royal KPN, a leading Dutch telecommunications company, said it earned 183 million euros ($200 million) in the second quarter, as cost cuts and debt repayments helped it reverse a loss of 9.27 billion euros in the period a year earlier. KPN has cut its staff and its debt by one-third since the year-earlier period, when it wrote down the value of mobile-phone licenses and assets in Germany and Belgium. Excluding one-time items in both periods, net income was 192 million euros, in contrast to a loss of 79 million euros. KPN also raised its forecast for income this year.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Iran Protests Ex-Envoy's Arrest
description: A spokesman for the Iranian Foreign Ministry, Hamidreza Assefi, reacted angrily to the arrest of a former diplomat, Hadi Soleimanpour, in Britain, saying it was politically motivated and carried out under the influence of Zionists. Mr. Soleimanpour, who was ordered into custody by a London court to face possible extradition to Argentina, was the Iranian ambassador to Argentina at the time of a 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires that killed 85 people. He is one of several Iranian government officials sought by Argentina for allegedly helping to carry out the bombing. Mr. Assefi said that the case lacked judicial basis and that Iran was going to hold talks with Britain over the arrest. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: BUSH ORDERS MOVE TO FREEZE ASSETS OF HAMAS CHARITIES
description: President Bush ordered the Treasury Department today to block and freeze the assets of six top leaders of the militant Palestinian group Hamas and five charities based outside the United States that administration officials said help finance Hamas.

title: Texas Governor Pardons 35 Arrested in Tainted Sting
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas yesterday pardoned 35 people, 31 of them black, who were arrested in 1999 in a drug sting based solely on the word of an undercover agent who has since been indicted on perjury charges.

title: Fouling the Air
description: In defiance of Congress, the courts and the requirements of public health, the administration is on the verge of effectively repealing a key section of the Clean Air Act. According to a report yesterday in The Times, the Environmental Protection Agency plans to issue a final rule next week that would allow thousands of industrial sites, including hundreds of old coal-fired power plants, to make major upgrades without installing new pollution controls, as currently required by law. Eliot Spitzer, New York's attorney general, has rightly vowed to sue the moment the rule becomes final. We are eager to hear Gov. Michael Leavitt of Utah, President Bush's nominee to run the E.P.A., try to defend this decision when he comes up for confirmation in September -- especially in light of his own clean-air director's vigorous opposition to the change.

title: Council Seeks To Toughen Gun Controls
description: In the aftermath of the shooting last month of Councilman James E. Davis, the City Council is pushing ahead with several changes in New York City's gun-control laws that would make the laws, already among the toughest in the nation, more restrictive.

title: Six Groups Said to Be Monitored In U.S. for Possible Qaeda Links
description: American law enforcement officials are monitoring the activities of at least six groups in the United States they suspect are linked to Al Qaeda, senior government officials in the United States and Europe said this week.

title: Fearing PC Havoc, Gumshoes Hunt Down a Virus
description: It is common wisdom in the computer security world that the criminals are separated from their pursuers by only a few lines of cleverly written software.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the fatal shooting of a 4-year-old girl and a man in East Orange, N.J., misstated the girl's surname. She was Naviana Hyppolite, not Gagliano.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Thursday misstated the year when California approved Proposition 13. It was 1978.

title: Occupational choices : Tuscany lures expats with a passion for wine
description: In Tuscany, Italy's premier wine-producing region, a number of non-Italians have begun to make a name for themselves as producers of quality wines especially in the Chianti area.

title: At Gaza Funeral, Arab Anger Boils and Israel Tightens Checkpoints
description: Thousands of enraged Palestinians at the funeral here of a slain Hamas official vowed today to take sweeping revenge against Israel, which signaled that it would continue to hunt down the leaders of militant groups.

title: Deputy Security Official Leaving Post
description: The White House announced today that the No. 2 official at the Department of Homeland Security, Deputy Secretary Gordon England, would return to his previous job as Navy secretary, only seven months after he was confirmed to the domestic security post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JIRANEK, DAVID
description: JIRANEK--David. It is with much sadness that we announce the death of David Jiranek, 45, who passed away Sunday, August 17. He was a Broadway producer, a writer, a photographer, a philanthropist and a family man. His passing will be deeply felt in the New York theater and in Old Greenwich, CT, where he and his family made their home. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Cricket Hooper Jiranek and their two daughters, Cat and Sailor, and an extended family that includes his mother Jen Jiranek and four half brothers: Theodore ''Teke'' Hoffman, R. Todd Hoffman, Robert H. Jiranek and James H. Jiranek.

title: Some Optimism From Intel Stirs Broader Hopes
description: Intel raised sales projections for the third quarter yesterday by about 5 percent, giving the stock market a momentary lift and providing new evidence for those arguing that the economy is picking up speed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, SHIRLEY
description: SIEGEL -- Shirley. Beloved aunt of Paul, devoted psychotherapist. Condolences to all her friends, colleagues and patients. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 W 76 St, Sunday, August 24, 11:15AM. All are welcome to attend. Burial to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Last Respects Are Paid to Head of U.N. Mission in Iraq
description: United Nations officials today paid their final respects to Sergio Vieira de Mello, who headed their mission in Iraq, as his body was flown out of the country to Brazil for burial.

title: Ohio State Suspends Clarett; Number of Games Unknown
description: Running back Maurice Clarett's future at Ohio State took another twist yesterday, as the university suspended him for multiple games this season but said he could resume practicing with the football team as soon as tomorrow.

title: First, Terrible News. Then a Call From Iraq Brings Joy.
description: Days near the 19th of the month have not always been kind to Marilyn Manuel and her family. Her father died on a 19th, and one of her brothers was killed in a hunting accident on Nov. 20, 2001. And what seemed perhaps the unkindest 19th of all came on Tuesday, when her family in Queens was told that she was among the 23 people killed when a truck bomb exploded outside the United Nations compound in Baghdad.

title: Deafness As Metaphor, Not Gimmick
description: Frank Datolla, a deaf friend of mine, attended a kindergarten graduation in which the students, all of them able to hear, had been taught a little American Sign Language so that they could sign a song about shapes. Imagine his shock then when these adorable petunias got to the verse about triangles and formed, with graceful rhythm and practiced fingers, not the sign for triangle but the sign for vagina.

title: AES RECEIVES $890 MILLION IN FINANCING FOR POWER PLANT
description: The AES Corporation, which sells electricity in 28 countries, completed $890 million in financing for a power plant in Cartagena, Spain. The 1,200-megawatt plant will open in early 2006, AES said. Lenders will not have recourse to AES in the event of a default, a spokeswoman, Sandra Ross, said. The plant will burn natural gas imported in liquid form through a terminal in Cartagena, which is on the Mediterranean coast. AES is based in Arlington, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIGA, EMILIE VERONICA
description: PIGA--Emilie Veronica, on August 22, 2003, of Ringwood, NJ. Beloved wife of Stephen M., dear mother of Mrs. Peter Margaret Bednarz, devoted grandmother of Jessica and Adam. A funeral service will be celebrated, 11 AM, Tuesday, at St. Catherine's R.C. Church in Ringwood. Interment will follow at Our Lady of Magnificat Cemetery, Kinnelon, NJ. Visiting hours will be Sunday 7-9PM and Monday 2-4 and 7-9PM, at the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, 781 Newark Pompton Turnpike, at Route 23, in Pompton Plains, NJ.

title: The Rural Life; Garden of Weeds
description: I don't remember when I gave up. Perhaps I still haven't. But so far, this goes down as the summer when I grew no vegetables. The potatoes volunteered, and so did some garlic and chives and a single cornstalk. Last year's radishes did all they could. The blueberries set fruit copiously, but all they ask is acidity and mulch. In mid-May I spent two weeks preparing the soil, creating a fine seedbed in the upper garden and tilling the lower one. Then the deluge came. I discovered that I'm a fair-weather gardener. I want to plant my garden seeds in rows, not runnels.

title: Skipper Is Arrested After 2 Die In Boat Crash
description: Two people were killed when the boat on which they were guests slammed into a stone jetty off the North Fork of Long Island early yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: Enqvist Finds Game in Time for Open
description: If any seeded player in the United States Open was hoping to play a journeyman qualifier in the first round, then drawing Thomas Enqvist will be a profound disappointment.

title: Religion Journal; Buddhist Academy Stirs Hope of Revival in Hawaii
description: Stephanie Buckland is so displeased with her students at the Pacific Buddhist Academy that she has sent them back outside the classroom to enter it again -- the right way.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: COKE EXECUTIVE RESIGNS The chief executive of Coca-Cola HBC, Irial Finan, who helped the company return to profit after a costly expansion into Eastern Europe, has resigned, the company said, citing personal reasons. Mr. Finan, 46, took over as chief executive in May 2001 after the founding Leventis family, which started the business in Nigeria 50 years ago, sought one of its longtime managers for the post. Mr. Finan has spent more than 22 years at the company, which is based in Athens. Doros Constantinou, who was HBC's chief financial officer until three years ago, will return to the company to succeed Mr. Finan, the company said.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, HERBERT R.
description: SILVERMAN--Herbert R. The Boards of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of Herbert R. Silverman, a cherished friend, benefactor and Life Trustee of the Medical Center and New York University. Mr. Silverman's son, Henry R. Silverman, Chairman, President, and CEO of Cendant Corporation, also serves on our board. A distinguished attorney and pioneer in the commercial finance industry, Herbert Silverman was a graduate of NYU School of Commerce. He went on to serve the University as founder and first president of the NYU Club, president of the NYU Alumni Federation, professor of finance and honorary retired Vice Chairman of the NYU Board of Trustees. Mr. Silverman was a man who touched the lives of many people, and he will be deeply missed by all who knew him. We send our deepest condolences to our friend and colleague, Henry, and the Siverman family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman, Boards of Trustees NYU School of Medicine Foundation NYU Hospitals Center Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean, NYU School of Medicine CEO, NYU Hospitals Center Theresa A. Bischoff President, NYU Hospitals Center

description: Chief Justice Roy Moore was suspended from the bench today for defying a federal court order to remove a 5,280-pound Ten Commandments monument he had installed in the Alabama Supreme Court building.

title: Attacker Is Fatally Stabbed
description: A 25-year-old man who was forced into a car at knifepoint stabbed one of his three attackers to death yesterday, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, was forced into a Toyota Camry about 3 p.m. at West 173rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue. He was stabbed in the back but managed to take the knife and stab one attacker, identified by the police as Alexander Hernandez, 18, before fleeing the car. The men drove Mr. Hernandez to Montefiore Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead. The 25-year-old man was taken to Columbia-Presbyterian Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital.

description: ''For the spectators, it's too bad, but I'm not complaining.''

title: Union Sues Over Moves To Discipline Prison Guards
description: The union representing more than 8,400 city correction officers announced yesterday that it had filed a federal suit after some members were disciplined for failing to report to work during the blackout that crippled transportation networks last week.

title: Parole Officials Won't Appeal Decision to Free Kathy Boudin
description: Kathy Boudin, the former 1960's militant who took part in a robbery two decades ago that left two police officers and a security guard dead, was paroled Wednesday on essentially the same testimony that she had given in May, when different parole commissioners decided she should remain in prison, according to transcripts of the two hearings.

description: There have been few such long-winded efforts to say that Coke is still it.

title: Jets Changing Policy on Season-Ticket List
description: After two weeks of receiving scathing criticism, the Jets have changed their season-ticket waiting-list policy. The $50 annual fee that fans must pay to remain on the list will now be credited to the eventual purchase of season tickets.

title: Conservatives of Two Minds On Backing Schwarzenegger
description: Hoping to unite their party around a single strong candidate, some prominent conservative Republicans endorsed Arnold Schwarzenegger for governor today and urged his principal Republican rivals to withdraw from the race.

title: Thank You For Flying Whatever Airline This Is
description: As summer vacationers know, airline travel is full of the unexpected. Some surprises are inevitable, but others come with government approval. Several of the largest airlines in the United States, with permission from the Department of Transportation, are now allowed to woo the public by advertising that they fly to places their airplanes never go. This arrangement may be good for these airlines, but it's bad for the industry and worse for the public interest.

title: A Runner Changes His Flag For Cash
description: This track season, the runner formerly known as Stephen Cherono of Kenya has achieved the world's fastest times in the 3,000-meter steeplechase and the 5,000 meters. He has also placed himself at the forefront of a controversial game of international hopscotch.

description: RAUSNITZ--Walter, Most beloved husband of Vera, caring brother of Egon and Paul, devoted father of Gerry and Sarita, and Susan and Peter Strauss. description: At the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., proclaimed his dream of a future in which everyone, no matter who, would be able to cry: ''Free at last! Free at last! Thank God almighty, we are free at last!''

title: Sparks' Mapp Barred For Drug Violation
description: Los Angeles Sparks center Rhonda Mapp was dismissed from the W.N.B.A. yesterday for violating the league's anti-drug program. Mapp, 33, a five-year veteran, cannot apply for reinstatement for at least two years, according to league rules.

title: Mets Lose by a Run, Again
description: The Mets' clubhouse was closed while players underwent drug testing today. It opened shortly before players stretched on the field, and Mike Piazza waited until the exercises began before sprinting past television cameras and joining his teammates.

title: Davenport to Meet Capriati for Title
description: Top-seeded Lindsay Davenport advanced to the final of the Pilot Pen tournament for the fourth time in the past five years with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Elena Dementieva yesterday in New Haven.

title: Freddie Mac Board Forced To Remove Chief Executive
description: Federal regulators forced the board of Freddie Mac yesterday to agree to remove its chief executive, Gregory Parseghian, to ease concerns about his involvement in an accounting scandal at the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCLEAN, DAVID BRUCE
description: McLEAN--David Bruce of San Francisco, CA and New York City, NY. Born March 20, 1952. Died peacefully at his home in Stinson Beach, CA surrounded by family and friends. David was loved and adored by his family, and a vast community of friends and admirers. He inspired us with his style, grace, beauty, humor and love. He will be sorely missed. A celebration of his life will take place on October 11, 2003 in Bolinas, CA. Gestures of remembrance can be made by donation to: The Bolinas Plaza Project c/o Bolinas Community Center, A non-profit ((501) (c)(3)) corporation, #

title: Japanese etiquette : An initiation in cleanliness rites
description: TOKYO  In Japan, cleanliness is not just a personal issue, but a public one. The day I realized this, I was sitting on the Tokyo subway and a man seated across from me leaned over and pointed at my shin.

title: Cedric Price, Influential British Architect With Sense of Fun, Dies at 68
description: Cedric Price, one of the most influential British architects of the 20th century, died on Aug. 10. He was 68.

title: Venus Williams Joins Serena on the Sideline
description: Arthur Ashe Stadium at Flushing Meadows may not be the house that Venus and Serena Williams built, but the sisters certainly helped rebuild the United States Open schedule. Their charismatic rise to the top of the women's game convinced tournament organizers and CBS executives that the women's final belonged in prime time.

title: Trainer for the Ages Pulls Another Upset
description: Thirty years to the month after he helped earn his nickname The Giant Killer for training Onion to victory over the legendary Secretariat in the 1973 Whitney Handicap, Allen Jerkens, at age 74, keeps pulling off the upsets at Saratoga Race Course.

title: 8 Members Of Congress Urge Release Of Immigrant
description: Members of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus are calling for the release of an illegal African immigrant from a Pennsylvania jail because of ''reprehensible mistreatment'' by federal immigration officials.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: 10,000 FLEE WILDFIRE A wildfire forced up to 10,000 people from their homes in Kelowna, British Columbia, and 3,000 more were set to flee at a moment's notice. Emergency officials said it was their "worst-case scenario" when the 42,000-acre fire south of the city pushed into a suburban neighborhood. A thick pall of smoke hung over the city of 96,000 as bits of ash floated down. No deaths or injuries were reported, but 15 homes were damaged or destroyed by the flames. (Reuters)

title: Queen Of Sport Continues Her Reign
description: Svetlana Khorkina is still the queen of gymnastics.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Style Radiates a Relaxed Precision
description: The singer Lizz Wright is 23, and she can remind you of the alloy of two different people that Steve Martin played in ''All of Me.'' She moves around a club as if she were just a person who came to see a show, and onstage she's unpretentious, verging on shy. But when she begins singing, her voice immediately focuses into a deeply relaxed state of precision; even when she said a musician's name after a solo, the two words radiated poise.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economy Contracts
description: South Korea's seasonally adjusted gross domestic product shrank 0.7 percent in the second quarter from the prior quarter, the Bank of Korea said. It was the second consecutive quarter of economic contraction. ''Consumer spending is still sluggish and labor strikes may hamper growth, but export growth will accelerate,'' said Cho Sung Tong, director general of the central bank's statistical department. ''It's unlikely the economy will shrink again in the third quarter.'' Consumer spending fell in the first half after the government tightened household lending rules in the fourth quarter of 2002 amid concern that rising defaults posed a risk to the banking system.

title: Liberia's Split Families Heal, Child by Lost Child
description: ''Good evening,'' said the voice of Radio Veritas, the Roman Catholic broadcast service in Liberia. ''This is the Red Cross family tracing program. We bring you the names of children who are looking for their parents.

title: Judge Orders Release of Trade Center Transcripts
description: A State Superior Court judge has ruled that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey must make public transcripts of radio transmissions among authority employees inside the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: IMPATH CONSIDERS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY AMID INQUIRY
description: Impath Inc., which analyzes cancer tests for doctors, said it was considering filing for bankruptcy protection and was in default of a credit agreement after an internal accounting investigation. The company, whose shares have not traded in almost a month, will be delisted from the Nasdaq stock market on Aug. 27, Impath said in a statement. Impath received an inquiry from the Securities and Exchange Commission about its accounting. The company, which is based in New York, said last month that it was conducting its own investigation into whether it overstated the amount of money owed by customers. The S.E.C. inquiry is in connection with that announcement, the company's statement said.

title: INSIDE
description: Alabama Judge Is Suspended

title: E.P.A. Defends Itself Against 9/11 Rebukes
description: Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency today defended their response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attack in New York, saying that they had done the best they could in a terrible situation and that a government report was wrong to criticize them.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Bush Stumps For Policies
description: President Bush made a campaign-style swing through the state, talking up his environmental and economic policies and tapping supporters for $1.4 million at a fund-raiser. Stopping at the Ice Harbor Lock and Dam on the Snake River, Mr. Bush said his approach to balancing efforts to promote a resurgence in the salmon population with the need to maintain the hydroelectric dams that provide water to farmers and power to the region was working well. He flew on to Seattle, where he said his tax cuts, plus his push for more trade and his plan to allow more logging, should help the state's ailing economy. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: EXPERTS RETRACE STRING OF MISHAPS BEFORE BLACKOUT
description: When an overheating electrical transmission line sagged into a tree just outside Cleveland at 3:32 p.m. on Aug. 14, the events that would lead to the greatest power failure in North American history began their furious avalanche, according to the most extensive analysis of the blackout yet.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Cancels Opera Date
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, worried about leftist protests, backed out of a performance of the opera ''Carmen'' he was to attend in Verona with Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany. About 150 protesters turned out anyway. Mr. Berlusconi said that he planned to see Mr. Schrder at an official meeting today, their first encounter since the downward spiral in German-Italian relations that began with public insults in July. Mr. Schrder attended the opera at the invitation of the European Commission president, Romano Prodi. ''I love coming to Italy,'' he told reporters. Elisabetta Povoledo (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Plan Singles Out Geese
description: Under a new federal proposal, state and local governments struggling to control flocks of Canada geese will no longer have to apply for federal permits to kill or harass the birds or destroy their nests. The population of Canada geese, protected as migratory birds, swells to 3.2 million in the spring, which officials said is one million more than states can manage. Large flocks can pollute water and damage property with their droppings. The proposal by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service would take effect after a period of public comment ending on Oct. 20. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Arrest in Death Of Bystander At Gang Fight
description: A suspect in the Aug. 13 stabbing death of a 13-year-old boy in East Harlem was arrested late Thursday, the police said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Help For Lenders
description: Thailand's central bank said it was drafting a plan to help commercial banks rid themselves of about 718 billion baht ($17.3 billion) in bad debts to stimulate new lending. The plan, which will be completed over the next several weeks, will probably establish a new mechanism for transferring banks' nonperforming loans to something similar to the Resolution Trust Corporation. Thailand has set up two such institutions since the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, but bad loans remain a persistent problem at its private banks, which list 21 percent of their loans as nonperforming, putting a constraint on new loan growth.

title: Power Not Fully Restored, Ontario Re-examines Policy
description: With engineers still struggling today to restore full power to industries and households in Ontario, a spirited debate has erupted over the wisdom of recent energy policies in the province, Canada's most populous.

title: In Giddy Rap Land, It's Senator Vs. Smut

description: Archie C. Epps III, one of the first high-ranking black administrators at Harvard, died on Thursday in Boston. He was 66 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

description: The ball hit by David Ferreira, a left fielder for the team from Saugus, Mass., went 15 feet, at most, in the seventh inning Thursday night against Richmond, Tex., in a United States semifinal game at the Little League World Series.

title: South Korea Foils Airlift of Radios to North
description: All in all, it was a perfect day for breaking North Korea's information monopoly, and Dr. Norbert Vollertsen and his band of volunteers were determined to take advantage of it. A brisk wind from the south was driving clouds and, Dr. Vollertsen hoped, large balloons carrying transistor radios north over the barbed wire of the demilitarized zone into North Korea, a country closed off from the rest of the world.

title: When Making 5 Diamonds Is Easier Than 3 No Trump
description: Conventional wisdom suggests that three no-trump is normally preferable to five of a minor suit unless the deal is very distributional or there is a serious weakness in a major suit. (Less often, a weakness in the other minor is a problem.) The diagramed deal does not, however, fit this generalization. There are no singletons, and the unbid suits are all doubly stopped. It was played at the Tri-State Regional Swiss Teams in Secaucus, N.J., this month.

title: 'A Little United Nations' Reduced to Ashes
description: The four-alarm fire that swept through a commercial strip on Queens Boulevard on Thursday left many businesses in charred ruins and their owners calling insurance adjusters.

title: Defeat Puts Liberty In Danger of Missing W.N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Time was running out and the Liberty's deficit was growing, but somehow it did not seem to sink in until the clock had expired that this time there would be no comeback. And now there might not be a postseason berth for the Liberty, either.

title: Wells Slips Up, and Hitchcock Is Shipped Out
description: Sterling Hitchcock acknowledged last night that he was buried on the Yankees' pitching staff behind four starters headed for the Hall of Fame. Hitchcock, who was traded to the St. Louis Cardinals for two pitching prospects, was right about his status. Time will tell about the others. Roger Clemens is an obvious Hall of Famer, and Mike Mussina and Andy Pettitte still have time to make their cases. But David Wells? A fine career, with nearly 200 victories, but perfect he's not.

title: Home Insurers Appeal Rate Cuts in Texas
description: State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance, Allstate and Farmers Group, the largest home insurers in Texas, are appealing a state order to cut homeowner rates an average of 16 percent.

title: Ex-Mets Find Happiness Playing for a Contender
description: Rickey Henderson longed for the off-season, when he could relax on the sand and enjoy the cool Caribbean breezes before he played winter ball. Robin Ventura sat back in the folding chair by his locker, contemplating life in Southern California after having transformed himself into a New Yorker. And Jeromy Burnitz beamed through his Dodger-blue batting-practice jersey, loving life in a playoff race for the first time as a major leaguer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, JULIUS OCHS
description: ADLER--Julius Ochs, 78, died on August 18, 2003 after a long illness. Mr. Adler is survived by his wife, Deirdre Spencer Adler, a son, Douglas O. Adler, two daughters, Anne A. Tarbell and Mary B. Malhotra, as well as an aunt, two sisters, three step children, 13 grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Mr. Adler was the son of Barbara Stettheimer Adler and Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President, General Manager and Treasurer of The New York Times from 1914 to 1955. From 1977 until 1992, Mr. Adler and his wife owned and operated the Canterbury Bookstore in Manhattan. Earlier in his professional career, Mr. Adler was affiliated with Interpublic, the New York Mets and The New York Times. Mr. Adler served in the United States Air Corps during WWII. He attended Princeton University. Mr. Adler's funeral will be private. Donations in his memory can be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: A 'Forest Brother' Remembers a Life on the Run
description: ON a leafy hillside just outside this village, a half-hour walk from Estonia's border with Latvia, there are nine capacious holes in the ground. On rare days when he feels up to it, Alfred Kaarmann hides in them and waits for the children to find him.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: HISTORIC BRIDGE RISING Workers hoisted the last stone into the central arch of a 16th-century bridge as the rebuilding of the span that was shattered in Bosnia's war entered it final stage. Hundreds of Muslims and Croats in Mostar, about 44 miles southwest of Sarajevo, mobbed both sides of the bridge and cheered as a small crane maneuvered the stone to the span. Built in 1566, Old Bridge, as it is known, remained relatively intact until its destruction by Croat forces in November 1993. Reconstruction began in June 2002 and is expected to be finished at the end of next year. (AP)

title: Cuomo Is Investigated by Lobbying Commission for Radio Ads
description: An advocate of softening the state's mandatory drug-sentencing laws has told the State Lobbying Commission that Andrew M. Cuomo directed and paid for part of a radio advertising campaign this year, possibly in violation of lobbying laws.

title: Competition Is Generating Deals on Luxury Vehicles
description: No matter how tough the times in the car business, the luxury market has always been a haven for profits and prestige. But this summer, incentives are soaring on luxury vehicles, just as they are on volume brands.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the fatal shooting of a 4-year-old girl and a man in East Orange, N.J., misstated the girl's surname. She was Naviana Hyppolite, not Gagliano.

title: Democratic Bandwagon Forcing Shift in Davis Camp
description: Some Democratic leaders in California and across the country, pessimistic about Gov. Gray Davis's chances to survive a recall election, are beginning to view Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante as the party's only hope for keeping the Republicans from taking control of the governorship.

title: Drug Maker Plans To Shed Business Of Hospital Goods
description: Continuing years of adjusting its product mix, the chief executive of Abbott Laboratories, the drug maker, announced yesterday that he would soon spin off the hospital supplies business to shareholders.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES LUCENT AFTER BRIBERY ACCUSATIONS
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said it was being investigated by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission after accusations that the company paid bribes in Saudi Arabia. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., is being investigated for possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the company said in an S.E.C. filing. The investigations follow a lawsuit against Lucent by the National Group of Communications and Computers Ltd., a company based in Saudi Arabia that claimed Lucent won favorable treatment from the nation's telephone agency by paying more than $15 million in bribes to the office's minister, Ali al-Johani.

title: Sports of The Times; Both Sides of Chicago Have Pennant Fever
description: WE are deep into the baseball season, with a little more than six weeks to go before postseason play, and a weird thing is appearing on the sports pages of the nation's newspapers. Specifically, it's occurring in the standings. As of yesterday morning, the Chicago White Sox were in first place in the American League Central, and the Chicago Cubs, flirting with first place all season, were one and a half games behind Houston in the National League Central.

His commitment and generosity to public television, most recently exemplified through the creation of the Dr Edward A. Raymond Endowment for Science and Nature Programming, has made a lasting impression on our community. Steven R. Rattner, Chairman William F. Baker, President

description: A federal judge in Manhattan told Fox News yesterday that it had to learn how to take a joke. Then he rejected the network's request for an injunction to block the satirist Al Franken from using the words ''fair and balanced'' on the cover of his book, ''Lies, and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right.''

description: This year's Travers was supposed to be a dream come true for horse racing in the wake of renewed interest in the sport, courtesy of an old legend named Seabiscuit and a new one called Funny Cide.

description: SCHRECKINGER -- Byron. Husband of Phyllis. Stepfather of Lauren. Son of Barbara and Jonas Schreckinger. Brother of Steven and Leslie. Services on Sunday, August 24, 10-11AM at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, New York, 914-235-9341

title: House-Sitting for the Boss As a High-Risk Love Ploy
description: When Ashton Kutcher got the news that ''My Boss's Daughter,'' the much-delayed bad-taste comedy he stars in, was being released, he must have felt as if he were being ''Punk'd.''

title: Mozartean Andsnes (Who Suspected?)
description: Last summer at the Risor Festival of Chamber Music on the southeast coast of Norway the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, the festival's co-artistic director, gave such an exquisite, vibrant and technically nimble performance of Mozart's Piano Concerto in E-flat (K. 271), that he seemed a consummate Mozartean. Actually, that was the first time Mr. Andsnes had ever performed a Mozart concerto. Perhaps he had been too busy exploring lesser-known corners of the repertory for piano and orchestra -- including works by Britten, Shostakovich and Enesco -- to get around to Mozart.

title: KPMG Faulted on Handling of Polaroid Financial Reports
description: A federal bankruptcy examiner yesterday criticized KPMG for not being vigilant enough in forcing Polaroid to report bad news on its financial statements before the company filed for bankruptcy in 2001.

title: An Onslaught of Computer Viruses
description: It has been an anxious few weeks for computer users trying to ward off various worms and viruses, which can take over their laptops and desktop machines and even bring businesses and public agencies to a halt. Malicious computer programs have been around for years, with hundreds of viruses apt to be circulating at any one time, but the attacks this month have been particularly trying. Yesterday experts barely headed off a programmed acceleration of a viral attack that has already flooded the Internet with hundreds of millions of infected e-mail messages.

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 5th District/Manhattan; In Manhattan, A Rare Sight: Republicans Squaring Off
description: Starbucks coffee shops are reading rooms, study centers, meeting places and date destinations. Rarely, however, have they served as the headquarters for a political campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, THOMAS HAMMILL
description: WALSH--Thomas Hammill, of Pelham, NY, died August 21, 2003. He is survived by his wife Mary McCauley Walsh, his children Thomas H. Walsh Jr, his wife Lynne, their son Christopher; Paul M. Walsh, his wife Cindy, their children Laura and David; Kathleen M. Walsh and Nicholas F. Walsh, his sisters Elizabeth, Rosemary & Grail Kearney. His entire professional career was in publishing. During WWII, he served as a Marine pilot in the Pacific and served during the Korean conflict. He retired as a Major. Friends may call at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY on Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Catharine's Church on Monday, 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to All Hollows High School, 111 East 164th Street, Bronx, NY 10452.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Executives On Leave
description: The Hong Kong subsidiary of the Bank of China said it put two officials on temporary leave as it reviews a $227 million loan made last year to a Shanghai property developer, Zhou Zhengyi, whose financial dealings are being investigated by mainland Chinese authorities. The bank executives are Or Man-ah, the subsidiary's deputy chief executive and general manager for corporate banking, and Kwok Chak Wah, the chief of one of the nine divisions of the corporate banking operations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Downgraded
description: Standard & Poor's lowered the credit rating of Fujitsu, one of Japan's largest computer and semiconductor manufacturers, to a level below investment grade, citing its poor prospects for generating profits. Standard & Poor's said Fujitsu was under pressure to cut prices for its telecommunications equipment, particularly in the United States.

title: Recalling the First Recall
description: The only successful recall of a governor in the history of the United States occurred on Oct. 28, 1921, in North Dakota. If Gov. Gray Davis is recalled from office, California and North Dakota will share a special piece of American history. But the similarities will end there. While the California recall is driven, for better or worse, by partisan politics, the North Dakota recall was a revolt against a corrupt administration. At least that's what I learned from my father, Theodore G. Nelson, the man who led the effort.

description: NEWMAN--Jeannette. Mother, We miss you still. Jeff, Charles, and their Families

title: A Shrine to Baseball as a Martial Art
description: In the dank stone hallway under the stands behind home plate, Hiroyuki Okita stands on a wooden box and cries his eyes out. His team, the defending champions from Meitoku Gijuku Academy, has just been eliminated from the national high school baseball tournament, and as captain he must face packs of reporters wanting to know why.

title: Federal Sex-Crime Charges Shock Friends of Ex-Judge
description: Friends and colleagues of Judge Stephen W. Thompson were dismayed when he was accused in April of possessing child pornography. Then came word on Thursday that Mr. Thompson, who was a judge for nearly 15 years and something of an institution in South Jersey legal circles, had been accused of traveling abroad to have sex with a minor. Suddenly, for those who know him, what had been bad news became almost unthinkable.

title: Thomas Fitzpatrick, 83; Treated Skin Diseases
description: Dr. Thomas B. Fitzpatrick, who wrote a landmark textbook on dermatology and helped develop a treatment for severe psoriasis that is now widely used for a variety of skin diseases, died last Saturday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 83.

title: From Intimate Schubert To Celebration of Drink
description: On Tuesday evening, just a few days after appearing in the Mostly Mozart production of Mozart's ''Il Re Pastore'' at the La Guardia Concert Hall, the British tenor Mark Padmore greeted listeners on a more intimate occasion: his New York recital debut at the Frick Collection, with the pianist Andrew West.

description: I've always resisted the term spell-binding, but sometimes nothing else will do.

title: Explosion of Brazilian Rocket During a Test Kills at Least 16
description: At least 16 people were killed and more than 20 wounded today as a result of an explosion during the test of a rocket at a military launching site used by the Brazilian government's space agency.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fund Group Acquisitions
description: A mutual fund group, CI Fund Management of Toronto, said it had agreed to buy the Assante Corporation's Canadian operations for 846 million Canadian dollars ($601 million) in cash and stock. In a separate deal, CI said it was acquiring Synergy Asset Management of Toronto for 116 million Canadian dollars ($82.5 million). The two acquisitions will make CI the second-biggest mutual funds distributor in Canada after the Investors Group, based in Winnipeg. Sun Life Financial of Toronto said it would maintain its 34 percent stake in CI. Assante, based in Winnipeg, will retain its asset management business in the United States, specializing in sports and entertainment clients. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Expansion Confirmed
description: The all-sector activity index, a proxy for the gross domestic product, rose a better-than-expected 0.9 percent in June compared with May, helped by a pickup in construction. For the April-June period, however, economic activity grew 0.1 percent compared with the previous three months, weaker than the second-quarter gross domestic product figures released earlier this month, suggesting that the figures could be revised downward.

title: Martin and Testaverde to Play More Tonight
description: They are two of the most important Jets and, this preseason, two of the most well rested. Curtis Martin and Vinny Testaverde have worked in unexpected obscurity, two stars who have spent more time on the bench than any of the rookie free agents desperate to make the team.

title: Energy Bill Draws a Deeply Split Utilities Lobby
description: Brigades of electric-industry lobbyists are lining up to greet returning members of Congress as they begin final work on the energy bill next month. But the industry is so riven with internal disagreements and backbiting after the Northeast blackout that some of the lobbyists worry that legislators may throw up their hands in exasperation and refuse to listen to any of them.

title: Mexico's Human Rights Retreat
description: Vicente Fox's election as Mexico's president three years ago was a euphoric moment, signaling the end of seven decades of highhanded one-party rule. With expectations so high, some disappointment was inevitable. Yet few would have predicted the disillusionment that has recently set in, leading to an abysmal showing by Mr. Fox's party in this summer's midterm elections. Mr. Fox has been hurt by circumstances beyond his power, like opposition control of Congress, America's anemic economy and Washington's post-9/11 immigration fears. Harder to excuse is his own diminished effort to follow through on crucially needed reforms. A telling example is in the area of human rights.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: Coke Executive Resigns
description: The chief executive of Coca-Cola HBC, Irial Finan, who helped the company return to profit after a costly expansion into Eastern Europe, has resigned, the company said, citing personal reasons. Mr. Finan, 46, took over as chief executive in May 2001 after the founding Leventis family, which started the business in Nigeria 50 years ago, sought one of its longtime managers for the post. Mr. Finan has spent more than 22 years at the company, which is based in Athens. Doros Constantinou, who was HBC's chief financial officer until three years ago, will return to the company to succeed Mr. Finan, the company said.

title: AMAZON CHIEF SELLS SHARES IN COMPANY AS STOCK RISES
description: The chief executive of Amazon.com Inc., Jeffrey P. Bezos, has sold more of his shares in the company, bringing his sales this month to $34.8 million as the stock traded at the highest level in 35 months. Mr. Bezos sold 50,000 shares Thursday, adding to the 800,000 he sold earlier this month, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He reduced his holdings in the company to 106.1 million shares, or about 26.7 percent of the outstanding stock. Mr. Bezos receives an annual salary of about $82,000. He derives most of his wealth from stock in the company and sells at regular intervals under a plan adopted to shield him from accusations of illegal insider trading. Amazon.com is based in Seattle.

title: A Communist Life With No Apology
description: Born in 1917, the year of the October Revolution, the historian Eric Hobsbawm has lived through much of ''the most extraordinary and terrible century in human history,'' as he describes it, from the rise of Communism and fascism to World War II, the cold war and the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

title: XCEL PHARMACEUTICALS REVIVES PLAN FOR INITIAL OFFERING
description: Xcel Pharmaceuticals Inc., which makes drugs to treat epilepsy and migraine headaches, revived plans to sell shares in an initial public offering and said that it wanted to raise as much as $75 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing released yesterday. Xcel said it planned to use the proceeds to acquire products and pay off debt. In January, the company withdrew a $97.8 million initial stock sale, citing unfavorable market conditions. All of Xcel's sales are tied to four drugs acquired from Elan, an Irish drug maker, and Novartis, Switzerland's largest drug maker, according to the filing.

title: U.N. Chief Says New Force In Iraq Can Be Led by U.S.
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan suggested today that the Security Council could set up a new multinational force in Iraq that would be led by the United States as the largest troop contributor -- a common practice in joint military operations.

title: The Giants End Camp With High Expectations
description: The Giants closed training camp today almost exactly as they started it, carrying high hopes for a potentially powerful offense and what they believe is a deeper defense, but with a few worries about injuries and their loose cannon of a tight end.

title: INFOSPACE FOUNDER ORDERED TO PAY $247 MILLION
description: The founder of InfoSpace Inc., Naveen Jain, was ordered yesterday to pay $247.1 million for insider stock trades he made while running the company. Federal District Court Judge Marsha J. Pechman said Mr. Jain and his wife, Anuradha, should pay $202.6 million in profits from the trading and $44.6 million in interest to InfoSpace, according to an order signed in Seattle. The judge ruled in May that Mr. Jain improperly transferred 2.5 million shares from InfoSpace trusts to his personal brokerage account and used another one million shares to pay off loans to InfoSpace. Mr. Jain denied that he made illegal insider trades and said the ruling was based on an erroneous footnote in the prospectus for InfoSpace's 1998 initial public offering.

title: Commercial Property/After the Blackout; Independent Generators Are Generating Interest
description: INDEPENDENT power generators? Major financial services firms and telecommunications companies already have them and a lot of other businesses are likely to want them in the wake of last week's blackout and dire predictions about the reliability of the nation's electrical grid, real estate executives say.

title: Search Is On in Suffolk For Administrative Judge
description: The death of Justice Alan D. Oshrin of State Supreme Court has left the administration of Suffolk's courts in the hands of a temporary replacement, Justice Robert Webster Oliver, and the search for a permanent administrator is shaping up to be a difficult one, court insiders say.

title: Untying The Knot
description: In most public accounts of divorce, there is no confusion as to why the couple is splitting up. The reasons are so sound -- the trails of manipulation, exploitation and betrayal so thick -- the only mystery is why the couple were together in the first place. Is it possible to imagine that Ronald loved Patricia or that Donald truly cared for Marla? What does love mean to someone who presents his bride with a prenuptial on the eve of their wedding, stipulating that she would get many millions of dollars for a marriage of four years, but only $1 million for less than that -- and then discards her on the deadline? And what does love mean to a woman who'd sign on that particular dotted line?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LING, DANIEL
description: LING--Daniel, of Canada, passed away at home on August 9, surrounded in love by his family. His life legacy has been teaching deaf children to listen and speak. For this, he was awarded the Order of Canada. See lingnotes.com.

title: Jennifer Luterman, Ryan Bloom
description: Jennifer Anne Luterman, a daughter of Lillian and Gerald Luterman of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Ryan Bloom, a son of Vivian and Henry Bloom of Johannesburg. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Reading, Writing and Retro
description: This year, schoolyard style delivers a blast from the past. Children's clothing designers are sifting through the canon of 1970's fashions and coming up with new variations of familiar old favorites. Whether the look is reinvented preppy, modified mod or mock-nerd rec-room chic, students are taking the clothes from their parents' childhoods and making them wearer-friendly. And for children who are fed up with the ''don't touch'' dictum, textures are in abundance -- corduroy, suede and cashmere at the head of the class. Who knew homeroom could be so hip?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GETTINGER, MILTON M.
description: GETTINGER -- Milton M., M.D. Yesterday would have been the 36th birthday of our son and brother, whose warm presence is always with us. His memory will be enshrined in a new research library at Lenox Hill Hospital, where he was on the staff, to be known as the Milton Gettinger, M.D. Study Center. description: STURZ--Irwin. April 4, 1915August 21, 2003. Loving father. Loving husband through two long marriages. One who lived well, died peacefully and went down swinging. A passionate golfer, Mr. Sturz was a longtime citizen of New York City and Scarsdale, NY, where he was quietly active in political causes, enjoyed the arts, and made lasting friendships with many, particularlly, his good neighbors in Gramercy Park. Mr. Sturz served honorably in the armed services after graduating from NYU. He worked as cryptographer decoder and accountant in the Army for The Manhattan Project. Mr. Sturz worked through his adult life as a CPA in the family's accounting business, where he was known for his humility, pragmatism, sound judgment, accuracy, warm heart and high ethical standards. Mr. Sturz is survived by his sister Janet, sons Steven and Joel, daughters-in-law Donna, Lisa and Mary, grandchildren Graham, Tyson and Daniel and great-granddaughter Maybelle. Some of his final words at the very end of a long illness were ''I guess I'm ready to go now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSCHBERG, REVA
description: KIRSCHBERG--Reva. (nee Godlove) 81, died August 22 at Roosevelt Hospital on Tenth Avenue. She suffered a stroke on August 20 while attending a Mostly Mozart concert at Lincoln Center. Mrs. Kirschberg was a renowned historian of Jewish art and Judaica. She was a founder and the first director of The Herbert & Eileen Bernard Museum at Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York. She contributed extensively to the book that catalogs the museum's collection, ''A Temple Treasury, The Judaica Collection of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York.'' A member of the temple's board, she also served as president of its Women's Auxiliary and was the chief archivist of the Temple. She served as a member of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion's Board of Overseers, was also a director of its Museum, and was the head docent for many years. She earned a bachelor's degree from the University of Texas and a master's degree in education from the University of Houston. She was born on November 22, 1921 to Hazel and Walter Godlove in Kansas City, MO. She was raised in Houston and moved to Manhattan in 1954. She is survived by daughters Ann Holland and Nancy Mantell; their husbands, Darrell Holland and Edmund Mantell; and grandchildren, Darrell Holland, Jr., Paul Holland, Joanna Brown, David Mantell, Adam Mantell and Ruth Mantell. She was preceded in death by husband Alan Kirschberg, who died in 1992, and husband Lt. Richard H. Holstein, who was killed in 1945 in Europe while serving in the U.S. Army. The funeral will be held at 11 AM on Monday in the main sanctuary of Congregation Emanu-El at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street. The family will receive friends after 4 PM on Monday at her residence. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Reva G. Kirschberg Memorial Fund at HUC-JIR, 4 W. Mercer Street, New York, NY 10012.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GITTELSON, ANDERS

Gittelson, whose brush name was Gisson, was born in 1921 in Brooklyn. Graduated from the Pratt Institute and was a Captain in the Army during World War II. Over four decades, his one-man shows extended from New York, Washington, Texas and California to London, Paris and Tokyo. His work is in the collections of the Smithsonian Institution and the Triton Museum of Art, in North Carolina. Among his private collectors were President Lyndon B. Johnson and W. Somerset Maugham. He lived and worked in Westport, Conn., for 25 years prior to his illness. Pre-deceased by his sons Glen and David Gittelson. Survived by his daughter Cathy Gittelson Winston of Atlanta and his stepchildren Gwen Pier of New York, Bruce Graham of Fairfield, Conn., and Eric Putzig of Bali, Indonesia. title: River Gods and Grottoes: 4 Italian Renaissance Gardens

I was in Rome to see four Renaissance gardens that have been preserved in the city and within a few hours' drive -- gardens inspired by the stately villas of classical antiquity but tricked out with all the competitive splendor, aquatic panache and passion for mythology typical of 16th-century potentates. Somewhere behind that door, I knew, lay one of those gardens -- a geometrical pleasure ground of terraces, alles and peerless views created by Cardinal Ferdinando de' Medici in the 1570's to house his vast collection of classical statuary.

Some mutter; others, in moments of exploding wrath, roll down their windows and curse at the laborers.
