Eliot's reply: ''I can understand your wanting to write poems, but I don't quite know what you mean by 'being a poet.' '' The exchange captures something essential about the disparity in caliber between the two writers, and it also explains why good satires of the literary life are hard to come by. Truly gifted authors have some books they want to write; it's generally the mediocrities who fixate on the trappings of ''being a writer.''

Previously, a sentiment like that would have been just another wry treat from the singer's bottomless bag of rhetorical tricks: take a clich and invert it, so that it's transformed into a blackly humorous punch line. Since Mr. Zevon was found to have terminal lung cancer last March, however, that declaration sounds far more literal -- and more poignant.

title: The Pair Who Turned Up the Heat in the Kitchen
description: THE photograph is of massive loft windows peering into a vacant dance space. Two men, Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane, are flying in opposite directions, like forest sprites, like madmen. No audience. Just empty space and two juggernauts. Paula Cort had to climb a two-story ladder outside the building to get that shot. But that's what the Kitchen, the performance loft down on Broome Street, was designed for -- play, excess, eccentricity. Anything could happen here, musically, photographically, visually. That was the aesthetic -- push boundaries, have fun. The image of Bill and Arnie dancing is a window into another era, a golden age when the baton of one generation of choreographers was passed on to the next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WESTERKAMP, PAUL RICHARD
description: WESTERKAMP--Paul Richard, 94 years old of Bayside, Queens, NY, died Wednesday, August 20, 2003 in Victoria House Nursing Home in Matawan. He attended Fordham University where he received his BA in accounting. He continued his education at Columbia University and received a Master's Degree in gas engineering. He worked as an HMO Administrator for Consolidated Edison in NY.. an Active fund raiser and volunteer for the Boy Scouts of America, and for the Association for the Help of Retarded Children. He was also a founder of the John Golden Pack, the first Cub Scout pack in the US for retarded children. Former First Lady, Eleanor Roosevelt, was the Pack's first Den Mother. He was a two time recipient of the Good Scout Award, and winner of the Silver Beaver Award from the Boy Scouts of America for distinguished volunteer activities. He was preceded in death by his first born son Dennis, in 1986, and his wife Kathleen of 62 years, in 2001. Surviving are his son and daughter-in-law, Patrick and Orr Westerkamp of Matawan, NJ, two grandchildren Richard and John, and two nephews Jack and Edward Morgan. Visitation will be held 2-4 & 7-9 PM, Friday, August 22, at the Waitt-Nelms Funeral Home, Morganville, NJ. Services will be held at St. Robert's Bellamine, Queens, NY, Saturday, August 23, 2003 at 9:45AM. Interment will follow in the Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York. Contributions may be made in his name to AHRC NYC Foundation, 200 Park Ave South, NYC 10003. Letters of condolence may be sent in his name via email on www.waittnelmsfh.com

title: ENROLLMENT GAINS
description: When public schools open in New Jersey next month, they will have about 26,000 more students than last school year. The state Department of Education expects a total of 1.39 million students, a spokesman, Rich Vespucci, said. Enrollment peaked in 1973-74, with 1.43 million students, and then declined. But it has continued to climb since the 1989-90 school year, when it was just over a million students. No leveling off is expected in the next few years, Mr. Vespucci said, but factors like immigration make it hard to forecast accurately. ''We're a little harder to predict than some places,'' he said. ''We are so diverse in so many ways.'' Debra Nussbaum

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Central Greenwich, Conn.; A Town With a Little City at Its Heart
description: THE downtown business district of Greenwich, a famously baronial community, has always accommodated working people who are not millionaires. They have lived in harmony in rental apartments over the shops, condominiums, midrise apartment houses, modest single-family and two-family homes, and larger homes on ample lots.

title: Personal Business; Wanted: Roommate, as Economic Necessity
description: JANEL STEINBERG thought her days of having roommates were long behind her. But last June, Ms. Steinberg, 33, found herself reluctantly welcoming a boarder into her home in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles. She lost her job as a marketing executive late last year and was struggling to cover the $1,650 monthly mortgage payment on the two-bedroom condominium she bought two years earlier.

title: The New Couples Next Door, Gay and Straight

title: Food; Tip of the Iceberg
description: In the 30 years since the dawn of ''American regional cooking'' -- a movement recently and entertainingly documented by one of its founders, Jeremiah Tower, in ''California Dish: What I Saw (and Cooked) at the American Culinary Revolution'' -- iceberg lettuce has been flat-out maligned in some quarters and simply ignored in others. When Alice Waters served her first salad of ''baby greens'' at Chez Panisse, it was truly revolutionary; now it's de rigueur. Just about every supermarket chain in America sells prewashed bags of mesclun, along with bags of herb mix, Asian mix, baby spinach and baby romaine. The watershed for me came about five or six years ago, when I sat down to dinner at Jack Binion's restaurant in the Horseshoe Casino in Tunica, Miss., and there on the menu were the words ''mesclun salad.''

In the summer, I would spend my days on the back patio, organizing the cards in different ways. First, I would organize them by player position, and then I'd reorganize them by batting average, for instance. I became very familiar with the players and the teams and the important measurements in the sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARK, NATHAN
description: CLARK -- Nathan. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Newmark). Devoted father of Edward and Jonathan. Cherished grandfather of Matthew and Gregory. Devoted brother of the late Helen Clark and Ruth Clark Sterne. Loving uncle of Richard Clark Sterne. Born in Brooklyn, on January 3, 1908, to Samuel and Bertha (nee Solomon). Bachelor of Science from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, MA in Education from N.Y.U. Following four years of technical and sales work in early radio, Mr. Clark commenced a remarkable career spanning 38 years as an innovator in vocational and technical education. Among his achievements as an educator and administrator in the New York City public school system were: introduction of one of the first Technical Electronics Courses in the United States; implementation of some of the nation's first computer programming courses at the high school level; establishment of a ''school within a school'' to address reading and mathematics remediation, as well as a program to develop saleable professional skills for handicapped youth. Most of Mr. Clark's career in education was spent at George Westinghouse Vocational and Technical High School, of which he became Principal from 1961 to 1972, after having been Principal of Food Trades Vocational High School and the Central Continuation School from 1957 to 1961. Throughout his career, Mr. Clark was also constantly involved in adult education and teacher training. His many activities in Community Service included membership on the Advisory Board of Cumberland Hospital, improvement of educational facilities at Rikers Island Reformatory, and serving as educational advisor to the Legal Aid Society, Family Court Section, New York County. Funeral private. Donations in lieu of flowers to the Alzheimer's Association.

Fiji, Japan, Scotland and even the rugby superpower, France, each stocked with professional players, will watch in disbelief as the Eagles advance to the World Cup quarterfinals for the first time.

title: The Week Ahead; MTV REDACTED
description: On Thursday, MTV simulcasts its Video Music Awards and as in previous years, who wins is of little importance. But the shenanigans that ensue when many of pop's biggest stars gather under one roof does make for good television. Watch the live broadcast and not MTV's ad infinitum repeats, which in the past have been shorn of the more controversial highlights. Last year, MTV removed the in-fighting between Eminem, Moby and a sock puppet. Neil Strauss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRAUER, FRED J.
description: BRAUER--Fred J. 92, Sarasota, FL, died August 15, 2003. He was born December 20, 1910, in St Louis, and came to Sarasota in 1985. He retired as an industrial designer and artist. He was a member of Society of Illustrators in New York, Art Directors Club of New York, and the New York Athletic Club. He was an Army veteran of World War II, who attained the rank of major and received the commendation ribbon and a Bronze Star. He was Lutheran. Survivors include stepdaughters Katherine Odre and Helen Krohley, both of New Canaan, CT, and Pamela Talarico of Spring Lake, NJ; a son, Michael of NYC; two grandchildren; six stepgrandchildren; and four stepgreatgrandchildren. Memorial services will be held later in New York and Missouri. Interment will be in St Louis. Memorial donations may be made to Plymouth Harbor Art Committee, 700 John Ringling Blvd, Sarasota, FL 34236.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ''I SAW in your eyes that you hate the world,'' Jennifer Aniston tells Jake Gyllenhaal in THE GOOD GIRL (2002). ''I hate it too.'' Ms. Aniston's character, a soul-sick small-town discount-store clerk, goes home every night to her house painter husband (John C. Reilly) who spends most of his time drinking beer, smoking marijuana and watching television with his lethargic best pal. When a handsome, brooding young cashier (Mr. Gyllenhaal) is hired, she's ripe for a reckless affair. The story also involves a Bible study group, sexual blackmail, fertility tests and possibly poison blackberries. Miguel Arteta directed -- Saturday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: How Restaurateurs Coped With the Blackout
description: RONNIE DRAGOON, the owner of the Ben's Kosher Delicatessen chain, based in Hicksville, estimates that the blackout cost him about $50,000: $35,000 in orders over two days at his nine locations, and another $15,000 in spoilage. ''It was not a great moment for us,'' Mr. Dragoon said.

title: From Mexico (via Brazil), The Next Nelly Furtado
description: OUTKAST -- Outkast keeps things light and catchy on the double single that previews its double album due in October. Big Boi's ''The Way You Move'' (Arista) has an airy, Earth Wind and Fire-like chorus between his fast-talking come-ons. But for music and wit, Andr 3000's ''Hey Ya'' prevails. The track rivals Beck as it mutates from handclapping folk-rock to electro, while the lyrics make their way from the pain of a couple's breakup to a quick rebound: ''Don't want to meet your daddy/ just want you in my Caddy.'' While Big Boi and Andre 3000 are splitting the album, they agree on their first priority: lust.

If a scarecrow could keep crows out of the field for a week, then the corn was too well rooted for crows to yank, and it was judged a success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, EMILY BINGER
description: COOPER -- Emily Binger. Aged 46, on July 16 after a long illness at her home in Pembroke, NH. At the time of her death she was a guidance counselor at Pembroke Academy (the local public high school). She served on the Budget Committee of her town and on the Board of Directors of the Granite State Independent Living Foundation based in Concord, NH. Emily is survived by her parents, Bronson Binger, of Brooklyn and Susan Storck Binger of New York, her sisters, Lucie M. B. Spieler (Mrs. Jay), of Coral Gables, FL and Sarah B. James (Mrs. Aaron) of Sheffield, MA, her brother, Walter Dreyer Binger, of Brooklyn, her nieces, Rachel and Anna James, her nephews, William, David and Frederic Spieler, her stepbrother, Timothy P. Wang, and stepsister, Katharine N. Wang, both of San Francisco, CA. Emily attended The Chapin School in New York and graduated from The Putney School and Rochester University where she received a degree in engineering. After four years with Dresser Industries in the Dakotas, Nebraska, Colorado and Texas, she worked as a hydrologist and geomechanical engineer with environmental engineering firms in northern New England and as an environmental paralegal. Emily's funeral is on Wednesday, August 27 at 2:00 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. at 90th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Granite State Independent Living Foundation, PO Box 7268, Concord, NH 03302-7268, to the Concord Community Music School, 23 Wall St., Concord, NH 03301, or to the charity of your choice.

title: QUICK BITE/Leeds Point; Seafood With a View
description: Don't confuse the Oyster Creek Inn with the nuclear power plant of the same geographical name. They are many miles apart. The seafood restaurant, way off Route 9, is the place all the locals go and the one that tourists wish they could find. It's at Leeds Point, south of Manahawkin, and three miles east of Smithville. Follow the two-lane Moss Mill Road (Route 561), which is bordered in phragmites and ends at the point, or come by boat and use the dock. On a clear night you can see the lights from Atlantic City.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Once-Violent Neighborhoods Stayed Calm During the Blackout
description: New Yorkers who lived through the arson and looting that ravaged the city during the blackout of 1977 were understandably edgy when the lights went out on Aug. 14. But it was clear by late evening that the blackout of 2003 would be nothing like its predecessor. This night did not belong to arsonists or looters; it belonged to families and neighbors who poured into the streets to use the headlights of parked cars for block parties and barbecues.

title: BackTalk; Little League Holds to Its Values in a Changing World
description: August. Dogs days of summer, yes. But, for millions of fans around the world, it's also Little League World Series time. For New Yorkers, it's a bit of a dull World Series. No New York City team is among the last 16 teams that made it to the banks of the Susquehanna this year. It's somewhat akin to a Major League World Series without the Yankees or the Mets. And this year something else is missing: there is no scandal, real or imagined, at the Little League World Series.

It will include everything from wartime mobilization and peacekeeping commitments, to reservist training and incentives for extended duty.

It could not have been prompted by the success of "Jaws" in 1975, since PG-13 was not created until 1984.

The interior is spare and cool with a neighborhood-joint feel about it: a lot of folks coming in waving hello to the chef, and two walls papered with Polaroid's of customers taken on the occasion of their birthdays.

title: An Energy Plan
description: WHEN the power went out on millions of people from Detroit to New York, it was indeed a wake-up call that we need to modernize our electric grid. But it was also a clear message that the energy policy debate in Washington has been dominated by special interests and short-term thinking. This debate cannot simply focus on drilling for more oil or searching for more natural gas. Rather, we need a long-term plan that invests in our infrastructure, protects our environment and enhances our security.

title: Pockets Full of Style
description: Patch pockets can be seen running down the legs of pants and the lengths of skirts everywhere. They were originally adopted from military cargo pants and paratrooper jumpsuits, becoming popular with young counterculturalists and skateboarders, who needed to free their hands. This summer, sophisticated women are wearing variations cut from satins, denim and cotton. But they seldom use the pockets.

title: McGREEVEY'S NATIONAL IDEA
description: At the National Governors Association meeting in Indianapolis last week, Governor McGreevey introduced a national transportation improvement plan. The proposal would create a private, nonprofit corporation that would issue federal tax-credit bonds worth $80 billion, with $60 billion to be divided among the 50 states for road improvements and $20 billion to pay down the principal on the bonds over 30 years. New Jersey would receive $2 billion and the program would provide 85,000 jobs in the state, a spokesman for the state Department of Transportation said. The plan is an alternative to President Bush's proposal and several plans before Congress, according to Micah Rasmussen, the governor's press secretary. The program that now finances the country's transportation programs will end on Sept. 30. Debra Nussbaum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CATES, DUDLEY FOULKE
description: CATES--Dudley Foulke. 85, of West Palm Beach, FL, died August 7, of complications from a stroke at Whitehall, a skilled nursing facility in Boca Raton. Devoted father of George Cates, Valerie Potvin, Jessica Zirinis, Dudley Cates Jr. and the late Alexander Cates. Survived by his brother David Cates. Mr. Cates attended Harvard and the London School of Economics, served as a lieutenant in US Naval Intelligence, World War II, in Austria. Partner of Kidder Peabody and Loeb Rhoades. President of United Funds, Kansas City. A Bible historian, Dudley wrote four books, ''The Rise and Fall of King Nimrod,'' ''Portents of the Coming Millennium,'' ''Blossoms of the Nile,'' and ''Discovered God's 'lost' People The Ten Tribes of Israel.'' Memorial services will be held at a later date in New York City and Palm Beach, FL.

title: Iran Demands Britain Free Suspect in '94 Argentine Bombing
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 24  President Muhammad Khatami of Iran demanded today that Britain apologize and release a former diplomat accused of having a role in the bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires in 1994.

title: Annelise Tufo, William Blackall

The Rev. Robert F. VerEecke performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius of Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Newton, Mass.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Dakota Fanning; A Cuddly Whirlwind
description: IN the last two years, Dakota Fanning, a precocious Southern-bred 9-year-old, has had a film career older actresses would kill for. She has played Reese Witherspoon as a child, held her own opposite Michelle Pfeiffer and Sean Penn in ''I Am Sam'' and, come Thanksgiving, she will appear with Mike Myers in a screen version of ''The Cat in the Hat.'' This summer, her name appears above the title in ads for her movie ''Uptown Girls.'' Dakota, a bundle of blond cuteness, stars all too credibly as a spoiled rich kid who bosses around her nanny, played not too credibly by Brittany Murphy.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; East Lyme Is Adding Upscale Units for Older Adults
description: EAST LYME, a 34.8-square-mile shoreline town of slightly more than 18,000 people, is developing a growth industry in new upscale residences for adults 55 and older. The success of two complexes built in 1996 and 2000 with a total of 158 homes has inspired developers to submit applications for 179 more units in three complexes, some of which are already approved and under construction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALSMAN, LEE
description: KALSMAN -- Lee. Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion records with profound sorrow the death of Lee Kalsman, a beloved friend and generous benefactor of the College. She and her late husband, Irving, dedicated their lives to the singular issue of Judaism and healing. First, they initiated a scholarship fund to foster chaplaincy training; subsequently, they sponsored a major conference; and ultimately, they endowed the Lee and Irving Kalsman Institute on Judaism and Health. Through this Institute, the College serves as a national think tank for those of all faiths committed to the mission of healing. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Peachy and Mark Levy and to their family whose loss we share. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President, HUC-JIR Burton Lehman, Chair of the Board, HUC-JIR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEMP, ISAY (SY)
description: STEMP--Isay (Sy). Passed away suddenly on August 19, 2003. Beloved husband of 53 years to Naomi Kramer Stemp; devoted father to Sarah, Ruth, Leo, and Morris. Loving grandfather to his eight grandchildren. Born in Russia, raised in Cuba, he came to the U.S; graduated from M.I.T. and went on to work in finance. He had a passionate searching intellect and boundless energy for helping others. He was a master teacher at the American Management Association for many years. He was a founding father of the Young Israel of West Hempstead, where his influence and generosity of spirit will always be remembered. He will be greatly missed.

title: What Was Michelangelo Thinking?
description: When Michelangelo was in his mid-70's, he worked almost every day for several years, according to Vasari, on a complex four-figure sculpture designed to mark his own tomb. It depicted a crucified Christ being returned to the lap of his mother with the aid of Mary Magdalene and a bearded man chiseled with the features of the artist. Vasari reported being told that Michelangelo became so enraged with his servant's incessant nagging to finish that he attacked and mutilated the sculpture (his assistant later repaired some of the severed limbs). In an unusually suspenseful piece of historical scholarship, MICHELANGELO'S FLORENCE PIET (Princeton University Press, $75), the art scholar Jack Wasserman uses a persuasive mix of technology and psychology to probe Michelangelo's intentions for this sculpture, which has been maligned by many over the centuries for its distorted proportions. Wasserman illustrates that when the massive sculpture is installed high above an altar, as he believes Michelangelo intended, rather than on a low pedestal as currently exhibited, the perspective adjusts correctly to the viewer looking up. Michelangelo therefore purposefully accommodated for distance and angle, common practice among Renaissance painters but not sculptors. Wasserman rejects Vasari's story and argues that Michelangelo engaged in ''selective pruning,'' that is, revision, not destruction. Unable ultimately to resolve the piece, though, Michelangelo gave it away, and it was not until the end of the 19th century that the Florence Piet came to be appreciated by a modern sensibility pioneered in sculpture by Rodin, who admired the statue's raw surfaces and fragmentary qualities, and who once said, ''That which is more beautiful than a beautiful thing is the ruin of a beautiful thing.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, HERBERT R.
description: SILVERMAN--Herbert R. 91, a corporate financial executive, leading figure in the commercial finance industry, distinguished attorney and philanthropist, died on Thursday, August 21, 2003, in NYC. Mr. Silverman founded Centaur Credit Corporation, a commercial finance company that merged with James Talcott, Inc, in 1945 to form one of the largest commercial lending firms in the world. He served as chairman and CEO of Talcott from 1961-1973. A pioneer and innovator in the commercial finance industry, Mr. Silverman was the founding president of the National Commercial Finance Conference (1948-1952) and served as its chairman from 1952-1958. He was also a senior advisor to Bank Julius Baer and chairman of the Finance Committee at Helmsley-Spear, Inc, from 1974-1990. Mr. Silverman received a BA from NYU in 1932, and a JD from St. Lawrence University in 1935. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1935. While pursuing his undergraduate degree, Mr. Silverman was the founding president of NYU's first all university student body government. In addition to his achievements as a business leader, Mr. Silverman was a Life Trustee of the NYU Board of Trustees and Medical Center; Honorary Retired Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, NYU; Adjunct Professor of Finace, NYU College of Business and Public Administration, 1973-1978; Professor of Finance, BPA; President, NYU Alumni Federation, 1958-1961; and founding Chairman of the NYU $111 Million Leadership Campaign. Mr. Silverman was a recipient of the Golden Medallion for Humanitarian Services, B'nai B'rith and the Albert Gallatin Award, NYU. He was a member of the ABA and New York Bar Association. Mr. Silverman, husband of the late Roslyn Moskowitz and Nadia Gray, is survived by his brother, Saul S. Silverman; son, Henry R. Silverman and daughter-in-law, Nancy Silverman; daughter, Karen Mayers and son-in-law, Daniel Mayers; grandchildren, Robin Silverman; Debbie Silverman; Cassie Silverman; Peter Mayers; Leslie Shroyer; and great-grandchildren, Amy Shroyer; Aaron Shroyer; Christopher Mayers; Lucia Mayers; Noah Keates; and Emma Keates.

title: Problems With Television Reception
description: Q -- I am no longer able to get television reception in my rent-stabilized apartment unless I buy cable service. I used to get reception for the free channels via a house antenna, but management says that since Sept. 11, the loss of the World Trade Center antennas means that our building no longer receives some needed signal for reception. While I am fully aware that antennas are the least of the Sept. 11 losses, it seems that the building management is giving me a story. I can't imagine that everyone else in the city is either hooked up to cable or does without television. Doesn't this constitute a decrease in services provided? Might my landlord have an obligation to provide an antenna that receives the free television stations, or hook me into cable for reception at no charge, or perhaps decrease my rent for loss of services? . . . Janice Jaffee, Manhattan.

There, Laurence Olivier, whom Tynan worshiped, had gathered a high-powered company of actors who were to perform a minor Jacobean play and ''The Broken Heart'' by John Ford. It happens every two years or so. But this time, on early Wednesday morning, Mars and Earth will be closer together than at any time in almost 60,000 years.

title: A Six-Month Revival Plan for Iraq
description: The terrorists who destroyed the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad last week not only blew up the most important symbol of international involvement in rebuilding Iraq. They also fueled growing doubts among the American people about the Bush administration's contention that Iraq is already on the way to recovery. In truth, Iraq is staggering ahead, at best, and the administration has yet to show that it has a realistic plan to produce tangible progress over the next six months.

Or the way they take superficial, perfunctory stabs at it, at least according to him.

title: Yes, It's Expensive, But It's the Hamptons
description: Re price gouging in the Hamptons [''A State, Not Just a State of Mind,'' Out of Order, Aug. 17]: Welcome to our world 24/7! As year-rounders, we have become so accustomed to paying premium price for just about everything basic to our lives, we hardly know the difference anymore. Start with the price of gas, usually 25 cents more per gallon for regular unleaded as compared with stations in Riverhead or Eastport. In the last five years, housing prices have swelled beyond the reach of most middle- and low-income earners, and many people who do business in the Hamptons or who work full-time out here are forced to live up-Island and join the daily ''trade parade'' commute along Sunrise Highway.

title: The Taint of the Greased Palm
description: In her article on corruption in the developing world, Tina Rosenberg describes how in Mexico City she even had to bribe the garbage man to pick up the trash (Aug. 10). The single most effective measure to curb this kind of corruption is to pay the garbage man a living wage. One reason there is not more resistance to the system of ''tips'' to low-level workers is that everybody knows that the workers can't live without them. While routine small bribes to traffic cops and the like are not nearly as damaging as the rampant high-level corruption in developing countries, the continuous paying of small bribes helps to create an atmosphere in which the multimillion-dollar payoffs are less repugnant.

title: Sports of The Times; Places May Be Small, But Dreams Are Big

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-24-03: The Ethicist; Cheating Cops
description: After an acquaintance was mugged, the apparent perpetrator, an African-American youngster, was promptly caught near the scene with the victim's belongings. At the station, the (white) acquaintance heard a (white) detective say that the young man was stopped simply for appearing suspicious (i.e., being black and running down the street in a white neighborhood in the wee hours). Only after he was in custody did the officers hear his description on the police radio. The detective instructed the officers to report that they heard the description before detaining him. This could affect the legitimacy of the arrest and even the prosecutor's ability to pursue the case. Should I notify anyone -- the victim's lawyer, the police or other authorities? Does my obligation change because I am an attorney? S.M., Chicago

She had eight children, Joseph, Elizabeth, Donna, Peter J., Jeremy, Arthur, John and Patrick. Daughters - in - law, Valerie, Jackie, Eva and Rachel and son-in-law John. She also had nine grandchildren. Gloria was a fighter and had a great sense of humor. She said her final message to her friends and family was ''eat dessert first, life is uncertain.'' She will be waked at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81 Street and Madison Avenue on Sunday, August 24, and Monday, August 25, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass is at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City, Tuesday, 10AM. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Center for Discovery, P.O. title: SMALLPOX PROGRAM ENDS
description: The state has suspended plans to vaccinate additional safety and health officials against smallpox. ''We feel we have sufficient personnel vaccinated to satisfy our preparedness plan in New Jersey,'' Dr. Clifton R. Lacy, commissioner of the state Department of Health and Senior Services, said last week. Last winter, 671 doctors, nurses, emergency medical technicians, firefighters and police officers received the vaccine, far fewer than the 1,000 who signed up for the voluntary program. The vaccination carries some risk of side effects, Dr. Lacy said. As people who have been vaccinated retire or leave the area, he said, others will be vaccinated to keep the number sufficient in the event of a terrorist smallpox attack. Debra Nussbaum

description: ADLER--Julius Ochs, 78, died on August 18, 2003 after a long illness. Mr. Adler is survived by his wife, Deirdre Spencer Adler, a son, Douglas O. Adler, two daughters, Anne A. Tarbell and Mary B. Malhotra, as well as an aunt, two sisters, three step children, 13 grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Mr. Adler was the son of Barbara Stettheimer Adler and Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President, General Manager and Treasurer of The New York Times from 1914 to 1955. Earlier in his professional career, Mr. Adler was affiliated with Interpublic, the New York Mets and The New York Times. Mr. Adler served in the United States Air Corps during WWII. title: Harvard Radical
description: It is no easy or enviable thing to take over an institution that perceives itself as matchless. And this is all the more true when, as is the case with Harvard University, a great many people, including some of the most powerful people on earth, share that view. Neil Rudenstine, who was Harvard's president from 1991 to 2001, had something like a nervous breakdown a few years into the job. He recovered, and the success of the remainder of his tenure was guaranteed by a combination of courtliness and an almost hyperbolic humility in the face of his own faculty. ''He would thank you for absolutely anything'' is how one university administrator I spoke with put it. By the time Rudenstine announced his intention to retire, the university's governing board, the Harvard Corporation, concluded that the institution had grown complacent, though of course it remained matchless. And so in March 2001, the board replaced Rudenstine with Lawrence H. Summers, a secretary of the treasury during the Clinton administration and a man more inclined to flatten than to flatter a colleague's vanity. ''We didn't think we were hiring Dag Hammerskjold,'' D. Ronald Daniel, a member of the corporation, conceded.

description: ESPN may be the last place a longtime viewer would expect to find a weekly dramatic series. ''Sunday Night Baseball'' is the definition of a weekly show to fans nurtured by the cable network on live games and studio news and highlight programs like ''SportsCenter.''

title: Coaches Turn to Web to Get the Message Out Without a Middleman
description: Coach Lou Holtz often tells his staff at South Carolina that he does not know how to turn on a computer.

title: A Race Can Be Won or Lost in the Pits
description: All Formula One teams practice pit stops with their crews trying to reduce the usual 8 to 14 seconds it takes to refuel their cars and get them back into the race. The Jordan team practices pit stops 60 times over a race weekend, rehearsing all eventualities, such as running back into the garage to exchange one set of tires for another in case a wrong pair is put on the car. It also practices putting out fires.

title: Creating Murals With Paint And Purpose
description: ON a list of famous artists from New Jersey, the name Michael Lenson does not immediately spring to mind. Yet Mr. Lenson, who died in 1971, is considered by many experts to be the state's most important muralist, and, if his sons have their way, more people will know it.

title: Investigator's Assignment Nears End
description: As befits a retired admiral, Harold W. Gehman Jr. would normally be sailing this summer. But for the last seven months, Admiral Gehman has had a single focus: to find out what caused the space shuttle Columbia to break up over Texas on Feb. 1, and in the process develop a new framework for official investigations of tragic events.

description: Faith and Violence

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Inside the N.B.A.; Talent Search Focuses on Africa
description: Africa has already produced one of the top centers in Hakeem Olajuwon and one of the elite of his era in Dikembe Mutombo. But the National Basketball Association believes you ain't seen nothing yet.

title: Grace and Goofiness at Goodspeed
description: THE usual way a theater commemorates a milestone is by bringing back the show that opened its doors.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on Aug. 10, about Hong Kong, misstated the date Britain handed the territory over to China. It was July 1, 1997. (Oct. 1 is China's National Day.)

title: United States Picks Up Three More Gold Medals
description: The gold medals piled up for the United States today in the world gymnastics championships: three golds in two events. They piled up, too, for Jordan Jovtchev, a 30-year-old Bulgarian, who tied for first place in two events 95 minutes apart.

description: Chief Justice Roy Moore of Alabama is on the ropes -- but his support is only growing.

title: Melissa Dubroff and Lee Wasserman
description: LEE HAROLD WASSERMAN, suddenly a single parent after Carol, his wife of 15 years, died of a brain tumor in 2001, balanced the care of his two young children with working full time as the director of the Rockefeller Family Fund, a philanthropy and advocacy organization in New York. Besides that, he also renovated a house in Bronxville, N.Y., for Rebecca, now 11, Jacob, 7, and himself.

title: Eric the Red
description: INTERESTING TIMES

title: 'Crackpots'
description: Memory is an odd fellow. Say you are retelling a story you have told many times before, the story about how your grandparents met in 1902. Say your grandfather, Mason Linn, was a train conductor who played the trombone and dreamed of being in vaudeville, and your grandmother, a young woman who played the violin, a young woman named Bess, with heavy dark hair, rode the train every day from Downingtown to downtown Philadelphia, where she worked as a salesgirl in Ladies' Hats in Wannamaker's department store.

description: NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL FRINGE FESTIVAL  Refractions Dance Collective in "They Ask Me Why." Wings Theater Company, 154 Christopher St. at Washington St.

description: During the finals of a recent tennis tournament in Newport, R.I., the television commentator and writer Bud Collins sat courtside, scribbling notes like a fashion editor at a runway show. ''I remember exactly what I wrote,'' he says. '' 'Awful attire.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OCHS, SUE
description: OCHS--Sue. 54, died on August 18, 2003, in San Francisco, CA. A loving mother, energetic grandmother, dutiful daughter, caring and generous friend, and exceptional civil rights lawyer. She approached life with creativity and simplicity. We will miss her.

title: Renaissance Gardens Near Rome
description: Extravagant designs provide dramatic, romantic vistas at every turn.

description: For five centuries, the tennis racket barely changed after Italian monks strung wood with cow intestines. But players in the 20th century saw a revolution in construction, design and especially composition. A look at some popular models.

description: Hundreds of children scavenge a living at a dump in Cambodia's capital.

title: Recent Looks at Tonality and Thorns
description: The Locrian Chamber Players specialize in new music, which its programmers define strictly: only works less than a decade old are considered. A couple of the pieces on the program the group played at Riverside Church edged toward the cutoff, and Toru Takemitsu's ''Between Tides'' (1993) just barely squeaked through.

title: Straitjackets, Machetes and, Oh Yes, Some Books
description: Shortly after 8 p.m. on Saturday, Tanya Sullivan and Okra P. Dingle walked onto a wooden stage at the Galapagos Art Space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where some 30 people had gathered. Over the next hour Ms. Sullivan freed herself from a straitjacket and lay on a bed of rusty nails. Mr. Dingle removed his shoes and socks and climbed a ''ladder of swords,'' consisting of four machetes in a wooden framework, and then, balanced on the topmost blade, placed a cinder block on his head and smashed the block with a hammer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Signs Rent-Aid Law
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced last week that he had signed a law that helps the elderly with their rent. The law raises the cap on disposable income for a program that exempts the elderly from rent increases in stabilized apartments. Under the law, municipalities may allow residents 62 or older to earn $24,000, up from $20,000, in the Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption program. The exemption is available in New York City and several counties, including Nassau and Westchester. In June, the Rent Guidelines Board approved increases of 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7.5 percent for two-year leases. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Wi-Fi Technology Moves From Storeroom to Store
description: Ann Marie Diogo has been a waitress for 18 years. So she was skeptical when her boss at the Royal Mile Pub in Wheaton, Md., recently replaced her paper order pad with a Toshiba palm computer that can wirelessly send her customers' orders directly to the kitchen.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has long insisted that his mayoralty should be judged by the state of the city's public schools, and he is about to get his wish.

description: The 2003 W.N.B.A. season came down to one game and one simple reality for the Liberty. A victory against Charlotte tonight would clinch a playoff berth; a loss would mean the end of the season.

title: Parties and Spending Limits
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board -- charged with enforcing controls on special interests in city elections and opening the process to political newcomers -- is understandably taking issue with what could be an unintended consequence of the plan to eliminate party primaries in local elections. The board fears that the plan will take the lid off party spending. The mayor's Charter Revision Commission, which is feverishly cobbling the proposal for nonpartisan elections for voter consideration in November, needs to take a breath. Whatever the merits of its larger case for nonpartisan balloting, the commission needs to make sure it doesn't sabotage the work of the board -- widely considered the nation's best since its inception in 1988.

title: LaBranche Asks That Hearing In Obstruction Inquiry be Public
description: LaBranche & Company, the biggest market maker on the New York Stock Exchange, said it had asked the Big Board to open to the public a disciplinary hearing into whether the company had obstructed an investigation of trading by withholding e-mail.

title: In First, Spaniard Wins Grand Prix
description: Fernando Alonso wrote history like an old pro today as he won the Hungarian Grand Prix to become the youngest driver and the first Spaniard to win a Grand Prix in Formula One.

title: Good Sitcom Is Rare, And Actors Know It
description: In the latest iteration of one of television's oldest preseason traditions, the actor Brad Garrett, of the CBS comedy ''Everybody Loves Raymond,'' did not show up to work last week in a bid to wangle a higher salary.

title: 'Then we'll have another war'
description: Republican Senator Richard Lugar talks about the failings of the Americans in Iraq and the road to reviving German-American relations.

title: Sports of The Times; Image? Education Is Now Everything
description: THERE is a row of homes with the curb appeal of decayed teeth across from a school with a metal North Star embedded in its brick, a symbolic road sign to direct children from the elementary building to a new middle school section. It's very Zen. It's very Andre.

title: Bobby Bonds, 57, Star and Father of Barry
description: Bobby Bonds, who blended power at the plate with speed on the bases to become one of baseball's top players of the 1970's and who combined with his son Barry to form the game's leading father-and-son home run twosome, died Saturday morning in the San Francisco Bay area. He was 57.

title: Sure-Handed Infield Helps Mets Get Grip
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 - It may have come with an unlikely configuration, but the Mets' infield is probably playing its best in two years. With rookies at times at all four infield positions, the Mets have played their best defense of the season the past two weeks, and pitchers and the coaching staff have credited that for the team's recent resurgence.

title: Security Is Not a Bad Thing, Mayor Finds
description: Less than an hour after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was seen in a television interview yesterday musing that he should have less security than the average New Yorker, the mayor found himself getting some crowd-control help from his own sizable police detail.

title: Jury Selection to Begin for Trial of Real Estate Heir in Drifter's Murder
description: After months of delays, jury selection is set to begin this week in the trial of Robert A. Durst, a scion of a powerful New York real estate family whose wife mysteriously disappeared in 1982 and who is accused of the gruesome slaying of a neighbor in this faded resort city.

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed Mother-in-Law, Police Say
description: A woman with a history of mental illness fatally stabbed her mother-in-law with a kitchen knife in their Queens apartment at dinnertime on Saturday, the police said yesterday.

description: The North Lawn of the White House looks like a serious headache of a home renovation project these days, with an open pit, mountains of dirt and excavators scarring the once pleasant grounds just outside the West Wing. Like many such renovations, this one ran into almost immediate delays and had no known budget, or at least none that anyone admits to.

title: Japan Detains the Sole Ferry to and From North Korea
description: NIIGATA, Japan, Aug. 25  Citing safety violations, Japan detained in the port here today the lone ship that ferries passengers between Japan and North Korea, two countries at loggerheads over Pyongyang's nuclear program.

title: In Investigation of Blackout, New Details on Timeline
description: Electrical problems were percolating around northern Ohio for at least an hour before failures in transmission lines there joined a chain of events leading to North America's biggest blackout, according to new details provided by utilities to a task force investigating the event.

title: For Thai, Red-Letter (and Red-Shirt) Day

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25  Three bombs exploded nearly simultaneously in a regional capital in southern Russia early today, killing at least 3 and wounding 17, some of them seriously, officials said.

title: Lighter, Faster, Stronger, With Strings Attached
description: Howard Brody, who serves on the International Tennis Federation's technical commission, remembered when a man at his Philadelphia tennis club took a 26-inch wheel rim from a bicycle and stitched it up with string to make it into a tennis racket.

description: Bull S.A., the computer company kept alive for decades with taxpayer money, has an opportunity to turn itself around.

description: From her starting weight of 182 pounds, Jennifer Hardesty, 5 feet 2 inches tall, faithfully recorded her daily weight-loss battles down to 140 in an online diary that attracted an audience of hundreds of strangers a day.

description: Sprinters from the United States made all the big news today at the world track and field championships, both on their legs and on their backs.

description: Cadbury Schweppes is expanding its agency roster by naming offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising to handle the global assignment for gum and mint brands like Certs, Clorets, Dentyne and Stimorol. Billings were estimated at more than $60 million.

title: How the Blackout Came to Life
description: With so much focus on the Ohio energy firm whose lapses may have triggered the blackout of 2003, it's been hard to remember that the real question is not how it started, but why it spread so far and so fast. Rather than tackle that question head-on, most commentators have reached for the usual metaphors: it was a chain reaction, a cascading failure, a domino effect. All of these are borrowed from the physical sciences. Maybe a better way to look at it is in biological terms.

description: BARRY BONDS is widely and deservedly known for his prodigious athletic skills as well as a personality that can be as abrasive as fingernails on a chalkboard.

title: Bloodshed In Iraq: A Hospital Sees It All
description: Jason Pronyk lay on his cot, his head wrapped in white bandages, his face riddled with tiny shrapnel cuts. He was brought to the American Army hospital here on Tuesday with 13 other United Nations employees after a bomb tore through their building in Baghdad.

description: Eager to have more Iraqis take responsibility for their country's security, American officials here are planning to ferry as many as 28,000 Iraqis to Eastern Europe for an intensive police training course.

description: Times writers pick their favorite moments at Flushing Meadows:

title: David Jiranek, 45, Producer With a Sideline
description: David Jiranek, a theatrical producer who was a founder of a brochure display business and a champion for the young victims of Rwanda's ethnic violence, died Aug. 17 in a swimming accident while on vacation in North Hatley, Quebec, his family said. He was 45 and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: 45 Dead in Bombay After Twin Blasts in Crowded Area
description: BOMBAY, Aug. 25  Two powerful bombs concealed in parked taxis today in the heart of Bombay, India's commercial capital, killed 45 people and wounded at least 135.

title: A Garden Flourishes Amid Chicago's Projects
description: The buffalo mozzarella at Fortunato, a tony restaurant in this city's Wicker Park neighborhood, is flown in from Naples, Italy, but some of the tomatoes tucked beside the cheese come from a place far closer. Though the diners here know nothing of it, the gourmet tomatoes are grown on the unlikeliest of farms, in a lot beside Cabrini Green, long one of the nation's most notorious public housing projects.

title: Giants Rookie Lineman Told Of Father's Death After Game
description: Jets quarterback Chad Pennington fractured and dislocated his left wrist Saturday night, but Giants Coach Jim Fassel knew that one of his players was soon going to be in greater pain.

title: Poverty, Chastity, Marketability: Advertisers Turn Monks Into Pitchmen
description: Even as lines are drawn in new clashes over religion in society, with flash points like the display of the Ten Commandments in an Alabama courthouse, Madison Avenue still turns to one set of the faithful to charm consumers on all sides of the culture wars: monks.

title: Among Countrymen, A Thai Player Is King
description: Paradorn Srichaphan is hardly a household name among sports fans in the United States, but tennis aficionados are beginning to take notice of his results, which have catapulted him more than 100 positions to No .11 in the world ranking over the last year.

title: On View: How King Shaped The Dream
description: His most famous words -- ''I have a dream'' -- were extemporized. And he routinely delivered whole sermons from memory. But as an extraordinary exhibition of his papers, books and other documents at Sotheby's auction house in Manhattan makes clear, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was an inveterate scribbler who jotted down thoughts and outlined speeches on the backs of envelopes and church programs and who scrawled entire essays in the flyleaves of paperbacks.

title: Critic's Notebook; Revisiting Faber College (Toga, Toga, Toga!)
description: As unlikely as it may seem, ''National Lampoon's Animal House'' is one of the most influential movies of the last 25 years, inspiring a cottage industry of subversive film comedies that have flourished at the edge of the mainstream. This year alone, two of its imitators did impressive box-office business: ''American Wedding,'' the third movie in the ''American Pie'' series, and ''Old School,'' which is basically an updating of the original.

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Kabul Troops Die in Ambush And Taliban Claim Role
description: Afghan officials have reported another attack on their troops in the southeastern part of the country, as five government soldiers died on Saturday when a military truck was ambushed by suspected Taliban fighters.

title: Patents; A low-attention video camera lets the photographer focus instead on the action.
description: IN THE late 1970's, early adopters of new technology had to be truly eager to own the first video cameras that went on sale. Officially, they were portable -- but only if you were willing to tape a family birthday party with a large and heavy shoulder-mounted camera that used separate lights and was tethered to a power cord.

title: Old ID Card Gives New Status to Mexicans in U.S.
description: For nearly a decade, Reynaldo Montes De Oca Suarez strived to be invisible. He melted in and out of crowds, ducking police officers and city officials. He flourished in the bustling anonymity of restaurant kitchens here, building a life as a cook amid the clattering plates and spitting frying pans.

title: Dynastic Regimes
description: Earlier this month, President Heydar Aliyev, who has ruled Azerbaijan almost continuously since 1969, installed his son, Ilham, as prime minister. President Aliyev, who has no vice president, is now ill. So Ilham, whose reputation has been mainly that of an international playboy, is first in line to succeed his father and is likely to win the presidency in October if his father does not run.

title: Undoing Voters' Will

title: 4 MILITANTS KILLED IN ISRAELI ATTACK
description: Israeli forces killed four members of Hamas, including a militant leader, with an airstrike in Gaza City tonight, shortly after Palestinian security commanders in Gaza said they had given orders to suppress Hamas rocket fire into Israel.

title: Phnom Penh Journal; Children Scavenge a Life, Of Sorts, in the Garbage
description: It is one of the saddest sights in this capital, a sprawling 100-acre garbage dump where trash fires burn and plumes of black smoke choke the air with toxic gases.

title: Brazil Eliminates U.S. Under-17 Team
description: Brazil scored twice in a three-minute span early in the second half yesterday and defeated the United States, 3-0, in a quarterfinal match of the men's under-17 world championship in Turku, Finland.

title: Big Inning Helps Tokyo Win Little League World Series
description: The championship game of the Little League World Series tonight was supposed to be a pitchers' duel. Michael Broad of Boynton Beach, Fla., and Yuutaro Tanaka of Tokyo had been the two best pitchers in the tournament, giving up a total of one run in 22 innings. Through three innings, the game lived up to its billing, as the two starters matched zeroes.

title: Sampras Returns to the Open, This Time to Say Goodbye
description: Few upsets rocked the start of the United States Open today, and most of the attention focused on an athlete who was not even playing  and would not play again. Pete Sampras, who is officially declaring his retirement, is scheduled to be honored tonight at Arthur Ashe Stadium as he bids farewell to the game he dominated.

title: Technology and Brain Power Used to Tame an Aging Grid
description: The day-to-day operation of the nation's power grid is, in many respects, a great marvel -- a second-by-second balancing act of the tremendously volatile thing known as electricity, a sometimes wicked creature with a mind of its own that can cause great damage in a hurry.

title: New Book Explores a Radical Mind
description: More than 10 years ago, Jean Boudin suggested that her friend Susan Braudy, a journalist and author, write a book about her daughter, Kathy Boudin, who was serving a sentence of 20 years to life for her role in an underground radical group's deadly robbery of a Brink's armored car in Nyack, N.Y.

title: Belgians Make Unlikely Climb to the Top
description: Ask Justine Henin-Hardenne and Kim Clijsters what the best story is in women's tennis, and they will quickly give the edge to the Williams sisters and their sibling rivalry, even if it has turned into a rout.

title: HORSE RACING: Racing Analysis; Trainers Wisely Decide Success Is Worth the Wait
description: This is a sport for the patient, and last week we saw three trainers who possessed that virtue; today, horse racing is a better game for it.

description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Company Keeps Sales Mantra but Drops the Dalai Lama
description: The Dalai Lama has preached nonviolence, urged cooperation between China and Tibet and expressed views on countless global issues. But for the record, he has taken no position -- pro or con -- on customer management software.

title: A Weapons Cache We'll Never See
description: Some 1,500 American investigators are scouring the Iraqi countryside for evidence of weapons of mass destruction that has so far eluded them. Known as the Iraq Survey Group and operating under the supervision of a former United Nations weapons inspector, David Kay, they are searching mostly for documents that will help them assemble a clear, if somewhat circumstantial, case that Iraq had or intended to have programs to produce prohibited weapons.

title: At 14, a Liberian War Veteran Dreams of Finding a Way Home
description: ''The war came before the rains in 2000,'' Dukuly Togbah remembered. ''I was 10 years old.''

title: Thomas Savage, 88, Novelist Drawn to the American West
description: Thomas Savage, whose spare novels of the American West, without six-shooters and gunsmoke, found wide acceptance in the 1940's and a whole new readership in his later years, died on July 25 in Virginia Beach, where he lived for the past six years. He was 88.

title: I.B.M. Looks to Genetics to Map a New Business
description: Gustavo Stolovitzky, a brash biophysicist at the I.B.M. division doing basic genetic research, seems an unlikely catalyst for a multimillion-dollar business investment.

title: Recalling for Dollars
description: Salivating specialists in the booming political finance industry estimate that the California recall race will have consumed a million dollars or more a day in campaign money by the time the candidates and their marketers arrive at the October vote. Estimates run as high as $75 million to revisit last year's election, which cost $100 million. That's a high price to pay for a constructive expression of democracy, never mind a deconstructive one. But the money chase is on in the mad world of recall politicking. The race seems certain to make a mockery of campaign finance restraint.

title: Fatalities grow as people use cheap but worthless 'drugs' : Fake malaria pills haunt Asians
description: TOMNOP DACH, Cambodia:  When the chills and fever struck, Ngeit Ngor knew his 14-year-old daughter needed drugs urgently.

title: As the League's Elite Fall, the Preseason Is Blamed as Evil but Necessary
description: Ernie Accorsi, the Giants' general manager, has seen preseason injuries change the course of football seasons and of men's lives. It is why, even today, he says he watches games in August with his heart in his throat, including Saturday night, when Jets quarterback Chad Pennington walked to the sideline holding his left wrist as if it were a wet dishrag.

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY: U.S. Open
description: Twenty-five years ago, the U.S. Open was moved from Forest Hills to Flushing Meadows. That's 25 years of spectacular strokes, unforgettable snapshots, tears and cheers at the National Tennis Center. SECTION F

title: Roy Neal; TV Correspondent, 82
description: Roy Neal, an NBC News television correspondent who covered the American manned space program from fledgling orbiters to the initial shuttle flights, died on Aug. 15 in High Point, N.C., where he had lived in retirement. He was 82.

title: Long Planning Cited in Death of an Ex-Priest
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25  State and local officials opened investigations today into the prison killing of John J. Geoghan, a former priest convicted of child molestation, saying the suspect, a self-proclaimed homophobe, had been planning the killing for more than a month.

description: Andre Agassi is 33, with a wife and a child, and another on the way. Pete Sampras, 32, after retiring officially tonight, will be hanging out in Beverly Hills with his wife and child, playing golf and enjoying his new life.

description: China Life Insurance, the country's biggest life insurer, said yesterday that it would announce plans Tuesday to raise as much as $3 billion in an initial public share sale, aiming to be the first Chinese insurer to tap the equities market.

When Jos Contreras struck out the Orioles' Jay Gibbons on a forkball in the seventh inning yesterday, it delighted Connors, the Yankees' organizational pitching sage. This is what the Yankees had been waiting for.

description: Julie Krone lobbied hard last week for the mount on Candy Ride for today's $1 million Pacific Classic.

title: For Pennington (Out 12 Weeks) and Jets, a Bad Prognosis
description: The unthinkable came to fruition yesterday for the Jets when they learned that quarterback Chad Pennington, who fractured and dislocated his left wrist Saturday night, would be out for at least 12 weeks. But Coach Herman Edwards did not rule out an even bleaker possibility: that Pennington could miss the entire season.

title: Plan to End City Primaries Moves Ahead
description: After months of hearings, public testimony and debate, the Charter Revision Commission appointed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected this evening to approve the details of a referendum that, if passed by voters, would end political primaries and establish nonpartisan elections in New York City.

title: G. W. Marquardt, War Pilot, Dies at 84
description: George W. Marquardt, an Army Air Forces pilot who took part in the World War II atomic bomb raids on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, died Aug. 15 at a nursing-care center in Murray, Utah. He was 84.

title: Celebrating Charlie Parker in an Easy, Neighborly Way
description: The drummer Billy Hart had just finished a set, and he was hanging around near the rear of the stage when the drummer Roy Haynes began his own set at the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival. It was after 6 on Saturday evening at Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem. As Mr. Haynes began with Parker's tune ''Diverse,'' Mr. Hart's face opened up. As Mr. Hart watched his elder colleague, his face became animated, and finally incredulous, as if he had heard a series of funny, slightly rude remarks.

title: 3 Schizophrenia Drugs May Raise Diabetes Risk, Study Says
description: Three drugs commonly prescribed for schizophrenia and other psychotic illnesses increased patients' risk of developing diabetes when compared with older antipsychotic medications, researchers said yesterday, presenting the results from a long-awaited study of patients treated at veterans hospitals and clinics across the country.

title: Iraq: In the Triangle of Terror
description: Attacks, assassinations, robberies. Baghdad descends into chaos as US troops lose a little more control over the city each day. The attack on UN headquarters has added a new quality to terror on the Tigris, as other Western foreigners join US soldiers as potential targets.

title: Miscellany
description: * ESPN, Bristol, Conn., will not show commercials during the premiere episode of its first scripted drama series, ''Playmakers,'' about a fictional football team. The episode, to run tomorrow, will be sponsored by Universal Pictures, Universal City, Calif., to promote ''The Rundown,'' a movie with Seann William Scott that is to be released on Sept. 26. There will be ''Brought to you by'' announcements before and after the episode as well as a trailer, two and a half minutes long, after the episode. ESPN is part of the Walt Disney Company , and Universal Pictures is part of Vivendi Universal.

title: Sylvestre Randafison, 75, A Madagascan Virtuoso
description: Sylvestre Randafison, a virtuoso of the valiha, considered the national instrument of Madagascar, and an ambassador of his country's music, died on July 12. He was 75.

title: Market Place; Earnings Below 1997, Disney's Stock Has Skeptics
description: Many investors seem to be treating shares of the Walt Disney Company as a growth stock. Roy Disney may not be one of them. The stock is up 31 percent so far this year, closing on Friday at $21.41 -- an impressive 26 times next year's estimated earnings of 82 cents a share, according to Zacks Investment Research.

title: Panel Approves Nonpartisan Election Plan for New York City
description: The Charter Revision Commission approved a measure last night to be placed before the voters in November that would end political primaries for municipal offices and establish nonpartisan elections. The move could pave the way for the most significant changes in New York City elections in nearly a century.

title: At Worlds, Alternate Becomes the Show's Star
description: In June, days before she turned 15, Chellsie Memmel was far from her best in the all-around competition at the United States gymnastics championships.

title: The Real Open Era: Classes to Masses
description: The dream began in January 1977, on a plane circling La Guardia Airport, when Slew Hester saw a snow-covered, little-used stadium tucked in a section of Queens. Within days, Hester, the new president of the United States Tennis Association, had met with New York City officials and an architect, and drafted plans to transform America's largest tennis tournament, the United States Open, from the cozy confines of a private tennis club in Forest Hills to a public facility in Flushing Meadows.

title: In the Blackout, Planners Found A Surprise Drill For Evacuation
description: The power failure that cascaded across eight states on Aug. 14 provided New York City officials -- who have been working on an evacuation plan for more than a year -- with something of an ad hoc dress rehearsal.

title: Senators Say Iraq Needs More U.S. Troops and Money
description: Senior senators from both parties urged the Bush administration today to send thousands more American troops to Iraq and said many billions more dollars were needed to stabilize and rebuild that country and Afghanistan.

title: Fox Plays Terminator, Ending Schwarzenegger Movie Puns
description: As the news media's intense interest in the California gubernatorial recall campaign continues, headline writers and television producers are burning through Arnold Schwarzenegger movie puns as quickly as the action-adventure hero kills and maims bad guys.

title: A Legendary Career Comes Full Circle
description: He was never interested in a farewell tour, but Pete Sampras has agreed to a farewell ceremony, and when he walks just a touch self-consciously on court at Arthur Ashe Stadium tonight during the first night session of this year's United States Open, he will complete the near-perfect circle of his career in the most appropriate place.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Spiritual Search And a Noir Comedy
description: The New York International Fringe Festival, which ended yesterday, is a remarkable event, testament to the unquenchable urge to create and perform, even under trying circumstances, that afflicts theater people. After a few days roaming the Village and the Lower East Side, clutching your festival program booklet like a tourist with a map and tracking down hole-in-the-wall theater spaces (20 of them, all told) that may be hidden behind storefronts or up a few stairways in buildings with unpromising facades, you can't help feeling that the arts are a kind of marinade for New York, soaked deep in its very flesh. And that's without ever seeing a show.

title: Ready Or Not
description: More alarm bells. This time they're being rung by a bearded New York physician whose mature, low-key manner (bedside and otherwise) is the farthest you can imagine from alarmist.

title: Computer Program That Analyzed Shuttle Damage Was Misused, Engineer Says
description: The computer program that helped NASA mistakenly decide that the shuttle Columbia had not been deeply harmed by a piece of falling foam would have predicted serious damage if used properly, said the retired Boeing engineer who developed the program.

title: Razov Again Shoots Down MetroStars
description: The Chicago Fire in general and Ante Razov in particular have dominated the MetroStars in recent years, especially this season. Chicago's 2-1 victory today at Giants Stadium left the MetroStars with a tie and five defeats in their last six games against Chicago.

title: Fast-Moving Fire Kills Mother and 2 Young Girls in Suffolk County
description: A 21-year-old mother and her two baby daughters were killed in a fast-moving house fire early this morning that was so fierce it kept the girls' father and an off-duty police officer from rescuing them, the Suffolk County Police said.

title: Connie Reeves, a Cowgirl Until the End, Dies at 101
description: Connie Reeves, who was very likely America's oldest cowgirl, died in San Antonio on Aug. 17, 12 days after she was thrown from her horse, Dr Pepper. She was 101.

title: Plan to Preserve Sept. 11 Remains Leaves Open Future Identification
description: The remains of more than a thousand people who died in the attack on the World Trade Center will be preserved in a memorial space built at ground zero, in the hope that science will advance to the point that they can be identified, according to city and state officials.

title: The Seeds of a Summer Revolt
description: Maybe it ran on the obituary page and I just missed it. But a notable death has apparently occurred, and has thus far gone unrecorded. The venerable watermelon -- the one with seeds -- has died, of entirely unnatural causes. It was at least 5,000 years old, and lived, well, fondly in our memories.

title: Campaign Merchandise, at a Store Near You
description: Political pundits have talked about the selling of political candidates for years, but the campaign to elect Arnold Schwarzenegger governor of California is giving the phrase new meaning.

title: Move Expected on Chvez Vote
description: With the opponents of President Hugo Chvez seeking to remove him through a recall referendum, the Supreme Court is expected as early as Monday to choose a new electoral board that would oversee the voting.

title: Reebok Stresses Logo in Campaign
description: Reebok International is stepping up efforts to promote the performance aspects of its footwear with a worldwide campaign centered on its logo.

description: TODAYExisting-Homes SalesJuly

title: An Unpatriotic Act
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has embarked on a charm offensive on behalf of the USA Patriot Act. He is traveling the country to rally support for the law, which many people, both liberals and conservatives, consider a dangerous assault on civil liberties. Mr. Ashcroft's efforts to promote the law are misguided. He should abandon the roadshow and spend more time in Washington working with those who want to reform the law.

title: No Peanuts or Cracker Jack, But a New Way of Singing
description: The smaller Bjork gets, the bigger she seems. On her most recent studio album, ''Vespertine'' (Elektra), she created a miniature world full of chiming music boxes and hiccupping computers. The disc, released in 2001, was full of exquisite songs about a private cataclysm; it charted what one lyric called the ''quietly ecstatic'' process of falling in love.

title: Somewhat in Demand
description: Cable television providers have rapidly increased the availability of video on demand, a service that lets subscribers order television programs or movies at any time using their remote controls. An estimated 40 percent of the roughly 70 million cable households in the United States had access to video on demand this month, up from 3 percent in January 2002, according to surveys by In-Stat/MDR, a research firm.

title: Downtown to the Opera?
description: To the Editor:

title: MediaTalk; Auctioning Off the Past to Make a Future in Music
description: Some musicians build on the past for new albums, others bury it. David J hawked his past, piece by piece on eBay, to finance his new CD, ''Estranged.''

title: Haroldo de Campos, 73, Form-Bending Poet
description: Haroldo de Campos, who transformed words into whimsical diagrams and subtle critiques of formal poetry as a founder of the 1950's Concrete poetry movement in Brazil, died Aug. 16 in So Paulo. He was 73.

title: U.S. Said to Plan Bigger Afghan Effort, Stepping Up Aid
description: In the next several weeks, the Bush administration is expected to announce a major increase in aid to Afghanistan that would greatly expand the American role in this country, senior American officials here and in Washington say.

title: Bomb Meant For Top Cleric Kills 3 Guards
description: A crude bomb slightly wounded a leading Shiite cleric and killed three of his bodyguards today in the holy city of Najaf.

title: Cadbury Schweppes Chooses McCann
description: Cadbury Schweppes is expanding its agency roster by naming offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising to handle the global assignment for gum and mint brands like Certs, Clorets, Dentyne and Stimorol. Billings were estimated at more than $60 million.

title: Study Spurs Hope of Finding Way to Increase Human Life
description: Biologists have found a class of chemicals that they hope will make people live longer by activating an ancient survival reflex. One chemical, a natural substance known as resveratrol, is found in red wines, particularly those made in cooler climates like that of New York State.

title: New Economy; How much can the Department of Homeland Security do about cyberattacks?
description: CAN Tom Ridge keep the homeland safe for Internet surfing?

description: Big French Computer Maker Hoping to Repay State Aid

title: New York State Promised $5 Million in Aid
description: President Bush on Saturday granted New York State $5 million in federal aid to help pay emergency overtime costs incurred during the blackout, federal and state officials said yesterday.

title: Liberia's Child Soldiers
description: The story of Dukuly Togbah, 14, is the story of Liberia.
