description: Men and women to watch, upset specials and those who got the easiest draws.

title: Marching On
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Terror in Bombay
description: Two car bombs struck Bombay, just minutes apart.

title: Entrepreneurial Space Shuttles
description: If the past of spaceflight lies with NASA, the future may lie with any of the two dozen teams that are hoping to win the X Prize.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Men Die In Shootings
description: Three men were shot, two fatally, in two separate incidents yesterday in northern Manhattan, the police said. At 9:10 p.m. on Frederick Douglass Boulevard between West 139 and West 140th Streets, Charles Gray, 31, of West 114th Street, was shot twice in the back and four times in the lower torso. He was taken to Harlem Hospital Center, where he died. An hour later and 50 blocks north in Fort George, a 26-year-old man was shot in the head on West 186th Street; he was pronounced dead at the scene. A 29-year-old man was shot in the stomach and was taken in a car to the Columbia-Presbyterian Center, where he was in stable condition. The police did not release the names of those victims, and did not know the motives of the shootings last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Studying Modern-Day Pavlov's Dogs, of the Human Variety
description: Ever since Pavlov trained dogs to salivate for meat powder at the sound of a bell, psychologists have used the principles of classical conditioning to study how animals and humans learn.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fox Drops Franken Suit
description: The Fox News Network decided yesterday to drop its complaint against the comedian Al Franken for trademark infringement, a spokeswoman for the network said, ending a dispute that a federal judge said never belonged in court. Fox had filed a complaint to block Mr. Franken from using the words ''fair and balanced'' on the cover of his latest book, ''Lies, and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right.'' But on Friday, Judge Denny Chin of United States District Court denied the network's request for an injunction, telling Fox it should be ''fighting for the First Amendment instead of undermining it.'' In a statement, Fox said, ''It's time to return Al Franken to the obscurity he's normally accustomed to.'' But the publicity prompted Mr. Franken's publisher to release the book early and it shot to the top of the Amazon.com best-seller list. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Lack Direction? Evaluate Your Brain's C.E.O.
description: You can be truly smart and still struggle in life if you lack the ability to plan, organize time and space, initiate projects and see them through to completion, and you cannot resist immediate temptations in favor of later better rewards.

title: Pataki Rejects Spitzer's Charge That His Energy Deregulation Policies Led to Power Failure
description: Gov. George E. Pataki publicly chastised the state attorney general today over his suggestion to a newspaper on Sunday that the governor's energy policies might have contributed to the extensive blackout two weeks ago.

title: After the Main Event, Hewitt Shows Signs of Improvement
description: If Pete Sampras is true to his word about retirement, Lleyton Hewitt will be the last man to have beaten him at the United States Open. The tenacious Hewitt was too fresh, quick and accurate for Sampras in the 2001 final as he won his first Grand Slam singles title, but there was no question about who did the upstaging last night.

title: VIVENDI TO CONTEST I.R.S. CLAIM OF TAXES OWED
description: Vivendi Universal, the media company, said it would contest a claim by the Internal Revenue Service that the company owes tax of about $1.5 billion plus interest linked to the sale of shares in the DuPont Company in 1995. Vivendi will contest the claim in United States tax court, the company said. Vivendi, which is based in Paris, said in April that it might have to pay $2.7 billion in United States taxes and interest on behalf of the Seagram Company. The I.R.S. challenged the way Seagram reported taxes after selling 156 million DuPont shares back to DuPont in 1995. Vivendi bought Seagram for $30 billion from the Bronfman family of Canada in 2000.

title: Driving Overtime, and Pushing the Limits
description: It took almost 36 hours, but his hectic driving schedule finally got the better of Bruce R. DuPont, the Midwest sales manager for ControlAir Inc., a maker of precision air converters, based in Amherst, N.H.

title: TENET TO SELL HOSPITALS TO HEALTH MANAGEMENT
description: Tenet Healthcare plans to sell five hospitals to Health Management Associates for $550 million to repay debt amid falling earnings and government investigations. In March, Tenet announced plans to sell or close 14 of its 114 hospitals after a federal inquiry prompted it to lower prices for the sickest Medicare patients. The deal announced yesterday will give Health Management hospitals with about $400 million in revenue and allow it to expand into Missouri. Health Management is based in Naples, Fla. Tenet, which has reduced profit estimates three times since November, is negotiating the sale of seven other hospitals, the company said. The company, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., is also closing hospitals in Santa Ana, Calif., and Philadelphia. Health Management, which operates in rural communities, will get hospitals in Crystal River, Fla.; Tullahoma and Lebanon, Tenn.; and Poplar Bluff and Kennett, Mo.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Joint Operation Against Taliban
description: American troops and planes joined Afghan soldiers in heavy fighting against a group of suspected Taliban fighters in the mountains of southeastern Afghanistan, Afghan and American officials said. Hafizullah Khan, the governor of Zabul Province, said that planes from the American-led coalition had dropped bombs and that American ground troops had taken part in the operation. Special Operations forces fought alongside Afghan forces, an American statement said. It said 14 anti-coalition fighters had been killed. No coalition casualties were reported. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, MARGE
description: TIERNEY--Marge. In loving memory of my dear friend Marge. Her caring and dedication to those less fortunate inspired everyone. To her family, colleagues, friends and the disabled whom she served, she was an example of love and acceptance. Her untimely death is an incalculable loss. We shall mourn and miss her. For information regarding funeral services, call 508-752-0486. Louise Friedman

title: City Schools Begin Registration To Ease the Opening-Day Crush
description: For the first time, parents in New York City do not have to wait until the first day of school to register their children for classes -- and officials hope they will not have to face the long lines that usually accompany the process.

title: Retold Facts Are Likely In Report On Shuttle
description: Unlike a report on a plane crash or a nuclear meltdown, the report of the board investigating the loss of the space shuttle Columbia, due to be released on Tuesday morning, is likely to hold few revelations about the physical details of the disaster.

title: Strains Emerge Between India and Pakistan After Bombings
description: BOMBAY, India, Aug. 26  The death toll from two powerful bombs planted on Monday in taxis here rose to 52 today, as the blasts threatened to derail a fragile rapprochement between India and Pakistan.

title: New College Season Begins This Week
description: The top four Division I men's college teams in the New York metropolitan area St. John's, Fairleigh Dickinson, Rutgers and Seton Hall begin their seasons this week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Tax-Free Week Returns
description: Starting today and continuing until Monday, the state sales tax of 4.25 percent will be waived on clothing and footwear priced at less than $110 per item, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. Forty-nine of the state's 62 counties, including New York City, Rockland and Suffolk, will remove their taxes on those items as well. Westchester and Nassau will retain the county taxes. Another tax-free week will be held in January. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Kmart Chooses Grey Global Units
description: The Kmart Corporation, the struggling discount retailer based in Troy, Mich., said late yesterday that it had named units of the Grey Global Group to handle several major advertising and marketing assignments. Total billings were estimated at $200 million to $250 million.

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 12th District -- Bronx; In the Bronx, a Reprise of a 2001 Primary
description: Standing outside of a Baskin-Robbins ice cream store in a strip mall in Co-op City, City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook seemed proud to be recognized by a steady stream of lunchtime shoppers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Virus Leaves Few Answers In Its Wake
description: Computer security experts and law enforcement officials are struggling to understand the motives of a mysterious software author who appears intent on prying open many of the electronic locks on the Internet.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fuel Service Stake Acquired
description: The Russian oil company Lukoil bought a majority stake in Serbia's second-largest fuel retailer today as Russian oil companies continue to expand into Central Europe. Lukoil will pay $226 million for 79.5 percent of the retailer, Beopetrol. Lukoil beat a Hungarian oil company to buy the stake. Lukoil owns oil refineries in Bulgaria and Romania. Other Russian oil companies, like Yukos Oil and Tyumen Oil, own pipelines, fueling stations and refineries in Ukraine and Slovakia. The purchase will increase the number of gas stations that Lukoil owns by about 20 percent. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: For a British Novelist, Tornadoes in August
description: In a recent article in The Daily Telegraph titled ''Someone Needs to Have a Word With Amis,'' the British novelist Tibor Fischer described furtively reading an advance copy of Martin Amis's forthcoming novel, ''Yellow Dog,'' on the subway and worrying that strangers would assume incorrectly that he was enjoying himself.

title: People
description: Patrick N. Palmer was named to the new post of executive vice president and chief strategic and planning officer at Chemistri, Troy, Mich., a division of the Publicis Groupe that works on General Motors accounts like Cadillac and Pontiac. Mr. Palmer had been chief strategic officer at on accounts like Red Lobster and Sara Lee at Euro RSCG Tatham Partners, Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas, as well as managing director for Euro RSCG Tatham's brand consulting division.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Russian Mogul Stays In Custody
description: A Greek prosecutor decided to keep Vladimir A. Gusinsky, a former Russian media mogul and critic of the Kremlin, in detention as the question of whether he should be extradited remained open and threatened to cause a diplomatic fracas. Mr. Gusinsky, 50, fled Russia three years ago amid accusations of fraud and money laundering. He was was arrested in Greece on Thursday. A senior Foreign Ministry official said American officials had intervened to oppose his extradition to Russia. ''On the one hand,'' the official said, ''the Russians want us to hand him over. On the other, the Americans are saying 'No, don't do it.' Ultimately, the justice minister will have the final say.'' Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital Deficits Reported
description: Thirteen general-care hospitals in New York City are operating at deficits deep enough that they require sharp spending cuts or significant outside aid to meet their financial obligations, according to a report released yesterday by a nonprofit research organization. The report, which is available at uhfnyc.org, does not name the hospitals or give details of their finances. But it cites the rising cost of insurance and supplies and the decline of Medicare payments as reasons for the worrisome deficits. The report by the group, the United Hospital Fund, analyzed 2001 financial data for 35 nonspecialty hospitals in the five boroughs. The hospitals had a combined $56 million deficit. Seven other facilities are considered financially vulnerable to drastic financial changes, such as drops in insurance payments. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Suiting Up With the New Woman Warrior
description: In his book ''Mismatch,'' published this year, Andrew Hacker, a political scientist at Queens College, culled a broad catalog of statistics to argue that American women were now outpacing men educationally, professionally, emotionally and soon perhaps athletically to an extent that could imperil human happiness.

title: Ethics Inquiry Clears Lawyer Whose Stories Were at Odds
description: David Rimmer, a prosecutor who presented very different accounts of the same murder in two trials here last summer, was formally cleared today in an ethics inquiry.

description: Music

title: When People Speak in Sync
description: People appear to alter their speaking tempos unconsciously to match the speech patterns of those around them, a new study shows. And musicians do the same thing when playing, but are even better at it, the study says.

description: To the Editor:

title: Support for the Safety of Side Air Bags; New Study Finds They Reduce the Risk of Dying in Collisions
description: Side air bags that include head protection systems can reduce the risk of dying in side-impact collisions by half, according to a study from an insurance industry group to be released Tuesday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DECLINES. Natural gas fell as utilities build reserves, easing concern about the potential for winter shortages. Natural gas for September delivery fell 19.7 cents, to $5.083 per million British thermal units.

title: FULTON FINANCIAL TO BUY RESOURCE BANKSHARES
description: The Fulton Financial Corporation, which operates 199 bank offices in four states, agreed to buy the Resource Bankshares Corporation, gaining operations in Virginia and Florida. Each share of Resource will be exchanged for 2.2 shares of Fulton. That values the deal at $195.6 million, based on Fulton's closing price on Friday and exercised stock options, said Jeff Peeling, senior vice president for finance at Fulton. Fulton, which has offices in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and New Jersey, said the purchase would expand its business into Virginia. Resource, which is based in Virginia Beach, has about $860 million in assets. Fulton is based in Lancaster, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MISTRETTA, CHARLES V., M.D.
description: MISTRETTA--Charles V., M.D. On August 25, 2003. Beloved husband of Anna Maria. Loving father of Maureen and Achim Dahinten, Laura and William Nelson, Carla and Nicolao Gaeta. Cherished grandfather of Alex, Claudia, Tucker, Samantha, Harrison, Flavia, Decio and Olivia. Dearest brother of the late Rose Catanzaro. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-5 & 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:15 AM , St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the National Kidney Foundation, 30 E. 33rd Street, Suite 100, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PELOSI, GENEROSA
description: PELOSI--Generosa. Beloved and cherished wife. Forever in my heart. Daniel Pelosi

title: The Currency of China Is Emerging as a Tough Business Issue in the U.S.
description: With unemployment high and American manufacturers reeling from three years of misery, politicians and businesspeople around the country have found a villain to blame for these troubles: China, or more specifically its currency.

title: At the Open, A Goodbye And Some Gutsy Play
description: It was the first day of the United States Open: a day for the players to board their shuttle buses and gleaming sports utility vehicles in Manhattan with their rackets, dreams and demons and end up on a hard court at the National Tennis Center with their pulses and minds accelerating.

title: Less Is More
description: To the Editor:

title: Pettitte Has Plenty For 16th Victory
description: Andy Pettitte jogged off the mound at Yankee Stadium last night as if he had somewhere else to pitch. The Yankees had kept the game in doubt by running into trouble on the base paths, and Pettitte had thrown 113 pitches. But Pettitte still chugged off the field.

title: EXIDE PERMITTED TO TAKE DEBT PLAN TO CREDITORS
description: Exide Technologies, the world's biggest maker of automobile batteries, won a bankruptcy judge's permission to seek creditors' approval of its plan to eliminate $1.3 billion in debt. Under the plan, Exide would exchange debt for new shares of the reorganized company. The plan values the reorganized company at about $950 million, according to court papers. Exide sought bankruptcy protection in April 2002 after accumulating more than $2.5 billion in debt, much of it from acquisitions.

title: Computer Virus: Call It Criminal

title: Help Comes to a Riot-Stricken City, but Its Problems Remain
description: At first glance, the little riot that erupted here this summer after a motorcyclist was killed in a police chase might seem like a long-awaited blessing for this forgotten ghetto tucked among the beach resorts on the southeast shore of Lake Michigan.

description: In its final report, the independent panel investigating the Columbia shuttle disaster arrived at 117 findings, from the complex to the stunningly simple.

description: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office is likely to forecast a federal budget deficit for next year that is even larger than the Bush administration has predicted, Congressional officials said today.

title: Into Space, Without NASA
description: Russell Blink is squeezing into a spacesuit. It is the real thing, made for Russian astronauts. John Carmack, his fellow dreamer, bought it for $5,000. Like the technologies for making rocket engines that showed up in industrial catalogs, it was, simply, out there.

title: Accounts
description: 24 Hour Fitness, a health-club chain based in San Ramon, Calif., to the San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, to handle the media planning and buying duties on its account, which had been handled by the San Francisco office of MediaCom. Billings are estimated at $20 million. Hill, Holliday is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. MediaCom is part of the Grey Global Group.

description: Mike Tyson's next opponent might not be a titleholder. He might not be a hand-picked challenger, either. He might not be a boxer.

description: Arnold Schwarzenegger bills himself as the Sacramento outsider in the recall race who can bring a new perspective to government.

title: NASA Launches New Space-Based Telescope
description: The last in the series of NASA's ''Great Observatories'' streaked into a starry sky early this morning, reaching its intended orbit around the Sun less than an hour later.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: China's Currency Policy Is Becoming Issue in U.S.

title: After Suffolk Fire, Retracing Lives Lost Too Soon
description: As investigators continued searching for a cause in the fire that killed a mother and her two daughters, relatives of the victims gathered today to grieve and wait for a phone call informing them the three bodies were ready to be buried.

title: Sir Wilfred Thesiger, Renowned Explorer and Writer, Dies at 93
description: Wilfred Thesiger, an adventurous writer who was arguably the last of the world's great explorers, and lucky enough to have lived at a time when the globe still had some uncharted corners, died on Sunday at a hospital in England. He was 93.

title: Budget Office Says 10 Years of Deficits Could Total $5 Trillion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 — The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said today that federal budget deficits could total $5 trillion over the next 10 years if discretionary spending grows in line with the economy and if Congress enacts programs strongly supported by President Bush.

title: United Links Loss to Reorganization Costs
description: The parent of United Airlines, the UAL Corporation, posted a net loss in July of $113 million, mainly because of bankruptcy reorganization costs, and said it had met loan terms for a sixth consecutive month.

His former colleagues and friends at The Internal Revenue Service Field Audit Group, Manhattan District, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a fatal boat accident off the North Fork of Long Island misstated the status of the search for a victim. The body of Timothy Sixtus, 41, is still missing; it was not found.

title: July New home Sales Dip From Record High
description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Sales of U.S. new homes dipped 2.9 percent in July, but were still ahead of expectations because June's record high sales pace was even greater than believed, a government report showed on Tuesday.

title: Bombings Kill 3 in Russia
description: Three bombs exploded nearly simultaneously in a regional capital in southern Russia early today, killing at least 3 people and wounding 17 others, some of them seriously, officials said.

title: Generosa Pelosi, 46, Widow of Financier
description: Generosa Ammon Pelosi, the widow of R. Theodore Ammon, a millionaire Manhattan financier who was killed at his home on Long Island in 2001, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 46.

title: Generations, Styles and the Video Awards
description: On Thursday night, MTV is to broadcast its annual Video Music Awards, which honor the best videos of the year -- or you might say, the most popular. As it happens, there may not be much difference. With music videos, bigger is often better: the most compelling ones tend to have bigger hits, bigger personalities and, of course, bigger budgets.

title: Richard Hooper, 40, of the U.N., Expert in Politics of the Mideast
description: Richard M. Hooper, an American official of the United Nations who specialized in the Middle East, died in the bomb attack last Tuesday on the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, Iraq, the United Nations said on Friday. He was 40.

description: Every day is Christmas at Armadillo Aerospace as the new toys and tools arrive in the mail.

title: Heredia Is Added To Bullpen
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre said again yesterday that he could never have too much pitching, and the Yankees have again taken that to the extreme. They picked up another reliever yesterday, the left-hander Flix Heredia, claiming him off waivers from Cincinnati.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Truck Strike
description: South Korea will introduce rules that allow the government to cancel the licenses of striking truck drivers who refuse to return to work, in an effort to prevent damage to the economy because of a rapidly expanding cargo backlog. About 30,000 truck drivers are striking for the second time in three months, causing several companies to ask the government for help. The strike, which started Thursday, has held up the delivery of about $338 million worth of exports, the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy said. South Korean ports including Pusan, the biggest in the nation, are operating at about half their normal daily capacity because of the strike.

title: San Giuseppe Vesuviano Journal; Who's Afraid of Vesuvius? (Pompeii Is History)
description: It was nearly 60 years ago, but Andrea Boccia vividly remembers the last time the moody mountain above him blew its stack.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Drug Maker Cutting Operations
description: The drugmaker Pfizer plans to reduce its operations in Germany in response to the country's planned changes in health care policy, Walter Kbele, the head of the company's German unit, told the newspaper Die Welt. The company, which is based in New York, said the German government's changes in drug pricing policy would cost Pfizer 140 million euros ($152 million) a year. Pfizer has already decided to move its research unit, which employs 150 people, from Germany to Britain. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Chang Plays in Farewell Match at U.S. Open
description: His muscular legs had a little of their old spring. His forehand carried a familiar but fading echo. Michael Chang did not exactly turn back the clock today in what turned out to be his farewell match at the United States Open, but he did delay the inevitable.

title: Tell Mars: New Yorkers Come in Peace
description: AFTER 9/11, we became the Sally Field of cities. ''You like me!'' Ms. Field gushed after winning the 1984 Academy Award for best actress. That was New York after the terrorist attack: barely able to believe the affection showered on it by the rest of the country.

title: Farewell to Sampras vs. Agassi
description: More than other individual sports, tennis depends heavily on durable rivalries -- clashes of styles or personalities that year after year provide a satisfying emotional charge for both players and spectators. One thinks of the incendiary battles between Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe, and of the struggles between the tempestuous McEnroe and the stoic Europeans, Bjorn Borg and Ivan Lendl. The same era, on the women's side, produced the equally reliable if less flamboyant rivalry between Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova. All these rivalries, of course, were claimed by the passage of time, and now another is disappearing, the long-running drama involving Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi.

title: Postwar Deaths of U.S. Troops in Iraq Exceed Combat Toll
description: The number of United States soldiers who have died in Iraq since May 1, when President Bush declared the end of major combat there, has surpassed the number of American deaths in the first stage of the war, which began on March 19.

title: Singapore Goes for Biotech
description: Like mice to cheese, top biotechnology talent will be drawn to mice -- a quarter of a million mice, to be exact. That, at least, is Singapore's hope.

description: ''He looked upon Father Geoghan as a prize.''

description: Tropical breezes and late nights, and a lifetime of memories for Nets forward Kenyon Martin and his wife, Heather, who are here on their honeymoon.

title: Injured Long Snapper Is Hit by the Giants 'Jinx'
description: The Giants' long snapper Ryan Kuehl stood on the sideline at practice today, with a long splint running the length of his right arm and a befuddled look on his face.

title: Liberty Media Won't Bid on Vivendi Assets
description: The Liberty Media Corporation said yesterday that it was withdrawing from the bidding for Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets. The company announced its decision on the eve of a meeting at which Vivendi Universal's board is planning to review possible offers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISHLER, ANNE (COHEN)
description: TISHLER--Anne (Cohen), 70, of New York City and Milford, PA. Died on August 24 after a long illness. Friends are invited for a gathering on Wednesday, August 27 from 2 to 4PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Born in Philadelphia, Mrs. Tishler lived in the Chicago area for many years and also previously resided in New Jersey. A lifelong interest in the Arts culminated with work as a volunteer for the Parsons Dance Company and also for the New York City Ballet where she received great satisfaction and made wonderful friends. Previously Mrs. Tishler worked in the Public Relations Department at the Whitney Museum of American Art. She also has been employed by the family business, Intermodal Equipment Parts, Inc. in Elizabeth, New Jersey. She is survived by Laurence, her husband of 49 years, daughters Elaine Marshall and Leslie Murray, sons Tony and Peter and eight grandchildren. She is also survived by her brother S. Marc Cohen of Seattle.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: CDTA"> McDATA TO ACQUIRE 2 COMPANIES Shares in the McData Corporation, a maker of switches for data-storage computer networks, fell nearly 18 percent yesterday after the company said sales this quarter would miss forecasts. McData also said it would buy two closely held companies. It will pay about $83 million in cash and assume $2 million in debt to acquire Nishan Systems, McData said in a statement, and will pay about $102 million for Sanera Systems. The purchases, which are expected to be completed in one to two months, and other investments will hurt earnings by 3 cents a share this quarter, the company said. Third-quarter profit, excluding some costs, will be 5 cents to 7 cents a share on sales of $105 million to $110 million, it said. Analysts on average expected profit of 7 cents and sales of $112.9 million, according to Thomson First Call. McData's Class B shares fell $2.20, to $10.24.    (Bloomberg News)

title: Blackout Shows Canada-U.S. Links in Security Vulnerability
description: At home when the blackout struck, Canada's defense minister, John McCallum, was forced to help manage the crisis with no lights, his cellular phone silenced and his Internet connections interrupted.

title: On Mets' Trip, Piazza Is Along for the Ride
description: The home in Manhattan Beach, Calif., was sold long ago and Mike Piazza says he stays with friends now when the Mets play the Dodgers in Los Angeles.

title: China Moves To Tighten Bank Credit
description: In a sign that policy makers fear the country's rapid economic growth may be too fast in some areas, China's central bank today raised the level of deposits that commercial banks and other lenders must keep at the central bank.

title: MEMO PAD
description: The decision last week by major domestic airlines to back away from strict policies on nonrefundable tickets was hailed yesterday by air fare experts as a significant victory for business travelers.

title: Selling New York Wine as Good . . . and Good for You (Who Knew?)
description: A few years ago at the annual show Albany journalists put on to amuse state politicians, a running gag involved an underworked state employee killing mosquitoes with a spray bottle filled with New York wine.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Thursday on the first-half earnings of Nestl, the food conglomerate, misstated the ownership of the bottled water brand Evian. It is owned by Danone, the French food group, not Nestl.

description: The General Accounting Office issued its final report today on how Vice President Dick Cheney came up with the administration energy policy two years ago. The accounting office said it had to piece together scraps of information from other sources because the vice president's panel had been so unresponsive.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Insurer To Sell Shares
description: China's biggest life insurer, the China Life Insurance Company, will seek as much as $3 billion in an initial share sale, 50 percent more than earlier planned, as it competes to be the first Chinese insurer to go public overseas. The state-owned company, which now controls more than three-fifths of China's life insurance market, is set to announce details of the sale today with its advisers, the China International Capital, Citigroup, Credit Suisse First Boston and Deutsche Bank. ''We had initially planned to raise about $2 billion from our share sale in Hong Kong,'' China Life's president, Wang Xianzhang, said in Beijing. ''Our profit has been so good last year and in the first half this year that our advisers are encouraging us to revise our target.''

title: A Casino Boss Who Started With a Bucket of Coins
description: ROBERT L. BOUGHNER knew from the start how to look like a high roller, even if he was only a college kid heading off for a drunken weekend in Las Vegas with other fraternity brothers. He took 4 $100 bills and 100 $1 bills and doubled them over, the hundreds on top, into a thick wad.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WHIRLPOOL CORP., Benton Harbor, Mich., the nation's largest appliance maker, said it had bought 10 percent of Alno, Pfullendorf, Germany, a maker of kitchen furniture, as part of a deal that involved Whirlpool's selling its Casawell Service furniture business to Alno. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Sports of The Times; Farewell Is Both Touching and Tearful
description: IT was veiled panic that Agustin Moreno believed he detected in the teenager across the net out on Court 18 of the National Tennis Center. It was fear.

title: Consultants Are on the Go Despite Economic Woes
description: IN the last two months, on separate trips done partly because I'm researching a book on business travel post-9/11, I've spent three days in Paris, three days in London, a week in Tokyo, a week in Dallas and another week in Ireland, with a trip to Hong Kong scheduled in three weeks.

title: Strains Emerge Between India and Pakistan After Bombings
description: BOMBAY, India, Aug. 26  The death toll from two powerful bombs planted on Monday in taxis here rose to 52 today, as the blasts threatened to derail a fragile rapprochement between India and Pakistan.

title: Universities in Decline
description: Public colleges and universities, which grant more than three-quarters of this country's degrees, have been steadily undermined by state budget cuts and a mood of legislative indifference. They have responded by raising tuition beyond the reach of many poor and working-class families. Now, faced with less and less state support, some universities have begun to cannibalize themselves by increasing class size and cutting course offerings, making it difficult for students to find the courses they need to graduate.

title: Tricking The Taste Buds: Science Seeks Sweet Disguise
description: The food industry, trying to offer healthier versions of popular foods without affecting the taste, is looking for new ways to trick the tongue. If it succeeds, grapefruit juice could be sweet without added sugar, and potato chips flavorful with half the salt.

title: Political Memo; Bush 'Compassion' Agenda: An '04 Liability?
description: President Bush is running for re-election as a ''compassionate conservative'' who has sought to bring a new Republican approach to poverty and other social ills. Indeed, his campaign Web site is lush with a ''compassion photo gallery'' showing him reading to schoolchildren, helping out at a soup kitchen and visiting an AIDS treatment center in Africa.

title: Address-Change Forms May Help Track Fraud
description: The United States Postal Service offers mail-forwarding to make it easier for people who move from one residence to another. It turns out that a change-of-address form is also handy in tracking down fraud.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the dispute over a power cable under Long Island Sound omitted a word from the explanation that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut gave for blocking use of the cable. He said it does not comply with the state's rules for the depth of a buried cable; he did not say that it was in compliance. The article also misidentified the residence of State Senator George Gunther of Connecticut, who called for an investigation of the project. It is Stratford, not Stamford.

title: Pataki's Losses Mount Amid Refinancing Fight
description: A bruising summer-long bout that could be titled State vs. City is continuing in the court's Appellate Division this week, with Gov. George E. Pataki fighting as hard as ever to block a deal that could save the city $500 million a year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Molester Gets Maximum Sentence
description: A Harlem handyman who was convicted in July of sodomy, attempted sodomy and two counts of sexual abuse, was sentenced yesterday to the maximum possible term, 61 years in prison. Prosecutors said the handyman, Clarence Wade, 50, abused three boys and two girls ages 8 to 13. Two of the children, whose names were not released, asked for a life sentence for Mr. Wade. ''Being molested and beaten does not feel good,'' one child said in a letter that was read before Justice William A. Wetzel of State Supreme Court. Mr. Wade did not speak at his sentencing. His lawyer, Neville O. Mitchell, said he is likely to appeal the sentence. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Final Shuttle Report Cites 'Broken Safety Culture' at NASA
description: WASHINGTON, AUG. 26  NASA will lose more shuttles and more astronauts to disaster if it does not transform its "broken safety culture," the independent board that investigated the loss of the space shuttle Columbia said today in its final report.

title: Israeli Strike, Missing Target, Kills 1 and Wounds 20
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26  While pressing its offensive against Hamas, Israel killed an elderly shopkeeper and wounded more than 20 other Palestinians with an air strike north of Gaza City tonight that missed its target, a senior militant from the Islamic fundamentalist group.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deutsche Telekom Seeks Polish Stake
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest phone company, yesterday offered to pay 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion) to Elektrim and Vivendi Universal for the 51 percent of Central Europe's biggest mobile phone company that it does not already own. Deutsche Telekom's cash offer for Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa stands until Sept. 5, the chief financial officer, Karl-Gerhard Eick, said on a conference call with journalists. The German company will pay for the purchase next year should the two companies accept the offer.

title: Arafat Picks Security Adviser He Had Shunned
description: Asserting his control over Palestinian security forces in the West Bank, Yasir Arafat appointed a new national security adviser today, while the militant Palestinian group Hamas called for fresh attacks against Israel.

title: Bush's Remarks to the American Legion Convention
description: BUSH: Thanks for that warm welcome. It is great to be here in St. Louis, Missouri, at the 85th annual convention of the American Legion. I wonder if I'm the only member here today from Post 77 in Houston, Texas.

title: Closing the Book on Lockerbie
description: Libya's erratic leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has earned a respite from American and international sanctions imposed after the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, but that is as far as Washington should go in rebuilding relations. Colonel Qaddafi remains a destructive force in international affairs, promoting his ambitions for African leadership by sponsoring warlords like Liberia's recently ousted president, Charles Taylor.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agere Takes Over Irish Company
description: Agere Systems said yesterday that it had bought the privately held Irish technology firm Massana. The deal is valued at about $26.2 million, based on Agere's closing price of $2.88 on Friday. All 45 employees of Massana will join Agere. Agere, a maker of networking chips, said it would use Massana's technology to make products that can improve the performance of corporate networks using existing copper wires. It also said it would deliver a new chip based on so-called physical layer device technology in early 2004. Agere shares fell 12 cents, to $2.76.

title: THOMSON SELLING HEALTH CARE MAGAZINES TO ADVANSTAR
description: The Thomson Corporation, owner of the First Call financial data service, agreed to sell its health care magazines to Advanstar Communications for $135 million as Thomson focuses on electronic information. The sale includes 15 publications for medical professionals, a veterinary conference and a unit that sells services to veterinarians and dentists, Advanstar said. The businesses had total revenue of $87.7 million last year. Thomson began selling publications in 2000 to expand in the faster-growing market for electronic financial, legal, scientific and educational material.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Sally Ride; Painful Questions From an Ex-Astronaut
description: Though she is a true pioneer, Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, strode into a hotel lobby here this month and went unnoticed. Dr. Ride, 52, enjoys going about life with a degree of anonymity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Robbery In Central Park
description: A man on his way to the bank to deposit the receipts from a small amusement park in Central Park was robbed at midday yesterday in the park, the police said. The thief gestured as though he had a gun and fled with the man's blue knapsack, which contained about $16,000, the police said. The man was not injured, the police said. An employee who answered the telephone at the amusement park, Victorian Gardens at Wollman Rink, would not comment on the incident. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

Embarrassed and stigmatized throughout his life, he found it difficult to concede that he was different, even to his closest friends.

description: Tiny, mobile and staggeringly abundant, microscopic organisms are premier colonists, famed for finding their way into any suitable habitat wherever it might exist. In fact, a phrase coined early in the last century to describe their movement and distribution is this microbial motto: ''Everything is everywhere.''

We extend our condolences to his sister Barbara and her family. Funeral services will be held Wednesday at Riverdale Temple at noon.

description: Thousands of Yale undergraduates are to arrive on campus tomorrow, only to be greeted by an unwelcome but all-too-familiar sight: the ninth labor walkout at Yale in 35 years.

description: ''You know I gotta do my show, even under the circumstances,'' R. Kelly said. And this disclaimer-that-really-wasn't-one pretty much summed up his wild performance at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AFGHANISTAN: JOINT OPERATION AGAINST TALIBAN American troops and planes joined Afghan soldiers in heavy fighting against a group of suspected Taliban fighters in the mountains of southeastern Afghanistan, Afghan and American officials said. Hafizullah Khan, the governor of Zabul Province, said that planes from the American-led coalition had dropped bombs and that American ground troops had taken part in the operation. Special Operations forces fought alongside Afghan forces, an American statement said. It said 14 anti-coalition fighters had been killed. No coalition casualties were reported.   Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: A Conductor Is Back, An Orchestra Reborn
description: At the end of many concerts the musicians can be seen hurriedly packing up their instruments and slipping away. The final performance of the new Lucerne Festival Orchestra here on Wednesday was very different. Once the cheers for the conductor, Claudio Abbado, finally died down, the instrumentalists lingered onstage, hugging one another and beaming.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Arson Ruling In Mosque Fire
description: A blaze that destroyed the Islamic Center of Savannah has been ruled an arson, said Bob Klitsch, chief investigator of the Savannah Fire and Emergency Services. An antique handwritten Koran was also destroyed in the fire at the two-bedroom house that served as a temporary mosque. About three weeks ago bullets were fired at its garage, a prayer area for women that was not in use at the time, and last week a burglar in a mosque member's apartment left a note with a swastika threatening Muslims, Dr. Saad Hammid, a center board member, said. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms have joined the investigation. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: BURLINGTON ALLOWED TO SEEK APPROVAL FOR ASSET SALE
description: Burlington Industries, a textile maker that sought bankruptcy protection in 2001, won a judge's permission to seek creditors' approval of a plan to sell its assets to W.L. Ross & Company for $614 million. Judge Randall J. Newsome of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., said the company could begin mailing ballots by Friday and set a vote deadline of Sept. 25. Burlington filed for Chapter 11 amid heavy debt and profit losses from low-cost Asian imports, citing $1.1 billion in liabilities.

description: ''Playmakers,'' ESPN's first dramatic series, is a show about football that shows almost no football.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Jackson; A City Powered by Politics and Vehicles
description: Enough about WorldCom, already. The demise of WorldCom, the telecommunications colossus, is just another sad story that Mississippi residents would like to forget. What they like to talk about in Jackson now is the Nissan plant that arose from a pasture a few miles north of town.

title: Presiding Over the Creation In Powdered Wigs and Stockings
description: Louis Langre ended his first summer as music director of the Mostly Mozart Festival on Saturday evening with a glimpse back at the beginning -- not the beginning of the festival, but of the universe. The work at hand was ''The Creation,'' Haydn's great oratorio that conveys an Enlightenment view of the first week of temporal existence. In its libretto, originally written for Handel (who never got around to setting it) but reworked for Haydn by Baron Gottfried von Swieten, passages from the Bible and Milton's ''Paradise Lost'' intermingle. And the score overflows with both vividly pictorial orchestral writing and choruses that are both devotional and exuberant.

title: Bush, Speaking to Veterans, Says Iraq May Not Be Last Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 - President Bush defended his policy on Iraq today, declaring that the United States had struck a blow against terrorism in overthrowing the government of Saddam Hussein. And Mr. Bush said the United States might carry out other pre-emptive strikes.

title: Pope Signs Extension With the MetroStars
description: The speculation about Eddie Pope, the central defender of the MetroStars and the United States national team, going overseas ended yesterday. Pope signed a four-year contract extension with Major League Soccer that will keep him with the MetroStars through the 2007 season.

title: Fish's Fans Add Flavor To First-Round Victory
description: The setting was center court at Arthur Ashe Stadium yesterday, and the crowd filled only half the seats as Mardy Fish took the court for the second match of the day. But as Fish methodically made his way through a straight-set victory, an odd, and somewhat comical, sight emerged in the otherwise sedate setting.

title: PITNEY BOWES AGREES TO PAY $49.5 MILLION FOR DDD
description: Pitney Bowes, the world's largest maker of postal meters and mailing equipment, said it agreed to buy the DDD Company for $49.5 million to expand its product offerings to government agencies. DDD has about 1,200 employees and provides messenger services, logistics support, and record and information management to government agencies and businesses. It will become a unit of Pitney Bowes called Pitney Bowes Government Solutions Inc. Michael J. Critelli, Pitney Bowes's chief executive, has said he will expand the company through acquisitions to increase its 2 percent share of the $250 billion market for mail products.

title: Dean Readies Ad Blitz More Than Year Ahead of Election
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26  Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont whose long-shot bid for the Democratic presidential nomination has surged to the top of several recent polls, plans to broadcast a new television commercial in six states beginning Friday and expects to raise $10.3 million during the second quarter, his campaign announced today.

title: Rising Obesity in Children Prompts Call to Action
description: Prevention has always been a cornerstone of pediatrics, more so than in almost any other medical specialty. Pediatricians vaccinate and screen. They counsel parents on ways to keep children healthy and safe. One area that pediatricians have not typically focused on, however, is preventing young patients from becoming overweight. Yet in the last 20 years, those who work in the field say, obesity has become the most prevalent chronic health problem among American children.

title: Investigators Offer Array of Ways to Fix Shuttle Program
description: The board that investigated the Columbia shuttle disaster offered 29 recommendations, including several issued during the course of the investigation in an effort to give NASA a head start on its "return to flight" efforts.

title: Making the World Safe for Humanitarianism
description: The humanitarian workers who died last week in the bombing of the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad may have achieved small victories alleviating human suffering in Iraq. But they would not have won the war against it. The harsh reality is that the risks of aid work often exceed its achievements.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drug Charge Overturned
description: A federal judge has overturned the conviction of a man found guilty in a trial in which a key witness's identity was kept secret. But in ordering a new trial for the man, Theo Frazier, the judge on Friday did not cite the secret witness, an undercover police officer whose identification in court, prosecutors said, would have put the officer in danger. Instead, the judge, Thomas P. Griesa of United States District Court, said the jury should have been told whether it was possible that Mr. Frazier was at an apartment under police surveillance to buy drugs for his own use. Mr. Frazier was convicted in April of aiding a drug operation. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Metrologic Instruments Raises Forecast
description: Metrologic Instruments Inc., a maker of bar-code scanning equipment, yesterday raised its sales and earnings estimates for the rest of 2003 in response to rising demand for its point-of-sale scanners and stronger business in China. Sales for the year will be $130 million to $132 million, up from earlier projections of $128 million to $131 million, the company said in a statement. Net income will be about $8.8 million to $9.3 million. The company has benefited from increased production at its plant in Suzhou, China, where it moved several units to lower the cost of labor and materials. Third-quarter revenue is expected to be $31 million to $32 million, with net income of about $2 million to $2.3 million, or 20 cents to 23 cents a share, the company said. Metrologic had previously forecast net income of $1.6 million to $1.8 million. Shares of Metrologic rose $5.44, or 17 percent, to $37.27.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: GREECE: RUSSIAN MOGUL STAYS IN CUSTODY A Greek prosecutor decided to keep Vladimir A. Gusinsky, a former Russian media mogul and critic of the Kremlin, in detention as the question of whether he should be extradited remained open and threatened to cause a diplomatic fracas. Mr. Gusinsky, 50, fled Russia three years ago amid accusations of fraud and money laundering. He was was arrested in Greece on Thursday. A senior Foreign Ministry official said American officials had intervened to oppose his extradition to Russia. "On the one hand," the official said, "the Russians want us to hand him over. On the other, the Americans are saying `No, don't do it.' Ultimately, the justice minister will have the final say."    Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: 50 DEAD IN BOMBAY AFTER TWIN BLASTS IN CROWDED AREAS
description: Two powerful bombs concealed on Monday in parked taxis in the heart of Bombay, India's commercial capital, killed 50 people and wounded at least 129, state officials reviewing the toll said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Candidates For Principal Advance
description: Eighty-six of the 90 aspiring New York City school principals who began studies in July at the Leadership Academy, the city's new 15-month principal training program, have completed the first phase, the program's chief executive, Robert E. Knowling Jr., said yesterday. In a report to the Department of Education, Mr. Knowling said that some of those who have left the program had been asked to do so. ''We don't want to make a 15-month error,'' Mr. Knowling said, adding that the principals-in-training would continue to be evaluated regularly. In the second phase this fall, trainees will be paired with principals. Katherine Zoepf (NYT)

title: British Intelligence Official Defends Iraqi Weapons Dossier
description: LONDON, Aug. 25  The senior intelligence figure who compiled Britain's dossier on Iraqi arms testified today that the attention-getting claim that Saddam Hussein could deploy unconventional weapons in 45 minutes was backed by reliable evidence and that its 11th-hour inclusion in the document was supported by security chiefs.

title: Hello to College Joys: Keep Stress Off Campus
description: Adults are often quick to tell college students: ''Enjoy yourselves. This is the best time of your lives.'' But for an increasing number of students, the college experience is marred by chronic anxiety, stress and distress.

title: Long Planning Is Cited in Death Of Former Priest
description: State and local officials opened investigations today into the prison killing of John J. Geoghan, a former priest convicted of child molestation, saying the suspect, a self-proclaimed homophobe, had been planning the killing for more than a month.

description: Two senior Bush administration officials today urged patience with the American occupation in Iraq, comparing the attacks against United States forces there to guerrilla strikes by bands of Nazis who fought on after World War II ended.

title: Dispute Between 2 Republican Congressmen Stalls Drug Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  Congressional aides trying to write a bill providing drug benefits to millions of elderly people said today that their work was stalled by growing disagreements and antagonism between the top Republican negotiators from the Senate and the House.

title: Raging and Gnashing Off the Beaten Path
description: A remarkable thing about American youth culture is that it moves with equal determination in two ways, into and away from plain sight. Whenever a viable new sound or rhythm comes along, it's packaged for mass consumption. That is what happened to punk and hip-hop. Both began by using stolen or damaged instruments, which were run off of boosted electrical current, then grew to majestic levels of expense and craft, aimed at millions of teenage consumers.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Disputed Transcripts Set For Release
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, reversing itself, said it would no longer resist the release of transcripts of more than 200 hours of employee and civilian conversations during the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, 2001. On Friday, responding to a court action by The New York Times, a state judge ruled that an agreement in July, which settled a suit the newspaper filed against the Port Authority to compel the transcripts' release, was valid and enforceable. The authority, which owns the trade center site, had objected to the release, citing privacy concerns and sensitivity to the victims' families. But yesterday, officials said they did not want to prolong the legal process. The authority has until Thursday to release the transcripts. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: The Death of John Geoghan
description: As a child molester, and a central figure in the Catholic Church's sexual abuse scandal, the defrocked priest John Geoghan was a predictable target for violence when he was incarcerated. He was being held in what the prison system calls ''protective custody,'' but that did not prevent his being left alone with a prisoner serving a life sentence for a murder that was apparently motivated by anti-gay bias. Security in the unit was lax enough that Mr. Geoghan's assailant was able to follow him back to his cell after lunch and bind, gag and strangle him before the guards arrived on the scene.

title: BERLIN: A DIETRICH VETO
description: A walk of fame planned for Berlin will have to do without the name Marlene Dietrich. The Dietrich family has barred the organizers from honoring the glamorous Berlin-born movie actress and singer (1901-1992), left, because, it said, the proposed tribute, including an engraving of the star of ''The Blue Angel'' (1930), does not do justice to her legacy. The site, including the hand imprints and autographs of German celebrities like Ute Lemper and Caterina Valente, is to open on Sunday in front of the Friedrichstadtpalast Theater, on a site where Dietrich performed in 1926 as a chorus girl. ''Had the city of Berlin initiated the project, this would have been a whole different story,'' said Frieder Roth, the Dietrich family lawyer. ''However, this is a private matter of the Friedrichstadtpalast, and therefore falls short of expressing significance of such a grand celebrity like Marlene.'' The celebrity strip is Berlin Pflaster, translated as Berlin Sidewalk. KRISTEN GRIESHABER

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew 7.3 percent in July from the month a year ago, helped by a rebound in exports. Japan's surplus swelled to 799 billion yen ($6.7 billion yen), smaller than economists had forecast. But shipments overseas surged 5.6 percent in July after declining in June, relieving anxieties that the country's export-led recovery would be derailed by a slowdown in the United States and other major markets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: HOSPITAL DEFICITS REPORTED Thirteen general-care hospitals in New York City are operating at deficits deep enough that they require sharp spending cuts or significant outside aid to meet their financial obligations, according to a report released yesterday by a nonprofit research organization. The report, which is available at uhfnyc.org, does not name the hospitals or give details of their finances. But it cites the rising cost of insurance and supplies and the decline of Medicare payments as reasons for the worrisome deficits. The report by the group, the United Hospital Fund, analyzed 2001 financial data for 35 nonspecialty hospitals in the five boroughs. The hospitals had a combined $56 million deficit. Seven other facilities are considered financially vulnerable to drastic financial changes, such as drops in insurance payments.   Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: French Foil Plot
description: The French authorities said they arrested a group of suspected mercenaries headed for Ivory Coast, foiling a plot to destabilize the fragile coalition government in power since France brokered a peace accord just three months ago. At least 10 people were taken into custody, they said. The men are being held under a new anti-mercenary law. Those arrested, according to Agence France-Presse, included Ibrahim Coulibaly, the leader of a coup in 1999. He is suspected of helping direct the civil war that broke out nearly a year ago, in which thousands died and millions were driven from their homes. Despite the peace accord, tensions in Ivory Coast, a former French colony, remain high. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

The previous year's net profit was 563 million Australian dollars ($367 million). The chief executive, Roger Corbett, said sales growth and cost reductions contributed to the record result. title: Rockwell Officer Resigns
description: Rockwell Automation, one of the world's largest makers of factory controls, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Michael A. Bless, was leaving the company.

title: Pope Signs Extension With the MetroStars
description: The speculation about Eddie Pope, the central defender of the MetroStars and the United States national team, going overseas ended yesterday. Pope signed a four-year contract extension with Major League Soccer that will keep him with the MetroStars through the 2007 season.

title: Lifestyles of the Extreme and Adapted
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: COMPUTER COMPANY CUTS JOBS AND SHUTS OFFICES The Computer Network Technology Corporation , which provides software and hardware for computer storage networks, cut about 150 jobs after it combined some operations and closed offices. The company said yesterday that it expected to save about $20 million from its cost-cutting, more than its initial forecasts of savings of up to $15 million. The company said its second-quarter loss widened to $25.8 million, from $2.1 million a year earlier. Revenue almost doubled to $96.7 million in the period ended July 31, from $48.9 million in the period a year earlier. Computer Networks expects to have revenue of $100 million to $110 million on earnings of 3 cents to 7 cents a share, excluding certain costs. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, the company is expected to earn 6 cents, the average of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.    (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit In Cleaners
description: A leading maker of cleaning products, Reckitt Benckiser, said yesterday that net income had increased 14 percent in the second quarter to 117 million ($184 million). Sales at the company, which is based in Slough, England, grew 7 percent, to 960 million ($1.5 billion), as the company introduced products and expanded its reach. The higher earnings prompted Reckitt Benckiser to raise its dividend and and its profit forecast for the year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Scientist Files Suit Over Anthrax Inquiry
description: Dr. Steven J. Hatfill, whom senior government officials have identified as a ''person of interest'' in their investigation into the 2001 anthrax mailings, filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing Attorney General John Ashcroft and other Justice Department officials of having violated his constitutional rights and the agency's own rules by making him a ''fall guy'' in their inquiry.

title: Process vs. Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: Raiders Win $34 Million In Oakland Coliseum Case
description: The Oakland Raiders' owner, Al Davis, was awarded $34.2 million yesterday by a Sacramento Superior Court jury, which found that officials from the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Inc. had misrepresented the projected attendance when they enticed the franchise to return from Los Angeles.

title: Gaffney Takes Parting Shot At Wage Law in Suffolk
description: The efforts of Robert J. Gaffney to kill Suffolk County's living-wage law have failed so far, but before leaving office, Mr. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, has decided to give it one more try.

title: A Quiet American
description: Pete Sampras retired a year too late for some spoilsports: he should have done it last year, they said, after his improbable victory over his long-time rival, Andre Agassi, in the United States Open final. This is part of the rap leveled against Sampras for years: no drama, no emotion, no courting of the crowd.

title: Cut-Rate Swedish Retailer Enters the Italian Market
description: To say Italians are fashion obsessed is like saying Americans love big cars or Brazilians love soccer. So can a Swedish clothing company renowned for making low-cost versions of top designers' fashions find success in the home of Prada, Versace, Armani and Valentino?

title: ZIMMER TO MAKE OFFER FOR CENTERPULSE
description: Zimmer Holdings Inc., which is trying to become the world's largest maker of artificial hips and knees, said yesterday that it would proceed with a $3.2 billion offer to buy Centerpulse after reviewing Centerpulse's accounting. Centerpulse said last week that the Securities and Exchange Commission began an informal inquiry into how its United States subsidiary accounted for inventory. A review by Zimmer executives did not alter the company's views about Centerpulse, Zimmer said. Zimmer's offer for Centerpulse and its major shareholder, Incentive Capital, expires today. Zimmer, of Warsaw, Ind., trumped a $2.5 billion bid from Smith & Nephew.

title: E.P.A. Exempts Old Plants From Using Anti-Pollution Devices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 — In one of its most far-reaching environmental actions, the Bush administration today adopted a final rule that will allow thousands of older power plants, oil refineries and industrial units to make extensive upgrades without having to install costly new anti-pollution devices.

title: Excavation's Finding at Mosque Site in India Could Fuel Dispute
description: In a report likely to bolster a sometimes violent Hindu nationalist campaign to build a temple at the site of a 16th-century mosque, the Archaeological Survey of India says it has found evidence that a structure resembling an ancient Hindu temple may lie under the mosque.

title: Liberty, Security and a Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Peculiar Is the Norm As Upsets Continue
description: The surprise 400-meter champion won late at night while wearing sunglasses. A Kenyan native won the steeplechase but ran a victory lap while carrying the flag of Qatar. An American sprint phenom turned pro right out of high school. Expected champions wilted like tourists on an endless line at the Louvre.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: CHIEF OF BIGGEST STATE QUITS The chief minister of India's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, resigned after the breakup of the governing coalition that she had led. The chief minister, Mayawati, whose Bahujan Samaj Party largely represents India's lowest castes, had clashed with her Hindu nationalist coalition partners over a development proposal near the Taj Mahal. Mayawati, who uses only one name, also withdrew from the national governing coalition.    Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Following Up column on Sunday misstated the amount of money that New York City could be required to pay as a penalty if there are excessive flyovers by planes from La Guardia Airport during the United States Open. It is up to $325,000, not $325 million.

title: A Maine Seacoast Road To Labor Day Pleasure
description: ''YOU know those dense little smoked oysters you find in tins at the gourmet store?'' Rebecca Charles asked, as she dipped a hand into a pan filled with apple-wood chips and water. ''I always found them oily and heavy, and I thought, There's got to be a way to do them lightly.''

title: Sleuths Try to Stay Step Ahead of Online Worms
description: Don't talk to Mikko Hypponen about pressure. Within minutes of first receiving a sample of the SoBig.F computer worm on Tuesday morning last week, Mr. Hypponen set out to beat the clock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOOD, PAUL
description: WOOD--Paul. Farewell to a treasured friend and mentor. Your words always inspire. Liz Gribin

description: U.S. Crop Policy Is Said To Hurt Mexican Farmers

title: One Vision From 1940's Still Rocks; Jack Kirby Heroes Thrive In Comic Books and Film
description: Michael Chabon's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ''The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Klay,'' is set in the world of 1940's comics publishing. The author's acknowledgments end with this loving coda: ''Finally, I want to acknowledge the deep debt I owe in this and everything else I've ever written to the work of the late Jack Kirby, the King of Comics.''

description: Maybe It Rolled Down the Vent?

title: Japan Frees North Korean Ferry After Holding It for Day in Port
description: Japanese authorities released the ship that ferries passengers between Japan and North Korea today, after detaining it for a day in Niigata for what the Japanese said were safety violations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, ROSE
description: LEVINE--Rose. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rose Levine, beloved mother and mother-in-law of our cherished friends, Hirschell E. and Deanna E. Levine, who are dedicated to supporting Jewish and humanitarian causes. We extend our deepest sympathies to Hirschell and Deanna, and to their entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: Blair Aide Says Arms Expert Agreed With Britain on Iraq
description: LONDON, Aug. 27  Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon said today that the weapons expert cited as the source of a BBC report casting doubt on Britain's reasons for going to war in Iraq had told him he supported the government's position.

description: In percent

title: For Two Giants Backups, Second Best Is Not Bad
description: No, Coach Jim Fassel insisted today, the injuries that have sidelined two N.F.L. quarterbacks -- the Jets' Chad Pennington and Atlanta's Michael Vick -- are not the reason Kerry Collins will not play when the Giants end their preseason against Baltimore on Thursday.

title: Asian Journey; At Ease in Vietnam, Asia's New Culinary Star
description: IT is enough to daunt all but the most gluttonous of gastronomes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, ELI
description: ROSEN--Eli, 88, of Sarasota, FL. Formerly of North Woodmere, NY. Died August 25. Beloved husband of Vera Horowitz for 63 years. Devoted father of Jon of Seattle, WA and Peter (Phyllis) of Atlanta, GA. Caring grandfather of Jason and Hope of Seattle, Sarah and Elissa of Atlanta. Brother of Rose and Mildred and the late Leo, Rebecca, Florence and Dorothy. Retired owner of Sagamore Cafeteria, Borough Hall, Brooklyn. W.W. II Veteran (1943-45), participant in Southern France Invasion August 1944. Memorial service Friday, August 29 in Sarasota.

title: 'Cabaret' to Close on Nov. 2
description: ''Cabaret,'' the Roundabout Theater Company's Tony Award-winning celebration of Weimar-era decadence, will close on Nov. 2 after more than five years, its producers announced yesterday. The show will have run for 2,306 performances and 37 previews.

title: Bill on Medicare Drug Benefit Is Stalled by House-Senate Republican Antagonism
description: Congressional aides trying to write a bill providing drug benefits to millions of elderly people said today that their work had been stalled by growing disagreements and antagonism between the top Republican negotiators from the Senate and the House.

title: Inertia and Indecision
description: The bitter bottom line of the Columbia disaster comes down to this: NASA never absorbed the lessons of the Challenger explosion in 1986, and four successive American presidents never decided where America's space program should head after the cold war -- and what it would cost in dollars and risk to human life to get there.

title: Japan Is Spending Heavily to Pursue a Weak-Yen Policy
description: The Japanese government is defying the logic of the foreign exchange market by keeping the yen from rising sharply in value against the dollar.

title: The N.F.L. wants to open its season with Super Bowl intensity.
description: BY now, Madison Avenue has staked claims to large chunks of the calendar. Advertisers and agencies have either horned in on existing holidays, from Valentine's Day and Cinco de Mayo to Halloween and Christmas, or shoehorned in celebrations concocted on their own, like Don't Do Dishes Day, Egg Salad Week and Toilet Tank Repair Month.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Circuits on June 12 about video games with monster-movie themes included an outdated reference to one game, I Was an Atomic Mutant. By the time the review was published, multiple-key commands required to switch between attack modes in a demonstration version of the game, on which the review was based, had been modified to launch certain attacks with a single keystroke. The game's producer noted the change by e-mail on June 13 and provided the updated version for evaluation this month.

title: Off the Menu
description: I would never buy an antique from KEITH McNALLY , left. He is too clever at creating the century-old look. Like his restaurants Balthazar and Pastis, his latest spot, SCHILLER'S LIQUOR BAR , on the Lower East Side at Rivington and Norfolk Streets, looks like a holdover from another era. The place is all white tile, wired glass, mismatched tables and dark metal chairs. Its name harks back to the days when the neighborhood teemed with Jewish immigrants. A few specialties -- like kasha varnishkes, chopped liver mousse and a Russ & Daughters herring plate -- evoke that era, too, but Mr. McNally also slips in fish and chips, sticky toffee pudding and Cuban sandwiches. Schiller's serves breakfast, lunch and dinner, with wines labeled Cheap, Decent and Good ($12 to $17 a carafe).

title: Postwar G.I. Deaths Now Exceed Toll From War
description: More American troops have now died since President Bush declared an end to major combat on May 1 than were killed fighting the war in Iraq.

title: Glavine Avoids the Braves; Seo Beats Them Head-On
description: If anything, this season of failure and lowered expectations has taught Tom Glavine the unattractive art of appreciation. True, right now he could be wrapping up another potential Cy Young award-winning season and anticipating another October with questions of whether the Braves can win the World Series. But you cannot beat time with the family.

title: Researchers Find Zoloft, a Popular Antidepressant, to Be Effective in Treating Children
description: Zoloft, a commonly prescribed antidepressant, is effective for treating moderate to severe depression in children and adolescents, researchers are reporting today.

title: First Pick the House, and Then the Figs
description: The fig tree in the backyard was one reason Emily Wasserman, left, bought her brownstone in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, four years ago. The tree was planted by Italian immigrants about 90 years ago, according to the granddaughter of a former owner. ''I've been told that there are a number of fig trees in Brooklyn, all planted around the same time,'' Ms. Wasserman said.

title: Premium on Readiness
description: To the Editor:

title: Euro Vote Is Unlikely Soon As Britain Focuses on Iraq
description: With Britain's government embroiled in public scrutiny of its reasons for going to war against Iraq, one unexpected casualty of the conflict could well be an early vote on joining the euro single currency.

title: Study Finds Rise in Benefits For the Unemployed of 9/11
description: In one way at least, the thousands of New York City workers left jobless after 9/11 were luckier than those unemployed earlier or later -- because they were far more likely to collect benefits from New York State's unemployment insurance program.

title: IZOD PLANS 155 STORES IN CHINA
description: Izod, the resurgent sportswear brand owned by Phillips-Van Heusen, announced a deal yesterday with a Chinese company to open 155 stores in China over the next five years. The Chinese company, Hempel International Group, has signed a licensing agreement with Phillips-Van Heusen to make and sell men's and women's sportswear. A spokesman estimated yesterday that the lines would bring in $100 million in retail sales over five years. Hempel, which is based in Hangshou, plans to open five stores in 2004, with another 15 by the end of 2005. Hempel does $1 billion in sales in 160 of its own stores in China. The licensing deal also covers Hong Kong and Taiwan. Tracy Rozhon (NYT)

title: Nina Fonaroff, 89, Dancer in Graham Troupe
description: Nina Fonaroff, an early Martha Graham dancer and a choreographer and teacher, died on Aug. 14 at a hospital in London, where she lived. She was 89.

title: Questions Surround Battered Brooklyn 3-Year-Old
description: The 3-year-old Brooklyn girl weighed only 16 pounds when she was taken to the hospital. She was covered in bruises and had a skull fracture. There was a burn on her chest, possibly from a cigarette. Last night, her condition was so grave that the authorities feared that she would not live until morning, several investigators said.

title: Beyond Ribs and Fish: Pizza's Day on the Grill
description: I'M not sure there is a grilled food that impresses guests more than pizza. The results, once you get the hang of the process, are outstanding.
