description: To the Editor:

title: They Call It a Shrimp, but Seldom to Its Face
description: ''Jumbo shrimp'' is an oxymoron, but even ''jumbo'' seems inadequate to describe tiger shrimp from the Atlantic off Nigeria. These beauties, bearing mahogany and gold stripes, are about a foot long and weigh at least half a pound.

title: In a Long Presidential Race, Dean Sprints
description: Crisscrossing the country this week with Howard Dean, the underdog turned top dog who has surged toward the front of the Democratic presidential primary field, you would almost think there was an election coming up.

title: New Rules To Open Up M.T.A. Budget
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that he would invoke a rarely used provision of state law to force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to adopt new regulations intended to make its finances and budget practices more transparent.

title: U.S. Agents to Join Saudis In Terror Financing Inquiry
description: The United States will station as many as 15 F.B.I. and Internal Revenue Service investigators in Saudi Arabia in what the Bush administration is describing as an important step in cracking down on Saudi involvement in the financing of Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups, administration officials said today.

title: Every Day, an Emergency at Work (Actually 150)
description: IN her 12 years tending to the needs of the distressed, Jennifer Frederick has worked through more than a few disasters. She was among those police communication technicians (or emergency operators) handling the telephones when a van loaded with explosives destroyed part of the World Trade Center in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, MARJORIE ANN
description: TIERNEY--Marjorie Ann, 56, of Albany and New York City, died Saturday, August 23 in NYC. Funeral Mass 11:00 AM Friday, August 29 in Saint Anne's Church, 130 Boston Turnpike, Shrewsbury, MA. Visiting hours on Thursday, August 28 from 4:00-8:00 P.M. in Mercadante Funeral Home & Chapel, 370 Plantation St, Worcester, MA. www.mercadantefuneral.com for directions and information.

title: In Jerusalem, Bloomberg Carries His Solidarity Message by Bus
description: Exactly a week after a suicide bombing here that killed 21 people, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg visited this grieving city today and encouraged its leaders and residents to fight back against terrorism, saying that New Yorkers and Americans were staunch allies in that effort.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: New Term For Child-Cruelty Minister
description: Judge T. Jackson Bedford Jr. of Superior Court in Fulton County sentenced the leader of the House of Prayer, the Rev. Arthur Allen Jr., to two years in prison for violating his parole on charges of child cruelty. Judge Bedford imposed the sentence a week after the capture of Mr. Allen, who was a fugitive for five months. He and four other church members were convicted last year of whipping children in church. Mr. Allen, 71, served 90 days in jail but violated a 10-year probation, which included agreeing to hit children only with an open hand and attending anger-management counseling. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAYNOR, SEYMOUR
description: GAYNOR--Seymour. On August 26, 2003 at the age of 98. Beloved husband of the late Nina. Loving father of Gordon and Jo, and the late Stephen. Proud grandfather of Stephanie, Lane, Adam, Scott and Lauren. Cherished great grandfather of Cameron, Sophie, Chloe and Dylan. Dear uncle of Carol and Jane. A gentle and poetic optimist.

title: New Jersey Removes 10 From Foster Homes
description: Ten children have been removed from New Jersey foster homes that officials have determined are unsafe as part of a statewide review of all foster care placements, child welfare officials said today.

title: Fear of Air Bag Sends Children To Back Seat, Saving Many
description: Parents' fear of the force of air bags is leading them to banish their children from the front seats of cars, vans and S.U.V.'s, a step that had the largely collateral benefit of reducing the number of child traffic fatalities by hundreds during the six-year period ended 2001, according to a new study.

title: Senior British Official Defends Report on Danger of Iraqi Arms
description: The senior intelligence figure who compiled Britain's dossier on Iraqi arms testified today that the attention-getting claim that Saddam Hussein could deploy unconventional weapons in 45 minutes had been backed by reliable evidence and that its 11th-hour inclusion in the document had been supported by security chiefs.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: WAR GAMES COLLISION Two helicopter gunships collided while landing in one of Russia's largest military exercises in years, killing six crewmen. The crash, at an airfield in the far eastern Primorye region, marred what had been intended as a showcase of military prowess. Defense Minister Sergei B. Ivanov blamed "lightheaded bravado and air hooliganism" by the pilots for the crash.    Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Vivendi to Deal With 2 Prospective Suitors
description: The bidding for the entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal narrowed to two contenders yesterday when the company's board, after meeting in Paris, declared that it would continue talks with General Electric's NBC division and an investor group led by a previous owner, Edgar Bronfman Jr., whose family controlled the Universal entertainment empire.

title: U.S. and North Korea Hold Side Meeting at 6-Nation Talks
description: BEIJING, Aug. 27  The United States and North Korea had their first face-to-face meeting in four months today as part of broader six-nation negotiations on ending North Korea's nuclear program, but diplomats downplayed prospects for an early breakthrough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HASLER, SIDNEY
description: HASLER--Sidney. Of New York, NY on August 25. Father of Wendy Moro & Denyse Coker. Grandfather of Perry Coker and Dean Moro. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ. For information, Gutterman-Musicant, 800-522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSTEIN, LEONARD
description: GERSTEIN -- Leonard. The Board of Directors and members of Bocaire Country Club, Inc. record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Leonard Gerstein, on Monday, August 25, 2003. We extend condolences to all of his family. Services to be held Wednesday, August 27, 2PM, at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7340 North Federal Hwy, Boca Raton, Florida. Kurt Merl, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Outlook For Pump Maker
description: Sulzer A.G., the world's second-biggest maker of pumps, said yesterday that it expected operating profit to increase at its four main units as a result of improving demand and cost cutting. First-half net income fell 40 percent, to 25 million francs ($17.6 million), or 7.1 francs a share, from 42 million francs ($30 million), or 12 francs a share, in the period a year earlier, when earnings were increased by gains on the sale of a business and real estate. Sales fell 8 percent, to 866 million francs ($612 million). Sulzer has sold lagging units and has cut jobs.

title: The Columbia Autopsy
description: The news in the final report of the panel that investigated the accident of the space shuttle Columbia was not about what happened, but in the distressing picture it paints about what comes next. By describing the space agency's missteps in harrowing detail and tracing the accident's roots far back in organizational history, the board's 248-page critique has made it inescapably clear just how daunting the task of reviving the nation's manned space program will be.

title: 2 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq; Aid Agency Pulls Out
description: Two American soldiers were killed in Iraq today and the international relief agency Oxfam said it had pulled its non-Iraqi personnel out of the country because of the worsening violence there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRICKMAN, ROSEMARY
description: STRICKMAN -- Rosemary. Died on August 25th at her home in Rancho Mirage, CA of pancreatic cancer. Beloved wife and best friend of 56 years to Arthur, adored mother of Ellen Walsh (Michael), Wendy Hoffman (Ted) and Nancy Stein (Bradley). Devoted RoRo to Arthur, Zachary, William and Perry. Good friend to many on both coasts. Rosemary fought her illness with courage, grace and wit right up to the end. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service and celebration of Rosemary's life will be held at a later date in Rancho Mirage. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCan), 2221 Rosecrans Avenue, Suite 131, El Segundo, CA. 90245.

title: A Shadowy Kind of War Still Grips Liberia's Countryside
description: ''There are thousands of us coming down the road,'' said George J. Foday Sr., a high school English teacher turned terrified refugee. ''Many thousands, and thousands more behind us.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: EasyJet Share Sale
description: The European no-frills airline, EasyJet, said its founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, left, sold 2 percent of the carrier to help finance bus, pizza, hotel and cruise ventures. Mr. Haji-Ioannou, who last year stepped down as chairman of EasyJet, sold eight million shares of the airline, reducing his EasyGroup holding company's stake to 70.1 million shares, or 17.8 percent, the carrier said in a Regulatory News Service statement. EasyJet is based in Luton, England.

title: Two Former Priests Moved By a Massachusetts Prison
description: Two former priests convicted of sexual abuse of children have been moved to the hospital wing of their prison after the killing of another jailed priest last weekend, prison officials said today.

title: About New York; In This Mess, Memory Lane Is a Foot Wide
description: FROM somewhere deep in the canyons of memorabilia there comes a faint crash, and what has fallen this time is anyone's guess. It could be that an avalanche of dead-celebrity accessories has sent Vincent Price's top hat toppling. Or maybe a spill of publicity stills has oiled the floor with forced grins.

description: Following are excerpts from the report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board, which was released yesterday.

description: If the inspiration for Angela Haynes to find her way from the tough streets of Compton, Calif., to the more refined world of professional tennis came from the success of Serena and Venus Williams, it came before she could even lift a racket.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: New Prime Minister
description: In a major cabinet reshuffle, the leader of the military junta, Gen. Than Shwe, divested himself of one of his titles, prime minister, to be replaced by Gen. Khin Nyunt, the government announced. General Khin Nyunt, who has headed military intelligence as one of the top three junta members, is seen by diplomats as more flexible than his hard-line associates. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: A Tale of Sex, Money and Politics, in 'Mayberry'
description: It has all the sordid elements of the perfect scandal: sex, money and politicians.

title: Air Force Lease With Boeing Seen Adding Billions to Cost
description: In harsh, but measured words, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office yesterday criticized a proposed $20 billion plan by the Air Force to lease 100 Boeing 767 air refueling tankers as being far more costly than expected and for failing to meet government rules on operating leases.

title: Artists' Haven: No Electricity, but What Views
description: Creaky, mice-infested and barely accessible, the 18 wooden shacks nestled among sand dunes here don't seem like much of a summer prize.

title: Limited Drama at Open as Some Top Seeds Advance
description: Kim Clijsters, the top-seeded woman, and Roger Federer, the No. 2-seeded man, advanced easily on a routine day at the United States Open today. What drama there was came from a familiar source.

title: Liberty, Security and a Law
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Weighs U.N. Command in Iraq, but With a Condition
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  The Bush administration signaled for the first time today that it might be willing to allow a multinational force in Iraq to operate under the sponsorship of the United Nations as long it was led by an American commander.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about protests in some Episcopal parishes over the ratification of the denomination's first openly gay bishop misstated the given name of a board member of Trinity Episcopal Church in Columbus, Ga., who opposed withholding money from the Atlanta Diocese. He is Michael Ankerich, not Mark.

title: U.S. Cuts Off Financing for AIDS Program, Provoking Furor
description: The State Department has discontinued financing for a small but well-regarded AIDS program for African and Asian refugees because it contends that one of the groups involved in the project supports forced abortions and involuntary sterilization in China, officials said this week.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: MINOR QUAKE FELT IN TWO STATES A minor earthquake rumbled through Hunterdon County yesterday afternoon, rattling dishes and startling residents in central New Jersey and Pennsylvania but injuring no one, according to the United States Geological Survey. There were no immediate reports of damage, said Butch Kinerney, a spokesman for the federal agency. The earthquake began at 2:24 p.m. and had a magnitude of 3.8. With a center about 10 miles southeast of Easton, Pa., the quake was felt as far east as East Brunswick, N.J., and as far south as Philadelphia, he said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: NASA Chief Promises Overhaul of Space Agency's Culture
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  The head of NASA pledged today that the space agency would be guided by the sharp criticism leveled by an investigative board this week, not merely for the sake of efficiency but out of solemn obligation to the astronauts lost on the shuttle Columbia.

title: Car Sales Slow Despite Spending on Incentives
description: In another sign of how competitive the car market has become, auto companies spent a record amount on incentives in July, yet their vehicles sat unsold on dealers' lots for a record length of time.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOOHER, EDWARD W.
description: TOOHER--Edward W. of Glen Head, NY, on August 25, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy (nee Roche). Loving father of Mark E. and Pat Weiss of Massapequa, NY, Kate and Rudy Carrano of Ossining, NY, and Paul and Julie of Norcross, GA. Dear grandfather of Erin, Patrick, Peter, Jen, Kate and Meghan. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Head, NY. Funeral Mass 9:30 A.M. Saturday, St. Boniface Martyr Church, Seacliff, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Contributions may be made to Regis High School, 55 East 84 Street, New York, New York 10028-0884.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Lawyer Guilty Of Stealing
description: A lawyer accused of embezzling more than $2 million from clients, much of it from an autistic man who then lost his home, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of theft. The lawyer, Dennis O'Brien, 61, admitted to Judge Linda G. Baxter that he stole money from 33 elderly clients' trust accounts to pay personal expenses. The autistic man, Ronnie Mich, 61, had the largest single loss, about $1.2 million. Mr. Mich was forced to move out of his Audubon home. Mr. O'Brien, who will be sentenced on April 2, faces up to 20 years in prison and up to 5 years to be served concurrently for violating probation for a similar case in 1999. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEELINGS, TOM
description: FEELINGS--Tom. Illustrator and Artist. Passed away on Monday, August 25, 2003. He is survived by his mother, three sons and a daughter.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Comtech Raises 4th-Quarter Earnings Estimate
description: The Comtech Telecommunications Corporation, a maker of data- and voice-transmission products, said yesterday that it had earned as much as 26 cents a share in the fiscal fourth quarter because of higher sales. Shares rose 29 percent. Comtech said in a statement that it had earned 24 cents to 26 cents, higher than its earlier estimate of 18 cents to 19 cents. The company had a net loss of about 3 cents in the period a year earlier, the chief financial officer, Robert Rouse, said. Sales in the quarter ended in July were about $51 million. The company now expects to earn 75 cents to 78 cents for the full year, Mr. Rouse said. It had been expected to earn 70 cents, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Its shares rose $5.15, to $22.95.

title: Car and Camp Bus Collide, Injuring 2 Teenagers and Child
description: Two teenagers and a child were seriously injured yesterday when a school bus taking 11 children home from a day camp on Long Island collided with a car here, the authorities said.

title: New Jersey Governor Draws Line On Nets
description: In the latest round of high-stakes poker over the fate of New Jersey's professional sports franchises, Gov. James E. McGreevey yesterday ruled out any new subsidies for current or future owners of the Nets and the Devils, despite a threat that the teams could move to New York.

title: Leiter to Join Fox for Playoffs
description: With the Mets probably headed for a last-place finish in the National League East, pitcher Al Leiter will not compete in the playoffs, but he will have a prominent role in them, as a part of the Fox broadcast team. A person who spoke with Leiter and with officials from the television network said Leiter would be the third broadcaster in the booth for one of the League Championship Series.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Milford: Manager Dies At Sex Shop Dies
description: The manager of a controversial sex paraphernalia store has died inside the store, apparently of a heart attack, employees said. The manager, Gary Cohen, 52, of Newington, collapsed on Saturday in the hallway of the Penthouse Boutique, a store that sells sex toys and fetish clothing. The store opened last month to public protest by residents of Milford. Mr. Cohen, a married father of three, helped manage the store and opened other stores in the chain. Chari Bruni, an employee, said yesterday that Mr. Cohen took the protest in stride. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Names Storage Chief
description: Darren Thomas, who worked for several years at Compaq and who has tried his hand at start-ups, will lead Dell's storage unit, the company confirmed yesterday. A Dell spokesman, Bruce Anderson, said that Mr. Thomas, who holds the title of vice president for storage at Dell, worked at Compaq for more than a decade and held jobs in its storage group. More recently, he founded Zambeel, a storage company that has since closed. Mr. Thomas will report to John Medica and Jeff Clarke, who lead Dell's product groups. The former chief of Dell's storage group, Russ Holt, will become a vice president for enterprise engineering, a group that oversees the design of storage systems and servers.

title: Aid Workers: Dangerous Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Administrator Sean O'Keefe's Statement
description: The following is text from NASA Administrator Sean O'Keefe's statement regarding the Columbia Accident Investigation Board's report. He delivered the statement in Washington, D.C. this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARTLAND, JOHN J.
description: GARTLAND--John J. The trustees, faculty, staff and students of The Culinary Institute of America (CIA) pay tribute to the life and philanthropy of John J. Gartland, Honorary Trustee. As senior partner at Corbally, Gartland & Rappleyea, Mr. Gartland was instrumental in the college's move to Hyde Park in 1972. As president of the James J. McCann Foundation, he supported the CIA, funding student facilities and scholarships. Jack Gartland was a leader who truly impacted the quality of life in the Hudson Valley. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Mr. Gartland's family, friends and colleagues.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Minor Quake Felt In Two States
description: A minor earthquake rumbled through Hunterdon County yesterday afternoon, rattling dishes and startling residents in central New Jersey and Pennsylvania but injuring no one, according to the United States Geological Survey. There were no immediate reports of damage, said Butch Kinerney, a spokesman for the federal agency. The earthquake began at 2:24 p.m. and had a magnitude of 3.8. With a center about 10 miles southeast of Easton, Pa., the quake was felt as far east as East Brunswick, N.J., and as far south as Philadelphia, he said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lobbying Fees Reach Record
description: City lobbyists earned a record $22.6 million in fees last year, up from $20.4 million in 2001 and more than twice the amount in 1997, City Clerk Victor L. Robles reported yesterday. The top earner from groups seeking to influence city legislation was the law firm of Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker. It received $1.7 million from clients, including Consolidated Edison, Forest City Ratner, the Hotel Association of New York City and the Greater New York Hospital Association. Wilson, Elser, with offices in 15 cities, including New York and Albany, was the top firm for the past five years in earnings from lobbying activities. It was the top-earning lobbying firm in state government last year as well. The top 10 city lobbyists accounted for 48 percent of the total earnings. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: The Gold Rush: As Other Pears Sleep, Bartletts Head to Market
description: THE Sacramento Delta's Bartlett pear district is a swampy anomaly in the arid, rapidly suburbanizing landscape of north-central California. Winding levee roads run level with the upper branches of a sea of lush green trees, dotted by modest farmhouses and occasional Victorian mansions. There's even a funkily decrepit rural Chinatown. The pear growers, many of whose families arrived with the gold rush, like to boast of their century-old groves.

title: Old Kremlin, New Kremlin: It's Still a Big Secret
description: This summer's biggest scandal the prosecution swirling around Russia's richest and most powerful company, Yukos Oil -- has spawned endless speculation about who really wields power under President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: OREGON: BREEZES MAY EXPAND FIRES Steady warm breezes from the west threatened to expand two fires in central Oregon. Officials said the blazes were 20 percent contained, with no end in sight. The fires that make up the B & B Complex fire cover 39,000 acres of national forest and the Warm Springs Indian Reservation and have prompted the removal of 300 people from a village, Camp Sherman. The two largest fires in the nation, each burning 45,000 acres in northwestern Montana, were mostly contained. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Market Place; Shareholders Win in Effort To Alter Pay
description: For what seems like forever, activist shareholders have been fighting to rein in runaway executive pay -- and losing every battle. Yesterday, the forces against excessive compensation won one.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Court Appoints Panel For Recall
description: The Supreme Court appointed a five-member elections board to organize a recall referendum that could end the presidency of Hugo Chvez in as little as 90 days. The board's first duty is to verify the 3.2 million signatures collected by adversaries of Mr. Chvez demanding his ouster. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Some Recommended Changes Are Already Occurring
description: Despite its harsh criticism of NASA's culture, the panel investigating the loss of the Columbia did not require the space agency to meet harsh new conditions before resuming shuttle flights, which could be as soon as next March.

title: 'Henry, What's New?': Kissinger in Action
description: CRISIS

title: Bush Declares Violence in Iraq Tests U.S. Will
description: President Bush characterized the continuing fighting in Iraq today as ''a point of testing in the war on terror,'' and vowed that the United States would not back down there or anywhere it confronts violent Islamic extremism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Views Vary
description: Germany's economy is still slumping, but hopes for a brighter future are taking hold. The Ifo Institute reported in its monthly survey of businesses that sentiment rose in August for the fourth consecutive month. The jump, to 90.8 from 89.3, in July was greater than analysts had expected. Business people remain gloomy about current economic conditions, with retail sales still weak. Manufacturers and wholesalers, however, are more confident. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Jim Beam Brands Picks New Agency
description: The Jim Beam Brands Company in Deerfield, Ill., said yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative part of its account, which had been handled by the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Leaders of California's Largest Union Vote to Raise Large Amounts to Defeat Davis Recall
description: The leadership of California's most powerful labor union voted today to oppose the recall of Gov. Gray Davis and promised to spend millions on an anti-recall campaign.

title: Traces of Enriched Uranium Are Reportedly Found in Iran
description: International inspectors have found traces of highly enriched uranium at an Iranian facility, according to a new confidential report distributed today. The traces could be an indication that Tehran has already produced weapons-grade nuclear materials.

title: Frederick Deming, 90, Banker And Treasury Dept. Official
description: Frederick L. Deming, an under secretary of the Treasury in the Johnson administration and a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, died Thursday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 90.

title: A Boot Camp in Israel Where the Drill Is Opera
description: His sweet tenor voice blooms from a handsome face atop the body of a former football lineman. No wonder the Metropolitan Opera anointed him with admission to its career-making development program, or that Plcido Domingo is giving him advice.

title: Japan's Bulls Chilled by Cool Snap
description: Just as the bulls were starting to return to Tokyo, Japan's economy appears to have hit a bump on the road to recovery. The culprit this time is not the banks or a major corporate collapse, but the coldest summer in a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRAWFORD, EUNICE
description: CRAWFORD -- Eunice. Of Liberty Corner, New Jersey, and Rockville Centre, NY. An active AGO organist, musician, family matriarch, and devout Christian, we wish her spirit a safe journey onward. Memorial service Thursday August 28, 2003 at 2 P.M. at The Presbyterian Church, Liberty Corner, New Jersey.

title: Excerpts From Report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board, which was released yesterday. The full text is online at nytimes.com/columbia.

title: Hollywood's Buying Back Stock, and Its Chief Is Selling
description: Hollywood Entertainment , which runs the Hollywood Video chain of stores, wants to buy back at least $30 million worth of its shares. Its chairman and chief executive, Mark J. Wattles, wants to sell almost as much.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Bomb Suspect Tries To Void Civil Verdict
description: A lawyer in Birmingham has filed a motion to set aside a $115 million civil verdict against Eric R. Rudolph, the bombing suspect, because he was not served with the suit and is too poor to afford a lawyer. Emily Lyons, a nurse who was blinded in one eye in an explosion at an abortion clinic in Birmingham, sued Mr. Rudolph in 2000, while he was in hiding. The lawyer, Emory Anthony, says the Lyonses' lawyer should have asked the court to print a notice of the suit in the newspaper. Mr. Rudolph was told of the suit after his arrest on May 31 and did not respond or appear at the trial this summer. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Oklahoma Files Fraud Charges Against WorldCom
description: The legal morass engulfing WorldCom thickened today as Oklahoma charged the telecommunications giant and six former executives, including Bernard J. Ebbers, the company's longtime chief executive, with 15 felony violations of the state's securities laws.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Banks Post Profits
description: Three of Canada's big five banks reported higher quarterly earnings today, with improved investment banking business and lower loan-loss provisions offsetting the strong Canadian dollar on revenues from American operations. The Royal Bank of Canada improved net income 7 percent, to 776 million Canadian dollars ($554 million). The Bank of Nova Scotia's earnings rose 11 percent, to 626 million Canadian dollars ($447 million), and the Bank of Montreal reported a 46 percent increase in earnings to 504 million Canadian dollars ($360 million). The period, which ended July 31, was their fiscal third quarter. Royal Bank and Bank of Montreal raised their quarterly dividends. Bank of Nova Scotia increased its payout earlier this year. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROILES, MELVYN L.
description: BROILES--Melvyn L. On August 26, 2003. Loving husband of Teresa Broiles. Devoted father of Karen. A member of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra for 44 years as Principal Trumpeter and Professor of Music at the Juilliard School of Music. The family will receive friends Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madsion Ave at 81 St. Funeral service Friday, 11AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: 'Raymond' Actor Reaches Deal With CBS
description: CBS and Brad Garrett, a star of the network's hit comedy ''Everybody Loves Raymond,'' settled their salary dispute yesterday, the network said last night.

title: Liberty, Security and a Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, pictures of two paintings yesterday with an article about an exhibition of the work of the Mexican painter Gunther Gerzso at the Santa Barbara Museum of Art in California were printed as negative images. The pictures are reprinted at right: a self-portrait (1945) and ''Nocturnal Landscape'' (1999).

title: Clinton and Nadler Seek Inquiry Into E.P.A. Response to Sept. 11
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Jerrold L. Nadler called yesterday for a Congressional inquiry into the Environmental Protection Agency's response to the World Trade Center attack, saying that the agency and the White House had not told the truth about potential health hazards.

title: The Magic of Comics! While Batman Turns 64, A Fan Goes Back to 9
description: In some ways, not much has changed in the old neighborhood. J. Jonah Jameson and The Daily Bugle still loathe the Amazing Spider-Man. Archie Andrews is still a goofy red-headed kid being lovingly tortured by Betty and Veronica. The Incredible Hulk, eloquent as ever, still utters, ''Hulk smash!''

title: TECO ENERGY TO SELL POWER PLANT
description: Teco Energy Inc., which is trying to avert a credit-rating cut, agreed to sell a power plant in Florida for $115 million to a private equity firm, GTCR Golden Rauner, and closely held Invenergy. The buyers, based in Chicago, will assume the plant's debt, which was $103 million on Dec. 31, a spokeswoman for Teco, Laura Plumb, said. Teco, based in Tampa, Fla., will continue to operate the plant in Hardee County, Fla., after the sale.

title: Father, Vowing Suit, Says Police Beating Killed His Son, 22
description: The father of a 22-year-old Washington Heights man who died after being pepper-sprayed and restrained by the police is suing the city, claiming that the officers attacked his son, Jose A. Mateo, without cause.

title: U.S. Team Heeds Warning And Avoids Another Upset
description: Nearly every day since the United States men's basketball team gathered to train for the Olympic qualifying tournament, the assistant coach Gregg Popovich has harped on one message and one game, voicing the thoughts that have tormented him for a year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Ex-Judge Is Under House Arrest
description: A retired judge accused of traveling abroad to have sex with a minor was released on bail yesterday from a federal detention center and placed under house arrest. The retired State Superior Court judge, Stephen W. Thompson, 57, is charged with traveling to Russia to have sex with a boy between the ages of 13 and 16, prosecutors said. He is charged with two federal felonies, which carry a total of 25 years in prison. Mr. Thompson was released yesterday on $2 million bail and placed under 24-hour house arrest at his home in Avalon under the supervision of his mother, Mildred Thompson. A federal magistrate banned Mr. Thompson from having contact with children, except for supervised visits with his nieces, and from using a computer, which could be used to obtain pornography. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: Pakistan Criticized as India Bombing Toll Rises to 52
description: The death toll from two powerful bombs planted on Monday in taxis here rose to 52 today, as the blasts threatened to derail a fragile reconciliation between India and Pakistan.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Company Cuts Jobs And Shuts Offices
description: The Computer Network Technology Corporation, which provides software and hardware for computer storage networks, cut about 150 jobs after it combined some operations and closed offices. The company said yesterday that it expected to save about $20 million from its cost-cutting, more than its initial forecasts of savings of up to $15 million. The company said its second-quarter loss widened to $25.8 million, from $2.1 million a year earlier. Revenue almost doubled to $96.7 million in the period ended July 31, from $48.9 million in the period a year earlier. Computer Networks expects to have revenue of $100 million to $110 million on earnings of 3 cents to 7 cents a share, excluding certain costs. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, the company is expected to earn 6 cents, the average of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

title: Amateur Has Lead At the Met Open
description: Andrew Svoboda sank a hole-in-one yesterday and finished with a five-under-par 67 to take the lead after the first round of the Met Life/Met Open at the Metedeconk National Golf Club in Jackson, N.J.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Indian Pt. Escape Questioned
description: Westchester County is continuing to question safety plans for the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y. The county has filed an administrative appeal of a ruling last month by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that approved the plan to evacuate a 10-mile area around the plant in case of a disaster. Charlene M. Indelicato, the county's lawyer, said Westchester was seeking information on how the agency concluded that the plant was safe despite misgivings from local communities about the plan. Mike Beeman, a spokesman for the agency, said he had not seen the appeal and would not have any comment until officials had reviewed it. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: U.S. Set to Take a Hard Line In Talks on Korean Arms
description: North Korea will come under intense diplomatic pressure to scrap its nuclear weapons program on Wednesday as the United States, North Korea and its four neighbors begin unusual six-party negotiations on how to resolve the Korean arms crisis.

title: U.S. DENIES SBC ON LONG-DISTANCE REQUEST
description: SBC Communications has failed to win Justice Department support for its bids to enter the $7 billion market for long-distance service in four states. SBC applied last month for long-distance approval in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Wisconsin, where it has 15 million local-phone lines, or 27 percent of its total lines. The Justice Department said yesterday in its decision that SBC had issued inaccurate bills to carriers who buy wholesale local services on its network. The Federal Communications Commission, which can rule on the application independently of the Justice Department's recommendation, has until Oct. 15 to make its decision.

title: Rabbi Accused of Stealing Grant Intended for Disabled Children
description: An orthodox rabbi in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with stealing about $700,000 in federal grant money that was supposed to go toward building a school for disabled children.

title: Jets Sign Another Quarterback
description: The Jets signed the veteran quarterback Jamie Martin to a one-year deal today, ending their search for an experienced backup to Vinny Testaverde. The rookie Brooks Bollinger will go into the season opener at Washington as the backup, but depending on how quickly Martin learns the Jets' offense, Martin could be the backup for subsequent games.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a report by the General Accounting Office on how the Bush administration developed its energy policy referred incorrectly to several groups that advised Vice President Cheney's energy task force. The groups, which the report described as ''principally petroleum, coal, nuclear, natural gas and electricity industry representatives and lobbyists,'' were from the private sector; they were not ''federal.''

title: Human Error Likely Cause Of Blackout, Timeline Says
description: Investigators of North America's biggest blackout say all signs from a nearly completed timeline point to human errors in the early stages in Ohio on Aug. 14 as the cause of the cascade into darkness.

title: U.S. Corn Subsidies Said to Damage Mexico
description: The more than $10 billion that American taxpayers give corn farmers every year in agricultural subsidies has helped destroy the livelihoods of millions of small Mexican farmers, according to a report to be released on Wednesday.

title: Seeds of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the death of the following American in Iraq:

title: CATALINA MARKETING DELAYS REPORTING RESULTS
description: The Catalina Marketing Corporation, which provides coupons and marketing services, said its auditor resigned and it had delayed filing earnings reports. It also said previously filed financial results were not reliable. Catalina's shares fell $2.57, or 21 percent, to $12.58 each after it disclosed the news. The company, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said on Monday that Ernst & Young had resigned as its auditor and the filing of its fiscal 2003 and first-quarter earnings reports would be delayed. Catalina said it was searching for a new auditor to review results from 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLANAGAN, GLORIA
description: FLANAGAN -- Gloria. The Center for Discovery Family extends its heartfelt sympathy to Arthur Flanagan and his family on the death of his loving mother Gloria. She was an impassioned advocate for the disabled and her legacy will live on through her children. She will be missed. The Center for Discovery

title: Two Bad Girls Look Good To an Awkward Shopgirl
description: Diego Lerman, the director of the moody, chiaroscuro character piece ''Suddenly,'' uses that title to comment on the changes that swarm over the three teenage girls at the center of his myth-adventures. But actually nothing happens suddenly because Mr. Lerman creates an intimate power play to contradict the jagged sharpness of the material; ''Suddenly'' was filmed in a stark, rough, black-and-white style that grabs your sympathy immediately.

title: Jets Are Getting Serious About Their Running Game
description: Ask center Kevin Mawae how he thinks Curtis Martin has played in the preseason, and a moment of levity finally finds its way into the Jets' depressing week.

title: Chowders Define a Williamsburg Sand Bar
description: WHAT a strange and maddening, almost wonderful experience is Hurricane Hopeful. The restaurant first opened on North Seventh Street in the leafy Hipchester district of northern Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in a tiny store dominated by thrashed surfing equipment and the scratchy sounds of weather radios hung from the walls. The menu was a rotating list of chowders. The vibe was takeout. The quality was excellent.

title: Fire or Ice? Both Suffice
description: TAMARIND, mango and pineapple are refreshing flavors on their own on a hot summer day, but they were not enough to satisfy Maria and Demetrio Aguirre. The couple, who are from the state of Michoacn in southwestern Mexico, take the juice of those fruits, mix them with a potent chili powder and freeze them into ice pops. The pops, which they sell at their store, Paletera La Michoacna in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, pack a palate-searing punch that is quickly soothed by the ice.

title: Need Milk? Expect a Bigger Bite
description: For Rafael Martinez, it is bad enough that the price of milk will go up 47 cents per gallon on Monday. But worse, the increase will arrive the same week he has to buy notebooks, sneakers and pencils for his two children going back to school in Washington Heights.

title: Mazda's President Is Chosen to Run Ford in Europe
description: The Ford Motor Company said tonight that it had named Lewis Booth, Mazda's chief executive, to run Ford's struggling European division.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; As Factory Jobs Vanish, There's Value in Buildings
description: Nearly a third of New Jersey's manufacturing jobs have disappeared since 1990, leaving thousands in need of jobs and numerous old factory buildings in search of new uses if they are to be productive again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREY, FLORENCE MAIER
description: GREY--Florence Maier, 81, of cancer on August 21, 2003. Florence Maier was a top fashion illustrator for 50 years. Her clients included Bergdorf Goodman, Saks Fifth Avenue, B. Altman, Macy's, Gimbel's, Women's Wear Daily, the New York Times Magazine, Seventeen Magazine, Jacobsen's department stores, Marshall's, Kaufman's, Simplicity Patterns, and McCall's. She was the first employer of supermodel Naomi Sims. Mrs. Grey had homes in New York City, Key Biscayne, FL, and Bridgehampton NY. She is survived by her husband, Jerry Grey (a professor at Princeton), her sister Roslyn Lesser of Naples, FL, and her niece Elizabeth Fryer of Wilmington, MA. Memorial donations in her name should be sent to the East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978-7048. There will be memorial gatherings to celebrate her life at the Bridgehampton Community House, Bridgehampton, NY at 4 PM on Sunday, September 7th and in the Casa Del Mar ballroom, Key Biscayne, FL at 4 PM on Sunday, October 26th.

title: The Jihad All-Stars
description: Yep, we've got 'em right where we want 'em.

title: High School Seniors Get Highest SAT Math Scores in 35 Years
description: The scores of high school seniors on the SAT math exam have climbed to their highest level in 35 years. Experts tied the gain to the growing number of students learning algebra in the eighth grade and taking more advanced courses in math after reaching high school.

title: Excellent Box, Sir
description: ''NICE sangria,'' the woman said, raising her tinkling glass in friendly salute.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Sues To Stop Online Spoofers
description: Amazon.com Inc., the Internet retailer, said yesterday that it had filed lawsuits to stop a handful of online marketers from illegally using its name. Amazon said it would seek millions of dollars in punitive damages from ''spoofers,'' whose e-mail messages falsely identify the sender. The suits were filed in seven federal district courts in the United States and in the Superior Court of Justice in Ontario.

title: Fired Auditors Questioned SureBeam's Revenue Policy
description: The SureBeam Corporation, which last week fired its audit firm, said last night that the auditors had questioned the company's basic method of recognizing revenue as well as two specific transactions.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Sentence Cut
description: In an unusual move, an appeals court reduced to 5 years from 13 years the prison sentence of a political dissident, Pham Hong Son, 35, who had used the Internet to promote democracy. The case, in which the defendant was convicted of espionage in June, drew wide condemnation from rights groups, who said it was the harshest punishment levied against a dissident in years. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNN, PAULINE
description: DUNN--Pauline. The Member Fleets of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade are saddened by the untimely passing of Pauline Dunn, wife of Mitchell, fellow respected NYC Yellow Medallion Taxicab Fleet Operator. Our thoughts and prayers are with Mitch, his three daughters and the entire family during this painful time. The Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade Ronald Sherman, President Jean Barrett, Exec. Director

title: Library Gets A Trove A Cartoonist Collected
description: The Library of Congress today acquired the nation's largest and most comprehensive private collection of original cartoon and caricature drawings, assembled over 60 years by the political cartoonist J. Arthur Wood Jr.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Business Briefing | Australia: Brewer's Profit Falls
description: Australia's largest brewer, the Foster's Group, reported an 18 percent decline in net income for fiscal 2003, with earnings squeezed by a competitive wine market in the United States and a restructuring charge to revitalize the company's dominant beer unit. After more than two years of expanding its Beringer Blass wine operations, Foster's profit margins are being pressured as United States drinkers take advantage of the abundance of inexpensive wine. Net income for the year, which ended June 30, was 462.9 million Australian dollars ($305 million), down from 560.9 million Australian dollars ($365 million) a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.5 percent , to 4.73 billion Australian dollars ($3.08 billion) Excluding one-time items, Fosters said profit rose 9 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about museum exhibitions in Washington misstated the race of Lesley Dill, whose 10-year retrospective at the National Museum of Women in the Arts touches on the issue of racial difference. She is white, not black. The review also misstated the year that Ms. Dill began incorporating verses of Emily Dickinson's poetry into her art. It was 1990, not 1994. The review also referred incorrectly to photographic images imprinted on fabric work by Ms. Dill. Her own image was not among them.

title: Texas Standoff
description: Political standoff is morphing into paralytic farce in the Texas Legislature. A special session ended in Austin yesterday with Democrats holding fast in their out-of-state exile against a brazen attempt by the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, to pick up six seats by gerrymandering incumbent Democrats out of power. The 11 Democratic state senators who foiled the power grab by fleeing last month are still in New Mexico, vowing to stay there as long as necessary. Gov. Rick Perry is just as firm in doing Mr. DeLay's bidding, promising another special session to once more seek redistricting -- the only question is when.

title: GUIDANT PLANS TO BUY BACK $250 MILLION IN SHARES
description: The Guidant Corporation said yesterday it would buy back as much as $250 million in shares in the next year and begin seeking European approval for its new drug-coated heart stent. The buyback is intended to offset declining values of stock-based compensation programs. In its last such announcement, Guidant said in 2001 that it would buy back as much as $200 million in shares. The company said it planned to file preliminary findings to European regulators this week for its stent, a tube used in heart patients to hold open arteries that have been cleared through surgery. The drug coating is designed to help prevent new tissue growth that may clog arteries. Guidant, based in Indianapolis, is the largest maker of bare-metal stents.

title: Where There's Smoke, There's Desire
description: Chefs all over town may dream of owning fancy restaurants, but some might secretly prefer to be Adam Perry Lang, left, who just opened Daisy May's BBQ USA at 623 11th Avenue (46th Street), a bright little takeout storefront that is serious about authentic barbecue. It fits right in on a gritty street of auto repair shops and lumberyards.

title: Clemens's Night Cut Short by Long Home Runs
description: Roger Clemens's mother, Bess, threw out the ceremonial first pitch at Yankee Stadium last night. Then she kissed her son before he warmed up to face the Chicago White Sox. It was a pitching change the Yankees never should have made.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Cites E-Mail As Evidence
description: Internal e-mail messages of the Oracle Corporation show executives knew that their hostile bid for PeopleSoft would hurt sales of PeopleSoft's software and urged analysts to advise clients to delay purchases of the stock, PeopleSoft said in court documents. Oracle said the e-mail messages, released yesterday, were taken out of context. The messages were part of an amended complaint filed by PeopleSoft against Oracle on Aug. 12. Oracle is trying to buy PeopleSoft for $7.25 billion. An Oracle spokesman, Jim Finn, said PeopleSoft's complaint was ''rife with comments taken out of context as PeopleSoft continues to litigate the issue in the court of public opinion.'' Oracle offered $16 a share on June 6, four days after PeopleSoft said it was buying J. D. Edwards. Oracle increased its offer to $19.50 a share on June 18. PeopleSoft has rejected the offers and is suing Oracle in state court in Alameda County, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, CAROLYN S.
description: MEYER--Carolyn S., 91, died August 26, 2003, in Columbia, S.C., and previously lived in Glen Head, and Katonah, NY. Mayflower descendant and graduate of Westover School, wife of J. Edward Meyer, Jr., deceased, and devoted grande-dame of the family, sons, J. Edward Meyer III, and D. title: Tangled Up in Blue As Wild Berries Outgrow Demand
description: ''WE made blueberry gel nuggets and tried putting them into bagels, but they liquefied in the toaster.'' Ed Flanagan, president and chief executive of Jasper Wyman & Son, was having lunch in the backroom of the Red Barn Restaurant and reminiscing over past sales schemes. ''Then we tried making blueberry candies, but chickened out when we realized we'd be going up against the big confectioners,'' he declared, taking a swig of blueberry juice. ''Have you heard that the University of Maine is looking into adding blueberries to hamburgers,'' he said somewhat hopefully. ''All it takes is one good idea.''

title: Tallying the Dead in Iraq
description: The American intervention in Iraq has reached a disheartening milestone. With the death of an American soldier yesterday in an ambush outside Baghdad, more American military men and women have now died in the postwar period than perished during the war itself. That grim statistic mocks President Bush's triumphant appearance aboard the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln on May 1, when he declared an end to major combat operations. More important, it makes clear that the United States will pay a high price in blood and treasure if the Bush administration persists in its misguided effort to pacify and rebuild Iraq without extensive international support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUELLER, GEORGE C., M.D.
description: MUELLER--George C., M.D., of Charleston, SC (formerly of Montauk and New York, NY) died peacefully at the age of 92 on August 22. Dr. Mueller was a retired Professor of Otolaryngology at the Cornell University School of Medicine and Attending Surgeon at The New York Hospital, where he spent his entire professional career except for his military service. During World War II, he served as a flight surgeon with the Flying Tigers stationed in the China, Burma, and India Theater. His unit provided fighter cover for Merrill's Marauders as well as for transports flying over ''the hump.'' At the airfield when a fighter plane crash-landed, Dr. Mueller led the rescue of the injured pilot trapped within the burning plane. Thereafter he was awarded the Soldier's Medal for Bravery. Later in the war, he was sole survivor of an aircraft crash and was promoted to the rank of Major. He married Frances McGrath, who died 29 years later, and is survived by his second wife, Laura Forrester Mueller, by his daughter, Helene Weld, by his son-in-law, Dr. Francis Weld, and by three grandchildren, Francis Jr., Alexandra and Margaret. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 11th at 9:30AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 65 St, New York City. This will be followed by a graveside service at The Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Animal Rescue Fund, PO Box 901, Wainscott, New York 11975.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Breezes May Expand Fires
description: Steady warm breezes from the west threatened to expand two fires in central Oregon. Officials said the blazes were 20 percent contained, with no end in sight. The fires that make up the B & B Complex fire cover 39,000 acres of national forest and the Warm Springs Indian Reservation and have prompted the removal of 300 people from a village, Camp Sherman. The two largest fires in the nation, each burning 45,000 acres in northwestern Montana, were mostly contained. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Chief Of Biggest State Quits

The chief minister, Mayawati, whose Bahujan Samaj Party largely represents India's lowest castes, had clashed with her Hindu nationalist coalition partners over a development proposal near the Taj Mahal. Mayawati, who uses only one name, also withdrew from the national governing coalition. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: The Price of Not Keeping the Peace
description: The cycle of violence that is once again gripping the Middle East presents the United States with another setback in its role as regional peace broker. Never has it become more clear that diplomacy alone cannot secure a workable truce between the Israelis and Palestinians. No resolution of the conflict is possible unless the United States pressures the two parties to make concessions that they have refused for decades to make. But what tools can Washington use? What if angry combatants on both sides decide that it is in their interests to continue to fight?

description: The Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise-line operator, said its chief executive, Micky Arison, and his family planned to sell as many as 32 million shares valued at about $1.11 billion to diversify their finances. The shares, expected to be sold over the next two years, equal about 4 percent of Carnival's stock, the company said. After selling the shares, the family would still control stock representing about 31 percent of the voting rights of Carnival. Mr. Arison's father, Ted, founded Carnival in 1972 with a single ship. title: Comparing Prescription Drugs
description: The befuddled consumer can be forgiven for not knowing whether one prescription drug is better than another for any given illness. Most of the time medical experts do not know either. That is because the drugs used in this country are seldom tested against one another in head-to-head combat. Instead, each is tested separately against a placebo and then, if shown to be safe and effective, is approved for marketing. Whether a new drug is better or worse than other drugs used for the same condition is seldom determined.

title: Two Tons of Morality

It is here, at the foot of the capitol, that Jefferson Davis became president of the Confederacy in 1861. It is where, little more than a century later, in his inaugural address as governor, George C. Wallace proclaimed: ''Segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever!'' Between the capitol and the courthouse sits the Dexter Avenue King Baptist Church, where the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., working as its pastor, began his leadership of the civil rights movement.

Ivanov blamed ''lightheaded bravado and air hooliganism'' by the pilots for the crash. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Starting From Scratch

I don't know whether he was a good samaritan or simply out of his mind, but he had a big smile on his face and was waving cars here and there with the flourish of a symphony conductor. Some cars obeyed his directives, and others didn't (there are still virtually no working stoplights in Baghdad), but he was definitely better than nothing -- and he was definitely having a good time.

title: Metro Briefing: New York

Robles reported yesterday. The top earner from groups seeking to influence city legislation was the law firm of Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker. It received $1.7 million from clients, including Consolidated Edison , Forest City Ratner, the Hotel Association of New York City and the Greater New York Hospital Association. Wilson, Elser, with offices in 15 cities, including New York and Albany, was the top firm for the past five years in earnings from lobbying activities. title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: EARTHLINK SUES 100 SENDERS OF JUNK E-MAIL EarthLink, the third-largest Internet service provider, filed a federal lawsuit yesterday against 100 e-mail spammers  mostly based in Alabama and Canada  who reportedly sent millions of unwanted messages. EarthLink claims the Alabama spammers used stolen credit cards, identity theft and banking fraud to finance Internet accounts and send out more than 250 million unsolicited commercial e-mail messages. The spammers hid their identities by creating an elaborate chain of fake names and nonexistent companies, the lawsuit said. "Our investigation has been ongoing for a number of months, and this is a very tech-savvy spam ring which has made this a particularly challenging investigation," said Karen Cashion, lead lawyer for EarthLink's lawsuit. (AP)
