description: The inmate accused of strangling John J. Geoghan, the former priest who was a pedophile, was a ''highly aggressive,'' emotionally disturbed child who was placed in a state residential center at 8, according to records of his trial for a murder in 1988 that were released today.

title: General Is Said to Want to Join '04 Race
description: Wesley K. Clark, the retired four-star general who has been contemplating a run for president, has told close friends that he wants to join the Democratic race and is delaying a final decision only until he feels he has a legitimate chance of winning the nomination.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Aug. 14 about sharing a family computer referred erroneously to one aspect of hard-drive management in the Windows XP operating system. Windows XP does in fact offer the ability to restrict a single user's hard-drive space, through a feature called Disk Quotas, when the operating system is configured to use a file system called NTFS. (Some new computers with Windows XP Home Edition are shipped with NTFS as the default; others must be converted to it for Disk Quotas to be available.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, YETTA
description: SCHNEIDER--Yetta. Of Long Beach, N.Y. March 23, 1904August 25, 2003. Survivers include her sons Jack, Robert and Ira Schneider, seven grandchildren and 11 greatgrandchildren. Graveside services will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. on August 28, 2003 at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, MARJORIE ANN
description: TIERNEY--Marjorie Ann, 56, of Albany and New York City, died Saturday, August 23 in NYC. Funeral Mass 11:00 AM Friday, August 29 in Saint Anne's Church, 130 Boston Turnpike, Shrewsbury, MA. Visiting hours on Thursday, August 28 from 4:00-8:00 P.M. in Mercadante Funeral Home & Chapel, 370 Plantation St, Worcester, MA. www.mercadantefuneral.com for directions and information.

title: Monument Is Now Out of Sight, but Not Out of Mind
description: After two years of controversy, a week of protests that resembled revivals and $1 million in lawyers' fees, the Ten Commandments standoff was resolved today in about an hour, by five men and a jack.

title: So Long, Pete. We Hardly Knew You.
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including comments about Pete Sampras's retirement and interpretations of the Columbia accident report.

title: France Defends Its Flouting Of Europe's Rules on Deficits
description: Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin of France defended his country's continued violation of Europe's budget rules today, saying his primary job was to restore growth and increase employment in France.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Improved Bladder Cancer Treatment
description: For certain patients with bladder cancer, having chemotherapy before surgery can prolong life, doctors are reporting. In a study of people with locally advanced bladder cancer -- tumors that had invaded the bladder walls or nearby tissue, but not other organs -- those who received a combination of four drugs before having their bladders removed had a median survival of 77 months, as opposed to 46 months in patients who had surgery alone. The study appears in The New England Journal of Medicine. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: Guantnamo Detainees
description: To the Editor:

title: A Well-Armed Candleholder For a Change of Pace
description: This fall, your table could hold the Nordic Light candleholder instead of a fold-out paper turkey. Jonas Grundell's painted solid birch candleholder, right, stores flat, and comes with four arms ($49) or seven arms ($65).

title: Making a Tough Slam, but Unflamboyantly
description: Some popular conventions, but not all, can readily be traced to their originators. Blackwood was, as one would suppose, begun by Easley R. Blackwood. Samuel M. Stayman, however, was not the first to think of the Stayman convention, although he popularized it. The splinter convention is used worldwide, although few know its origins. Dave Cliff and Dorothy Truscott (this writer's wife), each in the New York metropolitan area, thought of it independently at the same time.

title: Sealed Indictment Is Said to Charge Bank With Fraud
description: A federal grand jury here has issued a sealed indictment charging Crdit Lyonnais, the French bank, with fraud in connection with its acquisition of the assets of a failed California insurance company a decade ago, people involved in the matter said today.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Death Sentence For Rape
description: A Jefferson Parish jury sentenced to death Patrick O. Kennedy, 38, for the aggravated rape of an 8-year-old relative. The United States Supreme Court outlawed the death sentence for rape of an adult in 1977, but the decision did not address child rape. Under a state law, aggravated rape may be punished with death if the victim is under 12. Richard Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, said the last execution for rape was in 1964. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Youth Agrees to Plea Deal in New Jersey Rampage Plot
description: The youngest of the three teenagers who were charged with planning a shooting rampage in a suburb of Camden last month pleaded guilty today to an illegal weapons charge that will lead to a sentence of at least three years in a juvenile home.

title: Kindred World In Animation
description: In the 1990's the brothers Matt and Mike Chapman hoped to achieve some notoriety in indie rock. Mike Chapman played in a band from Athens, Ga., called Hi-Score, which recorded several songs for the label Kindercore. Matt Chapman was in Tallahassee, Fla., writing clever lyrics with his group the New You, which released a locally admired CD called ''Here's Where Things Turn Around'' on AAJ Records. Neither band made it.

title: 168 Years Later, a New Night at This Opera
description: Isn't it enough that Lucia goes mad, stabs her betrothed, Arturo, to death in the bridal chamber because she cannot be with her brother's arch rival, Edgardo, then dies, causing Edgardo to kill himself?

title: Evolution on the Meat-Sex Exchange
description: SEX, TIME AND POWER

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adidas Sells Bonds
description: The German sportswear and equipment maker Adidas-Salomon said yesterday that it had completed an offer of 400 million euros ($435 million) in convertible bonds. The company said it would use the proceeds to repay debt and reduce its interest costs. The bonds, which are to be issued to institutional investors outside the United States, Canada and Japan, are set to mature in 15 years and are convertible into about four million shares after October 2009, the company said. Stock in Adidas-Salomon, which is based in Herzogenaurach, Germany, rose 4 percent. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: What We Owe the Lost Crews of NASA (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Justice Roy Moore's Last Stand
description: Chief Justice Roy Moore's embarrassing defiance of federal law ended abruptly yesterday, when a moving crew rolled his Ten Commandments monument out of the rotunda of the Alabama Supreme Court building. It is unfortunate that this confrontation, which attracted a national audience, has been seen as a showdown between Alabama and the federal government. In fact, many of the heroes are Alabamians, and many who were the most derelict in defending the Constitution and federal power work for the federal government.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA UNIT PLANS TO TRIM 25% OF STAFF
description: Putnam Lovell NBF Securities Inc., the investment-banking arm of National Bank of Canada, plans to cut 35 jobs, or a quarter of its staff, reducing costs amid a slump in mergers and acquisitions. Jobs will be cut in the equity sales, trading and research areas in the New York office, a spokeswoman, Jennifer Keese, said. The company had about 140 employees before the cuts. Putnam Lovell, which is based in New York, plans to increase staff for its advisory, merchant banking and finance areas, the company said. National Bank, based in Montreal, bought Putnam Lovell in June 2002 for an undisclosed amount to increase its merger-advisory business in the United states.

title: In Iraq, a Necessary Sacrifice?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is no doubt that the enthusiasm for the whole space effort has waned over the years. Most Americans don't know what we are doing in space.''

title: Smoltz Goes on Disabled List
description: The Braves entered play today with baseball's best record, a 14-game lead in their division and one of the game's top closers in John Smoltz. The luxury of their large lead allowed them to place Smoltz on the 15-day disabled list today to rest his ailing elbow in preparation for the playoffs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Settlement In Abuse Case
description: In the biggest known settlement in a clerical sex abuse case in Ireland, a Roman Catholic order, the Kiltegan Fathers, has paid $353,000 to a man who said he was sexually abused by a priest as a 13-year-old. The victim, now in his 30's, told the High Court in Dublin that he was abused by the Rev. Peter Kennedy over several months in 1982, including an assault in the bedroom where his father lay dying of cancer. Father Kennedy, who faces charges of sexually abusing 18 people, is thought to be in hiding in Brazil. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Venezuela Looks to the Ballot Box
description: Recall elections poorly serve functioning democracies, as California's contortions amply demonstrate. In a country as sharply riven as Venezuela, however, efforts to organize a midterm referendum on the political future of President Hugo Chvez could result in a peaceful, democratic resolution of what is now a dangerous standoff.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: OSHA Cites Gristedes
description: The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has charged the Manhattan grocery store chain Gristedes with 73 safety violations at eight locations after an employee's arm was severed in a machine. The company was cited, among other things, for having walk-in freezers that cannot be opened from the inside. Gristedes faces a maximum fine of $186,500. In February, an employee at an East 96th Street store lost his arm in a machine called a cardboard baler. OSHA said the machine had no guard to prevent contact with its moving parts. Gristedes officials did not return a call for comment. John Catsimatidis, above, president of Gristedes, told The Associated Press that OSHA was right about the safety problems, but he denied that the company was at fault in the accident. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, HOWARD
description: KATZ--Howard. On August 26, 2003. Age 81. In Boca Raton, FL. Cherished husband of Gilda for 56 years. Adored father of Alan (Randi), Stuart (Carmen) and Jonathan (Robin). Beloved grandfather of Andrea, Sandra, Danielle, Derek, Stefanie, Pamela. Dear brother of Ira and Arlene. Patriarch and patriot. A proud son of Abraham. Above all, his life was a blessing. Alev Hashalom. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Red Magen David Adom. Services today, 1PM at Temple Beth El, S.W. 4th Avenue, Boca Raton, FL.

title: 'Mitigation' Is Desecration
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine-Tuning the Sound in Your Own Cinema
description: THE DVD may herald a new era in entertainment, but it has also brought home audio to a complicated new level.

title: Workers' Strike Hinders Arrival of Yale Students
description: More than 2,500 of Yale University workers went on strike today as undergraduates began returning to campus, solidifying Yale's reputation as having the most contentious labor relations of any university in the nation.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen declined after Japan's senior international finance official said he was trying to stem a rally in the Japanese currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.39 yen, up from 117.26 on Tuesday.

title: 2 U.S. Soldiers Are Killed and 5 Wounded in Iraq
description: Two soldiers were killed and five were wounded this morning in separate attacks that used improvised explosive devices planted in and around Baghdad, military officials said.

title: Big Flaw Seen In Overhaul Of City Schools: Poor Marketing
description: With the start of school just around the corner, current and former education officials say that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's efforts to overhaul the public schools are being undermined by a lack of a coherent communications strategy and a failure to build broad support out of the initial enthusiasm for his plans.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Charges In Crematory Remains
description: A grand jury indicted Ray B. Marsh on 787 felony counts in connection with more than 300 human remains found stacked and scattered last year at his crematory in Noble, the district attorney's office said. He will be arraigned on Sept. 23. Mr. Marsh's lawyer, McCracken Poston, said he would ask for the trial to be moved. The counts include theft by taking, abuse of a dead body, burial service fraud and making false statements. The charges against Mr. Marsh carry a maximum sentence of more than 7,000 years, Mr. Poston said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: An Illuminating Use of Vintage Parts
description: Lisa Nardone calls her company Rosie NYC, and her lighting ''jewelry for the room.'' The feminine but sophisticated pieces are produced in Italy, in Murano, Florence and Milan. ''I try to find places where this type of work has always been done, and get them to produce things they haven't done in years,'' she said. Ms. Nardone (top) moved to New York in 1986 after graduating from the Moore College of Art and Design in Philadelphia with a degree in advertising. After working at an ad agency, she spent 10 years at ABC Carpet and Home as a merchandise director. ''When looking over what a manufacturer had to offer, I was always rummaging through the back room, digging up the dusty old stuff and asking, 'Can you still make this?' ''

title: Rangers Bring Back Hlavac and Rucinsky
description: The Rangers reached into their past yesterday and signed the free-agent forwards Jan Hlavac and Martin Rucinsky to one-year deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KESSLER, GLORIA
description: KESSLER--Gloria. We mourn the passing of our cherished Gloria Kessler. Beloved wife of Sidney. Loving mother of Alison, Jerry and Eric. Dear sister of Muriel and Paula. Devoted grandmother of Marc, Howard, Beth, Craig, Barry, Scott, Jason and Brandon. Adored aunt, mother-inlaw and friend to many. We will miss her laughter, courage and warmth. She will remain in our hearts always.

title: Mets Put Weathers to Work
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 27 - David Weathers was one of the high-priced Mets the team elected to retain before the trading deadline last month, in part in the hope that he could help the younger relievers in the bullpen next season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Close to an Agreement On Drugs for Poor Nations

title: 33 Are Killed in Stampede at a Hindu Festival
description: Thirty-three people died today in a stampede at a Hindu festival in western India where tens of thousands of pilgrims try to bathe in the holy waters of the Godavari River in a single day.

title: What We Owe the Lost Crews of NASA
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about the new television show ''Clean House'' misstated the channel carrying it in New York. The show will be on Style, not on the E! cable channel. (Both are part of E! Networks.)

title: For Better or Worse, Artists' Shakespeare
description: With the legendary actor-manager David Garrick serving as Shakespeare's high priest, bardolatry swept mid-18th-century England to the point that painters, too, reproduced the words and scenes that actors portrayed onstage. The artists' response on canvas, of course, was not entirely devotional. Prints of their paintings also earned them a pretty penny.

title: Kingpin's Associate Is Sought in Police Captain's Shooting
description: It was shortly after midnight, and a 35-year-old police captain, one of the youngest on the force, had about 90 minutes to go on his shift yesterday morning as he drove west on 154th Street near Washington Heights. The woodsy, uphill belt of Jackie Robinson Park loomed before his unmarked, dark cruiser, a Chevy Malibu.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Thursday about low-income residents of Bayview, Va., who are finally moving into modern houses misidentified the device that one of them, Solomon Burton, has been using as an outdoor water source; though it resembles the hand pump he used for years, it is a freeze-proof hydrant.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: New Drunken-Driving Law
description: A person arrested for drunken driving can now be held in police custody for up to eight hours without a hearing, under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. James E. McGreevey. The new law is intended to prevent a drunken driver from getting behind the wheel while he is still intoxicated or his judgment is still impaired. The bill was drafted after a Navy ensign, John Elliot, was killed by a car driven by Michael Pangle, who had been arrested hours before for drunken driving and released. The law also requires written warnings to friends and relatives picking up drunken-driving suspects about their potential legal liability if the suspect drives a car while still impaired. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Indicted In Robbery
description: A federal grand jury yesterday indicted a man accused of trying to rob a bank by handcuffing a bank manager to a briefcase that he said contained explosives. The man, Anthony Buonanno, walked into the HSBC branch at 452 Fifth Avenue in July and asked to speak to a branch manager, federal prosecutors said. When a manager appeared, Mr. Buonanno handcuffed him and handed him a clock, which he said marked how much time was left until the briefcase exploded, prosecutors said. But a vault alarm suddenly sounded, the prosecutors said, and Mr. Buonanno fled and was captured. There were no explosives in the case. Mr. Buonanno's lawyer declined to comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Jets Turn a Gathering Into a Testaverde Rally
description: From the most famous Jet to the newest Jet, yesterday was about regrouping behind their oldest active player as well as starting the new season on an upbeat note.

title: OFFICEMAX EXECUTIVES SELL SHARES AHEAD OF ACQUISITION
description: Executives at OfficeMax Inc., the office supplies retailer being acquired by the Boise Cascade Corporation, sold $22.6 million of shares as they reached a four-year-high last week. Four executives, including the chairman and chief executive, Michael H. Feuer, sold 2.56 million shares after exercising options for the company's stock, according to filings at the Securities and Exchange Commission. OfficeMax, based in Shaker Heights, Ohio, has risen since July 14, when Boise Cascade, the lumber maker, agreed to pay $1.15 billion in cash and stock for the retailer.

title: NORTH CAROLINA REGIONAL BANK AGREES TO BUY RIVAL
description: The Yadkin Valley Bank and Trust Company, an Elkin, N.C., bank with $656 million in assets, has agreed to buy the High Country Financial Corporation, a bank with offices in adjacent markets. High Country shareholders will either get $24.02 in cash or 1.3345 shares of Yadkin for each share they own, the companies said. Based on High Country's most recent earnings report, the company had 1.42 million shares outstanding, which would make the deal worth about $34 million. Yadkin shares rose three cents, to $17.97 a share; High Country shares rose 84 cents, to $23.84 a share.

title: Unsolved Crimes Add to Plight of Serbs in Kosovo
description: The Bystrica River is not much of a stream in the heat of mid-August, just a weed-slicked trickle over smooth white stones that forms a pool in front of some old tires and a discarded refrigerator. Local young people would come daily to swim here, relief from the boredom that hangs over this tiny Serbian enclave in the Albanian-dominated province of Kosovo.

title: The Town House Morphs
description: WHEN Alan Wilzig and Karin Koenig move to a new town house in TriBeCa next year, Mr. Wilzig, a kinetic 38-year-old bank chief executive, might not even give Ms. Koenig a key to the front door.

title: Sewage Spill During the Blackout Exposed a Lingering City Problem
description: Minutes after New York City lost its power on Aug. 14, streams of raw sewage began to flow into surrounding waterways. By the time electricity was restored, 490 million gallons had spilled -- 145 million gallons from the city's largest pumping station, on the Lower East Side -- causing beaches to close and posing health and environmental hazards.

title: China's Growth Creates a Boom For Cargo Ships
description: Less than two years after many of the world's cargo ships lay idle and were worth no more than the scrap value of their steel, shipping lines around the world are enjoying one of their most profitable booms ever, and they have the rapid expansion of the Chinese economy to thank for it.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Sesame, Sesame Mucho

title: Online Get-Togethers For Linux Newcomers
description: Q. About a year ago I bought a computer with Linux Red Hat 7.1 installed. I have looked at several books for Linux users but have found them unhelpful. Is there a way to exchange ideas with other users?

title: Marion Hargrove, 83, the G.I. With Wry Tales of Army Life
description: Marion Hargrove, the hapless G.I. whose light-hearted account of Army basic training, ''See Here, Private Hargrove,'' became a No. 1 best seller in 1942 and transformed him into a World War II celebrity, died on Saturday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 83.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Worker Falls From Bridge
description: A painter fell off the Triborough Bridge yesterday afternoon and has not been found, Petty Officer Tom Sperduto of the Coast Guard said. The search was suspended around 6 p.m., and a fire official said it would probably resume today. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 10th District Manhattan; In Washington Heights, a Race Has a Familiar Look
description: In some parts of New York, it might be difficult to tell that there are City Council campaigns. But it would be hard to miss the race being waged in Washington Heights. Along any major street, campaign signs seem to be everywhere and caravans of the various political camps roll through the streets on most evenings.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

description: An article and a picture caption last Thursday about low-income residents of Bayview, Va., who are finally moving into modern houses misidentified the device that one of them, Solomon Burton, has been using as an outdoor water source; though it resembles the hand pump he used for years, it is a freeze-proof hydrant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ECCLES, MARY MORLEY CRAPO HYDE
description: ECCLES--Mary Morley Crapo Hyde, Viscountess. Died peacefully at home, Four Oaks Farm, on 26 August 2003. A memorial service will be scheduled for a later date.

title: Research Faults One AIDS-Drug Strategy
description: Intermittent breaks from drug treatment are not beneficial to certain people infected with the AIDS virus and can even worsen their condition, the largest study of the strategy has found.

title: ONEIDA ELIMINATES 100 JOBS AND SAYS IT MAY CLOSE PLANTS
description: Oneida Ltd., a maker of stainless-steel and silver-plated flatware, cut about 100 jobs at a flatware plant in New York and said it may close another plant in New York as well as plants in China, Italy and Mexico. The job cuts, at a plant in Sherrill, N.Y., will reduce annual costs by about $18 million, the company said. Oneida, which is based in Oneida, N.Y., said it would decide by the end of its third quarter whether to close a plant in Toluca, Mexico, and factories in Vercelli, Italy, and Shanghai. The company is also considering closing a facility in Buffalo, N.Y. Oneida had about 3,790 employees as of Jan. 25, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Chasing an Old Flame, Ancient Knowledge
description: THE direction of J. Garfield DeMarco's life was determined on New Year's Eve in 1964 when his father died in a car accident. His dream of a life of law and scholarship, one that would not be centered on the vast cranberry bogs and blueberry fields that his family owned in southern New Jersey, vanished.

title: Kirkland's Reports a Profit
description: Kirkland's Inc., a home decor retailer, reported a quarterly profit yesterday, reversing a year-earlier loss, as sales rose nearly 6 percent.

title: Estimates of Stored Natural Gas Are Probably Too Low, U.S. Says
description: The Energy Department said yesterday that its weekly natural gas inventory reports had probably been underestimating the amount of fuel that utilities were stowing for winter.

title: TWINLAB IN TALKS WITH PROSPECTIVE BUYER
description: The Twinlab Corporation, a maker of vitamins and dietary supplements, said yesterday that it was negotiating with a prospective buyer and would delay filing financial results for the second quarter. The company said that the purchase price most likely would not exceed the company's debt, and shareholders might receive ''no value.'' Sales at Twinlab, based in Hauppauge, N.Y., were hurt after it stopped selling dietary supplements containing ephedra, a substance used in weight-loss products that has been linked to heart problems.

title: MetroStars Reach Tournament Semifinals
description: The MetroStars have never captured a major title. One title they have been seeking besides the championship in Major League Soccer is that of the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup, the oldest soccer competition in this country.

title: Mothers Charged in Joyride by Girl and Boy
description: The mothers of a 9-year-old girl and a 4-year-old boy from Little Ferry who commandeered the family S.U.V. while home alone and struck four cars and a pedestrian, were charged today with endangering the welfare of a child.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: HUCKABEE WON'T SEEK SENATE SEAT Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, announced that he would not run for the Senate seat held by Blanche Lincoln, a Democrat. Mr. Huckabee had frequently been mentioned as a potential rival to Ms. Lincoln, who has announced she will seek a second term next year. Mr. Huckabee, who is serving his second four-year term and cannot succeed himself, told reporters that he would devote his energies to revamping the Arkansas public school system, which the State Supreme Court has declared unconstitutionally inadequate and underfinanced. (NYT)

title: Stottlemyre Fumes as Wells Is Shelled
description: David Wells had just pitched one of the worst games of his career, and for the third start in a row, he left the Yankees' clubhouse without talking to reporters. Now his teammates and coaches are also searching for answers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Won't Extradite Turk
description: A court in Cologne ruled that Metin Kaplan, the Islamic militant who is known as the Caliph of Cologne and whose group is banned, no longer has a right to asylum in Germany but may not be extradited to Turkey, where he is charged with involvement in a failed plot to fly a plane into the mausoleum of Kemal Ataturk, the founder of the Turkish republic. The court said it believed that evidence that the Turkish police had extracted by torture from his followers might be used in proceedings against him, in violation of international law. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Williamses Test a Life Without Any Games
description: Missing the Williams sisters at this year's United States Open? No need to worry. You should still have ample time to enjoy the free-swinging spectacle provided by tennis's first family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Car Runs Wild
description: A car hit 16 other vehicles last night in Jackson Heights and then crashed into a brick fence, the police said. Six people, including the driver, were slightly hurt, and the driver was arrested, though he had not been charged as of late last night, Detective Thomas Kuchma said. The crashes occurred on 76th Street between 35th and 37th Avenues, and witnesses reported that the driver of a gray 1996 Land Rover had been stuck behind a delivery truck before accelerating and hitting one car three times, then sideswiping the others. The driver was taken to Elmhurst Hospital in stable condition, the police said. Detective Kuchma said that the driver did not seem to be intoxicated. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Blackout Affects Hundreds
description: A power failure hit about 300 businesses yesterday, including a hospital and the headquarters of the responsible utility, Public Service Electric and Gas, a company spokeswoman said. Problems began around 4 a.m., when one of three circuits in a downtown area failed, causing another to fail as well. The company decided to shut down the third, to keep it from being overloaded, said the spokeswoman, Karen Johnson. St. Michael's Hospital used a generator but was not able to use its air-conditioners until 5:15 p.m., Ms. Johnson said, when all service was restored to the city. The problems were not related to the Aug. 14 blackout, she said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Verizon's Protest of Union Ad Is Overruled
description: An arbitrator has ruled against an effort by Verizon Communications to block a union from placing advertisements accusing a unit of the company of unfair practices.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a decision by the California Labor Federation, A.F.L.-C.I.O., to oppose the recall of California Gov. Gray Davis referred imprecisely to the federation. It is an organization of individual unions, it is not itself a union.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Microsoft To Introduce MSN Premium
description: Microsoft, whose MSN Internet service is losing money and customers, will sell subscriptions to use a new version of its software in a bid to attract clients. The service, MSN Premium, will cost $9.95 a month or $80 a year for a set of e-mail, security, calendar and digital-photo programs, Lisa Gurry, the MSN Group product manager, said yesterday. A version without some of the programs will cost less, she said. Sales will begin sometime in December. Microsoft is avoiding the business of selling high-speed Internet access and is pursing MSN software fees from clients using fast links from other companies. Those clients might be unwilling to pay the fee on top of access charges, analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GEORGE, ALLAN
description: GEORGE--Allan. July 31, 1914 to August 28, 1979. Missing you still after all these years. Missing your wisdom, humor and spirit, missing your love of life & knowledge, missing your boundless heart full of compassion and kindness. All of this will live on always in the minds and memories of those lucky enough to have crossed paths with you. I will love you always, my special and unique Dad. Love always, Catherine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROILES, MELVYN
description: BROILES--Melvyn. The Juilliard School is deeply saddened by the death of Melvyn Broiles, who was a member of the trumpet faculty from 1971 to the present. With dedication and great professionalism, he was an important performer and teacher for generations of brass players. We express our condolences to his wife and family. He will be greatly missed. Joseph W. Polisi, President Stephen Clapp, Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOOD, PAUL W.
description: WOOD--Paul W. age 80 years. of Port Washington, N.Y. on August 24, 2003. Beloved husband of Jacqueline. Devoted father of Stephen, Gregory, Mark and Paul. Loving grandfather of five. Also survived by four brothers and two sisters. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington, NY. Visiting hours Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass on Saturday, St. Peter of Alcantara, 9:30 A.M. Interment following at Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Ayuso Signs With Spurs
description: Larry Ayuso, the star shooting guard for Puerto Rico, will remember the Olympic qualifying tournament here for the moment when he finally made it to the N.B.A. The San Antonio Spurs signed the 26-year-old Ayuso today to a nonguaranteed one-year contract.

title: Administration Adopts Rule On Antipollution Exemption
description: The Bush administration relaxed its clean air rules today to allow thousands of industrial plants to make upgrades without installing pollution controls, arguing that other regulations were in place to reduce emissions.

title: High-Tech Containers For Seasonings
description: Grind's see-through, spring-action salt-and-pepper mills have the look of precision machine parts. Grind, which is based in Connecticut, also manufactures traditional pepper mills, napkin rings and bottle stops. The large satin-finish models shown (six and a half inches tall, $29.95 each) are made of a low-carbon stainless steel, and can be operated with one hand. The mills are sold exclusively at Williams-Sonoma, 110 Seventh Avenue (16th Street), (212) 633-2203, or next Wednesday at (800) 541-2233. Other Grind products are available at www.grinddirect.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOLGITSER, GEDELE
description: DOLGITSER -- Gedele, 75. Passed away on August 27, 2003. Beloved husband of Nora. Loving father of Konstantin and Dina. Proud grandfather of Denise and Andrew. We will always miss your kindness, warmth and loving generosity.

title: Six Flags Picks New Ad Agency
description: Six Flags Inc. in Oklahoma City, the operator of 39 amusement parks, said yesterday that it had named Doner in Southfield, Mich., to handle the creative and media parts of its account. Billings were estimated at $70 million to $90 million.

title: Turnaround by China: Center Stage at Talks on North Korea
description: BEIJING, Aug. 28  Whether or not the six nations gathered in Beijing this week agree on how to stop the North Korean nuclear program, the talks here seem likely to produce at least one breakthrough: the emergence of China as a more assertive diplomatic power.

title: Columbia Report Prompts Debate in Congress Over Space
description: A report citing a ''broken safety culture'' at NASA has provoked a wide-ranging debate in Congress over the future of the space program, with some lawmakers suggesting that human spaceflight be curtailed and others promoting a broad expansion of space exploration, including a revival of long-shelved plans to send astronauts to Mars.

title: An Internet Extension To Your Telephone Twin
description: Early adopters are sometimes frustrated by their friends' lack of interest in the latest digital toy. The makers of the SIPphone, an Internet telephone, have an answer for that problem: the device is available only in pairs.

title: California Law Provides More Financial Privacy
description: California enacted the nation's most comprehensive financial privacy protections yesterday, forcing banks and other financial institutions to obtain the permission of customers before sharing their personal data with outside companies and giving consumers more control over how information about them is shared in corporate families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARBER, STEPHANIE (NEE FREY)
description: BARBER -- Stephanie (nee Frey), of Manhattan and Lenox, MA., in Pittsfield, MA., August 26, 2003. Beloved wife of Arthur N. Collins, daughter of the late Victor and Rose (nee Nager) Frey, loving mother to Charles Victor Barber of Washington, DC and Hilary Williams Barber of Amherst, MA., stepmother to Benjamin Reynolds Barber of NYC and Willson Benn Barber of Becket, MA. and Nicholas Hillhouse Collins of Glens Falls, NY., and to Edith Trelease Wyman of Beaver, WV., Amy Victoria Hoptay of Sewickley, PA and Leslie Anne Collins of Augusta, ME., adoring grandmother to Jeremy, Rebecca, Kate, Olive, Nellie, Alexander, and Julia Barber, great grandmother to Sophie, and step grandmother to Ananda, Sarah, Jeanne, Jessica, Claire, Katherine, Mariah, and Alyssa. Co-Founder of former Music Inn in Lenox, MA. and former inn-keeper of Wheatleigh Estate in Stockbridge, MA. Calling hours Thursday 4-7PM at Roche Funeral Home, Lenox. Public Memorial service later this fall. Memorial donations to Music Inn Legacy Foundation C/O Roche Funeral Home, 120 Main Street, Lenox, MA. 01240.

title: To Keep Backs Straight, and Pencils, Too
description: YOUR children might be too young to outfit a dorm room -- or even to go to school. But the need to organize knows no age. It is never too early to furnish a child's room with a firm foundation of storage options that are easy to reach and tables and chairs that are scaled for youngsters. For elementary pupils, a rolling book bag can help keep backs straight and stress-free.

title: Finding Identity In a House Divided
description: Growing up in a Dublin suburb in the 1950's and 60's, Hugo Hamilton wore lederhosen and an Aran sweater, clothes that were emblematic of his divided life as the son of a German mother and an Irish father. He was ridiculed by classmates, who considered him German. Tauntingly, they called him Eichmann, and his brother, Franz, was called Hitler; the pair were subjected to a mock trial.

title: Flying Cheap
description: Southwest Airlines flew more passengers than any other airline in May, according to Transportation Department statistics, making it the first month ever that a low-cost carrier eclipsed the established major airlines. It is a telling milestone for the airline industry.

It will end, not begin, when the next Congress is sworn in, in January 2005.

title: Death and Deception
description: When a basketball player at the world's largest Baptist university was shot twice in the head near an old gravel pit and his former teammate was arrested and charged with pulling the trigger, the event seemed dramatic enough to open a beach holiday page turner.

title: U.S. Economy Growing Faster; Economists Raise Forecasts
description: The American economy grew at a revised annual rate of 3.1 percent in the second quarter, the government reported today, and the unexpected strength is leading economists to raise their forecasts for the rest of the year.

title: The Biggest Users of Sick Leave Face Transfer in Fire Department
description: Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday that the Fire Department would transfer 20 firefighters with the most sick leave absences to other assignments in an effort to stem what he called abuses of its medical leave policy.

At this point, robots were supposed to have become walking, talking humanoids on casters that either cater to our every whim or plot to take us over, depending on which movie you watched.

description: BERG--Barbara L. Devoted wife of the late Leo. Beloved mother of Sharon and Kenneth Schreiber, and Dr. Gordon and Diane Berg. Services today, 10 AM at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hills, New York.

description: Just two days after the Charter Revision Commission voted to send the issue of nonpartisan elections to New York City voters in November, a large group of labor leaders met yesterday to reaffirm their commitment to defeating the measure.

description: BEING beautiful pays off. Economists have found that men with above-average looks are paid about 5 percent more than those with average appearance, while those who are below average in looks have wages 9 percent below the mean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRIOR, HUGH
description: PRIOR--Hugh. On August 25, 2003. Born July 15, 1936 in Swanlinbar Co, Cavan, Ireland. Loving husband of Bernadette Finn. Beloved brother of John, Kathleen, Patrick, James, Thomas and Oliver. Cherished uncle of 41 nieces and nephews. Loving dad of Dutchess. Family will receive friends Thursday 7 to 9PM and Friday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10:30AM at Church of Our Savior, 38th Street and Park Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMMERMAN, JOHN O
description: ZIMMERMAN--John O, former President of GMAC and Chief Executor of GMAC in the early 1970's, died on August 27th in Stonington, CT where he made his home. He was 94. Mr. Zimmerman joined the General Motors financial staff shortly after his graduation from Dartmouth College Amos Tuck School of Business. His entire business career, aside from a tour of duty in the US Navy, was spent with the GM Financial staff and GMAC. He is survived by his wife Barbara, son Peter and daughter Anne.

title: In Vienna, a New View Of Wittgenstein Home
description: AN austere, flat-roofed villa at Kundmanngasse 19 was hardly noticed when it was finished in 1928 and almost torn down during postwar redevelopment. Even now, the large building -- home to the Bulgarian Culture Institute -- is something of an enigma. It is the only major work of architecture by the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein.

description: Genetic Poetry

title: After Breakthrough That Wasn't, Fledgling Filmmaker Tries Again
description: With Chicago's towering skyline and a sun-drenched Lake Michigan beach as his set, Pete Jones, a fledgling director who owes his small fame to reality television, is behind the lens of the camera again, wiser if not wounded.

title: British Defense Chief Testifies Arms Expert Supported Iraq War
description: Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon said today that the weapons expert cited as the source of a BBC report casting doubt on Britain's reasons for going to war had told him he supported the government's position on Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: United Arab Emirates:
description: The president, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahyan, ordered the Zayed International Center, a political research center financed by him and sponsored by the Arab League, closed. The center, opened in 1999, has drawn criticism from American and British groups that accuse it of promoting anti-Semitism. The center had invited European and Arab scholars who lectured against Israeli and American policy, including a French writer, Thierry Meyssan, who contends that the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, were a Jewish-American conspiracy to defame Islam. Abeer Allam (NYT)

description: The teams that lacked urgency tonight, one night after their electric meeting, also lacked crispness, as Argentina and the United States wafted through their games as if their heads were awash in the surf.

description: A former executive of the HealthSouth Corporation admitted yesterday that he falsified company tax returns, pleading guilty to participating in what prosecutors say was a $2.5 billion accounting fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCORMACK, ROBERT
description: McCORMACK--Robert. The President and Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York express deep sorrow at the passing of our Trustee Emeritus Robert McCormack. A graduate of the Columbia Business School, he was a respected colleague whose leadership as a Trustee was marked by exceptional insight, dedication and decency. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife, Susan Garner, and their children, Deirdre Garner McCormack & Andrew John McCormack. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: Isolating Grid Isn't State Plan In a Blackout
description: Even if they had been warned of mounting chaos in the Midwest in the hour before the Aug. 14 blackout, officials in New York probably would not have tried to spare the state by disconnecting from its neighbors, the chief manager of the state's power grid said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Electronic Arts To Create Games For Nokia Phones
description: Electronic Arts Inc. said yesterday that it planned to release game versions in the next two months that can be played on Nokia's hand-held game devices. The games will be compatible with Nokia's N-Gage system and will be released in time for the holiday shopping season, the companies said on Nokia's Web site. N-Gage is a hand-held video game player that also includes a cellphone, radio, Web browser and digital music player. It goes on sale Oct. 7. Shares of Electronic Arts fell $1.63, to $86.88. Nokia's American shares rose 52 cents, to $16.31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WORTMAN, JEFFREY D.L.
description: WORTMAN--Jeffrey D.L., 57, dealer in prints and drawings, Died on August 23 in New York City. He is survived by his parents, Dr. Harry and Marilyn Wortman, and brother, Stephen. Plans for a memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations to the John C. Glover Swimming Fund at Dartmouth College or the American Heart Association.

title: Sondheim, Film Aficionado; Choices for Telluride Festival Show Nonmusical Side
description: It is the kind of cool, glittering irony that you'd expect to hear in a Stephen Sondheim song, this piece of information that materializes when one of the enduringly gifted composers of musicals talks about his fondness for movies.

title: Online Games That Redefine Risk
description: THE feeling is intense. Not only are you securing the perimeter of a dark, forbidding enemy fortress with 10 other heavily armed soldiers, but there is more on the line than just your virtual life. You could also lose real money.

title: Foot Locker's new ad campaign timed to the back-to-school crowd.
description: THE largest American retailer of athletic shoes, Foot Locker Inc., is revamping the advertising and marketing for three of its retail chains. The ambitious overhaul, which includes the namesake flagship chain, is timed to coincide with the important back-to-school shopping season.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Stake Acquisition
description: Lone Star Funds, an investment fund based in Dallas, has agreed to pay 1.4 trillion won ($1.2 billion) for control of the Korea Exchange Bank, in the largest foreign investment in South Korea's financial industry. Lone Star becomes the third foreign investor to take control of a Korean lender, joining Newbridge Capital Ltd. and investors led by the Carlyle Group. For Lone Star, which seeks to profit from buying distressed assets, this will be its first purchase of a lender in Korea; it failed in an attempt to buy SeoulBank last year. Korea Exchange, the nation's fifth-largest lender, needs money to bolster capital eroded by provisions for bad loans. (Bloomberg News)

title: U.S. Seeking Foreign Investment for Iraq
description: American officials here are preparing an order that for the first time in decades would pry open most Iraqi industries for foreign investment, opening a new lifeline for an economy starved of capital during Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Governor Wins Court Delay In City Bid to Refinance Debt
description: Gov. George E. Pataki won a temporary victory in court today in his fight to keep the city from refinancing debt from the mid-1970's to help close its budget shortfall.

title: When Players Play
description: Miami Dolphins safety Sammy Knight is convinced he is a better player than he gets credit for.

title: A Good Corporate Citizen? This Scanner Can Tell
description: AS they sit there on the shelf, shrink-wrapped and safety-sealed, consumer products may not seem to tell much of a story. From the packaging, it is hard to tell whether sneakers were made by a company with a record of exploiting overseas laborers, or whether the pineapples in a can came from a farming conglomerate fined for polluting a watershed.

title: After Brooklyn Girl Dies, More Charges Are Weighed
description: A 3-year-old Brooklyn girl who suffered a skull fracture and was so malnourished that court papers described her as ''skin and bones'' died yesterday morning.

title: Two Share Lead At the Met Open
description: Tony DeMaria shot a par 72 for a two-round total of 141 and grabbed a share of the lead with Andrew Svoboda after two rounds of the Met Life/Met Open yesterday at the Metedeconk National Golf Club in Jackson, N.J.

title: Big Board Chief Will Get A $140 Million Package
description: Bowing to criticism of the secretive way it compensates its chief executive, the board of the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that its top executive, Richard A. Grasso, would receive lump- sum payments totaling $140 million in accrued savings and incentives, in addition to a base salary of $1.4 million and a bonus of at least $1 million.

title: 69,000 Died or Disappeared in Peru Conflict, Panel Reports
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 28  Dissecting 20 years of conflict, a government-appointed truth commission issued a voluminous report today that concluded that a fanatical, Maoist rebel group was responsible for the greatest number of deaths but also blamed three governments for widespread human-rights abuses.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: RWANDA: EUROPEANS CITE FLAWS IN ELECTION European Union observers said Rwanda's presidential election did not entirely meet "free and fair standards" but was an important step toward democracy. The incumbent president, Paul Kagame, won 95 percent of the vote in the first presidential election since 1994. The observers noted voter intimidation and stuffed ballot boxes. "The optimum conditions for a free and fair election were probably not met, but this presidential election is a promise for the opening of a new democratic era for Rwanda," the head of the observer mission, Colette Flesch, said. (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CHILE: COURT BARS PINOCHET RIGHTS TRIAL A bid to have Augusto Pinochet, the ailing 87-year-old former dictator, face human rights charges failed when the Appeals Court voted, 15 to 8, against taking away his immunity. The ruling, which cannot be appealed, came after a one-day hearing in the case of five leftist leaders kidnapped and presumed killed in 1976, the first formal human rights complaint filed against Mr. Pinochet, in 1998. The court did not give a reason for its vote.    (Reuters)

title: A Bigger Hard Drive Says 'Hold Everything'
description: Samsung introduced its first digital video recorder, the SIR-S4120R, this week. But the company, which is releasing the machine with DirecTV and TiVo, is not merely dipping a toe in; it is aiming to make a splash.

title: Webdenda
description: Pfizer , New York, named Wunderman , New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group, to handle direct marketing and relationship marketing duties for Zyrtec, the company's prescription allergy medicine. Spending was not disclosed. Those assignments had been handled by Deutsch, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which also created advertising for Zyrtec. Deutsch resigned all its Zyrtec duties, as well as its other Pfizer accounts, in a dispute over compensation policies. The Zyrtec advertising assignment was reassigned to Berlin Cameron/Red Cell, New York, part of the Red Cell division of WPP.

title: Wind Power's New Current
description: STANDING on top of a hill in central Massachusetts, Jonathan Fitch is surrounded by a grove of eight tall white windmills. He regards them like someone eager to trade in an old car.

title: General Finds Fault In Staffing At NASA
description: NASA is using inspectors who have no experience in aviation, space or other technical fields, and the Kennedy Space Center does not even have a formal training program, a member of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board said in a report of his own issued today.

title: Prisoners of Hate
description: As with so many of the bad things that happen in prison, it is hard to ascertain from the outside everything that led up to the murder of John J. Geoghan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAHAM, RUTH
description: ABRAHAM--Ruth. We regret to announce the passing of our dear mother, mother-inlaw, grandmother and great grandmother. Interment was in Israel on Tuesday, August 26. The traditional seven days of mourning began in Israel and will continue at her last residence 578 Trysting Pl, Cedarhurst, NY on Thursday, Friday, Saturday night, Sunday, and Monday morning. She was a true women of valor with a heart of gold who endured the worst of the Holocaust through the compassion of others, particularly Maria, and then devoted her life to repaying that selfless act. She was a deeply devout person who drew strength from her religious beliefs. We will miss her sorely. Abraham Sokolow and Shachar families

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; If Past Is Prologue, Rally May Start Cooling Down
description: It has been a wonderful six months in the stock market, and history suggests the rally might continue. But if it does, it might do so at a much slower pace, and a lot of today's hot stocks might fall by the wayside.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCI INC., Ashburn, Va., the provider of global communications formerly known as WorldCom, and Digex Inc., Laurel, Md., a provider of Web-site hosting services, said MCI had commenced a tender offer to purchase the outstanding shares of Class A common stock of Digex for 80 cents a share.

title: A Dream Remembered
description: On the 40th anniversary of the March on Washington, we look back on that day as the ultimate expression of Americans peacefully petitioning their government for change. But before the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. inspired the nation with his dream of racial equality, the march inspired fear. The Kennedy administration, Congress and the press spoke uneasily of mobs of black people rioting in the capital.

title: U.S. NOW SIGNALS IT MIGHT CONSIDER U.N. FORCE IN IRAQ
description: The Bush administration has signaled for the first time that it may be willing to allow a multinational force in Iraq to operate under the sponsorship of the United Nations as long as it is commanded by an American.

title: Bombardier To Sell Unit To Cut Debt
description: Bombardier Inc., the Canadian aircraft and rail equipment manufacturer, has broken with its rural Quebec roots by selling a unit that makes snowmobiles and other leisure craft for 1.23 billion Canadian dollars ($875 million) in cash. The buyers include Bain Capital of Boston and members of the Bombardier family, who still control the parent company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Disappointing Insurance Result
description: The French reinsurer, Scor, said that its net profit had doubled in the first half of 2003 but that the result was short of analysts' expectations. Sales fell 18 percent. Net profit was 42 million euros ($46 million), up from 21 million euros ($23 million) a year earlier. Sales fell to 2.1 billion euros ($2.3 billion). Scor said the decline in sales was mainly from the loss of a contract in Bermuda. Scor said that second-quarter profit was hurt by a 37.6 million euro ($40.8 million) charge resulting from tornado damage in the United States in May. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Rob Quish Quits Lowe New York
description: Rob Quish, who had most recently been president of the New York office of Lowe & Partners Worldwide, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is leaving the agency, he said yesterday.

title: Rebels in Nepal End Cease-Fire; Government Puts Army on Alert
description: In a surprise move, Maoist rebels withdrew from peace talks in Nepal today and declared the end of their seven-month cease-fire, prompting the government to put soldiers and police officers on high alert. But the rebels signaled that they might resume talks if the government gave in to a principal demand.

title: NASA Chief Promises Shift in Attitude
description: The NASA administrator defended himself today against suggestions in the Columbia accident report that the agency had cut corners to meet a schedule he had imposed. And he promised that the agency would achieve the major change called for in the report, fixing its culture to one more amenable to safety concerns.

title: Six Flags Picks New Ad Agency
description: Six Flags Inc. in Oklahoma City, the operator of 39 amusement parks, said yesterday that it had named Doner in Southfield, Mich., to handle the creative and media parts of its account. Billings were estimated at $70 million to $90 million.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Idea For Okefenokee Strip Mine Is Abandoned
description: The DuPont Company announced it would donate to the Conservation Fund 16,000 acres of land in the Okefenokee Swamp that it had intended to strip mine for titanium dioxide. The mining plan was halted by a nationwide opposition in 1997. International Paper will continue to exercise its rights to harvest timber on parts of the land until 2080. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday, assessing the prospects for earnings growth at the Walt Disney Company, misidentified the owner of a 3.1 percent stake in the company. It is State Street Global Advisors, not State Street Research, which owns 0.2 percent. The column also referred incorrectly to a $140 million decline in fiscal 2002 operating income at Disney's cable networks. It was a result of various factors, according to the company's financial filings, not solely the cost of rights to carry National Football League games. The column also misstated the percentage decreases in operating income for Disney's theme parks business. In fiscal 2002, it declined 26 percent, not 22 percent; for the first nine months of fiscal 2003, it declined 22 percent, not 27.6 percent.

title: Pierce Manages Mild Upset; Martin Ousts No. 16 Verkerk
description: In a United States Open starved for entertaining matches, Mary Pierce of France and No. 22-seeded Jelena Dokic of Yugoslavia locked into a second-round encounter today that featured risky shot-making and a wild momentum swing. Pierce won, 6-2, 6-7 (5), 7-6 (5), but the victory could hardly be deemed a major upset.

title: Stock Buyback Even as the Chief Sells
description: Hollywood Entertainment, which runs a chain of video stores, wants to buy back at least $30 million worth of its shares. Its chairman and chief executive, Mark J. Wattles, wants to sell almost as much.

title: Patriots Beat Bears; Finish Preseason 4-0
description: The New England Patriots completed an unbeaten exhibition season last night, rallying to beat the visiting Chicago Bears, 38-23.

title: Amateur Wins Title, So Pro Takes the Money
description: Andrew Svoboda earned the prestige by winning the $125,000 Met Life/Met Open yesterday, and Richard Massey earned the $23,000 first-place check.

title: Furniture Designer Answers Sirens' Call
description: SIXTEEN years ago, Michael Heltzer transformed himself from Wall Street lawyer to furniture designer and manufacturer. Now he is in the middle of another change. Mr. Heltzer, 42, who built his modern furniture company, known for its steel-frame outdoor lounges and tables, into a $6-million-a-year business, has found a new calling: refinishing luxury motorboats.

title: The Mets Pay for Heilman's Walks
description: Aaron Heilman did not require thundershowers at Turner Field to make his initiation to the major leagues any more turbulent than it is has been. But it did rain, twice delaying the Mets' game against the Braves, and shortening another of Heilman's confounding starts.

title: After a Ragged Start, Federer Displays His Wimbledon Form
description: The last time Roger Federer played a match in a Grand Slam tournament, he left observers at understated Wimbledon grasping for superlatives and Mark Philippoussis grasping the runner-up trophy.

title: British Soldier Killed in Confrontation With Group of Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 28  A British soldier was killed on Wednesday and another injured when their convoy encountered a mob of Iraqis blocking a road in southern Iraq as they returned to their base after arresting two loyalists to Saddam Hussein, British military authorities said today.

title: Velazquez Ties Saratoga Record
description: By riding two more winners yesterday, John Velazquez tied Jerry Baileys Saratoga Race Course record of 55 winners at the tracks meeting, with four days remaining.

title: Arafat Calls on Palestinian Militants to Halt Attacks on Israelis
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, appealed to Palestinian militant groups today to stop attacks on Israelis, saying the groups must give an American-backed peace effort a chance to work.

title: A Reason to Rejoice, a Reason to Record
description: WHEN there's a child on the way, technophiles may be happier than most other expectant parents. That's because in addition to the rosy anticipation of the baby's arrival, we get to buy new toys. Oh, sure, there are the assorted crib rattles and the Tickle Me Elmo doll, and that's all fine. But what really gets us excited is the grown-up toys. What's especially appealing is that these products suddenly leap from vaguely decadent luxuries to nothing's-too-good-for-my-child necessities.

title: After the Bombs, Retrofitting Paradise
description: THIS 51.7-square-mile island about 7 miles off the east coast of Puerto Rico has a reputation that far exceeds its size.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: BLACKOUT AFFECTS HUNDREDS A power failure hit about 300 businesses yesterday, including a hospital and the headquarters of the responsible utility, Public Service Electric and Gas , a company spokeswoman said. Problems began around 4 a.m., when one of three circuits in a downtown area failed, causing another to fail as well. The company decided to shut down the third, to keep it from being overloaded, said the spokeswoman, Karen Johnson. St. Michael's Hospital used a generator but was not able to use its air-conditioners until 5:15 p.m., Ms. Johnson said, when all service was restored to the city. The problems were not related to the Aug. 14 blackout, she said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: VF SAYS EARNINGS WILL INCREASE OVER NAUTICA DEAL
description: The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee jeans, has completed its $600 million purchase of Nautica Enterprises Inc. and said the acquisition would add to this year's profit. Nautica, which also owns the Earl Jean brand, will increase profit at VF on an earnings-per-share basis by as much as 7 percent, said VF, which is based in Greensboro, N.C. VF is also creating a sportswear division that will oversee the Nautica-related business. Nautica's founder, David Chu, will become chief executive of all Nautica-branded businesses.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Maybe P. Diddy's Early Bird Party?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BURACK, ROBERT
description: BURACK--Robert. 1903 to 1980. Child of old Boston. Remembered on his centennial. His love and laughter live on.

title: Your Very Being, Saved on a Swab For All Eternity
description: Can't quite come to terms with leaving this mortal coil? The DNA storage and profile request pack ($29.99, right, for one test) from CATGee, a London-based company, offers part of you -- your genetic code -- immortality. Included in the kit (which also comes in two- and four-test sizes) is a sterile swab to be swiped on the inside of your mouth, then placed in a special storage card (for safekeeping). A second swab can be sent to a laboratory for DNA profiling (for an additional fee of $59.95 -- envelope included). CATGee suggests using the kits to diagnose or cure the diseases of future generations, identify your remains after a disaster, or identify kidnapped children. David Nicholson, the company's founder and owner, says that ''confidentiality is assured.'' The kit can be found at Basics Furniture, 92 Seventh Avenue (15th Street), New York, (212) 691-5595; other retailers are available at www.catgee.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCRARY, JINX FALKENBURG
description: McCRARY--Jinx Falkenburg. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System mourns the passing and celebrates the extraordinary life of Jinx Falkenburg McCrary. Mrs. McCrary and her late husband John ''Tex'' McCrary were among the founders of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY. Both were ardent supporters and long-time trustees of the institution. Mrs. McCrary was a tennis star in California when she was discovered by film producer Sam Goldwyn. The first ''Miss Rheingold,'' Mrs. McCrary appeared on Broadway and in films until her marriage to Mr. McCrary brought her to Manhasset, NY. Beginning with ''Hi, Jinx,'' the couple launched a series of successful radio and television programs and became known as ''Mr. and Mrs. New York.'' Over a period of 12 years, through her radio and television programs, she helped to raise $12 million to build, support and expand North Shore University Hospital. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System is eternally grateful for the commitment and spirit of this wonderful woman. We extend our condolences to her sons Michael, Kevin and John. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Rowland And G.O.P. Pay for Misuse Of Party Card
description: Gov. John G. Rowland and the Connecticut Republican Party agreed today to pay the state $7,500 to settle a complaint over their use of a party credit card.

title: Two Injured as Car Crashes Into Rutgers Dorm
description: Two people, including a 7-year-old girl, were in critical condition this evening after a car crashed through a wall of a dormitory on the campus of Rutgers University, the authorities said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Cacti And High Notes For Putin
description: President Vladimir V. Putin's naval security detail -- a missile cruiser and its escort ship -- dropped anchor next to luxurious yachts off Sardinia in preparation for his weekend visit with the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi. Mr. Putin is to arrive tomorrow for an informal visit at Villa Certosa, Mr. Berlusconi's summer retreat, which reportedly has a cactus garden planted in the shape of a Roman amphitheater. Mr. Putin, whose two teenage daughters were guests at the villa last year, will be wined and dined in style. Italian news agencies reported that Andrea Bocelli, the pop-tenor sensation, would sing at an extravagant dinner on Saturday. Elisabetta Povoledo

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Contract At Nickel Facility
description: Inco Ltd. and a union representing 3,300 striking workers at its nickel-producing operations in Sudbury, Ontario, have reached a tentative contract. The workers, who have been on strike for 13 weeks, will vote on the proposal today. The Sudbury unit normally produces about 9 percent of the Western world's nickel, a crucial component in stainless steel. The price of nickel, which had been propped up by the strike, fell 4.7 percent after the agreement was announced. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Questions Shadow Slovak
description: With every misstep in Grand Slam tournaments, Daniela Hantuchova has faced questions about her slender frame. Now she will confront doubts about her emotional fitness.

title: A Television Network With a PC at Its Heart
description: NECESSITY may be the mother of invention, but it can also play parent to an inspired adaptation, as a college television department that was having trouble communicating with its own students found out. With some creative thinking and a piece of equipment originally intended for something very different, the college has found a way to deliver programming efficiently from its television department all over campus by way of the school's computer network.

title: Where Rubber Meets the Sky; A Veteran Winds Up the 'Motor' and Lets It Fly
description: Bob Bender wound the propeller just so. He released the model plane, which sailed and looped and soared almost up to the ceiling of Hangar B at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. Its several-minute jaunt -- time appeared to be suspended -- was powered by an unwinding rubber band.

title: MEDQUIST NAMES NEW PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: MedQuist, a transcriber of medical records, has named R. Timothy Stack president and chief executive, succeeding David Cohen, who retired in July. Mr. Stack, 51, had been president and chief executive of Piedmont Medical Center and served on MedQuist's board from 1997 to 2000, MedQuist said. His appointment will be effective Oct. 1. Mr. Stack joins the company as it struggles to increase profit amid higher health-care costs. MedQuist, based in Marlton, N.J., said last month that net income in the second quarter fell 12 percent to $10.8 million, from $12.3 million a year earlier.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Economic Growth
description: Malaysia's economy grew 4.4 percent in the second quarter compared with the quarter a year earlier, the country's central bank said yesterday, as rising semiconductor demand and higher prices for palm oil offset the effect of the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, that swept through parts of Asia last spring. The bank also raised its estimate of first-quarter growth, to 4.6 percent from an earlier estimate of 4 percent. The bank said it expected manufacturing, agriculture and mining to lead the economy up 4.5 percent this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Webdenda
description: Pfizer , New York, named Wunderman , New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group, to handle direct marketing and relationship marketing duties for Zyrtec, the company's prescription allergy medicine. Spending was not disclosed. Those assignments had been handled by Deutsch, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which also created advertising for Zyrtec. Deutsch resigned all its Zyrtec duties, as well as its other Pfizer accounts, in a dispute over compensation policies. The Zyrtec advertising assignment was reassigned to Berlin Cameron/Red Cell, New York, part of the Red Cell division of WPP.

title: Corinthian Reports 50% Growth in Profit
description: Corinthian Colleges Inc., an operator of vocational and technical schools, said yesterday that quarterly profit rose 50 percent because of acquisitions and higher student enrollment at campuses and through the Internet.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Huckabee Won't Seek Senate Seat
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, announced that he would not run for the Senate seat held by Blanche Lincoln, a Democrat. Mr. Huckabee had frequently been mentioned as a potential rival to Ms. Lincoln, who has announced she will seek a second term next year. Mr. Huckabee, who is serving his second four-year term and cannot succeed himself, told reporters that he would devote his energies to revamping the Arkansas public school system, which the State Supreme Court has declared unconstitutionally inadequate and underfinanced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIOELI, ROSE
description: GIOELI--Rose. On August 23, 2003. Loving aunt of Catherine F. Gioeli, A. Casey Gioeli, Daniel G. Gioeli and his wife, Debra. Great aunt of Cole and Grace. Graduate of Hunter College, Rose worked with Morris Abrams at Paul, Weiss, LLP, as a legal secretary for many years. She was an avid world traveler and devotee to the arts. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street Thursday, August 28, fr 7-9 P.M. and Friday, August 29, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, August 30th at 10 A.M. at Saint James R.C. Church, 23 Oliver Street (enter on James Street between Madison and Pearl Streets). Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 90 Orchard Street, NY, NY 10002 or to Seaman Church Institute, 241 Water Street, New York, New York 10038.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARALLO, ANGELO N.
description: TARALLO--Angelo N., 63, of Ridgewood, NJ on August 26, 2003. Beloved husband of thirty-eight years to Patricia (nee Klubnik). Loving father of Patricia Kitchen, Gina Ribaudo, Amy, and Beth. Dear brother of Katherine Trimarco, Ida Van Lindt, and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Julia, Andrew, Micaela, and Nicholas. The Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood, NJ where visitation hours will be on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral services depart the Funeral Home on Saturday, August 30, 2003 at 10:30 AM processing to Our Lady of Mt. Carmel R.C. Church where a Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10:45 AM. Cremation private.

title: In Reversal, U.S. Nears Deal On Drugs for Poor Countries
description: The United States said today that it was close to accepting an agreement, which it had rejected last December, to help poor nations buy generic medicines through exemptions from trade rules.

description: To the Editor:

title: Politics and Pollution
description: President Bush's critics have watched with mounting frustration as his administration has compiled one of the worst environmental records in recent history without paying any real political price. One reason may be that the issues at stake are too regional, like forest fires or salmon recovery, or too remote, like global warming. But the administration itself may now have witlessly altered this dynamic with its reckless and insupportable decision to eviscerate a central provision of the Clean Air Act and allow power plants, refineries and other industrial sites to spew millions of tons of unhealthy pollutants into the air.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the killing of John J. Geoghan, a former priest convicted of child molestation, referred incorrectly to Bernard F. Law, who as the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston allowed priests accused of abuse to remain in the ministry. He is a cardinal, not a former cardinal. (He resigned as archbishop in December.)

title: If the Webmaster's Busy, Everyone Else Can Pitch In
description: The latest version of Contribute, software from Macromedia that can help nonexperts update Web page content, allows Macintosh users to contribute shoulder to shoulder with their Windows co-workers. In addition to being compatible with Mac OS X, Contribute 2 has several new features for the Windows side, including the Macromedia FlashPaper function, which can be used to convert any printable type of document into an embedded Web page element.

title: Even Without Sears Card, Mayor Revels in Tax Discount
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went to a Sears in Queens yesterday to publicize the city's week of no sales tax on clothing under $110. Of course, until the city and state moved to plug budget holes this spring, there were 52 such weeks a year.

title: The Kids Left Behind
description: He was going to be the education president, and during the campaign in 2000 he hugged kids from coast to coast, crowing about the education miracle in Texas and promising to spread the Texas model nationwide.

title: In New Musical, Can't Live With 'Em, Or (Surprise!) Without 'Em, Either
description: ''The Thing About Men,'' a new Off Broadway musical that opened yesterday at the Promenade Theater, has a misleading sheen of irreverence to it. Written by Joe DiPietro (book and lyrics) and Jimmy Roberts (music), the show, in the end, presents the same hokey can't-live-with-'em-or-without-'em view of relations between men and women as did their previous collaboration, the long-running trifle ''I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change.'' But it sets off with a different, more interesting attitude entirely.
