title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Investment Cap Eased
description: China's new banking regulator, Liu Mingkang, left, has confirmed that the government plans to lift the ceiling on foreign bank ownership of local banks to 25 percent from the current 15 percent in a bid to improve the performance of midsize institutions. In comments Tuesday in The International Financial News, Mr. Liu said China should encourage foreign banks to become strategic investors in its midsize banks. ''A single shareholder can increase the holding to 20 percent, but total foreign investment shouldn't exceed 25 percent,'' Mr. Liu told a recent meeting of foreign bankers, the report said.

title: Brown-Forman Profit Falls
description: The Brown-Forman Corporation, the maker of Jack Daniel's whiskey and Southern Comfort liqueurs, said yesterday that quarterly profit dropped 14 percent after it settled a lawsuit over the distribution of Jack Daniel's in Britain.

title: Strike Up the Band: An Electronic Accompanist Jumps In
description: SONY has a hit product in Aibo, its robotic pooch that can ride a skateboard, respond to voice commands, take snapshots with its digital camera and play with a ball.

title: Designing for the Dispossessed
description: AT age 29, Cameron Sinclair was among the youngest speakers at the International Design Conference in Aspen, Colo., last week. He nonetheless brought a full auditorium to its feet Thursday morning with a review of his work with Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit organization he started from his Manhattan studio apartment with a scattering of volunteers and a shoestring budget.

title: People
description: * Kris Niblett was named to the new post of creative director at Alcott Routon, Nashville. She had been creative director at her own agency, Creative That Clicks, Fort Worth, Tex.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a furor in London prompted by harsh criticism of a new novel by Martin Amis misidentified his previous novel. It was ''Night Train,'' published in 1997, not ''The Information,'' which was published in 1995. The article also misspelled the surname of another literary celebrity of Mr. Amis's generation. He is Ian McEwan, not McEwen.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Utility Executive Named
description: The utility holding company AES Corporation has named Eduardo Bernini, a Brazilian executive, to succeed Steven Clancy as head of its embattled division in Brazil. Mr. Bernini, who is to take over Monday, guided Eletropaulo, AES's main Brazilian asset, through its privatization in 1998. For the last three years, he has led local operations for Electricidade de Portugal. His first task will be to try to conclude a renegotiation of about $1.2 billion of debt that AES owes to Brazil's development bank, BNDES. AES borrowed the money to buy Eletropaulo in 1998, but as a result of an energy crisis in 2001 and an economic slump the company has defaulted. BNDES is insisting that AES must pay the debt or hand over control of Eletropaulo. AES gets about a quarter of its global revenues from Brazil. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Man Fired by Warehouse Kills 6 of Its 9 Employees
description: A man with a long but low-level arrest record returned this morning to the small auto supply warehouse from which he was fired six months ago, killing six of its nine employees, including two of the company's principals.

title: Satisfying the Law, And the Neighbors
description: SOME homeowners choose to install windmills in their backyard to help reduce their power bills. It helps if they have friendly neighbors and a willingness to lobby local authorities.

title: Ford Is Predicting a Profit in Europe
description: The Ford Motor Company, which named a chief of European operations Tuesday, said today that it expected the division to return to showing a profit in the fourth quarter.

title: Giants' Levens to Get His Shot Against the Ravens
description: The Giants' game against the Baltimore Ravens on Thursday night, their last of the preseason, will not feature many starters -- quarterback Kerry Collins will not see action unless he catches a ball on the sideline -- but it will determine how the rest of the roster shapes up.

title: Berlin Journal; Liebchen, There's a Piggish Eater on the Lawn
description: Gunshots rang out late the other night near Altestrasse, a street of imposing ocher houses and gardens alongside the Grunewald, the large forested park on the western edge of Berlin. There was no other way to deal with the marauders than to kill them.

description: About 40 teachers and their supporters rallied outside City Hall yesterday, protesting the dismissal of thousands of teachers who had failed to pass teacher certification exams.

description: What if you held a bidding war and no one wanted to fight? That might somewhat resemble the current predicament of Canary Wharf, London's financial center born on the ruins of old docks in the 1980's.

Riordan, whose chief strategist produces Mr. Schwarzenegger's commercials, lost the Republican primary for governor to Bill Simon Jr. last year. It was 18 percentage points, not 42.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERMAN, JEAN
description: HERMAN -- Jean. Beloved wife of the late Harry Herman, loving mother of Jill Kline and Joan Nabatoff, devoted grandmother of Diane, Richard and Ross Nabatoff and Billy Kline and Carole Feuer. Cherished great grandmother of Andrew, Nathan and Alison Nabatoff and Alexandra Feuer and Will Feuer. Services private.

title: A State Pursues WorldCom; Effects Seen On U.S. Case
description: The legal morass engulfing the telecommunications giant WorldCom worsened yesterday as Oklahoma charged the company and six of its former executives, including Bernard J. Ebbers, WorldCom's longtime chief executive, with 15 felony violations of the state's securities laws.

title: Your Message Here, in a Flash
description: IN an industrial building on the Jersey City waterfront, workers busily printed supersize images for building facades and billboards intended to paper even the most casual viewer with brand awareness. Suspended near the rafters were full-color images of the youth tribes of Gap and giant emblems of National Basketball Association teams; on a far wall a portrait of a Seagram's vodka bottle hung two stories high.

title: Germany Offers to Expand Afghan Force if the U.N. Approves
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder said today that Germany would expand its military presence in Afghanistan if the United Nations extended the mandate for the international force there.

title: Gold-Medal Message From Mexican Woman
description: When she crossed the finish line tonight after having run the fastest quarter-mile of her life, Ana Guevara of Mexico flexed her biceps. It was a flamboyant but appropriate gesture, given the way she had muscled past the field over 400 meters at the world track and field championships.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 16 about fires during the blackout misidentified the Connecticut city where a woman was killed in a blaze that officials attributed to a candle left burning. It was Waterbury, not Westport.

title: With Bird in Charge, Pacers Fire Thomas
description: When Donnie Walsh, the Indiana Pacers' chief executive, hired Larry Bird as his president of basketball operations on July 11, Walsh told him he was inclined to keep Isiah Thomas as coach but had concerns about the team's late-season swoon. He wanted Bird's opinion.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: WATKINS GLEN: FIRST WEST NILE DEATH An 81-year-old man from upstate New York has become the first person in the state to die this year after being infected with the West Nile virus, health officials confirmed yesterday. The victim, from Schuyler County in the Finger Lakes, was hospitalized on Aug. 8 with symptoms of encephalitis, or swelling of the brain, and died on Tuesday, said George Roets, a spokesman for the Schuyler County Department of Community Services and Public Health. Mr. Roets said that health officials were not sure where the victim had contracted the mosquito-borne virus. An 86-year-old woman from the Bronx was hospitalized with the virus on Aug. 11 and is recovering. (AP)

title: Sports of The Times; U.S.T.A. Should Promote The Game, Not the Babes
description: ONLY one forbidden Russian could pout her way into the hearts of middle-age men seeking a Kevin Spacey moment amid the ''American Beauty'' rose petals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORGEL, SIDNEY A.
description: ORGEL--Sidney A., Ph.D. The New York State Psychological Association is deeply saddened by the death of a respected friend and accomplished professional, Past President Sidney A. Orgel, Ph.D. We extend our condolences to his wife June, his children David, Carol and Seth, and his grandchildren. He will be missed.

Service at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City, at 1:00 P.M. on Thursday, August 28.

title: No More Arguments Over '5 More Minutes'
description: It's not just what children watch on television that worries parents (the V-chip was supposed to take care of that), but how much time they spend staring at the screen. Several new sets from RCA allow parents to set limits on TV viewing time, even if the children get home before the parents do.

title: De La Hoya Shrugs Off Pain in His Left Wrist
description: Oscar De La Hoya lied yesterday. That's what he said. But he has issued warnings before that he will say anything to confuse an opponent.

title: Jinx Falkenburg, Model, Actress, Pioneer Of Radio and TV Talk Shows, Dies at 84
description: Jinx Falkenburg, one of America's highest paid cover-girl models during World War II, and later, with her husband, Tex McCrary, a pioneer talk-show star on both radio and television, died on Wednesday in Manhasset, N.Y. She was 84 and lived in the nearby village of Mill Neck.

title: North Koreans And Americans Begin Dialogue
description: The United States and North Korea had their first face-to-face meeting in four months here this afternoon as part of six-nation negotiations on how to end North Korea's nuclear program, but diplomats played down prospects for an early breakthrough.

title: Blair Says He Would Have Quit if BBC Claims Were True
description: LONDON, Aug. 28  Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he would have had to resign had there been truth to a BBC report that his government had "sexed up" an intelligence dossier on Iraq with dubious information.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Date For Cleric's Verdict
description: The chief judge in the treason trial of the radical Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Bashir said in court that the judges would announce a verdict on Tuesday. Mr. Bashir is widely thought to be the spiritual leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, the terrorist organization he helped set up in the early 1990's. He denies there is such an organization. In his final court statement, Mr. Bashir said he was accountable only to Allah, not to the prosecutors or judges, whom he accused of acting under pressure from the ''infidels.'' He included Singapore and Australia, as well as the United States. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: For Houston Schools, College Claims Exceed Reality
description: At Jack Yates High School here, students had to make do without a school library for more than a year. A principal replaced dozens of experienced teachers with substitutes and uncertified teachers, who cost less.

title: NIKE ANNOUNCES THE FILLING OF 5 EXECUTIVE POSITIONS
description: Nike Inc. has named five people to executive positions. The executives included Tom Arndorfer, who will serve as vice president and chief financial officer of Nike USA. Nike, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., said Mr. Arndorfer has been with Nike since becoming its controller for global footwear in 1996. Nike also named Jim Carter vice president and general counsel. Adam Helfant was named vice president for sports marketing in the United States. Nike appointed John Hoke as its vice president for global footwear design, and Bernie Pilska as vice president and corporate controller.

title: Schwarzenegger Is Pressed for His Views on Social Issues
description: Facing aggressive questioning, Arnold Schwarzenegger, the actor-turned-candidate-for-governor, found himself having to lay out his positions today on a range of contentious social issues that he had so far avoided in the hectic California recall election.

title: Revlon Running Near Empty

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDERS, LESLEY SPRING
description: SANDERS--Lesley Spring. An unforgettable woman, bright, beautiful, creative and caring. A shining light extinguished at the too young age of 54. Resident of New York City and Litchfield, Conn. Devoted and beloved wife of Steven A. Sanders. Precious mother of Geoffrey and wife, Debbie. Darling daughter of Helene and Leonard Spring. Loving sister of Meryl Mann and husband, Michael. Adored daughter-in-law of Vivian Sanders and the late Daniel Sanders. Dear niece, aunt, cousin, friend and respected colleague. Role model for all. A woman of great integrity, energy and love who blessed us with her presence for too short a time. Service Friday, August 29th, 11 AM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. Contributions in Lesley's memory may be made to the Helene Spring Library at East End Temple, 245 East 17 Street, NY, NY 10010.

title: Shuttle Report Spurs A Debate in Congress
description: The report citing a ''broken safety culture'' at NASA has prompted a broad debate in Congress over the future of the space program, with some suggesting that human spaceflight be curtailed and others promoting expanded space exploration.

title: The Mailbox, Not the Mail, Is the Draw
description: The mailroom at 50 Murray Street (below), a former I.R.S. office in Manhattan converted into rental apartments, sheds new light (literally) on the task of depositing the mail. Government-issue metal mailboxes have been replaced with glass ones (lightly frosted for privacy), lighted by concealed bulbs. And the mail carrier creates performance art. ''He changes the installation every day,'' said Jay Valgora of V Studio, who designed the mailroom. (V Studio is a subsidiary of WalkerGroup, and Mr. Valgora is design principal for both). Passers-by also get in on the show -- the back of one set of boxes faces the street. Junk mail is tossed into an altar in the mailroom's center. V Studio is at 95 Morton Street, New York; (212) 462-8000.

title: A Chicken (Or a Flock) For Every Lawn
description: Here's a hen party for your lawn from Catherine Hunter, a Belgian artist and ceramicist. She originally made the lawn birds by hand, but moved production to a factory in Normandy, France, when demand grew. Why hens? ''I had chickens at home when I was young, and think they are a very sympathetic animal,'' she said. ''My work tends to have a round shape and a sense of humor, so it fit.'' The models, which vary by body position, have charming names like Amlie, Dsire, Francine and Hlne. The roosters are Georges and Jules. There are also chicks. Made of glazed earthenware, they have hand-attached details. Available in eight colors, the hens, which are roughly life size, are $160 each, the roosters $170; a set of three youngsters is also $170. From DHF Imports; (352) 732-6644.

title: Prison Policy Put Priest in Unit With His Killer, Experts Say
description: John J. Geoghan, the defrocked pedophile priest strangled in prison by another inmate, was confined in the same protective custody unit as his attacker largely because the Massachusetts Department of Correction long shunned using protective housing for vulnerable inmates and has only two such units for its 9,500 prisoners, lawyers and experts familiar with the case say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLIDAY, ERNEST M.
description: HALLIDAY -- Ernest M. Known to his friends as Hal. Died August 1, at home in Manhattan, at age 89. Editor of American Heritage Magazine for many years. Author of ''Understanding Thomas Jefferson'' and ''John Berryman and the Thirties'' and ''The Ignorant Armies''. Hal was one of the first important critics of Ernest Hemingway. Hal was a passionate lifelong advocate of civil liberties and the separation of church and state. Memorial service to be held in Graduate Lounge of Philosophy Hall, Columbia University, at 4 P.M. on Saturday, September 20.

title: Velazquez Ties Saratoga Record
description: By riding two more winners yesterday, John Velazquez tied Jerry Bailey's Saratoga Race Course record of 55 winners at the track's meeting, with four days remaining.

title: Mideast Peace: The Money Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERTOCCHI, BALDO V., M.D.
description: BERTOCCHI--Baldo V., M.D. Lutheran HealthCare mourns the loss of Dr. Baldo W. Bertocchi who was affiliated with Lutheran Medical Center for more than 50 years, first as a resident, then as a highly respected attending physician in obstetrics and gynecology. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. His friendship, loyalty and dedication will be missed by all of us. Wendy Z. Goldstein, President & CEO Howard Smith, Chairman, Board of Trustees Eugene Gibilaro, M.D. President, LMC Medical & Dental Staff

title: Is the Ride Over For the Hamptons?
description: AFTER the blink-and-you-missed-it summer of 2003, marked by controversies both old (the crowds, the traffic jams) and new (gay men arrested for having sex on the beach, the mysterious draining of Georgica Pond), and increasing concerns about the slumping summer rental market, many New Yorkers are approaching the Labor Day weekend with a pressing question on their minds: ''Are the Hamptons finally over?'' Page 6.

title: North Korea Says It May Test an A-Bomb
description: North Korea told diplomats from five other nations on Thursday that it planned to declare formally that it has become a nuclear power and may test an atomic bomb in the near future to prove it, according to senior Bush administration officials.

title: Fresh Glimpse in 9/11 Files Of the Struggles for Survival
description: Until yesterday, when the Port Authority released its raw historical records from Sept. 11, the two men were remembered from glimpses as the north tower of the World Trade Center was heaving toward collapse. One was short, the other tall. They carried a crowbar, a flashlight and walkie talkies. Beyond that, say some who survived that day, the smoke had blurred their faces and hair and clothes into gray.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially over the Labor Day weekend, and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: You've Been to the Game, Now Take a Look at the Artwork
description: In the catalog for ''The Perfect Game: America Looks at Baseball,'' the sweet and nearly pitch-perfect show at the American Folk Art Museum, the writer Roger Angell evokes what it must have been like to visit the Polo Grounds or Yankee Stadium on a midweek afternoon in, say, 1934.

title: States to Fight Easing of Rules On Pollution By Power Plants
description: A day after the Bush administration issued new rules that will relax pollution-control regulations for thousands of power plants and factories, environmental groups and state officials across the Northeast began preparing legal challenges to the policy shift.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telstra Reports 6.3% Decline In Profit
description: Australia's national phone company, Telstra, yesterday reported a 6.3 percent decline in net profit for the year through June, to 3.4 billion Australian dollars ($2.2 billion), but raised its second-half dividend by 10 percent. The chief executive, Zigmund Switkowski, said the results included a write-down of 965 million Australian dollars ($618 million) in the first half to cut the value of the company's assets in Reach Global Services, a cable venture in Hong Kong. John Shaw (NYT)

title: British Soldier Is Killed in Clash With a Mob in Southern Iraq
description: A British soldier was killed on Wednesday and another wounded when their convoy encountered an angry mob of Iraqis blocking a road in southern Iraq as they returned to base after arresting two suspected loyalists of Saddam Hussein, British military authorities said today.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: John Shearman, 72, Art Scholar Consulted on Vatican Frescoes
description: John Shearman, a historian of Italian Renaissance art who advised on the restoration of Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican, died on Aug. 11 while on vacation near Lethbridge, Alberta. He was 72.

title: Can a Nice Guy Beat a Bad Boy?
description: The subject of the British director Shane Meadows's ''Once Upon a Time in the Midlands'' is a wry counterpoint to the film's sprawling, epic title. The movie is a soulful domestic comedy that has more in common with the enchantingly freakish twitches of life in a Bill Forsyth film like ''Local Hero'' than with one of Sergio Leone's blood-orange epics like ''Once Upon a Time in the West.''

title: U.S. Rolls to Victory
description: For the United States men's basketball team, trying to recover its pride from last summer's nightmare world championships, qualifying for the 2004 Olympics is not enough. Winning every game here, no matter how meaningless, is the goal.

title: Few Fans Seek Out Clay-Court Specialist
description: Court 11 at the National Tennis Center has a waist-high fence on one side and a grandstand that seats about 1,200 on the other. Spectators can walk by the fence, chat with friends or glance at the United States Open match on their way to the food court.

title: College Football at a Crossroads
description: Mark Murphy earned All-Pro honors and a Super Bowl ring as member of the Washington Redskins. He acknowledges that most of his teammates neither graduated from college nor really cared about doing so.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Sunday with an article about Israel's rejection of a conditional cease-fire offer from the Palestinian Authority misstated the location of two Palestinian children shown throwing rocks at an Israeli tank. They were running behind the tank, not in front of it.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Miner's Profit Rises
description: The Australian mining company, BHP Billiton, said yesterday that its attributable profit increased 2.9 percent to $1.9 billion in the year through June. Sales increased 15 percent to $17.5 billion. The chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, an American appointed in January, said that the profit increase was led by strong demand for iron ore, and that fourth-quarter revenue indicated a rising global demand for oil and metals. The annual dividend was raised 11.5 percent, to 14.5 cents a share although earnings per share were fractionally less at 31 cents a share. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Chronicler of Private Moments Is Named Poet Laureate
description: The Library of Congress said today that it would name Louise E. Glck as the nation's poet laureate.

title: NASD Wants More Supervision Of Brokers Facing Complaints
description: NASD, formerly the National Association of Securities Dealers, proposed rules yesterday that would increase supervision of brokers who have a history of customer complaints.

title: $100 million to keep a hugely popular pickup hugely popular.
description: FEW products are as vital to a company as the F-Series pickup is to the Ford Motor Company.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Heavy Fighting In The South
description: American aircraft bombed suspected Taliban positions in southern Afghanistan as heavy fighting continued, officials said. Afghan and American forces have been battling militants in Zabul Province since Friday. There have been no American casualties, but at least 14 Afghans have been killed. A senior Afghan commander said that his soldiers had found three dead Taliban fighters and that four of his men had been wounded. In a separate incident, American troops were attacked by 10 gunmen near the border with Pakistan in Paktika Province. American airstrikes forced the gunmen to withdraw toward the Pakistani border. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter column on Monday, about renovations to the stretch of White House lawn where television correspondents do stand-up shots, misspelled the surname of a senior producer at ABC who is the liaison for the project. He is Peter Doherty, not Dougherty.

title: Why Do Polluters Get a Break?
description: To the Editor:

title: France Calls for International Force in Iraq Under the U.N.
description: Warning that the unstable situation in Iraq could fall into ''anarchy,'' France called today for the creation of an international military force and a provisional government there under United Nations authority.

title: Lottery Numbers
Cautiously, the Jets Close Out Their Preseason
description: At least Vinny Testaverde looked good on the coin toss.

title: Sports of The Times; Shades of Gray in the N.B.A.
description: ''IS this fun?'' Larry Brown was asked yesterday as he readied himself for another rollicking night at the Roberto Clemente Coliseum as the coach of the David Stern All-Stars, otherwise known as the United States national team.

title: Financing the Neophyte
description: When he first presented himself as the un-politician -- the swaggering Everyman in the California recall melee -- Arnold Schwarzenegger firmly vowed to be the enemy of fat-cat donors and special interests. ''I haven't sold out to any special interest groups,'' he growled in excoriating rivals like Lt. Gov. Cruz Bustamante, a Democrat promised millions from Indian casino tribes. ''They already have taken money. They already have sold out.''

title: GENERAL IN IRAQ SAYS MORE G.I.'S ARE NOT NEEDED
description: The top American commander for Iraq said today there was no need for more American troops there, but he encouraged Muslim allies like Turkey and Pakistan to send peacekeepers and said accelerating the training of a new Iraqi army should be considered.

title: ArvinMeritor Extends Dana Bid But Doesn't Raise Offer Price
description: ArvinMeritor Inc. extended its bid for a rival auto parts maker, the Dana Corporation, through Oct. 2, but did not raise its offer of $15 a share, or about $4.4 billion, for the company. Some analysts said that would make it difficult for Dana's shareholders to reconsider their earlier rejection of the offer.

title: Drafty. Decaying. Oh, I Loved It.
description: ''JUST a little camp,'' my great-grandmother called it. And though the summer house on Cape Cod that my family flocked to each August -- a 4-story, 11-bedroom conglomeration of bays, gables and dormers we called the Big House -- was anything but little, it was undeniably rustic, from its seaweed-stuffed walls to its single shower (outdoors, under a pine tree).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Robbers Invade Home
description: A woman and her five young children were the victims of a home invasion and robbery yesterday morning, when three thieves stole more than $164,000 in cash from their home in Prospect Heights, the police said. The woman's 9-year-old son used her cellphone to call his father, who reported the crime to the police. The police said the woman and her 3-year-old son had answered a knock at the door of their Underhill Avenue home when one suspect pointed a gun at them and demanded money. The suspects then fled through a window with the money and with jewelry worth $10,000 to $15,000, the police said. Two men and a woman were arrested less than 15 minutes later behind 665 Bergen Street, the police said, and the weapon, an imitation pellet gun, was found in a garbage can on the block. The money was recovered. The police said there was a large amount of cash in the house because the woman's husband handles construction companies' payrolls. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the influence on movies of the comic book writer and illustrator Jack Kirby misspelled a name in the title of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Michael Chabon, who said in the book's acknowledgments that he owed a deep debt to Mr. Kirby and who discussed Mr. Kirby's work. It is ''The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay,'' not Klay.

title: New Mexico Player Hangs Himself
description: University of New Mexico forward Billy Feeney hanged himself in an apparent suicide early this morning outside an apartment complex in downtown Albuquerque, authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Beach Waste Was Accidental
description: The syringes, crack vials and raw human sewage that have washed up on the Jersey Shore this summer, closing various beaches for days at a time, do not appear to be intentional acts of malice, state environment officials have concluded. The waste seems to have come from overflowing sewers, storm drains, shorelines and sewage treatment plants, officials said. In a statement released on Wednesday, the Division of Criminal Justice's Environmental Crimes Bureau said it had spent weeks investigating beach closures and other incidents between July 11 and Aug. 19. Tyrone Richardson (NYT)

title: Wells Could Lose A Turn
description: Despite a brief meeting among David Wells, Manager Joe Torre and Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees and Wells, their struggling left-hander, failed to come to a resolution yesterday concerning Wells's failure to throw in the bullpen between starts. With the issue still unresolved, Torre delayed a decision on whether Wells would take his normal turn in the rotation Monday against Toronto.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSSBERG, JERRY
description: GROSSBERG -- Jerry. We mourn the loss of our good friend, Jerry Grossberg. He fought a long battle in and out of hospitals, making a friend of every doctor and nurse he met. That's the kind of guy he was, a gentle, lovable soul, respected and loved by all who knew him. His wife Ellen was with him every step of the way; we all marveled at her strength. Heartfelt condolences to Ellen, their son Jayson and their daughter-in-law Alix. Jane and Michael and Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JACOBSON, FLORENCE
description: JACOBSON--Florence. Mom, you left us August 29, 2002. You gave such love and fullness to our lives. You are always with us. We miss you with all our hearts. Margot and Hele

title: Brushing Off the Party Crashers; Brooklyn Boss Celebrates Despite Corruption Inquiry
description: On board the party boat Bargemusic in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, the wine was flowing, the chicken wings were disappearing, and a man in a spangly red vest and matching sneakers was lip-synching the disco hit ''Got to Be Real.'' Soon he urged the guests to give it up for the guest of honor, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr.

title: 36 Hours | Galveston, Tex.
description: THE story of the crumbling but achingly beautiful port city of Galveston, it is often noted, can be divided into three phases: the architectural boom in Victorian palaces and ornate banking edifices that followed its creation as a prosperous trading outpost on the Gulf of Mexico, much of which was washed away by the devastating hurricane of 1900; a descent into a ''triad of vice'' of drinking, gambling and prostitution that gave Galveston a Big Easy kind of edge absent elsewhere in Texas; and a revival pinned on the expectation that urban renewal and a more sober tourism trade will pave the way to a brighter future. No doubt Galveston is recovering some of its luster since the days when the novelist Edna Ferber compared it to Miss Havisham, the old jilted bride of Dickens's ''Great Expectations.'' Its shops and restaurants are bulging with tourists, and it is almost impossible to book a good hotel room for a weekend on short notice. The stunning design of its 19th-century mansions jump out at you, especially if you're arriving from nearby Houston where so many old structures were razed to make way for a futuristic skyline. It can safely be said that Galveston, an island city bathed in sunlight and a salty sea breeze, these days resembles a club-hopping teenager more than a bitter old woman. SIMON ROMERO

title: After Cornering Suspect, Police Doubt He's Gunman
description: A suspect in the shooting of a police captain early Wednesday surrendered to heavily armed officers yesterday after a tense two-and-a-half-hour standoff in a peaceful Brooklyn neighborhood. But after questioning the man for several hours, investigators said they did not believe he was the gunman.

title: Dr. King's Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Maverick Award For Class Clown

title: Where Ladies Lunched, and Boys Grew Up
description: On this island it is easy enough to find a native. Still, some people who moved here as adults treat me like a rare specimen when I tell them I grew up in Manhattan. Their voices will rise in pitch, and then the inevitable question, ''Where?'' For such newcomers, I have discovered, no answer is too specific: ''Downtown'' or ''the East Side'' will simply trigger another ''Where?'' It is not as if they want to send my parents a fruit basket, but I surrender to their curiosity: ''20th Street,'' I tell them, ''between Second and Third Avenues.''

title: THE PORT AUTHORITY TAPES: In the PATH System; Calmly Taking Riders Out of Harm's Way
description: Just minutes after the first plane struck the World Trade Center, the full sense of chaos and panic had yet to overwhelm the PATH station below the twin towers. But the dispatcher on site knew something was seriously wrong as he directed the arrival of thousands of commuters during the morning rush.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Lawsuits Dismissed
description: A federal judge has thrown out two lawsuits filed by Deutsche Bank in which it seeks more than $500 million for damage caused to the bank's office building at 130 Liberty Street when the World Trade Center collapsed on Sept. 11. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District ruled that among other things, Deutsche Bank had failed to meet a key legal standard necessary for it to sue the city: establishing that the city owed the bank a higher standard of care than it did other residents and businesses. The suits had charged that the city negligently contributed to the collapse of 7 World Trade Center by storing diesel fuel there. The bank also charged in its lawsuit that the city prevented repair crews from entering the bank building when Lower Manhattan was sealed off. A bank spokeswoman declined to comment until the judge's decision could be read. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and an article in House & Home yesterday about John Hix, an architect, and his work on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques misstated part of the name of one of his projects, a small resort. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is Hix Island House, not Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOOD, PAUL W.
description: WOOD--Paul W. The officers, board and congregation of Temple Emanuel mourn the passing of Paul W. Wood and extend heartfelt condolences to Jacqueline Wood and her family. Paul's artistry and insight into the deeper meaning of Jewish symbols are concretized in the magnificent stained glass windows, ark and eternal light that grace our sanctuary. As we are moved by his works on levels that are intellectual and emotional, so we responded to the man, whose keen mind and gentle ways nourished and inspired us. May his memory be a benediction. Funeral Service is at St. Peter's Church, 1327 Port Washington Boulevard, Port Washington on Saturday, August 30 at 9:30 AM. Dr. Robert S. Widom, Rabbi Mandell Dalis, President Temple Emanuel of Great Neck

title: A First Take on Ring, Part 2
description: In content and promotional impact, "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy is a multifaceted machine. Last August "The Fellowship of the Ring," the first of Peter Jackson's three films, was released on DVD with a fair-size list of extras. In November a much-extended special edition appeared with 30 more minutes woven into a movie that already ran 178 minutes, and with many more extras to examine every aspect.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Internet Law Voided
description: A federal appeals court struck down a state law prohibiting distribution of pornographic materials on the Internet to children. The court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit sided with the American Booksellers Association, the American Civil Liberties Union and other groups, which said the law was too sweeping and violated the First Amendment rights of adults. It also ruled that the law impermissibly interfered with interstate commerce. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Congressman Faces Felony Charge in Fatal Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  Representative William J. Janklow of South Dakota was charged today with second-degree manslaughter in the death of a motorcyclist who was struck by Mr. Janklow's car on Aug. 16.

title: Jerusalem Holy Site a Tense Crossroads Again
description: Quietly but insistently, the Israeli authorities have pried open to non-Muslims the man-made plateau here that is one of the world's tinderboxes, the symbol and nexus of conflict between Jews and Arabs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCRARY, JINX FALKENBURG
description: McCRARY--Jinx Falkenburg. It is with profound sorrow that the Board of Directors of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with deep sorrow the passing of Jinx Falkenberg McCrary, our longtime friend and a founding member of UCP/NYC. We extend our deepest sympathy to her sons, Michael, Kevin and John. Leo Hausman, Chairman, Martin Hausman, President UCP of NYC, Inc.

title: Gory Rite of Passage for Would-Be Action Heroes
description: Paul Hough's video documentary ''The Backyard'' opens today at the Cinema Village, but it probably belongs in the American Museum of Natural History's annual Margaret Mead Film and Video Festival. It's an astounding anthropological study of that strange tribe known as the American teenager.

description: Raising Victor Vargas

description: WHO -- Ken Wilhelm, 58, lawyer

title: THE PORT AUTHORITY TAPES: On the Phones; Many Questions, But Few Answers
description: Each time the phone rang, another fearful, confused, urgent or sometimes oblivious voice asked for information that the Port Authority police officers at their various command desks mostly did not have.

description: To the Editor:

title: School of MTV As College Prep
description: Labor Day weekend is the time when 2.5 million Americans start their first semester of college. If the Showtime series ''Freshman Diaries'' is to be believed, every single one of them prepped at MTV's ''Real World.''

title: INSIDE
description: A Warning From North Korea

title: Reyes Again Justifies A Scout's Act of Faith
description: The arm that fires balls across the infield as if he is in a shooting gallery was unremarkable four years ago. The legs that power his body across the bases as if he is running for his life were too slow for most teams. There was little noteworthy about Jos Reyes when the Mets signed the Dominican teenager in 1999.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Begins Group For Workers Not in Unions
description: Hoping to increase its political clout, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced yesterday that it was creating a novel organization for nonunion workers who agree with the labor movement on many issues and want to campaign alongside labor on those issues.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit For Retailer
description: Europe's largest retailer, Carrefour, said yesterday that its first-half profit rose 17.9 percent from the first half of 2002, reaching 472 million euros ($514 million). The company also raised its growth estimate to 6 percent for the year, up from 5 percent at the beginning of 2003, and said it expected its earnings per share to rise at least 10 percent. The company, which has stores in 30 countries, expects it will have 10,000 outlets before the end of 2003. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Effort to Diminish Arafat Is Said to Strengthen Him
description: When the United States pushed Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to appoint a prime minister three months ago, American and Israeli officials hoped that Mr. Arafat would recede from the scene, profile diminished and power diluted.

title: Greenspan Says Fed Shouldn't Be Restricted by Formal Targets
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 29  Fending off critics who say the nation's monetary policy has become too personalized and idiosyncratic, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, stepped up his insistence today that the Fed should continue to have broad discretion and not be hemmed in by formal rules or even by long-established traditions.

title: Peru Report Says 69,000 Died in 20 Years of Rebel War
description: A government-appointed truth commission said in a report issued today that more than 69,000 people were killed between 1980 and 2000, over twice the previous estimates of the death toll for the period of war and rebellion.

title: Rate of Rape at Academy Is Put at 12% in Survey
description: Nearly 12 percent of the women who graduated from the United States Air Force Academy this year were the victims of rape or attempted rape in their four years at the academy in Colorado Springs, with the vast majority never reporting the incidents to the authorities, according to a survey by the inspector general of the Defense Department.

title: THE PORT AUTHORITY TAPES: In Windows on the World; Doing as She's Told, But It's Not Enough
description: Christine Olender, an assistant to the general manager at Windows on the World, had already done everything she could. The breakfast guests and restaurant employees had been collected on the 106th floor of the north tower.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Not-Guilty Plea In Baby's Death
description: A man accused of tying an electrical cord around his 1-year-old son's neck and hanging him from a shower-curtain rod has pleaded not guilty. The man, Juan Batista, 27, of Corona, was arraigned on Wednesday on two counts of murder. The child's body was found on July 26 in a bathroom at the Crown Motor Inn, the police said. Mr. Batista had taken the child there after seeing the baby's mother with another man, the police said. Mr. Batista, who then tried to hang himself, is in a Brooklyn hospital under psychiatric watch, the Queens district attorney's office said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Mars: I'm Disappointed
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 18th District -- Bronx; Unions' Interest Ratchets Up the Intrigue in a Bronx Race
description: Pedro Gautier Espada is 29 years old, and his current race for City Council in the Bronx represents the ninth time that he has campaigned for political or public office. And given a similar number of races undertaken by his father, City Councilman Pedro Espada Jr., the younger Mr. Espada has seen more than his share of Bronx politics.

title: All in This Together: A Family, a Small Boat, A Long Trip to Canada
description: THINGS had gone beautifully. We were coming into Chelsea Piers after a 12-day journey through New York's waterways, bringing our 30-foot wooden fishing boat into a graceful curve, successfully throwing the dockmaster our bow line. But then a heavy current carried us starboard. ''Watch out!'' all four of us on board seemed to yell simultaneously. And instead of slipping nicely into our berth, we crashed into the dock, causing the feet of the unfortunate dockmaster to slide right out from under him.

title: Folk Art Paradise Springs Back to Life
description: THE 56-year-old Shelburne Museum here, the most awesome folk art phenomenon in the United States, has been livening up in the last few years after a long fallow period.

title: A Win for Missy Elliott at Music Video Awards
description: For 11 and a half months of the year, MTV treats music videos as second-class programming. And why not?

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: VIDEOTAPE SHOWS HOSTAGES The F.B.I. has obtained a videotape of three Defense Department contractors captured by Colombian rebels when their small plane crashed in February, United States officials said. The tape was made by a journalist with the rebels' permission. It is the first evidence that the three men are still alive. They were captured by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia when their plane crashed on an antidrug mission. The rebels want to exchange the men for jailed guerrillas.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Changes For War Crimes Prosecutor
description: The Security Council voted unanimously to remove Carla Del Ponte as prosecutor of the United Nations war crimes tribunal for Rwanda while also endorsing her reappointment as prosecutor of war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia. Ms. Del Ponte, a former Swiss attorney general, had fought to retain control of both tribunals. The Rwandan government, which she has accused of obstructing her investigations into the 1994 mass killings there, lobbied to have Ms. Del Ponte replaced. The Council's resolution, recommended by Secretary General Kofi Annan, spoke only of improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the tribunals by putting each one under a separate prosecutor. Mr. Annan is expected to nominate Hassan Jallo, the attorney general of Gambia, to take over the Rwanda tribunal. Susan Sachs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESPOSITO, SALVATORE, J., JR.
description: ESPOSITO--Salvatore, J., Jr. The Officers, Board of Trustees and Staff of The American Parkinson's Disease Association, Inc. mourn the loss of our past President and member of our founding family, who dedicated his life to finding the cure and easing the burden of those afflicted with Parkinson's disease. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife Lillian, his children, grandchildren and his sister Sophia. His guidance will be missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers contributions to The American Parkinson's Disease Association, Inc., 1250 Hylan Blvd, Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305 would be appreciated. Vincent N. Gattullo, President Joel Gerstel, Exec Director

title: A Different Standard of Living
description: The Dominican authorities spent tens of millions of dollars on new stadiums and pavilions for the recent Pan American Games, but when they needed bomb-sniffing dogs to protect visiting athletes and spectators, they had to borrow them from the international airport here.

title: E.P.A. Says It Lacks Power To Regulate Some Gases
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it did not have the legal authority to regulate emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases under the Clean Air Act.

title: Miscellany
description: * RL Public Relations and Marketing, Century City, Calif., opened Sportivo, an agency specializing in sports marketing aimed at Latinos. Sportivo is based in Century City and has offices in Buenos Aires and Mexico City.

title: Another Guilty Plea in HealthSouth Case
description: A former vice president of the HealthSouth Corporation has admitted lying to auditors about the value of an investment, becoming the 14th executive to plead guilty in an accounting fraud that prosecutors say will exceed $2.5 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Loss
description: The reinsurance company Munich Re reported a fifth consecutive quarterly loss, hurt by a proposed change in German tax law. The net loss was 365 million euros ($397 million) in the second quarter, compared with a loss of 383 million euros ($417 million) in the quarter a year earlier. The loss included 1.12 billion euros ($1.22 billion) that the company set aside for taxes because of the proposed change in the law. Before taxes, Munich Re, based in Munich, earned 737 million euros ($802 million) in the quarter, compared with a 1.3 billion euro ($1.4 billion) loss a year ago. Gross premium income rose 2.3 percent, to 9.9 billion euros ($10.8 billion).

title: Yanks Head to Boston, Lead and Confidence Rebuilt
description: The starting pitcher was not pounded, Mariano Rivera did his job, the Yankees' offense was adequate and the idle Boston Red Sox did not gain any ground. Hysteria need not reign as the Yankees head to Boston for a three-game series that begins tonight. The Yankees shook off two straight dismal efforts and slowed down the Chicago White Sox with a 7-5 victory yesterday, averting a three-game sweep.

title: Trading Needed Medicine
description: The prognosis for a lot of sick people in the world's poorest nations, and for the health of the current round of global trade talks, may soon brighten considerably as a result of the Bush administration's retreat from one of its more unfortunate unilateral diplomatic stances.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm And Handspring Win Patent Suit Filed By NCR
description: Palm Inc. and its smaller rival Handspring Inc. did not infringe patents for a hand-held computer system owned by NCR, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The judge, Kent A. Jordan at Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., upheld a finding by a magistrate in July 2002 that the two makers of hand-held devices did not rely on technology patented by NCR for a personal terminal. Palm said in June that it agreed to buy Handspring for about $168.9 million in stock. NCR, the largest seller of automated bank-teller machines, sued Handspring and Palm in March 2001, saying they used NCR inventions for devices that let users shop and conduct other business with credit-card-sized terminals connected to communications networks. NCR wanted a percentage of Palm and Handspring sales and was seeking ''significant'' amounts, a Palm lawyer, Brad Hulbert, said. Executives of NCR could not be reached for comment. NCR shares rose 5 cents, to close at $28.65. Handspring shares rose 8 cents, to $1.03. Shares of Palm rose $1.04, to $18.03.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES ENDS STOCK OPTIONS TO BOARD Computer Associates International , the world's fifth-largest software company, said yesterday that it had ended stock-option grants to its directors and increased their yearly fee to $60,000. Pay rose to $150,000 in so-called deferred stock units, under a plan that shareholders approved yesterday. Last year, board members received $49,000 in stock options and $45,000 in cash. The eight nonemployee directors, including former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, can take half their pay in cash and will also receive dividends. Computer Associates raised the pay to keep it equivalent with that of rivals and because the board's duties increased as new corporate-governance rules were adopted, a proxy statement said. The company's chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, and vice president, Russell M. Artzt, sit on the board and get no additional pay. Shares of Computer Associates fell 7 cents, to $25.06.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Editorial Observer; When Life Offers a Choice Between the White Wall and the Brick Wall
description: When Bartleby, the scrivener, is asked by his boss to help with some law-office drudgery, Bartleby says what lowly employees everywhere long to say: ''I would prefer not to.'' Despite his employer's attempts to change his mind, and to learn his reasons for turning down assignments, Bartleby never says much more. ''Why do you refuse?'' his boss asks. ''I would prefer not to,'' Bartleby replies placidly. ''You will not?'' his boss asks. ''I prefer not,'' Bartleby says.

title: Have Moviegoers Reached a Verdict?
description: IN ''Runaway Jury,'' opening next month, Dustin Hoffman, Gene Hackman, John Cusack and Rachel Weisz are involved in the trial of a gun manufacturer. The film is less about the trial, though, than about the battle between a corrupt juror and a hard-nosed jury consultant. That's the way it goes in courtroom movies. Either all the action takes place in the jury room or moviegoers are kept completely in the dark about deliberations. You can't blame the screenwriters; they have every reason to keep that part of the drama a mystery. Jurors shouldn't feel unduly unimportant, though. In a lot fo trial films, including some of these, all available on video, it's not about the defendants either. Sometimes the film's big stars are playing the lawyers. Naturally.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: 9/11 LAWSUITS DISMISSED A federal judge has thrown out two lawsuits filed by Deutsche Bank in which it seeks more than $500 million for damage caused to the bank's office building at 130 Liberty Street when the World Trade Center collapsed on Sept. 11. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District ruled that among other things, Deutsche Bank had failed to meet a key legal standard necessary for it to sue the city: establishing that the city owed the bank a higher standard of care than it did other residents and businesses. The suits had charged that the city negligently contributed to the collapse of 7 World Trade Center by storing diesel fuel there. The bank also charged in its lawsuit that the city prevented repair crews from entering the bank building when Lower Manhattan was sealed off. A bank spokeswoman declined to comment until the judge's decision could be read. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about the mystery writer Martha Grimes and her new novel about the publishing industry, ''Foul Matter,'' misstated the meaning of the publishing term used as the book's title. ''Foul Matter'' refers to the edited manuscript and proofs of a book that have been superseded by revised or corrected versions or by the final printed work. It is not a term for an unedited manuscript.

title: KELLWOOD LOWERS PROFIT FORECAST AS ORDERS FALL
description: The Kellwood Company, maker of the Sag Harbor and Koret clothing lines, reduced its profit and sales forecasts for the year because of lower than expected orders from two department store chains, the J.C. Penney Company and the Kohl's Corporation. Excluding some costs, profit is expected to be $2.60 to $2.65 a share, the company said. In May, Kellwood forecast profit of at least $2.70 a share. Orders were $30 million less than expected, with about half of the shortfall coming after the chains decided not to repeat two promotional programs with Kellwood. The expense of producing new clothing lines will add about 7 cents a share to costs. Kellwood also said its second-quarter profit had increased 70 percent, to $6.69 million.

The suspect was taken to Mercy Medical Center, and the extent of his injuries was not known. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: What's Junk on the Mainland Is a Ride on a Maine Island
description: ONE Saturday several weeks ago, six men in tuxedos clambered into the back of a 1975 Chevrolet pickup with a broken window, a smashed taillight, a leaky tire and a bumper sticker proclaiming: ''I Brake For Lobsters.'' They were headed for a wedding at the Chebeague Inn, overlooking Casco Bay on the coast of Maine. Brad Pattershall, the bridegroom, sat in the cargo area, a flower in his lapel.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Cleric Suspended
description: Muhammad Sayed Tantawi, left, grand imam of Al Azhar, the most prestigious religious institution in Sunni Islam, suspended a cleric who issued a religious edict demanding that Muslim countries boycott the Iraqi Governing Council appointed by the United States. The cleric, Sheik Nabawi al-Ish, declared the Council illegitimate because it was forced upon the Iraqis by an occupying power. Dr. Tantawi, who is appointed by the Egyptian government, said that Sheik Ish did not represent Al Azhar and that only Iraqi clerics could proclaim edicts regarding Iraq, the official news agency MENA reported. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Associates Ends Stock Options To Board
description: Computer Associates International, the world's fifth-largest software company, said yesterday that it had ended stock-option grants to its directors and increased their yearly fee to $60,000. Pay rose to $150,000 in so-called deferred stock units, under a plan that shareholders approved yesterday. Last year, board members received $49,000 in stock options and $45,000 in cash. The eight nonemployee directors, including former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, can take half their pay in cash and will also receive dividends. Computer Associates raised the pay to keep it equivalent with that of rivals and because the board's duties increased as new corporate-governance rules were adopted, a proxy statement said. The company's chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, and vice president, Russell M. Artzt, sit on the board and get no additional pay. Shares of Computer Associates fell 7 cents, to $25.06.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 280 American service members killed since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Residential Real Estate; Income-Limited Units in Greenwich
description: Construction is to begin next month in Greenwich on a four-story rental building that will include nine apartments with income restrictions, following a legal fight that the developer ultimately won after citing Connecticut's Affordable Housing Law.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP., El Segundo, Calif., a provider of technology services, said it had signed a 10-year, $342 million contract to provide computer, help desk and network infrastructure services to Malayan Banking , Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia's largest banking group.

title: Why Do Polluters Get a Break?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: BEACH WASTE WAS ACCIDENTAL The syringes, crack vials and raw human sewage that have washed up on the Jersey Shore this summer, closing various beaches for days at a time, do not appear to be intentional acts of malice, state environment officials have concluded. The waste seems to have come from overflowing sewers, storm drains, shorelines and sewage treatment plants, officials said. In a statement released on Wednesday, the Division of Criminal Justice's Environmental Crimes Bureau said it had spent weeks investigating beach closures and other incidents between July 11 and Aug. 19.

title: This Company's Shareholders May Regret It if They Don't Sell
description: AMONG the bad Internet investments that were sold to gullible buyers in the spring of 2000, Register.com stands out. Unlike most companies that went public in the frenzied weeks just before the bubble burst, Register managed to hold on to the cash it raised. Now it plans to distribute the cash to its investors.

title: Shopping List | Cooling Off
description: SUN is a good thing and a hot, humid thing. But outwitting the heat is no problem thanks to new body-heat lowering devices designed for an instant chill out. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Profits Up for Retailer of Pet Supplies
description: Petsmart Inc., the pet supplies retailer, said yesterday that second-quarter profit surged 31 percent after it remodeled stores and added services like veterinarian checkups.

description: To the Editor:

description: ON THE STREET

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar after a government report showed the United States economy expanded at the fastest rate in three quarters. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0871, down from $1.0885.

title: Mind the Gap
description: Direct your attention for a moment away from the bombings, intrigue and frustrations of Baghdad to the swath of southwestern Iraq that has been controlled by the United States Marines.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Record Trade Deficit
description: Australia posted a record current account deficit of 12.7 billion Australian dollars ($8.1 billion) in the second quarter, as a result of weak exports and strong demand for imports. The deficit raised concerns that the country's overall economy might have contracted. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Tony Blair's Iraq Dossier
description: The secret workings of Tony Blair's government have been on public display this month as a judicial inquiry has gathered testimony on the death, apparently by suicide, of a British weapons scientist, David Kelly. Yesterday, it was Mr. Blair's turn to testify. His defense of almost all aspects of his government's use of intelligence material during the months leading up to the Iraq war was spirited but unconvincing. Despite all the protestations of innocence by Mr. Blair and his aides, it is clear that his government embellished the truth in its stark warnings of an imminent Iraqi threat.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about Israel's rejection of a conditional cease-fire offer from the Palestinian Authority misstated the location of two Palestinian children shown throwing rocks at an Israeli tank. They were running behind the tank, not in front of it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Demand Is Up Sharply For Stomach Operations

title: Child of Hell Is Plague on His House
description: THE TATTOOED GIRL

title: A Pay Package That Fat Cats Call Excessive
description: Richard A. Grasso has succeeded at what some would consider an impossible task: making Wall Street gasp in astonishment at someone else's compensation.

title: Prosecutors Fight DNA Use for Exoneration
description: After seeing more than 130 prisoners freed by DNA testing in the last 15 years, prosecutors in Florida and across the country have mounted a vigorous challenge to similar new cases.

title: Cinematic Surprises, Refreshing As Real Life
description: FUNNY about reality in entertainment: as hard as it may be to pin down what's true to life in the movies and on television, you know it when you see it. Even when that reality is disturbing, to acknowledge its truthfulness can feel as rejuvenating as a gulp of fresh air.

title: Free Tutoring Reaches Only Fraction of Students
description: A vast majority of New York City children who were eligible for free tutoring last year under a new federal law never got the extra help, and critics say there are few signs of improvement this year.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: BOMBS AT A BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANY Two small bombs shattered windows at the Emeryville offices of the Chiron Corporation , a biotechnology company, but nobody was hurt and the authorities said damage was minimal. The police and company officials declined to comment on possible suspects; Chiron and its executives have recently been the subject of animal-rights protests. Chiron, which makes drugs, is required by the Food and Drug Administration to test products for safety and effectiveness on animals before it can sell them. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Jinx Falkenburg, a model and early talk-show star, reversed the places of residence of her sons. John Reagan McCrary 3d lives in Mill Neck, N.Y., and Kevin Jock McCrary lives in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Compensation Offer
description: A charity foundation headed by a son of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said it would pay compensation to the relatives of three victims killed in the 1986 bombing of a disco in what was then West Berlin. The foundation declined to provide details but said the payment was a gesture of humanity that was not tied to any acceptance of responsibility for the bombing. In 2001, a German court found that the Libyan state bore a considerable share of responsibility for the blast, as Libyan agents helped plan it. The explosion killed two American servicemen and a Turkish woman and injured more than 200 people, many of them American soldiers. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CHILDREN'S KILLER SENTENCED TO DEATH Closing a criminal case that shocked Japan, a judge sentenced to death a man who killed eight children in an elementary school two years ago. The man, Mamoru Takuma, 39, who had previously received treatment for mental illness, pleaded guilty to killing seven girls and one boy and to injuring 13 other children and 2 teachers at a school near Osaka.

title: On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: Accounts
description: * Cable One, Phoenix, to E. B. Lane Marketing Communications, Phoenix, to handle its account, which had been handled by Hadley & Associates, Oakton, Va. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Cable One, which provides cable television and high-speed Internet service to 53 communities in 19 states, is part of the Washington Post Company.

title: Teenagers Make the Best Hors d'Oeuvres
description: Though vampires, werewolves and the creatures of various mad doctors continue to appear in horror movies, they've taken a back seat to the more modern, psychopathic human monsters initiated by Alfred Hitchcock's ''Psycho'' (1960) and institutionalized by Jonathan Demme's ''Silence of the Lambs'' (1991). But in 2001, Victor Salva's ''Jeepers Creepers'' brought in a highly respectable $37.5 million at the box office by serving up the first freshly imagined supernatural monster in quite some time.

title: Charlie Brown and His Crew, All Fired Up to Lose
description: If Kermit the Frog can still be a scintillating talk-show guest more than a decade after Jim Henson's death, then surely Charlie Brown and his ''Peanuts'' circle of friends can carry on now that their creator, Charles M. Schulz, is gone.

title: Sargsian's Bad Volley Leads Blake to Victory at U.S. Open
description: James Blake watched Sargis Sargsian flub a volley today during their fourth-set tie-breaker in the second round of the United States Open, and Blake could only smile. Blake had blown numerous opportunities when his 6-3 lead in the tie-breaker evaporated into a 6-6 tie. On the next point, Sargsian saw nothing but open court and tapped his shot into the net to hand Blake a 7-6 lead.

title: Junkyard Heaps Find a New Home
description: PEAKS and Chebeague Islands, just off the coast of Portland, Me., provide a new lease on life for broken-down cars that otherwise would be headed for the scrap heap. The reason? The islands are among 15 in Maine that have no state-maintained roads and thus no reqirement that vehicles driven there pass state inspections. And so the populace happily makes do with cars that might elsewhere be branded as death traps. Page 8.

title: Verizon Talks Are Halted
description: Verizon Communications Inc., the local telephone carrier, and unions representing 78,000 employees in the Northeast halted contract negotiations until Tuesday, a federal mediator, Peter Hurtgen, said yesterday in a statement. Verizon and the unions, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, have been seeking to avert a strike that could hamper service in 13 states from Virginia to Maine. The contracts expired Aug. 3.

title: White House Proposes Reviews For Studies on New Regulations
description: The White House budget office plans to require government agencies starting next year to employ panels of independent experts to review the quality of scientific analyses used in developing regulations.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Don't judge Dominic Restaurant/Social Club by the name. There is no baked manicotti on the menu. This is not surprising, because the chef and owner is John Villa, whose Portuguese-inspired Pico dazzled diners and critics, but alas, not enough of them. In a quick adjustment, Mr. Villa has converted Pico into a much more modest Italian restaurant, just one step up from a cafe. The lush fabrics and velvet booths have been replaced by little tables, the decoration is limited to a few old-fashioned ceramic plates on the exposed brick walls, and the menu has been whittled down and simplified.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Special Teams Rally Giants From a 17-Point Deficit
description: Just as the Giants were about to fall into a pit of mediocrity tonight, about to close their set of preseason games with the ugliest of four losses, they were rescued against the Baltimore Ravens in the most unlikely of ways. Their special teams turned the game around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERSON, PAULA. (NEE WINTER)
description: BERSON--Paula. (nee Winter). Author and illustrator, on August 25, 2003. Predeceased by her beloved husband, author-illustrator Harold Berson, survived by her loving nephews Andrew, Jed and John Feffer, sister-in-law, Edith Berson Feffer, & friend since 1946, Anita Feldman.

title: Adam Style: Antiquity And Beyond
description: The Paris designer Dominique Kieffer, whose chic linens are favorites with French interior designers, says her latest line was inspired by the hallmark colors (pale pinks and greens) of the 18th-century Scottish architect and designer Robert Adam. It seems that Adam style, which swept Britain in the 1760's, has never gone out of style.

title: Graffiti at Dean Rally Irks a Republican
description: As he watched Howard Dean's rally in Bryant Park on Tuesday night, Councilman James Oddo, a Staten Island Republican, grew increasingly angry about what was behind Dr. Dean: a backdrop purposefully covered with graffiti.

title: U. of Michigan Alters Admissions Use of Race
description: The University of Michigan unveiled an admissions policy yesterday that preserves affirmative action but applies it less strictly, without assigning any numerical advantage, or extra points, to minority applicants.

title: Sad to See Summer End? Travel Industry Is, Too
description: Long lines at airports, car-rental counters and hotel registration desks this Labor Day weekend are of little consolation to the weary travel industry, which is already looking past them to expectations of another difficult fall.

title: Jean-Selim Kanaan, 33, U.N. Aide in Iraq
description: Jean-Selim Kanaan, a United Nations staff member with both French and Egyptian citizenship, died in the bomb attack on the organization's Baghdad headquarters on Aug. 19, the United Nations announced on Tuesday. He was 33.

title: New Student Discipline Code Gets Mostly Positive Response
description: The public response was mostly positive last night to a new student discipline code for the city schools that takes effect this fall.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS IN DEAL WITH AMERICAN AIRLINES
description: British Airways will sell tickets in its own name to 12 trans-Atlantic destinations under an agreement with an alliance partner, the AMR Corporation's American Airlines. The cities, which include Cincinnati, Indianapolis, Nashville and New Orleans, are the first of more than 100 that will eventually be included in the so-called code-share accord. Tickets will go on sale Aug. 31 for travel beginning Sept. 17. The initial 12 destinations also include cities in Canada, Latin America and the Caribbean.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. In Talks On Big Payroll Job
description: I.B.M. is in exclusive talks to perform payroll and benefits work for Procter & Gamble after beating out Accenture Ltd. and Convergys. About 700 employees of Procter & Gamble, the nation's biggest household-goods maker, would transfer to I.B.M., a P.& G. spokesman, Damon Jones, said. He declined to disclose the value of the possible multiyear contract. Accenture and Convergys had been in talks for the work, Mr. Jones said. Computer services companies are seeking so-called business process outsourcing deals to do processing, billing and payroll work as companies slow spending on information-technology contracts. John Jones, an analyst at the SoundView Technology Group, estimated I.B.M.'s contract with Procter & Gamble to be worth about $500 million over at least six years. Convergys, which like Procter & Gamble is based in Cincinnati and handles billing for AT&T Wireless Services and Triton PCS Holdings, said it dropped out of competition for the contract. Representatives for Accenture, which handles customer and computer services for clients including AT&T, did not immediately return phone calls.

title: Why Do Polluters Get a Break?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Orders Use of Cable Under Sound
description: An underwater electrical line that became the object of intense political debate after the Aug. 14 blackout will be allowed to shuttle power between Long Island and Connecticut as early as Monday, after an order issued yesterday by Spencer Abraham, the federal energy secretary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDERS, LESLEY SPRING
description: SANDERS -- Lesley Spring. Our precious daughter has left us. Our hearts are broken. We have been weakened losing you. But strengthened by so many beautiful memories that will last forever. No day will go by without thoughts of you. We were blessed with the special joys and pride you brought to our lives. We will always love you and all you meant to us. Mom and Dad

title: ABBOTT TO ADD WORKERS AT PLANT IN ARIZONA
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it planned to add 90 employees and expand manufacturing at a plant in Arizona to make reclosable containers for its Ensure nutritional drink. Abbott's Ross Products unit will receive $3,000 to $6,000 for each new hire from Arizona's Department of Commerce to use for employee training, the company said. The site now has about 400 employees and 25 contract personnel. The Ross unit makes drinks like Ensure for adults and baby formulas under the brand names Similac, Isomil and PediaSure. Abbott is based in Abbott Park, Ill.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economy Contracts
description: Brazil's economy shrank 1.6 percent in the second quarter, meaning the country effectively has been in recession since the left-leaning government of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva took office in January. According to the national statistics institute, the 1.6 percent contraction in the second quarter came after a contraction of 1.4 percent in the first three months of the year. Trying to inspire confidence in the market, Mr. da Silva's economic team raised Brazil's benchmark interest rate to 26.5 percent earlier this year to stifle inflation. But the rising rates also stopped the already slowing economy. Last week, the central bank, eager to spur growth, made its third rate cut in as many months. The overnight rate is now 22 percent. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Children's Killer Sentenced To Death
description: Closing a criminal case that shocked Japan, a judge sentenced to death a man who killed eight children in an elementary school two years ago. The man, Mamoru Takuma, 39, who had previously received treatment for mental illness, pleaded guilty to killing seven girls and one boy and to injuring 13 other children and 2 teachers at a school near Osaka. James Brooke (NYT)

title: FIRSTENERGY UNIT GETS $450 MILLION CREDIT LINE
description: The FirstEnergy Corporation, whose power transmission lines failed shortly before the Aug. 14 blackout began, said yesterday that its Ohio Edison subsidiary had arranged a new $450 million secured credit line. It said that including that credit line, its liquidity, which was defined as cash on hand plus unused borrowing capacity, stood at $933 million on Tuesday, up from $274 million on June 30. The company also provided more detail on its second-quarter cash flow, which had been much less than in the same period of 2002, and said it hoped to raise $500 million to $750 million by selling stock in the near future, with the money to be used to reduce debt. Floyd Norris (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If there would be a church, a mosque, and a synagogue inside here, I think it would be ideal. It's hard to see so much hatred in such a holy place.''

title: White Has Plenty To Win Second Gold
description: At the start of the women's 200 meters tonight, Kelli White felt tired, empty. This was her eighth round of sprints at the world track and field championships. She rocked from side to side in Lane 6 and wondered if she had anything left.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Western Digital Shares Soar On Acquisition News
description: Shares of Western Digital, a disk drive maker, had their biggest gain in 13 months yesterday after the company said that buying the Read-Rite Corporation would increase profitability. The shares rose $1.98, or 21 percent, to $11.48 after rising as high as $11.65. The shares have gained 80 percent this year. Western Digital bought most of the assets of Read-Rite, a maker of disk-drive parts in bankruptcy, last month for $95 million in cash, plus assumed debt. The company, led by Matthew E. Massengill, its chairman and chief executive, said late Wednesday that the acquisition would help widen gross margin, the share of sales left after paying production costs, more than it had estimated. The company said late Tuesday that first-quarter sales would rise at least 18 percent, as demand for hard drives was meeting the high end of the company's estimates in all markets.
