description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Settlement In Wellstone Crash
description: Ten months after Senator Paul Wellstone died in a plane crash in Eleveth, his family and those of the five other passengers who were killed agreed to a $25 million settlement with the company that operated the flight, Aviation Charters Inc. of Eden Prairie, and affiliated companies. Lawyers for the families of the victims said that the crash was the result of pilot error. The National Transportation Safety Board has not officially announced the cause of the crash. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Pact to Help Poor Nations Obtain Drugs Is Delayed
description: The World Trade Organization came close tonight to approving an agreement to help poor nations buy lifesaving generic medicines through new exemptions from trade rules, only to postpone the final decision.

title: Merck Wins Ruling on Osteoporosis Drug
description: Merck said yesterday that a federal judge had upheld a patent for its osteoporosis drug Fosamax, blocking a proposed generic version by Teva Pharmaceutical Industries until 2018.

title: A Child of Nature Shows His Pop-Culture Roots
description: Ellsworth Kelly was the Chet Baker of the new, cool painting of the late 1950's and early 60's. Of all the members of the post-Abstract Expressionist generation that included Agnes Martin, Jack Youngerman, James Rosenquist, Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns, no one made paintings so sweet and pure and easy to like. His work didn't profoundly alter the course of art history, but its suavely prettified Minimalism has been a reliable source of gratification for more than 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALKENBURG, JINX
description: FALKENBURG--Jinx. Darling Jinx--You will always be in our hearts and minds. We celebrate your life, your strength, your charm and your beauty. We will miss you always. We love you forever. Your West Coast Family-Claudia, Andrew, Josh, Cody, Bob, Lou, Bobby, Talitha and Mimi

title: Step Right Up, See the Man Eat Light Bulbs. (No Off Broadway Marquee Is Safe.)
description: If you've been waiting to see a man put out a lighted cigar on his tongue, chew up and swallow a light bulb and hammer a nail up his nose and into his skull, then congratulations, your patience has been rewarded.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aozora Debt Upgraded
description: The credit of Aozora Bank, a former nationalized lender now held by Softbank and other companies, was raised by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The upgrade came as Softbank awaited approval to sell its 49 percent stake in the bank to Cerberus Partners, a United States investment fund that already owns 12 percent of Aozora. The S.&P. cited the bank's efforts to write off nonperforming loans and the benefits of a Softbank share sale. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Slain Cleric Offered Several Faces
description: Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, the influential Iraqi Shiite leader killed in Najaf today, tried to negotiate different worlds.

title: Blair's Top Image Strategist Resigns
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 — Alastair Campbell, the influential and combative director of communications and strategy for Prime Minister Tony Blair, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Bishops' Chief Stands Firm on Celibacy Rule
description: The president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops said in an interview yesterday that the American bishops were unlikely to be receptive to a recent request from priests in Milwaukee to discuss opening the priesthood to married men.

title: Winners and Performers
description: The Video Music Awards, held Thursday at Radio City Music Hall, brought together the usual culture clashes that MTV loves to orchestrate.

description: A car bomb exploded outside a Shiite shrine in Najaf on Friday, killing a moderate cleric.

description: SCIAKY--Isaac. On August 29th, 2003. Beloved father of Daniela Sciaky and Reed Corderman. Loving grandfather of David and Sara Corderman. Partner of Arlene Dubrow. Service Sunday, August 31st, 2003 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: White Supremacist Inquiry
description: The leader of a white supremacist group based in the state is being investigated by a federal grand jury for ordering or encouraging a 1999 shooting spree carried out by a follower, Benjamin Smith, that left three people dead, including Mr. Smith. The leader, Matthew Hale, has been charged with soliciting the murder of a federal judge, and is accused of asking his father to lie during a grand jury investigation. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, MELVIN
description: STEVENS--Melvin. Beloved husband of Debby for 52 years, died August 28 of lung cancer. He was an active outdoorsman sharing his love for fishing, sailing, skiing and tennis, as well as fine food, jazz and theater with family and friends. He began his career with Macy's as a CPA and rose to controller. Debby and he also own two businesses. Mel is survived by Debby; their sons, David, Peter and Seth and their wives; and grandchildren, Emma, Samuel, Luke, Sarah and Benjamin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, FLORENCE
description: RUBIN--Florence. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Florence Rubin, beloved mother of David Rubin. We extend our deepest condolences to David and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: G.I. DIES IN FALL A Special Forces soldier died during operations against Taliban forces in southeastern Afghanistan. The soldier, who was not identified, died in a fall in Dai Chopan, in Zabul Province. American planes have bombed the area for several days and American ground troops have joined up to 1,000 Afghan government troops to hunt for Taliban members. Afghan officials have reported at least 9 government and 14 Taliban casualties, but the G.I.'s death was the first among American soldiers.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)

description: Lottery Numbers

description: ROTO-ROOTER INC., Cincinnati, a provider of plumbing and drain-cleaning services, said it would acquire franchises in California, Oregon, Utah, Arizona and Texas to increase income. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose as traders seemed to want to sell dollars ahead of the long holiday weekend. In New York, the euro settled at 1.0996, up from 1.0880.

title: Mary Eccles, 91, a Collector Of Johnson-Boswell Material
description: Mary Viscountess Eccles, a bibliophile who built up what is widely considered the world's finest collection of rare books and manuscripts relating to Samuel Johnson and his biographer and friend, James Boswell, died on Aug. 26 at her home, Four Oakes Farm, in Somerset County, N.J. She was 91.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about legal troubles facing the head of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, Clarence Norman Jr., referred incorrectly to the amount of work done for the party by the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, who is investigating him. Mr. Hynes and party officials both say his work was limited to one task; he was not a longtime lawyer for the party.

title: Federal Judge Blocks Work On Casino in the Hamptons
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that the Shinnecock Indian Nation could not start building a proposed casino in Hampton Bays, on Long Island, for at least a year and a half.

title: Punishment to Fit the Crime
description: A respected plague expert from Texas Tech University is scheduled to go on trial this fall on charges of violating federal security statutes. The underlying question is whether federal officials are simply being diligent in enforcing rules for handling infectious agents or are instead inflating minor violations into a major federal case.

title: RADIOSHACK PLANS TO CUT BACK ON MANUFACTURING
description: The RadioShack Corporation said it would manufacture fewer of its own products to direct its attention toward its consumer electronics retail stores. It will eliminate 373 jobs at plants in Texas and North Carolina. After two years of streamlining and increased subcontracting, the company said, its profit in the third quarter of 2003 may rise to 33 cents a share, more than earlier forecasts.

title: Inching Ahead With North Korea
description: It's hard to call the latest round of nuclear talks with North Korea successful when they were punctuated by Pyongyang's threats to test a nuclear weapon. Yet the three-day session in Beijing that ended yesterday actually registered more gains than losses. Though there was no progress on the main issues of substance, the ground has been prepared for further diplomacy, or, if necessary, international action to contain the North Korean nuclear threat.

title: MOTOROLA SELLS ITS STAKE IN SYMBIAN FOR $88 MILLION
description: Motorola Inc., which helped found Symbian Ltd. five years ago to develop software for mobile phones, is selling its stake in the venture to its partners Nokia and Psion to focus on other cellphone programs. Nokia and Psion will buy the 19 percent stake for $88 million, making them the two largest shareholders in Symbian. The transactions value Symbian, which is based in London, at $474 million, the companies said. It was the first day Motorola could dispose of its shares under terms of the venture. Symbian and Microsoft are competing to provide software for phones that incorporate technology similar to personal computers. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., said it would continue to sell Symbian-based phones and would focus on software that runs on the Java operating system. Nokia will hold 32.2 percent of Symbian and Psion will raise its portion to 31.1 percent, the companies said.

title: Losing Weight Online
description: To the Editor:

title: City Opera Faces Possible Strike
description: The members of the theatrical wardrobe workers' union, Local 764, voted on Wednesday night to authorize a strike against the New York City Opera two weeks before the scheduled beginning of its fall season.

title: One Vehicle on the Road, Two Others in the Garage
description: To some drivers stuck in traffic this holiday weekend, it may look as if every car in America is on the road in front of them.

title: A Second Act for Dos Passos And His Panoramic Writings
description: Anyone who tried to find some of John Dos Passos' classic novels and travel narratives in recent years would have had to look long and hard. Many of his books had been out of print for more than six decades, and even now his work is rarely taught in American literature courses.

title: Greenspan Argues Against Strict Rules for Fed
description: Fending off critics who say the nation's monetary policy has become too personalized and idiosyncratic, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, stepped up his insistence today that the Fed should continue to have broad discretion and not be hemmed in by formal rules or even by long-established traditions.

title: William Scherle -- Congressman, 80
description: William Scherle, who represented southwest Iowa for four terms in Congress, died on Wednesday in Council Bluffs. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAY, ROBERT
description: GRAY--Robert. August 29, 2003. Beloved husband of Nicki Gray. Loving father of Lee, Cathy and Jodi. Cherished grandfather of Andrea, Corey, Dean and Kimberlee. A kind and generous man who thought of the needs of others and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Graveside service Sunday, August 31, 11 AM at Union Field Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquest Into Diana's Death
description: Six years after the deaths in a Paris car-crash of Diana, Princess of Wales, and her companion, Emad Mohammed al-Fayed, British authorities said for the first time that a coroner's inquest would be held, but they declined to say when. A French inquiry in 1999 found that the couple's French chauffeur, Henri Paul, who also died, was driving too fast. But Mr. Fayed's father, Mohammed al-Fayed, the owner of Harrods department store in London, claims that British secret services murdered the couple. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Pact on Drugs Stalls Again In Trade Talks
description: The World Trade Organization failed again tonight in its attempt to approve an agreement to allow poor nations to import inexpensive medicines by relaxing patent and trade laws.

title: Op-Art
The Port Authority Transcripts
description: On Thursday, the Port Authority at last released hundreds of pages of transcripts of telephone conversations and radio transmissions recorded on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001. It takes only a few pages of reading to rekindle the intensity of those hours just after the first plane struck the north tower of the World Trade Center. In a real sense, these transcripts and the recordings on which they are based are forensic documents. They help piece together a clearer picture of how Port Authority employees responded to the almost impossible crisis of that morning. The mistakes that were made -- like advising one group of people not to evacuate the World Trade Center -- were more than counterbalanced by genuinely heroic efforts to free others trapped in burning offices or disabled elevators.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAPLAN, SIDNEY S.
description: KAPLAN--Sidney S. It is one year that you left this earth. You remain in my heart forever. The pain lingers on, the memories of the wonderful life we shared are a source of great comfort. You are missed by all who loved you. You are unforgettable. Your wife, children and grandchildren.

title: GRUPO TMM PLANNING TO REPURCHASE TEXAS RAILROAD LINE
description: Grupo TMM, which dropped plans this week to sell control of Mexico's biggest railroad to Kansas City Southern, said it would also take back a Texas rail line from Kansas City Southern. TMM's rail unit exercised an option to repurchase Mexrail, a 521-mile railway linking Laredo, Houston and Beaumont, and will return $32.7 million to Kansas City Southern on Sept. 4, TMM said. Kansas City Southern agreed to the option when it acquired 51 percent of Mexrail in May. Kansas City Southern's purchase of Mexrail was part of a plan to extend its network into Mexico. A crucial element of the plan was the $412 million purchase of TMM's 43 percent stake in TFM. Kansas City Southern owns 37 percent of TFM, and the Mexican government owns 20 percent. TMM, Mexico's largest transport company, on Monday canceled the TFM transaction. A spokesman for Kansas City Southern said it would press its case that the TFM accord was binding.

title: A Late Riser Is a Rising Star
description: Todd Pletcher's 2-year-old filly Ashado, a rising star, does not like to work out in the morning.

title: A Top Aide to Blair Resigns as a Dispute Over Iraq Rages
description: Alastair Campbell, the influential and combative director of communications and strategy for Prime Minister Tony Blair, announced his resignation today as controversy raged over his role in portraying the nature of Iraq's threat to the West.

title: Computer Virus Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; For Davenport, A Clearer Path To the Finals
description: WHEN Serena Williams had knee surgery a few weeks ago, only one player sent her flowers -- Lindsay Davenport.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about British hearings into events leading up to the war against Iraq misstated the governmental role of a key figure in the case. Until his resignation yesterday, Alastair Campbell was Prime Minister Tony Blair's director of communications and strategy, not security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHILD, MARION
description: SCHILD--Marion, August 28, 2003 at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale. She is remembered with love by her nieces and their husbands, her grand nieces and nephews, her surviving cousins and friends all over the world.

title: China at Korea Talks: Taking Diplomacy Upstage
description: Even though the six nations that gathered for talks here this week have yet to agree on how to stop North Korea's nuclear program, at least one breakthrough was evident: the emergence of China as a more assertive diplomatic power.

title: Feast on the Yankees' Pitching Continues
description: The Yankees are playing another contending team and following their discouraging pattern. When they play bad teams, the Yankees look flawless. But good teams expose their problems, and their fiercest rival did so tonight.

title: Cleared in Captain's Shooting, Man Still Faces Gun Charge
description: A man questioned in the Wednesday shooting of a police captain was cleared as a suspect yesterday, only to be charged with illegally possessing a firearm at the time of his arrest.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inuit Win Land Rights
description: Five thousand Inuit in northern Labrador won a land settlement giving them broad governing rights over an area the size of New Jersey that is rich in nickel. The Inuit will get more than $200 million to implement the accord, which has been debated for 25 years. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: The Blackout No One Noticed
description: On July 22, my birthday, I got up to go to the bathroom, took 10 steps, heard a rumble, turned around and watched a 2,000-pound steel beam fall across my bed. Then the roof peeled off. Then the wall collapsed, showering the room with bricks, cinder blocks and mortar. My boxer shorts, flapping wildly from a headboard knob, flew to a lamppost two blocks away, where they hung for two days, like a flag of defeat, until I reclaimed them.

title: An Iraqi Shiite Who Moved Between Religion, Revolt and Politics
description: Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, the influential Iraqi Shiite leader assassinated today in Najaf, tried to negotiate different worlds.

title: Officers' Sept. 11 Accounts: Catastrophe in the Details
description: ''The first thing that hit my senses was the quietness of it all,'' remembered Inspector Timothy I. Norris of the Port Authority Police Department. Seconds after the south tower of the World Trade Center collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001, he was in the basement, near the usually bustling PATH Square. ''It was surreal. Then as we panned our flashlights about, we observed the devastation that had taken place.

title: Car Bomb in Iraq Kills 95 at Shiite Mosque
description: A powerful car bomb exploded here outside the holiest Shiite shrine today, killing as many as 95 people, according to hospital sources. One of the dead was the most prominent Shiite cleric cooperating with United States forces in Iraq.

title: Dayne's Future Decided, But Fassel's Not Telling Yet
description: Ron Dayne's immediate future with the Giants has been decided. He just does not know what it is yet.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Russian Out On Bail
description: Vladimir A. Gusinsky, a fugitive Russian tycoon and critic of the Kremlin, was released on $108,000 bail from a Greek prison. But a local court barred him from leaving Greece pending a ruling on extradition to Russia, which he fled in 2000 in the face of fraud and money-laundering charges. Mr. Gusinsky was arrested when he arrived last week from Tel Aviv. He insists the charges against him are a Kremlin plot to silence him. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about John Shearman, an art expert who advised the Vatican on the restoration of the Sistine Chapel, misstated his wife's surname. She is Kathryn Brush, not Bush.

title: Jets Are Still Sorting Through Some Issues
description: Ted Cottrell, the Jets' defensive coordinator, was sure he could detect signs of progress even though the starters were consigned to the sideline Thursday night in the final preseason game against the Philadelphia Eagles. After all, he reasoned, if the backups who played the entire game were making the correct calls and adjustments, it had to bode well for the starters.

title: 2 Bids to Expand Pool Of Potential U.S. Leaders
description: Comparisons between the actor who would be California governor and the actor who was California governor usually end with the same codicil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, PEARL C.
description: MILLER--Pearl C. Beloved daughter of the late Charles Cohn and Bella Cohen Cohn, adored sister of Seymour Cohn and the late Mildred Cohn, Maurice Cohn, Irene Colvin and Sylvan Lawrence, devoted and loyal wife of the late Henry Miller, and cherished aunt and great-aunt to each and every member of the Cohen and Cembalest families. Born on October 20, 1906 in New York City, the youngest daughter in a large and accomplished family, Pearl devoted herself to her studies, eventually becoming a teacher in the New York City Public School System. As a young girl, Pearl began her life-long involvement with Tranquillity Camp. As the ideal embodiment of the Cohen family credo ''Noblesse Oblige,'' Pearl soon became the indispensable right-hand of her uncle, the late Elias A. Cohen, one of the truly great men of his time, who founded Tranquillity Camp in 1919. After his sudden passing in July of 1952, Pearl shouldered the tremendous responsiblity of keeping the Camp going. For well over 50 years, Pearl selflessly and tirelessly devoted every minute of every day to her family, and to each of the children whose character was so quietly and subtlely molded by her example. Despite her towering intellect and photographic memory, Pearl, like so many members of the Cohen family before her, never talked down to anyone. To us she was a unique individual, a giant. When flattered by anyone, she would characteristically brush it off with a small wave of her hand, saying ''It's nothing. I just do what I do.'' She made it all seem so simple. Services will be held on Sunday, August 31, 2003, 11AM at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Tranquillity Camp, Inc., 170 Tranquillity Rd., Earlton, NY 12058, would be appreciated.

title: PEOPLESOFT BUYS REMAINING SHARES OF J. D. EDWARDS
description: A little more than a month after taking control of J. D. Edwards, PeopleSoft said yesterday that it had bought all remaining shares not tendered in its exchange offer. PeopleSoft, based in Pleasanton, Calif., initially bought 105 million shares of J. D. Edwards, a smaller rival, on July 17. The company paid $7.05 in cash plus 0.43 of a share of PeopleSoft common stock for each remaining Edwards share. PeopleSoft, a maker of software for automating business processes, is fighting a hostile takeover by Oracle, which announced its intent just days after PeopleSoft announced the Edwards acquisition. Oracle's proposed takeover is being held up pending a Justice Department investigation into the antitrust implications of such a merger. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Judges and Sentencing
description: To the Editor:

title: BP Expands Its Interest In Russian Oil
description: The BP Group said today that it would buy a stake in the Russian oil company Slavneft for $1.35 billion, and would fold the operations into its new joint venture with the Tyumen Oil Company.

title: Manslaughter Count Filed Against a Congressman
description: Representative Bill Janklow, who served four terms as governor of South Dakota before winning election to Congress last year, was charged in his home state today with second-degree manslaughter because of a traffic fatality there two weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BISCONTI, PETER V., M.D.
description: BISCONTI--Peter V., M.D. Of Eastchester, NY on August 28, 2003. Husband of the late Helen Mary Rohan. Father of Peter V. Jr., Helen A. Tobin, Margaret R. Monroe, Robert F. and Virginia G. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, Tuesday 2-4PM and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, Wednesday 10AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bid For Telecom Stake
description: A consortium led by the American International Group and including Newbridge Capital appears to have won a lengthy struggle for control of Hanaro Telecom, Korea's second-largest broadband provider. Hanaro's board, under government pressure, voted to accept $500 million for 39 percent of Hanaro's shares at 4 percent below market value. The LG Group, now Hanaro's largest shareholder, with 16 percent of the shares, said, however, that it would fight the deal at a shareholders' meeting in October. SK Telecom, Hanaro's third-largest shareholder, agreed to cover Hanaro's immediate debts by investing 120 billion won ($101.7 million) in six-month bonds. Hanaro, which ranks behind Korea Telecom among broadband providers, has been losing money for four years. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Blair Aide Resigns Over Role

title: Fear and Valor: The 9/11 Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BILLY, WILLIAM
description: BILLY--William. Aug. 30, 1993 Dear Bill, who could have known that forever was a day. I miss you. Bill

title: CHIQUITA TO SELL ITS STAKE IN CITRUS JOINT VENTURE
description: Chiquita Brands International, the banana producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its stake in a citrus joint venture to a partner for cash and the assumption of debt. The company did not announce specific terms of the deal. The venture, Packers of Indian River, based in Fort Pierce, Fla., grows and packs citrus products. Chiquita has been selling less profitable businesses and trying to reduce costs. It said in April that it would sell its operations in Panama.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Heat Death Toll Put At 11,000
description: The Ministry of Health recorded 11,435 more deaths than usual during an extensive heat wave in the first two weeks of August. A government commission is investigating flaws in the health system that left many elderly people unattended in early August, when temperatures in some areas rose above 104 degrees. Many bodies remain unclaimed and have been buried in paupers' graves as a temporary measure. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Ending the Battle of the Badges
description: Sometime this fall, the New York City fire and police commissioners will agree to a plan that sets out rules for coordinating their departments' responses to emergencies. But establishing protocols, while an important step, will not be sufficient to end the harmful rivalry between the Police and Fire Departments and the wasteful duplication of resources it encourages.

title: An American Idol? Not Yet, But It's Here for the Audition
description: SO, thousands of people line up for an opportunity to warble pop songs in front of abusive judges and heartless television viewers, for a slim chance of gaining fame, fortune and a recording contract. Any car that aspires to become an American idol should have it so easy.

title: G.M. Building Sells for $1.4 Billion, a Record
description: Harry Macklowe, the developer whose career has died a thousand deaths, came alive again Thursday night when he signed a contract to buy the 50-story General Motors Building for a record-setting $1.4 billion, the most ever paid for a skyscraper in the United States.

title: Joyously Reviving Difficult Music
description: Almost nobody plays the music of Eric Dolphy anymore. But the ambitious pianist Eric Reed is giving it a try through tomorrow night at Iridium with a group called the Eric Dolphy Project, and the results are better than anyone could have predicted: joyous, profound, well organized. At the late show on Thursday, the audience applauded longer and more spontaneously after each piece than at any jazz performance I've been to in months.

title: July Spending By Consumers Shows a Rise
description: Consumer spending rose in July at the fastest pace in four months and Chicago-area manufacturing expanded by the most in more than a year, adding to evidence the economy strengthened at the start of the third quarter.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Endorsement: Suffolk County
description: This fall marks a pivotal moment for Suffolk County, currently ridden by scandals over land purchases and health insurance and saddled with a budget gap in excess of $100 million. The county executive elected to succeed the three-term incumbent, Robert Gaffney, will have to deal with all those problems, and restore confidence in the much-abused program to preserve the county's fast-disappearing open spaces while pushing ahead with smart development to create jobs and affordable housing. Then there is the rising problem of ethnic tension, with Hispanic migrant workers the targets of beatings and arson.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: No Extradition For Argentines
description: The government has decided not to seek extradition of 39 former Argentine military officers and a civilian charged here with genocide, torture and terrorism during Argentina's military dictatorship. An Argentine judge ordered the officers' arrest in July at the request of a Spanish judge, Baltasar Garzn. The decision was based on the expectation that the Argentine Supreme Court would approve the repeal of amnesty laws that had protected former officers from prosecution. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Success Is in the Grapes; From a Scruffy Past, a Winemaking Capital Emerges
description: On the far end of Long Island's North Fork, a new winemaking region has flowered in recent years, and this little dot of a village, once among the scruffiest and saddest on all of Long Island Sound, has emerged as its unlikely capital.

title: DELTA TO RECALL 250 PILOTS LAID OFF DURING WAR
description: Delta Air Lines, the third-largest commercial airline in the United States, said it would recall 250 pilots who were laid off during the Iraq war and increase its capacity by 12 percent by the end of the year. The first of the recalled pilots will return to work Oct. 1, according to Peggy Estes, a spokeswoman for Delta, based in Atlanta. Global air traffic fell by almost 20 percent in April, after the war and the outbreak of SARS discouraged people from flying.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Caution Over Euro
description: Sweden may delay entry into Europe's monetary union beyond 2006, even if voters support the euro in the Sept. 14 referendum, should the union's accord on its member nations' budget policy collapse, Prime Minister Goran Persson said. ''If it turned out that, from when we vote 'yes' now until 2006 when we're planning to join, something happens, we'll let the government and Parliament examine it,'' Mr. Persson said in an interview with Swedish state radio's P1 channel. ''If the stability pact works, we will of course take our place.'' Swedish euro opponents are 14 percentage points ahead of supporters, according to a poll commissioned by the TT news service, and 16 percent are undecided.

title: Novartis Pulls Ad After F.D.A. Complains
description: Novartis, the European drug maker, is pulling a television advertisement for Lamisil, its toenail fungus treatment, after the Food and Drug Administration contended that the ad overstated the medicine's effectiveness.

title: Jack Eisner, 77, Holocaust Chronicler, Dies
description: Jack P. Eisner, who used the millions he made in the import-export business to tell the story of how he survived the Holocaust in a book, play, movie and many public appearances, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: G.I. Dies In Fall
description: A Special Forces soldier died during operations against Taliban forces in southeastern Afghanistan. The soldier, who was not identified, died in a fall in Dai Chopan, in Zabul Province. American planes have bombed the area for several days and American ground troops have joined up to 1,000 Afghan government troops to hunt for Taliban members. Afghan officials have reported at least 9 government and 14 Taliban casualties, but the G.I.'s death was the first among American soldiers. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: INTEL TO OPEN A RESEARCH OPERATION IN SOUTH KOREA
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's biggest computer chip maker, said it would open a research center in South Korea this year to develop semiconductors for mobile telephones and consumer electronics. Chuck Mulloy, a spokesman for Intel, declined to give a specific location or say how many people would be employed at the center. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., already has sales and marketing offices in South Korea and is investing aggressively in Asia; it said earlier this week that it would open new plants in China and Malaysia.

description: An article yesterday about British hearings into events leading up to the war against Iraq misstated the governmental role of a key figure in the case. Until his resignation yesterday, Alastair Campbell was Prime Minister Tony Blair's director of communications and strategy, not security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DORSEY, JANIE (NEW)
description: DORSEY--Janie (New), 79, of Bay Harbor, Florida, passed away Sunday, August 24, 2003. She is the widow of the late Big Band Leader Tommy Dorsey who passed away in 1956. Graveside service will be held today at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York where she will be interred next to her husband.

title: German Coalition Team Hints It Will Seek Re-election in 2006
description: With Germany's economy sprouting the first tender shoots of recovery, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder and his coalition partner, Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, signaled this week that they planned to run again as a team in 2006.

title: Arrest of Judge May Reopen Divorce Cases
description: The arrest of Gerald P. Garson, the Brooklyn matrimonial judge accused of taking bribes to show favoritism in divorce cases, has opened the door for a potential overhaul of the state's system of selecting judges, a process that could take years.

title: Five Are Chosen to Join Board of a Reorganized WorldCom
description: A former United States deputy attorney general, a retired chairman of a major accounting firm and a large investor are among the five people WorldCom identified yesterday as future members of its board.

title: Houston Punishes Former Principal in Undercount of Dropouts
description: The Houston Independent School District will dock the salary of the former principal and a computer technician at Sharpstown High School, where false claims of no dropouts led to a state audit that found that nearly all the Houston schools examined were vastly undercounting dropouts.

title: In Gamble, New York Schools Pay to Get Parents Involved
description: For the three years Francine O. Honegan was a leader of the Parent Teacher Association at Middle School 144, in the Bronx, the group tried everything to get more than the same two dozen parents to attend meetings.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle yesterday provided an erroneous clue for 59 Down, seeking the answer ''BON.'' The clue ''__ chance!'' was incorrect because that expression, in French, is spelled ''Bonne chance!''

title: Wells to Start Monday, But He's Still Angry
description: David Wells will start for the Yankees on Monday after all, and tonight he finally listened to the pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre and threw in the bullpen between starts. But Wells is still furious over what he perceives as slights from Manager Joe Torre and Stottlemyre.

title: Angry Drivers Fill It Up, Up, Up; Get Used to It, Analysts Say; Surging Fuel Prices May Persist
description: Seated in the cab of his 18-wheeler, a Peterbilt 379, W. C. Rich -- a man who crisscrosses the country hauling furniture -- pulls out a folder full of diesel fuel receipts at a rest stop here.

description: To the Editor:

title: Death and Hesitation
description: The car bomb that killed one of Iraq's most important spiritual leaders today was apparently met by a political vacuum in the nation's capital, where the Iraqi and American officials charting the country's future seemed unsure who should respond and how.

title: Arrest Made In Attacks On Computers
description: A Minnesota teenager who the authorities said created a virulent version of the Blaster computer worm was arrested yesterday morning by federal investigators who were tracking the origin of the worm that wreaked havoc on users of Microsoft Windows.

title: Million Youth Event Returns, Not to Harlem, but to Brooklyn
description: Organizers of the Million Youth March announced yesterday that the rally would return this year for the first time since 2000, taking place in Brooklyn instead of Harlem and stressing peaceful activities like voter registration.

title: QUALITY DISTRIBUTION PLANS INITIAL OFFERING TO PAY DEBT
description: Quality Distribution Inc., which transports chemicals by tanker trucks in the United States, plans to raise as much as $132.3 million in an initial public offering to pay debt. The company, which owns more than 7,700 bulk tank trailers and 157 terminals, has appointed Credit Suisse First Boston, Bear Stearns and Deutsche Bank to underwrite the share sale, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Quality Distribution did not say how many shares it plans to sell or at what price. It plans to use the proceeds to help repay loans of about $368.9 million, according to the filing.

title: A Former Child Soldier Fights Her Memories
description: CHINA KEITETSI'S entire life has been a battle.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Gen. Wesley K. Clark's debate over whether to seek the Democratic nomination for president overstated the amount pledged through DraftWesleyClark.com to support him. It was $1.007 million, not $1.7 million. The article also misstated the Web address for another group that supports him.It is www.draftclark2004.com, not www.draftclark.com.

title: Money Flowing Past Loopholes In Recall Race
description: Just three years after Californians voted to impose controls on campaign financing, the unexpected recall election is turning into a spending frenzy without limits.

title: Canadian Economy Posts Decline in Quarter
description: After several years as the star performer in the industrial world, the Canadian economy went into reverse in the second quarter, weighed down by a sharp appreciation of the Canadian dollar, as well as by outbreaks of SARS in Toronto and mad cow disease in Alberta.

title: No to Tennis Divas, Yes to Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT RISES. Last-minute buying by commodity funds pushed wheat prices higher. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for December delivery was 8.75 cents higher at $3.81 a bushel.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Family Fare column in Weekend yesterday about the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum's 11th Annual Tugboat Festival tomorrow misstated the site of the event at one point. As noted at the end of the report, it is Pier 86 at West 46th Street and 12th Avenue, not the 86th Street Pier.

title: Running Back Sees Both Sides of Colorado Rivalry
description: This is not how fans of the University of Colorado imagined it three years ago, when Marcus Houston, a Denver native and one of the most recruited high school running backs in the nation, announced that he would stay in state and play for their team. Then again, it is not how fans of Colorado State imagined it either.

title: As Crime Rises, Washington's Chief Comes Under Fire
description: A spate of gang shootings. Auto thefts up in every police district. A breakdown in the city's 911 system. A serial arsonist at large.

title: Heavens Above, Parking Lot Below
description: This week Mars was closer to Earth than it had been for 60,000 years. But if you ventured out at night to look for ice caps and canals, chances are you saw only a slightly brighter and more pinkish smudge than usual. That's because 99 percent of Americans (and Europeans) live in places tainted by light pollution, according to NASA. Two-thirds of American homes no longer have a view of silky strands of the Milky Way -- we've ''lost'' 2,000 stars.

title: Public College Tuition Increases Prompt Concern, Anguish and Legislation
description: From New York to California, the nation's public colleges and universities have posted eye-popping tuition increases for this fall. Tuition will jump 39 percent at the University of Arizona, 30 percent at the University of California, 28 percent at the State University of New York and 25 percent at the City University of New York.

title: KOREA ARMS TALKS CLOSE WITH PLANS FOR A NEW ROUND
description: The United States, North Korea and four other nations ended three days of sometimes fiery negotiations here on Friday and decided to keep talking, as Bush administration officials concluded that the diplomatic track still offered the best hope of resolving the Korean nuclear crisis.

title: Ashcroft to Defend Ban on Some Abortion Protests, Angering His Longtime Allies
description: The Justice Department plans to go to court to defend a federal law that bans protesters from blocking access to abortion clinics, a move that is angering some opponents of abortion who have been strong supporters of Attorney General John Ashcroft.

title: Housing for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Prime Minister Takes On Broadcasting Service
description: The government of Prime Minister John Howard is in a battle with the publicly financed Australian Broadcasting Corporation, accusing it of ''biased, and in particular anti-American'' coverage of the war in Iraq.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Economy Shrinks
description: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted economic output was 3.7 percent lower in the second quarter than in the first, mainly because of the SARS outbreak last spring, which hurt tourism and related industries, like retailing. But output was just 0.5 percent below levels a year earlier. HSBC, the city's biggest bank, raised its estimate for total growth this year to 1.5 percent from 0.5 percent, and for next year to 4.2 percent from 1.3 percent, citing the disappearance of SARS in June and Beijing's decision to relax restrictions on travel by its citizens to Hong Kong. Mainland tourists tend to come for the shopping, and some are buying property. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: BERKSHIRE DISCLOSES PURCHASES OF NEXTEL DEBT
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company run by Warren E. Buffett, bought debt issued by Nextel Communications with a face value of more than $500 million in the nine months ended June 30, according to state regulatory filings. Nextel, the mobile telephone operator, rejected advice from bankers to file for bankruptcy court protection last year, and its fortunes have since rebounded, with rising subscriber rolls and falling debt. Four of Berkshire Hathaway's insurance units spent $468 million to acquire Nextel bonds and preferred shares with a face value of $506 million, according to documents filed with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.

title: At UConn, New Stadium, New Doubts
description: While a stadium was being constructed, a football conference was being destroyed. As workmen hurried to put together the final pieces of Rentschler Field, a project that was supposed to create not just a shiny new place for the University of Connecticut to play football but a foundation for the Huskies to compete at the highest levels of the sport, some university presidents were tearing apart Connecticut's future conference, the Big East.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telephone Sales
description: The German mobile phone company Siemens expects unit sales to rise as much as 20 percent this year as customer demand rebounds in response to the introduction of 30 handset models since last October. The company, based in Munich, expects to sell as many as 39 million units in the fiscal year ending in September, after already topping the 33 million units it sold in all of last year, a spokesman, Axel Schafmeister, said.

title: Woman Killed and Four Others Hurt in Car Crash in Queens
description: A 21-year-old male driver fleeing a police car in Queens on Thursday night slammed into another car, killing its driver and injuring her two children and two other relatives, the police said yesterday.

title: Steve Nash Takes the Time, To the Benefit of Canada
description: At tip-off Thursday afternoon, barely two dozen fans sat sprinkled throughout Roberto Clemente Stadium to watch Canada and Venezuela play a meaningless second-round game in the Americas Olympic qualifying tournament.

title: Editorial Observer; What Gidget Knew:Women and Surfing Are an Endless Combination
description: Every modern generation at some point finds itself captivated by a film that illustrates the thrill of surfing. Sandra Dee surfed ''Gidget'' into the forefront of American culture in 1959. Seven years later the director Bruce Brown chronicled surfing legends around the globe in ''Endless Summer.'' Last year ''Blue Crush'' harvested a fresh following eager to hang 10. The current surf documentary, ''Step Into Liquid,'' makes the sport even more hypnotizing.

title: YES Sues Over a Move by Time Warner
description: The YES Network asked the State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to stop Time Warner Cable from charging its customers in New York $1 extra to watch its cable channel, which carries Yankees and Nets games. YES said Time Warner Cable had violated an agreement to treat it equally with MSG Network and Fox Sports New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAKOVICH, MICHAEL STEVEN
description: JAKOVICH--Michael Steven, 43, of Boca Raton. Loving husband of Elena; father to Nathan, Stefen and Alex; brother to Robert; son to Elaine Brooks, and mourned by former wife, Jody, and all those students whose lives he touched and changed forever. He trusted and believed in everyone. Principal, teacher, humanitarian and idealist, Michael's wonderful sense of humor, his poems and love will never be forgotten. ''His heart was too big for this world.'' Graveside service 10:30 AM, Sunday, August 31, at the Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about Howard Dean's cross-country campaign trip misattributed a quotation about the campaign's resemblance to a ''movement'' with ''protest-size crowds'' and not ''politics-size crowds.'' It was from Garance Franke-Ruta, a reporter for the American Prospect, not Natasha C., who interviewed Ms. Franke-Ruta and posted the comments on her Web log, which is chronicling the campaign.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Defense Secretary Quits
description: The secretary of defense, Angelo T. Reyes, resigned, saying he wanted to spare the armed forces from a ''well-organized effort'' to discredit him. Mr. Reyes is a former military chief of staff who abandoned Joesph Estrada, then the president, in 2001 at the height of broad protests that led to Mr. Estrada's downfall. In July, soldiers mutinied in Manila and demanded Mr. Reyes's resignation, saying he was incompetent. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Telecom Acquisition
description: Amrica Mvil, the wireless telephone company controlled by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hel, will buy the wireless company BCP, based in So Paulo, for $625 million in cash and assumed debt, consolidating its dominant position in Latin America. The seller is a group of 34 banks, including Citigroup, that took over BCP in April after it defaulted on some debt. The purchase price includes the debt owed to the banks, Amrica Mvil said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Romp to East Title Has Been Thrown Into Turmoil
description: Jos Contreras plopped the rosin bag at the back of the mound, adjusted his cap, kicked at the dirt around the rubber with his right foot and took a few steps forward and spread the dirt around again. Everyone with a pulse at Fenway Park knew Contreras was one batter, maybe less, from being replaced. While Contreras stalled, Jeff Weaver threw in the bullpen. It was that bad for the Yankees. Already.

title: Scores on Math Regents Exam To Be Raised for Thousands
description: Thousands of students who initially failed the troubled Math A Regents exam in June will receive passing grades under a new scoring chart issued yesterday by the New York State Education Department, a department spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, HOWARD
description: KATZ--Howard. On August 26, 2003. Age 81. In Boca Raton, FL. Cherished husband of Gilda for 56 years. Adored father of Alan (Randi), Stuart (Carmen) and Jonathan (Robin). Beloved grandfather of Andrea, Sandra, Danielle, Stefanie, Pamela and Derek. Dear brother of Ira and Arlene. Patriarch and patriot. A proud son of Abraham. Above all, his life was a blessing. Alev Hashalom. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Red Magen David Adom.

title: Italy Is Youth Team Victor After Slim Win in Semifinals
description: The World Junior Team Championship -- officially named the World Youth Team Championship -- ended on Thursday in Paris with a victory for Italy. Furio and Stelio di Bello, who are brothers, teamed with Ruggiero Guariglia, Fabio Lo Presto, Francesco Mazzado and Stefano Uccello to defeat Denmark in the final by 87.7 imps.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a call by Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, to repeal some of President Bush's tax cuts misstated the amount he said would be saved by the rollback and other suggested cost-saving measures. It is $40 billion, not $40 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Reinsurer Posts Gain
description: The reinsurance company Swiss Re said it earned 691 million Swiss francs ($488 million) in the first half of the year, up from 118 million francs ($83 million) a year earlier, helped by growth in its property and casualty business and recent overhaul measures. The company, which was forced to cut its dividend last year for the first time since 1906, said it expected continued improvements in performance. The company, based in Zurich, said an absence of major claims against policies also helped results, which were better than analysts had expected. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Lifeguards Reflect on a Summer of Blah
description: From her post atop the lifeguard stand at the sparkling Asser Levy pool at East 23rd Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, Kristine Ramos was in a fine position yesterday to pronounce on the summer that is nearly gone. ''It was not all that busy, actually,'' she said.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY: THE NEW GROUND ZERO
description: A look at the ideas, people and institutions competing to fill ground zero's void, from the mysterious Museum of Freedom to the unassuming architect who is remaking the face of New York. A special issue of Arts & Leisure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, CAROL
description: TAYLOR--Carol. Prize-winning reporter for World Telegram and Sun for 25 years, died August 28 in St. Petersburg, Florida at 89. She was among the journalism students expelled from Louisiana State in the 30's when the school newspaper criticized political boss Huey Long. In 1957, she was the only journalist to sail on maiden U.S. voyage of Mayflower II. Survivors included daughter, Susan Taylor Martin, foreign correspondent for St. Petersburg Times; grandson Steven and a great-granddaughter.

title: Gillette Moves in Court on Schick Razor
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, took more actions yesterday to try to pre-empt hefty competition from the four-bladed Quattro razor that Schick-Wilkinson Sword has said it will introduce in a few weeks.

title: Fox Won't Distribute Film on Jesus
description: Mel Gibson is expected to show some major studios a version of his controversial movie about the crucifixion of Jesus by mid-September in the hope of finding a distributor, Hollywood executives said today. But one studio, 20th Century Fox, which usually releases Mr. Gibson's movies, has already said no.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCORMACK, ROBERT
description: McCORMACK--Robert. The President and Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York express deep sorrow at the passing of our Trustee Emeritus Robert McCormack. A graduate of the Columbia Business School, he was a respected colleague whose leadership as a Trustee was marked by exceptional insight, dedication and decency. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife, Susan Garner, and their children, Deirdre Garner McCormack & Andrew John McCormack. Lee C. In the cafeteria of the building where I work, a similar name -- Jay M. Kimmelsman -- appears on a plaque commemorating New York Times employees killed during World War II. Jay M. Kimmelsman worked in the department of outgoing mail. When I pass the plaque, I think of him. I feel a connection.

When the invitation to the seventh mob arrived in my e-mail box, I felt the small shiver of excitement that has fueled the phenomenon since its debut here in June.

title: When Co-op Sale Deposit Is at Stake
description: Q. Our co-op apartment was put on the market, and in February 2003 we signed a cash-deal contract with a buyer who placed a 10 percent deposit into an escrow account. The closing was set for April 2. No broker was involved. The contract said that the buyer should submit his application to our corporation within 10 days after receipt of the fully executed contract. Five months have now passed and the buyer has not done so. He has also been reluctant to communicate, and his lawyer did not return calls from our lawyer. Can we retain the deposit? What is the procedure for doing so? And is there any way the buyer can prevent us from selling our apartment? . . . Kenneth Wu, Manhattan

title: Detour
description: On that warm night in July, you lift yourself up to the railing of the overpass above the Los Angeles River. In the distance you can hear the cars moving along the Hollywood Freeway, and beyond it you see the glow of the city lights. I want to believe that as you fall you feel nothing more than the wind rushing up against your face. There is no pain. No impact. In my dreams you are suspended in midair.

title: HOUSING RULES REVISED
description: The state's Council on Affordable Housing proposed new rules last week intended to make it easier for municipalities to provide low- and moderate-income housing. Under the old system, each community had to have a fair share of lower-priced housing based on a complicated formula that many town officials criticized as cumbersome and developers used as a wedge to build large, dense housing complexes. Under the new rules, towns would have to require one new lower-priced unit for every 10 housing units built, and one unit for every 30 jobs created by new commercial construction. Critics questioned whether the new rules would have the desired effect or would result in keeping the poor and minorities in cities. They complained that the new rules allow towns that are not growing to avoid providing low- and moderate-income housing. Critics also complained that the rules doubled the number of units that could be set aside for the elderly, from 25 percent to 50 percent. George James

title: Credit Card Tips For College Students

title: Help Wanted
description: Walter Kirn's deceptively facile essay on unemployment states baldly that the only two reasons people get jobs are to make money and to dodge annoying spouses (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 17). In making this claim, he unintentionally reflects the horrifically corroded values of modern America, in which one can write what appears to be a thoughtful piece on vocation without ever mentioning what has gone missing from the employment scene altogether: the learning of a craft or a trade as a lifestyle, the thing that for centuries gave meaning to the lives of even those people who had no money and annoying spouses.

title: A Cemetery for the Living
description: ON a quiet side street in the East Village lies the New York City Marble Cemetery, the second nonsectarian cemetery built in Manhattan. Created in 1832 by several enterprising businessmen as a profit-making venture, the cemetery provides a social hub and respite for its neighbors that surpass its original intent. Residents and curious passers-by alike are drawn to the green oasis on East Second Street between First and Second Avenues, sequestered behind an imposing wrought-iron fence and surrounded by a three-sided 12-foot-high stone wall overhung with ivy.

title: This Boy's Freedom
description: For more than 50 years I have gone back and forth from Spanish, my first language, to English, my adopted one, feeling duty to both and freedom in neither. I love my homeland of Puerto Rico as one loves a mother, yet I am wedded to America as one is to a generous but difficult wife. Racially, I exist in neither a white nor a black world, owing accountability to both and, because of their restrictions, ill at ease in each. I grew up with my heart divided by passion and obligation. The conflict between the two is evident in recalling nine summers, first in Puerto Rico and then in New York, between the ages of 9 and 18.

title: Heart-Attack Heart to Heart

I'm in my 60's and otherwise in good health, but my wife excessively worries about health problems, particularly mine. I didn't tell her about this discovery, both to spare her the worry and to shield myself from the stress of her 'hovering,' which might increase the likelihood of another heart attack. I think this is the right decision, but I have occasional guilt feelings. Is it ethical? Anonymous, California

title: In Trying Times, Many Ways To Ask, Will You Hire Me?
description: JOBLESS for two years now, Michael Walker has sent out roughly 2,400 rsums, gone on 18 interviews with no offers and drained both his savings account and his 401(k). ''I have a standing offer that I'll pay $2,000 cash to the person who refers me to a full-time job,'' said Mr. Walker, a software engineer from Seattle who is in his 40's.

title: Now Free to Marry, Canada's Gays Say, 'Do I?'
description: When David Andrew, a 41-year-old federal government employee, heard that the highest Ontario court had extended marriage rights to same-sex couples two months ago, he broke into a sweat.

description: Even though his 26th birthday was not until today, Felix Sanchez splurged on Friday night and gave himself a present a day early. On a cold and rainy evening, he won the 400-meter hurdles at the world track and field championships in 47.25 seconds, his best time and the fastest time in the world in five years.

title: Coming Attraction
description: CALL it returning the state to its roots. It has been a dozen years since the drive-in movie classic, The Fly, last flickered on a giant New Jersey screen. The owners of the Route 35 Drive-In in Hazlet brought it back in 1991 for one last showing before they razed the theater and put up a modern multiplex that sits on the site these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIGHTER, VOLNEY FOSTER (TURK)
description: RIGHTER -- Volney Foster (Turk). On August 27, 2003, at age 100, of Bedford Hills and Fishers Island, NY. A founding partner of Harrington, Righter and Parsons. They were the first company to specialize in representing television stations nationally to the advertising industry. Mr. Righter was a graduate of St. Paul's School, Class of 1922, Harvard College, Class of 1926 (a longtime class agent) and Harvard Business School, Class of 1928. A member of the Board of Trustees of the Katonah Museum of Art. Married to the late Sarah Williams Righter. Father of James Volney Righter, of Boston, MA, and Robert McCormick Righter of Denver, CO. Also survived by granddaughter Eliot Righter Ramos and grandson Mark Hamilton Righter, and four great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. Matthew's Church, on Saturday, September 6, 2003, at 3 PM, in Bedford, NY. Interment will be private. In memoriams to Katonah Museum of Art.

title: Tough Start to the School Year
description: Many of the 50 million American children who return to public school this week will be carrying a good deal more than lunch boxes. Faced with a dismal economy and deep budget cuts, some schools are asking families to contribute basic supplies like paper, pencils and even soap. Others are charging students steep fees to join athletic teams. Worst of all, teacher layoffs are driving up class sizes and jeopardizing enrichment programs that have been shown to improve student performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, LORRAINE INA
description: SMITH--Lorraine Ina. On August 29, in Fairfax, VA. Born November 12, 1922, to Molly Weisblum and Charles Waldman in Brooklyn, NY. A talented singer and actress, she studied voice at the Juilliard School, attended Queens College and graduated from Northwestern University (BS Speech, '45). She traveled in the road companies of ''Brigadoon,'' ''Showboat'' and ''On the Town.'' She married Gerald Morton Smith, an attorney, in 1954 and remained his devoted wife until his death in 2000. A loving parent, she was also a community activist and PTA president in Valley Stream, New York. She is survived by her son Carlton M. Smith, of NYC, son Mark S. Smith and daughterin-law Mina M. Smith of Vienna, VA, and their daughters Larissa R. Smith and Talia S. Smith, who embrace and carry on their grandmother's love of music.

The article also misstated the date of one of the country's partitions; the last one was in 1795. (There was none in 1830, when Chopin fled.)

title: A Way To Break The Cycle Of Servitude
description: ON this Labor Day weekend, let us remember low-wage workers. Twenty percent of the work force -- 26 million people -- earn $8.23 an hour or less. Most of them are not teenagers snagging pocket money, but adults supporting families. With so little income, too many Americans are pushed into poverty, and getting out of this trap is increasingly difficult.

title: Editorial Observer; The Gambles and Gaffes Behind Two Tragic Space Shuttle Disasters
description: For those of us who covered the investigation of the space shuttle Challenger accident in 1986, the parallels with the latest inquest into the disintegration of the shuttle Columbia in the skies over Texas are eerie, and deeply disturbing. One can only hope that the remedial actions NASA now takes prove more successful than its fixes the last time around. The odds are not good given the pressures and weaknesses that hobble this once-proud agency.

title: The Very Picture Of Rural England
description: ALMOST 20 years ago, when we were living in London, my wife, Betsey, and I bought and restored a stone cottage in Lechlade, a village in the Cotswolds. For a year or two, it was a weekend place; since then we have used it mainly for vacations. Gradually, we have grown deeply attached to the house, the village and the region, which is the essence of bucolic England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALLIN, ALEXANDRA (KALLINIKIDOU)
description: KALLIN--Alexandra (Kallinikidou), of Manhattan, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on August 28, 2003 from congestive heart failure. She was the daughter of Eleni and Vasilios Kallinikidou and was born in Chalcedon, Turkey on November 27, 1906. She is survived by a niece, Helen Moneo, a nephew, Nicholas Kantargi, a grandniece, Consuelo Onks, a grandnephew, Peter Moneo, four great-grandnieces and great-grandnephews, and several cousins. Alexandra Kallin taught and tutored Greek for many years. A long admirer of the Greek language and culture, as well as a devout communicant of the Greek Orthodox Church, she established in 1993 the Kallinikeion Foundation whose aim is to promote the Greek language and Orthodoxy. The Kallinikeion Summer Greek Language Institute at Hellenic College, Brookline, Mass. is one project of the Foundation. The Foundation also recently financed the construction of a library at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. Funeral services, to be presided over by Archbishop Demetrios of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, will be held at 10:30 AM, Wednesday, September 3, at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St. Miss Kallin will lie in state at the Cathedral where visiting hours will be from 6 to 9 PM, Tuesday, September 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISNER, JACK P.
description: EISNER--Jack P. November 15, 1925-August 24, 2003. Born in Warsaw, Poland. Died in New York City. Cherished husband of Sara. Devoted father of Lee, Philip and Arnold. Beloved and respected grandfather of Alexandra and Lauren. A charismatic, inspirational and innovative leader of the Holocaust survivor community, he built up a successful international trade business after surviving the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising and Majdanek, Budzyn and Flossenburg concentration camps as a teenager. Served as a witness at Nazi war criminal trials. He was the founder of the Warsaw Ghetto Resistance Organization and the Holocaust Survivors Memorial Foundation and organizer of the first Holocaust commemoration event in the United States. He retired from business in 1978 to dedicate his life to write, lecture, and produce films and plays to educate the public on the significance of the Jewish Holocaust. Jack was the author of the autobiographical ''The Survivor'' (Morrow, 1980; reprinted by Kensington) on which the movie ''War and Love'' (written by Abby Mann and directed by Moshe Mizrahi) and the Broadway play ''The Survivor'' (written by Susan Nanus) was based. He produced documentary films and appeared in many others based on the Holocaust. He established the first Institute of Holocaust Studies at CUNY with public scholarly lectures and the first chair in Holocaust Studies at the Harvard Divinity School. Jack was the inspiration and sponsor of the controversial Goldberg Commission created to investigate the role played by American Jews during the Holocaust and chaired by Supreme Court Justice Arthur Goldberg. In 1993 he created the Children's Memorial Monument in Warsaw at the entrance of the Jewish cemetery dedicated to the one and a half million Jewish children killed by the Nazis. The memorial is visited by hundreds of thousands of tourists each year. In 1995 he organized the first Holocaust memorial event ever held at the Vatican at which Pope John Paul II presided. In the past decade he turned his attention to lecturing and writing on the role that Christianity and its teachings contributed to the Holocaust. He dedicated himself to promoting ChristianJewish tolerance and dialogue. His latest book ''The Happy Boys'' deals with the immediate postwar struggle of his group of orphaned teenage friends to rebuild their lives after the concentration camps. It is due to be published in early 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, PEARL C.
description: MILLER--Pearl C. Beloved daughter of the late Charles Cohn and Bella Cohen Cohn, adored sister of Seymour Cohn and the late Mildred Cohn, Maurice Cohn, Irene Colvin and Sylvan Lawrence, devoted and loyal wife of the late Henry Miller, and cherished aunt and great-aunt to each and every member of the Cohen and Cembalest families. Born on October 20, 1906 in New York City, the youngest daughter in a large and accomplished family, Pearl devoted herself to her studies, eventually becoming a teacher in the New York City Public School System. As a young girl, Pearl began her life-long involvement with Tranquillity Camp. As the ideal embodiment of the Cohen family credo ''Noblesse Oblige,'' Pearl soon became the indispensable right-hand of her uncle, the late Elias A. Cohen, one of the truly great men of his time, who founded Tranquillity Camp in 1919. After his sudden passing in July of 1952, Pearl shouldered the tremendous responsiblity of keeping the Camp going. For well over 50 years, Pearl selflessly and tirelessly devoted every minute of every day to her family, and to each of the children whose character was so quietly and subtlely molded by her example. Despite her towering intellect and photographic memory, Pearl, like so many members of the Cohen family before her, never talked down to anyone. To us she was a unique individual, a giant. When flattered by anyone, she would characteristically brush it off with a small wave of her hand, saying ''It's nothing. I just do what I do.'' She made it all seem so simple. Services will be held on Sunday, August 31, 2003, 11AM at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Tranquillity Camp, Inc., 170 Tranquillity Rd., Earlton, NY 12058, would be appreciated.

title: Searching for a Defining Look In the Land of Ben & Jerry's
description: SURE, wars and trade agreements, Supreme Court appointments and budget vetoes all mark a presidency. But what about a president's personal style? Ronald Reagan brought California elegance -- all pomade and cummerbunds; Bill Clinton, with his tamed bouffant and gimme caps, a certain slick hickness. And George W. Bush, hugged as he is by platter-size belt buckles, imparts a Texas extra-largeness wherever he goes. So with Howard Dean raking in the cash and towering like the Green Mountains over his Democratic rivals in polls, it is time to imagine a presidency, and a nation, under the sway of Vermont style.

The average scores of students in the state, 515 in math and 501 in verbal skills, were below the national averages of 519 in math and 507 in verbal skills. George James

description: CHARGING people for the amount of garbage they throw away does have the effect of changing long-held habits. For one family, the Ackleys in Stonington Borough, it completely changed the way they disposed of their household trash.

title: House Proud
description: IN 1847, the settlers of Marshall, a southern Michigan town strategically set on the stagecoach route between Detroit and Chicago, received unwelcome news. Expected by its founders to become the state capital, Marshall lost out through political chicanery (as local lore has it) to its upstart neighbor, Lansing. Today the old affront looks more like a blessing. On the one hand, Marshall, 171 miles east of Chicago and 117 miles west of Detroit on the railroad line that soon replaced stagecoaches, lost its chance to become the center of state government. On the other, the absence of development meant that hundreds of 19th-century houses were preserved and passed down for generations, making Marshall (population 7,459) a magnet for those who crave a weekend ''where the fast lane ends'' (as the chamber of commerce boasts on its Web site).

title: A Minister's Message: The Past Is Perfect
description: IT'S time to remember Wallace Nutting (1861-1941), a savvy congregational minister who abandoned the pulpit in 1904 to preach an idealized version of the American past. Through lectures, writings, sentimental photographs and the manufacture of Pilgrim-era furniture, he spearheaded a colonial revival across America in the early decades of last century. It made him rich, a household name, and a trademarked brand. He was the Martha Stewart of his day.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Tourmaline, by Joanna Scott. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) An American businessman takes his wife and four sons to the island of Elba in the 1950's to search for gems and a fresh start. Nearly 50 years later, his youngest son returns to extract the truth of his family's troubling experiences there, reconstructing the past through village gossip and the residue of marital distrust. This philosophically probing novel ''once again shows Joanna Scott to be a writer who takes different directions from book to book,'' a quest that ''separates the genuine artist from the fake,'' Jeffrey Eugenides wrote here last year.

title: A French Roadblock to Free Trade

Farming is a way of life, the French argue, which governments are entitled to protect from the impact of ''mindless trade liberalization'' in a way that they ought not protect, say, refrigerator manufacturers. The French have a strong attachment to the ideal of the bucolic countryside, and a change in agricultural policy can be blown up into a threat to national identity.

title: Honoring the Dead in the City That Never Weeps
description: FROM the very start of serious planning, it was clear that the Sept. 11 memorial at ground zero would face a host of obvious and largely unprecedented challenges. As the design effort has proceeded, however, a less obvious challenge has begun to make itself felt. It arises from the fact that the commemorative ground sits right in the heart of Lower Manhattan, amid the busy streets and soaring towers of the downtown business district. It is the challenge of creating a memorial in a city that, for most of its history, has abhorred the very idea of memorials.

title: Ye Olde Handel Dusted Off by an Iconoclast

Each uses period instruments and occupies three CD's, and although the choice between them is not easy, I prefer the more recent set, conducted by Ren Jacobs. But what really interest me are the differences -- differences in singing, conducting and philosophy -- and how they may have sparked the sharply divided critical response the Jacobs set has received.

title: 'Beautiful Shadow'
description: In one of Highsmith's early notebooks there is a short vignette about a boy who wonders why he is happy at one moment and sad the next. As the boy grows older, he becomes increasingly fascinated by the nature of consciousness and people come from afar to ask him the question: 'What and why am I?' Like the boy in her story, Highsmith was a writer in search of identity. On every page of her cahiers and diaries the same self-searching questions are asked over and over again. Was she the sum of her consciousness? Or was her self merely made up of the perceptions of other people? 'There is an ever more acute difference ... between my inner self which I know is the real me, and various faces of the outside world,' she wrote in 1947. And could a writer, forever assuming the personalities of his or her characters, even have such a thing as a stable identity?

In June, 84 years after Sun Yat-sen, the Chinese Nationalist leader, first proposed locating the dam downstream of the scenic Three Gorges, sluice gates closed and the silt-laden waters of the world's third-longest river began filling the cavernous gap between a series of sheer cliffs to form the biggest reservoir in the world.

Shouts of toddlers touching sea anemones and grunts of surprise from adults observing a three-foot-long lake sturgeon indicate the bait is working.

title: Puzzling
description: Merryl Maleska Wilbur's reminiscences about her father, Eugene, were poignant and enlightening (On Language, Aug. 17). It was during his tenure as puzzle editor that I became engulfed in cruciverbalism and have remained an addict ever since. I knew nothing of him personally but could sense from his style that he was straightforward, witty and demanding, erudite but not pedantic, all the while eschewing obfuscation. His daughter's description of his family background and his role as father, husband and educator brought forward a personality that completely matched his work. How wonderful to have such a man as a father.

And every year, legions of people pay thousands of dollars each for the privilege of declaring, along with him and stadiums full of like-minded followers: ''I will lead, not follow! I will believe, not doubt! I will create, not destroy!''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn; On Cobblestone Streets, History Lingers
description: AS far as anyone knows, no vinegar has ever been mass-produced in Vinegar Hill, a minuscule neighborhood covering only eight blocks close to the Manhattan Bridge anchorage and abutting the Brooklyn Navy Yard on the borough's northwestern shore. In fact, its name comes from the site in County Wexford, Ireland, where Irish rebels fought the English in 1798. At one point, the area was called Irish Town after the people who settled in the buildings on its cobblestone streets.

title: Blood Sport
description: Just before I entered my teenage years, when cable suddenly made more channels available than there were shows to fill them up, ''North Dallas Forty'' seemed to be on TV all the time. The movie, based on a novel by Peter Gent, a former receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, is about a depraved professional football team, and as a kid I couldn't bear it. The players are loathsome cretins whose hatred for one another is matched only by their hatred for themselves. The coach is a cold, vicious tyrant, the games are murderous spectacles. The locker room is worse: with discomforting regularity, a hypodermic needle is jabbed into a player's mangled knee, and then he's good to go. Nothing -- not even the inept Joe Pisarcik's seemingly endless tenure as the starting quarterback for my beloved New York Giants -- was more depressing than this movie. I loved sports; I even loved Pisarcik, in a way. Why was this behind-the-scenes nihilism getting mixed up with my sports?

description: Kristen Leigh Fauver, a daughter of Alane George of Raleigh, N.C., and James Fauver of Bonita Springs, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Kevin Corcoran, the son of Katherine Schilling and Richard Corcoran, both of New York. title: Breaking the Heat
description: In these moist, drag-slag days, when the city's heat makes your rayons cling, it's reassuring to note that it's not only the temperature of the food you eat that has the capacity to cool. What you want on days like these is intake that makes you feel like the frosty inside of a fridge, and aside from ice cream, cold drinks and just plain ice applied to wrist, neck or ankle, very few foods actually lower body heat. But some can create an arctic blast visually, tactilely and gustatorily. Sometimes it's the cool crackle of the perfect gazpacho; sometimes, the perfume of an especially silken Crenshaw melon. Always, it's the sweetness and astringency of heirloom tomatoes. Sometimes the perfect late-summer meal is as far away as Copenhagen or as near as the Upper West Side.

description: A picture caption on Aug. 3 with an article about a controversial barrier being built to separate Israel from the West Bank misidentified a piece of equipment on a road near the structure. It was an Israeli military vehicle, not a tank.

description: THE Rev. Michael O'Connor and an assistant, Robert Snider, held Grace Hamilton's arms, steadying her against the ocean waves that crashed into their legs at Robert Moses State Park one recent Sunday.

description: Stephanie Lynn Snitow, the daughter of Emily Snitow of Westfield, N.J., and Neal Snitow of North Plainfield, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Daniel Jacoby, a son of Marcia Jacoby and Dr. Robert Jacoby of Guilford, Conn.
