title: U.S. Sprinter Tests Positive For Stimulant
description: Kelli White of the United States, the women's champion at 100 and 200 meters at the world track and field championships, has tested positive for a stimulant, and that could cost her the gold medals she won here and could prevent her from competing in the 2004 Olympics in Athens, the sport's world governing body said today.

title: In Stratford, a Question of Leadership
description: IN the suburban town of Stratford, voters will decide in November whether to adopt a mayoral government after having a town manager system for 82 years, a question that is dividing both government officials and citizens in the town of nearly 50,000.

title: Yankees Continue a Discouraging Pattern
description: BOSTON, Aug. 29 - The Yankees are playing another contending team and following their discouraging pattern. When they play bad teams, the Yankees look flawless. But good teams expose their problems, and their fiercest rival did so Friday night.

title: Amid a Revival, Seeking Balance
description: Butch Davis has a great-grandfather who was a Cherokee Indian and another who was a Nazarene minister for 50 years. He is the son of a coach. He has a son, Drew, 10, who nearly died at 7 months from a tricky case of whooping cough.

description: Sireesha Kanthi Soma, the daughter of Padma and Somaiah Soma of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., is to be married today to Dr. Ashwin Jathavedam, the son of Hamsa and Perin N. title: For Once It Paid To Gas Up on the Turnpike
description: But wait, there was even more good news for drivers last week. Motorists have long grumbled about paying higher gasoline prices on the state's toll roads. Last week, however, the New Jersey Turnpike had a surprise.

title: Huskies Ring in New and Resolve to Keep Rolling
description: It took the Connecticut football coach a while to make his way off the field today in the long minutes after the Huskies opened Rentschler Field, their new $91.2 million field, and their season with a 34-10 victory over Indiana. There were just too many people to hug.

description: In a middle school cafeteria this month, people who provide community services from East Tremont in the Bronx met with people they barely knew: other people who provide community services from East Tremont in the Bronx.

title: Giants Make Final Cuts a Day Early
description: By 8 a.m. today, relieved smiles filled the Giants' locker room. The congratulations had been passed around. The anxious moments were done. There was no list, no dramatic announcement. Those who fell victim to the Giants' final cuts had been told quietly by Coach Jim Fassel. By 8, everyone left in the Giants' locker room was still a Giant.

title: A Whiff of Anti-Semitism And a Touch of Snobbery
description: With all due respect, I would like to point out to Rabbi Schneier that the fine citizens of Westhampton Beach were not all living in share houses seven years ago. Some of us had even read a book by then and many of us considered ourselves God-loving family folks of varied religious preferences. Westhampton Beach has been a wonderful place to live and visit for many, many years. One reason for this is the handiwork of our Maker. This is not a recent miracle, ongoing civic improvements notwithstanding. Suffice to say, I count my blessings for being able to live in Westhampton Beach. I felt the same way the first time I arrived here some 20 years ago.

description: AS the founder and leader of the Kingdom Life Christian Church in the Devon section of Milford, Bishop Jay Ramirez is as impressive as he is charismatic. Impeccably dressed, handsome and articulate, the former high-ranking Emergency Medical Service official is a picture of control.

description: HOLMES--Neal H. Of Pittsburgh, PA., on Wednesday August 27, 2003. Mr. Holmes was co-founder of Allied Security Inc. where he served as C.E.O. and Chairman of the Board. He also served as Chairman of the Board for the Allegheny County Port Authority and a Board member of the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. He was a veteran of the U.S. Army. Survived by wife June Holmes, Children Renee Holmes, Neal H. Holmes II. stepchildren Jamie Beck and James Aiello Jr.

title: Kykuit Expands Rooms Open to Public
description: A new Grand Tour at Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate at Pocantico Hills, N.Y., bundles into a single package the existing tours of the house, gardens and sculpture collection. It also includes limited access to the previously unopened second-floor balcony of the home.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 17 about the new National Constitution Center in Philadelphia misstated its location in two references. It is one block north of Market Street, not one block east; a glass wall in the Llewellyn Citizens' Cafe at the center frames Independence Hall, which is two blocks to the south, not three blocks to the west.

title: Need a Doggie Bridal Veil?
description: The name Well Bred seems so appropriate for a certain store on Main Street in Clinton that its less likely sub-sign -- The Pet Bakery -- almost escapes notice. Only a chalkboard propped out front lets passersby attach absolute certainty to the inkling that they have stumbled onto something genuinely kooky: ''Finally, the 2004 Poop Calendars are here!'' it promises.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Pettitte Is in Background and at Forefront
description: Andy Pettitte wondered if it had taken him one sloppy throw in one bad inning to destroy any chances the Yankees had of conquering Pedro Martnez and the Boston Red Sox today. Pettitte basically gift-wrapped three runs for Boston in the first inning, which is why he walked back to the dugout with his glove covering his face. Pettitte wanted to muffle his screams and hide, too.

title: The World; A Democracy That Has Room Even for Violence
description: AMERICANS can count on one hand the incidents of large-scale political violence in the last 10 years: the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, and on the federal building in Oklahoma City. The most recent major racial disturbance was in Los Angeles in 1992, the last sustained period of broad upheaval in the 60's and early 70's.

title: For the Pequot Museum, a Fading Vision
description: AT the Foxwoods Resort Casino, a $99 million expansion is under way, the first addition in several years at what is already the world's largest casino. The 120,000-square-foot project, however, has some observers worried about the lack of growth at another ambitious enterprise operated by the Mashantucket Pequots: the Mashantucket Museum and Research Center.

title: Wilson Makes Torre Look Very Smart
description: Enrique Wilson has come to expect that he will play when the Yankees face Pedro Martnez. Manager Joe Torre likes the quality of Wilson's at-bats, even without looking at his career numbers. But those numbers keep getting better, too.

title: Page Two: Aug. 24-30 -- The Week Ahead; THE CAMPAIGN GETS SERIOUS
description: Labor Day has always meant the start of serious politicking. And that is certainly true this year for the Democratic presidential candidates, who are preparing for a burst of activity over the next week. On Tuesday, John Kerry formally announces he is running for president, while in Iowa and New Hampshire, Richard A. Gephardt launches television advertisements. On Thursday, the candidates gather in Albuquerque for the first of six official debates. With the public presumably paying attention, Democrats are expecting something more than a mild evening on stage. Adam Nagourney

title: Executive Life; It's Back to School, To Become a Teacher
description: BLAME the weak job market. Or the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Or the corporate accounting scandals that have left some workers disillusioned. Whatever the reason, as students head back to the classroom for the new school year, so are many executives who are aiming to become public school teachers, according to education experts and administrators of teacher training programs.

title: Philippines Pressed on Killing of Journalists
description: For about four months, a picture of a police officer accused of killing a journalist, Edgar Damalerio, has appeared daily in newspapers throughout the Philippines. With the killings of other journalists still unsolved, editors and publishers concerned that justice would again elude one of their own have promised to keep publishing the suspect's picture as long as he remains at large.

title: Tens of Thousands March in Funeral for Slain Cleric

title: Hay Days
description: Every three years, the sounds of coaching horns and clip-clopping hooves are heard along Bellevue Avenue in Newport. This year, 70 horses and 16 coaches from eight states turned out for Coaching Weekend, an event sponsored by the Preservation Society of Newport County. Riding on top of the coaches were members of the Newport summer colony and guests of the owner-drivers. Hats were mandatory, as were jackets and ties for men. After the drives, the guests attended lunches on the estates, and the horses went back to the stables for a shower.

title: Nice
description: For centuries, foreigners have been drawn to the aqua blue waters of the Bay of Angels and the sun-steeped city crowding its shore. Russian and British aristocracy made the town their winter home in the early 1800's, when it belonged to the kingdom of Savoy and most of its residents spoke Italian. American tycoons and Hollywood starlets discovered the city in the 1920's, when it was again part of France.

title: ADULT CARE PROGRAMS INVESTIGATED
description: A handful of adult day care centers in the state are being investigated for suspected violations that range from overcharging Medicaid to luring potential patients who did not appear to need the centers' services with free toaster ovens, state officials said. The Department of Human Services' program-integrity unit and the Division of Criminal Justice are investigating 16 of 122 such centers in New Jersey. More than $600,000 in suspicious charges was submitted by the day care centers, including charges for patients who had died, said Ed Rogan, a spokesman for the human services agency. Other alleged violations include operating a facility without a nurse on duty and enrolling patients who did not qualify for the services. The centers have skyrocketed in popularity, offering physical therapy, vaccinations, blood pressure monitoring and help with bathing and grooming. Wendy Ginsberg

title: On the Market
description: 2-bath 1,200-square-foot duplex with private terrace at 50 Bridge Street, $550,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRICKMAN, ROSEMARY
description: STRICKMAN -- Rosemary. Died on August 25th at her home in Rancho Mirage, CA of pancreatic cancer. Beloved wife and best friend of 56 years to Arthur, adored mother of Ellen Walsh (Michael), Wendy Hoffman (Ted) and Nancy Stein (Bradley). Devoted RoRo to Arthur, Zachary, William and Perry. Good friend to many on both coasts. Rosemary fought her illness with courage, grace and wit right up to the end. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service and celebration of Rosemary's life will be held at a later date in Rancho Mirage. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCan), 2221 Rosecrans Avenue, Suite 131, El Segundo, CA. 90245.

title: Voluntown Man To Head V.F.W.
description: EDWARD S. BANAS SR., a Vietnam veteran who lives in Voluntown, was set to be sworn in as commander-in-chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars last week, making him only the second Connecticut resident to win the top post in one of the nation's largest veterans' organization.

title: A Whiff of Anti-Semitism And a Touch of Snobbery
description: In your article about the Hampton Synagogue, Rabbi Marc Schneier was quoted as saying Westhampton Beach was headed for Potters Field before the arrival of the synagogue. I think he is way off base with that remark. This village has always been family-oriented, with generation after generation returning for the summers, and in some casea to live here year round. Thanks to the dedication of the Village Trustees, a nightclub, which caused much disruption, was closed down, and ordinances discouraging group rentals were passed.

title: Business; Going Gold? Maybe, if Enough Cellphones Ring
description: ONE of the most popular songs in the country last week, ''Crazy in Love'' by Beyonc Knowles and featuring Jay-Z, was not released only on compact disc and to radio stations. It was also sent to cellphone users who wanted to download it as their ring tone.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE first image in Mark Romannek's psychological drama ONE HOUR PHOTO (2002) looks like something from ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' but it's only a photo-processing machine that Sy Parris uses in his job at SavMart. Sy (a chillingly good Robin Williams) is a middle-aged lonely guy who develops an obsession with customers who seem, to him, like the ideal happy family. Sy makes an extra set of prints of all their pictures and has papered one wall of his apartment with them. This might have gone on harmlessly (relatively) forever, but two events shake things up: Sy discovers, from film brought in by another customer, that the family isn't nearly as perfect as he'd thought. And Sy's boss fires him, giving him nothing to do all day but stalk - Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:50 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Posada's Homers Help Yankees Bat Back the Charging Red Sox
description: So here were the Red Sox, with a three-run lead in the first inning and their best pitcher on the mound. In the last 10 days, they had chewed four games off the Yankees' division lead. They were the hunter, and the Yankees were fleeing in fright.

title: Enlightenment For a Web Site That Went Too Far
description: The story of Salesforce.com and the Dalai Lama reached its conclusion last week. You might recall that Salesforce, long a supporter of Tibetan causes, invited 500 employees and journalists to an appearance in San Francisco by the Dalai Lama, who is embarking on a tour of the United States.

Westendorf of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Keith Pratt, the son of Nancy and Keith Pratt of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. H. Alfred Allenby, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the First Congregational Church of Falmouth in Falmouth, Mass.

title: Summer of Sun? We Wuz Robbed
description: THE weather was lovely last Tuesday in Brunswick, Me. But that doesn't mean Barbara Held was happy. She was sitting in her office at Bowdoin College there watching the students roll in with their parents for orientation and feeling so miserable that she was giving herself a headache.

title: New Look at Pius XII's Views of Nazis
description: Pope Pius XII has been branded by some authors and Jewish leaders as ''Hitler's Pope'' for his silence during the Holocaust.

title: Gauge Nears 'E' at Riverhead Raceway
description: PILOTING a 600-horsepower car around a quarter-mile oval track is like running a thoroughbred around a baseball diamond: too much power and too little room to maneuver. The margin for error is slim, and the emphasis is on control, not raw speed.

description: New York City's first Starbucks has served its last latte. The branch, at 2379 Broadway, at 87th Street, closed two weeks ago in a neighborhood that has changed tremendously since Starbucks came on the local scene nearly a decade ago.

title: Wanted: Big, Fast, Hits Like Sapp
description: The name of Warren Sapp's official Web site provides perhaps the most succinct job description.

title: Investing; Wall St. Reform Falls Short, Survey Says
description: WILL the corporate governance reforms put in place since Enron's collapse prevent such scandals from recurring?

title: The World: A Question of Timing; Israel Puts Hamas Political Leaders in Its Cross Hairs
description: THERE is something of a mystery to Israel's new campaign to kill members and leaders of Hamas, a mystery that goes to the heart of the standoff with the Palestinians: Why didn't Israel do this a year ago, or two years ago? And if it was a bad idea then, why is it a good idea now?

title: Trojan Horses Decked Out in Leafy Green
description: AMONG gardeners, there is a dark joke about which plants make the best gifts for pesky neighbors and annoying acquaintances. Although I've yet to play this game, I've been tempted. Topping the gift list are plants with runaway metabolism, affectionately known as "the flowers of discontent."

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Westport Country Playhouse misspelled the name of a co-founder of the theater. He is Lawrence Langner, not Langer.

title: Hyundai North America Chief Resigns
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30 - Finbarr J. O'Neill, the chief executive at Hyundai North America, resigned on Friday from the Korean carmaker and is expected to take a similar job next week with the troubled Japanese automaker Mitsubishi Motors.

title: Sometimes, They Serve the City. Sometimes, They Just Serve.
description: As the setting sun glinted off the Rolexes in the front row of Arthur Ashe Stadium at the United States Open on Thursday, Jennifer Capriati laid waste to Martina Sucha before an indolent crowd, many fans with sunglasses still perched atop their frosted blond heads. Capriati skipped a serve down the center line and Sucha bonked it wide. No action here.

title: Beckham Scores In League Debut
description: David Beckham took just two minutes to score in his Spanish league debut yesterday, helping Real Madrid to a 2-1 victory over Real Betis in the season opener.

title: Unions to Push to Make Organizing Easier
description: On Labor Day, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. plans to announce a nationwide campaign that union leaders say is crucial to assuring labor's future, a campaign that aims to change federal laws to make it easier for workers to join unions.

title: Page Two: Aug. 24-30; TEEKID PHONED HOME
description: Among law enforcement officials and computer security experts there is a long-standing truism that brilliant computer criminals never get caught. So, on Friday, when federal agents arrested Jeffrey Lee Parson, 18 of Hopkins, Minn., for releasing a copycat version of the Blaster worm that bedeviled computer operators this month, one could only ask, what was he thinking?

title: Trojan Horses Caparisoned in Leafy Green
description: AMONG gardeners, there is a dark joke about which plants make the best gifts for pesky neighbors and annoying acquaintances. Although I've yet to play this game, I've been tempted. Topping the gift list are plants with run-away metabolism, affectionately known as ''the flowers of discontent.''

title: Patricia Alcamo, William McCulloch
description: Patricia Joy Alcamo, a daughter of the late Judith A. Alcamo and the late Dr. I. Edward Alcamo, is to be married today to William Brennan McCulloch, a son of Patricia G. and James C. McCulloch of Batesville, Ark. The Rev. James W. H. Sell, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate on the grounds of Sullivan House, a bed-and-breakfast in New Shoreham, R.I., on Block Island.

title: Muslims Gather in New York to Remember Revered Cleric
description: A hundred Muslims gathered in Queens last night to mourn Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, the Shiite cleric killed in Friday's bombing in Najaf, Iraq, calling him a martyr who endured a lifetime of oppression.

title: Dreamy Sounds From The 'De La Guarda' Guy
description: DIANNE REEVES -- This jazz singer finally got around to making a small-group acoustic album, but ''A Little Moonlight'' (Blue Note) is nearly as ponderous as her other albums astride the jazz/pop fault line. When she wants to swing hard and efficaciously, she can; it happens on the title track. More often, however, her voice is frustratingly confined to the pedestal she has built for it. Still, the simple fact of a small band is a good thing: to hear this colossal, precisely aimed voice skipping down scales, not skimping on any of the notes along the way, and with so few other instruments intruding on it, is to hear good singing.

title: Analyze This
description: In the mid-19th century, a group of German engineers, fleeing the Great Turnip Famine of 1852-54 in Upper Silesia, arrived on our shores, here to disperse to the great academic centers. They were brilliant engineers. English, however, was not by them very well spoken. In their technical writings, for example, they showed a decided affinity for the passive voice. But the substance of their published materials was such that it afforded a certain acceptance of, even preference for, their awkward syntax.

title: This Is Her Life, and It May Be Yours Too
description: SLEEPING is so conventional. Think about it: people go to bed at night, and they do it in generally the same way. At 15, Heather Woodbury, a bohemian growing up in Berkeley, Calif., decided to be different. She was going to stay awake, permanently. Sure, there were some obstacles. ''After three days without sleep,'' she discovered, ''you become clinically insane.'' But madness wasn't going to stop a rebellious teenager with a defiantly stubborn streak. Armed with bottles of caffeine pills, Ms. Woodbury spent a long four-day weekend with a friend, awake.

title: John Lansdale Jr., 91, Is Dead; Found German A-Bomb Project
description: John Lansdale Jr., the head of security for the Manhattan Project who helped lead American forces to Germany's atomic bomb project before Soviet forces could reach it, died on Aug. 22 at his home near Annapolis, Md. He was 91.

title: Agassi Waits As the Rain Plays Games

title: REPORT ON SENTENCES CHALLENGED
description: State officials are challenging the validity of a newspaper report that concluded that a criminal ''is likely to do as much time for sticking up a convenience store as for killing a child.'' The Star-Ledger examined 123 child deaths from 1998 to this year. 2003. In the cases the newspaper reviewed, four people were convicted of murder, which carries a sentence of 30 years to life. John Hagerty, a spokesman for the Department of Law and Public Safety, said the conclusion by The Star-Ledger did not account for the variables of each case and ignored the findings of various courts. ''Murder is murder in the state of New Jersey,'' Mr. Hagerty said. ''Regardless of a victim's age, the penalty is the same. You have to look at the facts and circumstances of every case.'' Wendy Ginsberg

On Sept. 5, 1882, thousands of workers in New York risked being fired for taking an unauthorized day off to participate in festivities honoring honest toil and the rights of labor. This first commemoration of Labor Day testified to labor's rising power and unity in the Gilded Age and its sense that both were necessary to withstand the growing power of capital.

title: Knocking on the Playoff Door
description: No team has repeated as Super Bowl champion since Denver in the 1997 and '98 seasons. And when a team gets to the Super Bowl and loses, it often disappears. From the 1997 season through the 2001 season, no team that lost the Super Bowl won a playoff game the next season. Three A.F.C. teams (Tennessee, Indianapolis and Cleveland) and two N.F.C. teams (the Giants and Atlanta) that made the playoffs last season did not make the playoffs the season before. Teams seem to come from nowhere to gain entry to the postseason. Actually, they do come from somewhere: they were usually building without much fanfare and on the cusp of becoming playoff-caliber teams the previous season. The next season, everything clicks. Which teams fit that bill for 2003?

title: I Don't Want to Grow Up!

title: How to Talk About Israel
description: The Jewish Problem pops up in the strangest places. In the winter of 1991, at the height of the first gulf war, I asked a right-wing Japanese politician who still wields considerable power in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party to explain the Japanese role in the Middle Eastern conflict. After clearing his throat with some perfunctory remarks about oil supplies and United States-Japan relations, he suddenly stopped midsentence, gave me a shrewd look and said: ''Look, we Japanese aren't stupid. We saw Henry Kissinger on TV. We know how America operates. We're perfectly well aware that this war is not about Kuwait. It's about Jewish interests. It's all about Israel.''

title: In the Footsteps of the Romans
description: IN June my husband, three children and I headed from our home in Glasgow to ''the South'' -- that is, England -- for the weekend. The lure was Hadrian's Wall: nearly 73 miles long, coast to coast, sometimes visible, sometimes long gone, built by the Roman emperor Hadrian in about A.D. 122 to 128 to keep the northern barbarous tribes out of Roman Britain or, at the very least, to tax them for the right to enter it. Today, the adventurous can walk the entire length of the wall on Hadrian's Wall Path National Trail -- made up of paved road, gravel pathways, grassy and turf rights of way and new metal bridges. The path opened in May to much fanfare, and to the tune of about $9.5 million.

description: A recent pick for Granta magazine's list of the top 20 young British novelists, Dan Rhodes has made a leap from his clever short fiction to TIMOLEON VIETA COME HOME: A Sentimental Journey (Canongate, $23), a whimsical, menacing exploration of thwarted love. The Timoleon Vieta of the title is a stray mutt with an affectionate disposition and eyes ''as pretty as a little girl's.'' His latest master is Cockcroft, a washed-up gay composer whose lonely exile in Umbria is interrupted by the arrival of a young man known only as the Bosnian. This dour and rather sadistic fellow proves less adept at conversation than at the once-weekly sexual act with which he pays his rent. The Bosnian's hatred of dogs and Cockcroft's regrettable decision to choose man over man's best friend results in Timoleon's banishment, and it is the dog's arduous journey home, or rather the stories of those he encounters along the way, that constitute the second half of the novel. This cast includes a broken-hearted Welsh woman, a deaf Italian girl, a Chinese orphan and a tragic Cambodian family. Although these narratives seem pointlessly digressive at first, they accrue into a powerful pattern of love and loss among the damaged and doomed. The worldview here would not be unfamiliar to admirers of James Purdy, and Vien Thuc's witty dog illustrations, incorporated into the book, lend emotional shading to the tale. Rhodes's unadorned prose style is either translucent or plain, depending on your taste, but his presentation of the thorny dream of life is sad, funny and often riveting. Sam Lipsyte

title: 'The Known World'
description: The evening his master died he worked again well after he ended the day for the other adults, his own wife among them, and sent them back with hunger and tiredness to their cabins. The young ones, his son among them, had been sent out of the fields an hour or so before the adults, to prepare the late supper and, if there was time enough, to play in the few minutes of sun that were left. When he, Moses, finally freed himself of the ancient and brittle harness that connected him to the oldest mule his master owned, all that was left of the sun was a five-inch-long memory of red orange laid out in still waves across the horizon between two mountains on the left and one on the right. He had been in the fields for all of fourteen hours. He paused before leaving the fields as the evening quiet wrapped itself about him. The mule quivered, wanting home and rest. Moses closed his eyes and bent down and took a pinch of the soil and ate it with no more thought than if it were a spot of cornbread. He worked the dirt around in his mouth and swallowed, leaning his head back and opening his eyes in time to see the strip of sun fade to dark blue and then to nothing. He was the only man in the realm, slave or free, who ate dirt, but while the bondage women, particularly the pregnant ones, ate it for some incomprehensible need, for that something that ash cakes and apples and fatback did not give their bodies, he ate it not only to discover the strengths and weaknesses of the field, but because the eating of it tied him to the only thing in his small world that meant almost as much as his own life.

title: Help Wanted

People need to work in order to be able to make a contribution, and I would suggest that it is a feeling of uselessness, as much as the lack of money, that is so soul-destroying for the unemployed. Any job, no matter how menial it may appear, allows a person to have some dignity, and it is not in the nature of the vast majority of civilization to be idle. There are also many jobs that give a good degree of job satisfaction. As an Englishman who lives and works in the United States, I can state that the majority of Americans, and particularly those involved in manual jobs and in the service industries, work extremely hard, and take great pride in giving their best.

That picture (now in a new, and newly subtitled, print) is among the very few French movies about the criminal class in which neither the characters nor the filmmakers are afflicted by the delusion that they are Americans.
